title: Who's to Blame for an Isolated White House?; Moral Relativity
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. McCall's Embarrassment
description: State Comptroller Carl McCall calls it an ''appearance problem.'' Actually, it is only the latest embarrassment suffered by a politician operating under New York's lax campaign finance rules, which impose virtually no limits on contributions and provide no public financing. Like Gov. George Pataki a few months ago, Mr. McCall is trying to explain away the fact that a state contract went to someone who later became a political benefactor.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: THE RUSH TO KEEP UP
description: Thousands of parents, fearful that their children might fall behind, are plunging into the world of ''supplemental education,'' a booming new industry of learning centers, private tutors, how-to books and software designed to test a child's skills. A special section, Education Life.

title: Buying a Campaign For Very Little Down
description: A generally accepted rule in California politics is that the state is so big and its television markets are so expensive that it takes a minimum of $10 million to make a good run for the United States Senate. And that doesn't include the $5 million or so, maybe even $10 million, that can be spent winning a primary to get on the fall ballot.

title: A Remedy for the Rootlessness Of Modern Suburban Life?
description: Attacks on suburbia are as old as cul-de-sacs. Suburbs have always been derided as bourgeois, consumerist and conformist. But now they have become the enemy of family values, too. That's right. Karl Zinsmeister, the editor of the conservative magazine The American Enterprise, has written that ''suburbia is actually a fairly radical social experiment,'' one that can be linked to ''the disappearance of family time, the weakening of generational links . . . the anonymity of community life, the rise of radical feminism, the decline of civic action, the tyrannical dominance of TV and pop culture over leisure time.''

title: Staten Island Officer Dies, Four Days After Shooting
description: Four days after he was shot through the windshield of his patrol car at a Staten Island housing project, Police Officer Gerard Carter died early yesterday without recovering consciousness, the fatal bullet still lodged in his brain.

title: Gay Issues a Problem For Illinois Democrat
description: Almost from the moment he won the Democratic nomination in this year's race for governor in Illinois, Representative Glenn Poshard, a downstate moderate, has been under pressure to move to the left on issues like gun control, abortion and gay rights. If he does not, party leaders say, he may not run well in the more liberal Chicago area to the north, which is where Illinois Democrats seeking statewide office tend to win or lose elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANKOFF, EDITH R.
description: JANKOFF-Edith R. Loving wife of the late Bernard R. Jankoff. Beloved mother of Susan & Stephen Beatus, John and Ronnie Jankoff, & Judy Jankoff and Mel Herman. Devoted sister of Honey R. Beldoch. Adored grandmother of Stacey, Jennifer and Stuart. Passed away on July 30th at her home. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York City, Sunday, August 2nd, at 11 A.M.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Brazil's Economic Half-Steps; President Eases Market Rigors
description: Last fall, as the wave of financial crises surging through Asia threatened to engulf emerging markets around the world, the Brazilian President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, appeared to be taking swift, decisive action to distance his country from the trouble.

title: Who's to Blame for an Isolated White House?; Nation of Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REBELL, HARRY
description: REBELL-Harry. We mourn the loss of our dear friend. He lived life to the fullest and served as a mentor to all who had the privilege of knowing him. To his family we extend our heartfelt sympathy. We will always remember and miss his adventurous spirit for living. Gloria and Paul Asnes

title: Judge Rejects Two Separate Drug Mergers
description: A Federal judge has blocked two mergers involving four of the nation's biggest drug wholesalers.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Patterns column on the Fashion page on Tuesday, about a possible new schedule for the New York women's shows in Bryant Park, misidentified a firm that has been involved in conversations about the change and referred incorrectly to its role. The firm is A. Form Architecture, not FTL Architects. A. Form designs the layouts for the tents at the shows. Neither firm provides the tents.

title: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT A SLOWER PACE IN THE 2D QUARTER
description: A powerful array of forces at home and abroad slowed the economy to a modest but still healthy pace during the second quarter, the Government said today.

title: BANKNORTH AND EVERGREEN SET $291.2 MILLION MERGER
description: Banknorth Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Evergreen Bancorp Inc., a bank holding company based in Glen Falls, N.Y., for $291.2 million in stock. Banknorth will issue about 7.9 million shares in the acquisition and exchange nine-tenths of a share for each Evergreen share outstanding. Shares of Evergreen rose $2.50, or 9 percent, to $30.25, on the Nasdaq stock market. Shares of Banknorth dropped $3.3125, or 9 percent, to $34.9375, also on the Nasdaq. Banknorth, based in Burlington, Vt., has assets of $3 billion and seven banks in Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Vermont. With the Evergreen deal and the $52 million acquisition of BankBoston Corporation operations announced in July, Banknorth will have assets of $4.3 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ERICKSON, DON
description: ERICKSON-Don. Ten years and you are thought of with love every day. Pooka

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUMARESQ, ELEANOR
description: DUMARESQ-Eleanor. We note with sorrow the passing of a loyal friend who, along with her husband, John, were among North Shore's early supporters and tireless workers. As a long-term volunteer, as an Auxiliary President, and the wife of a Board President ''Ellie'' was considered by all a loving member of the Hospital family. She will be missed by her many friends at North Shore. We extend our most sincere condolences to her family. Saul B. Katz, Chairman, Board of Trustees John S. T. Gallagher, Chief Executive Officer North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASILEVSKY, HELEN
description: BASILEVSKY-Helen, 59. Of New York City and Rensselaerville, NY. Beloved daughter of Nathalie and sister of Peter, died July 31, 1998 after a long illness. An artist and teacher, she was the head of the Art Department at Nightingale Bamford School, highly respected and well loved by friends, colleagues and several generations of students. Her work has been shown in galleries and museums but her proudest accomplishment was the many students who gained an appreciation for beauty, art and culture through her efforts as a teacher. A gentle, gracious person who was always more interested in others than herself, she will be sorely missed by all those whose lives she touched. Funeral services will be held on Sunday night August 2, 1998 at 6 P.M., at Christ the Savior Russian Orthodox Church, 340 East 71 Street, New York, New York, 10021. Burial services Monday, 9:45AM at Christ the Savior Church with interment at The Russian Orthodox Convent of ''Novo Diveevo'', 100 Smith Road, Nanuet, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to City Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Ave., NY NY 10017 and Christ the Savior Church.

title: Congress Cancels a Vote to Increase Visas
description: One week after announcing a compromise to increase the number of visas available for high-technology workers, Congressional leaders canceled planned votes today on the legislation under the threat of a veto.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNSTEIN, NOAH
description: BROWNSTEIN-Noah. Exactly six years ago today at 4:30PM while I was holding and kissing your hand the very worst news came to my ears. You had been snatched from us and it was the worst day of my life. I kept kissing your hand and talking to you but you never answered me. Time is no healer, the whole in my heart is getting bigger & the ache harder. It's terribly lonely and if only we could hear your sweet voice with one of your bright sayings, the ache would become a smile. Rest in peace our dearest treasure. Forever with love, Mom and Dad

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on July 19 about the revival of the Chip Hilton series of sports books by the late Clair Bee misstated the school where Bee worked as the athletic director. It was the New York Military Academy, a prep school in Cornwall-on-the-Hudson, not the United States Military Academy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMON, WILLIAM
description: SIMON-William. August 1, 1992. Bill, forever loved, remembered and cherished. Always in our hearts and minds. Love, Mom and Elli

title: The Grand Central B.I.D. War
description: New Yorkers who understand the key role that business improvement districts have played in the city's revitalization may have been unnerved by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's decision to dissolve the Grand Central Partnership, one of the largest and best-known B.I.D.'s. The Mayor's action seems drastic, but his position is not, on the whole, unreasonable.

title: Jersey Girl Heads The Field in Test
description: Jersey Girl missed a chance to make history when she skipped the final leg of the Triple Tiara, but her trainer, Todd Pletcher, is hoping she will go on to make history on her own.

title: Calipari Says He's A Net All the Way
description: With the lockout of the National Basketball Association's players keeping him from tutoring his players, John Calipari spent nearly an hour yesterday conducting a clinic for children at River Dell High School in Oradell, N.J. When he was finished, Calipari insisted that despite holding an escape clause in his contract after the upcoming season, he would not use it.

title: Wide Open Spaces Lure The Best and the Worst
description: Montanans are learning that their ''last best place'' label cuts two ways. It attracts land investors as prominent as Ted Turner and Charles Schwab. But it also attracts runaway loners as troubled as the Unabomber and Russell E. Weston Jr., the man charged with killing two Capitol Police officers.

title: Rex Lardner, 80, Author of Humorous Books and Articles
description: Rex Lardner, a humorist who spent the better part of his life doing what he did best and enjoyed most, writing, playing tennis and making people laugh, died on Monday at the top of his game, playing mixed doubles with his usual tenacious skill at a court near his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 80 and the author of more than a dozen books and hundreds of magazine articles.

title: Corporate Earnings, Hurt by Asia Crisis, Depress Shares
description: Share prices dropped sharply yesterday, more than erasing big gains from the prior day, in a sign that investors remain troubled by unimpressive corporate earnings.

title: Johnson Is Shipped To Astros
description: The Yankees did not get Randy Johnson last night, but they didn't have to get the dominating pitcher to keep him from the Cleveland Indians. That is because the Seattle Mariners traded Johnson to the Houston Astros.

title: Europe Says Yes to Arms Industry Mergers
description: Military industry mergers may be history in the United States, but in Europe they are very much alive.

title: Who's to Blame for an Isolated White House?; McCarthyism, Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, an article on Tuesday about Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's criticism of China for the arrest of several dissidents misspelled the Chinese President's name. He is Jiang Zemin, not Jian Xemin.

title: Gore Outlines Privacy Measures, but Their Impact Is Small
description: The Clinton Administration announced a new privacy initiative today intended to protect children and medical patients, among others. But while the proposals were ambitious, the Administration can enforce few of them without the consent of Congress or private industry.

title: Eating Up the Summer; With Tables Full, Restaurants Skip Traditional Break
description: Just a few years ago -- or once upon a time, as the trend flies -- the high-end restaurants of Manhattan wouldn't have considered staying open all summer long.

title: The Roundabout Is Struggling But Is Used to It
description: Sometimes a dose of neurotic energy and a manic-depressive business history can have their blessings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUSS, REGINA
description: GRUSS-Regina. Passed away peacefully on Thursday, July 30, at the age of 100. Beloved wife of the late Oscar Gruss, founder of Oscar Gruss & Son Incorporated, member firm of the New York Stock Exchange. Beloved and devoted mother of Emanuel Gruss, Elizabeth Goldberg and the late Olga Gruss Lewin, aunt of Alicia Schwieger, mother-in-law of Riane Gruss, grandmother of Tamar and Steve Olitsky, Daniel and April Goldberg, Andrew and Marina Lewin, Clement and Susan Lewin, Leslie Gruss and Michael Rosen, and Brenda Gruss and Daniel Hirsch, and great aunt of Ian and Anne-Francoise Schwieger, and Jeremy and Cindy Schwieger. She is also survived by 11 great-grandchildren, two great-grandnephews and two great-grandnieces Oren, Jonathan, Leni, Joshua, Nathaniel, Sylvana, Sarah, Jacob, Shaina, Ripton, Morgan, Jonathan, Irene, Aidan and Lara. Mrs. Gruss was the recipient of The Jewish Museum's Mayer Sulzberger Award in recognition of her interest in support of art and Jewish culture. Services will be held Sunday, August 2, at 1:45 P.M., at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family requests that no flowers be sent and that any contributions be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AROND, IRMA KRASNA
description: AROND-Irma Krasna. Our tower of strength, our role model for everything, a wife, mother, grandmother, sister, friend and teacher who was the essence of dignity, integrity, grace, beauty, and love of life. Beloved wife of Lionel, loving mother of Carol and Harold Finkel & Miriam & Sandy Pauker, proud grandmother of Rebecca and Leigh Finkel and Sarah and Elizabeth Pauker, and devoted sister to Estelle Roth. Funeral services: Sunday, August 2nd at 11:30AM, at Kirschenbaum, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Brickyard 400 Is Fast Closing the Gap
description: A day before May's Indianapolis 500, a ticket scalper stood alone on a street corner near an entrance to the speedway. He was holding up a sign with the words, ''Buy one, get one free.''

title: Selma Holzman Is Remembered
description: Perhaps they don't make basketball coaches quite like Red Holzman anymore, but they surely don't make coaches' wives like Selma Holzman, either.

title: Who's to Blame for an Isolated White House?; Congress's Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, WILLIAM MCCHESNEY
description: MARTIN-William McChesney, Jr. The Board of Directors of The New York Stock Exchange mourns the death of our former President, esteemed colleague and friend, William McChesney Martin, Jr. He served as the first full-time paid President of the Exchange from June 30, 1938 until April 16, 1941. He returned to conduct a study of the Exchange in 1971 where his insight and initiative led to changes in the governance of the Exchange. His dedication and commitment to the Exchange and the securities industry will endure. Richard A. Grasso, Chairman and C E O, New York Stock Exchange, Inc.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Resume Slide On Worries About Profits

title: GROUP BUYS REMAINING 49% OF DUCATI MOTOR
description: Investors including Texas Pacific Group and an Italian unit of Deutsche Bank A.G. bought the 49 percent they did not own in Ducati Motor S.p.A., Italy's third-largest motorcycle maker, for an undisclosed sum. Texas Pacific, an investment firm led by the financier David Bonderman and based in Fort Worth, and Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Development Capital Italy, a $135 million buyout fund based in Luxembourg, and their co-investors bought the remaining stake from Claudio and Gianfranco Castiglioni. The group bought 51 percent of Ducati in September 1996 for 500 billion lire ($285 million) from Cagiva S.p.A., Italy's biggest motorbike maker. Ducati Motor, which is based in Bologna, Italy, will continue to operate under its current management, Texas Pacific said.

title: Paula Jones's Lawyers Ask That Her Suit Be Reinstated
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones asked a Federal appeals court today to reinstate her sexual misconduct suit against President Clinton, arguing, among other things, that a lower court should never have excluded evidence about any relationship he had had with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Regulators Move to Shut Down Trading Group After Arrests
description: Securities regulators in four states, aided by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, have moved to shut down an options trading house that they accused of defrauding investors of millions of dollars this year through the sale of options on foreign currency.

title: Judith Albert, 59, Toy Designer Whose Doll Led to Buyer Frenzy
description: Judith F. Albert, a toy designer whose credits include the redesign of the Cabbage Patch doll for the mass market as well as other commercially successful dolls, died July 20 from breast cancer at her home in Mill Neck, N.Y. She was 59 years old.

title: With Johnson There for the Taking, Yanks Balked
description: The Yankees could have had Randy Johnson tonight. Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman could have called the Seattle Mariners and agreed to their demands, and Johnson, one of this generation's best pitchers, would have joined George Steinbrenner's juggernaut.

title: Military Spending Approved With Curbs on Rights Abuses
description: The Senate has approved a $252 billion military spending bill that includes an amendment barring the Pentagon from conducting training missions with foreign soldiers who have committed human rights abuses.

title: Serbs Say Kosovo Drive Is Over, But Little Changes on the Ground
description: Out of sight of the diplomats, foreign monitors and aid workers, there were thousands of new refugees in the Serbian province of Kosovo today, fleeing attacks just a day after the Government decreed that its military offensive was over.

title: Japan's New Chief Vows to Act on Economy
description: On his first day as Japan's Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi once again tried to reassure the world that he would move swiftly to address Japan's economic problems, hiring a new adviser whose stature as a financial heavyweight rivals those of many in the West.

title: Who's to Blame for an Isolated White House?; Chief Executive's Case
description: To the Editor:

title: In Martha 101, Even Class Anxieties Get Ironed Out
description: Is Martha Stewart a colonialist tool? An American populist? Or is she merely a flyspeck on the damask tablecloth of history?

title: Charles C. Tillinghast Jr., 87, Former Chairman of T.W.A.
description: Charles C. Tillinghast Jr., a lawyer, businessman and investment banker, who was chairman of Trans World Airlines and a former chancellor of Brown University, died July 25 at his summer home in Little Compton, R.I. He was 87.

title: HOLLAND CHEMICAL ACQUIRES TAB CHEMICALS
description: Holland Chemical International N.V. of Amsterdam, the No. 1 distributor of chemicals used in oil and gas extraction in the United States and Canada, said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held Tab Chemicals Inc. of Chicago for an undisclosed price to strengthen its United States distribution activities. Tab has annual sales of $70 million and employs about 60 people. John Regout, vice president of Holland Chemical, estimated the value of the combined chemical distribution market in the United States and Canada at $15 billion to $20 billion. Holland Chemical had 1997 sales of $937.6 million and net income of $25.1 million.

title: Black Parents Say Learning Supersedes Integration
description: African-American parents are more interested in having public schools raise their academic standards than put their energies into promoting integration, according to a new survey by Public Agenda, a nonprofit research organization, and Public Education Network, a national umbrella group of organizations whose goal is to improve public education.

title: Daring to Dream of Eradicating Poverty
description: What's the definition of an honor you can't refuse?

title: Early 80's Return, With English Artifice
description: Pop nostalgia has a 15-to-20-year timetable: a 1950's revival in the 1970's, a wave of neo-psychedelia in the 1980's, tributes to old-school hip-hop in the 1990's. Right on schedule, hit-makers from the 1980's are swallowing some pride to share summer package tours and play the songs on their greatest-hits albums.

title: Who's to Blame for an Isolated White House?; Starr's Motives
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvie Branscomb, a Shaper Of Vanderbilt U., Dies at 103
description: Harvie Branscomb, the chancellor of Vanderbilt University from 1946 to 1963, who put the institution on the path to national prominence, died on July 23 at his home in Nashville. He was 103.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BANK OF NEW YORK CO. appointed James Mason as a managing director to head a new mergers advisory unit for media and telecommunications companies.

title: Mental State of Suspect Is Debated in Slaying Case
description: Michael B. Laudor, the schizophrenic man accused in the stabbing death of his pregnant fiancee, Caroline Costello, continues to show signs of unrelenting mental illness, including confusion about whether Ms. Costello is actually dead.

title: Teen-Agers Soar, but Eldredge Wins
description: In what may have been the most technically brilliant night of figure skating ever for men in this country, a pair of teen-agers displayed their jumping mastery only to be trumped at the Goodwill Games by the completeness and maturity of Todd Eldredge.

title: Watch the Birdies: Hurst's 65 Is Nearly Picture Perfect
description: With Se Ri Pak grabbing so many headlines in women's golf, Pat Hurst has been overlooked.

title: Journal; Shall We Dance?
description: At Leonard Bernstein's memorial service in 1990, the playwright Arthur Laurents brought down the house when he said, ''There were only two things Lenny was afraid of -- God and Jerry Robbins.''

title: Man Dies After Police Officer Sprays Him With Pepper Mace
description: A 29-year-old Long Island man died shortly after he was sprayed by pepper Mace while being arrested by two Suffolk County police officers on charges of driving without a license, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Satu Sinnolai, Buddhist Abbot And Pastor, 79
description: Satu Khamphouy Sinnolai, one of the first Buddhist monks from Laos to take refuge in the United States and the first to arrive as a pastor to immigrants in the New York metropolitan region, died on May 28 at Bridgeport Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 79 and lived in that city.

title: Sewage Leak Prompts Closing of Bronx Beach
description: Just days after the city temporarily closed beaches in the Rockaways, officials shut down Orchard Beach in the Bronx yesterday because of a sewage leak in Westchester County.

title: International Briefs; More Europe Scrutiny Of Paper Maker Merger
description: The European Commission said yesterday that after a one-month review it had decided on up to four more months of scrutiny for the $4.8 billion plan by Enso Oyj of Finland and Stora A.B. of Sweden to merge and create the world's biggest paper maker. There are concerns that the deal could threaten fair competition in Europe's paper industry. Stora and Enso together have annual sales of more than 60 billion markkaa, or $11.1 billion.

title: 4 Officials Suspended After Russia Protests
description: The International Amateur Boxing Association suspended two referee/judges, as well as one judge and one referee from the boxing finals at the Goodwill Games at the Theater at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. The suspensions followed a formal protest by the Russian Boxing Federation and its delegation and an evaluation of the officiating.

title: Thomson Multimedia Finds Friends With Deep Pockets
description: For years, Thomson Multimedia was known mostly for two things: color television sets and losses.

title: Think Tank; 'Lolita' Turns 40, Still Arguing for A Right to Exist
description: Vladimir Nabokov promised that ''Lolita,'' his thin novel about a pedophile named Humbert Humbert and a 12-year-old nymphet named Delores Haze, had ''no moral in tow.'' He was interested only in what he called the ''esthetic bliss'' of the writing.

title: Senator's Draft Bill Defines Options in Puerto Rico Plebiscite
description: As Puerto Rico prepares for a plebiscite in December, a Senate committee chairman today released a scaled-back draft bill that defines the three options: commonwealth, statehood or independence.

title: Biggest German Bank Admits and Regrets Dealing in Nazi Gold
description: Germany's biggest bank, Deutsche Bank AG, acknowledged yesterday that it had dealt in Nazi gold during World War II and said it ''regrets most deeply injustices that occurred.'' But it declined to say whether its wartime officials knew that some of the gold might have come from concentration camp victims.

title: Event Founded to Fight Bias Is Accused of It
description: The Gay Games, founded 16 years ago as a way to bring together through sports competition people who were being excluded from mainstream life, have found themselves on the eve of the fifth ''Gay Olympiad'' in Amsterdam being accused of the very thing they were created to fight: sexual discrimination.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about the golfer Si Re Pak misidentified the president of her native country, South Korea. He is Kim Dae Jung, not Kim Young Sam, who is the former president.

title: I.B.M. Guilty Of Illegal Sales To Russian Lab
description: An I.B.M. subsidiary pleaded guilty today to illegally exporting 17 advanced computers to a Russian nuclear weapons laboratory and agreed to pay an $8.5 million fine in what Federal investigators believed was the first criminal conviction against I.B.M.

title: Who's to Blame for an Isolated White House?; Mixing Cause and Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: Who's to Blame for an Isolated White House?; Weakening the Office
description: To the Editor:

title: United in Birth, 12 Twins in 30 Hours
description: The bulletin out of Beth Israel Medical Center yesterday morning was intriguingly incomplete. ''At least'' five sets of twins, the notice read, had been born there in the last 24 hours. The wording raised two possibilities: either doctors there had no idea exactly what was going on, or a statistically improbable occurrence was becoming even more so.

title: Who's to Blame for an Isolated White House?; Not Above the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Vows 'Complete and Truthful' Testimony
description: President Clinton declared today that he would testify ''completely and truthfully'' in the Monica S. Lewinsky investigation on Aug. 17 but said that until then he would have no public comment on the matter.

title: India and Pakistan Fail To Narrow Differences
description: An effort to open regular talks between India and Pakistan on divisive issues including nuclear weapons and Kashmir collapsed in acrimony today, with the two countries accusing each other of setting conditions that made a sustained dialogue impossible.

title: Ex-Investment Banker Charged
description: Michael Lissack, a former Smith Barney Inc. investment banker, has been charged with using the Internet to harass executives at his old firm by posting messages that solicited phone calls to the company's headquarters and, in some instances, to the homes of executives.

title: Utility Chief Resigns Post Over Lilco Pay
description: After weeks of withering criticism over a $42 million compensation package, William J. Catacosinos resigned under pressure yesterday as head of the two-month-old Marketspan energy company, and board members chose his rival, Robert B. Catell, to take his place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, JEROME
description: ROBBINS-Jerome. The School of American Ballet notes with sorrow the death of its distinguished alumnus & great friend, Jerry Robbins. He was an artist of the first rank, one who could spin choreographic gold when working with legendary ballerinas, Broadway veterans or SAB students. Chairman Albert Bellas, Chairman of Faculty Peter Martins, President Larry Alan Smith and Executive Director Nathalie Gleboff, with the Board, faculty, staff and students join the legions of devastated admirers around the world.

title: For a Second Day in a Row, A Slain Policeman Is Buried
description: Officer Jacob Joseph Chestnut of the Capitol Police was buried in Arlington National Cemetery today under skies streaked with gray after a funeral in which hundreds of police officers wept and laughed alongside dozens of members of Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONANNO, PETER J.
description: BONANNO-Peter J., M.D. Of Tenafly on July 31, 1998. Beloved husband of Bernadette (nee Bautz). Devoted father of Bernadette Kingham, Patricia Costello, Jay, Peter and Edward. Loving grandfather of Kelly, T. Peter, Justin, Jeffrey, Christina, Kristen, Peter, Timothy, Peter and Hanna. Dear brother of the late Joseph, Salvatore, Thomas, James, Dominick, John and Mary. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly on Sunday 35 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Monday 10AM, Mt Carmel Church Tenafly, Interment Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Tenafly. Memorials to Holy Name Hospital Oncology Center, Teaneck, N.J. would be appreciated.

title: New York Lottery Has New Ad Agency
description: The New York State Lottery said yesterday that it would switch advertising agencies on its high-profile account after a decade with the agency that created the familiar and popular campaigns carrying the theme ''Hey, you never know.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ANHEUSER-BUSCH COS., St. Louis, said its brewery workers had opted to continue contract talks with management rather than embark on a strike after rejecting a contract offer in a vote that was counted on Thursday.

title: Plan Is Approved to End Car Insurance Surcharges
description: The State Department of Banking and Insurance approved plans yesterday to replace car insurance surcharges with a system that would assess premiums based on driving history.

title: Ship That Rescued Jews Is Offered a New Home
description: The Mayor of Glen Cove has offered a home port to the Regina Maris, a 90-year-old sailing vessel that smuggled Jewish refugees out of Nazi Germany during World War II but is now decaying at the East End of Long Island.

title: M.T.A. Leases Building In Lower Manhattan
description: In what is being billed as one of the largest lease transactions in New York City history and one of the largest in the nation this year, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has agreed to lease the entire 1.6 million-square-foot building at 2 Broadway in lower Manhattan.

title: Study Says Trading Pollution Permits Would Be Economical
description: Paying other countries to cut their pollution could be the cheapest way for the United States to help control the heat-trapping gases that cause global warming, the Clinton Administration said in a new economic analysis released today.

title: Clinton Goes to Hamptons To Golf and Raise Money
description: Having tried in the White House Rose Garden to blunt questions about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, President Clinton flew to East Hampton this afternoon to relax on the golf course and raise money on the rubber-lobster circuit.

title: International Briefs; Sanwa Bank in Japan Barred From Fund Sales
description: Japan's fourth-largest bank, Sanwa Bank, was barred yesterday from selling mutual funds for a year by the Financial Supervisory Agency, which said Sanwa had bribed officials of the Ministry of Finance and Bank of Japan in exchange for information about interest rates and bank inspections.

title: Who's to Blame for an Isolated White House?; No Confidant
description: To the Editor:

title: American and Iranian Try To Bridge Decades of Hurt
description: A former hostage from the American Embassy in Teheran came together here today with one of the former Iranian students who directed the seizure of the embassy for 444 days from 1979 to 1981, for what the organizers hoped would be a dialogue of reconciliation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSNER, DAVID
description: MOSNER-David. Of Nanuet, NY died on July 31, 1998 at the age of 72. Beloved and loving husband of Shirley (nee Passick). Cherished & loving father of Miriam and her husband Dr. Lawrence Suchoff, Michael and his wife Michelle, Daniel and his wife Lynn, Judith and her husband Fred Saltzman, Philip and his wife Barbara. Adored and loving grandfather of Rachel, Eve, Noah & Joshua Suchoff, Benjamin, Jessica, Seth & Rebecca Mosner, Blair and Hilary Mosner, Liza, Richard & Max Saltzman, Andrew and Thomas Mosner. Services are on Sunday, August 2, 12 noon at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Route 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey. The family will sit shiva at the Mosner residence in Nanuet, NY. Donations may be sent to the David Mosner Memorial Fund at the Reuben Gittelman Hebrew Day School, New City, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDIN, BENJAMIN
description: LUDIN-Benjamin, age 90. Died in Freehold, New Jersey, July 29, 1998. title: Keeping the Census Fair
description: In 1990, for the first time in decades, the Bureau of the Census produced a count that was less accurate than the one that preceded it. Under Congressional direction, the agency consulted the National Academy of Sciences and came up with a new, more statistically sophisticated procedure. But Republican leaders have declared war on the plan. In effect, they are fighting for a census in which some Americans count for more than others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, HAROLD
description: MELTZER-Harold, 89. Of Naples, Florida formerly of Jersey City, New Jersey, and Englewood, New Jersey died on July 25th in Naples, Florida. Beloved and devoted husband to Evelyn, father to Eleanor Daniels and grandfather to Steven Daniels. He was a distinguished member of the New Jersey Bar since 1930 and an active real estate lawyer and developer. He was Of Counsel to Starr, Gern, Davison & Rubin or its predecessor firms since 1981. A nationally ranked senior tennis player until well into his 80's Harold served as a member of the U.S. Senior Davis Cup team. As a philanthropist and activist in Jewish causes, Harold was past President of Temple Emanuel of Englewood, long time Chairman of the Englewood United Jewish Appeal and was a life trustee of the Jewish Home and Rehabilitation Center of Jersey City. Services were held at the Hodges Funeral Chapel, Naples, Florida. Contributions should be made to the Jewish Home and Rehabilitation Center, Rivervale, New Jersey.

title: About New York; Nannies Whose Hearts Ache for Home
description: THE day her youngest daughter turned 10, Dora Marta could not help her blow out the candles on her frosty birthday cake because she was hundreds of miles away. Her daughter and her other two children were back home, in a speck of a town tucked away in the northern mountains of Honduras.

title: Mental Patient Accused Of Strangling Roommate
description: A patient at a state psychiatric hospital for the criminally insane was charged yesterday with strangling his roommate to death with a pair of socks, the authorities said.

title: Sports of The Times; A Game? Business Side Is Evident
description: ON this bright afternoon, three groups of young ballplayers assembled in the outfield of Shea Stadium to hear baseball talk from major league players. This was the teaching portion of the the Junior Mets-Emigrant Bank baseball program.

title: Goodwill Games Fail to Draw Crowd
description: At the delicatessen across the street from the Nassau Coliseum, the Goodwill Games have been deemed a dud.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''No one wants to get this matter behind us more than I do, except maybe all the rest of the American people.''

title: BILL TO OVERHAUL CAMPAIGN FINANCE SURVIVES IN HOUSE
description: A steady majority of the House voted repeatedly today to shield a bipartisan campaign finance bill from a final onslaught of amendments, making it all but certain that the measure will win final House passage next week.

title: Union Pacific Track-Sharing Order Is Lifted
description: Saying that rail congestion in the Houston area had eased considerably, the Surface Transportation Board announced yesterday that it would not extend its six-month-old emergency service order on the Union Pacific Corporation, the nation's largest railroad.

title: Political Memo; Main Task for D'Amato's Rivals: To Set Themselves Apart
description: Mark Green turned up at a television interview about his Senate candidacy the other day armed with a copy of a year-old bill sponsored by a rival, Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, that proposed that the Federal budget surplus be spent on social programs and tax cuts. The bill, Mr. Green asserted, was proof that Mr. Schumer was not committed to using the surplus to shore up the Social Security system -- Mr. Schumer's repeated public statements to the contrary notwithstanding.

title: F.B.I. Looks for Evidence Of Racial Bias by Police
description: The F.B.I. is investigating accusations that the Trumbull Police Department, whose 68 officers are white, routinely singled out black and Hispanic drivers for traffic charges.

title: Over at the Local Bar, Bad Men, Feisty Women
description: In ''Linc's,'' a new Showtime comedy series, all the men are bad and all the women are good. Linc himself (Steven Williams), a 50-ish Washington bar owner, is a narrow-minded Republican who, upon learning that his daughter has had a lesbian relationship, asks a priest, ''How well do these exorcisms work?'' Johnnie (Georg Stanford Brown) is an evil lobbyist who wants only the best for the tobacco industry. Harlan (Joe Inscoe) is a Southern white racist who keeps telling his young black waitress about ''our old cook Bessie.'' And Winston (Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje) is a cab driver with an inflated notion of his appeal to women. In the first episode, one black man tells another to go back to Africa.

title: Builder Pleads Guilty To Bribing I.R.S. Agent
description: A man who owns several construction companies around the state pleaded guilty yesterday to bribing an Internal Revenue Service agent over the course of a decade in exchange for the agent's help in manipulating tax audits in his favor, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Baby Switch In Virginia Is Investigated
description: The authorities in Virginia are investigating whether two girls born three years ago at a Charlottesville hospital were deliberately switched and sent home with the wrong parents.

title: Jailing of Ex-Mayor Shows a Tougher China
description: The 16-year sentence given today to Chen Xitong, the powerful former Mayor and Communist Party boss of Beijing, is intended to show that China's leaders are serious about cracking down on the corruption that is eating away at the core of their authority.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: Louisiana Tinkers With Calendar Again
description: Back in the 1996 Presidential campaign, Louisiana Republicans moved the date of their caucuses to the front end of the election year in a brassy effort to steal some of the attention and influence usually accorded the first-in-the-nation Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary. But when jealous Republican leaders in Iowa and New Hampshire hinted that the party faithful in their states might punish candidates who participated in the Louisiana caucuses, most of the big names heeded the warning and avoided them.

title: ABC TV Gets a New President With Wider Duties
description: ABC has named Patricia Fili-Krushel, the president of the network's daytime division, to the position of president of the ABC Television Network, and increased the duties of that position to include oversight of ABC's news and entertainment divisions.

title: Jets Take Hard Hit: Jones Is Out for Season With a Knee Injury
description: The Jets suffered the most significant injury in the Bill Parcells regime today. Middle linebacker Marvin Jones, their leading tackler, tore up his left knee in an accident at practice and is out for the season.

title: Who's to Blame for an Isolated White House?; Where the Fault Lies
description: To the Editor:

title: Dispirited Republicans Struggle for Foothold in West Virginia
description: Sally Kay is running for Congress this year. But hardly anyone in her home state of West Virginia knows it.

title: Joined in a Corporate Marriage, but Divided by Style and Vision
description: Long before Robert B. Catell and Dr. William J. Catacosinos parted company yesterday, the two strong-willed utility company executives had established themselves as men of such different vision and personality that their partnership at the helm of the Marketspan Corporation seemed destined for trouble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEHEAD, O.Z.
description: WHITEHEAD-O.Z. (Zebby), age 87. Died on July 29, 1998, Dublin, Ireland. After a short illness. Attended St. Marks School '30 and Harvard. Actor in Hollywood, in ''Grapes of Wrath, ''The Lion in Winter'', ''Ulysses'' & many other films and television productions. He worked with Henry Fonda, Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy. In 1950's joined Baha'i faith and moved to Ireland in 1963. In 1972 he was elected to the newly formed Baha'i National Assembly in Ireland and served until 1987. Author of books and essays on Baha'i faith and biography of Gish sisters. He sponsored an annual playwright competition in Ireland, and in 1965 received the Actor's Church Union Award for the Best Actor in the Dublin Theatre Festival for his performance in Eugene O'Neill's ''Hughie''. Member, Kildare Street Club in Dublin and other clubs. Baha'i funeral service and burial in Ireland on July 30.

title: Backstedt's Late Surge Gives Him Slim Victory
description: Frankie Andreu said before the start of the Tour de France's 19th stage today that his legs were dead and that there was no point in expecting him to join a large, early breakaway.

title: Odd Corporate Couplings
description: Politics, it used to be said, makes strange bedfellows. But that process is nothing like the current wave of mergers, which are creating convoluted arrangements that are chosen not to make the business run better, but to get a deal done.

title: I.M.F. Team Backs a $2.2 Billion Loan for Hard-Up Ukraine
description: An International Monetary Fund team announced today that it would recommend a $2.2 billion loan to Ukraine, where the United States has showered assistance for much of this decade but where the economy remains crippled by corruption and a lack of reform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREATREX, NILES T.
description: GREATREX-Niles T. 72. Died July 28, 1998 in Cortland, NY. He was born January 5, 1926 in New York City, NY the son of William and Irene Reilly Greatrex and had been a resident of Syracuse since 1980 and previously resided in New York City. He was a past member of St. Paul's Catholic Church in New York City. Prior to his retirement in 1969, he was an Addressograph Operator at the New York Daily News for 15 years. He was a veteran of WWII, serving with the United States Navy from 1944 to 1946. Surviving are one brother; John J. Greatrex of Syracuse, NY, one sister; Emily Bostick of Dewitt, NY. He was predeceased by one brother; William Greatrex, and two sisters; Margaret Clarkin and Susan Rotavera. Donald L. Barber Funeral Home, 5016 North Main St, Homer, NY.

title: Slam Declarer's Nightmare: An Unexpected Trump Card
description: Two favored teams went down to defeat at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here Thursday.

title: LeShon Johnson's Outlook Is Positive
description: At running back, the Giants have Gary Brown, who is efficient between the tackles, Tiki Barber, who is best in the open field, and Tyrone Wheatley, who exhibits a combination of skills when he can stay healthy.

title: CityHawks Vow They Will Return
description: Despite the CityHawks' 5-23 record in two years in the Arena League, and less-than-hoped-for attendance, New York's experiment with football on a carpeted hockey rink will continue.

title: SNECMA-G.E. UNIT GETS $300 MILLION JET-ENGINE ORDER
description: CFM International said yesterday that it had received a $300 million order from Boullioun Aviation Services Inc. for CFM56-7 engines for 30 Boeing Company Boeing-737 aircraft. CFM International is a joint venture between France's state-owned aviation company, Snecma S.A., and the General Electric Company. Boullioun, an aircraft leasing company in Bellevue, Wash., that is a unit of the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company of Japan, also placed an option for an additional 30 engines. Delivery of the 737's to Boullioun is scheduled between 2001 and 2006.

title: In a Modern Hall, An Elegant Sound Meant for a Salon
description: Classical chamber music, by definition, was meant for performance in chamber-size spaces like salons, household music rooms or, at most, a banquet hall in some prince's palace. Listeners who have never heard chamber works played in intimate settings, where you can feel the vibrations of, say, a string quartet traveling through the floor right up into your feet, don't have any idea of how exciting it can be.

title: A Brassy Band of Angels With a Funky Idea of Wit
description: The idea of artistic fusion might have been created for the choreographer Dianne McIntyre and the musician Lester Bowie, but only in the most vital sense of the term.

title: Fearful Cambodians Fleeing Villages After Daring to Oppose Ruling Party
description: For many Cambodians, a vote against the ruling party in last Sunday's parliamentary election was an act of physical bravery.

title: Mets Trade Pulsipher And Gilkey
description: The day began with a curious trade for a pitcher who leads the major leagues in losses. It continued with a deal for a player the Mets passed on as a free agent last spring.

title: Hyundai Cuts 4% of Workers
description: The Hyundai Motor Company today dismissed 1,569 employees, or 4 percent of its work force, making use of new labor laws to cut wages and weaken its powerful unions.

title: SYBRON CHEMICALS BUYS RUCO POLYMER FOR $95 MILLION
description: Sybron Chemicals Inc. acquired two privately held companies, the Ruco Polymer Corporation and the Ruco Polymer Company of Georgia, yesterday for $95 million plus $15 million in assumed debt. The Ruco Polymer Corporation, based in Hicksville, N.Y., makes and sells polymer intermediates used mainly in powder and high solids coatings and in fiber-reinforced plastics. It has annual revenue of $80 million. Sybron, based in Birmingham, N.J., makes and sells specialty chemicals. It had sales of $49 million in the quarter ended June 30. Shares of Sybron were unchanged, at $28, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: COURT APPROVES MARVEL REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: A Delaware bankruptcy court approved Marvel Entertainment Group Inc.'s modified plan of reorganization yesterday. The last major impediment to Marvel's Chapter 11 reorganization was overcome on Thursday when the investor Carl C. Icahn agreed to the amended reorganization plan, which calls for Marvel to be merged into a unit of Toy Biz Inc. In the merger, which is expected to be completed in September, each outstanding Marvel common share will be canceled. Mr. Icahn is to receive a combination of stock and warrants in the newly merged company on top of a $3.5 million cash payment. Marvel is a New York publisher of comic books best known for its Spider-Man and Incredible Hulk characters. Toy Biz, also of New York, holds a royalty-free license to make toys based on Marvel's cartoon characters.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN AT 6-WEEK LOW. Traders sold yen for dollars on new evidence of strength in the United States economy and confidence that Japan will not defend its currency. The dollar rose to 144.65 yen from 143.66.

title: A Slaughter of Cormorants in Angler Country
description: The double-crested cormorant is a protected species, its safety guarded by Federal law. But on the Lake Ontario shoreline west of Watertown, N.Y., the long-necked black birds have become a pest to anglers, who say the growing colonies of cormorants are devouring smallmouth bass and, along with them, the livelihood of people who sell bait and run charter fishing trips.

title: Privacy Concerns Delay Medical ID's
description: The Clinton Administration has temporarily backed away from its plan to assign every American a computerized code that would be used to track medical records, saying the ''unique health identifier'' will be delayed until Congress adopts legislation to protect patients' privacy.

description: Prosecutors charged a mother-and-son team with credit card fraud yesterday, a move that will help insure that the suspects remain held in New York while their possible role in the disappearance of an Upper East Side widow is investigated.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CATTLE FUTURES FALL. Cattle futures fell to the lowest level since May 1996, hurt by ample beef supplies and increased consumer purchases of pork. The August contract fell 1.225 cents a pound to 58.875 cents.

description: GEHNRICH-Charles A. Of Upper Brookville, New York. On July 31, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Martha. Devoted father of Joan Pedigo, Charles, and Robert. description: On the first stop of a two-day tour of Monmouth and Ocean Counties yesterday, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed two bills appropriating $11.5 million for the preservation of historic sites.

description: Maribel Navarrete pointed to the blotchy water stains that mark the ground-floor walls of her brownstone on 29th Street off Fourth Avenue. ''The water comes up through the drain, through the toilet, through the shower,'' she said, describing what happens when it rains hard. ''This isn't clean water.''

title: Case in Los Angeles Raises Concerns Over Secrecy of Wiretaps
description: The official report of Ramiro Delaherran's arrest last December seems to be a straightforward account of some very lucky police work: Los Angeles County Sheriff's officers stopped him because he made an abrupt left turn without using his signal. Then they happened to find that the red Ford Thunderbird he was driving was loaded with 150 kilograms of cocaine.

title: Jet Set Keeps Wet
description: With the humidity in planes typically under 10 percent, the air is drier than the Mojave. That may be why supermodels on the Concorde spritz Evian on their skin. Now Skinceuticals is proposing a different approach. Its Hydrating B5 Gel contains hyaluronic acid, which attracts water and boosts the effect of any moisturizer, the company says.

title: Buying a Farm (Sort of) and Reaping the Rewards
description: Rosemary and basil perfume the air, and the freshly washed beets, carrots and lettuce glisten on the tables at Genesis Farm. It's noon on Tuesday, and a genteel gathering of about 10 people rush the modest wooden garden house in Blairstown to pick up their share of produce harvested just that morning, some of it still warm from the sun. They also get bunches of flowers, and as many raspberries and blackberries as they want to pick.

title: Borneo's Wild Side
description: JUST don't look up and talk at the same time,'' suggested Walter, our guide. As we entered the cave it quickly became apparent why. The ground was covered with a thick carpet of spongy guano, a dead giveaway of the thousands of bats hanging from the dimly lighted ceiling. Flying rapidly in and out of the cave's entrance were tiny swiftlets whose nests bring high prices as the main ingredient for bird's nest soup.

title: Swift, if Flammable, Solution: Jets Get Cox
description: The volatile Bryan Cox, a three-time Pro Bowl performer who has spent $100,000 on fines in his career, agreed to a contract with the Jets today that would make him the middle linebacker in place of the injured Marvin Jones.

title: Museum for a Tribe That Struck It Rich
description: The ice will creak, the wind will whistle and the air will be cold when a simulated glacial crevasse and the rest of the Mashantucket Pequot Museum in southeastern Connecticut opens on Aug. 11.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1999 Saab 9-3; A Solid Breakaway From the Cookie Cutter
description: WHEN Saab introduced its redesigned 900 in 1994, cheers quickly turned to groans among many die-hard fans of the Swedish icon. They thought that the car didn't seem as tough or as durable as its predecessor; they complained that it lacked the traditional solid feel of a Saab. Since General Motors acquired 50 percent of the company four years earlier, many of the traditionalists concluded that Saab, which had maintained a distinctive character in a sea of generic look-alikes, had succumbed to Americanization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, WILLIAM MCCHESNEY, JR.
description: MARTIN-William McChesney, Jr. The Board of Directors of The New York Stock Exchange mourns the death of our former President, esteemed colleague and friend, William McChesney Martin, Jr. He served as the first full-time paid President of the Exchange from June 30, 1938 until April 16, 1941. He returned to conduct a study of the Exchange in 1971 where his insight and initiative led to changes in the governance of the Exchange. His dedication and commitment to the Exchange and the securities industry will endure. Richard A. Grasso, Chairman and C E O, New York Stock Exchange, Inc.

title: Nudes Across America
description: The photographer Spencer Tunick is singularly uninformed (Sunday: ''Nudes Across America,'' July 12). He believes that the elk antler arches in each corner of the Jackson town square are ''about excess, about man's ambition to kill and overindulge.''

Survived by his wife Natalie Rogers, daughter Colette, brother Sheldon, sisters Mildred and Florence, many nephews, one niece.

title: Campers Are Given a Turkey's-Eye View of Dinner
description: Now that Victor Gunyea has met a live turkey, his mother may have to start brainstorming alternatives for the main dish of their Thanksgiving dinner. Because if Victor, 10, has his way, no one in his family will be feasting on the traditional holiday bird.

description: BULLARD-Doris. Great animal lover. Died suddenly and unexpectedly July 28, 1998. My good friend, you will be dearly missed. Jane Rosenbloom

title: Postwar Reformers, Stretching the Limits
description: Patrick Uden, a British television producer, is something of an amateur psychologist. He's also a jazz fan, and combining his avocations makes it possible for him to explore a subject that fascinates him: the creative process. ''I'm very interested in the way people express themselves,'' Mr. Uden said recently from his London office.

title: Food; Fiesta Fare
description: In theory, party food should be fast food, particularly in the summer. A hostess's best friend is the kind of recipe that can be prepared in large quantities well ahead of time.

title: A Group Uproots Arabs to Plant Jews
description: For decades, the Jewish National Fund has been known for its tree-planting and land reclamation projects in Israel. Generations of Jews have given money to plant a tree in Israel, vicariously greening the country.

title: James Lighthill, 74, an Innovative Mathematician
description: Sir James Lighthill, an innovative British mathematician whose ideas about aerodynamics influenced the design of the supersonic Concorde, died on July 17 while he was trying to swim around the Isle of Sark in the English Channel. He was 74 and lived in London.

title: Pearl Harbor
description: To the Editor: Here is a supplement to the excellent information in the Q & A about Pearl Harbor (June 28). A cruise on the Star of Honolulu gives a good overview of the area. From topside, one can get a 360-degree view of Pearl Harbor. Taking a good map is recommended; the one available on board is elementary. While few Navy ships may be present, the brief stop near the Arizona Memorial can bring tears to one's eyes.

title: Zoot Hoot
description: High style, zoot suits and Hollywood glam dressing added spark to this year's Midsummer Night Swing festival, which featured live big bands on the Fountain Plaza at Lincoln Center. On swing and salsa nights in July, concertgoers radiated a fresh enthusiasm for both dancing and fashion -- a new craze, perhaps?

title: Craig Wilson, Dr. Dawn Sears
description: Dr. Dawn Victoria Sears, a podiatrist in St. Albans, Queens, was married in Manhattan on Friday to Craig Franklin Wilson, an associate in the law offices of Gerard J. Marulli in Manhattan. Former Mayor David N. Dinkins officiated at Tavern on the Green in Central Park.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Jason Binn; Night Owl With A Curfew
description: JASON BINN, a co-founder of Ocean Drive Magazine in Miami Beach and, as of this summer, a co-owner of Hamptons Magazine, spends winters in Florida and summers in New York. He doesn't waste a minute in either place. At 7 P.M. sharp last Wednesday, he met the actor Billy Zane at the Regency Hotel. From there, the two dropped in on a Hugo Boss party at the Guggenheim Museum's branch in SoHo, then on a party for the new magazine Gear, started by Bob Guccione Jr. They separated after making plans to meet later that night.

title: Modest Proposal
description: In its last five-year campaign, Yale University raised $1.7 billion, helping to push its endowment close to $6 billion. Harvard, with a $12.8 billion endowment, is in the midst of raising $2.1 billion more. In an era when a large endowment is a measure of prestige among top universities, few have questioned the wisdom of accumulating such huge nest eggs.

title: Emily Todd, Liam Harte
description: Emily Bishop Todd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Todd of Ashfield, Mass., was married yesterday to Liam Harte, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Harte of Reading, England. Canon Alfred G. Mitchell, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Dromard, Ireland.

title: The Way a Fish Needs a Bicycle
description: I AM surrounded by women. Tall, short, fat, thin, tank top, crop top, flattop, bobbed, blunt cut, dreadlocks, Goldilocks, hair the color of wheat, whisky, midnight, creme de menthe; they're young, old, sweet, weird, pierced, plucked, smoothed, branded, braided, bald; with pants too big, pants too small, kilts, culottes, khaki. Black, lots of black. Pajama pants. Flannel. Latex. Cashmere. Tattoos.

title: A Twist on History In Mixed Media
description: MIXED media artworks, including collages, photography and digital art, are featured in a collection, ''Histories (Re)membered,'' on display at the PaineWebber Art Gallery. The art, on loan from the permanent collection of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, will be on display at this free exhibition through Sept. 11.

title: Working to Reactivate Indian Point 2
description: THIRTY-FIVE miles north of New York City, on the banks of the Hudson River here, workers have been toiling around the clock to reactivate Indian Point 2, one of three nuclear reactors whose stark silhouettes stand out in sharp relief against the rural countryside.

title: Severe Weather Warning
description: The year 1998 may be remembered as the time when weird weather became the norm. From the storms that pounded California over the winter to the drought that fed Florida's fires this summer, the one constant of the weather has been its bizarreness. In March, New York City experienced record-tying spring heat a few days after late-season snow. Santa Barbara, Calif., received 21 inches of rainfall in February, a once-a-millennium event. Texas endured weeks of 100-degree-plus July heat, resulting in scores of deaths.

title: July 26-August 1; A Policy of Mutilation
description: Sierra Leone got back its most wanted criminal. Foday Sankoh, who led a brutal movement called the Revolutionary United Front, which has made the country all but ungovernable for nearly a decade, was sent back to Freetown by Nigeria, which arrested him last year when he arrived on a arms-buying spree.

title: Introduction
description: Readers faulted us for letting our cover article on Bernard Arnault and the luxury business take center stage over a report on child rape in South Africa. And Thomas Lynch's essay on baby boomers and death led many to send in anecdotes about making their own funeral preparations.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on July 19 with an article about an exhibition of work by the painter Myron Stout in Provincetown, Mass., carried an incomplete credit. The picture of the artist in his studio was taken by Norma Holt.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article in Arts & Leisure today about the difficulty in filling museum directors' jobs includes an outdated reference to the post at the Whitney Museum of American Art. After the section went to press, Maxwell L. Anderson, director of the Art Gallery of Ontario, was appointed director of the Whitney.

title: For Eggplant Dishes, Fresh Guises With Tomatoes and Herbs
description: EGGPLANT provides a note of dark beauty to the displays at produce stands. And in summer, when it is freshly picked, firm and glossy, eggplant is at its best. That the eggplant repertory focuses on the Mediterranean makes it particularly welcome in warm weather.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLARD, ROSALIND
description: GALLARD-Rosalind Wife of the late F. Edmund Gallard. Mother of Don Gallard of Denver, Colorado; Lorraine Gallard of Bethesda, MD; and Ken Gallard of Taos, New Mexico. Sister of Walter Abrams of Valley Stream, New York. Grandmother of Dewey Gallard and Solomon Kuckelman. Lifelong friend of Roz and Murray Martin. She will be remembered for her deep love of family, her strength, her intelligence, her elegance. Despite advancing illness, she continued to be a loving inspiration to her children. Graveside services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J., on Monday, July 27, 11 AM. Memorial contributions in her name may be made to Jewish Heritage for the Blind, Brooklyn, NY, or Alzheimer's Association. Date of passing, July 25, 1998.

title: Edward F. Edinger, 75, Analyst And Writer on Jung's Concepts
description: Dr. Edward F. Edinger, a leading Jungian analyst whose books on the interplay between symbols and psychology carried the concepts of Carl Jung to a new generation of American analysts, died on July 17 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column last Sunday about the physical links between the tracks of New York City's subway system and the commuter rail lines misidentified the subway division that includes the L line. It is the BMT, not the IRT.

title: Not Just Knickknacks, but What?
description: THE Brooklyn Historical Society created a stir nine years ago by installing large photographic cutouts of Ralph Kramden and Ebbets Field and a model of the Coney Island Cyclone in its landmarked 1880 building in Brooklyn Heights. In a place where Brooklynese was hardly spoken, these icons of popular culture seemed brash. But lately the society has seemed to be in a holding pattern. Its 155,000-volume library is closed, and a new show promised for this year has yet to materialize. Meanwhile, the once-innovative exhibit stands unchanged.

title: Public Schools See Enrollment Slowing Down
description: After seven years of galloping growth, enrollment in the New York City public school system has suddenly begun to slow down, puzzling demographers but bringing relief to school officials, who for years have had to accommodate swelling numbers of children in cramped and aging schools.

title: A Top M.B.A. Is a Hot Ticket as Salaries Climb
description: The 1990's were supposed to be lean years for graduates of the nation's top business schools. Overpriced, overabundant and caricatured in movies like ''Working Girl,'' M.B.A.'s were destined for the same fate as junk bonds and Manhattan real estate -- or so business school deans and business journalists predicted at the start of the decade.

title: Perplexing Formula Clinches Slim Majority for Cambodian Chief
description: Battered by coups, violence and voting day manipulation, Cambodian voters waiting to learn the results of last Sunday's elections faced a new challenge today: mathematics.

title: Messiaen's 'Francois' Has Staying Power
description: PERMANENCE, these days, comes electronic. Even in the world of what was once ''classical'' music, the most a composer can expect for a big work is a run of performances leading to a recording, after which the score might as well be dropped in the ocean.

title: Bragging Rights to the Bicycle, All Thanks to a Frenchman
description: IT wasn't just an amazing and entertaining interlude on the New Haven Green recently when a daredevil bicyclist strutted his stuff as part of the International Festival of Arts and Ideas. His performance was the prelude to a ceremony commemorating the first patent awarded for the bicycle, which occurred in New Haven in 1866. That milestone, combined with the fact that the bicycle was first mass-produced in America in a Hartford factory 12 years later, gives Connecticut bragging rights over a technology that has changed the world.

title: INSIDE

description: Somewhere in america tonight, in a delicious rite of childhood, a teen-ager will curl up in a window seat or overstuffed sofa to devour a young-adult novel. . .about murder, incest, rape or drug addiction. These are the subjects of a spate of recently published young-adult novels that have some librarians and parents concerned.

title: Street News With Flash
description: These days, everyone is going up-market -- even the homeless. In Los Angeles, a new monthly magazine called The Big Issue is being hawked by the city's vagabonds, who get to keep 60 cents of each issue's $1 cover price. Shunning the mean-streets reportage of ''homeless'' newspapers like Street News in New York City, The Big Issue aims instead to divert readers with celebrity coverage and service fluff. The first issue put Jack Nicholson on the cover and offered a report on telepathic pet communication. The second brought a first-person account of a dance rave in the California desert.

description: Students attending Prof. Samuel V. Wilson's ''spy class'' at Hampden-Sydney College in Virginia can expect to be regaled with tales of derring-do and cold war double agents.

title: The Elevator as Circus, And Confessional
description: Office-building elevators may provide a relatively short ride to work, but they go a long way toward contributing to the human comedy. Some passengers have nothing to do but listen; others take the opportunity to have some fun with all those people pretending they are unaware of their fellow passengers. And sometimes a ride on an elevator can be a journey toward enlightenment.

description: WHEN I TOLD MY father I was looking for something interesting to do the summer after high school graduation, I was not quite prepared for his suggestion: the Army.

Guthrie Speers Jr., a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel on Chocorua Island in Squam Lake.

title: As Mariners Unravel, Yankees Come Together
description: Summer days pass, the Yankees continue to be as reliable as the tides, and slowly they move toward standards of success established generations ago. The Yankees were 50 games over .500 today after beating Seattle, 5-2, and it is becoming conceivable that they will win more games this season than any team has won in any season.

description: MANY would call this month the doldrums. There just doesn't seem to be much spunk to go outside and pull weeds, mow lawns or plant anew.

description: An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about noisy air-conditioners at a West Village restaurant, Zinno, misstated its location. The restaurant, which is on West 12th Street, is between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, not between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: No Merger, but Two Cash-Out Plans
description: TWO closed-end funds -- the Scudder Spain and Portugal fund and the Growth Fund of Spain -- said recently that their boards had voted to end a controversial merger agreement. Instead, the two funds, which trade at discounts to their net asset values, are taking steps to allow shareholders to cash out at net asset value.

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

description: Moments before the start of the Indianapolis 500, you can look out from the front stretch grandstands and see human beings packed together, hip to hip and dozens of rows high, for at least three-quarters of a mile to your left and to your right -- to say nothing of the wall of faces directly across from you.

title: And Luxury For All
description: The cover of the magazine of July 12 pictured a glamorous woman holding a wineglass to highlight the main article involving luxury and the fashion magnate Bernard Arnault. In small print on the upper-left corner of the cover were listed three other articles, including ''Child Rape in South Africa.'' When child rape takes a second seat to ''luxury and those who can afford it,'' something is terribly wrong.

title: Why Johnny's Doing Calculus: The Booming Education Industry
description: In late May four teachers and administrators, sitting solemnly behind a table at the office of a top Manhattan public school, delivered the bad news to Elizabeth and Antonio Trindade. Their son, Lorenzo, could not keep up. He needed to be placed in special education classes at a smaller school.

title: Out With Old Blooms and New Weeds
description: Keep up with maintenance: water, weed, deadhead and fertilize. Don't let butterfly bush (Buddleia davidii) go to seed; cutting back spent flowers to the next set of buds will keep new flowers developing through summer. Keep removing spent flowers from annuals like cosmos and snapdragons. Divide and transplant iris and day lilies that are done blooming.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Now the Nehantics Ask U.S. Recognition
description: THE Nehantic were one of the most numerous and historically significant Indian groups encountered by European settlers in Connecticut. But by 1870 they were declared extinct by the state. Their 300-acre reservation, which encompassed all of the Black Point peninsula in East Lyme, was sold.

title: Her Job: Maintaining Journalistic Goodwill
description: BEFORE writing an article, Zhang Qianli of Xinhua, the Chinese national press agency, likes to think, and smoke. ''I smoke five cigarettes before I write,'' the reporter said. It's a habit, he added. In Nassau County, it's a challenge.

description: The story of Chicago Bears running back Curtis Enis has taken another interesting turn.

title: In California, 2 Resorts Fit For Toddlers
description: AS I pushed my 15-month-old son's stroller through the contemporary, art-filled Spanish Colonial lobby at the Four Seasons Aviara, in Carlsbad, Calif., I felt guilty for spoiling the serene atmosphere of the resort. My husband, Duke, and I had just driven down from Los Angeles in Friday-night rush-hour traffic, with two overheated pug dogs and Nicholas, who spent the entire ride wailing about the indignity of being confined to his car seat. He was still complaining vociferously as I wheeled him through a striking tiger-striped wooden arch (made by splitting an African tree called an antigrade) toward the reception desk.

title: The Nation: Strike Force; The Relentless March Of Labor's True Foe
description: THE 54-day General Motors strike erupted over local issues, like the auto maker's push to speed up work at a plant in Flint, Mich., but the strike shared a theme with walkouts as far away as Denmark and South Korea.

title: Jabs Are Traded in Round 1 of Race for California Governor
description: In California politics, this lazy summer season is traditionally the lull before the autumn storm, but the two major party candidates for governor began trading thunderbolts here on Friday night in the first of five promised debates. And when it was over, they had shed sweat, heat and light on topics from abortion to the death penalty to offshore oil drilling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, JEROME
description: ROBBINS-Jerome. Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater mourns the loss of a great pioneer of dance and the contribution he made to the arts community. A source of inspiration & creativity, we remember Jerome Robbins with much admiration. The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is proud to have been a part of his genius during our 1993 New York City Center Season where we performed his ballet, New York Export-Opus Jazz. Our sympathies are extended as we remember his talent and the passion with which he practiced his profession.

Peters. Kimberly A. Thompson, a certified marriage commissioner, is to officiate at the Meadowood, a resort in St. Helena, Calif.

title: A Secret Proceeding With No Secrets
description: For those who think they are learning something about the grand jury process as Kenneth Starr's investigation of President Clinton winds down, I have a cautionary word. I have been involved on both sides of grand jury matters for 20 years now, and this is not what it's like. What we are seeing instead is an exclusively political process, one where hyperactive journalism and relentless spinning by the participants have largely turned the tidy truths of the law into laughable fictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMPEL, ROY
description: LAMPEL-Roy. Age 50, Red Hook, NY, Monday, July 27, 1998, following a traffic accident. He owned several manufacturing businesses in New York and was active in trade associations in the Manhattan garment center. Father of Adam, son of Milton and Sylvia, brother of Neal, brother of the late Susan Lampel Levy, companion of Theresa. Private funeral services were held on Wednesday, July 29, 1998, at Burnett, Rockefeller & Hand Funeral Home, Red Hook, NY, 914-758-5042.

title: Back To the Blackboard
description: A recent survey suggested that education professors are out of touch with the reality of the American classroom, students' needs and the public's desires. The survey, by the research organization Public Agenda, concluded that education professors value the learning process over the right answer and creativity over grammar and spelling, and they consider discipline a low priority.

title: Out of Miss Porter's, And on to Cambridge
description: ON a cool, overcast June morning as the 1998 school year was winding down, Alice M. DeLana bade farewell to 39 years of teaching at Miss Porter's School in Farmington by delivering the commencement address. By turns elegant, cerebral and humorous, much like the woman herself, the speech asked graduates to revere and appreciate the power of words.

title: Job of Film Liaison Restored
description: WHEN the phone rang in Iris Stevens's county office in White Plains recently, a Hollywood location scout was inquiring about shooting parts of a film on the life of Ruben (Hurricane) Carter in Westchester, with other scenes set for Toronto. The producers wanted to know about nightclubs with black clientele. She will explore possible sites in New Rochelle.
