description: THE SETTING The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum at Fifth Avenue and 88th Street, where some 300 people have come on Tuesday evening to hear Dennis Hopper, the director of ''Easy Rider,'' talk about that iconic 1969 counterculture movie. The talk, in the dimly lighted Peter B. Lewis Theater, is part of the Guggenheim's ''Art of the Motorcycle'' exhibit. Many in the crowd have come straight from the office and are laden with suits, briefcases and cell phones. But there are a few exceptions.

title: I.M.F. Official in Moscow Presses Kremlin on Reform
description: Stepping up pressure on Russia to follow through on its long list of promises to foreign creditors, a top official from the International Monetary Fund ended a previously unannounced round of meetings in Moscow this evening with a warning to the Russian Government that its actions this month would be carefully scrutinized.

title: Snap, Crack, Pop: Bursting Gum's Taboo
description: IT was a fairy tale wedding. The sky was a glorious, sunny blue. Everything, from the radiant bride to the fabulous flowers, was perfect. Everything, that is, except the bridesmaid chomping away on a wad of gum.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: CRUISING IN ASIA: Holland America is offering 50 percent discounts on three 15-day cruises of the 1,214-passenger Nieuw Amsterdam between Hong Kong and Singapore this fall. With the discounts, fares start at $2,113 a person, double occupancy; round-trip air fare from the East Coast is an additional $999. The discounts apply to the Oct. 20 and Nov. 19 sailings from Hong Kong to Singapore and the Nov. 4 sailing in reverse. Among the ports are Da Nang, Vietnam; Siracha, Thailand; Muara, Brunei; Kota Kinabalu, Malaysia; Port Kelang, Malaysia. On the Hong Kong-Singapore itinerary, the ship spends two days in Hong Kong; on the reverse itinerary, it spends two days in Thailand. Reservations must be made through travel agents; for more information, the line has a Web site: www.hollandamerica.com.

title: Sports of The Times; The Yankee Fan Can Live With This Outfit
description: YOWLS of rage echoed from hillside to hillside, carried across the gray waters of Puget Sound: That's it? That's all these blankety-blanks could get for the certified Best Pitcher in Mariners History?

title: Rivalry for Leadership Shadows Assembly Race
description: No sooner had Assemblyman Adriano Espaillat begun campaigning in front of a subway station in Washington Heights recently than he was confronted by the appearance of a red van, carrying huge posters bearing the image of his opponent and blaring music that drowned out his words.

title: Is There Demand Even for Copies Of Collectibles?
description: HOLLYWOOD-CRAZED collectors have long been willing to pay handsomely for original props like Dorothy's red shoes. But reproductions of collectibles?

title: Superbugs
description: There was nothing out of the ordinary about the slender glass tubes of blood that arrived in Sharon S. Rotun's laboratory late in the afternoon of March 20, 1998. A pale, stocky woman with the impatient manner of someone who is overworked and underpaid, Rotun was the microbiology supervisor at United Hospital Medical Center, a small community hospital in the working-class town of Port Chester, N.Y., just north of Manhattan in Westchester County. The two blood cultures were among roughly a dozen sent to the lab that day. Whoever ordered the testing was evidently in a hurry, Rotun recalls, because he or she hadn't even bothered to scribble the usual instructions on the accompanying slip.

title: POSTINGS: Avalon Bay to Put Up 3 Buildings; Queens West's New Developer
description: Avalon Bay Communities, a real estate investment trust, has been selected to build the remaining three buildings in the first stage of Queens West, the large-scale mixed-use development along the East River in Long Island City, Queens.

title: A 20-Year Retrospective At a Mill in Claverack
description: A RAMBLING clapboard mill dating from 1767 and an 1805 brick mansion with an imposing portico: one painted ox-blood red, the other a glistening white, the buildings stand on the Merchant and Ivory Foundation estate here along with locust trees that have trunks so ridged as to seem like carvings. Other assets include a large mill pond lying placid and, until gravity forces it over a dam -- to become a river shaded by more trees -- a stream and a resident woodchuck, which at this time of year can be seen burrowing for dear life in the undergrowth. It is no wonder that the filmmakers Ismail Merchant and James Ivory have made the estate their country seat and even less surprising that Frederic Church chose to build his Romantic folly, Olana, on the Hudson River a few miles away.

title: Young, Vulnerable And Violated In the New South Africa
description: Suzanne Daley's disturbing account of child rape in the new South Africa was chilling and Donna Ferrato's stark photographs even more so. However, by publishing the 9-year-old victim's name and face with no regard to hiding her identity, aren't we only contributing to her violation? Or do rape-privacy conventions in publishing only apply to victims in the United States?

title: U.S. vs. the World In All-Star Game
description: Major League Soccer borrowed a page from hockey for its third All-Star Game today in Orlando, Fla., matching the league's best Americans against the best foreigners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, EDNA R.
description: KENNEDY-Edna R. On August 1, 1998. Loving great-aunt of Karolyn Kennedy Lord. Devoted aunt of Rita O'Meara Sachs. Survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd St. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, Blessed Sacrament Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Style; Gift Rap
description: On the tricky issue of gifts, ours is a mixed marriage. I was brought up in an orthodox home in which each holiday and anniversary and birthday required some concrete and definite offering. A gift. Because I am challenged in the art of giving, my pathetically inept tributes were invariably received with suppressed shock, along with a dead-giveaway counterfeit smile. I can still remember my father lighting up with synthetic joy at the grotesque paper tie I made for him in grammar school.

title: July 26-August 1; Biting Remarks
description: Mike Tyson snapped again. Near the end of a three-and-a-half hour public hearing before members of the New Jersey State Athletic Control Board, Tyson lost his cool and uttered an expletive as his lawyer, Anthony Fusco Jr., made an impassioned plea for the panel to give the former world heavyweight boxing champion a boxing license.

title: It's Kenya's Farmers vs. Wildlife, and the Animals Are Losing
description: On a clear day, Agnes Patita can see the tourists in vans inching along dirt roads, searching the plains for antelope, zebra, giraffe and, if they are lucky, an elusive pride of lions.

title: July 26-August 1; A Disputed Election
description: Cambodians voted with obvious enthusiasm last Sunday, embracing the chance to choose their new government after years of coups and bullying by their leaders. International observers pronounced the election a success, and Stephen Solarz, heading an unofficial American delegation to monitor the vote, sounded like Muhammad Ali when he declared that he had witnessed ''the miracle on the Mekong.''

title: Swap Meet
description: A STREAM OF WINDOWS Unsettling Reflections on Trade, Immigration, and Democracy. By Jagdish Bhagwati. 531 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $30.

title: Of the South and Its Imprint on Literature
description: TO drop the term ''Southern writers'' in a roomful of literati is to find oneself momentarily in possession of a staff as powerful as Moses'. Opinion sucks itself up into two formidably glittering walls, while faces turn, some alight in passionate defense, others with chins drawn in and hackles visibly raised. The dispute goes well beyond whether William Faulkner was the American Shakespeare or a suffocatingly long-winded chronicler of characters who were the same way themselves. It also goes beyond ideas about the region itself, though these are apt to cloud the issue.

title: ABC's First, Then B.A.'s
description: As the City University of New York begins to phase out remedial courses at senior colleges, the debate continues over what role, if any, remediation should paly in higher education. But across the country, the sourses remain a major part of the curriculum. Here is a snapshot based on figures released this year, for fall 1995. (''High'' signifies schools with more than 50 percent minority enrollment.)

title: HONK, GRRR
description: This summer, Arnold Nerenberg, a clinical psychologist in California, formed the International Association of Road Rage Experts. * Data indicate that the number of road ragers grows by 7 percent a year; Nerenberg says that the afflicted ''tend to be less-forgiving people in general.'' * The rage can overtake anyone. In Massachusetts in 1994, a church deacon fatally shot a medical technician in the chest with a crossbow during a highway argument. * New York State has three ''Road Rage Vans'' -- unmarked vehicles that videotape aggressive drivers and radio ahead to waiting cop cars. This and other programs have resulted in some 20,000 tickets in the last year. * For your protection, Bulldog Direct, a Cincinnati company, sells a ''Road Rage Protection Package'' that includes a helpful additive: Kevlar door paneling.

title: It's Not Just a Myth: They Do Speak With Their Hands
description: IN the documentary ''The Italian-Americans II: A Beautiful Song,'' which has its premiere on Tuesday at 8 P.M. on WLIW (Channel 21), a Long Island public television station that broadcasts throughout the New York area, Nick Stellino, a cookbook author of Italian descent, describes the way he and family members used hand gestures when speaking to one another. As Mr. Stellino explains, there was more to these gesticulations than the casual observer might suspect. Each family member adopted and honed his or her own singular flourish: Mr. Stellino himself liked to jab at the sky, while his father favored a to-and-fro motion with hands in front of chest, and his brother Mario adopted a dramatic shoulder-rolling arm movement. The gestures were like signatures, within which could be found clues to the speaker's personality.

title: In TV, It Can Always Be Worse
description: THIS spring the call went out to the creators of television programs: The networks want something original, something fresh; no more cop shows, lawyer shows, emergency-room shows and sitcoms about the dating dilemmas of New York City twentysomethings.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Former Children
description: In Reluctant Witnesses: Children's Voices From the Civil War (Westview, $24), Emmy E. Werner lets children tell what it was like to fight and endure the first modern war. As many as 400,000 children and adolescents served in the armies of the Civil War, the youngest as drummers and bugle boys, the older ones as soldiers. Many more suffered as civilians. Much of what they say in battlefield letters, diaries and memoirs from the safe harbor of old age is an unsurprising rehash -- war has always brought privation, terror, compassion and death. Yet even in war, children see things their own way. Flushed out of a berry patch by the noise of artillery, a 13-year-old from Gettysburg views a battle perched on a rail fence until waves of troops swarm over a hill toward him and he scoots home. An Atlanta boy looks out an upstairs window to see famished Union troops ravishing the fruit from his family's grapevines like ''a flock of hungry bluebirds.'' The best stories are the least-told tales of former slave children, particularly Susie King, who spent much of the war in a Union camp teaching emancipated children and soldiers to read. Unlike other combatants, whose war began in exhilaration and often ended in despair, hers began in fear and ended in hope. Werner, a developmental psychologist at the University of California, Davis, has written several books on the resilience of children. This one is too much a collection of quotations, providing only a lean meal. However, these voices make an important point: when both sides fight on home soil, there are no victors. Laura Green

Tiles can also work loose and fall out when buffeted by high winds. Tiles that are not exposed to the sun may grow moss.

description: Time has stood still for the village of Prek Yi Hin. Gaunt cows graze near rice and corn fields. In the cool underneath the stilt houses, women cut banana leaves and pigs nap. Politics also follows a long tradition in Prek Yi Hin, about 20 miles from Phnom Penh. A village leader administers what few programs reach here and chooses who gets rice when the harvest runs out.

The clothes are being modeled by full-figured young spokeswomen, including Mia Tyler, an actress (left); Abbie Kearses, a television reporter, and Kym Hampton of the Women's National Basketball Association. They will take part in a photo shoot and fashion show at Chelsea Piers on Tuesday.

And, trying as he is to begin an America's Cup campaign, each of his calendar hours looks more like a week of commitments. Not a good time to be running late.

description: Toward the end of this last school year, Theodore R. Sizer, the author and strategist of school reform, was sitting at a long table in the windowless office of the Francis W. Parker Charter Essential School here. Mr. Sizer is a largish, shambling fellow with shaggy brows and merry little eyes, an ironist with a deft sense of human folly. At that moment, however, he had lost his sense of humor. He and his wife, Nancy, had just agreed to become co-principals of Parker, a three-year-old junior and senior high school founded on the progressive principles with which he is associated.

From 1991 to 1997, enrollment at girls' schools has increased 15.4 percent, according to a study by the National Coalition of Girls' Schools. During the same period, the total population of elementary and secondary schools rose 7 percent, according to the National Center for Education Statistics.

description: REBELL-Harry. title: OUTDOOR PERILS
description: Earlier this summer, a female hiker entered an outhouse in a county park in northern Colorado, Horsetooth Mountain. Noticing a glowing red dot in the privy's waste pit, she bent down for a closer look and saw a man inside holding a video camera. She screamed (hey, who wouldn't?) and the man, clad in rubber hip boots, escaped through a hatch on the outside of the building. Lots of strange things happen in county, state and national parks -- in 1997 there were 416 nonassault sexual offenses in national parks, including many Peeping Tom episodes -- but this one has Colorado investigators scratching their heads. One theory (as yet unproved) is that the images will find their way to the Internet, where this sort of ''gotcha'' voyeurism is widely on display.

But through a prism of pragmatic politics, his comments seemed to make sense: The latest Gallup Poll shows that 59 percent of Americans say that homosexual behavior is morally wrong. In his own party, Mr. Lott played to a particularly receptive audience because Republicans are far less accepting of homosexuality than Democrats.

title: Cultural Crossroads In Vietnam
description: ''YOU must go to Hoi An,'' everyone from Vietnam connoisseurs to one-time visitors to that country ordered us. It was the Venice of Vietnam, we heard, a magically preserved Sleepy Hollow of coexisting Asian cultures. From the 16th to the 19th century, it had been a magnet for Southeast Asian commerce, drawing European, Chinese and Japanese merchants who sailed down the Thu Bon River to trade silks, Chinese medicines, paper, porcelain, oils, spices and more during four-month spring fairs. Many of the Chinese and Japanese stayed in Fai Fo, as it was then called, marrying Vietnamese women, and building houses, temples and assembly halls in their native styles.

title: The White House Shamus

And of all the hardened Beltway competitors at the St. Albans Tennis Club, from Jack Valenti to Vernon Jordan to Strobe Talbott, not one is more famous for his flat-out desire to win than the middle-aged man on court No. 8 serving this morning, down two games to one. Facing the net, he fiddles with his glasses, then squares his shoulders like a football lineman. He tosses the ball in the air, grunts as he serves, rushes the net, then grimaces as the ball whizzes by him.

It is in the form of electronic bulletin boards, which that provide a focal point for neighborhoods ranging in size from the area around a strip mall to communities defined not by physical boundaries but by the bonds of common interests and ideals.

Services will be held Sunday, August 2, at 1:45 P.M., at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family requests that no flowers be sent and that any contributions be made to the charity of your choice.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC; Drawing Sound From the Sights Of Medieval Art
description: ANY experienced fan of medieval music knows how drastically the performance of this repertory has changed over the decades. The frustrating fact is that we can only guess how it used to sound. All that remains is a bit of written music, often in notational styles difficult to decipher: a mere shadow of the music actually played and sung during the Middle Ages.

Walter Isaacson, Time's editor, gambled that the iconic Jordan would astound the sports world in the coming week -- and sure enough, the cover subject came through with a stellar performance that won the championship for his Chicago Bulls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUDENHEIM, JAY M.
description: FREUDENHEIM-Jay M. July 31, 1998, of Katonah, NY. Wonderful husband and best friend of Lenore for 58 years. Loving father of Lynn Cavo, Steve Freudenheim and Jill Lieberman. Proud grandfather of five and great-grandfather of two. Services private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Katonah Museum of Art, Route 22 at Jay St, Katonah, NY 10536.

description: GUCWA-David J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of David J. Gucwa, associated with The Times from 1993, until retiring in 1997.

title: No Taxis, To the Relief Of Residents
description: Residents of Harborview Terrace, a city housing project on West 55th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues, are breathing easier this week. That's because city officials say they will deny a request for a permit to put a taxi stand on the block.

title: No Border War as Residents In 2 Counties Fight Building
description: Though separated by the Bronx-Westchester border, residents of North Riverdale and southwest Yonkers have banded together to fight a planned 17-story building they say will overwhelm both communities.

title: Thomas F. Ryan, Bagpiper And Chicago Icon, Dies at 97
description: They played ''Danny Boy'' for Tommie Ryan the other day, and how could they not? In the three-quarters of a century since he arrived in Chicago with his fiddle, a wiry 22-year-old refugee from the Irish nationalist rebellion and 14 months in a British prison camp, Thomas F. Ryan had played the same sad strains in sunshine and in shadow at more than 1,000 funerals.

title: Co-Chief Executives: Can Two Be a Crowd?
description: IT is hard enough for investors to tell whether many of the recent corporate mergers make sense. But figuring out whether the power-sharing agreements made by top executives of the merged companies will work is nearly impossible.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: UNUSUAL protagonists propel the better films on television this week: a British matron during the Nazi blitzkrieg, a girl in mortal fear of her uncle, a Protestant minister and a runaway princess.

title: Young, Vulnerable And Violated In the New South Africa
description: When I opened the July 12 issue, I flipped past the major articles to Suzanne Daley's ''Young, Vulnernable and Violated in the New South Africa,'' eager to read a well-rounded report on a disturbing social issue. To my dismay, I found myself at the end of the article having read nothing more than the account of one South African girl, interspersed with token comments on the situation and statistical comparison. What began sounding like an in-depth look at child rape on a continent where disease and mistreatment of women and children are rampant befuddled me with the abrupt and unexpected ending.

title: Unusual Contest, Unusual Winner
description: CONSIDER the plight of John J. Wooten, the artistic director of Theaterfest, a professional summer stock company that means to offer ''something for everyone,'' in his words.

title: Sonny, We Didn't Have Calculators Back Then (And I Had to Walk)
description: A generation ago, every engineering student, prospective physicist and budding chemist carried a slide rule. Made of ivory, wood or (later) plastic, a slide rule looked like a fancy ruler but used logarithms to perform mathematical functions, from simple multiplication to trigonometry.

title: History of Glass On Display in England
description: The new National Glass Center in Sunderland, 275 miles north of London, is, appropriately, made mostly of glass, including a gently sloping glass roof on which visitors can walk (still -- despite some embarrassing cracks that have appeared in the roof, possibly design flaws, possibly the work of vandals).

title: Mount Motherhood Is Steep Enough for Her
description: EVER since I finished reading ''Into Thin Air,'' Jon Krakauer's book about the disastrous Mount Everest expeditions of 1996, I have been thinking about adventure. Or more specifically, about being adventurous and why I apparently am not. I was fascinated by the enormous difficulty of climbing Mount Everest, and by the climbers' willingness to suffer horribly for the experience of standing on top of a mountain. And yet, groaning up the rock face of daily life with small children, which can leave one feeling hypoxic by dinner time, I simply can't imagine choosing a vacation of pain and uncertainty, no matter what the eventual high.

title: Let the Hugfest Begin: Mets Beat Dodgers in the 9th
description: Earlier this week, Matt Franco pointed out to Lenny Harris that none of the current Mets had a pinch-hit home run this season. Franco and Harris are the Mets' top two pinch-hitters, and Franco told Harris something should be done.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, ERIC ALAN
description: ELIAS-Eric Alan. On July 31, 1998, at age 49. Cherished son of Jeanne Snyder and the late Leonard Elias. Devoted step-son of Sam Snyder and Rita Elias. Dear half-brother of Alyse, Matthew and Susan, step-brother of Eileen and Susan, nephew, uncle, loving friend of Susan Simon. Services Sunday, August 2, 11:30 AM, Garlick-Hellman Funeral Home, 1091 Yonkers Ave.

title: A Slimmer County
description: Keeping a campaign pledge to reorganize government to make it more efficient and more cost effective, County Executive Andrew J. Spano has sent to the Board of Legislators a law abolishing the Department of General Services. The proposed law, which transfers certain General Services functions to other county departments, also calls for a Department of Information Technology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSO, VITO M.
description: RUSSO-Vito M. On August 1, 1998. Beloved husband of Diana. Loving stepfather of Alexandra Kaufman, Valerie Lenes and Victoria Maghsadi. Adored grandfather of Jeffrey, Adam and Noah. Brother of Madeline LaMorte and Mary Scutellaro. Former owner of Mario Industries, Inc. Lamp and Shade Manufacturer of Mt. Vernon, NY. A former Board Member of Mt. Vernon Hospital, Westchester Advisory Board of Chemical Bank, Colburn Home of the Aged and the Westchester Community Foundation. Mr. Russo was involved in many philanthropic activities throughout his lifetime. He was an avid yachtsman. Visiting hours, George T. Davis Funeral Home, New Rochelle, NY, Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Chapel service Tuesday, 3 PM, at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Vito and Diana Russo Trust Fund, New York Community Trust Company, 2 Park Ave, NY, NY 10016.

title: Vandalism of Terns Reported
description: An environmental crusader who has labored for seven years to establish a sanctuary for endangered terns on Gardiners Point, an island off the East End, reports that 30 of this season's chicks have been killed by a trespasser.

title: Off to Another Time With 'Die Fledermaus'
description: THE Opera Theater of Connecticut has selected ''Die Fledermaus'' for its summer production, with performances scheduled Thursday and Saturday evenings at 7:30, as well as next Sunday at 6 at the Andrews Memorial Theater in Clinton.

title: Ideas & Trends; Why Russia Needs No 'Saving Private Ryan'
description: CENTURIES ago, when laying siege to Moscow was a coming-of-age rite for aspiring young plunderers and sackers, a tradition developed in which invading chieftains camped southwest of town, on a big hill by the Moscow River, and awaited word of surrender. Legend says Napoleon slept there, in 1812, at the climax of one of history's most infamous military campaigns. This was no ordinary hill. Was, because it no longer exists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDENBERG, BERNARD
description: FRIEDENBERG - Bernard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Bernard Friedenberg, associated with The Times from 1966, until retiring in 1982.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASILEVSKY, HELEN
description: BASILEVSKY-Helen, 59. Of New York City and Rensselaerville, NY. Beloved daughter of Nathalie and sister of Peter, died July 31, 1998 after a long illness. An artist and teacher, she was the head of the Art Department at Nightingale Bamford School, highly respected and well loved by friends, colleagues and several generations of students. Her work has been shown in galleries and museums but her proudest accomplishment was the many students who gained an appreciation for beauty, art and culture through her efforts as a teacher. A gentle, gracious person who was always more interested in others than herself, she will be sorely missed by all those whose lives she touched. Funeral services will be held on Sunday night August 2, 1998 at 6 P.M., at Christ the Savior Russian Orthodox Church, 340 East 71 Street, New York, New York, 10021. Burial services Monday, 9:45AM at Christ the Savior Church with interment at The Russian Orthodox Convent of ''Novo Diveevo'', 100 Smith Road, Nanuet, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to City Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Ave., NY NY 10017 and Christ the Savior Church.

title: Volunteers Join a Study of Women Over 50
description: AT 72, Teresa Weth of Somers is aware she may not live to the year 2005 to learn the results of the Women's Health Initiative, an unprecedented 7- to 10-year national health study of 164,500 postmenopausal women.

title: Labyrinth of Solitude
description: In december 1997, a man with the wonderfully aztec and spanish name Cuauhtemoc Cardenas became the Mayor of Mexico City and initiated a series of reforms, one of which, the most delicate of all, took place in plain view. It was an earnest municipal campaign to clear the unlicensed sidewalk vendors from the downtown zone around Mexico City's central plaza, the Zocalo. Sidewalk vending in that particular neighborhood is an ancient custom. In Aztec times, when Mexico City already figured as one of the world's largest cities, a market stood on that very spot, near the Main Temple on one side of the plaza. And the vendors have never disappeared. Photographs from the 19th century show what the vendors look like today: a lone person, often a woman, squatting by a tiny carpet on the sidewalk, displaying a pathetic handful of goods for sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MURIEL S.
description: FRIEDMAN-Muriel S. Died on Thursday, July 23, 1998. She was the beloved mother of Marcia Gaffner, Allen Friedman and Neil Friedman, loving grandmother of Aaron, Noah and Josh Gaffner and the adored mother-in-law of Jimmy Gaffner. A dedicated member of UJA, she was the recipient of the Golda Meir Woman of the Year Award. She will be remembered for her warmth, devotion to family and continued commitment to Judaism.

title: Are Small-Cap Stocks Ready for a Rally?
description: JUST as baseball fans often look at a batter who is in a slump and say, ''He's due,'' many analysts who follow small-capitalization stocks are saying they are ready to rise.

title: Food Supplies Low
description: Even though the need to nourish the poor continues unabated, summer donations to Food-Patch have dropped, the Millwood-based food bank reported last week.

title: Correction
description: An article on July 19 about the relationship between a company's environmental policies and the performance of its stock misspelled the surname of an asset manager at Salomon Smith Barney who said the idea of environmental investing remained a hard sell on Wall Street. She is Lisa Leff, not Laff.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: An Orchestra That Resounds With the Brilliance of Youth
description: MANY things about the Russian Symphony Orchestra seem to resonate of formative youth. The ensemble was organized just six years ago, and the average age of its members is 25. But to judge from a collection of exceptionally well-produced recordings, the sapling Russian Symphony might be as old as its musical roots. Indeed, the youth of its players is belied by an intensity, insight and precision that usually come with more years on stage than most of these musicians have lived.

description: HOPE IN A JAR

title: Right or Wrong to Name Names?
description: To the Editor:

description: Becoming Laura Ingalls Wilder

title: Injury to Keep Real Quiet Out of Action Until Winter
description: Real Quiet, who barely missed becoming the first Triple Crown winner in 20 years, is out of next Sunday's eagerly anticipated rematch with Victory Gallop in the $1 million Haskell and probably will not race again until winter.

title: Q&A/Mark Morganelli; Performer and Promoter of Jazz Concerts
description: MARK MORGANELLI began college as a chemistry major, but it took only a week before his love of jazz prevailed and any chance of his becoming a scientist was gone. Instead, he became a performer and promoter of jazz concerts in Manhattan, Westchester and elsewhere.

title: A Dental Hero
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; China Tries a Great Tippy-Toe Forward
description: EVER since the Communist Party took charge here in 1949, China's leaders have thrived on an unending cycle of political campaigns. With quaint-sounding names like Let a Hundred Flowers Bloom or the Cultural Revolution, campaigns were supposed to sound noble. The realities were often horrific.

title: FARNSWORTH CENTER
description: The success of the Farnsworth Museum is the result of its willingness to be regional and keep a narrow focus. In the case of this show, devoting all its gallery space to paintings by the Wyeths is a wonderful opportunity to anyone who can see the show during its run. Here is a chance to see the Wyeths as they see themselves, which is what I think Ms. Weisgall really objects to. I will be thrilled to see this show, and I am sure that, for years to come, many people will be glad to know that a selection of Wyeth works are available at the center whenever they can make the journey. That is an opportunity, not a restricted view, and The Times should be able to tell the difference.

title: Another Masterpiece
description: To the Editor:

title: Cashman Catches Breath After Not Making Deal
description: Fifteen minutes before the midnight Friday trade deadline, Seattle General Manager Woody Woodward called Brian Cashman, the Yankees' general manager, asking whether the Yankees would make the deal for the left-hander Randy Johnson.

title: In Bali, $3 Goes A Long Way
description: I LEANED back lazily in my hammock and surveyed the panorama from my private veranda: coconut palms and mango trees in sizzling jungle greens, cascades of purple trumpet vines and pale-yellow frangipani, a tropical explosion of foliage that would have kept Gauguin working overtime for a month. While waiting for breakfast to arrive, I mulled over the day's options: A massage and body scrub? Shopping? My thoughts were interrupted by the arrival of a mug of industrial-strength, locally grown coffee and a big plate of juicy pineapple and papaya. It was all impossibly sweet and delicious, but for a frugal traveler there was something even sweeter about this cottage in the central hills of Bali: the price tag. It was $2.85 a night, breakfast and tax included, at the prevailing rate of 14,000 rupiah to the dollar.

title: Habitats/A Happy Wanderer in SoHo, TriBeCa and Greenwich Village; From Sublet to Sublet, in a Downtown State of Flux
description: EVEN though she is only 23 and works as a graphic designer and not as a lawyer, say, or an investment banker, there are certain things Dana Snider will not put up with just to live in Manhattan. She will not take a roommate. And she will not live in an undesirable neighborhood.

title: New Effort Keeps Lincoln and Friends Looking Their Best
description: In the cool shade of some old trees in the Concert Grove in the eastern end of Prospect Park, Greg Phillipy was brushing wax onto the craggy bronze face of an Abraham Lincoln statue. It was Thursday afternoon and he had drawn some spectators.

title: Heart Attack Kills Serb on Trial for Genocide
description: A former Bosnian Serb official who played a key role in organizing three notorious prison camps during the Bosnian war died today, apparently of a heart attack, in his cell at The Hague where he was standing trial for genocide.

title: Freeze Frame
description: IN his white chef's jacket, Jimmy Chiappa ushers a visitor into his kitchen, gently removing a cat from the domestic clutter that covers the table. Modestly built, with an open, affable face, he doesn't look like the sort of man who makes his living battling 320-pound blocks of ice with a chain saw. In fact, Mr. Chiappa, 35, is an artist whose medium just happens to be ice. Over the last five years, he has turned out enough frozen sculpture -- at least 2,000 pieces, he estimates -- to fill a small museum, or a very large freezer.

title: Good Tidings for River
description: President Clinton has named the Hudson one of 14 American Heritage Rivers. Begun by Mr. Clinton in September, the American Heritage Rivers program has three objectives: the protection of natural resources and the environment, economic revitalization and historic and cultural preservation.

title: Theater to Psychiatry to 3:30 A.M. Fiction
description: CHARLES ATKINS of Woodbury has followed an unusual career path on his way to becoming a novelist. After graduating with a bachelor's degree in theater from New York University, he went back to school for premed studies. Then he worked as an emergency medical technician, earned a medical degree at Emory University in Atlanta and completed a psychiatric residency at Yale-New Haven Hospital in New Haven.

title: Ties That Bind, Ties That Break
description: PETER KWAN spends three nights a week at his bachelor pad in Murray Hill, and the other four nights at his mother's apartment in Chinatown, where he keeps his old room even though he moved out years ago. On one of his days off, he visits his father in a nursing home in the West Village.

title: Conceding the Grim Past, Germany Invites Jews
description: HALF a century after the world learned the full horror of Hitler's campaign to extinguish Jews, few countries have worked harder than Germany to atone for past evil. Nazi concentration camps like Dachau and Bergen-Belsen have been preserved as museums and draw tens of thousands of visitors every year. Every major city has its memorials and museum exhibits, from ''The Topography of Terror'' at the Berlin Museum to the Frankfurt Jewish Museum's immense model of the city's old Jewish ghetto. Dozens of historic synagogues have been meticulously reconstructed from rubble, though most are devoid of actual worshipers.

title: A Leading Edge in the Repair of Cartilage
description: IN the near future, scientists should be able to produce a wide range of spare body parts for transplants by growing body tissue. In fact, some techniques for what is known as tissue engineering are already available in the form of skin grafts and bone cartilage.

title: Movie Offers A Window Into Life Of Reeve
description: THE Hallmark Productions remake of Alfred Hitchcock's 1954 classic ''Rear Window'' being filmed in Yonkers will also become an intimate cinematic view into the struggle the actor Christopher Reeve has faced since his May 27, 1995, horse-riding accident that left him paralyzed, the executive producer of the film said.

title: Robert Wood Johnson Opening Crohn's Center
description: The Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Brunswick has opened a center for the treatment of chronic inflammation of the colon or intestinal tract -- conditions often misdiagnosed.

title: Streetscapes/88 and 90 Grove Street; West Village Houses With a Past Colored by the Arts
description: BUILT simultaneously in 1827 but for separate owners, the little houses at 88 and 90 Grove Street were later occupied by a landscape architect and an artist in the Greenwich Village art revival and, in the 1920's, were taken over as a double house by neighboring brother-sister owners. Now two new families have divided these unusual houses and are restoring them.

title: Miss Hendrix, Dr. Stavropoulos
description: Nicole Paulette Hendrix and Dr. Christos Ioannis Stavropoulos were married on Friday at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in Manhattan.

title: A Site for Tara Circle
description: Barring further setbacks, Tara Circle, an Irish education and cultural center, will finally find a new home at a former college in Yonkers. The group, which plans to lease and then buy a building once used by Iona College, will offer programs in Irish history, language, music, theater and dance, James Rice, one of the center's planners, said.

title: The Nation: Delusions; Paranoia Is Universal. Its Symptoms Are Not
description: A DERANGED man who believes that the Central Intelligence Agency and other secret Government forces are conspiring to control his mind goes on a rampage, and innocent people die.

title: The Rainbows Are Coming!
description: Once a summer since 1972, a loose-knit group of hippies called the Rainbow Family has converged on various plots of publicly owned land to pray for world peace. . .and party wildly. The Rainbow gathering started small, but it has grown into a sprawling, messy, weeks-long bash for hordes of anti-establishment revelers. This year, some 25,000 Rainbows descended on Springerville, Ariz. (population 1,900), setting up in a sensitive meadow in the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest. Springerville is a conservative town, and residents and U.S. Forest Service staff braced for the worst, based on rumors and reports from previous Rainbow gatherings about environmental destruction, wildfires, burglary, rampant public nudity and drugs. How bad was it? Here's a look.

title: QUICK BITE/New Brunswick; You Say Potato, They Say 'No Problem'
description: There are no scalloped or mashed potatoes on the menu, but otherwise One Potato, Two Potato specializes in exactly what you would guess.

title: Looking for Love
description: THE WAY I FOUND HER

title: What Glassmakers Did on Their Own Time
description: GLASS has largely gone unrecognized in discussions of American folk art. Gay LeCleire Taylor, the curator of the Museum of American Glass at Wheaton Village here, has organized the first major museum show devoted to glass folk art. The term folk art usually implies a work made by an individual with limited formal training. But highly skilled artisans, who wanted to do more than their factory jobs demanded, superbly crafted the 120 glass objects currently on display.

title: Debate Over the Police Divides Lloyd Harbor
description: ALL is usually quiet in the Village of Lloyd Harbor. Located on a peninsula on the North Shore, this picturesque area of gently rolling hills, parks and estates has only about 3,500 residents in its 9.2 square miles. Elaborate houses spread out by two- and five-acre zoning characterize the affluent community, once home to Henry Fonda, Billy Joel and the Bee Gees.

title: Lighting Out For the Territory, This Time in 3-D
description: Mark Twain's America

title: Dos and Don'ts Of Runway Shows
description: TO get to Day for Night, a stylish space on fashion's new frontier in the westernmost reaches of Chelsea, you need to take a slow-moving, living-room-size, don't-touch-the-walls-they're-filthy freight elevator up to the 18th floor. Including waiting time, air kisses and loading-dock chitchat of the ''Love your Prada man-purse'' variety, it takes maybe 10 minutes.

title: NEW YORK BEGINS TO RAID AND CLOSE ADULT BUSINESSES
description: Fulfilling the Giuliani administration's longstanding promise to restrain the city's sex industry, police officers raided three topless clubs late Friday and building inspectors shut them down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILGRAM, GRACE SMELO
description: MILGRAM-Grace Smelo. Age 83, on Thursday, July 23, 1998, at her home in Washington, DC. Grace Milgram, housing economist, social activist, and beloved mother of Betty Milgram of Silver Spring, MD, and Gene Milgram (Vicky Owens) of Annapolis, MD. Also survived by a host of other relatives and friends in her native Philadelphia, NYC, Washington, DC, and elsewhere. Graduate of Antioch College, 1937; University of Pennsylvania master's and Ph.D. in City Planning, 1967; divorced in 1969 from the late Morris Milgram. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, August 8, 1:30 PM, at Thomas House (in lobby), 1330 Massachusetts Ave, NW, Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave, Montgomery, AL 36104.

title: Lea Varelas, Eric Medow
description: Lea Varelas and Eric Charles Medow, vice presidents in investment banking at Salomon Smith Barney in New York, were married yesterday in Pebble Beach, Calif., by Gary D. Skraba, a California deputy commissioner of civil marriages, at the Lodge at Pebble Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PETERS, MARK R.
description: PETERS-Mark R. 9/6/21-8/4/78 Remembered with love.

title: The Millennium Bug Looms
description: Fear of chaos in the world's computer systems in the year 2000 may be hard for most people to take seriously. The temptation is to assume that since technicians created the problem, technicians can solve it. But with only 516 days until the fateful turnover, it is clear that the United States is not moving fast enough to fix its computers or prepare for significant disruptions. Instead of addressing a potential crisis, many leaders in business and government are complacent, declining to act for fear of lawsuits or engaging in political fights. Their lack of attention could be crippling.

title: Mainers Say Hello Headsets, Farewell Chicken Plucking
description: The tide used to blush red with chicken blood here and when it ebbed, leave watermarks written in feathers. Flurries of down sometimes whitened Main Street, as if left by a town pillow-fight. Pleasure boats shunned the harbor, fearing the slimy fat that would coat their hulls. And summer visitors, not used to the smell, held their noses as they passed from odor to odor: the poultry plants, the sewage plant, the fish plant.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Banker
description: IT'S mind-boggling to consider what $1 trillion is worth. It makes up the total gross domestic product of Britain. It could buy the majority of California's seven million single-family homes and condominiums. It is also the value of all announced merger-and-acquisition activity in the United States this year.

title: Q and A
description: Putting Up the Dog

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUMMOND, JAMES C.
description: DRUMMOND-James C. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James C. Drummond, associated with The Times from 1953, until retiring in 1987.

title: A Little Nurturing of Nature, the French Way
description: THE twin colonnades of plane trees that line the Cours Mirabeau in this ancient French city to the south are not there by accident. Some human eye devised the spacings, guided the beginnings, then let nature take its course. The hand of man is everywhere to be observed on France's natural beauties. Nature is to be revered, but it is also to be improved on.

title: Socko Finish
description: As a physician for more than a half-century, I have interest in many aspects of living and not living and thought Lynch's piece was totally amusing. Two years ago, a much-loved octogenarian sister died. She intended that there be no casket, burial plot, funereal worship or similar facade.

description: To the Editor:

title: Word for Word/Killing Hitler; Blow the Fuhrer From the Train And Other British Plots
description: A SUITCASE packed with explosives, to be tossed beneath the Fuhrer's train. Commandos in fake Nazi uniforms in an Alpine raid. Clothing laced with anthrax. Lethal cleaning ladies. A poisoned cup of tea.

title: Mr. Babbitt Keeps Plugging
description: His favorite programs, including restoration of the Everglades and the repair of the national parks, are getting hammered by the appropriations committees in Congress. His reputation in Washington is clouded by an investigation into allegations that contributions to the Democratic Party influenced his decision on an Indian casino license. Yet far from treading water, Bruce Babbitt is charging around the country doing what a Secretary of the Interior ought to be doing: spreading a gospel of stewardship and using the inherent powers of his office to put in place environmental strategies that, with any luck, will outlive his tenure.

title: Military Fires a Warning Shot at Law Schools
description: After getting word that several law schools were barring its recruiters from campus, the Department of Defense decided to take a closer look, and over the last few months it has notified 40 law schools that their policies most likely violate Federal law.

title: Crime
description: In her stunning first mystery, ''A Free Man of Color,'' Barbara Hambly devised a lavish historical setting to summon up the intoxicating -- and dangerous -- pleasures of Mardi Gras, as pursued by the jaded residents of New Orleans in 1833. Drawing on a darker chapter of local history for FEVER SEASON (Bantam, $23.95), Hambly plunges us into the appalling spectacle of a city caught in the grip of the yellow fever epidemic of 1834. ''Bronze John,'' as the suffering citizens call this baffling plague, has made a charnel house of the city, with its rumbling ''dead-carts'' and overflowing cemeteries and hospitals no better than holding pens for the dying.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're not chicken

title: On the Job, and Happy About It
description: Did you start out working in the field you always wanted, or did you take a less direct course to your dream job?

title: David Eigen and Cynthia Poster
description: Cynthia Poster, a daughter of Dr. Joan Poster and Dennis B. Poster of Southport, Conn., was married last evening to David Lawrence Eigen, the son of Joan and Robert Eigen of Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Robert Orkand officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COVEY, SUSAN SINGER, M.D.
description: COVEY-Susan Singer, M.D. Age 55, of Fairfield, CT, died July 31, 1998, after a long and courageous fight against cancer. After graduating Vassar College, Downstate Medical Center, she did her medical training at Yale. As a radiation oncologist, Susan was an endless inspiration to her patients and colleagues in a lifelong battle against the disease to which she succumbed. Her spirit and compassion live in her children Anne, David, Aaron, and Michael, her sister Marilyn, Susanna, friends and patients. Funeral services will be Monday, August 3rd, at Abe Green's Funeral Home in Fairfield. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the American Cancer Society. We love you mom, you didn't need a dress rehearsal.

title: Amphibious
description: Once found only under water, goggles are making a splash on the street, sold alongside sunglasses and Yankees caps by sidewalk peddlers.

title: Far From the Ring and the News, A Corner a Fighter Calls Home
description: CAMILLE EWALD'S house, as wide and stately as Tara, stands at the end of a dirt road, shrouded by bushes and shade trees. Still, Mike Tyson gawkers manage to find it. They come all the time when the boxer is far away from the news, and, especially, when he is in it.

title: Recipe for a Good Time: Surrealism and Pop Culture
description: AT first, Surrealism and popular culture would seem to be oil and water. Surrealism mines dreams and the unconscious, while popular culture is concerned with surface and commonplaces. But in recent years they have been brought together in exhibitions concerned with proving that High and Low are related. At the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, the union is a given. Surrealist ideas have become part and parcel of everyday life; the art, while often edgy, is also self-assured. It is a recipe for a good time.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Eating Fire and Drinking Water

title: A New Generation of Deal Makers
description: A DECADE ago, it was easy to name Wall Street's top mergers-and-acquisitions specialists. They were swashbucklers who craved the spotlight, and their role in major deals was often as big as the chief executives'.

title: Trying to Relax, Drinkers Make Others Tense
description: They've been coming on Thursday nights for years, young professionals looking to unwind with a drink or two at El Rio Grande, a Tex-Mex restaurant and bar on Third Avenue. But as the crowds have swollen this summer to unprecedented size, neighbors complain that the after-work scene has gotten out of hand. And they are suing to make it stop.

title: A Life Spent In the Past, Of a Fashion
description: Senta Sundberg loves orange, her son and her cats. She has been an executive secretary and sung at Carnegie Hall. (Well, the small stage.) She never tells her age; Sundberg women never do. She's divorced. And for the last five years, she has been a real estate agent at F. J. Kazeroid Realty Group on Seventh Avenue.

title: As Art Museums Thrive, Their Directors Decamp
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Oxygen Tank Threat Seen
description: ''Bomb Alert,'' says one. ''Ground Zero'' and ''Enter Area at Own Risk,'' proclaim two others. Embedded in the front lawns of the neat homes along East 32d Street in Midwood, the brightly lettered signs are but three of eight that warn passers-by of impending disaster.

title: Declaring the Classics Very Much Alive
description: AFTER years of seasonal worrying about what to do with the Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival, Marya Martin has been persuaded, by the evidence, that continuing what she founded is worth the candle. The formula -- two weeks in August of thematic concerts with established performers and informal explanations -- satisfies her, and the audience is certainly out there. So all right, she'll head it up again.

title: Old Portugal
description: To the Editor: In his June 14 article, ''Hilltop Castles Guard the Past,'' Mitchel Levitas states that ''Portugal remains the most reluctant country in Europe when it comes to embracing modernization.'' Can he be referring to the excellent road system, the beautiful, modern tiled bathrooms found everywhere, or the pure water coming from every spigot? Could he be referring to the convenient, modern, local transportation or the fabulous and copious literature sent to us by the Portuguese National Tourist Office?

title: Hoffa Opponent Tries to Win Reform Votes
description: At first glance, Tom Leedham's race for the teamsters presidency appears pretty far-fetched. So much seems stacked against him.

title: In America; A Case Of Lies
description: The days and nights pass with excruciating slowness for Jeffrey Blake. At age 29, he has spent more than a quarter of his life in state prison. Now the man whose testimony put him in prison says he was lying all along.

description: The Pact

title: Agency Investigates Shaking Death of a Baby
description: The city's child welfare agency is investigating the circumstances that led last month to the shaking death of a 4-month-old girl who had been placed temporarily in a Queens foster home while her assigned foster mother was out of town, city officials said yesterday.

title: Banks' Obligations
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Crowd
description: FROM PLATO

title: July 26-August 1; Restricting Fraternization
description: The Pentagon is ordering the Army to restrict its policies governing dating, sexual intimacy and other close relationships between officers and enlisted soldiers. The change makes the Army's fraternization policy consistent with those already in effect in the Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps. Those services bar most personal relationships between officers and soldiers, to preserve discipline in the ranks.

description: THE BLACK FLOWER

description: To the Editor:

title: Raha Mootabar and Cameron Iraj
description: Raha Natasha Mootabar, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hamid Mootabar of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Cameron Darius Iraj, a son of Dr. Jasmin Moshirpur Iraj of Douglaston, Queens, and the late Dr. Iraj Iraj. Ahmad Pakzad, a Muslim minister, performed the traditional Persian ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan.

title: Celestial Harmony
description: The universe of ''Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus'' just keeps expanding. John Gray's 1992 self-help manual has sold 6.5 million copies and has generated audio and videotapes, a CD of love songs, a Broadway show and now a board game. (Sample question: ''Bigger is a) better; b) not better; c) who cares?'') ''You constantly want more from him,'' said Pattie Smith, a former drug counselor who owns the book, videos and board game. ''The material is like vitamins or nutrients.'' She credits the Mars/Venus philosophy -- which holds that men and women must understand the differences in how the sexes communicate -- with saving her marriage. After training at the Mars and Venus Institute in Mill Valley, Calif., she became one of 200 workshop leaders teaching the techniques. During one of the telephone interviews he schedules on a ''media day'' every two weeks, Mr. Gray, a psychologist, said, ''People call this an overnight success, but they forget I was in practice for close to 20 years before I wrote the book.'' KIMBERLY STEVENS

description: With each passing day, Grand Central Terminal is looking better than it ever has. Meanwhile, it is becoming something it never was.

description: After building a record of frustration in the United States, Moni Maker won her first Breeders Crown race yesterday, capturing the $500,000 Breeders Crown Trot at the Meadowlands.

description: TWO years ago, standing in front of houses ready to plunge into the sea, Gary A. Vegliante, the Mayor of this tiny barrier island village west of Westhampton Beach, predicted that within five years 90 percent of all the houses his community had lost to storms -- 190 out of 246 -- would be rebuilt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGOOD, CLARENCE S., M.D.
description: LIVINGOOD-Clarence S., M.D. The Department of Dermatology of Henry Ford Health System, Detroit, MI, mourns the passing of our founding chairman on July 27, 1998 at the age of 86. He was the chairman between 1953 and 1976 & was the Executive Director of the American Board of Dermatology (ABD) between 1963 and 1992. Until his current illness, he remained active in affairs of the department, the institution and the ABD. He played a pivotal role in the development of dermatology as a specialty and made numerous contributions to our specialty at the national and international level. His love and knowledge of baseball were legendary. He was well loved and highly respected by colleagues, patients and friends. We offer our deepest condolences to his children, Bill, Louise, Susan, Beth and Larry and their families. Henry W. Lim, MD Chairman Edward A. Krull, MD Chairman Emeritus Department of Dermatology Henry Ford Health System Detroit, Michigan

title: Restaurant Reviews Show Too Much Crankiness
description: The restaurant review [Dining Out] on July 19 finally moved me to complain about the reviews. Consistently, I learn a lot about what the reviewer likes to eat (broccoli rape not too bitter, sauces not too intense or thick) and very little about the restaurant. The ratings are extremely inconsistent and often do not jibe with the descriptions. The prose is infuriating. Everything is either ''sparked'' or ''touched'' or ''glossed'' or ''brightened.'' Syntax is tortured, editing is sloppy. Many descriptions of dishes are perfunctory (''Linguine with white clam sauce was as it should be'' and ''Penne filetto . . . brought the classic combination.'' Yes, but what did they taste like?) Wine is never mentioned; was there a wine list, what was it like, was the staff knowledgeable and helpful with wine and food?

title: The Street Fighter Who Galls the N.B.A.
description: Billy Hunter leaned over a conference table in a suite of Manhattan law offices one day last June and stared at David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association. With the N.B.A.'s owners threatening to lock out the players in an increasingly strained labor dispute, Hunter, the executive director of the players union, spoke with a provocative bluntness.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT; Let Oil Companies Talk to Iran
description: LEADERS in Teheran and Washington -- suspiciously, skittishly -- are inching toward normalization of relations. For the year-old Government of Iran, there is a growing awareness that the country's future lies in integration into the international community rather than in revolutionary struggle against it -- a goal that is difficult to reach without at least the acquiescence of the United States.

On these bright summer evenings, the terrace is the place to be, among the blooming, honey-scented array -- lilies, petunias, sweet william -- and looking to the tended upswept hill beyond, like a continuation of the lawn, we could be in a manor house park.

title: July 26-August 1; Justice Thomas Criticizes His Many Critics
description: Although his delivery was measured and unemotional, Justice Clarence Thomas made an extraordinary speech to a large gathering of black lawyers and judges, a group that included many of his critics. Until now, Justice Thomas had spoken only before groups carefully selected to insure their friendliness.

description: TALK about site-specific art! If you were creating a gallery installation about the marine environment, where better than in a museum in a town called Oceanville on the Jersey Shore?

title: Severe Weather Warning
description: The year 1998 may be remembered as the time when weird weather became the norm. From the storms that pounded California over the winter to the drought that fed Florida's fires this summer, the one constant of the weather has been its bizarreness. In March, New York City experienced record-tying spring heat a few days after late-season snow. Santa Barbara, Calif., received 21 inches of rainfall in February, a once-a-millennium event. Texas endured weeks of 100-degree-plus July heat, resulting in scores of deaths.

title: Sarah Bonney, Matthew Lapides

So, in 1994, the city moved peddlers into Sara Delano Roosevelt Park. But they settled in a bit too well, erecting semi-permanent structures that the city, on Thursday, began to dismantle.

Two days earlier, AT&T, the No. 1 long-distance carrier, had unveiled a $10 billion joint venture with British Telecommunications, Britain's largest phone company. description: Orchard Beach in the Bronx was reopened to swimmers yesterday after Parks Department officials determined that the water had not been contaminated by a sewage leak in Westchester County.

description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Newport'' (June 21) has many good ideas for visiting this wonderful city, but by highlighting taxi costs, car rentals and auto tours, the article encourages more traffic on already crowded streets.

description: After winning the Brickyard 400, Jeff Gordon's stock car was followed around the track by an armored truck, symbolizing the $1 million bonus he was about to receive from Winston. It was the only vehicle Gordon did not run away from today.

title: The Nation; In the Census Battle, It's Politics vs. Logic
description: FOR years, Thomas P. O'Neill's famous dictum that all politics is local has been gospel in this capital, believed in the soul, repeated early and often. But Tip O'Neill hadn't seen this year's fight over statistical sampling to augment the 2000 Census and to account for those who are generally missed by traditional head-counting methods.

title: Fans Few but Happy At Goodwill Games
description: TERESA DUKE studied a map of Long Island spread across her lap as she sat behind the wheel of her gray Mercedes in parking lot No. 6 at Eisenhower Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEHEAD, O.Z. (ZEBBY)
description: WHITEHEAD-O.Z. (Zebby), age 87. Died on July 29, 1998, Dublin, Ireland. After a short illness. Attended St. Marks School '30 and Harvard. Actor in Hollywood, in ''Grapes of Wrath, ''The Lion in Winter'', ''Ulysses'' & many other films and television productions. He worked with Henry Fonda, Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy. In 1950's joined Baha'i faith and moved to Ireland in 1963. In 1972 he was elected to the newly formed Baha'i National Assembly in Ireland and served until 1987. Author of books and essays on Baha'i faith and biography of Gish sisters. He sponsored an annual playwright competition in Ireland, and in 1965 received the Actor's Church Union Award for the Best Actor in the Dublin Theatre Festival for his performance in Eugene O'Neill's ''Hughie''. Member, Kildare Street Club in Dublin and other clubs. Baha'i funeral service and burial in Ireland on July 30.

title: Fewer Contested Races Seen in Westchester
description: A YEAR after the Westchester electorate went through one of the most highly contested elections in county history, this year's local races will for the most part be the opposite.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF; For Most Russians, Opportunity Isn't Knocking
description: WHEN I go back to Moscow I feel like Edmond Dantes, the hero of ''The Count of Monte Cristo.'' Dantes goes to Paris after two decades of imprisonment to find that friends and rivals of his youth have changed from provincial fishermen and small-time clerks into decorated generals and powerful bankers, barons and marquises -- pillars of French society.

title: Winning Stocks Are Losing Momentum
description: For stock market investors, great earnings news is no longer good enough.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Seamus Redivivus
description: Fed up with his life and the pressures of celebrity, the Irish painter Seamus Boyne fakes his own death, setting in motion a huge public outburst of adoration (including cover stories in major news magazines) and unwittingly sparking a madcap adventure in the best picaresque tradition. Seamus's 17-year-old daughter, Tory, who hasn't seen her father in years, flies from America to Dublin to attend his funeral -- and the boozy wake -- in order to make a final peace with him. Instead, the two are caught up in a hilarious, breathless ride across Ireland, pursued by mysterious kidnappers. Dick Wimmer, who created Seamus in an earlier novel, ''Irish Wine,'' has brought him back in BOYNE'S LASSIE (Zoland, paper, $12), complete with his endless thirst for Guinness, his roaring love of life and his captivating Irish brogue. Tory is no less a distinctive character, an engaging and enthusiastic match for her dad -- even when he's disguised as a monk and blasting across the countryside on his flashy American motorcycle. Their reunion brings a true reversal of fortune (and eventually reconciliation) as Tory gets under the skin of the man she has been ''creating'' in her mind ''out of newspaper clippings and magazine articles'' and a few glorious childhood memories. Wimmer is a master of voice, expertly playing Seamus's middle-aged blarney against Tory's coming-of-age bleat in this wonderful -- though teasingly short -- comic novel. Erik Burns

title: At a Camp by the Sea, Sun and Solace for Children With H.I.V.
description: Children living with H.I.V. or AIDS in New Jersey often reside in cities. To provide some respite from the burdens of the disease and urban ills, the Newark-based AIDS Resource Foundation for Children has held a seaside summer camp for five years at St. Clare's Bed and Breakfast at Gateway National Park in Sandy Hook.

title: Corrections

title: Competition And Drugs: Just Say Yes
description: Athletes have always been contemptuous of sport's attempts to regulate drug use, but they tended to keep their mouths shut. Most resented the whip hand that testing gave management, but they were too afraid of being caught, punished, embarrassed to speak up unless they were squeaky clean, retired or busted.

title: Indian Food Finds Its Way Inland
description: INDIAN restaurants in Fairfield County have been generally clustered in Stamford and Norwalk, so it is a bit of a surprise to find a new one, Sangeet, in Ridgefield.

title: July 26-August 1; Voluntary Affirmative Action
description: These days backers of affirmative action have had to find creative ways to keep the policy going. Such is the case for the Federal Communications Commission. In April a Federal appeals court struck down its requirement that broadcasters conduct special efforts to hire minorities. Last week, the F.C.C. Chairman, William E. Kennard, announced that several of the nation's largest networks, radio groups and cable companies had agreed to maintain affirmative action programs on a voluntary basis.

title: Benitez Loses Fight for Gold in New York Homecoming
description: When Roberto Benitez, a native of New York, walks the streets of Marquette, Mich., he does not see a Latin face, and there is not a Caribbean restaurant within a hundred miles. To ease his homesickness, Benitez cooks rice and beans in his dormitory and turns on merengue music.

title: Off-Road Philippines

The country's fifth-largest island, it has less than half of one percent of its population. Parts of it remained unexplored well into this century; a Stone Age tribe, the Tau't Batu, was discovered there only in 1978.

title: Bridgeport's Barriers, What Went Wrong
description: As the author and designer of the street closings in the Phoenix Project in East Bridgeport, I wish to clarify the intent of this bold effort in regard to the article ''Bridgeport Debates Its Barriers'' (July 5).

title: Does a Roach Motel Have 5-Star Potential?

Her teammates were Carol Simon and Linda Lewis, both of Las Vegas, Nev., Karen Barrett of Vancouver, Wash., and Margie Gwozdzinsky and Susan Wexler, both of Manhattan. Sounds like a great place to live and a fabulous place to visit? You bet. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATTERY, MARTIN FRANCIS

title: Votes Taken On Land, Gambling And Drugs
description: State lawmakers returned from summer recess last week to consider several bills that required action by Aug. 3 if they were to be presented to voters as ballot questions in November. title: July 26-August 1; Neglect at Nursing Homes
description: For residents of America's 17,000 nursing homes, conditions have improved since 1987, when Congress set stringent Federal standards. But in two days of hearings, the Senate Special Committee on Aging heard that the abuse and neglect of patients continue at many nursing homes. The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, delivered a harsh judgment on homes in California, nearly one-third of which have been cited for violations that could cause death or life-threatening harm. Other witnesses said they believed that similar problems existed elsewhere.

title: PULSE; Chez Goo-Goo
description: It's no secret that the desire to dine out taps into one of humankind's first and most primal urges -- the need to be fed. It makes sense, then, that one of the latest trends in the downtown restaurant world is to give establishments baby-friendly names that could have come from Dr. Seuss. There is the star-infested restaurant and lounge Moomba (133 Seventh Avenue South), not to mention bistros like Boughalem (14 Bedford Street), Po (31 Cornelia Street) and Titou (259 West Fourth Street). A typical 3-year-old would feel most welcome. The latest example is Babbo, opened last month at 110 Waverly Place by Mario Batali in partnership with Joseph Bastianich (of Becco and Frico). Babbo is colloquial Italian for daddy. Looks as if the guys who opened any of the countless Mama's Pizzas were really on to something. DANY LEVY

title: Ideas & Trends: Contagion Effect; A Guide to the Modern Domino Theory
description: IN another era, the domino theory was used to justify why America was risking lives in Southeast Asia and other battlefields of the cold war. Lose one country to Communism, and others would fall. Historians will long argue whether the theory was right, or a politically convenient fiction. But few were willing to gamble on finding out, until the threshold of national pain became too great in the rice paddies of Vietnam.

description: When HFS Inc. and CUC International merged in December to form Cendant, most of Wall Street was delighted. After all, here was a marriage of two aggressive, profitable companies that made their living on marketing acumen without having to get their hands dirty making or owning much of anything. A few lonely voices wondered whether the high value the market was putting on these two ''virtual'' companies was built more on enthusiasm than fact.

title: HIS WAY
description: (Diamond) Dayne Henry, an Oklahoma gambler who fled to Brazil after pleading guilty to tax-evasion charges in 1988, wants to go home to Muskogee, Okla., someday. In fact, he wants to be buried there, under a one-ton tombstone engraved with buxom angels, dice, a poker hand and the words: ''This is the only game I didn't win. I did it my way.'' Though left behind, Henry's loyal wife, Dourames -- who already owned the plot -- placed the stone, but the St. Joseph Catholic Cemetery Association, finding it rather unholy, wanted it removed. Dourames filed suit in July and lost and the stone was taken away. This crusade is not over, though, and it should make for a gripping test of whether. . .well, of whether Diamond can rest in tacky peace. ''We will appeal,'' says D.D. Hayes, Dourames's lawyer. ''You should be able to have what you want when you're dead.''

At the Bonnard show at the Modern the other day, the big landscapes and especially the pictures of Marthe, Bonnard's wife, looked less pretty, more audacious than I'd recalled (I'm talking about a certain simmering, subterranean emotion and weirdness of drawing). Bonnard's pictures are best when they're biggest, and when the colors buzz, and these paintings suddenly seemed wild in a way that was mildly shocking.

Also survived by brother Alfred Winograd (Betty), sister Mae Bassin, sister-in-law Rhoda Semo and brother-in-law Ronald Smith (Carole Smith). Sam was a man of peace. He was active in the World Federalist Association for over 50 years and received the Chevalier Order of the Crown from the Belgium government, their highest honor. At the center of the cross, surrounded by a cobblestone traffic circle, is a 178-foot classical column the color of heavy cream, dedicated to George Washington: the country's first Washington monument, conceived in 1809 and built between 1815 and 1829. Before we reached it, however, our guide, Jamie Hunt, ushered us into a doorway just past a row of stately, if somewhat severe, brick town houses built in the second quarter of the 19th century.

In no time this tour de force had taken on the medicinal whiff of something punishing, instead of the aura of so-called entertainment value that we associate with ''Armageddon,'' ''Deep Impact,'' ''The Negotiator'' or ''Lethal Weapon 4.''

Poetry had no real audience: the thoughtful public had been lost -- first to the novel, then to film and popular music. Those who called themselves poets had given up on life and retreated to the academy, where (to recast the old Soviet saw) they pretended to write and a handful of little magazines pretended to publish them.

title: When the Character Calls, Minnie Driver Listens
description: MINNIE DRIVER is equally at home telling an off-color joke or spelling Aeschylus correctly on a crossword puzzle, as she did recently in a rare moment of repose at a midtown Manhattan hotel. The 27-year-old British actress, who has made a career for herself in the United States in hit movies like ''Big Night,'' ''Grosse Pointe Blank'' and ''Good Will Hunting,'' displays a dizzying array of attributes: she's intellectual and earthy, statuesque and spirited. Perched on a chair with her legs tucked under her, she looks very much the rising star, with high-heeled lizard-print sandals on her feet and with her unruly ringlets pinned up in a smooth twist. But her frank personality penetrates any pose, whether it be through her irrepressible laugh, which invites complicity, or her sudden seriousness when she talks about the professional and personal tumult of the last few months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAERTSCHI, CLARA
description: BAERTSCHI-Clara. 96, of Boynton Beach, FL, mother of Claire Parssinen of Westerly, RI, died July 12, 1998, at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, FL. Mrs. Baertschi was born March 27, 1902, in Interlaken, Switzerland, the daughter of Karl and Anna Trachsel-Hofmann. She married Alfred Baertschi on May 22, 1922, in New York City. He died in 1967. Mrs. Baertschi and her husband were prominent restaurateurs who opened such restaurants as Au Petit Trianon and Chalet Suisse in New York City. During the rationing of World War II, she and her husband introduced traditional Swiss cheese dishes such as fondue and cheese and onion pie to Americans for the first time. In addition to her daughter, Mrs. Baertschi is survived by four grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. A service will be held at 3:30 PM, Tuesday, August 4, 1998, at the Greenman Memorial Chapel in Elm Grove Cemetery in Mystic, CT.

title: Editorial Observer; Connecticut Politics -- It Isn't Brain Surgery

I covered the capitol for a long time, and the only surprise I can remember was the day the State Senate, caught in a violent battle between fans of the deer and fans of the whale, dyspeptically voted to name the human being official state animal.

title: Trouble in the Other Mexico
description: The poor, heavily Indian state of Chiapas in southern Mexico is a world apart from cosmopolitan Mexico City. It is also home to the four-year-old Zapatista rebellion for Indian autonomy, land reform and a new Mexican political order. President Ernesto Zedillo has mishandled relations with the Zapatistas since peace talks collapsed in 1996, abandoning dialogue and trying to impose his own solutions. As an elected leader, Mr. Zedillo is responsible for preserving constitutional order. But he can better do so by compromise than by confrontation.

title: So Much for the Imperial Presidency
description: A quarter century ago I wrote ''The Imperial Presidency,'' which argued that the American Constitution envisages a strong Presidency within an equally strong system of accountability. When the constitutional balance is upset in favor of Presidential power and at the expense of Presidential accountability, the office can be said to become imperial.

title: TENET AND VANGUARD IN BIDDING FOR ALLEGHENY HOSPITALS
description: The Allegheny Health Education and Research Foundation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell eight hospitals in the Philadelphia area to Vanguard Health Systems Inc. for as much as $540 million as part of its bankruptcy reorganization, while leaving the door open for a rival proposal from the Tenet Healthcare Corporation. The closely held Vanguard, which is based in Nashville, would pay $460 million and could add as much as $80 million if the hospitals' earnings are better than projections. Allegheny said Tenet had also offered to buy the hospitals but without specifying a price. Allegheny agreed to complete due diligence with Tenet, which is based in Santa Barbara, Calif., so that Tenet could consider a definitive proposal. The Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh, where Allegheny is based, would have the final word on any offer. Shares of Tenet fell $1.125, to $28.8125.

title: Doctor vs. Mob in a Poisoned Environment
description: Dr. Tomas Stockmann has thrown off the last traces of self-control, and the results are not pretty. He has been addressing the citizens of the coastal Norwegian town where he has been known for years as a benevolent if eccentric physician and scholar. Yet he's unrecognizable at the moment, his features engorged with contempt, his voice loud and scalding. He has climbed a chair on the speaker's platform; he is imitating a rabid monkey, scratching himself. He is also, he makes it very clear, imitating the people who are watching him.

title: SARA LEE TO SELL THREE FACTORIES IN EUROPE
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it would sell three factories in Europe, generating $200 million in cash, as part of a plan announced last September to reduce its manufacturing base and focus on managing brands. The maker of clothing, packaged foods and body care products said it was selling two soap and lotion plants in Italy to Cover SRL, a packaging company. It will also sell an aerosol factory in Belgium to Trost Group International, one of Europe's top five aerosol-can makers. The Chicago company, which also makes Hanes underwear and Sara Lee baked goods, said it would use the proceeds to buy back shares. Its shares rose $1.9375, to $52.0625.
