title: DAMES & MOORE BUYS RADIAN FROM DOW FOR $117 MILLION
description: The Dames & Moore Group, the engineering and construction company based in Los Angeles, has acquired Radian International L.L.C. from the Dow Chemical Company for $117 million in cash, expanding its process engineering business. Radian, based in Austin, Tex., generates annual revenue of about $300 million from the engineering and construction services it sells to large companies and government agencies. The purchase, which was completed on Friday, will increase Dames & Moore's annual revenue to more than $1 billion. Dames & Moore has more than 7,800 employees at offices in more than 30 countries.

title: German Carbon Concern Has Rise in Earnings
description: SGL Carbon A.G. of Germany, the world's biggest maker of carbon and graphite products for the auto and steel industries, indicated yesterday that second-quarter profit from operations rose 13 percent. Implied profit rose to 61 million marks ($34 million), or 3.10 marks a share, from 54 million marks, or 2.64 marks a share, in the 1997 period.

title: A March for Black Youth Leads to Rising Tensions
description: At this point, the Million Youth March being organized by a former Nation of Islam official and scheduled to be held in New York City in September is only in the formative stage. But plans for the rally have already drawn concern, with city officials worried about the size of the march and some Jewish groups saying the event's organizers have a history of virulent anti-Semitism.

title: Marine Fliers Are Arraigned In Crash Case

title: By Design; Time to Put Your Foot Down
description: Flats have outpaced stilettos as the chic shoes for fall. Designers have chosen them to give a new look to this year's revival of long skirts, tacitly acknowledging that high heels are not universally popular as everyday wear.

title: Welcome to Grenada, Mr. Castro
description: A dictator who rules a country as long as Fidel Castro has governed Cuba sometimes gets to edit the history he helped create. Mr. Castro did just that over the weekend when he visited Grenada, the tiny Caribbean island the United States invaded almost 15 years ago in the name of preventing Cuban contamination in the hemisphere. Mr. Castro clearly savored the irony of his warm official greeting by the democratically elected Government of Prime Minister Keith Mitchell. He was welcomed with steel bands, a 21-gun salute and an official thank-you for Cuba's help in building the airport that Washington once viewed as a dangerous extension of Cuba's military reach into the eastern Caribbean.

description: Andy Pettitte will skip his scheduled start against the Oakland Athletics in Tuesday's doubleheader because of a muscle strain in the back of his pitching shoulder.

title: Alfred Schnittke, Eclectic Composer, Dies at 63
description: Alfred Schnittke, an iconoclastic composer who won fame in the West as he struggled against the restraints of Soviet cultural ideology at home, died yesterday at the University Hospital in Hamburg, Germany. He was 63 and lived in Hamburg and Moscow.

title: The Prosecutor Who Spoke Up
description: Democrats have added a new tactic to the campaign to protect President Clinton from an independent investigation of White House fund-raising during 1996. That tactic is to punish the truth-tellers. The victim in this tale of political revenge is Charles La Bella, who was billed as an indispensable star when Attorney General Janet Reno brought him in to direct the Justice Department's campaign finance task force. Then in April, Ms. Reno's spokesman circulated word that Mr. La Bella had done such a stellar job in getting the campaign investigation on track that he would be returning to California as interim United States Attorney for San Diego. He dreamed of permanent appointment.

description: In a strong show of partisan backing, New York Democrats running for the United States Senate and for governor voiced support for President Clinton yesterday, saying they accepted his denials of an affair with a White House intern and would be delighted if he would campaign with them for the general election this fall.

title: A Triumph for Campaign Reform
description: In the end, the numbers themselves sent the most powerful message. After a year of false promises, poison pills and delays, the House approved the Shays-Meehan bill to clean up the corrupt campaign fund-raising system by a decisive vote of 237 to 186. With 51 Republicans defying Newt Gingrich and supporting reform, the vote shattered the idea that campaign reform is a partisan issue. Also demolished were the predictions of Republican leaders and worshipers of conventional wisdom in Washington that reform was dead. The measure now stands an excellent chance of surviving the tests ahead and winning approval as the final bill.

title: Following Benford's Law, or Looking Out for No. 1

HILL asks his mathematics students at the Georgia Institute of Technology to go home and either flip a coin 200 times and record the results, or merely pretend to flip a coin and fake 200 results. The following day he runs his eye over the homework data, and to the students' amazement, he easily fingers nearly all those who faked their tosses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTNER, SYLVIA
description: ORTNER-Sylvia, widow of Melvin Ortner, her high school sweetheart, and beloved daughter of Bess Berkowitz and Mort Clyne, was born on January 8, 1910 in Far Rockaway, New York. On August 3, 1998, surrounded by her loving family, she passed gracefully away in Key Biscayne, Florida. Throughout her life she enjoyed modern and classical dance, theatre, music and art both vicariously and personally. Few people loved culture so and devoted as much time and effort to making art, dance, and music available to the community at large as did Sylvia Ortner, a founder and one of the first Presidents of the Five Towns Music and Arts Foundation. A native New Yorker, she moved to Woodmere, Long Island in the 1940's and through the Foundation brought opera divas, artists, musicians, and writers to the suburbs. For two years she studied at Teacher's College Columbia University. A lifelong educator & proponent of Progressive Education, she first worked at the Little Red Schoolhouse, then served as Principal of the Ethical Culture School, and later taught at the Brandeis School in Lawrence, Long Island. Her specialty and passion was teaching reading to the very young and instilling in them a love of books and literature. She also studied at the Traphagen School of Design and applied her talent in art and design as an interior decorator. Her homes were distinguished by their grace, beauty and truly remarkable openness. Friends, neighbors, even strangers were welcomed with enthusiasm and generosity. Her tireless energy and insatiable zest for life will be long remembered by her family and her many many friends. Sylvia never stopped learning and growing. At the age of fifty she returned to Hofstra University and took great pride in participating in graduation ceremonies & receiving her belated Bachelor of Arts. Within herself Sylvia lived with obdurate dignity in a time & place when a woman could walk down Central Park West wearing white gloves and a pearl necklace. She is survived by her two devoted children Peter Bruce and Toni Ortner and her three much beloved grandchildren: Lisa Michelle Lampe, Lian Margaret Ortner, and Katherine Mao Qun Ortner. The family will celebrate Sylvia's life on August 10th and 11th, and receive visitors at their summer cottage in Southold, New York.

title: CROWN BOOKS TO CLOSE 79 STORES AND LAY OFF 1,250
description: The Crown Books Corporation, the discount chain based in Landover, Md., said yesterday that it would close 79 of its 174 stores as soon as possible and lay off 1,250 workers as it tries to emerge from bankruptcy protection and return to profitability. Crown plans to close all of its stores in Philadelphia, Seattle and Texas but to keep a ''strong presence'' in the Washington area, Chicago, San Francisco, Los Angeles and San Diego. Pearson, which owns The Financial Times and Penguin Group, said net income for the six months ended in June rose to $:62.3 million ($101 million), or 10.8 pence a share, from $:34.4 million, or 6 pence, in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Fuddruckers Hamburger Chain Being Sold
description: Unique Casual Restaurants Inc. agreed today to sell its Fuddruckers chain of 204 hamburger restaurants to King Cannon Inc. for $43 million in cash to raise capital for its other restaurant business. Unique said the final sale price of Fuddruckers, which had $133.9 million in sales in the 1998 fiscal year, depended on its earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation, as well as its working capital on the closing date, which should be in November. Shareholders will vote on the agreement, which is expected to bring the company $33 million to $35 million after transaction costs, Unique said. Unique will take a charge on the sale because the book value of the chain is $50 million to $60 million, said Donald Moore, chief executive.

While the current Newport festival continues (ending in Los Angeles on Sept. 20), the Film Forum begins a weeklong engagement on Friday for ''Festival,'' Murray Lerner's documentary of Newport Folk Festivals from 1963 to 1966.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, MELVIN J.
description: FOX-Melvin J. On August 3, 1998. After graduating from American University with a degree in Economics in 1941, Mr. Fox worked in the U.S. Treasury & the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. In 1946, he was a founding director of the U.S. Committee for the United Nations Day, under chairperson Eleanor Roosevelt. He was a charter member of the staff of the Ford Foundation at its creation in 1951. During his 26 years with the Ford Foundation, he worked on programs related to African studies at U.S. universities and on development projects in Africa. At the beginning of his career, he participated in the first Ford Foundation mission to West Africa, and at the end he was appointed Representative for West Africa. He acted as chairman of the Center for Applied Linguistics and chairman of Mohawk Trail Concerts, and was an avid tennis player. He is loved and will be missed by his family, Jonathan, Kat, Chas, Larry, Jo, Lucy, David, Hannah, Madeline, Christina, Matt and Chris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSEN, A. WILLIAM, JR.
description: OLSEN-A. William, Jr., who led The Hotchkiss School as headmaster from 1960 to 1981, died July 30 at his home in Lakeville, Connecticut. Mr. Olsen was born in Tientsin, China, on May 15, 1921. He was the son of the late Albert W. Olsen and Gertrude Richards Olsen, and the family lived in China, where the senior Olsen was engaged in an import-export business. Mr. Olsen was graduated from The Hotchkiss School in 1939 and from Yale University in 1943, where he was manager of the Yale football team and a member of the Whiffenpoof Singing Group. He attended Columbia & received a Master's Degree in history from that university in 1948. He began his teaching career at Hotchkiss in 1945 and spent five years as a teacher of English and History at Deerfield Academy. In 1953, he returned to his alma mater to teach English and work in admissions. In 1960, he was named the sixth headmaster of Hotchkiss and presided over that instituion for the next two decades. Under his wise and careful stewardship, the School prospered and became coeducational in 1974. In addition to his wife, Jean Rohrbach Olsen, he is survived by a daughter, Liza Olsen Waters, and three grandchildren, William Doubleday Waters, James Stryker Waters, and Jessica Dann Waters, all of Andover, Massachusetts; a twin sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Olsen Horne of New London, New Hampshire, and another sister, Mrs. Sally Olsen Davis, also of New London. A 2:00 PM memorial service will be held Wednesday, August 5th at the Salisbury Congregational Church in Salisbury, Connecticut. A reception for family and friends will immediately follow the service. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Mr. Olsen may be sent to existing funds at The Forman School in Litchfield, Connecticut; The Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Connecticut; Sharon Hospital in Sharon, Connecticut; and The Berkshire - Taconic Community Foundation in Great Barrington, Massachusetts. For information, Newkirk-Palmer Funeral Home of Lakeville, Connecticut.

description: SCHEUING-Richard Woodward. Of Locust, NJ, died Aug. 2, 1998 at his residence. He retired in 1985 as executive vice president of Sabin Robbins Paper Co., Cincinnati, after 32 years. He was the originator of the ''Fleet Week'' ceremonies in New York Harbor, starting in 1988. He was the former vice president and director of the National Maritime Historical Assoc. and received several honors and awards from the association. He was former president of the New York Council of the Navy League and a former national vice president of the league. He was vice president & director of the Soldiers, Sailors, Marines and Airmen Club of New York and president of the Twin Lights Historical Society, Highlands, NJ. He was a member of the Naval War College, the Circumnavigators Club, New York; the Naval Institute, Annapolis, MD.; the Canadian Club and Metropolitan Club, New York, and the Atlantic Highlands Yacht Club. He was a World War II Merchant Marine Veteran, with the rank of Captain, and was a recipient of the Navy's Meritorious Public Service Award. He took part in the invasion of Normandy on D-Day. He is survived by his wife, Doris Cridland Scheuing. All services private. Memorial donations may be made to the Navy League of the United States Scholarship Fund, 2300 Wilson Blvd., Arlington, VA. 22201.

title: New York Times Puts An Account in Review
description: WQXR-FM and WQEW-AM in New York, the radio stations owned by The New York Times Company, placed in review their account, which has been handled since 1990 by McCaffrey Ratner Gottlieb & Lane in New York and a predecessor agency, McCaffery & Ratner. Billings were estimated at $500,000.

title: Ford July Car and Truck Sales Off 4.3% Amid Discount Curb
description: The Ford Motor Company's domestic car and truck sales fell 4.3 percent in July as lower car sales and a cutback in price discounts offset a modest rise in the demand for trucks.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CABLE DESIGN TECHNOLOGIES CORP., -- Pittsburgh, a maker of data transmission cables, acquired an 80 percent stake in HEW-Kabel, Wipperfurth, Germany, a maker of specialty cables, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Taking a Long View Of Temporal Dance
description: The performing arts program at the Walker Arts Center here is probably the largest of any museum in the country, but even so it has never tried anything like ''Life Performs Art,'' which opened on June 28 and runs through Sept. 20. Using artifacts like stage props, painted backdrops, photographs and films, music and other sound effects and, almost incidentally, videotapes of actual performances, it is essentially a retrospective of the work of three dance-based performance artists: Bill T. Jones, Meredith Monk and Merce Cunningham.

title: Too-Public Phones
description: Across the aisle from me on Metro-North one recent morning, a man was talking on his cell phone. ''Good morning, Emily, can I speak to Frank?''

title: Lawyer Wins the Battle of His Client's Life
description: IN another time and another courthouse, the conviction of a defendant on four counts of first-degree murder, and the sentencing of that defendant to life in prison without parole, would be considered something of a loss for a defense lawyer.

title: America Online Grows Despite Increasing Fees
description: Showing that a 10 percent price increase hardly dented its rapid growth, America Online said its operating earnings totaled $57.3 million for the quarter that ended June 30, a tenfold increase over the same period a year earlier. That represents operating income of 23 cents a share, exceeding the 19 cents that analysts estimated.

title: As Simple as Iced Tea: 1 Part Sugar, 1 Part Water
description: AT restaurants in the South, where iced tea is poured -- and refilled -- as freely as water, the tea is usually served sweet. Very sweet. But tastes up North are less universal, and how the tea is sweetened is usually left up to the customer.

title: Ernest Dickerman, Defender of the Wilderness, Is Dead at 87
description: Ernest M. Dickerman, who was known by the Sierra Club as ''the granddad of the Eastern wilderness'' for his efforts to persuade people to defend their forests and wilderness from the power saws and bulldozers of loggers, developers, road builders and other commercial interests, committed suicide late Friday or early Saturday at his cabin in the mountains of Buffalo Gap, Va. He was 87.

title: Leave the Oil Reserve Alone
description: Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt will announce tomorrow whether he favors opening up an environmentally fragile corner of the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska to oil exploration, and if so, under what conditions. Gov. Tony Knowles wants it opened up, as does Alaska's Congressional delegation and several big oil companies. Mr. Babbitt should say no to all of them. The area was set aside as an emergency oil reserve for the Navy in 1923, and even now is regarded under Federal law as a resource to be tapped only in compelling circumstances. With supplies plentiful and prices low, there is no reason to drill in this sensitive area or expend a resource that may be required later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSO, VITO
description: RUSSO-Vito. The Westchester Community Foundation's present and former Board Members and staff extend deepest sympathy to the family of Vito Russo. The example of his selfless generosity and concern for others and the community helped build this organization. We are not only grateful, we shall miss him.

title: Ties Strained Over Water and a Checkpoint : Malaysia's Leader Fires Hot Words at Singapore
description: KUALA LUMPU  Relations between Singapore and Malaysia  rocky during the best of times  hit a new low Tuesday as disputes over water supply to the island republic and a railway border checkpoint came to a boil.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 31 about the demolition of the actor James Stewart's house in Beverly Hills misidentified a next-door neighbor. He is Albert Hoxie, not Moxie.

title: National News Briefs; A Satellite Lost in June Is Sending Signals Again
description: A $1 billion satellite that went dead and disappeared six weeks ago while observing the sun has begun transmitting brief signals, and NASA officials said yesterday that they hoped the spacecraft could return to duty.

title: Labor Professor Free Of Defamation Suit
description: Beverly Enterprises, the nation's largest nursing home operator, yesterday withdrew its defamation lawsuit against Kate Bronfenbrenner, a Cornell University professor of labor relations. The company had accused Ms. Bronfenbrenner of slandering it last February when she called it a notorious labor law violator at a meeting in Pittsburgh organized by members of Congress.

title: Must Census Be a Divisive Wedge?; Follow the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: B.I.D. Inequality
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''All humor emanates from New York. All people in New York are funny and get funnier as they get older, and everyone outside New York gets less funny.''

title: Betting on Tomorrow
description: Like an oval gem lying in the dunes along the ocean, Monmouth Park nestles on 600 acres within sight of the Atlantic. In its 52d year, it is aggressively trying to find and cultivate people to replace the lost generation of horse racing fans. And for the sixth straight year, it seems to be bucking the national trend and succeeding.

title: Pastrami King Abdicates for Life in Manhattan
description: It's not just that Pastrami King, a classic kosher delicatessen that served as a Queens political clubhouse and courthouse maven hangout for 37 years, has shuttered its doors. The problem is that it's moving to Manhattan.

title: A Bases-Loaded Walk in the 10th Inning: Mets Will Take It
description: Lenny Harris stood outside the batter's box, reading the sign that told him to swing away on a 3-1 count and the bases loaded in the 10th inning. When the message was completed, Harris turned away from the third-base coach, Cookie Rojas, and looked for Bobby Valentine in the Mets dugout.

title: Suffolk County Ban On Smoking Is Sustained
description: A Federal judge has upheld a Suffolk County law that bans smoking in restaurants, including bars that are part of the restaurants.

title: Heat Making Illegal Border Crossings Deadlier
description: Jesus Ortiz Garcia had been stumbling all day through the sweltering mesquite scrublands north of the Mexican border, his lone liter of water long since drained. But it was not until his woozy head began to throb, his feet had blistered, his stomach had soured and he had begun to get the distinct impression that he was going blind that he decided it might be wise to turn himself in to the Border Patrol.

title: CHASE TO BUY TRUST AND ESCROW BUSINESS FROM PNC BANK
description: The PNC Bank Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its corporate trust and escrow business to the Chase Manhattan Corporation. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Under the deal, PNC said, 6,000 accounts with debt of $55 billion will be transferred to the Chase Manhattan Trust Company, a part of Chase Global Trust. PNC's corporate trust business serves as indenture trustee for municipal and corporate debt and as agent for escrow arrangements. PNC said the sale did not include its institutional trust businesses. PNC, based in Pittsburgh, is a bank holding company with $72 billion in assets. Chase, based in New York, is the nation's largest bank, with assets of $367 billion.

title: Sports of The Times; McNabb and Syracuse Aim For a New Level of Success
description: DONOVAN McNABB showed up for the Big East Conference football media day yesterday with a slightly new haircut, a distinctly new attitude and a renewed sense of mission.

title: U.S. Privatization Move Threatens Agreement to Buy Enriched Uranium From Russia
description: A $12 billion deal to turn surplus bomb uranium in Russia into fuel for American nuclear power plants is threatened by recent moves that will cut uranium prices and give Russia less revenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, MORRIS (DICK)
description: APPEL-Morris (Dick), on Tuesday, August 4, 1998. Devoted and beloved husband of Belle (Bobbie). Cherished and loving father to Albert and Robert, and evercaring and loving father-in-law and grandfather to Irena, Robin, Elliott, Alex and Nikki. He will be missed dearly. His memory will stay with us forever. Services are on Thursday, August 6, at 12 Noon, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. Funeral to follow at Beth David Cemetery, LI.

title: Charter Panel Drops Plans for Nonpartisan Elections and Full-Time Council
description: The city's Charter Revision Commission has further narrowed its focus to campaign finance reform, abandoning proposals last night for nonpartisan elections and for making membership in City Council a full-time job.

title: TV Notes; TV Chief at Miramax
description: Miramax Films yesterday named Billy Campbell, who resigned this summer as the No. 2 programming executive at CBS, as president of the newly announced Miramax Television division.

title: Thousands of Refugees Flee Serb Mountain Attack
description: Thousands of refugees, many of them children, lumbered down mountain trails in wagons and tractors and on foot today, fleeing Serbian Government forces but finding almost no place to hide in the broiling heat.

title: S.I. Teen-Ager Charged In Officer's Slaying
description: The teen-ager suspected of mortally wounding Officer Gerard Carter near a Staten Island housing project was charged with second-degree murder yesterday, a day after the slain officer's funeral.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSSETT, WILLIAM T.
description: GOSSETT-William T. The President and Trustees of Columbia University express deep sorrow at the passing of our Trustee Emeritus William T. Gossett, Esq. He generously contributed his wisdom and talent to Columbia and higher education for the advancement of human welfare and equality in America. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to Mrs. Kathryn Gossett, and their family. George Rupp, President of the University Stephen Friedman, Chair of the Trustees

title: Y.& R. Earnings And a Buyback
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York said yesterday that revenue rose 7.7 percent in the second quarter from the corresponding period a year earlier. But because of large one-time charges related to its initial public offering in May, the agency company reported a steep loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONADEO, JOHN, MD.
description: DONADEO-John, MD. The Officers and members of the New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute express their profound sorrow at the death of their esteemed colleague. He held many offices in our educational program and will be missed by generations of students. Condolences are extended to his wife Jean, his children and the rest of his family. Lester Schwartz, MD President/Society Eslee Samberg, MD President/Institute

title: 9 Held on Charges They Ran a Newark Drug Ring
description: Nine men described by law enforcement officials as members of a loosely knit heroin distribution gang were arrested by Federal agents today and charged with multiple counts of conspiring to sell narcotics from a home on a residential street in Newark, Federal and local prosecutors said.

title: Bulging Disk in Neck Stops Miller For Season and Perhaps for Career
description: Corey Miller, whose tenure with the Giants dates to his days as a backup to Lawrence Taylor, will not play this season and is on the verge of retirement after tests revealed that he has a herniated disk in his neck, an injury that caused some temporary paralysis in a practice last week.

title: Beaujolais Meant to Be Saved and Savored
description: In Georges Duboeuf's Beaujolais museum here there is a fading pre-World War I photo of mustachioed workers posing at a local manganese mine with their picks and shovels. The mine and those miners are long gone, but the manganese remains in the soil, extracted these days almost exclusively by grape vines. It is the mineral that gives long life to the most important local wine, Moulin-a-Vent, the king of Beaujolais.

title: Testimony in 1975 Murder Raises Hope of a Solution
description: In what could be a breakthrough in the investigation of a Greenwich teen-ager's murder almost 23 years ago, a man who was once a suspect testified before an investigative grand jury today in exchange for immunity, his lawyer said.

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column on Thursday, about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Charter Revision Commission, misstated the academic field of a professor hired by the commission to assess a proposal on nonpartisan city elections. The professor is a historian, not a political scientist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NYGAARD, EIGIL A.
description: NYGAARD-Eigil A. On July 25th, 1998. Retired Ambassador and Counsel General to Norway. Survived by Patricia Wilberg, Haiko Wilberg and family in Norway and Sweden. Visitation Wednesday, 4-6 PM. Services 6 P.M., at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 11403 Queens Boulevard, (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: British Petroleum Posts Drop in Net Income
description: British Petroleum P.L.C. said yesterday that its second-quarter net income fell by 26 percent, because of the recent plunge in crude oil prices to their lowest level in more than 10 years. The company said its second-quarter profit, before exceptional items, tumbled to $:542 million ($883 million) on a replacement cost basis, which takes account of the market value of oil products held in storage. The profit a year earlier amounted to $:740 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, JACK
description: SCHWARTZ-Jack. On August 4, 1998, loving husband of the late Harriet Schwartz, devoted father of Steven and Joseph, loving grandfather of Aaron, Nathaniel, Eli, Erica, Andrew, loving brother of Miriam Zimmer and Charlotte Yurman. Funeral services at Gutterman's, Woodbury, LI, Thursday August 6th at 12 noon.

title: Susan B. Anthony Marches Again, in Song
description: The tradition at Glimmerglass Opera is to balance rarities against favorites, and conventional productions against ones in which a directorial free hand can yield anything from revelatory insight to outright loopiness.

title: Liberties; DNA in the U.S.A.
description: You'd think a President in a heap of trouble about sex would not bring his motorcade to a screeching halt for an unscheduled stop-by with a blond model.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DATLOF, CLAIRE (NEE ZASLAU)
description: DATLOF-Claire (nee Zaslau). On August 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Samuel; dear mother of Dr. Steven (Diane) Datlof and Susan Datlof; sister of David Zaslau; devoted grandmother of Samuel Harrison Datlof, Nina Harrison Datlof, Andrew Malcolm Stream and Sara Elizabeth Stream. Relatives and friends are invited to graveside services Thursday, 11AM precisely, Cedar Park BethEl Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey, block 3. Family will return to the residence of Dr. Steven Datlof. Family suggest contributions in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: New Java Venture By Sun and I.B.M.
description: In a collaboration between two fierce computer industry competitors, the International Business Machines Corporation and Sun Microsystems Inc. plan to begin shipping the latest version of their jointly developed Java operating system for networked computers.

description: Forgione on His Own

title: Owners Give Grim Picture Of Impact of Taxi Rules
description: Executives of the taxi industry said yesterday that the city's strict new safety regulations had led to a drop in the price of taxi licenses and had begun to chase some drivers out of the industry.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Sunbeam and Ousted Chief Executive Sign Cooperation Agreement
description: The Sunbeam Corporation and Albert J. Dunlap, who was dismissed as chairman and chief executive of the troubled appliance maker, reached an agreement yesterday to work together to fight a string of shareholder suits against Sunbeam and to cooperate in an investigation into the company's accounting practices. Mr. Dunlap has also agreed to resign from the board.

title: TV Notes; Stern on Saturday Night
description: CBS has picked a name for the television version of Howard Stern's radio show, which is to begin running on CBS stations later this month.

title: Adidas-Salomon Posts Drop in Quarterly Net
description: Adidas-Salomon A.G., Europe's largest maker of athletic shoes, said yesterday that its second-quarter net income fell 25.1 percent as golf-equipment sales of its new Salomon unit declined in Japan and the United States. Net income fell to 46 million marks ($25.8 million) from 61 million marks a year earlier. This year's figures for the whole compared are compared with figures for Adidas alone last year.

title: Medicine Isn't Attracting Best and Brightest; Nursing Home Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Sets Deadline for Strike at Bell Atlantic
description: Unions representing 85,000 workers at Bell Atlantic have set a strike deadline for 12:01 A.M. on Sunday, threatening a job action that could inconvenience millions of consumers from Maine to Virginia by creating delays in telephone repairs and in reaching directory assistance.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the arraignment of two marines on charges stemming from the fatal air accident at an Italian ski resort last February misstated the title of Lieut. Gen. Peter Pace, who decided that the two aviators should be tried. General Pace is commander of the Marine Forces Atlantic, not commandant of the Marine Corps.

title: Some new fashion campaigns have gone retro-happy.
description: FASHION advertisements are often incomprehensible -- a pastiche of images of half-naked women, perhaps, barely interacting with the product they are supposed to be selling.

title: Hoping to Avoid Court on Switched Babies
description: For now, all the two families are swapping are baby pictures.

title: The New Line On Harbaugh: He Has a Line
description: When we last left quarterback Jim Harbaugh, he was doing his punching bag imitation in Indianapolis. It got so bad for both the 3-13 Colts and Harbaugh that the question around the National Football League was what would happen first, the Colts winning a game or Harbaugh losing a limb?

title: Of Rhythms in a Dance Before the Vibraphone
description: The vibraphonist Bobby Hutcherson loves density, and he loves rhythm. For years he has worked on a small-group model that meshes his own percussive-melodic instrument with a piano. Last week at Birdland he previewed a band representing a new variation on the concept: a quintet with the pianist Geri Allen, the bassist Christian McBride, the drummer Al Foster and, for part of the set, the alto saxophonist Kenny Garrett.

title: House Panel Threatens Reno Over Campaign Finance Inquiry
description: Attorney General Janet Reno and a House investigating committee approached a showdown today over whether she should ask for an independent counsel to prosecute campaign finance abuses.

title: Big East Conference Trying to Regain Composure
description: For Michael Tranghese, the commissioner of the Big East Conference, his job has been a test of endurance:

title: High Levels Of Pollutants Found in Mud In the Hudson
description: High levels of PCB's, cancer-causing industrial chemicals, have been found in mud at the bottom of the Hudson River near a 26-acre toxic waste site in Hastings-on-Hudson, New York State environmental officials say.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Land of Homeowners; Most Israelis Own Houses, but Oh Those Mortgages
description: Julie Zuckerman and Josh Kulp, an American couple who moved to Israel three years ago, did not know what to expect when they shopped for their first mortgage here. What they got was a dizzying education in one of the more complicated home finance systems in the developed world.

title: Monitoring Efforts Fail To Stop Baby Switching
description: Despite sophisticated systems to keep mothers and their newborn babies together, the nation's leading hospital accreditation organization said today that it had recorded three instances of baby switches in maternity wards and seven abductions in the last four months.

title: Positive Test Doubted By Free House's Trainer
description: A growing scandal involving a controversial drug has potentially ensnared one of California's leading older horses, and yesterday his trainer expressed disbelief that the horse had tested positive.

title: Students, Seeking a Leg Up, Crowd Into Summer Classes
description: Every morning inside a muggy, blue classroom a few blocks from the Williamsburg Bridge, a cluster of teen-age girls fresh from Guangdong province, China, try to wrap their tongues around the strange sounds of English. A floor above, a 17-year-old former dropout scrambles to make up for the two years that she spent working in a Chinatown beauty salon, instead of at school. Around the corner, ignoring a boom box blasting on the street below, a pair of anxious young women cram for exams that have kept them from graduating.

title: The Delights of Oaxaca: Moles and Much More
description: FOR me, one of this city's chief pleasures is the opportunity to eat really authentic ethnic food. In other cities, immigrants are usually forced to intermingle, but the geography of Los Angeles encourages people to stick with their own kind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARAH, ALBERT
description: FARAH-Albert. Age 86, of Brooklyn, NY, formerly of Englewood, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Jean (nee D'Angelo). Dear father of Albert and his wife Mildred of Haworth, NJ; Kenneth, and his fiancee of NYC. Dear brother of George of Delray Beach, FL.; Catherine of Brooklyn, & his sisterin-law, Lillian of Boynton Beach, Florida. Adored grandfather of Jeffrey, Gregory, Christopher, Caroline and David. Albert, along with his three brothers, Richard, Henry and George, they founded Loungees, a ladies' loungewear manufacturing business in Brooklyn. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Cecilia's RC Church in Englewood, NJ, Wed., 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Albert Farah Cardiology Research Fund at Columbia University, Mail Code 7718, 475 Riverside Drive, NY, NY 10115. Beaugard Funeral Home, 869 Kinderkamack Road, River Edge, N.J. 07661.

title: Suspect Is Killed by an Officer In a Drug Sting Gone Wrong
description: An undercover narcotics officer shot and killed one suspect and wounded another last night in a shootout after a ''buy-and-bust'' operation in the South Bronx went awry, the police said.

title: THE CHEF
description: AN eggplant gratin -- typically a dish with a layer of toasted bread crumbs topping softened eggplant -- is a fine enough thing. But a variation I've always preferred is one devised by Richard Olney, which features a blanket of custard in place of the bread crumbs. Now, I've developed my own version: layers of roasted eggplant that sandwich a rustic tomato and pepper confit, all covered by a saffron-scented custard.

title: Allied Signal In $9.8 Billion Hostile Bid In Electronics
description: Allied Signal, a maker of aerospace and automotive products, announced yesterday that it was starting a $9.8 billion unsolicited offer for AMP Inc., a 55 percent premium over Monday's closing price.

title: NatWest Profit Gains On Banking Business
description: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. said yesterday that its first-half profit rose a better-than-expected 46 percent on gains in British banking, private banking and venture capital. The company, Britain's third-largest bank, said its first-half profit rose to $:715 million ($1.16 billion) from $:489 million a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASSEL, CLAIRE
description: GASSEL-Claire. The congregation of the Mohegan Park Jewish Center extends its condolences to our president Philip Gassel and his family on the death of his beloved mother Claire Gassel. May God comfort them among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mohegan Park Jewish Center

title: New York Area Republicans Rebel on Campaign Limits
description: Far more than Republicans from anywhere else in the country, House Republicans from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have been bucking their party's leadership to support legislation to overhaul the way Federal elections are financed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYLE, MARIE E. (NEE RODDEN)
description: BOYLE-Marie E. (nee Rodden), 87. On August 3, 1998. Loving wife of the late James F. Boyle, caring mother of Richard J. Boyle, Eileen T. McCarthy & Kathleen O'Brien. Beloved grandmother of Ann Marie and Richard Boyle, Jr., Eric and Erin McCarthy and John, Jim and Eileen O'Brien. Visiting on Wednesday 7:00-9:00 P.M., Thursday 2:00-4:00, 7:00-9:00 PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial on Friday 10:15 AM, Our Lady of Angels RC Church, 74th Street, and 4th Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

description: SAGER-LLoyd. title: Brooklyn Man Set Wife Afire, Authorities Say
description: A Brooklyn woman was critically burned yesterday after her husband sprayed her with gasoline and set her on fire before fleeing with the couple's sons, the police said.

title: Commercial Real Estate; New Elevators Offer Shorter Waits
description: New Yorkers spend a lot of time in, and waiting for, elevators. In fact, some building managers say the most common complaint from tenants is that the elevators are too slow and that the waiting time is too long.

description: COHEN-Esther. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Esther Cohen, beloved Mother of our devoted Member and leader of Sisterhood, Maguy and Dr. Simon Naparstek. title: Iraqi Rejection Of Scrutiny Brings Rebuke From U.S.
description: Iraq's decision to go for broke and refuse to discuss any further cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors provoked a warning from the White House today that the action will only insure that Baghdad remains under sanctions indefinitely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, ROSE
description: SILVERMAN-Rose, 101. Died peacefully on August 4th. Beloved wife of the late David, adored mother of Marcia Levine, devoted grandmother of Margie & Elliot Greenberg, Howard and Julia Levine, loving great grandmother of Jason and Adam Greenberg. Service today 12 noon ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Lower Income Taxes Proposed in Japan
description: Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan proposed lowering the nation's income tax rates across the board today and said tax cuts for next year could exceed $41.7 billion, the amount Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi has pledged.

title: RECYCLING INDUSTRIES TO PURCHASE METALS BROKER
description: Recycling Industries, a metals recycling company with about $360 million in annual revenue, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Jefferson Iron and Metal Brokerage Inc. for an undisclosed price. Jefferson, based in Birmingham, Ala., has annual revenue of $170 million. The deal will allow Recycling Industries, based in Englewood, Colo., to market its products through Jefferson, which sells more than 1.5 million tons of recycled materials a year to customers including steel mini-mills and foundries. Recycling Industries produced about two million tons of ferrous materials last year.

title: New Danger to Campaign Reform
description: Only a day after campaign finance reform won approval in the House on Monday, Newt Gingrich opened a threatening new counterattack. The Speaker's latest strategy is to sideline the Shays-Meehan bill to overhaul the election fund-raising system by getting Republicans to support another bill disguised as reform but actually aimed at maintaining the corrupt status quo. If this sham legislation passes with more than the 237 votes won by Shays-Meehan, it would become the final bill approved by the House. Today we urge lawmakers not to be fooled by Mr. Gingrich's tactics and to reject his phony substitute.

title: Medicine Isn't Attracting Best and Brightest; H.M.O. Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Lolita' Defying Expectations
description: Movie studios rejected the director Adrian Lyne's adaptation of the 1954 Vladimir Nabokov classic, ''Lolita,'' because the film was too expensive, it had little star power and its potentially offensive sex-with-a-child subject matter made the two-hour-and-17-minute film commercially risky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUFTIG, MARVIN S.
description: LUFTIG-Marvin S. Beloved husband of Alice; devoted father of William Luftig, Marsha Marchwinski and Peter Luftig. Dear brother of Paul Lufitg, Nancy Rabinowitz, & Barbara Greenberg. Cherished grandfather of Jason, Kira, Daniel, Scott, Adam and Samantha. Services are today at 12 noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Vancouver: Where the Far East Now Begins
description: THE waiter leaned down, presenting a basket in which several wiggling spotted prawns, just fetched from the fish tank, were awaiting our pleasure. Did we want them cooked quickly in wine and oil? In a good Chinese restaurant, it is always best to take the waiter's hints.

title: Congo Replay
description: When rebellious Congolese troops announced their intention of overthrowing President Laurent Kabila and seized two large cities in the eastern part of the country on Monday, many people had the impression that they were reliving a familiar drama.

title: Domestic Turmoil Threatens the Land of Morning Calm
description: Min has the same problems that many young wives have dealt with. She wants a baby but can't get pregnant. She has caught her husband flirting with other women and suspects the worst. (Her best friends assure her that her husband must love her because she's terrific but suggest she try a new perfume.) And the husband won't stand up to his father, who is also his boss. Min is also Empress of Chosun, her friends are her ladies-in-waiting, it is the late 19th century, and her actions could have international consequences.

title: TV Notes; Cartoons Gaining
description: Ever since those quirky cartoon characters Chicken, Cow, Dexter and Dee Dee began appearing every weeknight, instead of once a week, the Cartoon Network's ratings have shot upward.

title: Scaffold in Times Sq. Is Carefully Taken Down
description: Workers are continuing the delicate task of dismantling the giant construction scaffold that buckled and broke in Times Square last month, killing a woman in a nearby hotel and paralyzing traffic for several days.

title: Tbilisi Journal; A Historic Trove of Houses, in Need of Handymen
description: No one here seems to know how Tbilisi's old town avoided the devastation wreaked across the Soviet Union by short-sighted planners who razed countless old neighborhoods to make way for ugly concrete apartment complexes. But survive it did, and today it is a delightful maze of cobbled streets, twisting lanes, colorful wooden facades and marvelous architectural detail.

title: INSIDE

title: The War Inside Bill Clinton

title: Journal; Get The Hook
description: Show business is a cruel business. When your act is toast, you get the hook. On the same day that Linda Tripp was giving her ''I'm just like you'' speech, bulldozers were razing O.J. Simpson's $4 million manse for its proud new owner in Brentwood. Remember when every room, every window, every pebble of gravel on that estate was diagrammed in magazine spreads, on Web sites and in the wall-to-wall jurisprudence of Court TV? Now its final destiny as just another L.A. teardown barely merited a media mention, let alone a sentimental sigh. The O.J. soap opera had long since been canceled, so the house was just another set being struck. Unburdened by memory, America, once bored, is always on to the next good show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEARNS, MALCOLM, JR.
description: STEARNS-Malcolm, Jr. Of Haddam, CT and Point 'O' Woods, NY, beloved husband of Julia Black Stearns. Died suddenly, Saturday, August 1, 1998, at Point 'O' Woods at the age of 80. The proud father of Martha K.S. Patrick, Sarah M. Stearns, Ann S. Pardun, Amanda S. Merullo, and Jennifer S. Mottur, he also is survived by his four sons-in-law, Robert Patrick, Gary Pardun, Roland Merullo, and Thomas Mottur; four grandchildren, Jessica Patrick, Rebecca Pardun, Zachary Pardun, and Alexandra Merullo, and his brother, John P. Stearns. Born October 28, 1917, to Malcolm and Annis Stearns, he graduated in 1939 from Amherst College, served in the U.S. Navy in WWII, and retired with the rank of Captain from the Naval Reserves. After seven years teaching at Wesleyan University & ten years at Pratt and Whitney Aircraft, in 1965 he turned his avocation into his vocation by becoming a Fine Arts dealer, developing renowned expertise in Georgian silver, under the name of Hobart House. A passionate supporter of many people, communities, and causes, he gave generously of his time and resources. His spirit and enthusiasm are a legacy to all that knew him. In lieu of flowers, gifts in his memory may be made to The First Congregational Church of Haddam, The Church at Point 'O' Woods, or a charity of your choice. A memorial service will be held Sat., Aug 8, 1998, at 5 PM at Point '0' Woods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLAR, MARIA LEIPER
description: MILLAR-Maria Leiper. Of Meriden and Hanover, N.H. died July 16, 1998 in Lebanon as the result of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. She was born in Pennsylvania in 1906 and graduated with honors from Vassar College. She wrote advertising copy for Macy's in New York, and Bamberger's in Newark, N.J. and for 30 years was Senior Editor for Simon and Schuster where she was responsible for such titles as Einstein's ''Evolution of Physics'', ''Stories of Langston Hughes'', the early books of Rachel Carson, and Mary McCarthy, Josephine Johnson's Pulitzer Prize-winning, ''Now in November'', and a collection of hymns that bears her name. She is listed in ''Who's Who of American Women'', ''World's Who's Who of Women'' and ''The Dictionary of International Biography''. She was a lifetime member of the Appalachian Mountain Club where she was known as a highly accomplished rock climber. A cliff she pioneered in the Shawangunk Range is known as the Maria Route. She also led an expedition in the Canadian Rockies which reached a higher point on Mount Confederation than had been achieved in earlier attempts on that peak. Her husband of fiftyfour years, David Millar died in 1987. She is survived by a sister, Margaret Gibson of Chatham, MA. At Mrs. Millar's request, there will be no funeral service.

title: The Peach's Progress to Culinary Stardom

And yet there is a long and honored tradition in which the peach plays a leading role in savory courses -- and until you've grilled one, we swear, you'll never know what you've been missing.

title: Opening in Fits and Starts, and a Little Sounding Like a Lot

In Morton Feldman's ''Viola in My Life I,'' content is emptied to a wisp, but some wisp. Contrariwise, David del Tredici's ''Haddock's Eyes'' yatters away excitedly on an elementary tune made of upward and downward scales. Michael Torke changes just the endings of phrases in his rock riff ''The White Pages.'' Fred Lerdahl, in his ''Fantasy Etudes,'' changes the beginnings as well, to make a fluent and fluid stream of music emerging from the fits and starts with which it opens.

title: Making The Sweet Stuff In a Rolls
description: ICE cream makers are one of the few categories of kitchen equipment that come in a range as vast as that of cars does, from the Hyundai to the Rolls. There's the Donvier Hand-crank Ice Cream Maker ($50), a small device that will get you to ice cream bliss eventually. The one-and-a-half-quart container must be frozen overnight and cranked by hand. A step up is the White Mountain Ice Cream Maker ($199.95), which, though electric, makes ice cream the old-fashioned way with crushed ice and rock salt -- but you do get more ice cream, about four quarts. And many swear by the Williams-Sonoma Ice Cream Maker, a heavy machine with a self-contained refrigeration unit that whips together a quart and a half in 25 minutes. It costs $429.

Storage Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Columbia, Mo., owned 187 self-storage centers as of Dec. 31. Its shares rose 25 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $22.50. title: DUANE READE AGREES TO ACQUIRE ROCK BOTTOM STORES
description: Duane Reade Inc., the largest drugstore chain in New York, said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Rock Bottom Stores Inc., another drug retailer, for about $61 million in cash. Rock Bottom, with stores in Queens, Brooklyn, Staten Island and Nassau and Suffolk counties, had about $225 million in sales in the year that ended in January. title: BANK OF NEW YORK PLANS TO BUY 80% OF EVEREN CLEARING

Under the agreement, Everen Clearing will be merged into BNY Clearing Services, a newly formed entity. The seller, the Everen Capital Corporation, based in Chicago, will retain a 20 percent stake in BNY Clearing Services. Bank of New York said BNY Clearing Services would keep its headquarters in Milwaukee and added that no staff reductions were planned. Everen Clearing processes trades for Everen Capital's Everen Securities Inc., a brokerage firm.

title: Stretching and Shrinking to Meet the Music's Needs

Like most ensembles of its kind, it draws on a large pool of freelancers, most of them young enough to have grown up during the early-music movement's current period of commercial and artistic assertiveness. And in keeping with the period instrument world's unspoken doctrine of elasticity, it expands to Romantic orchestral proportions and shrinks to Baroque chamber orchestra size as the repertory demands.
