description: Indonesia and Portugal announced today that they had agreed on the broad outlines of an autonomy plan for the disputed territory of East Timor that would give the Timorese the right to local self-government and control of educational and cultural affairs.

title: Musicians and Listeners Find Each Other on Web Pages
description: PETER MALICK has been playing blues guitar and recording since the 1960's. He started out as a member of the psychedelic-era band Listening, then carved out a larger reputation as lead guitarist for the James Montgomery Band. He sank into heroin addiction in the 1980's; during his recovery, he discovered computers and the Internet.

title: Web Shopping Tangles
description: To the Editor:

title: Can U.S. Insure Medical Privacy?; Viagra vs. the Pill
description: To the Editor:

title: Zyman Joins Board Of Launch Media
description: Sergio Zyman, the former senior vice president and chief marketing officer at the Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta, was named to the board of Launch Media Inc. in Santa Monica, Calif., a new media entertainment company specializing in music.

title: 300-Booth Pavilion to Be Built To Add Space to Javits Center
description: With its expansion plans stuck in a deadlock between the Governor and the Mayor, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center has accepted a private company's offer to erect a temporary structure to help fill an urgent need for more exhibition space, officials said yesterday.

title: Desert Designing: Start With Red
description: When Ricardo Legorreta, the Mexican architect known for sculptural designs saturated with color, was chosen to design the Visual Arts Center at the College of Santa Fe, N.M., he knew exactly where to find his palette. He went to the desert, where he saw the red rocks and the dazzling shifts of color in the sky, from pink to purple to blue to charcoal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEARNS, MALCOLM JR.
description: STEARNS-Malcolm Jr. The Art & Antique Dealers League of America mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Malcolm Stearns Jr. of Hobart House whose sage counsel enlightened us all. The League wishes to express its sympathy to his family.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: COOPER DISCLOSES BUYBACK AND FATE OF AUTO PARTS UNITS
description: Cooper Industries said yesterday that it planned to buy back as much as $500 million in stock and to register to sell as much as 19 percent of its auto parts business in a stock sale as it focuses on selling electrical products and hardware. The Houston-based company, which makes Champion spark plugs, said the buyback would be completed before it finished a sale or public offering of its auto parts units. Cooper said in April that it was considering options for the business. Its shares fell $3.0625, or 6 percent, to $48.0625, partly because yesterday's announcement ''raises an element of doubt about an outright sale,'' said Jeffrey Sprague, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.

title: Web Shopping Tangles
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach Browns? Seifert Says No
description: Just as George Seifert's new career as a studio analyst for ''The N.F.L. Today'' on CBS is beginning, the former San Francisco 49ers coach has to fend off the notion that he may become the coach of the new Cleveland Browns.

title: A Half-Million Pictures to Beautify Your Words
description: Bill Gates has established himself as the Lorenzo de' Medici of digitized art through his privately held company, the Corbis Corporation, which has amassed the rights to 23 million images and photographs. Now, through a partnership with Compaq's Alta Vista search service, Mr. Gates is throwing open the gallery doors to the public.

title: Phone Lines, and Lines and Lines, Keeping Their Appeal
description: CALL it phone-line meltdown, if you will; consumers know it well. It's that angina-inducing moment when an avalanche of both voice and data transmission needs threaten to turn your single, humble phone line, as well as your patience, into a pile of ashes.

title: Summer, and Working Is Easy; Nation's Resorts and Parks Are Feeling the Labor Pinch
description: Sonji Thomas of Kingstree, S.C., started working at the Pavilion Amusement Park in this popular beach resort in late May, after finishing her junior year at Columbia College, a small liberal arts school in this state's capital.

title: Small Stockholders Again Refuse to Panic
description: Jean Taranto isn't the kind who frets over a gyrating stock market. Prices go up and down, sometimes violently, but the American economy appears to be as strong as ever, she says. All that is to say that the stock market selloff Tuesday, which saw the Dow Jones industrial average plunge 299.43 points, is just one of the things investors must get used to.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; Reincarnation: A Restored Path to Inner Peace
description: IN 1960, John P. and Jean Humes returned from a trip to Japan with a life-size, made-in-Japan teahouse. They erected it by an existing pond on their property here and cut paths through the woods to it from their house above. Pretty and unremarkable, the garden at first must have been like many similar installations -- static, postcard-like copies of Japanese, French or Italian gardens tucked into the corners of the private estates on Long Island's North Shore, its Gold Coast.

title: Sex Shops Try to Obey Law, as Written
description: Despite a string of resounding legal victories by the Giuliani administration in its effort to curb New York City's sex industry, the vast majority of 144 adult video stores and strip clubs singled out by a new anti-sex shop law are investing their hopes in a novel legal strategy that a State Supreme Court Justice could either bolster or dismiss in a hearing in Manhattan today.

title: ABC and ESPN Make a Dual $600 Million Bid to Acquire N.H.L. Television Rights
description: Despite falling ratings for National Hockey League telecasts, ABC and ESPN have mounted a combined $600 million bid for broadcast and cable television rights for five years to start in 1999, said executives involved in the talks.

title: Believe It Or Not! Marino On the Run
description: No need to rub your eyes and blink this fall. Believe it. The most productive passer in National Football League history will be quarterbacking a run-oriented offense.

title: You're on Candid Camera. Pay Up.
description: DRIVE aggressively on the Beltway, Interstate 495, north or east of Washington, and a computer-operated radar gun and camera will single your car out; the computer will look up the registration and send a warning letter to the owner. A Maryland state trooper may watch, too, but the system can operate on its own.

title: Todor Zhivkov Dies at 86; Ruled Bulgaria for 35 Years
description: Todor Zhivkov, the Communist ruler of Bulgaria from 1954 until his ouster in 1989, died on Wednesday in Sofia, the capital. He was 86.

title: In Boston, All Roads Lead to Museums
description: Boston, the ''Athens of America'' a century ago, is called the Hub by its current residents. Certainly in terms of art, the moniker is apt. Museums abound, large and small, old and new, independently run or affiliated with colleges. Some are in the heart of the city; others form a bright constellation across the surrounding countryside. At this time of year, most are conserving energy for the season ahead, and big-effort shows are at a minimum. But summer downtime is always a good time for a museum visit. The atmosphere has a casual, ''glad to be in the shade'' feel. Permanent-collection galleries are uncrowded and inviting. And exhibitions that are low on buzz but packed with ideas have a chance of getting the attention they deserve.

title: 3 New Cable Channels
description: Three new 24-hour cable television channels in the New York area made their debut on Wednesday, offering viewers tips on where to find the best bagels, a tour of the Bronx with Robert Klein, the comedian, and local traffic and weather reports.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: You have probably heard that Michael Jordan has finally, after many delays, opened a steakhouse in Grand Central Terminal. You have probably also heard that David Rockwell, who is responsible for some of the city's glitziest restaurants (Nobu, Monkey Bar, Payard Patisserie), designed it. Given all that, you probably do not expect what you will find.

title: Do We Expect Moral Leadership From a President?
description: To the Editor:

title: United Healthcare Takes a $900 Million Charge
description: Proving that few, if any, companies are immune to the financial perils facing health care providers, the United Healthcare Corporation, one of the nation's largest health maintenance organizations, said yesterday that it was taking a $900 million charge in its second quarter, in part to abandon unprofitable Medicare plans.

title: Trainer's Dream: Sweep in Hambletonian
description: Chuck Sylvester, a horseman for 30 years, has been living in a dream world since last Saturday, when all four horses he entered in the eliminations qualified for tomorrow's $1 million Hambletonian, the first leg of trotting's triple crown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMMEN, JACK
description: KAMMEN-Jack. On August 5, 1998 of Teaneck. Beloved husband of Olive Kammen (nee Miller). Devoted father of Richard and Michael Kammen, Cynthia Waldemar, and the late Lisa Kammen. Cherished grandfather of 6 grandchildren. Funeral Service Saturday 10 AM at the Volk-Leber Funeral Home, Teaneck, NJ. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery, Hackensack. Visiting Friday 2-4 & 7-9pm.

title: Jack Brickhouse Dies at 82; Colorful Chicago Broadcaster
description: Jack Brickhouse, whose avuncular cheer and exuberant storytelling imbued his calls of more than 5,000 Chicago Cubs and White Sox games, died of cardiac arrest at St. Joseph Hospital in Chicago yesterday, said a spokeswoman. He was 82.

title: Can't Sing? No Problem. How About Safecracking?
description: There's a difference between foolish and funny.

title: Bach, Tangos And the Beach
description: The Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival, which opens its 15th season this weekend at the Bridgehampton Presbyterian Church, was started for reasons that were entirely noncommercial but sensible nonetheless. Marya Martin, a flutist from New Zealand who settled in Manhattan, and Ken Davidson, who ran his own investment company, had recently married, and Mr. Davidson was dismayed by the prospect that Ms. Martin would be spending her summers traveling the festival circuit while he worked in the city and spent weekends on his own in the Hamptons.

title: Sports of the Times; Yanks Chase The Ghosts Of 1906 Cubs
description: THE Yankees aren't playing against other American League teams anymore. For the rest of the season, they'll be playing the ghosts of a team that existed nearly a century ago.

title: Man Who Burned Wife Is Charged With Murder
description: Jennifer Corbin, a 28-year-old Midwood, Brooklyn, woman who the police said was sprayed with flammable liquid and set on fire by her husband, died at 4:45 P.M. Wednesday at Staten Island University Hospital, city officials said.

title: Sex, Honor and Grade Point Averages
description: Somer Chipman and Chasity Glass have achieved the kind of academic success in high school that is often a passport to membership in the National Honor Society. Yet neither of these 17-year-olds made the cut at Grant County High in Williamstown, Ky. Both are teen-age mothers, apparently a disqualifying factor for the selection panel. Its decision was misguided.

title: Foreign Economic Warning Hurts American Express
description: Nervous investors drove shares of the American Express Company down 6.8 percent yesterday after the company warned that its growth overseas would be hampered by the Asian financial crisis and by a softening of the global economy.

title: Worldcom's $6.1 Billion Sets Record
description: Worldcom Inc. sold a record $6.1 billion of bonds yesterday, attracting good demand in an otherwise choppy and worried corporate bond market. The money will help pay for Worldcom's acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation.

title: Cox's Temper Masks Good Side of Player
description: The problem with Bryan Cox, now a linebacker with the Jets, is that over the years he has been his own worst enemy. Reporters love to chronicle players with big mouths who say obnoxious things, make obscene gestures to fans and tell the commissioner he knows what he can do with his fines. Even if you act like the pope off the field, that image of a chronic bad boy is forever forged by the media if you constantly act the fool on the 50-yard line.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: TOSHIBA CLASSIC

title: State Considering Toll Increase For Atlantic City Expressway
description: State transportation officials announced today that they are considering a proposal that could result in the first toll increases on the Atlantic City Expressway in almost 30 years, and that they might double tolls for drivers who pay in cash.

title: 7 Arrested in U.S. Effort to Stop Cuban-Cigar Sales
description: Taking aim at outlaw cigar aficionados, Federal officials have charged the operators of an upscale restaurant and a private club in Manhattan with selling illicit Cuban cigars to customers, and yesterday four other men were also arrested on cigar-related charges.

title: Americans Fish as Resentful Canadians Observe a Salmon Ban
description: In a routine year for the Lax Kw'alaams Indian tribe led by Don Reynierse, the sight of salmon boats on the icy north Pacific at the beginning of salmon fishing season would be cause for good cheer.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA STOCK UP 14% ON NEWS OF TCI ORDER
description: Scientific-Atlanta Inc. said yesterday that Tele-Communications Inc. had ordered ''substantial quantities'' of advanced digital-cable control boxes, with deliveries to begin later this year. Terms of the contract, the first that TCI, the second-largest United States cable-television operator, has placed with Scientific-Atlanta, were not disclosed. Scientific-Atlanta's shares rose $2.9375 each, or 14 percent, to $23.9375. The Explorer 2000 set-top box, which TCI initially plans to distribute in Salt Lake City, can handle interactive applications for consumers, including Internet access, video on demand and electronic banking. They also can provide telephone service using the Internet.

title: Green Lashes Out at Schumer and Ferraro
description: Throwing an elbow into what has been a subdued and mannerly Democratic Senate primary, Mark Green assaulted both his rivals for the Senate nomination yesterday, criticizing Geraldine A. Ferraro as bereft of ideas and Representative Charles E. Schumer as a career politician who will do anything it takes to be elected.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LISKIN, ELLIOT
description: LISKIN-Elliot. August 7th. The warmth of his laughter, his wisdom, vitality, integrity, loving ways and ''The memories linger on.'' Grandchildren, Children, Joyc

title: A Room Full of Swinging Chatterboxes
description: The trombonist Wycliffe Gordon's first set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night was a big conversation. The drummer of Mr. Gordon's group, Alvester Garnett, likes to interact. So for all the soloists, Mr. Garnett tapped away, using brushes or rim shots or the sharp hiss of his snare drum to prod the improvisers into talking. And Mr. Garnett played quietly: the show took on intensity from the interaction, and from the swing.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Paul DickersonAmerican Fine Arts22 Wooster Street SoHo Through Sept. 3

title: Love Songs And Other Delights From Brazil
description: Pop needs popularizers, the musicians who pull lesser-known idioms into the mainstream. But the most effective popularizers end up making themselves obsolete; once they've made clear that a style is accessible, listeners can go to the source and skip the middleman. In the 1960's, Sergio Mendes prolonged America's affection for the bossa nova by meshing Brazilian rhythms with songs like ''Fool on the Hill'' and ''The Look of Love.'' More recently, on albums including ''Brasileiro'' (Elektra) and ''Oceano'' (Verve Forecast), he has drawn his material from Brazil's best songwriters. That makes Sergio Mendes and Brasil '99, who opened a five-night stand at the Blue Note on Tuesday night, a pleasant cover band with a sure-fire repertory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, JEAN FAIR.
description: MITCHELL-Jean Fair. On August 5, 1998 at the age of 88. The Brearley School community mourns the loss of our former Head of the School who served from 1947-1975. She will be remembered with respect and admiration for her wisdom and devotion to Brearley. In keeping with Miss Mitchell's wishes, there will be no funeral service, but there will be an appropriate occasion in the fall for her friends to pay tribute to her. Gifts in Miss Mitchell's memory may be made to the Jean Fair Mitchell Fund, a discretionary fund for the Head of the School, or to the Jean Fair Mitchell Scholarship Fund at The Brearley School, 610 East 83rd Street, New York, NY 10028.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, PHYLLIS F.
description: CANTOR-Phyllis F. The Board and Staff of the Educational Alliance deeply mourn the passing of Phyllis, beloved wife of Richard A. Cantor. The Cantors rose above their personal ordeal to recognize and generously support the plight of those less fortunate older New Yorkers served by the Alliance. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Richard and the entire Cantor family.

title: Holmes Still Sees Dollar Signs
description: Larry Holmes has a saying that traces back to growing up in poverty with 11 siblings in Cuthbert, Ga.: the shade of a toothpick is better than the boiling hot sun.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose against the yen for the first time in three days amid doubts that proposed tax cuts would pull Japan out of its slump. In New York, the dollar traded at 144.38, up from 143.86 on Wednesday.

title: SEAGATE TO TAKE A CHARGE AFTER CO-FOUNDER RESIGNS
description: Seagate Technology Inc., the world's largest maker of computer disk drives, said yesterday that its co-founder Alan F. Shugart had resigned from its board in a separation agreement that will result in a charge of $8 million to $10 million this quarter. Details were not disclosed, and Mr. Shugart said he could not comment because of a confidentiality clause. Two weeks ago, Seagate removed Mr. Shugart, 67, as chairman and chief executive in a bid to revive the struggling company. The president, Stephen J. Luczo, 41, was promoted to replace him. The shares of Seagate, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., rose $2.5625, to $24.5625.

title: Kanell Expecting A Hefty Raise
description: Danny Kanell said he is confident as he prepares for the Giants' preseason opener Saturday against the Bengals. The Giants will make a statement about their confidence in Kanell next week when they plan to begin serious negotiations that should yield Kanell a new, and far more lucrative, contract.

title: Helena Rubinstein Plans Store in SoHo
description: The venerable cosmetics company Helena Rubinstein, which vanished from the United States a decade ago, is making a comeback. The company plans to open an 8,000-square-foot store and spa in SoHo in January, company executives said this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACER, LILLIAN
description: RACER-Lillian. Age 84. Passed away on August 1, 1998, after an extended illness. Devoted wife of Max Racer, beloved mother of Marilyn Bartlett. Funeral held August 4. Burial at New Montefiore Cemetery, L.I. Loved by all who knew her. Hers was the passing of a great soul. Memorial contributions may be made to Jewish Women International, Residential Treatment Ctr of Israel, 1828 L St NW, Ste 250, Washington, DC 20036

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, ANN S.
description: STEIN-Ann S. On August 5, 1998. Of Cupertino, Ca., formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Wife of the late Richard J. Stein, mother of Diane Greenberg and Sally Stein, grandmother of Sarah and Sophie Greenberg; Barnard College '36; Research Assistant, New York Medical College and Margaret Sanger Research Bureau; Past President, Westchester Chapter, Archaeological Institute of America; dedicated voluteer at Westchester Residential Opportunities. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Federation of Jewish Philanthropies & Barnard College.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the rebellion in Congo misidentified the organization that a rebel leader, Arthur Zaidy Ngoma, once worked for. It is the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, not the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: Takeover Rumors Send Olivetti Shares Higher
description: The shares of Olivetti S.p.A. surged yesterday for a third day on talk that British Telecommunications P.L.C. or another foreign rival was plotting to acquire the Italian telephone and office equipment company. The stock gained 34 lire, to 3,929, yesterday and has climbed more than 7 percent since Monday's close.

title: Region Gains Jobs, but Gap in Incomes Widens
description: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut continue to benefit from robust job growth, but the income gap has widened sharply between the highest- and lowest-paid workers, according to two reports released yesterday.

title: *** Restaurants
description: With the closing of Daniel last week and the departure of Gray Kunz from Lespinasse, New York quickly lost two of its six four-star restaurants. Luckily, more than two dozen three-star restaurants -- merely excellent rather than extraordinary -- remain open, including these 12. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, JOAN
description: FOX-Joan. On August 5, 1998 after an extended illness. Beloved mother of Christine, Warren and Antonia. Widow of Walter J. Fox. Memorial service Monday, August 10, 1998, 11:00AM, St. Vincent Ferrer, 66th St and Lexington Ave.

title: TNT Prepares a Smashing Debut
description: If the top three fighters on the six-bout card do what they are supposed to do, then TNT's inaugural boxing show on Sept. 22 at the Theater in Madison Square Garden will be dynamite.

title: Chrysler's Chief Will Fare Quite Well in Daimler Merger
description: Whether the merger of Chrysler and Daimler-Benz succeeds or not, Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, is guaranteed to do well, documents released by the companies showed yesterday.

title: Todi Journal; For a Happy Few, the Hamptons With Castles
description: Amid rolling hills, olive groves and sunflower fields, only the glint of aquamarine swimming pools hints that this ancient countryside, long ruled by princes and Popes, has new landlords.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNGDAHL, C. RICHARD.
description: YOUNGDAHL-C. Richard. Of Tequesta, Florida. Formerly of Short Hills, NJ, August 6, 1998. Husband of Catherine Youngdahl (nee Mason), father of Carl R. Youngdahl Jr of Bloomington, Minn, Lee R. Youngdahl (Joan) of Short Hills, NJ, John M. Youngdahl (Catherine) of Summit, NJ, Karen E. Youngdahl of Allentown, PA, and Ann Youngdahl Weber (Greg) of Sioux Falls, SD. Brother of Eileen Youndahl Gunberg (Edwin) of Charlottesville, VA. Also survived by 8 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Monday, August 10, 1998 at 1PM, from St John's Lutheran Church, 587 Springfield Avenue, Summit, New Jersey. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations in his name may be made to Good Shepherd Home, 6th and St John's Streets, Allentown, PA, 18103. For information, contact William R Dangler Funeral Home, Summit, NJ.

title: A.W. Olsen Jr., Hotchkiss School Headmaster, 77
description: A. William Olsen Jr., whose more than two decades as headmaster of the Hotchkiss School brought coeducation and robust expansion to that preparatory boarding school in Lakeville, Conn., died July 30 at his home in Lakeville. He was 77.

title: Handpicked G.O.P. Candidate Drops Out
description: The Republican nominee for state comptroller, part of what Gov. John G. Rowland has touted as his ethnically diverse, handpicked ticket, withdrew his candidacy today amid concerns about his involvement in a bank fraud case in Puerto Rico, a partially falsified resume and his lateness in paying Federal income taxes.

title: SEAGRAM TO SELL ITS STATE IN FRENCH FASHION HOUSE
description: The Seagram Company agreed yesterday to sell its majority stake in Herve Leger, a French fashion house, to the closely held BCBG Max Azria, a maker of men's and women's clothing, for an undisclosed price. The sale by the Seagram subsidiary G. H. Mumm & Compagnie of Paris will allow Seagram to focus on its entertainment and liquor businesses. The sale follows Seagram's agreement last month to sell its Tropicana juice unit to Pepsico Inc. for $3.3 billion to help finance its planned purchase of Polygram N.V., the world's largest music company. Shares of Seagram fell 75 cents, to $34.1875.

title: Stock Options at Hughes
description: The Hughes Electronics Corporation said today that it was giving about 14,000 employees stock options to promote teamwork after its reorganization into a communications company by its parent, the General Motors Corporation. Hughes, the provider of the 185-channel DirecTV television broadcast system, will give employees the chance to buy 100 Hughes shares at $43.56, or the average of today's high and low share price. Employees cannot exercise the options for two years.

title: Rural Tent Revivals in an Urban Setting; Shouting Congregations Evoke Rousing Gatherings of the South
description: By the time the Rev. Dr. John H. Boyd Sr. stepped up to the pulpit beneath his gospel big top the other night, his audience had already been on its feet for some time, swaying to the music that pulsated from towering stacks of loudspeakers.

title: Sunbeam Says It Might Adjust Financial Results Back to 1996
description: The Sunbeam Corporation said yesterday that it would have to restate last year's financial statements and possibly the results for 1996 and the first quarter of this year as well, because of possible accounting irregularities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, RAYMOND J.
description: WALSH-Raymond J. On August 5, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Nora. Devoted father of Raymond J. Jr., Christopher J., Patrick C. Walsh and Claire T. Davies. Also survived by twelve grandchildren and one great-grandson. Reposing at the McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains on Saturday 2-4 PM and Sunday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial on Monday at 11 A.M., Our Lady of Sorrows Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: A Dramatic Interplay of Video and Real Imagery
description: Using the pompous title ''European Perspectives on the Media Arts,'' the Guggenheim Museum's SoHo branch has ushered in a series of shows that focus on ''media art practices'' in Europe, exploring the work of key artists in the field. Fabrizio Plessi, an Italian known for his large video installations, inaugurates this new series, and this show is his New York debut as well. Despite the unpromisingly academic title of the series, Mr. Plessi gets it off to a lively start.

description: WINTMAN-Abraham. Congregation Orach Chaim expresses profound sorrow to our dedicated member & trustee Sandra Welkes on the loss of her distinguished father, a true son of his people. We extend heartfelt condolences to her mother, brother and entire family. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Michael D. Shmidman, Rabbi Wolf Scheck, Pres.

title: Is a Dead Rat an Omen Or Just a Dead Rodent?
description: Except for the killing of a large rat, almost nothing happens in Jesse Peretz's somnolent, richly atmospheric debut film, ''First Love, Last Rites,'' which is set in the Louisiana bayou country at the steamy height of summer. That rat, of course, has to carry a lot of symbolic weight.

From 1975-1983, Kirk was General Manager of Norwegian America Line's North American operations. In 1985 he became Executive Director of Loews Corporations' Grande Collection of Hotels. In 1987 he was named President, Society Expeditions Cruises, Seattle. He remained an active industry consultant, developing plans for a new concept in cruise sales. Family and friends from around the world greatly mourn his passing.

Gates, and 16 other executives available for pretrial depositions that last as long the Justice Department deems necessary.

description: As investors watch CNBC for the latest update on the volatile stock market, Prudential Real Estate is aiming at that affluent audience by advertising a $3.5 million luxury home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, ROBERT J.

title: Faces Watch Over Park
description: The now obscure figure of Roscoe Conkling (below) strikes a heroic pose at the southeast entrance to Madison Square Park. In palmier days, Conkling was a silver-tongued Republican orator who bestrode New York state politics in the Gilded Age. The six-acre park, bordered by Fifth and Madison Avenues and stretching from 23d to 26th Street, is overlooked by the venerable Flatiron and Metropolitan Life buildings. With a slight leap of the imagination, a visitor can go back to an earlier era. The people in the park are an unassuming lot, 9-to-5'ers out for a smoke, men killing time on benches. Although the grass has been reseeded, there is something scruffy, even Hopper-esque, about the place. Keeping Conkling company in a southward vigil are other bronzed shades: Adm. David Farragut, who captured New Orleans for the Union during the Civil War; William Seward, Lincoln's Secretary of State, who is perhaps enjoying a last laugh over his ''folly'' of purchasing Alaska, and the dapper, mutton-chopped Chester Arthur, the 21st President. The park seems to have been passed by in the city's rush north, and that makes it a fitting place to evoke a quieter day.

He veered smoothly away from politics into typical Seinfeld territory, wryly observing the manners and absurdities of contemporary life. ''Everyone lies about sex,'' he said. ''People lie during sex. If it weren't for lies, there'd be no sex.''

title: House Gives Assent On Election Finance
description: In a final rebuke to its Republican leaders, the House concluded months of struggle and approved a bipartisan bill to overhaul the way the nation's political campaigns are financed. The vote, which was stronger than a preliminary one earlier in the week, shifts the spotlight on the subject to the Senate.

title: BASEBALL: Taking Irabu at His Word; Yankees' Interpreter Is Translating a Season to Remember
description: George Rose drove through the stoplight-infested streets of Tampa, lost and unsure and wondering how angry his large passenger would get. Hideki Irabu had a dentist appointment on this February day in Florida, and Rose, the new interpreter for the Yankees pitcher, was now more than an hour late and wondering if Irabu would be upset.

title: Do We Expect Moral Leadership From a President?; Above Reproach
description: To the Editor:

title: Observer; A Shudder of Disgust
description: Here's a picture of the White House lawyer Lanny A. Breuer leaving the courthouse Tuesday with his lawyer Mark Lynch. But where is Mr. Lynch's lawyer?

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: F.C.C. Would Cut Call Cost Abroad
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved a draft proposal today that could help cut the cost of Americans' international phone calls.

title: Olympic Swimming Star Banned; Tampering With Drug Test Cited
description: The career of Michelle Smith de Bruin, the Irish swimmer who won three gold medals at the 1996 Summer Olympics, appeared to end in disgrace yesterday when swimming's world governing body banned her from competition for four years after finding that she had manipulated a drug test by spiking her urine sample with alcohol.

title: 3 Degrees of Separation on the Road to Art
description: You don't have to read Walter Benjamin to understand the laws of mechanical reproduction. Anyone who has ever used a Xerox machine knows that images reproduced time and again degrade and change. The grays dissolve and eventually the subtle features of the image disappear. At the same time, the aura, the authentic atmosphere around the original object, vanishes.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about Dr. Peter S. Raven, director of the Missouri Botanical Garden, misstated the size of the staff of the New York Botanical Garden. The New York garden has 547 employees, not about 100. The Missouri garden has 354.

title: Phyllis D. Michelfelder, Counselor, 76
description: Phyllis Deveneau Michelfelder, who devoted her life to the rehabilitation of women with the alcohol and drug problems that she had overcome, died on July 18 at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. She was 76 and lived in nearby Gulfstream.

title: Furniture That Returns Your Gaze
description: Practical glamour sounds oxymoronic, but it is, after all, the secret to mirrored furniture. What other kind of furniture needs nothing more than a bottle of glass cleaner and a paper towel to bring it back to glory? Which explains why mirrored furniture -- tables, chairs, screens and the like, all clad in either colorless or pastel reflective glass -- was such a hit in this country in the 1920's and 1930's.

title: Lewinsky Said to Detail Clinton Affair
description: Ending months of anticipation with a resigned shrug, Monica S. Lewinsky walked into a Federal courthouse here today, and, a lawyer familiar with her account said, testified that she and President Clinton had carried on a sexual affair inside the White House.

title: Lainie Kazan, With Much Pluck and Luck
description: One of the basic laws of show business survival is that perseverance ultimately pays off. If you have a modicum of talent and keep plugging tirelessly on, with any luck you too can one day ascend into the semi-legendary realm. Take Lainie Kazan, who opened a three-week engagement at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Tuesday evening. Now well into her 50's, the Brooklyn-born performer who started out as Barbra Streisand's understudy on Broadway in ''Funny Girl'' has built a dual career as a torch singer and a comic actress specializing in zaftig, devouring Jewish mother caricatures.

title: State Panel Suggests Death Penalty Rules
description: A state commission formed to streamline implementation of the death penalty released its final report yesterday, recommending that prosecutors be allowed to repeat the sentencing phase of capital trials in cases in which the original jury could not reach unanimity.

title: Panel Votes to Charge Reno With Contempt of Congress
description: A House investigating committee voted along party lines today to charge Attorney General Janet Reno with contempt of Congress, transforming into a criminal case the battle over whether an independent counsel should be appointed to prosecute campaign finance abuses.

title: Family of Missing Girl, 13, Is Clinging to Hope
description: Nestled alongside this small town on the Monterey Peninsula is the old Fort Ord, a sprawling Army post on the Pacific Ocean, once home to 36,000 people but rendered obsolete by the round of military base closings several years ago.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Louima Sues, Asserting a Blue Wall of Silence
description: Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who prosecutors say was tortured in a Brooklyn police station, asserted in a lawsuit yesterday that New York City and the police officers' union were ultimately responsible for what happened because they had jointly encouraged a blue wall of silence that fostered misconduct.

title: Standoff Between Boston Globe and Its Star Columnist Provokes Turmoil in Newsroom
description: The Boston Globe and its columnist Mike Barnicle found themselves at a standoff yesterday, with the newspaper continuing to demand his resignation and Mr. Barnicle refusing to provide it.

title: A Disciple of Parker's Yet Still His Own Man
description: The alto saxophonist Frank Morgan, one of the last of the second-generation Charlie Parker disciples, comes and goes; his engagement at the Jazz Standard is his first in New York in two years.

title: Pataki Signs Law to Widen Defibrillator Use
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has signed legislation aimed at encouraging far wider use of a new generation of compact, automated heart defibrillators -- machines that doctors have said can save thousands of lives and can be operated by almost anyone with training.

title: Do We Expect Moral Leadership From a President?; Abuse of Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Unemployment in Germany Drops to 10.9%
description: The German unemployment rate fell to the lowest level in 20 months in July as companies hired workers to keep up with the economy's growth. But industrial output unexpectedly decreased the month before, an indication that the economic expansion might slow.

title: On My Mind; Freedom From Religious Persecution: The Struggle Continues
description: On July 21 Iran hanged a citizen who follows the small faith of Bahai, on the charge of trying to convert a man who follows the huge faith of Islam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASON, HERBERT S.
description: CHASON-Herbert S. Eighty, on August 6, 1998, of Harrison, NY. Beloved husband of Phoebe. Loving father of Betty, Mark & Debra. Adoring grandfather of Dylan, Heidi, Martin, Nicolas, William, Skyler & Glenn. Devoted brother of Stanley. You'll live forever in our hearts. Funeral services to be held at Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Avenue, Rye, N.Y., 914-967-6262. Donations in his memory may be made to United Hospital Hospice, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573.

title: Full Moon? The Lakeview Has an Unexpected Vacancy
description: What Johnny Weissmuller did with a jungle yodel, Erin Quinn Purcell may be poised to accomplish with The Scream.

title: Slow Start Doesn't Keep Foley Down
description: The Jets began the 30th anniversary of their Super Bowl year tonight with the first string dominating the Philadelphia Eagles. Then the backups got sloppy in the second half as the Eagles made comeback noises.

title: TWO OPERATORS OF FUNERAL HOMES IN $578 MILLION DEAL
description: The Service Corporation International agreed yesterday to acquire the Equity Corporation International, an operator of funeral homes and cemeteries, for about $578 million in stock. Service, based in Houston, will also assume an undisclosed portion of debt. The agreement would create a combined company with 3,600 funeral homes, 500 cemeteries, 175 crematoriums and revenue of nearly $3 billion. Equity, based in Lufkin, Tex., owns and operates 326 funeral homes and 81 cemeteries. The shares of Equity jumped $2.8125, to $24.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange, where Service rose $2.375, to $36.375.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Changes in Upstate Utility
description: Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, an upstate New York electricity and natural gas utility serving two million customers, plans to separate its regulated utility in the United States from its unregulated energy sales units and form a holding company to oversee both.

title: Hispanic Population Is Near Overtaking That of U.S. Blacks
description: The nation's burgeoning Hispanic population is closing in on 30 million and in seven years will overtake blacks as the country's largest minority group, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Town Council Approves Giving Land to Indians
description: A casino run by an Indian tribe from western Oklahoma would be built in a municipal parking lot in Wildwood under a development plan granted final approval yesterday by the City Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVKIN, DOROTHY CARNEGIE.
description: RIVKIN-Dorothy Carnegie. Of Old Westbury, New York, died on Thursday, August 6th at the age of 85 after a long illness. She was the Chairman of the Board of Dale Carnegie Training. She was born in Tulsa, Oklahoma where she spent her early life & attended the University of Oklahoma. She was married to Dale Carnegie, author of ''How to Win Friends and Influence People'' as well as founder of Dale Carnegie Training. Upon his death in 1955, she continued his work as President and CEO. She wrote several books including ''How to Help Your Husband Get Ahead'' and ''Don't Grow Old, Grow Up''. The Company continued to grow & prosper under her leadership. Today, Dale Carnegie Training is in over 70 countries and has nearly 5 million graduates of Dale Carnegie Training. After her retirement in 1978, she remained as Chairman of the Board until her death. She was active in civic matters including Old Westbury Gardens, Old Westbury Horsemen's Foundation and The Raleigh Tavern Society of Colonial Williamsburg, Virginia. Dorothy Carnegie Rivkin is survived by her husband of twenty-two years, David Rivkin; her daughter, Donna Dale Carnegie of Lake Oswego, Oregon. Predeceased by her daughter, Rosemary Crom. She is also survived by 3 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren, as well as 3 stepchildren & their families. The family has requested in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Dorothy Carnegie Foundation, 1475 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, New York 11530.

title: First-Half Net Down At Barclays Bank
description: Barclays P.L.C., Britain's second-largest bank, said yesterday that its first-half net income fell 1.8 percent as rising earnings in its main banking businesses were offset by the loss of income from the BZW equities unit it sold. The bank said net income fell to $:887 million ($1.45 billion), from $:903 million a year earlier.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Summer hours vary for galleries and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: N.B.A. Owners' Group Brings an Abrupt End to Session
description: Negotiators for the National Basketball Association and its players met constructively, they thought, for nearly two hours yesterday morning. Then they broke for lunch, and each side had to wonder what was in the water the other side had with its food.

title: Richie Powers, 67, a Referee in the N.B.A.
description: Richie Powers, whose 23 years as a National Basketball Association referee ended in bitterness, died last Friday in Lehigh Valley Hospital in Allentown, Pa., where he lived. He was 67.

title: BRANDYWINE REALTY TO BUY 68 PROPERTIES FROM LAZARD
description: Brandywine Realty Trust said yesterday that it would buy 68 commercial properties from Lazard Freres & Company, creating one of the Mid-Atlantic's largest office and industrial property owners. The purchase would increase Brandywine's holdings by about 50 percent, to 248 properties and 18 million square feet. It includes 172 acres available for the development of 1.4 million square feet. Brandywine, based in Newtown Square, Pa., will issue $135 million of convertible preferred securities to Lazard, the New York investment bank, and pay $240 million in cash. It will also assume $237 million of debt. Brandywine's shares rose 75 cents, to $19.50.

title: With Results Faltering At E.D.S., Chief Resigns
description: Lester M. Alberthal Jr., under pressure from board members and shareholders to turn a faltering Electronic Data Systems around, has resigned as chairman and chief executive, the company said today.

title: U.S. Strategy: Keep the Pressure on Iraq
description: The United States vowed today to ''keep the pressure on'' to persuade Iraq to end its defiance of United Nations arms inspectors, but said it was too early to contemplate a military response to the latest standoff between Iraq and the United Nations. Iraq said on Wednesday that it would end all cooperation with the inspectors.

title: What the Texas Experiment Shows About H.M.O. Liability
description: As one jokester said, ''H.M.O.'s work well until you get sick.'' Managed care plans, with an eye on the bottom line, are making medical treatment decisions better left to a patient and his doctor. Yet they are not held accountable for the practice of medicine -- except here in Texas. And now Congress is threatening to overrule our groundbreaking state law.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on July 27 about the apartment of Jen Graffam-Wink and Chris Wink, a founder of the Blue Man Group, referred incorrectly to the group's structure. There is no head Blue Man.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Stephen Prina and Tobias Rehberger

title: SECURITY COUNCIL CLOSES ITS RANKS AGAINST BAGHDAD
description: The Security Council closed ranks today to berate Iraq for ending cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors, but took no action other than to demand that Baghdad reverse its decision.

title: Fun, Feathers And Physics
description: Tell children they're going to watch a 45-minute demonstration involving gravity, torque and angular momentum, and their eyes will probably glaze over. Tell them they can watch a circus instead, and they'll undoubtedly perk up. After all, how are they supposed to know that a circus act is really a physics lab with a sense of humor?

title: INSIDE
description: Calm Returns to Wall Street

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, SARAH
description: COLEMAN-Sarah. Passed away peacefully at home on August 3. Loving wife of the late Charles Coleman. Beloved mother of Walter and Aaron. Devoted grandmother of Sharon, Steven, Daniel and David and great grandmother of Stephanie.

title: Kimmel Is Hoping Patience Pays Off With Scatmandu
description: A year ago at Saratoga, John Kimmel tied with the soon-to-be-Hall of Famer Bill Mott for the most victories by a trainer at the six-week meeting. But this year, with many of his top fillies retired, Kimmel will apparently be counting on allowance horses and untested 2-year-olds to stay at the top of the trainer standing.

title: Congo Asks Neighbors to Press Rwanda to Halt Aid to Rebels
description: Facing a mounting rebel threat, President Laurent Kabila of the Congo sought today to persuade other African leaders to press Rwanda to end its support for a six-day old rebellion.

title: PROTECTION ONE TO BUY FRENCH SECURITY ALARM CONCERN
description: Protection One Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire about 65.6 percent of Compagnie Europeenne de Telesecurite, a French security alarm company, for about $94 million. Protection One said the acquisition would enable it to expand into continental Europe and increase its subscriber base to more than 1.4 million. Protection One, based in Culver City, Calif., provides monitoring and related security services. It had 1997 revenue of $144.8 million. Compagnie Europeenne has annual revenue of about $75 million.

title: House Approves Measure Barring Gay Adoptions in Washington
description: In one of its last acts before recessing for an August vacation, the House today approved a measure that would bar adoptions by gay couples in the District of Columbia.

title: Few Triumphs for Those Sifting 60 Feet Of Rubble, Listening for a Muffled Voice
description: Floodlights lit the 60-foot-high pile of rubble and metal that once was a three-story building while Red Cross workers and soldiers crawled over it like ants, digging feverishly with picks and shovels and stopping only once in a while to listen for signs of life: a muffled voice, a whimper or a cry.

title: FOCUS ON SUSPECTS IN PAST ATTACKS
description: Administration officials said the attacks on two American embassies in East Africa only minutes apart today probably were carried out by one of a small number of sophisticated terrorist groups presumed to have attacked American installations in the past.

title: Anti-Communists' Zeal
description: To the Editor:

title: New Rules for Metal Bats Alarm a Maker
description: With the N.C.A.A. apparently on the verge of ordering significant changes in the way aluminum bats are constructed, a major bat manufacturer announced yesterday that it had filed a $267 million pre-emptive lawsuit against the collegiate governing body.

title: Favorable Schedule for Liberty As It Makes a Post-Season Push
description: With six games left in the Liberty's season, the schedule could not have been planned any better for New York as it tries to clinch a spot in the Women's National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: Consultants Investigated Over Bribes For Buildings
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office is investigating allegations that the construction industry consultants who guide architects, engineers and contractors through the complicated web of city permits have bribed city officials and construction contractors, investigators said.

title: Serge Golovine, 73, Ballet Star Of the 50's and Choreographer
description: Serge Golovine, a star of the Grand Ballet du Marquis de Cuevas in the 1950's who was considered one of the most brilliant dancers of his generation, died on July 31 at the Hopital Ambroise-Pare in Paris. He was 73 and lived in Paris.

title: Call for Inquiry After Detective Says District Attorney Botched JonBenet Investigation
description: Boulder's Mayor today demanded an investigation into complaints by a city police detective that the District Attorney's office had ''effectively crippled'' the 20-month-old investigation into the killing of JonBenet Ramsey.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN WEAKENS. The dollar climbed against the yen on disappointment over the economic plans outlined by Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan. In New York trading, the dollar rose to 146.13 yen from 144.32 yen on Thursday.

title: Changing the Drug Laws
description: Four years ago, in one of his first proposals as Governor, George Pataki announced that the time had come to revamp New York State's rigidly Draconian drug laws. Enacted in 1973 under Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, the laws mandated such penalties as 15 years to life for being caught with four ounces of cocaine. Designed to suppress the drug trade, these sentences rivaled those for murder and rape. But instead of wiping out the drug markets, the laws overloaded prisons and court dockets with addicts and low-level couriers.

title: Pettitte Waits a Day for Clearance
description: Andy Pettitte threw 30 pitches yesterday and reported that he felt no pain from a strained muscle between his left shoulder blade and his spine. He exhaled. Pettitte will exhale again if he wakes up today without stiffness, because the left-handed pitcher will then be allowed to start Sunday against the Royals.

title: International Briefs; Indonesia Seizes Assets Of Bank Shareholders
description: Indonesia said yesterday that it had seized the ''shareholders rights'' of four large banks, a sign the Government is holding the owners of troubled banks responsible for their problems. It did not name the four banks, though it said they were among a group of six it took control of in April: Bank Danamon, Bank Dagang Nasional Indonesia, Bank Modern, Bank Umum Nasional, Bank Tiara and Bank PDFCI.

title: International Briefs; Unilever Says Profit Was Flat in 2d Quarter
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch household products maker, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit was little changed from a year earlier as the Asia crisis continued to weigh on its business. Unilever said its second-quarter net income before exceptional items edged up to $:472 million ($769 million), from $:466 million a year earlier. Sales for the three months that ended on June 30 fell to $:7.4 billion, from $:7.9 billion a year earlier.

title: Tokyo Leader Calls for Cuts In Tax Rates
description: In his first major policy speech since taking over as Prime Minister a week ago, Keizo Obuchi today proposed cuts in individual and corporate taxes and additional spending for public works while making less-concrete promises to deregulate the economy and trim the Government budget.

title: Immigration Agency Spurs Process for Naturalization
description: Under pressure to reduce an unprecedented backlog of citizenship applications, the Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday announced measures that agency officials said would cut in half the time immigrants must wait to become United States citizens.

title: With Financiers and Fans, Women's Pool League Civilizes a Hustler's Game
description: It was 6:30 already, half an hour after the matches were supposed to have started, and the fans were getting antsy. They itched to see behind the blue curtain, into the cordoned-off area of the Amsterdam Billiard Club, where the Black Widow, the Duchess of Doom and the rest of the best female pool players in the world warmed up for the first evening session of the 1998 Brunswick Billiards New York Classic. Hearing the boom of the break, the collisions coming like sporadic cannon fire, was almost too much to take.

title: Stocks Gain, But It's Too Early to Cheer
description: The stock market rallied for a third day yesterday as investors bought stocks whose prices had been pummeled during, and even before, the headline-grabbing selloff that began in mid-July.

description: The baby sitter is downstairs, the children are asleep. The phone rings. A maniac is calling -- from the upstairs extension.

title: Rent Deregulation Has Risen Sharply Under 1997 Law
description: Since New York lawmakers scaled back rent regulations last summer, at least three times the number of apartments in New York City have been deregulated under the new laws as under the old ones, a new study has determined.

description: Tale of the Cat returns to the scene of his most promising moments when he heads a strong field of eight Saturday in the 71st running of the Whitney at Saratoga.

title: A Pop Side To Opera, From Italy
description: At the end of this century, as at its beginning, opera arias have become major pop draws. In or out of the opera house, the attractions are the same: heroic emotion, prodigious musicianship, enduring melodies and a sense of prestige. Separated from the operas that hold them, arias -- especially bel canto arias from Italian operas -- are also as easily digestible as pop songs; they become identified with the singer, not the role, turning a photogenic tenor into a romantic figure from a more gracious era.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a museum exhibition in Minneapolis devoted to the visual and performing arts misstated the names of the museum and the exhibition. It is the Walker Art Center, not Arts, and the exhibition is called ''Art Performs Life,'' not ''Life Performs Art.'' The article also misstated the date of a Merce Cunningham Dance Company performance at the Walker in the 10th-anniversary celebration of the museum's sculpture garden. It will be on Sept. 12, not Sept. 20.

title: 2 Civilians And G.I. Confirmed As Killed
description: A 27-year-old Army sergeant who spent some of his early years in the small Missouri town where President Harry S. Truman was born and who served in the Persian Gulf war was identified by the Defense Department yesterday as one of the eight Americans killed in the terrorist explosion that tore through the United States Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya.

title: Fassel, Less Tense, Begins the Season No Less Intense
description: A year ago, Giants Coach Jim Fassel said he faced his team's first preseason game with this thought: ''Boy, I'd like to win.''

title: PHYMATRIX TO STUDY SALE OF HEALTH CARE BUSINESS
description: The Phymatrix Corporation said yesterday that its board would review next week the possible sale of its physician-practice management business as the industry continues to struggle with rising health care costs. The company, based in West Palm Beach, Fla., which had $346.6 million in revenue in its latest fiscal year, said board members had proposed focusing on Phymatrix's clinical-trials business, which manages sites that help drug companies accelerate research. Phymatrix shares have fallen 68 percent from a price of $17 in October, closing yesterday at $5.75, down 9.375 cents. Last month the company hired the investment banker Salomon Smith Barney to evaluate its strategic alternatives, including a possible merger.

title: MEDIAONE GROUP TO BUY BACK UP TO 4.1% OF SHARES
description: Mediaone Group Inc., a cable-television giant, said yesterday that it would buy back up to 25 million shares, or 4.1 percent, of its common stock. The buyback is worth more than $1.2 billion, based on yesterday's closing price of $48.3125, up $1.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The buyback -- which will take place over the next three years -- will increase earnings per share by reducing shares outstanding. Mediaone is based in Englewood, Colo.

title: Vacco Says Man Led Ring In Illegal Sale Of Medicines
description: A Bronx man who is suspected of leading one of the largest black-market prescription drug operations in the state was indicted yesterday after more than $1 million worth of prescription medicine was found in his apartment, the authorities said.

title: A Debate About Teaching the Holocaust; Seeing Jews as Victims Invites New Attacks
description: How should the Holocaust be taught? Today, a specialized field of study has grown up around the catastrophe. There are undergraduate and graduate courses, academic centers and conferences, fellowships and endowed chairs. There are libraries devoted to it, along with museums, films, docudramas, Internet sites and novels.

title: Judge Cites Possible Breaches Of Ethics Guidelines by Starr
description: A Federal judge here has found that prosecutors investigating President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky may have violated Federal rules by providing protected grand jury testimony to journalists, according to court papers that were unsealed today.

title: G.M. Marketing Chief Glum In Assessing Strike Damage
description: The nearly eight-week-long strike this summer at two General Motors parts factories will continue to hurt the auto maker's sales until October, and some customers have been permanently lost, G.M.'s top marketing executive said here today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Bomb-proof is a relative term. Tell me what size bomb, and I'll tell you what the proof is.''

title: Phone Workers Stage a Walkout as Strike Deadline Nears
description: Thousands of unionized telephone workers shut down directory assistance in New York yesterday as they staged a two-and-a-half-hour wildcat walkout aimed at pressuring Bell Atlantic to help avoid a strike at 12:01 A.M. Sunday, when their contract expires.

title: Lewinsky Story Feeds Cable News Networks
description: The images hardly make for compelling television: mostly Monica S. Lewinsky getting out of cars and Kenneth W. Starr getting into them. The talking heads make up a largely overexposed collection of former prosecutors, defense lawyers and pundits. And often there has not been a whole lot of hard news to headline.

title: 5 Officers Said to Cheat Newark's Gun Program
description: A grand jury has voted to indict five Newark police officers accused of taking guns or money related to a weapons buy-back program by the department in March, officials announced yesterday.

title: 'Magic Hour' Canceled
description: The final stunt for ''The Magic Hour'' will be a vanishing act. The late-night talk show, featuring the basketball legend Earvin (Magic) Johnson as its host, has been canceled by its syndicator, 20th Television, after only two months because of low ratings.

title: Jury Awards $760 Million in Chemical Trial
description: A jury here has assessed punitive damages of more than $760 million against five oil and chemical companies for injuries suffered by workers building the Stealth fighter at the Lockheed Corporation, lawyers involved in the case said today.

description: A child welfare supervisor was arrested yesterday when he tried to walk into the Brooklyn Family Court building with 31 small plastic bags of marijuana, city officials said.

description: Marketing Chief of G.M. Gives Gloomy Assessment

title: Op-Art
description: When you consider how many millions of people live, work and play in Manhattan's relatively few square miles, it isn't surprising that most New Yorkers are highly skilled in spatial relations. They quickly learn that only the most economical use of space by each of us will keep the traffic flowing, the pedestrians walking and the city functioning.

title: Mayor Intensifies Criticism Of Planned Youth March
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has intensified his criticism of the planned Million Youth March, pointing in particular to statements made by the march's primary organizer that gang members might be brought into the city to take part.

description: The experimental grass field at Giants Stadium is expected to be in playable condition for tonight's game against the Cincinnati Bengals. A concert last weekend at Giants Stadium left brown and yellow patches of worn grass and what appeared to be tire tracks on the field.

title: Journal; Who Chose 'The Magus'?
description: If further proof were needed that publicity can sell anything in America, here it is: ''Ulysses,'' a novel that is to beach reading what the Ring Cycle is to shock-jock radio, has now made the best-seller list, clocking in, as of yesterday, at No. 3 among paperbacks at amazon.com, where it has leaped ahead of the novelist laureate of Oprahland, Wally Lamb. On Amazon's ''hot 100'' list of paperbacks and hardcovers, it is even beating ''The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People'' (reading ''Ulysses'' is not among them) and that ever-popular anti-Joycean screed, ''Don't Sweat the Small Stuff.''

title: Piazza Looks Like Last Angry Man
description: Mike Piazza is not saying much these days. He does not need to. The body language says it all, especially the scowl.

description: Michelle Smith de Bruin, the Irish swimmer who was banned Thursday for four years because her random drug test had been manipulated, denied yesterday that she had done anything wrong and vowed to fight to clear her name.

description: Attorney General Jay Nixon of Missouri had no trouble winning the Democratic nomination in last Tuesday's United States Senate primary. But a major political problem he faced before the primary is still with him as he heads into an uphill general election battle with the Republican incumbent, Christopher S. Bond.

DiEleuterio, yesterday awarded a $392 million contract to build and operate the system to the lone bidder, Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group of Pasadena, Calif.

title: WINSTAR COMMUNICATIONS BUYS BOWNE'S LANSYSTEMS
description: Winstar Communications Inc. bought the assets of Bowne & Company's Lansystems unit for about $23 million in cash as the company enters the data-services business. Bowne, a New York-based financial printing company, sold the computer systems provider because it was not ''a perfect fit with Bowne's corporate strategy,'' said Robert M. Johnson, chairman and chief executive of Bowne, which bought Lansystems last month as part of its purchase of Donnelley Enterprise Solutions Inc. Winstar offers broadband local communication services to businesses, long-distance carriers, fiber-based competitive access providers, mobile communications companies and local telephone companies.

title: U.S. Judge Orders a Rwandan to Surrender for Trial on Genocide
description: A Federal District Court judge in Texas this week ordered a Rwandan who has been indicted for genocide in Africa but who is living in the United States to surrender to an international war crimes tribunal for Rwanda.

title: Job Growth Slowed a Bit in July But Still Kept to a Vigorous Pace
description: The economy created jobs at a slower but still robust pace last month, and the unemployment rate held steady at 4.5 percent, the Labor Department reported today. Continued strong employment growth in service industries more than offset the damage that Asia's woes are inflicting on manufacturers.

title: Corrections

From 1960 to 1963, her program was called ''The Shari Lewis Show.'' ''The Shari Show,'' a syndicated program, began in 1975.

description: Communist bureaucracy made Aleksandr I. Ginzburg stateless during the cold war. French bureaucracy would have left him stateless now if he had not raised his voice in protest.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on July 10 about the Internal Revenue Service overhaul misstated a requirement for shifting the burden of proof in civil tax disputes to the I.R.S. The shift applies to all cases involving individual taxpayers, and to cases involving corporations, trusts and partnerships whose net worth is less than $7 million; it does not limit the provision to individuals whose net worth is less than $7 million. The same error appeared in a chart in the Money & Business section on July 26.

title: Political Briefing; For Campaign 2000, A Month of Tuesdays
description: Back in the spring of 1984, some Southern states got together and created the first regional ''Super Tuesday'' by scheduling their Presidential primaries for the same early date in the nominating season. title: Editorial Observer; The Dead Cormorants of Little Galloo Island
description: I've been trying for several days now to imagine the person or persons who pulled ashore last week at Little Galloo Island in eastern Lake Ontario and began firing at the double-crested cormorants that nest there, killing nearly 900 of them. It isn't the heat of the act that interests me but its coldness, the fact that it was an economic crime, in all likelihood, rather than an act of murderous insanity. Cormorants feed mainly on non-game fish, yet many anglers believe, falsely, that the cormorants in the Great Lakes have sharply reduced the numbers of game fish, like trout and bass. Someone apparently believed it strongly enough to act upon it.

title: Arbitrator Sets Hearing Date To Decide if Players Get Paid

title: HUNTSMAN PACKAGING SEEKS APPLIED EXTRUSION
description: The Huntsman Packaging Corporation said yesterday that it had offered $10.50 a share, or about $117 million, to buy Applied Extrusion Technologies Inc., the second-largest United States maker of plastics used for soda bottle labels and snack-food packages. Applied Extrusion's shares jumped 23 percent, gaining $1.75 each, to $9.125, before Nasdaq trading of its stock was halted. Applied Extrusion, which had sales of $262.3 million in the 1997 fiscal year, makes labels for consumer products including Coca-Cola, Pepsi-Cola and Hershey candies. It is based in Peabody, Mass. Huntsman Packaging is part of the Huntsman Corporation.

title: Excerpts From Order Regarding Leaked Grand Jury Information
description: Following are excerpts from a ruling by Judge Norma Holloway Johnson of Federal District Court here, ordering hearings on whether the office of the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, had disclosed grand jury information about the Lewinsky matter. Judge Johnson said she found preliminary evidence that Mr. Starr's office had violated Federal Rule 6(e) that prohibits prosecutors, grand jurors and certain individuals other than witnesses from disclosing ''matters occurring before the grand jury.'' The ruling, made on June 19, was unsealed yesterday.

title: Vatican Snubs Israeli Protest Over Naming Of Palestinian
description: The Vatican today firmly rebuffed Israeli efforts to block the appointment of a Palestinian Archbishop in Galilee, saying such nominations ''are the reserve of the Pope in the exercise of his supreme power.''

title: BELIEFS
