description: They are the two Mets most likely to be booed. But tonight, a change of scenery made a difference for Mike Piazza and Mel Rojas.

title: HOMEGOLD FINANCIAL TO SELL EMERGENT UNIT'S ASSETS
description: Homegold Financial Inc. agreed yesterday to sell the majority of its Emergent Business Capital unit's assets to a concern it described as a ''major financial services company'' for about $85 million. The transaction, expected to close next month, includes all of the unit's operations except for its asset-based lending business, which the company plans to sell separately, Homegold said yesterday. Homegold, based in Greenville, S.C., originates, services and sells nonprime first- and second-lien residential mortgages loans. It had revenue of $49.3 million in the six months ended June 30. The company said total assets of the small-business loan unit, excluding the asset-based lending unit, were $65 million, or 14 percent of the total company at June 30.

title: Colombia Installs New President Who Plans to Talk to Rebels
description: Andres Pastrana, a Conservative planning to begin peace talks with increasingly aggressive rebels, took office as President today, ending the scandal-ridden presidency of Ernesto Samper by declaring, ''Change begins today.''

title: Maybe a Dostoyevsky With Better Teeth
description: As an author and deadpan humorist, Calvin Trillin often recycles his life into his essays and stories and then recycles them into books. In ''Family Man,'' his latest and his 20th book, he says that for a writer nothing is off the record. He gave an early warning to that effect to his wife, Alice, and their two daughters.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE JUMPS. Coffee prices rose 2.4 percent after a report showed a sharp decline in exchange inventories. Concerns about a possible port strike in Brazil helped the rally. September coffee rose 3.20 cents, to $1.352 a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RALPH H.
description: MILLER-Ralph H., 91. Devoted and beloved uncle of Cathy Cohn Marshall, Dr. Peter (Joan) Cohn, Dr. Kenneth (Joan) Cohn, Richard (Geula) Cohn, Stephanie (Martin) Cowan, & great-uncle to Corinne, Alison, Amanda, Alan, & Clifford. Attorney and friend to many. Graveside services are at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York, on Sunday, August 9, at 2 PM.

title: August 2-8; A Case of Switched Identity
description: Paula Johnson of Ruckersville, Va., had been raising little Callie Marie for three years when, in order to induce the presumed father to pay child support, she had a paternity test done. The test showed that Callie wasn't his child -- and another test showed Ms. Johnson wasn't the mother.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph last Sunday with an article about apartment developments built under the state's Mitchell-Lama program was published in error. The building shown, identified as the Cooper Gramercy development on the northwest corner of Second Avenue and 23d Street, was actually the East Midtown Plaza co-op on the opposite side of Second Avenue.

title: At Magellan and Contrafund, Thinner Portfolios
description: TAKING a lesson from the School of Focused Investing, two of Fidelity Investments' three biggest funds have drastically pared the number of stocks in their portfolios over the last six months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNGDAHL, C. RICHARD
description: YOUNGDAHL-C. Richard. Of Tequesta, Florida. Formerly of Short Hills, NJ, August 6, 1998. Husband of Catherine Youngdahl (nee Mason), father of Carl R. Youngdahl Jr of Bloomington, Minn, Lee R. Youngdahl (Joan) of Short Hills, NJ, John M. Youngdahl (Catherine) of Summit, NJ, Karen E. Youngdahl of Allentown, PA, and Ann Youngdahl Weber (Greg) of Sioux Falls, SD. Brother of Eileen Youndahl Gunberg (Edwin) of Charlottesville, VA. Also survived by 8 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Monday, August 10, 1998 at 1PM, from St John's Lutheran Church, 587 Springfield Avenue, Summit, New Jersey. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations in his name may be made to Good Shepherd Home, 6th and St John's Streets, Allentown, PA, 18103. For information, contact William R Dangler Funeral Home, Summit, NJ.

title: Where Squirrels Defend Turf
description: Udall's Cove. The name evokes thoughts of a trenchant television drama about a group of seafaring teen-agers. But in reality the cove is in far northeastern Queens. And it's not really a cove.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on July 26 about noisy air-conditioners at a West Village restaurant, Zinno, misstated its location, as did a correction in this space last Sunday. It is at 126 West 13th Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue.

title: With Roots in Dance Music but Not for Dancing
description: IT'S not uncommon nowadays to see the funky techno of the Prodigy and the jazzy drum-and-bass of Roni Size described in the music press as electronica. This usage is odd for two reasons. The first is that terms like techno and drum-and-bass, or even just dance music, already ably describe the work of these artists. The second is that electronica had a different meaning before American writers, looking to herald the next big thing in pop music, got their hands on the word.

title: In Europe, New Allure of Air-Conditioning
description: Marco Liberali decided not to fiddle around while Rome burned. Seeking relief from Rome's tropical temperatures, the 41-year-old mechanic installed central air-conditioning in his family's apartment on the edge of the city.

title: Nine-Ball Battle of the Sexes
description: THE SETTING Despite the fine weather and a wealth of attractions throughout the city, some 30 fanatics spent last Saturday night at Brownstone Billiards, a smoky basement at Flatbush and Seventh Avenues. One possible lure: The chance to challenge Billie Billing, 12-time New York State champion of the Women's Professional Billiards Association, to a game of nine-ball. Her record in the weekly challenge, which started last February, stood at 692-53.

title: A Challenge To Immunity Of Lobbyists At the U.N.
description: Last year, as India's envoy to the United Nations headquarters here was sipping coffee in the delegates' lounge, her aide pointed out the man at the next table.

title: Marketspan Pursues More Big Changes
description: THE Marketspan Corporation, the energy company created when a Brooklyn Union Gas holding company merged with the remnants of the Long Island Lighting Company, made announcements last week that have analysts wondering if the new utility has found its direction, possibly giving relief to investors who have painfully watched their stake in the company slide by more than 20 percent since it was formed two months ago.

title: Mary Jean Bonadonna, Robert Ely
description: Mary Jean Elizabeth Bonadonna, a daughter of Patricia and Vincent Bonadonna of Barrett Park, Staten Island, was married yesterday to Robert Duff Ely, a son of Ambassador Nancy Ely-Raphel of Washington and Dr. Robert A. Duff of Carlsbad, Calif. The Rev. Kenneth Applegate performed the ceremony at the Mayfield (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Lives; Diary of a Dependent Spouse
description: It happened again just the other day. At Heathrow Airport in London, the passport agent riffled through my paperwork and then, in the universal monotone of bureaucrats, asked, ''You're still a company wife?'' I had to say yes. For right there in my passport, a plain scarlet seal valid through the turn of the millennium confirms my status as an American abroad: my ''dependent spouse visa.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ONE THOUSAND CHESTNUT TREES

title: Living With Work That Needs Its Own Room
description: BACK in 1978, when Donald and Mira Rubell had just started buying art, they considered their first major purchase -- a painting by Francesco Clemente -- an act of sheer courage. Mr. Clemente's self-portrait was huge, 7 by 13 feet, and, in the delicate jargon of the art world, ''difficult'' because of its grotesque depiction of the artist.

title: Leah Goldman, And Eric Lesser
description: Leah Michelle Goldman, the daughter of Stanley Goldman of Longmeadow, Mass., and the late Vivian S. Goldman, is to be married today to Eric Lawrence Lesser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Lesser of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Michele Lenke will officiate at the World Trade Center in Boston.

title: Jessica Yep And Paul Chan
description: Jessica Cho-Yi Yep, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David G. Yep of Brooklyn, is to be married this afternoon to Paul Ming Chan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mo Yam Chan of Clifton, Va. The Rev. Philip Yang, a Lutheran minister, is to perform the nondenominational ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations in Manhattan.

title: County Correction Officers Getting Knife-Proof Vests
description: Atlantic County corrections officers are the first county employees to wear vests designed to withstand cutting and piercing. State officers were issued the same kind of vests last year after a corrections officer was stabbed by a prisoner with a homemade knife.

title: GURU: Bash; The Man to Call To Get Your Dog Past a Co-op Board
description: HE has cured a springer spaniel of what he diagnosed as ''rage without reason.'' He has helped a Great Dane overcome sibling rivalry after the birth of its owners' first baby. At the moment, he is ministering to a bulldog with a compulsive appetite for its master's Gucci belts and Hermes bags.

title: Siobhan Lally, Terry Perdue
description: Siobhan Caitlin Lally and Terry Dwayne Perdue were married yesterday at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Charles S. Dolan performed the ceremony.

title: Old LSD Tattoo Hoax Shows the Need for Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYNES, NORMAN A.
description: HAYNES-Norman A. His Loving Family expresses with God's Grace the passing of a truly great human being. Norman, affectionately known as ''ACE'', walked the beat on 125th street in Harlem as a NYC Policeman for over 25 years. He spent his retirement travelling and as an active member of the Kodiak Fishing Club, the American Legion-Post #

title: Jamie Rubin, Christiane Amanpour
description: Christiane Amanpour, the chief international correspondent for CNN, was married yesterday to James Phillip Rubin, the Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs.

title: A Georgia Baritone Captures The British
description: IN a New York theater climate that regularly welcomes Britons, famous or otherwise -- whether Ralph Fiennes or Eddie Izzard -- there is something particularly gratifying about an American unknown causing a stir in London. And a Georgia-born baritone named Shuler Hensley most definitely is doing just that as the menacing Jud Fry in the Royal National Theater's current revival of ''Oklahoma!''

title: The Olympics' Drug Problem
description: The drug scandals rocking the world of international sports have confronted the Olympic movement with a much larger credibility problem than its leaders seem to realize. Although the Olympic Games no longer represent the ideal of amateurism, they still embody ideals of fair play and honest competition. Yet drugs have put even those simple values at risk. Why in the world would anyone, much less hundreds of millions of people, choose to watch a competition in which the race goes not to the swift but to the chemically enhanced?

title: Long Lives the Mockingbird
description: IN Monroeville, Ala., where Harper Lee and Truman Capote once raced by Boo Radley's house as children, the 1903 courthouse still rises in the square, its bell tower, now electrified, chiming the hours. After a new courthouse was built in the 1960's, this one was marked for demolition. But citizens who prized the landmark and its role in ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' -- as a fictional setting of Harper Lee's novel and the model for the courtroom in the movie of the same name -- managed to preserve it.

title: From 18 Championship Holes to 9 Small but Artistic Ones
description: The nine holes in ''Strokes of Genius,'' the artist-designed miniature golf course on the grounds of the Montclair Art Museum through Sept. 6, reflect a heady variety of themes -- xylophones, mini-storage sheds, a Hindu deity -- as well as whimsy. Leon Willburn of Teaneck included two-foot-tall billiard balls as hazards; Orlando Cuevas of Jersey City incorporated the strategies of chess, and Margaret Murphy of Jersey City mimicked the croquet game in ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIGRO, EDITH
description: NIGRO-Edith. On August 3, 1998, beloved wife of the late Dr. Anthony Nigro, loving mother of June Rose Alfieri & Dr. Richard Nigro, adoring grandmother of six and great grandmother of two. Private funeral services were held. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Anthony and Edith Nigro Scholarship Fund, Saint David's School, 12 East 89th Street, New York, New York 10128.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOARTY, PATRICK J.
description: HOARTY-Patrick J. Of Hollywood, FL, formerly of Vinegar Hill, NY. Suddenly on August 8, 1998. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Fond brother of the late Lt. Michael J., U.S.A.F., Alice, Ann and Thomas D. Veteran of the Battle of the Bulge. Holder of the Bronze Star for Valor and the Purple Heart. Also survived by many nieces, nephews and grand-nieces and grand-nephews. In lieu of flowers Masses requested.

title: The Jets' First Audition Lifts Some a Step Up
description: Coach Bill Parcells still has many questions about the Jets' roster, most of which probably will be answered by about midnight next Saturday. By then, the Jets will have had another week of two-a-days and will have played their second exhibition game, Saturday against the Baltimore Ravens.

title: Seattle for Beans
description: To the Editor: The article on Seattle by Jesse McKinley (Frugal Traveler, July 5) was a refreshing departure. He stayed at inexpensive lodgings and did not always seek out the most expensive eateries.

title: Ms. Brustein, Mr. Ruderman
description: Jacqueline Hope Brustein, the daughter of Ellen Gloria Brustein and Lawrence Brustein of East Brunswick, N.J., was married last evening to Paul David Ruderman, a son of Judy and Howard V. Ruderman of Pomona, N.Y. Cantor Irving Shulkes, the bridegroom's uncle, officiated at Windows on the World in New York.

description: ELIAS CORNER+

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SISKIN, SAMD
description: SISKIN-Samd/ 80. Passed away on August 4, 1998 in Hallandale, Fl. A gentle man of dignity & character, he was loved and respected by his family and friends. Survived by his loving children, Susan and Darrell Mahler, Jay and Penny Siskin, Lee and Sylvia Van Damm, Mitzie and Bill Gillman and Linda Van Damm and Stephen Hanson, cherished seven grandchildren and devoted sister Bernice Mendel.

title: James Dobson Jr., Gopa Gohel
description: Gopa Gohel, a daughter of Ansuya and Raman Gohel of Cleveland, was married there yesterday to James Lane Dobson Jr., a son of Patricia Dobson of Watchung, N.J., and the late Mr. Dobson Sr. The Rev. Thomas Flynn performed a Roman Catholic ceremony at the Sheraton City Center, followed by a Hindu ceremony performed by Maharaj Bharat Joshi.

title: The Nation; Campaign Finance: The Lateral Pass
description: Now that the Federal budget is actually in balance, there is probably no subject on which Congress has legislated with more short-term success but less long-term impact than campaign finance.

title: Corrections
description: A review on July 19 about ''Hullabaloo in the Guava Orchard,'' by Kiran Desai, misspelled the name of the novel's hero. It is Sampath, not Sanpath. The same review incorrectly identified the character who falls into a vat of broth; it is a spy from an atheist organization, not a monkey or Sampath in the form of a guava.

description: To the Editor:

title: Aqueduct Assaults
description: An assault on a woman who was jogging along the Old Croton Aqueduct has prompted the police in Hastings-on-Hudson to join officers in Dobbs Ferry and Irvington to increase patrols of the heavily wooded trailway. Seven women have been approached by unidentified men on the aqueduct in those villages since early June, and five of the women were physically attacked, Detective Sgt. Wayne Pietropaolo of the Hastings police said.

title: Second Mate
description: CRANE SPREADS WINGS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLANT, WILLIAM
description: GALLANT-William. Of Bala Cynwyd, PA, on August 7, 1998. Son of Nancy Ash and Mark Gallant, brother of Emily, grandson of Lydia Gallant and Helen and Arthur Ash. Nephew of Jane Ash and Barbara and Scott Gallant, friend of so many. Adored and cherished by all. We will miss him more than we can ever say.

title: Taking a Flier on a Ferry
description: AN unlikely vessel is racing through the waters between Bar Harbor, Me., and Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, four times a day. This ship, nearly as big as a football field, travels up to 55 miles an hour. It can accommodate 762 passengers, 240 cars and 4 buses.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You don't expect such a thing like this. You wonder why someone would want to do this. Even if you have a problem with any country, why attack innocent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZALBERT, ROBERT
description: ZALBERT-Robert. August 5, 1998. Born December 6, 1907. Loving father of Barbara and Gene and father-in-law to Patricia and Howard. Cherished grandfather of Paul, Todd, Jennifer, Stephanie, Steven and Erica. Adored great grandfather of four.

title: Life Stirs Again in A Theater Long Dark
description: AFTER nine years of darkness, the old Shakespeare Theater in Stratford is getting cleaned, painted, and repaired for reopening. New, lighted makeup mirrors hang in dressing rooms. Lanterns, helmets and the chaise Katharine Hepburn reclined on in ''Antony and Cleopatra'' are neatly organized in prop rooms. The brass water fountains and theater seats, relocated decades ago from the Ziegfield theater in Manhattan, are clean again. And there are modern additions, including handicapped access ramps and a web site (www.Stratfordfestival.com).

title: Rescuers and Investigators Sent by U.S. Begin to Arrive
description: As President Clinton vowed today that the United States would not buckle under to the threat of international terrorism, American Government personnel were arriving in East Africa to begin the grim tasks of helping the victims and opening an investigation into Friday's nearly simultaneous bombings of the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.

description: The Snake Charmer

title: Social Security Needs Wall Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Catapano And Bill Thomas
description: Lisa Anne Catapano, a daughter of Kathleen and Philip Catapano of Sea Cliff, N.Y., was married yesterday to Charles William Thomas Jr., a son of Suzanne and Charles Thomas of Summit, N.J. Msgr. Richard C. Bauhoff performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Museum Offers Hands-On Science
description: ANYONE who thinks science is dry and technical should go to the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, where a new exhibition, The Experiment Gallery, is running through Sept. 13. Described as ''science fun for everyone where you do the experiments,'' the exhibition features 26 hands-on activity stations exploring sound, light, weather, mechanics and electricity.

title: Megan Carey, William Kilgallen
description: Megan Marie Carey, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Carey of Glen Cove, N.Y., was married yesterday to William John Kilgallen, the son of Mary E. McClay of Levittown, N.Y., and Kevin P. Kilgallen of Westbury, N.Y. The Rev. James McConnell performed the ceremony with Bishop John R. McGann, the bishop of the Diocese of Rockville Center, N.Y., at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove.

title: Wheels for Hire
description: To the Editor: Susan Allen Toth's amusing essay on rental cars past (''The Little Cars That Could,'' July 12) brought to mind the time I was driving a rental car in a sudden tropical storm on a high-speed road that seemed to have no shoulders and no exits. I wildly felt around the dashboard for the wiper switch and managed, in short order, to pop the trunk and then the hood.

title: Almond Pedicure: It's a Guy Thing; From cosmetic dentistry to facials and face lifts, more men are making vanity a priority.
description: NOT long ago, Elise Berenzweig's mother telephoned to say she'd spotted Elise's husband, Evan, dallying on a weekday afternoon at a suburban New Jersey nail salon. Elise took this news in stride, guessing that Evan had added manicures to what she terms his ''going at it full force'' beauty regimen.

title: European Links to U.S. Focus of New Guide
description: Travelers who want to trace their roots in England, France and the Netherlands can find information in a 24-page booklet issued by a new organization, Exporting Cultural Heritage Overseas. The booklet, titled ''Europe's Best Kept Secret,'' offers background and travel information about the cities of Bournemouth, Poole, Portsmouth and Southampton in England, Cherbourg and Le Havre in France and the province of Flevoland in the Netherlands, places that hold interest for Americans because of their connections to emigration beginning in the 17th century and, more recently, the Normandy landing on D-Day in World War II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLE, DOROTHY FAY (BUNNY)
description: LITTLE-Dorothy Fay (Bunny). At age 93, on August 5th, in Hanover, New Hampshire. Wife of the late Dwight R. Little, survived by daughters Ann Rubenstein of Santa Fe, New Mexico; Katharine King of Washington, D.C.; and Margaret Warren of Brunswick, Maine; six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Daughter of Sidney B. Fay, late Professor of History at Harvard University, Mrs. Little graduated from Smith College and taught at the Cambridge School (Weston, Massachusetts), the Bement and Eaglebrook Schools (Deerfield, Massa chusetts), the Pine Cobble School (Williamstown, Massachusetts), and the Northampton (Massachusetts) Day School. In 1933 she co-founded with Ruth Hill McGregor the Greenwood Music Camp (Cummington, Massachusetts) and served as its Director for its first 50 years. In recent years, Mrs. Little was a Suzuki violin teacher in Hanover, New Hampshire. Service arrangements are incomplete. Gifts in memory may be made to the Greenwood Music Camp, Inc., c/o P.O. Box 484, Northampton, MA. 01601.

title: Golf Links of a Different Kind
description: I WAS standing on the first tee of Kilmarnock Barassie Golf Club in southwestern Scotland. I'd just spent an entirely sleepless night flying in from New York and my body ached all over. My golf bag had missed its connection to Glasgow and was stranded in London, so the clubs at my side were a curious collection of implements that I'd scrounged from the pro, including one of those hideous extra-long putters. My feet hurt from the new golf shoes that I'd been forced to buy, a pain that was only a little mitigated by the hope that British Airways might reimburse me the $85 I'd just spent. (I'm still waiting.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARCIA, JERRY
description: GARCIA-Jerry. Three Years Have Passed Since You Left This Place. The Other Ones Have Come, But Not With Your Grace.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: PROSPECT PARK; A Few Summer Moves
description: BY the light of the moon, Twyla Tharp's dancers will combine her exuberant choreography with heartland asceticism for a Celebrate Brooklyn performance on Saturday evening at the Prospect Park Band Shell. Ms. Tharp's hyperpunctuated modern-dance company, Tharp!, will perform ''Sweet Fields,'' ''The Fugue'' and ''Roy's Joys.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAWHAN, SAMUEL F. JR.
description: SHAWHAN-Samuel F. Jr. Of Potomac, Md., on August 4, 1998. Devoted and loving husband of Ruth A. (nee Edwards). Loving father of Kevin . Dear brother of Patsy Barclay. Uncle of Marilyn, Kathy, and Thomas. A memorial service will be held at a future date.

title: Matching the Food to the View Outdoors
description: AL fresco dining has become so popular it scarcely seems to matter if the locale overlooks a parking lot or Dumpster (yes, we've even experienced that), just so long as it is outdoors. Many a restaurateur with a smidgeon of sidewalk to call his or her own puts out tables and chairs and calls it patio or terrace dining.

title: Keeping Customs
description: To the Editor: Francine Prose's essay on the aftereffects of travel (''Elements of Style,'' July 19) reminded me of the customs that my husband and I discovered living in Japan 46 years ago.

title: Royals' First Mistake? Leaving the Dugout
description: Forfeiting to the Yankees would be more beneficial than playing them, a rival American League manager suggested earlier this season. A forfeit is neat and clean, while playing the Yankees is messy and depressing, serving only to confirm their greatness -- and just how crummy you are by comparison.

title: Grace Notes
description: ''The only handwritten letters I get these days are from stores,'' said Barry Cooper, a real estate developer who is an avid shopper. Thank-you notes have become de rigueur, from Madison Avenue boutiques to Pottery Barn and J. Crew. In their retail sales programs, Paul Stuart, Bergdorf Goodman, Lord & Taylor and other stores require classes in the art of writing thank-you notes to customers.

title: Valet Parking Introduced at Kennedy
description: Passengers driving to Kennedy International Airport who are in a rush to make a flight and don't want to waste too much time parking (and waiting for the van that invariably seems to stop at every other terminal before theirs) now have an alternative: valet parking.

title: Your Home; Power to The People -- For Less
description: Last year, New York State began deregulating the state's electric power industry, with the idea that competition would lower prices and the plan that every consumer be able to buy electricity on the open market by the end of 2001.

title: August 2-8; Doubt on Crime Statistics
description: Crime has been dropping dramatically for the past six years, to the lowest level since the 1960's, when the late-20th-century crime wave exploded in the United States. But now charges are being raised that police commanders in several cities have falsified their crime statistics to keep up with the nationwide decline, and this is raising concern that some crime data may be skewed.

title: The Whole Disraeli
description: BENJAMIN DISRAELI LETTERSVolume 6: 1852-1856.Edited by M. G. Wiebe, Mary S. Millar and Ann P. Robson.Illustrated. 622 pp. Toronto:University of Toronto Press. $125.

title: Bell Atlantic Phone Workers Go on Strike Over Contract
description: Thousands of workers at Bell Atlantic walked off the job this morning as the telephone company and two unions failed to reach agreement before the workers' old contract expired at 12:01 this morning.

title: The World; Congo Catches Rwanda's Disease
description: FOR anyone setting out to write a history of recent strife in Central Africa, few opening lines could be more tempting these days than: In the beginning there was Rwanda.

title: Seeking Unity in Jewish Giving
description: ONCE the envy of fund-raisers of all faiths, the United Jewish Appeal and the Council of Jewish Federations were unrivaled philanthropic powerhouses among American and Canadian Jews, many of whom viewed them as central to any charitable work done on their behalf.

title: In Brooklyn and L.I. Communities, a Sense of What's at Stake in Debate Over Census
description: Nestled near Stony Brook Harbor on Long Island's North Shore, the hamlet of St. James wears its suburban tranquillity on a monogrammed sleeve. Its shady streets adjoin manicured lawns. Volvos and minivans sit outside two-story homes. Nearly all of the people are white and middle or upper class.

title: Commercial Property/Connecticut; Extended-Stay Hotels Extend Their Popularity
description: IN recent years, the hotel industry has scrambled to respond to an increasingly mobile business community. Companies sending employees on assignments that could last from two or three days to two or three years were clearly underwhelmed by traditional hotel services and rates.

title: Alien Nation
description: DREAMLAND

title: No Invitation
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Louima Case Delayed Further as Defense Team Faces Conflict Charges
description: On the first anniversary of what prosecutors say was the torture of Abner Louima by police officers at a Brooklyn station house, the case against five officers is bogged down in a dispute over legal representation.

title: Team in Transition Aims for Stability
description: Peyton Manning is wearing No. 18, the same number his dad, Archie, wore when he was the New Orleans Saints' quarterback. It is the first time in a long time that Manning has dressed in that number.

title: Marcy Schulder, Andrew Barkan
description: Marcy Rebekah Schulder, a daughter of Marilyn and Howard Schulder of Manhattan, was married on Thursday evening to Andrew Brett Barkan, the son of Fran and Jay Barkan of Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert officiated at the Pierre in Manhattan.

title: PULSE; Howard Hughes and You
description: Fear of germs from all sorts of contact once thought to be innocuous is growing. There are now antibacterial ballpoint pens designed by C&K; Manufacturing, Nike ACG sneakers with an antibacterial foot bed and a new line of germ-free Clean Use calculators from Casio. And these are not being marketed exclusively to the Howard Hughes fan club, either. Products from dishwashing liquids to body lotions have seen sales rise with the addition of ''antibacterial'' to their labels. No-rinse hand sanitizing lotions like Purell are even being dispensed in public restrooms, left. And new competition for Purell is Jao, which also offers aromatherapy benefits (available at Bigelow Pharmacy).

title: Catherine Hugo, Wilbur Swan 3d
description: Catherine Marie Hugo and Wilbur Martindale Swan 3d were married last evening at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Boniface Ramsey performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, RICHARD
description: KAISER-Richard. The entire Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center community joins together in mourning the passing of our dear friend Richard Kaiser. Dean Herbert Pardes acknowledges with gratitude Mr. Kaiser's dedication to the advancement of quality medical care and academic research. Mr. Kaiser will long be remembered for his interest in and commitment to cardiology research at Columbia. His devotion to our faculty and to science was inspiring and led to his thoughtful and enthusiastic participation in many of our programs including regular seminars led by Dr. Allan Schwartz, assistance in the establishment of the Kenneth Forde Professorship in Surgery and the founding of the Richard and Lynne Kaiser Family Foundation Molecular Cardiology Laboratory. We will miss his friendship, foresight, advice and humor. We join together in expressing our tremendous sorrow to his wife, Lynne, their children Joseph, Charlotte, Martha & Henry & the entire Kaiser family. Dean's Office,Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons The Department of Medicine The Department of Surgery and The Alumni Association

title: The Living Search Among the Dead in Nairobi Mortuary
description: Samson Maunda had spent the night looking for his brother. His last stop was the City Council Mortuary, where the linoleum floor was covered with blood. There was no place to step without walking over a corpse.

title: Southampton Sleeper With Top Choices
description: THE Plaza Cafe is a sleeper. It opened in Southampton in December with little fanfare. It is still not filled to the rafters as are more touted Hamptons spots. But it should be.

title: The Carver Chronicles
description: For much of the past 20 years, Gordon Lish, an editor at Esquire and then at Alfred A. Knopf who is now retired, has been quietly telling friends that he played a crucial role in the creation of the early short stories of Raymond Carver. The details varied from telling to telling, but the basic idea was that he had changed some of the stories so much that they were more his than Carver's. No one quite knew what to make of his statements. Carver, who died 10 years ago this month, never responded in public to them. Basically it was Lish's word against common sense. Lish had written fiction, too: If he was such a great talent, why did so few people care about his own work? As the years passed, Lish became reluctant to discuss the subject. Maybe he was choosing silence over people's doubt. Maybe he had rethought what his contribution had been -- or simply moved on.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Fitting a Big Store Into a Small Space
description: OLD COUNTRY ROAD from Eisenhower Park on the west to the Wantagh State Parkway on the east is mostly lined by mom-and-pop stores, automobile-related businesses and restaurants.

title: Hayley Schwartz And Eric Lehrfeld
description: Hayley Natalie Schwartz, the daughter of Frederick Schwartz of North Woodmere, N.Y., and the late Sally Schwartz, is to be married this evening to Eric Andrew Lehrfeld, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Lehrfeld of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik is to officiate at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

title: Charity Begins, For a Gastronome
description: The Place, a restaurant and bar that opened two weeks ago at 310 West Fourth Street (near Bank Street), aims to satisfy both the gastronomic and charitable instincts. The proprietor, Alexander Achilleos, says he plans to donate a share of the profits to children's charities, starting with the Fresh Air Fund. Eventually, he hopes to reach 10 percent and to educate children on the cultures, and foods, of regions around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDELL, IRWIN
description: BENDELL-Irwin. Husband of Jane. Father of Mark, Daniel and Bruce. Services 3 PM, Sunday, Mt. Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Street Furniture Designs Stuck in Gridlock
description: SOME of the world's leading architects have designed newsstands, bus-stop shelters and public toilets for New York City. Not just models and renderings; life-size ''street furniture'' -- tall enough to walk in, sturdy enough to sit on.

title: Joyce Davis, Steven Lansman
description: Dr. Joyce Cheryl Davis, a Manhattan dermatologist, and Dr. Steven Louis Lansman, a cardiac surgeon who is the director of the heart and lung transplant program at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, are to be married today in Atlantic Beach, N.Y. Justice Louis I. Kaplan of State Supreme Court in the Bronx is to officiate at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Saul Davis.

title: POSTINGS: SoHo Developer Calls It a 'Loftel'; A Hotel for Greene Street
description: A hodgepodge of five buildings along Greene Street in SoHo reminds Tony Goldman of a smile with a few missing teeth. But that will change once his $15 million hotel (or loftel, as he likes to put it) is completed on the site by October 2000, he says.

title: Michael Zamore, Abigail Smith
description: Abigail Smith, the daughter of State Representative Marjorie K. Smith and Peter Smith of Durham, N.H., is to be married at her parents' house this afternoon to Michael Seth Zamore, the son of Frances and Joseph Zamore of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLING, EILEEN
description: MILLING-Eileen. On August 7, 1998 of Roslyn Heights, L.I. (President of Public Relations Analysts). Beloved wife of Leonard, devoted mother of Susan & Gerry McHugh, cherished grandmother of Ryan and Jennifer. Memorial service Monday, 3:30 P.M., at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

description: CENTRAL PARK

title: Ex-Yankee Employee Files Suit
description: A former Yankees clubhouse attendant has filed a lawsuit against the team, alleging he was fired last year because he had the virus that causes AIDS. He also alleges that players harassed him because he was gay.

title: Gamblers: Downside Of a State Cash Cow
description: A COUPLE of years ago, Marvin A. Steinberg recalls, the state conducted a one-day ''intercept study'' on people at the legal gambling establishments within its borders: casinos, greyhound racing, jai alai and off-track betting.

description: Men Giving Money, Women Yelling: Intersecting Stories

description: KOSOVO A Short History. By Noel Malcolm. 492 pp. New York: New York University Press. $28.95.

title: Laureen Sexton, Edward Feller
description: Laureen Ann Sexton and Edward Arthur Feller were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Woodside, Queens. The Rev. Donald Berran officiated.

title: Tara Carney, Bo Garrett
description: Tara Anne Carney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Carney of Matinecock, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christian Fueller Garrett, the son of Lucretia Robbins of Wyndmoor, Pa., and Donald P. Garrett of West Chester, Pa. The Rev. Paul Butler performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Chapel of St. Dominic in Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Abortion Debated in Chile, Where It's Always a Crime
description: Nine years after Gen. Augusto Pinochet decreed that abortion was a crime in Chile even when necessary to save the mother's life, the Chilean Senate has taken up the issue for the first time.

title: U.S. Oilmen Chafing at Curbs on Iran
description: American oil companies, the largest players on the energy-rich Caspian Sea, are expressing growing exasperation with the White House policy forbidding American investment in Iran.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: VARIETY spices the choice vintage movies on television this week: an American frontier saga, a musical about Paris fashions, a memorable drama about the Titanic disaster and a thrilling suspense story of post-World War II Vienna.

title: Muscles Yankee Nets Campbell Record 5th Hambletonian
description: Muscles Yankee didn't surprise anyone by capturing the 73d edition of the $1 million Hambletonian today in the bright sunshine at the Meadowlands. The victory gave the driver John Campbell his record fifth success in the most prestigious event in harness racing.

title: EATING WRONG
description: * At Southern Progress Corporation -- the Birmingham, Ala.-based company that publishes ''Cooking Light'' and ''Southern Living'' -- they take recipes seriously. For ''Cooking Light'' alone, they experiment with more than 4,000 a year in a test kitchen. * Annual grocery bill: $57,000. * Some ideas just don't work. Becky Pate, one of the testers, says 15 percent are utter failures. * Like? ''Black-Bean Blinis.'' Sounded good, says Pate, but they came out as grayish-green hockey pucks with ''the texture of leather.'' * ''Campground Soup'' was made using dehydrated chicken and dried peaches. ''It smelled horrible and tasted the same,'' says Pate. * And then there was ''Snappy the Snapper,'' an attempt to home-cook an entire 15-pound red snapper. The test-kitchen staff member who tried still recalls ''having this giant eyeball sticking out at me.''

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Vicki Elizabeth Van Deusen and Douglas Michael Peters omitted the bridegroom's education. He graduated from Stanford University.

title: One Mental Health Service Does Receive Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: No Bed Of Roses
description: The view from my apartment window is not so green and sunny anymore. For years I looked across the street at blue sky above patches of flowers and vegetables that spanned the block of Amsterdam Avenue between 89th and 90th Streets. It was a community garden -- what one neighborhood paper called a ''West Side Eden'' -- and the community fought hard against the developer who wanted to despoil it. But the bulldozers proved as unstoppable as the tanks at Tiananmen Square. This summer an 18-story building blocks the sky, and concrete smothers the earth that once nourished tomatoes.

title: At the Casinos
description: Atlantic City Hilton

title: Nina Lihn and Roger Wiederhorn
description: AMONG friends, Nina Wilson Lihn is known as a gregarious, high-energy supermom, the sort of person who gets in and out of crowded grocery stores quicker than anyone else. Until recently, she worked as a managing director of corporate finance at Chase Securities in Manhattan, yet still cooked waffles and bacon for her three children every morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ELI
description: ROSENBERG-Eli. A valued Brother of the St. Cecile Lodge #

title: On L.I., a Touring Version of Vietnam Wall
description: ED CORRELL rubbed a piece of paper furiously with a black crayon, making an imprint of letters that took shape into names. Too many names.

title: Demolition Derby
description: LIFE IN THE BALANCE

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Penn and Teller; Mixing Houdini And Harpo
description: PENN JILLETTE -- the larger, more boisterous half of the comedy and magic act Penn & Teller -- stripped off his gray suit, his red-and-black silk tie and his red Doc Marten boots (size 15) and stood in the green room of ''The Daily Show'' on Thursday evening, naked save for Calvin Klein briefs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 12 about a new state program of relief from school taxes misstated the income cap for participation by people 65 and older as well as the starting date for them. The program for the elderly begins this year and is available to homeowners, married or single, with annual incomes of up to $60,000. There is no $30,000 ceiling for single homeowners.

title: August 2-8; Legislators Vote to Accuse Reno of Contempt
description: No top Government official has ever been prosecuted for contempt of Congress. But that did not stop the House Committee on Government Reform and Oversight from voting along party lines last week to charge Attorney General Janet Reno with the crime. The committee's complaint is that Ms. Reno refuses to turn over memorandums from the Justice Department's top investigators, including Louis J. Freeh, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, holding that the law requires her to ask for an independent counsel to investigate Democratic campaign finance abuses in the last election.

title: A Sullen Futurism Deadened by Fear of the Future
description: ''RUSSIAN FUTURISM,'' five compact disks in three packages from Arte Nova, appropriates a title to which it may not be entitled. Futurism had a distinct time, place and description, and none of the music offered here fits the last two of these. The visual arts were Futurism's focus; the musical arm survives in accounts of it. Aside from an all but undecipherable shellac record, this brief, brave movement came and went, leaving only its ideas behind.

title: Ms. McClintock And Mr. Malloy
description: Heather Elaine Allen McClintock and Mark Lawrence Malloy were married yesterday in Newbury, Vt. Shirley Beresford, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Newbury Center Town House with Judge Haldane Robert Mayer, the chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington.

title: August 2-8; Watching Kosovo Simmer
description: Washington and NATO, embarrassed by a brutal Serb campaign against ethnic Albanians in the southern Serbian province of Kosovo, warned Yugoslavia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, yet again that he risks military retaliation.

title: Sports of The Times; Rose Jr., Forever His Father's Son
description: HE came not to talk, only to hit. Pete Rose Jr., famous son with a bulked-up body and a prefab burden, came to New Jersey, the Northeast League, where the only at-bats were.

title: Some Lessons on Brothers, and Bugs
description: David Folsom Jr. dashed across the large backyard, raced onto the porch behind his house, ducked behind a chair and popped out next to Rachel Joseph, who was sitting at the table.

title: After Trump, Restaurant Has a Cause
description: SABATINI'S specials of the day included veal francese ($16) and spaghetti and meatballs ($10), both with soup and salad. These are customer favorites, and in the dining room, the little square tables draped in white linen cloths were filling nicely with casino employees on break.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ABRAMSON, SOL
description: ABRAMSON-Sol. August 12, 1996. Two years ago, you left us. Deeply missed, remembered with love. Elsie and Children

title: Correspondence/Duh; Today's Kids Are, Like, Killing The English Language. Yeah, Right.
description: As a father of two pre-teen boys, I have in the last year or so become a huge fan of the word ''duh.'' This is a word much maligned by educators, linguistic brahmins and purists, but they are all quite wrong.

title: Keeping the Boom From Busting
description: I was reassured that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is ''Keeping the Boom From Busting'' (July 19). Jacob Weisberg provides insight into the analytical approach that has kept American economic policy steady enough not only to direct the domestic economy in a historically productive course but also to avoid catastrophe generated by international developments.

title: What to Water and What to Harvest
description: Gardens need about an inch of water a week. Healthy lawns will recover from periods of drought, but the winter survival of trees and shrubs planted this year depends on even, regular watering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, ROBERT J.
description: MITCHELL-Robert J. On August 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary Jo (nee McDermott) and the late Audrey (nee Koch). Loving father of Robert Jr., Kathleen, Patrice Francois, Matthew and the late Mark. Dear brother of Margaret Mitchell. Dear step-father of Terri McCarthy O'Brien, Beth McCarthy McErlean, Kathleen McCarthy Benson, Maureen McCarthy Wilcoski, Nancy McCarthy, Sean McCarthy, Meghan McCarthy & the late Tommy McCarthy. Adored grandfather of nine grandchildren. Funeral mass Saturday, 11AM, at St. Augustine Church, Larchmont, New York. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers the family request donations to the Mark Francis Mitchell Scholarship Fund, C/O Fairfield College Preparatory School, North Benson Road, Fairfield, CT. 06430.

title: The World; A Scorecard on Terrorist Attacks
description: Hours after the deadly car bombings at the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania Friday, President Clinton vowed to hunt down those responsible ''no matter what or how long it takes.'' But history suggests it can take a very long time. When terrorists take aim at Americans abroad, the perpetrators are rarely identified with any certainty and seldom caught or punished -- almost always because of the complications of joint investigations with foreign countries.

title: Thinking It Over, Wall St. Wants Results
description: The market giveth and the market taketh away. Investors learned that much last week. The question is: What will the market do now?

title: Melinda Wenner, Matthew Bradley
description: Melinda Lea Wenner and Matthew Harrington Bradley were married yesterday at St. Gabriel's Episcopal Church in Cole's Creek, Pa. The Rev. Frank Edmands, an Episcopal priest, officiated, and the Rev. Gerald V. Lardner, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Giants Win, Naturally, To Open the Preseason
description: In the first football game played on a grass field in the 22-year history of Giants Stadium, the Giants opened their preseason with the team's defense forcing the visiting Cincinnati Bengals into four turnovers that led to four Giants scores.

title: A Director With a Reverence for Things Past
description: MICHELE LaRUE considered her name. No need to do that until now; Michele LaRue is, after all, her real name. And no need to sort out components of her identity, as an editor and an actress, as a colleague and the wife of Warren Kliewer, producing artistic director of the East Lynne Company, the country's sole professional theater exclusively and zealously bent on preserving and producing old -- very old -- American plays.

title: Julie Chizewer, Jeffrey Weill
description: Julie Chizewer and Jeffrey Weill were married last evening by Rabbi Dov Taylor at the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago.

title: Generations Marking a Maternal Line
description: WHEN dignitaries gathered in Seneca Falls, N.Y., recently to begin this summer's celebration of the 150th anniversary of the first Women's Rights Convention, one Greenwich resident had a special reason to appreciate the ceremony. Coline Jenkins-Sahlin, 47, heard First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton praise her, along with her daughter and her mother, for continuing the legacy of their common ancestor: Elizabeth Cady Stanton.

title: Picasso Works Installed At Birthplace in Malaga
description: The house in Malaga, Spain, where Pablo Picasso was born on Oct. 25, 1881, and lived for 17 months before his family moved next door, reopened on June 22 as a small museum for Picasso's work. The five-story building, which had been open to visitors from 1988 to 1996, has been transformed into the first of two Picasso museums planned for Malaga, on Spain's southern Mediterranean coast.

title: An Alaskan Paradise Regained
description: I WAS in Alaska almost a decade ago when a ship nearly three times the length of a football field went aground, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil into the Eden of Prince William Sound. Day 1 was shock and trauma. Day 2 disbelief. By the third day, fishermen who would never so much as wince if their hands were pierced by grappling hooks were crying like infants. Alaska's beloved inland sea, with all its otters and whales, puffins and bald eagles, was thought to be mortally wounded.

title: The Clinton Crowd Has Left, And So Has Georgica Pond
description: PRESIDENT Clinton has been gone a week, but the biggest mystery of his visit to Long Island still remains: Who drained Georgica Pond?

title: The Bags Are Nice, but About That Big White Thing . . .
description: Louis Vuitton, the purveyor of luxury luggage and clothing, is coming to Greene Street, and some in the neighborhood can't wait for it to open. The reason? They want an end to the construction, which they say is blocking the way for people walking along Greene between Spring and Prince Streets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOPERBERG, IRVING
description: COOPERBERG-Irving 18 AV 5757 As long as we live, he too will live; for he is now a part of us. As we remember him. Lou

title: Newark Seeks Developers For 1,000 Wooded Acres
description: As the state moves ahead with an unprecedented effort to preserve undeveloped land in New Jersey, Newark officials have come forward with a plan to develop 1,000 acres of wooded property that the city owns in West Milford.

description: THE ODD SEA

title: A Vigorous First
description: Sauvignon blanc, 1997, Macari Vineyards, Mattituck. (About $12.)

description: Weeks

title: Pottery, From Couture to Ready-to-Wear to Mass Market
description: JONATHAN ADLER wants to be perfectly clear: he has all the respect in the world for traditional potters who churn out pretty glazed vases and earth-tone dinner plates. But when he approaches the kiln, he is not thinking Mother Earth, but rather a different sort of woman -- Coco Chanel, say.

title: Stephanie Gold and David Mendel
description: Stephanie Julie Gold, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard E. Gold of Longmeadow, Mass., was married last evening to David Stuart Mendel, a son of Lois E. Mendel of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and the late Eric Mendel. Rabbi H. Hirsch Cohen officiated at the Willowbend Country Club in Mashpee, Mass.

title: Bard Festival Features Tchaikovsky
description: SOME summer festivals rely on a welcoming ambiance and an array of well-known artists to bring in the audience; others take the pops concert route, with lightweight repertory that makes no great demands on the -- oft as not -- picnicking listeners.

title: Checks Of Nannies Allowed
description: FIVE years after their infant son, Kieran, was fatally hurled across his bedroom by a nanny, Peggy and David Leahy Dunne attended the signing of a state law, the first in the United States, which gives parents the right to request a national criminal background check of a prospective caregiver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDERSON, EDWIN M.
description: BEDERSON-Edwin M., August 4. We who loved him in life would not lose him in death. Alyse, Stephen, Emily, Neal, Eric

title: For Brisbane's Chefs A Tropical Bounty
description: TIERED verandas and graceful palms remain hallmarks of Brisbane, despite the surge of shiny new office buildings that tower above the mangrove-fringed banks of the Brisbane River. Dynamic and progressive, this northern city is the country's third-largest state capital, with a population of around 1.5 million in the greater Brisbane area.

title: Floods Now Imperiling Big Cities, China Says
description: Chinese officials say the nation's worst flooding in 40 years, caused by a fast-swelling Yangtze River, now threatens to overwhelm several large cities in the central part of the country.

title: Palisa Kelley, David Strachan Jr.
description: Palisa Rose Kelley and David Donaldson Strachan Jr., lawyers in Manhattan, were married last evening. The Rev. Marjorie Bowens-Wheatley, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Park Savoy, a caterer in Florham Park, N.J.

title: After 50 Years, Ruth Still Stars
description: JAMES FORD can usually spot them the moment they walk in the front door of his office at the Cemetery of the Gate of Heaven here. They are the ones in blue Yankee hats and pinstripe shirts -- fathers and their young children, mostly -- who typically stop in the main building to ask directions.

title: Made In Prague, Bound for the U.S.
description: AT the height of the cold war, hundreds of cartoons shown in the United States were actually made in Communist Czechoslovakia. Throughout the 1960's, episodes of ''Tom and Jerry,'' ''Popeye'' and ''Krazy Kat,'' as well as animated versions of classic children's books like ''Madeline'' and ''In the Night Kitchen,'' came into American theaters, homes, schools and libraries straight from the animation studios of Prague.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 9, 1998
description: Weeks

title: The View From/New Canaan; Young Musicians Practice, Young Composers Work
description: IF you closed your eyes, you would think it was Tanglewood. A Beethoven string quartet sang out from one practice room. Rameau emanated from another. A contemporary composition put a pianist through paces in the auditorium. Everywhere a visitor went, there was intense musical activity.

title: Worlds Collide Under a Merciless Australian Sun
description: IN the opening scene of Nicholas Parsons's film ''Dead Heart,'' two aborigines emerge from the blazing Australian desert to join Poppy, an elder, for a few hands of poker in the nonexistent shade of a scraggly little tree. Cards are shuffled and the talk turns to aboriginal ways of dealing with wrongdoers. In one tale a person's ribs are pulled apart and his heart taken; in another an arm is removed and sucked on. Then Poppy tells them the story of Wala Wala station.

title: Sarah Jones And Eric Lusk
description: Sarah Elizabeth Jones and Eric Butler Lusk were married on Friday at the Dingletown Community Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Martin Montonye, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Not for the Faint of Head
description: Forget the summer potboilers. This month Ruth Gitlin, Silda Wall Spitzer, Lilly Stern and the others in their circle will be reading Proust -- ''Swann's Way,'' to be precise, an intimidating work where madeleines, the small, shell-shaped cakes, play a central role. The three are members of a book group founded more than a decade ago by a half-dozen professional women who wanted to ''plug the holes'' in their otherwise impressive educations, according to Ms. Spitzer, a lawyer.

title: Murdoch
description: Funny thing about the Murdochs and their never-ending crusade to unshackle the masses from the elitist yoke by making the world more wonderful through dumb-downing (''Murdoch,'' by Geraldine Brooks, July 19).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, BERNARD A.
description: LAWRENCE-Bernard A. Son of Ada and Morris Cohen; died at home in Elizaville, NY on August 7, 1998 and is survived by his brother Matthew and his beloved family of friends. Bernie was a successful, accomplished commercial photographer in Manhattan. After he retired from commercial photography, he devoted himself to teaching photography at the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan. He was a wood turner and a maker of fine wooden furniture and objects of art. Bernie was creative, talented and skilled in so many wonderful ways. Bernie loved to fish in the wilderness and he loved the Indian and Eskimo peoples. And Bernie, lest we never forget your gourmet cooking, and all our fun dining together. We love you, Bernie. You will always be with us. Graveside service Sunday, August 9 at 11AM at Riverside Cemetery in Saddle Brook, New Jersey.

title: GOVERNMENT LAGS IN STEPS TO WIDEN HEALTH COVERAGE
description: In 1994, when President Clinton's effort to reshape the American health care system collapsed, a political consensus emerged from the rubble: in the future, any such changes should be made piecemeal, one step at a time.

title: An Urban Beacon, the Swingline Sign May Outlast the Factory on Which It Stands
description: For Harold Jordan and other operators of the No. 7 train, the gigantic Swingline Staplers sign atop the company's Skillman Avenue factory is more than just the marker for the midway point along the Times Square-Flushing route. Amid the industrial skyline of western Queens, it is a neon beacon treated with the same reverence a sailor would bestow on a lighthouse.

title: Judge Censured
description: In a unanimous decision, the State Commission on Judicial Conduct late last month censured Judge Mary H. Smith, 52, of County Court for a ''pattern of inappropriate behavior'' on the bench. The 11-member panel took the action because, it said, the judge interfered in the relationship between a lawyer and a client by speaking to defendants outside the presence of their legal representatives. Also, the commission reported, Judge Smith had urged the defendants to enter guilty pleas.

title: Wildlife Haunts the Runways
description: ONE late afternoon in 1994 Andrew Pothanszky was flying back to Stratford from Bangor, Me. He was alone, piloting his single-engine Piper Dakota, coming in to land at Igor I. Sikorsky Memorial Airport, when a flock of Canadian geese crossed in front of him.

title: Two's Company, Three's a Society
description: NEW YORK often seems like individuality run amok. So in a city with a statue dedicated to liberty, why not groups devoted to a peculiar pursuit of happiness? Thumb through the Yellow Pages and the Encyclopedia of Associations or click around the Internet and you'll find eccentric New York societies, associations and clubs galore.

title: Correction
description: A chart on July 26 about the Internal Revenue Service overhaul misstated a requirement for shifting the burden of proof in civil tax disputes to the I.R.S. The shift applies to all cases involving individual taxpayers, and to cases involving corporations, trusts and partnerships whose net worth is less than $7 million; it does not limit the provision to individuals whose net worth is less than $7 million.

title: DIARY
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Questions for: Franklin Graham
description: Since Franklin Graham is a popular Christian evangelist, he should really think carefully about spreading casual and contemptuous misinformation about non-Christian religions (Sunday: ''Questions for: Franklin Graham,'' July 12). His recent remarks about Hinduism and Islam reveal a level of ignorance and cultural chauvinism that are unworthy of an educated man.

title: Playing It the Company Way
description: Summer can bring out the most memorable in corporate gamesmanship -- not the backstabbing kind, but those company-sponsored sporting events that can be a lot of laughs in spite of, or maybe because of, the players they attract. There are three-mile runs that appeal to hard-charging Type A's and softball games that sometimes draw the far less athletic. And, of course, some competitions get way too competitive. Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Chart Readers See Little Promise of a Rally
description: THE steep drop in equity prices over the last two weeks may have surprised many people, particularly those whose portfolios contain little more than blue-chip stocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONTRIER, GABRIEL
description: FONTRIER-Gabriel. Beloved husband of Mary, devoted father of Bunny, Toinette, Suzanne, and Michele passed away on August 5 after a long illness. He also leaves his sister, Celeste, and his nephew, David. He was Professor Emeritus at Queens College, editor/music critic for the L.I. Press and a distinguished composer. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Aaron Copland School of Music, Queens College, Flushing, New York.

title: Lawyers Weigh Effect of Conviction of Missing Colleague
description: When Michael Abbell, a former Justice Department extradition chief, and William M. Moran, a criminal defense lawyer, were charged with the crimes of the Colombian drug cartel they represented, lawyers nationwide denounced the prosecution as a Government effort to intimidate the defense bar.

title: Glasses Menagerie
description: In a recent video, an ode to materialism, the hip-hop idol Sean (Puffy) Combs mentions Matsuda sunglasses, but he's wearing Barry Kieselstein-Cords. B.K.C.'s, as they're called, are the latest from the animal-loving designer whose handbags and jewelry are home to a menagerie of frogs, alligators and other beasts.

title: The Nation: When Too Much Isn't Enough; All Monica, All the Time: A Viewers' Guide
description: ASSUMING his usual role defending and defending and defending President Clinton on television, Lanny J. Davis looked a bit weary last Wednesday night on MSNBC's ''The News With Brian Williams.'' He was spun out.

title: OUT THERE: Los Angeles; The Conga Room: Where Nuevo Los Angeles Is Converging
description: IF you want to see the future of Los Angeles at play, put on your dancing shoes and head for the Conga Room, a recently opened Latin music club and restaurant, whose combination of top-notch salsa bands and sizzling interior design has brought sophisticated Hispanic style to an ethnically mixed audience.

title: The World: Fidel Without Fear; An Old Star Loses His Punch Lines
description: THE high point of Fidel Castro's state visit to this 133-square-mile ''Spice Isle'' last week was the speech he delivered at Tanteen, a cricket field flanked by a simple grandstand and a stack of cargo containers. As a couple of thousand people listened patiently and the occasional dog ambled across the grounds, the Cuban leader lectured Grenadians for an hour and a half on the history of slavery in the West Indies and assorted other topics.

title: Nissan Gives a Glimpse Of Its Plan for Recovery
description: ITS advertising slogan notwithstanding, Nissan has not been enjoying the ride. Now, it is counting on some new models to get it down a very bumpy road.

title: Cindi Rupp and Erik Rand
description: Cindi Rupp, a daughter of Donna M. Rupp of Bayhead, N.J., was married yesterday to Erik Kenneth Rand, a son of Colleen S. W. Rand and Dr. Kenneth H. Rand of Gainesville, Fla. The Rev. Richard A. Weber, a minister of the Life Spirit Congregational Church, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Estherwood, a historic house on the grounds of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Timing the Market Isn't Everything
description: OF all the days to plunk your annual contribution to Junior's college fund into the market, you picked July 17, the exact day that the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index hit its 1998 high. Now his kitty for 1998 is worth 8.1 percent less than it was when you started.

title: Catherine Burke, David Gedney
description: Catherine Marja Crimmins Burke, a daughter of Seija Nordling Burke of Puunene, Hawaii, and Geoffrey K. Burke of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to David Louis Gedney, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Gedney Jr. of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Michael Zeman, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Talmadge Hill Community Church in Darien.

title: Barbara Atwood, Alexander Cobb
description: Barbara Margaret Atwood, the daughter of Doris Atwood Sullivan and the stepdaughter of Paul R. Tall and cool and defiantly self-reliant, Mrs. Peel -- ''the widow of a famous test pilot'' -- was fluent in nine languages (including kung fu), could tie knots in mastermind-bending schemes and shoot the cork off a champagne bottle at 50 paces.

Rather than create dances for just one medium, he regularly invents them for Broadway, television, film and the concert stage. He loves choreographing but enjoys teaching just as much. Moreover, these are not the only unusual aspects of his life. When he started his modern dance company in New York in 1951, Alvin Ailey, Arthur Mitchell, Lar Lubovitch and Eliot Feld were among its first members.

To hear Elliott Carter in the company of Bach, say, or Steve Reich alongside Stravinsky, will shed light not only on the newer music but also on the older.

title: A Challenge for John McCain
description: Among senators proud of their independence, no Republican stands out more than John McCain of Arizona. Yet last week Mr. McCain sounded an uncertain trumpet as the battle over campaign finance legislation shifted back to the Senate after the House approved the Shays-Meehan bill to ban soft money. Instead of rushing to assert his earlier leadership in favor of such legislation, Mr. McCain waffled and raised doubts about how hard he would push for Senate passage this year. His attitude is puzzling and self-defeating. If Mr. McCain wants to keep his reputation as a champion of clean politics, he needs to drop the naysaying and direct the charge. If he does, campaign reform can win.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Summer of 1963
description: ''Dear Jackie Kennedy,'' 15-year-old North Wagoner writes to the lady whose picture she carries everywhere, ''Do people (men especially) ever touch you when you don't want them to and if so, what do you do?'' It's the summer of 1963 and North's parents have taken off for Europe, dumping her with her cousin Dee's family at Glass Lake. Drag-racing, motorboats, boys at the yacht club -- this summer should be fun. But it isn't. Dee's father, Uncle Judd, a plastic surgeon who exhales a boozy odor of well-fed ruthlessness, sneaks into North's room at night. He also cajoles her into going for rides in his Stingray and, between kisses and threats, photographs her in compromising ways. North grasps wildly for a tactful means of escape. Jackie would know what to do. In OH, JACKIE (Story Line, $19.95), Maudy Benz, an editor, writer and performance artist, tells North's story with tenderness and impressive control. The dancing surfaces of sports cars and lake water, the clink of a highball glass in Uncle Judd's sweaty hand, make the novel buzz with tension. In a strangely emblematic moment, North is pushed off a high diving tower by Dee's boyfriend, Shrimp; when she plunges feet first through the airless void of the lake, the surface appears above her, as promising yet remote as her glittery idol. Sally Eckhoff

The drama unfolds through the eyes of a midshipman (Franchot Tone), superb playing sets the tensions, and a compact scenario does the rest, with Catalina Island filling in for Tahiti. description: STILLERMAN-Maxwell, M.D., of Ft. Lauderdale and East Hampton, died on August 5, 1998 at age 89. Beloved husband of Carolyn, devoted father to Robbie Stillerman, Rosalind and Michael Seiden, and Diane Haut. Loving grandfather to Marc, Carolyn and Rachel. A selfeffacing, gentle man, he conscientiously practiced pediatrics for 52 years with a keen eye & a dogged determination to find effective treatments for infectious diseases. Born in Brooklyn in 1909, Dr. Stillerman graduated from Columbia University and Downstate Medical Center. His early research led to several breakthroughs in the treatment of polio, measles and rheumatic fever. In 1937, he began his private pediatrics practice in Great Neck, NY, where he cared for two generations of children. He combined his love of research with his medical practice, producing ground-breaking original research in the treatment of strep throat. Although retired in 1984, Dr. Stillerman always pursued the study of medicine; he and Carolyn were honored by the American Academy of Pediatrics for their distinguished clinical contributions to research in private practice. Funeral services Sunday, August 9, 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck. Memorial contributions may be made to the Maxwell & Carolyn Stillerman Education Fund, Dept. of Pediatrics, North Shore University Hospital, 300 Community Drive, Manhasset, New York 11030.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISE, HAROLD
description: WISE-Harold. We deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend Harold and send to June and Shera our deepest expression of love. Harold was a mentor to so many of us and left a far reaching legacy. He founded the Residency Program in Social Medicine at Montefiore, the first of its kind in the country. He founded & directed the Martin Luther King Health Center in the Bronx, which was one of the first community health centers in the country and was a model for providing healthcare to the poor which is in use to the present day. Harold taught us that healthcare needs to be delivered in people friendly settings in communities; as opposed to in hospital settings. He developed the concepts of the community health worker and the healthcare team. Harold was an early pioneer of family centered healthcare. He founded the Valentine Lane Health Practice, one of the first health practices to use collaboration between medical and psychosocial providers. He brilliantly incorporated complimentary health practices in his medical practice. Traditional boundaries could not contain Harold, he was so far ahead in so many areas. A true healer, his light improved so many of us that it touched. We love you Harold and miss you terribly. John Falencki and Steven Tamarin Friends and Family Physicians, NYC NY County Chapter of the AAFP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORA, SHINICHIRO
description: TORA-Shinichiro. Popular Photography Magazine's present and past staff celebrate the life of our teacher, friend, illustrator, and highly talented art director for over 35 years, who left us August 3 to be with the greatest artist of all. Graphic designer, photographer, lecturer, and inspirational advisor to generations of young Japanese artists trying to find their way in America, Mr. Tora, a graduate of Tokyo University, was a member of the Society of Illustrators, past director of the Art Directors Club, former chairman of the Japanese Graphic Design Exhibition, and present director of the JapaneseAmerican Association. There were many exhibitions of his work, including shows at the Art Directors Club, the Japanese Advertising Photographers Association, and the International Art Directors Exhibition in Beijing, China. He was a regular contributing writer to Idea magazine since 1974. Among over his 100 honors, manyfor graphics in Popular Photography, were the Art Director Club Gold Awards in 1974, 1980, and 1986, plus several awards from the Society of Illustrators. Brave and gallant, he was with us as long as he could move his pencil or click his mouse. He is survived by his wife, Mie to whom we extend our deepest sympathies. A memorial service will be held at a future date at the Japanese-American Association, 15 West 44th Street in Manhattan.

So it is an event of great significance to the Makah people, who consider the whale hunt to be a sacramental act. It is turning out to be an event of great significance to people who aren't Makah too.

Available for years only on a single, small-label recording by Mack McCray (and only on LP), it was given a second wind in 1989, when Ursula Oppens included it in an inspired pairing with Elliott Carter's ''Night Fantasies.'' Recordings by John McCabe and Christopher O'Riley followed, and now Gloria Cheng-Cochran offers the second recording of the work to be released this year (after Hermann Kretzschmar's performance on an Adams disk from the Ensemble Modern on RCA): a beautifully delineated, unusually vivid account (Telarc CD-80513).

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Manet Under Steam
description: First exhibited in 1874, Edouard Manet's painting ''The Gare Saint-Lazare'' depicts a young woman with a book in her hands and a puppy in her lap, and a child who gazes into the distance, her back to the viewer. Through a background of black railings, the viewer glimpses railway tracks, a cloud of smoke and steam and, in the distance, some roughly sketched house facades. ''What had remained unrecognized,'' Juliet Wilson-Bareau writes in MANET, MONET, AND THE GARE SAINT-LAZARE (National Gallery of Art/Yale University Press, $45), ''was that the sketchy architectural details in the upper left corner of the picture are in fact a precise depiction of the front door and one of the windows of the studio into which Manet moved in July 1872.'' Thus the exact site of the painting is identifiable, which in turn yields new interpretations. Wilson-Bareau, a freelance curator, notes that several other Impressionists painted the station at around the same time as Manet, most notably Claude Monet and Gustave Caillebotte. But Manet's aims ''were more complex than theirs,'' she writes. ''He both presents and obscures the 'reality' of his scenes, disdaining to clarify the storytelling elements that he despised in the history and genre painting so popular in his day.'' The book also explores Manet's long and troubled relationship with the Salon, a state-run annual exhibition from which he was often excluded. It is a fascinating and valuable work of scholarship. Robin Lippincott

Adl-Doost reads a recording of the daily lunch menu for the United States Geological Survey's cafeteria in Reston, Va. (703-648-7777). Through word-of-mouth, she has become a national cult phenom for her lively delivery and farewell songs. Now she's about to be the star of ''The Lunch Lady,'' an independent documentary, scheduled for 1999 release, that tries to explain the allure by talking to her fans. Which is? ''It's the charm of her voice,'' says Michael Fisher, a Bloomingdale's creative director who asked Adl-Doost to record ''The Night Before Christmas'' for last year's Christmas display window. ''It gives you the same oomph as a self-help book.''

title: Two Feuding Democratic Voices Call a Truce
description: Two long-feuding pillars of the Democratic Party, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Democratic Leadership Council, have agreed to a detente in which they pledge to stop attacking each other and to seek common ground to help the Democrats this fall and beyond.

title: Peddling and Paddling to Stay Young at Heart
description: Peg Kocher plopped down on a rock, slipped on her flippers and -- waddling like a penguin -- waded backward into the cool waters of Little Neck Bay, across the street from her home. With a flutter of kicks she was off, taking the first strokes of her daily half-mile swim.

title: Where the Opera Soars Above Heat And Shared Spaces
description: BACKSTAGE in the heat, fans whirring and hairdos wilting, the cast of Donizetti's ''Lucrezia Borgia'' prepared for a grand night of opera at the Caramoor International Music Festival here. The venue is becoming known to opera mavens for its emphasis on the bel canto tradition and the young artists who regularly rack up rave reviews here. Performances are semi-staged, with costumes and a fair amount of acting, but the emphasis is on the music, conducted by Caramoor's opera director, Will Crutchfield.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, ROBERTA LEE
description: MARKS-Roberta Lee. Of Westfield, NJ. Devoted and beloved wife of Sheldon, cherished and loving mother of Gregg and Jessica, loving sister of Ely Margolin. Funeral services at Temple Emanu-El, 756 East Broad Street, Westfield, Sunday, at 9:30 AM. For additional information, please call ''Kreitzman's Memorial Home,'' 1888-351-4414.

title: Penciled In
description: Just when it feels as if summer is in full bloom, those back-to-school items begin appearing on store shelves as a reminder that all flowers fade. One of those items, a box of 24 colored pencils from Crayola, should brighten up the blues for Rachel Mason of Blairstown. It's decorated with a drawing she did (in colored pencils, of course) as a third grader at Blairstown Elementary School last year. She was one of 10 children around the country who won the Crayola Colored Pencils Box Challenge, in which about 5,400 pupils grades three through six submitted their art to be judge by Mark Teague, a writer and illustrator of children's books. Teachers had to assign artwork based on a lesson; Rachel's showed how lovely the world would be if everyone recycled. Her art teacher, Paula George, received a $1,000 grant from Crayola for use in her classroom. Rachel's pencil box, and the nine others, will be on sale only through this school year.

title: Libertarian Paradiso
description: Lazarus Long doesn't care much for American bureaucracy (''Government is an octopus,'' he grumbles), so he wants to start all over, creating a spiffy new nation on an unpopulated Caribbean shoal, the Misteriosa Bank, situated about 120 miles west of the Cayman Islands. He'll call it the Principality of New Utopia; place it on a grid of huge, pillar-mounted concrete platforms, and govern it based on the notions of maxed-out individual liberty and capitalism celebrated in Ayn Rand's 1957 novel, ''Atlas Shrugged.''

title: Life Imitates the Jersey Side of Reality
description: WHO changed the rules when I wasn't looking? The last time I checked, when Spiro Agnew was Vice President, things made sense. Left was left and right was right. You had your sports, your art, your politics and your landfills, and you knew which was which. Things were exactly clear, despite the Buffalo Springfield song.
