description: To the Editor:

title: When the Salmon Play Hard to Get
description: The afternoon darkened as thunderheads moved in from the west, lightning crackled, a sudden stiff breeze swept up the steep valley of the Upsalquitch River and in a matter of minutes I was fishing in torrents of rain, rain so heavy that it was difficult to cast a long line.

title: POP/JAZZ; So What's All the Fuss About 'Keeping It Real'?
description: IN the lobby of MTV's headquarters in Times Square on a recent weekday, a young man in sneakers, warm-up pants and a T-shirt emblazoned with the Nike logo bumped into a friend coming out of an elevator. ''What's up?'' he asked, to which the friend replied, ''Oh, just keeping it real.'' The expression has become something of a mantra among the hip-hop set, intended as an affirmation of one's cultural integrity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLINER, OSKAR
description: OLINER-Oskar. The Touro College Faculty and Board extends to Mr. Martin Oliner, distinguished member of our Board of Trustees, its deepfelt condolences on the passing of his beloved father, Mr. Oskar Oliner. Mr. Oskar Oliner was an outstanding product of the Polish Jewish community. His life reflected the disaster which befell his family and community. From the ashes of destruction, he rebuilt a distinguished home and family. His only son Martin Oliner is noted for his dedication to continue the legacy of his forbears and to rebuild Jewish life in the United States and Israel. Dr. Bernard Lander President Dr. Mark Hasten Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Questions Linger After Police Shooting in Ossining
description: WHEN her son was 10 months old, Renee Malone left the streets of the Bronx and the perils that often haunt overcrowded inner-city neighborhoods for a better life in the suburbs. Signs of spring abounded that March day when she arrived in this village overlooking the Hudson River -- Chris Anthony Malone in tow. The season's first flowers were in bloom. The air was full of promise, and the chubby baby boy had already begun walking, she recalled recently.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT; Yes, France Is a Friend Of the Euro
description: FEW countries have done more than France to guarantee the successful start of Europe's common currency; fewer still have received less credit for their efforts.

title: The Details of Life, as Observed in a Long and Multi-Faceted Career
description: MANY masters of 20th-century photography regarded the camera as an extension of the eye that could capture human experience in a straightforward manner. Henri Cartier-Bresson asserted, ''What the eye does is find and focus on the particular subject within the mass of reality; what the camera does is simply to register on film the decision made by the eye.'' Hence, spontaneous judgment became a valued artistic asset.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Pleasantville, N.Y.; A Small Town That's Big on Tranquillity
description: THE idyllic name of this small village, set in the rolling hills of central Westchester County, evokes images of an undisturbed tranquillity and small-town wholesomeness like something out of the movie ''The Truman Show.''

title: Reliving the Pain of a Deadly School Shooting
description: Five months after his mother was shot to death along with four girls in a schoolyard here, 3-year-old Zane Wright still does not understand where she has gone. His father, Mitchell Wright, will explain it to him when he is old enough, sometime after his seventh birthday.

title: A Review of the Works of Pavel Tchelitchew in Katonah
description: PAVEL TCHELITCHEW had two American retrospectives, one at the Museum of Modern Art in 1942, the other at the now defunct Gallery of Modern Art in 1964. The two institutions, one avant-garde, the other at best revisionist and at worst high camp, symbolize the fluctuations of taste during the period and their effect on the Russian-born artist's reputation, which is now being revived at the Katonah Museum of Art here.

description: ONCE again, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is thumbing his nose at the world community. Last week, he said he is through cooperating with international weapons inspectors and wants the crippling economic sanctions on his country lifted.

title: Tennis Opens Marketing Window for College
description: ONCE again Westchester tennis fans will be able to see 16 of the all-time tennis greats, close up and live, competing for $200,000, right in their own backyard.

title: Proposals Awaited for L.I. Breast Cancer Study
description: AFTER five years of meetings, symposiums and throat-clearing, the Long Island Breast Cancer Study Project seems to be moving ahead as a deadline nears for proposals for the development of a program to investigate relationships between breast cancer and environmental contamination on Long Island.

title: Keep the Oven Off: It's Time to Grill Vegetables and Chill Fruit
description: WHEN the temperature climbs into the 90's, the idea of cooking elaborate meals is not particularly appealing. On a recent weekend, with people to stay and guests coming for dinner, it was so hot that turning on the oven was out of the question, let alone standing over a hot stove. So I decided to serve a room-temperature meal, which can be prepared in advance (a smart decision, as it turned out, since a thunderstorm knocked out the electricity in the late afternoon).

title: Q&A/Patty Rademacher; Psst! Want a Low-Fat Diet, but With Zing?
description: PATTY RADEMACHER has 25 years of professional culinary experience on her resume as a caterer, cooking instructor and food product demonstrator -- not to mention routinely preparing sumptuous meals for friends and family at her Newtown home. A health issue in her family, however, required her to rethink her entire methodology -- to reduce saturated fats in the daily diet, maintain the flavor of the foods and introduce a new eating life style.

description: GIRARDOT-Claire Lily. Her son Christopher, her mother Mamie are inconsolable over their loss of Claire Lily Girardot on August 9, 1996. She was the niece of Lily Pons. Please think of her affectionately. Once again, we would like to express our thanks and appreciation to her doctor and the entire staff at Lenox Hill Hospital, Park Avenue, New York.

And in Katonah, Carol Hosdale, an exercise instructor and empty nester, might decide to combine an inventive salad with store-bought lasagna for the dinner with wine and candles she and her husband enjoy every evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVKIN, DOROTHY CARNEGIE
description: RIVKIN-Dorothy Carnegie. Of Old Westbury, New York, died on Thursday, August 6th at the age of 85 after a long illness. She was the Chairman of the Board of Dale Carnegie Training. She was born in Tulsa, Oklahoma where she spent her early life & attended the University of Oklahoma. She was married to Dale Carnegie, author of ''How to Win Friends and Influence People'' as well as founder of Dale Carnegie Training. Upon his death in 1955, she continued his work as President and CEO. She wrote several books including ''How to Help Your Husband Get Ahead'' and ''Don't Grow Old, Grow Up''. The Company continued to grow & prosper under her leadership. Today, Dale Carnegie Training is in over 70 countries and has nearly 5 million graduates of Dale Carnegie Training. After her retirement in 1978, she remained as Chairman of the Board until her death. She was active in civic matters including Old Westbury Gardens, Old Westbury Horsemen's Foundation and The Raleigh Tavern Society of Colonial Williamsburg, Virginia. Dorothy Carnegie Rivkin is survived by her husband of twenty-two years, David Rivkin; her daughter, Donna Dale Carnegie of Lake Oswego, Oregon. Predeceased by her daughter, Rosemary Crom. She is also survived by 3 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren, as well as 3 stepchildren & their families. The family has requested in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Dorothy Carnegie Foundation, 1475 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, New York 11530.

title: Jazz Comes Into Its Own at Caramoor
description: The notion of jazz as a spectrum of seri ousness with art on one end and entertainment on the other -- rarely holds water. As soon as you've decided that you're hearing art, you get entertainment's rude joy buzzer, and vice versa. So if you're creating a new outdoor jazz festival, as the producers at Caramoor did a few years ago, it's best to go directly to a varied group of the best musicians you can find, rather than impose an unintimidating theme on the music and hope for the best.

No one knows those stories better than family, and as about 50 Long relatives gathered today for an old-fashioned family reunion, the people who hold tiny pieces of that legacy fitted them together to form legend.

description: In an interpretation that could bolster New York City's move to shut down sex shops, a State Supreme Court justice yesterday warned that efforts by shop owners to include nonpornographic material along with their adult-entertainment fare would not automatically exempt them from new zoning laws.

title: Embassy Security Is Not Optional
description: As Washington mourns those who died in Kenya and Tanzania last week and begins the difficult hunt for the terrorists who spilled so much blood, it must reckon with its own failure to safeguard American diplomats. Not enough has been done to improve security at American embassies and consulates, especially in places like Africa where the threat of terrorist attack was considered low.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVKIN, DOROTHY CARNEGIE
description: RIVKIN-Dorothy Carnegie. The Board of Trustees of Old Westbury Gardens wishes to express its gratitude to Dorothy Carnegie Rivkin for her sensitive appreciation of both its beauty and its expanding needs to serve an ever-growing public. We make note of her love of gardens, especially in the creation of her own, and know it will bring joy to her remaining family and friends at this time of sorrow. Mary S. Phipps, Chairman Carol E. Large, President

title: Metro Business; Cablevision Creates TV and Music Unit
description: Cablevision Systems Corporation yesterday announced the creation of Radio City Networks, a unit that will develop and produce televised events and music programming. Initially, Radio City Networks will include Radio City Television and Much Music USA.

title: NORTHWESTERN MUTUAL ANNOUNCES DEAL TO BUY RUSSELL
description: As expected, the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company of Milwaukee formally announced yesterday that it would buy the closely held Frank Russell Company, the world's biggest consultant to pension funds, giving Northwestern's agents more investment products to sell. Terms were not disclosed, though analysts estimated that the purchase price was about $1.2 billion. Northwestern, which is owned by its policyholders, is the largest provider of individual life insurance and the fifth-biggest United States life insurer over all. Russell advises institutions and individuals with more than $1 trillion in assets, compiles stock indexes like the Russell 2000, a benchmark for small companies, and oversees about $42 billion in investment programs.

title: Oxygen Tank Explosion Intensified Fire
description: A fire that killed four people in a 20-story apartment building here on Sunday afternoon was fueled by an exploding oxygen canister, which intensified the blaze, officials said today. Although they had not yet determined a precise cause, investigators said that the fire appeared to have started accidentally.

description: To the Editor:

title: In the Hunt for Useful Genes, a Lot Depends on 'Snips'

description: Metropolitan Life Insurance, the nation's second-largest life insurer, has hired Goldman, Sachs to help it decide how to issue stock to investors, according to a report from an insurance-rating company.

title: In Midtown, Yet Another Shower of Bricks; Panic on Lexington Avenue, but No One Is Injured; Streets Are Closed
description: A section of masonry 12 feet high and 4 feet wide came loose from the 40th floor of an office building on Lexington Avenue yesterday morning, showering the crowded midtown street below with thousands of pieces of brick, two of which pierced the roof of a commuter bus.

title: 4 Shore Rides Closed After Steel Pier Accident
description: The owners of four amusement arcades along the Jersey Shore have closed their Rickey Rocket rides after a 180-foot steel tower on the Steel Pier ride collapsed on Sunday, apparently from a faulty weld, officials said yesterday.

title: Chicago Boys, 7 and 8, Charged In the Brutal Killing of a Girl, 11
description: In a case that has sent chills across this city, two boys, ages 7 and 8, have been charged with murdering an 11-year-old girl -- striking her with a rock, sexually molesting her and suffocating her with her own underwear -- apparently to take the bright blue bicycle she had been riding, the police said today.

title: Sales Booming for New Apple Computer
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had received more than 150,000 orders for its new iMac Macintosh computer since the company began taking orders a week ago. The iMac, which is aimed at the consumer and education markets, goes on sale Saturday at a suggested retail price of $1,299.

title: WING INDUSTRIES BUYING 80% OF ATRIUM FOR $180 MILLION
description: Wing Industries, a door maker based in Greenville, Tex., agreed yesterday to buy 80 percent of the Atrium Companies of Dallas for $180 million, expanding its business to include windows. Atrium said its controlling shareholder, Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., had agreed to sell its stake to Wing, which is controlled by the New York investment firm Ardshiel Inc. and GE Investment Private Placement Partners II, a unit of the General Electric Company. The R. G. Darby Company, another building-products concern controlled by GE Investment and Ardshiel, will be combined with Wing and Atrium, creating a company with more than $400 million in revenue.

title: Liberty to Face Struggling Mercury
description: Three and a half weeks ago, the roles were clearly reversed. The Liberty was struggling around the .500 mark while the Mercury was cruising at 11-3 when the teams squared off in Phoenix on July 18.

title: Battle Heats Up Over TV Talent
description: Comedy Central, whose biggest star, Craig Kilborn, is being lured away by CBS, is announcing today that it will replace him with someone CBS had once coveted: Jon Stewart.

title: Corrections
description: A sports chart yesterday showing how the Yankees' record this season compares to some past seasons misidentified the team they defeated in the 1961 World Series. It was the Cincinnati Reds, not the San Francisco Giants.

title: The Courtship Of Black Consumers; Corporate America Absorbs a Growing Number of Minority-Owned Businesses
description: Long before other girls her age were torturing their tresses with hot combs and chemical straighteners, Terri Gardner and her dog, a mutt named Cinnamon, became testers for the shampoos and pomades her father mixed in the basement of their brick bungalow on Chicago's South Side.

title: Hall of Fame Joins Past and Present
description: Ansel Williamson, the onetime slave who trained the first winner of the Kentucky Derby in 1875, was inducted into the thoroughbred Hall of Fame today as a legend of racing's past. He was joined by 45-year-old Bill Mott, who saddled Cigar and is a legend of the present, the youngest trainer ever enshrined.

title: Cosmo's editor moves to Glamour, heating up the competition between two ad-rich magazines.
description: RUTH WHITNEY, who made her multifaceted vision of young women the trademark of Glamour magazine for more than three decades, is retiring as its editor. S. I. Newhouse Jr., the chairman of Advance Publications, has recruited Bonnie Fuller, the editor of its archrival, Cosmopolitan, to succeed her.

title: State Dept. Halts a Pioneering Boeing-Russian Space Venture
description: Worried that sensitive aerospace data were being transferred overseas, the State Department has suspended all work between the Boeing Company and its Russian and Ukrainian partners in a pioneering venture meant to fire rockets into space from a floating platform at sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHONEY, TIMOTHY J., SENIOR
description: MAHONEY-Timothy J., Senior. His colleagues and friends at Marsh & McLennan Companies mourn Tim's passing on Thursday August 6th and express our deepest condolences to his family. Tim began a distinguished career in the Risk and Insurance Services field in 1960 and joined Marsh & McLennan in 1985. We will remember him for his commitment to Client Service and Business Development, and his sense of enthusiasm and humor as we worked together. A.J.C. Smith, Chairman and CEO

title: HARRAH'S TO ACQUIRE RIO SUITE HOTEL IN LAS VEGAS
description: Harrah's Entertainment Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Rio Hotel and Casino Inc. to entice customers from its other United States casinos to vacation at Rio's sole property, the upscale Rio Suite Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev. Under the deal, reported in The Wall Street Journal yesterday, Rio's shareholders will receive one Harrah's share for each Rio share held, or a total of about $518 million based on Friday's closing price. Harrah's, of Memphis, will also assume about $370 million of Rio debt. The Rio, one of the most luxurious resorts in Las Vegas, will help Harrah's, the second-largest United States casino company, bring more customers to that city. Shares of Harrah's rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $20.25; Rio was up 62.5 cents at $19.50.

title: Foreign Affairs; Forgive and Forget
description: In the wake of the U.S. embassy bombings in East Africa, the White House kept putting out the same sound bite on every network: An unnamed senior official was quoted as saying, ''We will not forgive and we will not forget.'' That is a noble sentiment. There is only one problem. If you look at the Clinton Administration's foreign policy over the past two years, there has been a consistent pattern of forgiving and forgetting.

title: Vigilance at the Embassy Gate
description: In the aftermath of Friday's bombings in Kenya and Tanzania, some have blamed the State Department for failing to provide adequate security. But as a former American Ambassador, I agree with the Clinton Administration officials who say that there is no such thing as absolute security at home or abroad.

title: Raymond E. Brown, 70, Dies; A Leading Biblical Scholar
description: The Rev. Raymond E. Brown, an internationally influential Roman Catholic biblical scholar who taught at Union Theological Seminary for two decades, died on Saturday in Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City, Calif. He was 70 and lived in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Public Lives last Wednesday about the radio personality Don Imus and his brother, Fred, misstated their role in the removal of an old structure on state property they are leasing from New Mexico. At the request of the Imuses, the state agreed to remove the structure; as leaseholders, the Imuses paid $6,696 as reimbursement for site clearance, not as a penalty.

description: The only rookie likely to be a starter among the 12 players the Jets drafted this year is far from being a glamorous figure or major collegiate name.

description: After years of delays and legal wrangling, jury selection began today in Susan H. McDougal's embezzlement trial in a Santa Monica courthouse.

description: As rescuers dug through the deep rubble of a collapsed building today in a final, desperate search for victims of the bombing at the American Embassy here, American law enforcement and intelligence teams began sifting through the scattered debris in an equally painstaking search for the tiniest clue that might provide evidence about the culprits.

description: British Airways P.L.C., Europe's largest airline, said yesterday that its pretax profit for the three months that ended on June 30 rose 59 percent, excluding a one-time gain a year earlier. The airline earned a pretax profit of $:145 million ($236 million), up from $:91 million a year earlier after excluding a one-time profit of $:129 million recorded from the sale of a stake in U S Airways Group Inc.

description: Inches. Fractions of inches, to be more precise. That is how close Mets Manager Bobby Valentine estimated Todd Hundley had come to hitting two home runs on Sunday afternoon.

description: The Mechanics Institute, 144 years old, featuring one of the oldest chess clubs in America, concluded its 1998 International Tournament with a victory for Julian Hodgson, a 35-year-old English grandmaster.

description: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton on Monday mourned the victims of the bombings in Africa, vowed to "do whatever we can to bring the murderers to justice" and said the United States would "not be deterred by the threat of other action."

description: A conservative former Defense Minister of France and an aide have been formally placed under investigation on suspicion of taking part in a money-laundering scheme to finance their political party.

Devoted Opa to his three angel grandchildren, Michelle, Julia, and Nikki, who gave him much joy. He also left his brother, John, with whom he was very close. title: FOOD STAMP FRAUD CITED IN NEW YORK
description: Federal officials said yesterday that they had broken up the largest food-stamp fraud ring ever in New York, a $60 million scheme in which individuals sold their food stamps to Chinese takeout restaurants, which in turn sold them to bodega owners, who then redeemed the coupons from the Government.

title: BB&T TO ADD THE BROKERAGE FIRM SCOTT & STRINGFELLOW
description: The BB&T Corporation, North Carolina's fourth-largest bank, agreed yesterday to buy the brokerage firm Scott & Stringfellow Inc. for $131 million to expand its investment banking and brokerage business. BB&T, which is based in Winston-Salem, will exchange one share for each share of Scott & Stringfellow, which split its stock last week. Scott & Stringfellow, which is based in Richmond, has 31 offices in the Carolinas, Virginia and West Virginia and manages more than $10 billion in assets. Its shares rose $2.50, to $31.25, but BB&T fell $1.0625, to $33.375.

Roger Sherman Derby, of Pontiac, MI., Joel Morse Derby, of Syracuse, New York, Leora Derby Howe, of Brattleboro, Vermont, Lizzie and Milo, of NYC. Interment private. title: COCA-COLA IN $187 MILLION DEAL FOR RUSSIAN BOTTLER
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it would buy one of its Russian bottlers for $187 million from Inchcape P.L.C. The London-based Inchcape is selling its bottlers to concentrate on its world-leading car-distribution business. It is also discussing selling its South American bottling operations to the Chilean bottler Embotelladora Arica S.A. Inchcape had planned to spin off its South American operations. Coca-Cola, based in Atlanta, regularly buys and sells bottlers as part of a strategy to consolidate its distribution system into a handful of key operators around the world. In the Russian acquisition, Coca-Cola is acquiring Inchcape bottling plants in Nizhny Novgorad, Volgograd, Samara and Yekaterinburg.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN STAYS WEAK. The dollar was little changed against the yen on expectations Tokyo will not quickly clean up the nation's banking mess. The dollar rose as high as 146.70 yen, before falling to 146.30 yen in New York.

title: Editorial Observer; The Architecture of Cellulose City
description: Last week I destroyed a nest that hornets had built inside my horse trailer. It was a perfect hornets' nest, a gibbous paper moon with a hole at the bottom, and it was, to speak now of its inhabitants, perfectly irascible. The nest was made of paper nearly the color of the trailer's aluminum walls, and I was surprised to feel -- I was wearing beekeeper's coveralls, a veil and gloves at the time -- how soft it was, like the globe of a Japanese lantern.

title: Thomas M. Mulry, 73, a Critic Of School Absenteeism Policies

title: '41 Best Seller Is Back and Clawing
description: Never mind what makes Sammy run. What makes Sammy sell?

title: Body of Suspect Found After Leap From Bridge
description: The body of a suspected jewel thief who jumped from the 149th Street Bridge on Sunday afternoon to escape capture was found beneath the bridge yesterday by police divers, the police said.

title: MUELLER TO ACQUIRE HALSTEAD, A COPPER TUBE MAKER
description: Mueller Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Halstead Industries for $92 million in stock. Halstead, based in Greensboro, N.C., operates a copper tube mill in Wynne, Ark., and a line sets operation in Clinton, Tenn. It had 1997 sales of $250 million. It also has a 15 percent interest in Kobe Copper Products Inc., which makes enhanced copper tubing in Pine Hall, N.C. Mueller, based in Memphis, makes copper, brass, aluminum and plastic products. It had revenue of $452.5 million in the six months ended June 27. Shares of Mueller slipped 25 cents, to $33.125.

title: Questions Over Met's Show of Minor Artist
description: All her life, Judith Rothschild was a journeyman artist. She studied art and worked steadily from the time she graduated from Wellesley College in 1943, exhibiting mainly in small, respectable galleries and always trying new ways to paint. But she never achieved much fame or following, and when she died in 1993 she was largely unknown to the public and to many in the art world.

title: Man, 21, Is Shot to Death in Attack Outside Courthouse
description: A 21-year-old man was shot to death today in front of the state courthouse here after being attacked by a group of young men, witnesses and the police said.

title: 2 Small Subsidiaries at Core of Dispute
description: As Bell Atlantic continued to negotiate yesterday with the union that represents the company's 73,000 striking workers, the talks focused in part on two of the telephone giant's small but fast-growing subsidiaries.

title: Valderrama to Return Against the MetroStars
description: Carlos Valderrama and the Miami Fusion have apparently worked out their differences. The Colombian midfielder has been practicing with Miami and he will return Saturday when the MetroStars visit the Fusion for a game that will be televised by ABC.

title: A Waiver Deal Puts One Question to Rest
description: Over the weekend in Denver, Brian McRae wondered who would spell him in center field if he needed a day off down the stretch.

title: REWARD IS OFFERED AND CLUES STUDIED IN AFRICAN BLASTS
description: The United States offered a $2 million reward today for information about the American embassy bombings, and eyewitnesses told investigators they had seen a truck that may have carried the bomb that wrecked the embassy here. The witnesses may provide clues to the identity of the terrorists who carried out the attack.

title: Tacky? It Beats Pipe Fitting, Mate
description: If you enjoyed the movie, you might get a kick out of what purports to be ''The Real Full Monty.'' Well, not 100 percent real, since tonight's ''Inside Story'' report on A&E doesn't come through with full frontal nudity. But if you're willing to settle for active buttocks, the display may serve.

title: Northrop Grumman in Deal
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation, the fourth-largest United States military contractor, agreed today to buy a closely held software company for $55 million in cash to broaden the computer and information services it sells to the Federal Government. Northrop Grumman plans to buy Inter-National Research Institute Inc., based in Reston, Va., which is expected to generate revenue of $60 million this year. The software company employs 500 and has eight sites in the United States and one in Britain.

title: Do Clinton Haters Have Own Agenda?; New Salem Witch Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Medicare Vastly Overpaid H.M.O.'s, an Inquiry Finds
description: Health maintenance organizations have been receiving more than $1 billion a year in overpayments from the Medicare trust fund because their administrative costs are ''highly inflated,'' Federal investigators said today.

title: Broadway Producer Has Big Accounting Woes
description: Livent Inc., the producer of such Broadway shows as ''Ragtime'' and ''Show Boat,'' announced yesterday that an internal investigation had found serious accounting problems involving millions of dollars.

title: St. John's Isn't No. 1 And Is Glad That's So
description: A preseason coaches' poll yesterday predicted that Duquesne would win the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference football title and that St. John's would finish in third place.

title: State Asks Oxford to Increase Its Reserves
description: The New York State Insurance Department announced yesterday that it had asked Oxford Health Plans, the troubled managed-care company, to increase its reserves for its New York plan by $152 million to insure that it had sufficient funds to pay medical claims over the next year.

title: Study Finds More Fraternal Twins in Lands of Plenty
description: IT is well known that twin births occur when a single fertilized egg splits very early in embryonic life, producing identical twins, or when separate eggs are fertilized, producing nonidentical, or fraternal, twins. But much remains unknown about why an embryo might split or why a woman might release more than one egg when she ovulates.

title: Still Seeking A Perfect Balance
description: As a first-year law student, my future husband, Kris, walked into the school's career counseling office to ask about strategies for combining a successful career with a happy family life. The surprised (female) counselors complimented him for his progressive attitude -- but offered not a single word of practical advice.

title: Do Clinton Haters Have Own Agenda?
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Prices Steady as Strong Demand Is Expected at Auctions
description: Treasury bonds were little changed yesterday, with yields at one-month lows and prices at highs, reflecting expectations that Asian financial turmoil would bolster demand at the Treasury's $37 billion quarterly debt sale this week.

title: I.R.S. Commissioner to Name Executive Team to Remake Troubled Agency
description: Commissioner Charles O. Rossotti of the Internal Revenue Service, using the broad powers Congress gave him last month to pick his executive team to remake the beleaguered agency, will appoint two deputies and a chief computer executive today.

title: Grief at Inexplicable Loss As Victims Are Buried
description: Mtendje Rajabu was laid to rest today in a deep, sandy grave under a grove of coconut trees, three days after a terrorist bomb killed her as she stood on duty at the entrance to the American Embassy in a snappy uniform with red epaulets on her small shoulders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, PADDY
description: QUINN-Paddy. On August 8, 1998. It is a sad day with the passing of Paddy Quinn for Sheila and all those who knew and loved him. He will be so missed forever in our hearts. Come and say goodbye to Paddy at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, Wednesday, 10 A.M. Burial to follow at St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, New York.

title: Executive Changes
description: CENDANT CORP., Parsippany, N.J., promoted Mary Mahoney to president and chief executive of its Howard Johnson hotel chain, succeeding Stephen Phillips, who will become chief executive at the AFM Hospitality Corp. in Toronto.

title: Unwanted Children / From Hungary to America, and Back : Two Adoptions End in Return to Sender
description: EGER, Hungary  When they left the state children's home here in 1996, 7-year-old Gabor and 8-year-old Karoly were looking forward to a bright future as the newly adopted sons of two American couples in the wealthy suburbs of Connecticut.

title: Free Speech and Public Safety
description: The ''Million Youth March'' proposed for Harlem over Labor Day weekend presents some classic questions about the constitutional rights of free expression for people with abhorrent views. Khalid Abdul Muhammad, the march organizer, has a record of outrageous anti-Semitic rhetoric. He wants to stage his event along Malcolm X Boulevard in Harlem, an area that New York City's police have rejected for reasons of traffic and security. Some black leaders not aligned with Mr. Muhammad have nevertheless worried out loud about censoring people who want to take part in what is being billed as a march to empower minority youth.

title: A Letup By Yanks? The Twins Only Wish
description: As a longtime player and coach with the Yankees, Frank Crosetti called Babe Ruth, Joe DiMaggio and Mickey Mantle teammates, and when Crosetti counseled Joe Torre in Oakland last week, the Yankees' manager listened. After all, Torre said, Crosetti has enough World Series rings for all his toes and fingers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLIED SIGNAL INC., Morristown, N.J., the maker of aerospace and automotive products, formally began a $9.8 billion hostile bid for AMP Inc., Harrisburg, Pa., a maker of electrical connection devices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLINER, OSKAR
description: OLINER-Oskar. The Yeshiva of Far Rockaway extends heartfelt condolences to our friend, Mr. Martin Oliner and family upon the tragic loss of their father and guide, Oskar Oliner, O''H. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Just a Bunch of Guys Who Har-mo-niiiiize; The Sound of Barbershop Quartets Echoes Happily Through the Land
description: Five years ago at Christmas time, John Gonzalez, a munitions specialist with the Defense Department, took his teen-age son, Marco, for a haircut in their new hometown, Albuquerque, N.M. While they were waiting, a quartet of a cappella singers came in to entertain the customers with carols, wringing an irresistible sentiment from the familiar holiday music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIDELSON, FEIGA
description: EIDELSON-Feiga. The entire family of the East Midwood Jewish Center profoundly mourns the passing of the loving and devoted wife or our distinguished Cantor Emeritus Joseph Eidelson. She was a paragon of warmth, sensitivity, virtue and integrity. She will be sorely missed by us all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her beautiful family. Dr. Alvin Kass, Rabbi Marsha Shlefstein, President

title: A Man of Outsized Acts and Spending
description: Garth H. Drabinsky, the Canadian showman whose flamboyant rise to prominence on Broadway has apparently come to a halt, was a man who inspired both admiration and resentment from his colleagues in the staid business of live theater.

title: Former Special Counsels See Need To Alter Law That Created Them
description: They are a rarefied roster of not quite two dozen, the men and women who have served as independent counsels investigating high Government officials over the last 20 years. They have delved into accusations of everything from cocaine use by a senior White House aide to perjury, influence-peddling and favor-trading, and have produced decidedly mixed results, from no indictments to convictions to reversals on appeal.

title: Sports of The Times; The Legend No One Has Heard Of
description: WHEN he steps on the court with the one of the all-time greats, with a Connors or a Borg, he hears people say, ''Who the hell is this guy?'' Mansour Bahrami has a story to tell, though, and it happens to be the stuff of legend.

title: Stock Buyback for Payless
description: Payless Shoesource Inc. said today that it would buy back up to $150 million of its stock. The buyback represents about 8 percent of the company's outstanding shares. Payless, based in Topeka, operates a chain of more than 4,250 discount shoe stores. It had sales of $1.4 billion in the six months that ended Aug. 1. The stock closed at $56 today, up 6.25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Holocaust Survivors Tell of Horrors at Trial of Accused Guard
description: Three Holocaust survivors, testifying in the Federal case against a Brooklyn man accused of hiding his wartime role in liquidating European Jews, said yesterday that no one who worked for the Nazis in the death camps and ghettos of Poland could have been unaware of the daily horrors and mass murders that took place there.

title: INSIDE
description: Another Shower of Bricks

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: The Indie Scene Revs Up
description: It wasn't just your imagination. Finally, there's proof that department stores and mass-marketed designers have reached an intolerable level of banality: fashion's indie movement has begun.

title: BASEBALL: And Now Batting Cleanup . . .; Maybe Valentino the Beanie Baby Can't Hit, but Who Cares?
description: Forget Mark McGwire, Sammy Sosa, Ken Griffey Jr., Kerry Wood and Juan Gonzalez. Baseball's real stars this season, the ones almost guaranteed to pack the house, are Peanut, Glory, Stretch, Valentino, Derby, Chip and Tuffy.

title: Pepsico to Post a $200 Million Tax Gain
description: Pepsico Inc. said today that it planned to post a third-quarter tax gain of at least $200 million from its Puerto Rico concentrate operations.

title: A Conversation: With Tyler Volk; Using Flows and Fluxes to Demythologize the Unity of Life
description: Sometimes science and myth merge to make a kind of chimerical beast, and perhaps the most magical of those Chimeras is the Gaia hypothesis, developed a quarter century ago by James Lovelock, a British atmospheric chemist, and Lynn Margulis, an American microbiologist. The notion that our planet's surface functions like a giant organism, one interconnected whole, was named after the Greek earth goddess, and it has attracted not just pagans and mystics but also atmospheric chemists, ecologists, oceanographers, microbiologists and geologists.

title: Fix for Some E-Mail Security Problems Is Reported
description: The leading provider of software that routes electronic mail through the Internet plans to announce on Tuesday that it has developed a simple and free fix for a security vulnerability discovered in three E-mail programs made by the Microsoft Corporation and the Netscape Communications Corporation.

title: SARA LEE BUYING HOT-BEVERAGE UNIT FROM QUAKER OATS
description: The Sara Lee Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Continental Coffee Products Company from the Quaker Oats Company. Terms were not disclosed. Continental Coffee, of Houston, markets coffee and other hot beverages to food-services, convenience store and warehouse club customers. It has annual revenue of $149 million. Sara Lee, the food and consumer products company, and Quaker Oats, which makes food and beverage products, are based in Chicago. Shares of Sara Lee rose $1.50, to $50.50, while Quaker Oats slipped 18.75 cents, to $55.

title: Essay; Facing Modern Perils, Medical Schools Ponder the Classics
description: The humble microbe E. coli showed up all green and evil on the cover of Time magazine last week and made it official: This is becoming the year of the germ.

title: Uneasy About Timing of Fund-Raisers, Clinton Shortens Trip
description: President Clinton began a transcontinental fund-raising spree today, but his spokesman said that the President felt uncomfortable on the political circuit so soon after the bombings at two United States embassies in Africa and that as a result he was cutting short his time on the road.

title: Judge Halts CUNY Remedial Cutback Efforts
description: A state judge yesterday ordered the City University of New York to temporarily cease preparations to end remedial classes at its senior colleges pending a trial on whether the university violated the state's open meeting law.

title: Minolta's Account Switches Agencies
description: The Minolta Corporation USA said yesterday that it had named Hill, Holliday/Altschiller in New York to handle its account, which had been handled for three years by Lois/E.J.L. in New York, part of Lois/U.S.A. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Prostitution Is Charged At an Estate Mansion
description: A woman described by prosecutors as a Morris County socialite was charged yesterday with turning her 20-room mansion into a house of prostitution that catered to local executives.

title: Hong Kong Index Hits 5-Year Low
description: Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell to its lowest level in five years, amid concern over tumbling corporate earnings and the stability of China's currency.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a series of Broadway performances by the comedian Jerry Seinfeld misstated the name of a television talk show that he appeared on last week. It is ''Late Show With David Letterman,'' not ''Late Night With David Letterman.''

title: U.N. Chief Reports Little Help in Monitoring Balkan Arms Ban
description: Five months after the Security Council imposed an arms embargo to quell the fighting in Kosovo, no international organization has volunteered to do intensive monitoring of the ban, Secretary General Kofi Annan told Council members today.

title: Black Filmmakers Win Prizes and an Audience
description: The Urbanworld International Film Festival, a competitive festival for black independent filmmakers now in its second year, announced its winners on Sunday after presenting more than 70 commercial and independent films over five days to an audience of 5,000 at the Cineplex Odeon Worldwide Plaza Cinemas in Manhattan.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I expected kids to clamor for it, but it was fun to watch grown men with their Beanie Babies. And you'd be surprised how many players have their own collections.''

title: Charlestown Journal; On the Whole, Caribbean Isle Is Not Part of a Sum
description: Barely two miles of water separate the pair of islands that make up the tiny Caribbean nation of St. Kitts and Nevis. But if the 10,000 or so people who live on the 36-square-mile speck of land called Nevis voted as predicted today in a referendum on secession, the smallest country in the Western Hemipshere will soon be severed in two.

August 12, 10 AM, Sunset Chapel, Northern Boulevard, Manhasset.

title: A Sad Stop in Germany, Before the Last Trip Home
description: In silence broken only by a drum roll, the flag-draped coffins bearing the bodies of 11 Americans killed in the explosion at the United States Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, last Friday were received with full military honors early today at the American Air Force base here.

title: 3 Strikeouts Continue McGwire's Frustration
description: A dejected Mark McGwire emerged from the showers at Busch Stadium with a blue towel wrapped around his waist, another wrapped around his neck, and a forlorn look on his face. The muscular giant who is chasing Roger Maris's 37-year-old record of 61 homers in a season had a dismal game tonight, striking out three times against the Mets while the Cardinals lost, 4-2.

title: Ford Cutting Average Price On Cars and Trucks 0.3%
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that the average price of its 1999 model cars and trucks will decrease three-tenths of 1 percent, or about $61, from comparably equipped 1998 models. It dropped the prices of its highest-volume cars, the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable, significantly.

title: The Melding of Mind With Machine May Be the Next Phase of Evolution
description: WE humans have been trying to accelerate our own evolution for millennia, and while in some ways we appear to be getting away with it, biological computing could well test the forbearance of Mother Nature.

title: Moving the Spirit (and Feet) With Ancient Utterances Updated
description: All three bands on the bill at Central Park Summerstage on Sunday afternoon reached the peaks of their sets with the same refrain: ''Qalander mustt mustt,'' chanted and declaimed and hurled aloft with the shouts of the audience. Qalander was a 13th-century mystic renowned for his intoxication with divine love; the music encouraged and embodied that ecstasy.

title: Congo Says It's Reversing Rebel Gains
description: Claiming the Congo Government's first major success against a week-old insurrection, Congolese officials said today that their troops had succeeded in beating back rebels who had captured several strategic towns in the southwest of the country, encircling many of them at a military base.

title: Giants May Gamble on Plan for Safety
description: There is a secret plan afoot for the Giants' rookie safety, Shaun Williams. But something this simple can't stay a secret for long.

description: Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller, criticized the Board of Education yesterday for failing to keep accurate records of student immunizations, saying about 30 percent of the students in a group of high-risk districts his staff examined had not received all the shots required by state law.

title: Police Think Church Worker Knew His Killer
description: A 71-year-old church worker who was stabbed to death in the parish offices adjoining a downtown church here during Sunday Mass may have known his assailant, the police said today.

title: Scientist at Work: Dr. Patricia Wright; Saving Madagascar's Bounty for Its Lemurs and Its People
description: Patricia Wright's trail to Madagascar and environmental heroism began in the 1960's with an act that is now considered the antithesis of conservation: the purchase in a Brooklyn pet store of an owl monkey, and then a second one to keep it company.

title: By Design; Cargo, at Home and Abroad
description: Ever since Yves Saint Laurent turned the sailor's pea jacket into fashion in 1962, military surplus clothes have become sources of inspiration for many a designer. This year, multipocket cargo pants turned up in men's and women's fashion collections on both sides of the Atlantic and will certainly be filling store racks in the coming months.

title: LaFontaine Decides To Call It Quits
description: For 15 seasons with the Islanders, the Buffalo Sabres and the Rangers, Pat LaFontaine was one of the National Hockey League's most productive centers. At a news conference today at Madison Square Garden, at age 33 and concerned about his six concussions, he will retire.

description: CHESIN-Cecil Steuer. 8/11/96. Mom, you are with me always. Forever in our hearts. Love, Sorrell

title: Health Care Deal Crumbles As Stock Dives
description: In a much-anticipated parting, the United Healthcare Corporation's $5.5 billion acquisition of a rival health care giant, Humana Inc., collapsed over the weekend after the value of United Healthcare stock fell $2.9 billion late last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMEN, PHYLLIS
description: KAMEN-Phyllis. Much beloved wife of Paul, passed away on August 9. Born in Brooklyn, she taught in the New York City Public Schools for 20 years. Nothing gave her more pleasure than her large extended family including four children Leslie, Randy, Jeffrey and Scott; and eight grandchildren Elissa, Ari, Adar, Amy, Max, Hannah, Abigail and Daniel. She is also survived by a sister Pearl and a brother Alvin. She lived in Belle Harbor, Queens, and Fort Lauderdale, Florida. There will be a hole in the lives of all who knew and loved her. Services to be held on August 11 at 1 P.M., at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue. Donations in her name may be sent to Hadassah.

title: Personal Health; A Study Guide to Scientific Studies
description: TO paraphrase P. T. Barnum, there's a study born every minute, and there are countless suckers out there ready to believe anything they hear or read. Many people make significant changes in what they eat, drink, take or do based on research that is far from conclusive. Some become unduly alarmed about suspected but unproven risks to health, especially ones in the air, water or food supply, that they cannot control. Others decide that, because what is ''fact'' one week is sometimes contradicted by a new study finding the next, they won't change any habit until ''the scientists make up their minds.''

description: ROTH-Joseph. To Carol, Peter, Noreen, Ryan, Andy, Trisha and Family, our thoughts and prayers are with you. Love, Dorothy & Joe Donovan & Family

title: Dance Award Goes to Jacob's Pillow
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival has won the 47th Annual Capezio Dance Award. The summer festival, in Becket, Mass., was honored in a ceremony on Saturday night at its Ted Shawn Theater. The award is given to dancers, choreographers, dance companies and institutions in recognition of their contributions to dance in the United States. The Pillow is the first producing organization to win the prize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALM, MICHAEL D.
description: PALM-Michael D. Of New York City, at his home in Telluride, CO., on August 7, 1998, of heart failure caused by complications from AIDS. Mr. Palm was the co-founder of Centre Reinsurance. Founded in 1988, Centre Reinsurance grew to become a major diversified provider of financial services and products. He was one of the most significant philanthropic forces in the Gay and Lesbian Community. He provided substantial support to the Human Rights Campaign, where he served on the Board of Directors, GlAAD (the Gay and Lesbian Alliance against Defamation), and other organizations. He also provided significant funding for AIDS Organizations, including GMHC, where he was Senior Vice President of the Board of Directors, TAG (Treatment Action Group), and the Cornell Clinical Trials Unit. The Michael Palm Treatment Center in GMHC's new building was named in his honor. The Michael Palm Foundation, established in 1995, has provided over $10 million in grants to these and other organizations involving arts and education, including the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Metropolitan Opera, and Yale University. Michael is survived by his mother, Irma Palm, and his sister, Melissa Jamula, both of Reading, Pennsylvania. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to The Michael Palm Foundation, for information contact (212) 206-8209.

title: Congress Exceeds Its Reach
description: A House committee's vote last week to cite Attorney General Janet Reno for contempt is no answer to the standoff over her refusal to hand over memorandums advising her on whether to appoint an independent counsel to investigate Democratic Party fund-raising. This has made what should be a rational accommodation of the legitimate needs of two separate branches of Government into a contest of wills.

title: Genesis Direct Buys Edge
description: Genesis Direct Inc., a mail-order catalogue company that went public in May, has purchased the Edge Company catalogue for $21 million in cash and notes and $1.7 million in stock to expand its line of gift and collectibles for middle-aged men. Genesis Direct markets sportswear for the National Basketball Association and Major League Baseball.

title: Swiss Center Lease Is Sold
description: The lease on the Swiss Center, a landmark office property in the Rockefeller Center complex, has been sold to a group headed by the German investors Aby Rosen and Michael Fuchs.

title: The German Consensus
description: Gerhard Schroder, the German Social Democrat who may put an end to Helmut Kohl's chancellorship in elections next month, came to Washington last week to see and be seen with President Clinton. Along with trying to assure Germany that strong ties to America will continue, Mr. Schroder is reinforcing parallels with a politician he admires. He paints himself as a tough and energetic reformer running against a stodgy incumbent.

title: Two Agencies Are Expanding Abroad
description: A direct marketing agency and a health care communications agency announced overseas acquisitions. Terms were not disclosed.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE PLUMMETS. Coffee prices fell more than 7 percent as concerns eased that a port strike in Brazil would disrupt exports at a time of abundant supplies. Coffee for September delivery fell 9.75 cents, to $1.245 a pound.

description: As his rendezvous with a grand jury draws near, the face that President Clinton shows in public could not seem more relaxed.

description: 40 Years of Staying

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest yesterday, referring to an article about trading in the stock market, misstated the close of the Dow Jones industrial average on Monday. It was 8,574.85, not 8,674.85. (The article reported the close correctly.)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: The Race for the Melons Has Begun
description: HAND MELONS ARE HERE. They've put the sign out on Route 29 in Greenwich, N.Y. It's not much of a come-on, but cars are rolling into the parking lot of the Hand Melon Farm, lured by the muskmelons (commonly but incorrectly called cantaloupes in the United States), which run second only to the horses at Saratoga in local popularity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACHER, ARTHUR
description: LACHER-Arthur. Dedicated physician and devoted Jew who served man and God with abiding grace and love. Taken in the prime of life from his loving wife, Ellen, his adoring children, Jason, Rebecca and Dr. Jonas Leibowitz and granddaughter Nina Joy. They together with his beloved mother, Lee Lacher, adoring sister, Susan Alter Klaperman, beloved in-law parents, Louis Pearl Marks have lost their dearest treasure. Funeral today, at 11:30 A.M. at Gutterman and Musicant, Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: Sedgwick Reports Loss in First Half
description: Sedgwick Group P.L.C., the world's third-largest insurance broker, said yesterday that it had a first-half loss after it set aside $:80 million ($130 million) to cover the cost of reimbursing some pension investors. Sedgwick had a loss of $:7.1 million, compared with a profit of $:46.2 million a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUMBINNER, ROSLYN SINGER.
description: GUMBINNER-Roslyn Singer. On August 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Devoted mother of the late Mark N. Finston, and the late Joan Finston. Survived by her daughter-in-law Beth Waters Finston and her adoring granddaughters Betsy and Deborah Finston. Dearest sister of Hortense Ginsberg of New York City and Edwin Singer of Corpus Christi, Texas. and sister-in-law of Nell Singer. Funeral services private. Donations in her memory may be made to the Beth Israel Medical Center, 10 Nathan D. Pearlman Place, New York City, New York.

title: Jeter's Play Improves at Every Turn
description: His face cemetery serious, Derek Jeter briefly watched Joe Torre answer questions from reporters at Yankee Stadium yesterday before announcing that he could handle Torre's job as the Yankees' manager. Jeter walked away, a sliver of a grin giving away his true feelings.

title: Balloon Soars Over Atlantic, Setting Record In Solo Flight
description: Speeding along at more than 100 miles an hour, the adventurer Steve Fossett yesterday became the first balloonist to cross the South Atlantic Ocean.

title: Nets' Williams Is on the Fast Track
description: Jayson Williams is not someone who is comfortable with idle time. With the National Basketball Association players locked out, the All-Star center for the Nets is spending his off season running from one appearance to another trying to fill the gaps in his schedule.

title: New Jersey Man Denies Links To World Trade Center Blast
description: A New Jersey man and native of the Gaza Strip who has been detained for the last five months based on classified allegations that he is linked to the World Trade Center bombing denied those charges today in deportation hearings here.

title: Lessons in Dance and in Life
description: Mirrors line a wall, floor to ceiling, in a room drenched with sunlight. A cassette player pumps out jazz rhythms, and an instructor offers direction, encouragement and praise. Student dancers explore new movements, performing to reflections of themselves. They are their own audience, and the feedback is instantaneous.

title: Moscow Journal; For the Rolling Stones' Fans, Satisfaction at Last
description: Mick Jagger said it all, in Russian.

title: A Clinton Adviser Testifies About First Days of Lewinsky Crisis
description: For 90 minutes, Harry Thomason, a television producer and friend of the Clintons, testified here today before the grand jury about how he helped the President navigate the first chaotic days of the Monica S. Lewinsky crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESSINGER, PAUL
description: SCHLESSINGER-Paul. The Doctors and Staff of SLPT MD PC mourn the passing of Paul J. R. Schlessinger, MD. Our deepest sympathies to his family. Dr. Schlessinger was the founder of this OB/GYN practice in 1950. Until his retirement he was a dedicated and concerned physician. He will be missed by all.

title: Camp, With Reading, Writing and Nature
description: Eleven-year-old Mamasa Njie knew all about the mosquitoes, poison ivy, uncomfortable mattresses and occasional homesickness that awaited her at camp. But she had not counted on three hours a day of classwork in reading, social studies and math and science.

title: KEY ENERGY TO BUY THE REST OF DAWSON FOR $202 MILLION
description: Key Energy Group Inc. agreed to buy Dawson Production Services Inc. for about $202 million in cash, to create the world's largest oil and natural gas well service company. Key will pay $17.50 each for the 11.5 million Dawson shares outstanding on a fully diluted basis. It will also assume about $150 of Dawson's debt. Key already owns a 7.4 percent stake in Dawson, which it acquired in June. Dawson's stock rose $3.625, or 28 percent, to $16.50, while Key rose 12.5 cents, to $9.9375. Key, based in East Brunswick, N.J., raised its offer after failing to entice Dawson's board earlier this month with a bid of $14 a share.

title: H. B. FULLER PLANS TO TRIM WORK FORCE AND CLOSE PLANTS
description: The H. B. Fuller Company, North America's leading maker of industrial adhesives, said yesterday that it would trim its 6,000-employee work force by 10 percent and close a quarter of its adhesives plants in the next 18 months as part of a plan to save $30 million a year. The company said it expected to take a pretax charge of $40 million to $45 million in the next six quarters as a result of the plan. H. B. Fuller also warned that profit from continuing operations in the third quarter ending Aug. 31 would be below the 78 cents a basic share it earned a year earlier. The St. Paul-based maker of adhesives, sealants and paints said it would consolidate operations, close plants and sell units to try to bolster profits.

title: Church Says Burglar Sought Saint's Icon
description: Queens detectives were dispatched to dust for fingerprints yesterday around the altar of St. Irene Chrysovalantou Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Astoria, where church officials said they were once again the victims of an attempt to steal their most precious treasure: the icon of St. Irene that, the faithful maintain, wept on the eve of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Judge Rules Gates Must Give Deposition in Public
description: A Federal judge ordered yesterday that the Government's pretrial questioning of William H. Gates and other executives of the Microsoft Corporation must be opened up to news organizations.

title: Pale Dry Sherries: The Fresher the Better
description: THE Bordeaux region of France runs on Champagne. Whether it is an anniversary dinner at a back-country chateau or a business lunch in town, the table wine will be red Bordeaux, but the aperitif will always be Champagne.

title: Are Watergate Comparisons Fair?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bell Atlantic Workers End Strike; Pact Gives Union Job Assurances
description: Bringing a swift conclusion to a two-day-old strike that had begun to inconvenience telephone customers from Maine to Virginia, Bell Atlantic employees returned to work yesterday after reaching a tentative agreement with management that insures that jobs in the company's high-technology growth areas will go to union employees.

title: British Petroleum Is Buying Amoco in $48.2 Billion Deal
description: British Petroleum P.L.C. announced today that it would acquire the American oil giant Amoco for $48.2 billion in stock in the largest oil industry merger ever.

title: State's Crime Rate Falls For Fifth Straight Year
description: The state's crime rate fell for the fifth straight year in 1997, by 7 percent, and the total number of reported crimes was the lowest since 1973, according to figures released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, HERMAN
description: MARCUS-Herman, on August 10, 1998, in his 88th year. Devoted husband of the late Ruth Marcus. Beloved father of Jo-Ann Kalb and Linda Marcus Sherry. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan and Jamie Kalb, and Dana Sherry. Graveside service Wednesday 11AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: A Brooklyn Race Pits Two Former Friends and Allies
description: They were not merely up-and-coming officials from the same Brooklyn neighborhood, but kindred politicians close enough to have been the best of friends for years. Over nightcaps in neighborhood bars, they planned their political futures. They worked on each other's campaigns. They went to family reunions together and even, at times, vacationed together.

title: Holyfield Taking a Cut Even Before the Fight
description: A couple of months ago at a charity golf tournament in New Jersey, Evander Holyfield joked that he would probably have to pay out of his own pocket to make a bout against Vaughn Bean, the International Boxing Federation's No. 1 contender.

title: No Wood-Burning Oven? Crank Up the Grill
description: IN Sonoma County, California, this spring, a friend and I were treated to a wonderful home-cooked meal of rack of lamb grilled over a wood fire. The chops were so succulent and so delicately flavored that we immediately started thinking about building a wood oven in the backyard of the house in rural Vermont where we spend a lot of time in the summer. Then we thought better of it, because the remnants of meals might be just one more attraction for the wildlife that frequents the place -- deer, porcupines, bear.

title: Brother Questioned in Beating of Brooklyn Toddler
description: A 14-year-old boy was being questioned last night in the severe beating of his 2-year-old sister yesterday afternoon in the family's Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: Despite Loan Package, Russian Stocks and Bonds Fall Again
description: Russia's markets were swept along in a global economic downdraft today. By the end of the day's trading, stocks and Government bonds were selling at near-historic lows -- that is, even lower than on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SKLOVER, M. CHARLES.
description: SKLOVER-M. Charles. Three years since you are gone. Missing your love, your intellect, your kindness. Love forever. Branka

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: W. H. BRADY CO., Milwaukee, an industrial products manufacturer, will cut about 200 full-time positions, or about 7.4 percent of its work force, to reduce costs.

title: F.B.I. Sifts Vehicles' Scraps From Debris for Blast Clues
description: F.B.I. agents began reconstructing hundreds of pieces of vehicles blown apart by a powerful bomb at the American Embassy here last Friday, in a painstaking attempt to identify the pickup truck that apparently carried the explosives.

title: GUIDANT AGREES TO ACQUIRE INCONTROL FOR $135 MILLION
description: The Guidant Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Incontrol Inc. for $6 a share, or $135 million. Guidant said it would account for the transaction as a purchase and take a $90 million charge. Incontrol, based in Redmond, Wash., designs devices for the treatment of atrial arrhythmia, a common heart-rhythm disorder. Guidant, based in Indianapolis, provides products and services to treat cardiovascular and vascular diseases. Guidant's shares fell $2.0625, to $72.5625. Shares of Incontrol were up 34.375 cents at $5.625.

description: STACKEL-Belle (Bobbi) nee Rottell. On August 11. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Loving mother of Linda Fleisher & Stephen Stackel. Devoted grandmother of Kenneth Fleisher, Dean Stackel, Stacey Bennett, Gregory Stackel and Dayna Fleisher. Proud great grandmother of Alexa Paige, Brett Tyler Bennett, and Benjamin James Stackel. Loving sister of Sol Rottell, Ruth Papier and Al Rottell. Services are today 1 P.M., at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels'', Queen Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, New York. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: Clinton's Way Out
description: When President Clinton testifies to the grand jury on Monday, he isn't completely limited to one of two approaches: denying that he had sex with Monica Lewinsky or acknowledging that he did. There is a third option that sophisticated lawyers like the President's would surely offer him.

title: Judge Lets Strip Club Reopen, With Dancers Wearing Bikinis
description: A Bronx strip club that was one of the first closed under the city's new zoning law can reopen, a judge ruled yesterday after the club's owner promised that they would clothe their dancers in bikinis.

title: Liberties
description: It makes perfect sense that Geraldo could be the ''NBC Nightly News'' anchor for the millennium. It makes perfect sense that ''60 Minutes'' could hire Murphy Brown as a correspondent. It makes perfect sense that Bill Clinton could go onto the board of Dreamworks.

description: HIRSCHHORN - Bernard. Forty years and the memory keeps churning, to be what you wanted me to be is still my yearning. Herbert

title: De Beers Profits Fall After Cut in Sales
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. and De Beers Centenary A.G. said yesterday that their combined earnings fell by 33 percent in the first half of 1998 because of a decision to cut back on diamond sales to support prices. The two units of the South African diamond producer said that their combined first-half net income fell to $405 million, from $606 million a year earlier.

title: Continental Set To Take Charge
description: Continental Airlines, the nation's fifth-largest airline, said today that it would take a third-quarter charge of $77 million to retire jumbo jets operating in Asia and turboprop commuter planes.

title: Harvard Is Favored To Repeat
description: Harvard's defense of its title and the opening of the $45 million, 27,800-seat Princeton Stadium shared the focus yesterday during the Ivy League's media day at Lyman Orchards Golf Club in Middlefield, Conn.

description: Lambert Bridge Merlot 1995, Sonoma County, Calif. About $20.

title: AVIATION SALES IN DEAL FOR PRIMARK'S MAINTENANCE UNIT
description: The Aviation Sales Company agreed yesterday to buy the Triad International Maintenance Company from the Primark Corporation for about $70 million in cash in a bid to service the airplane-maintenance needs of more major airlines. Aviation Sales said Triad operated a wide-body-aircraft repair station in Greensboro, N.C., and had $72 million in revenue for the six months ended June 30. The Miami-based Aviation Sales, which manufactures and repairs airplane parts and distributes parts for customers, had $256.9 million in revenue in 1997. The acquisition will help Aviation Sales expand its airplane-maintenance business, which is now restricted to smaller planes.

description: Closing Up

title: Vinegar's Secret Life, as an Aperitif
description: CLUSTERED on a silver tray in the center of Seasons, the restaurant in the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago, are slender hand-blown flasks of liquids in tones of pale straw, amber and burgundy.

title: Infant Mortality Falls Again, In Step With Rate Nationwide
description: The number of babies who died before their first birthday continued to fall in New York City last year -- though not in all neighborhoods -- in a decline health officials say reflects less drug use, better prenatal care and fewer pregnancies among teen-agers.

title: RELTEC TO PAY $200 MILLION FOR POSITRON FIBER OF CANADA
description: The Reltec Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Positron Fiber Systems Corporation, a Canadian maker of telecommunications equipment, for $13.625 a share, a total of $200 million. Reltec, based in Cleveland, provides telecommunications systems, components and services. Positron, based in Montreal, develops broadband-access network systems for local telecommunications carriers. The shares of Positron Fiber rose $1.625, to $13, while Reltec fell $1.4375 a share, to $33.4375. Reltec said Positron's largest shareholder, Positron Inc., which owns 27 percent of Positron Fiber, had agreed to throw its shares behind Reltec's offer.

title: 3 Executives Are Charged In Kickbacks For Repairs
description: Three executives of construction companies who supervised school and hospital renovations were charged yesterday with conspiring to take tens of thousands of dollars in kickbacks from other companies they helped obtain work on the projects.

title: Blockbuster Music Is Sold by Viacom
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its chain of Blockbuster Music stores to Wherehouse Entertainment Inc. for $115 million in cash, shedding a business that had not met expectations.

title: Retired Seaman Is Found Robbed and Murdered
description: An 81-year-old retired merchant marine was found murdered in his Staten Island home yesterday, apparently the victim of a robbery, the police said.

title: Methodists Act Against Homosexual Unions
description: The United Methodist Church's highest court ruled yesterday that ministers who conduct same-sex unions violate the denomination's law and can be tried in its courts.

title: TV Notes; Comedic Musical Chairs
description: Craig Kilborn might get to keep his ''Five Questions'' comedy bit when he moves from Comedy Central to CBS, but he shouldn't expect to get on the air anytime soon, certainly not before Jon Stewart slides into the chair Mr. Kilborn is vacating as star of ''The Daily Show.''

title: 'Bunny' Breeds Rapidly, Sinking Belarus Economy
description: It's not easy to get fiscal respect when your national currency is nicknamed the bunny, as in, ''That will be 500,000 bunnies, madam. Cash or check?'' But in Russia's westerly neighbor Belarus, where the bunny is king, appellation is the least of the economic worries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEIROWITZ, JANE
description: MEIROWITZ - Jane. Beloved mother of Sharon and Arthur Gage, Ellen and Richard Rose. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Dear sister of Ruthe Piken. Services were held on Tuesday, August 11.

description: KOCH - WESER - Gertrude (nee Dinkelacker), 92 years, on August 10, 1998 in Pleasantville, New York. Survived by her husband Reimer Koch-Weser, her daughter Gisela O'Brien, her son Dr. Peter KochWeser. Five grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Funeral arrangements were private. For information Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, New York.

title: TV Notes; Civil Rights Era As a Mini-Series
description: In what is intended to be one of the first big television projects of the new century, ABC is to present an eight-hour mini-series based on the civil rights-era books by Taylor Branc to be broadcast in January and February of 2000.

title: SPORTS AUTHORITY REJECTS BID BY GART SPORTS
description: Sports Authority Inc., the biggest United States sporting-goods retailer, rejected a bid of $445.2 million by the Gart Sports Company to buy a majority stake and said it might shelve its agreement with Venator Group Inc. as well. Sports Authority's chief executive, Jack Smith, said Gart's bid of $20 a share for a 70 percent stake was worth only $14 a share for all of the retailer's shares. Sports Authority also said it was not enamored of Venator's agreement to buy the entire company. A 43 percent tumble in the stock of Venator has shrunk its offer to $10.55 a share, or $335.2 million, from the original $18.40 in May. Shares of Sports Authority, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., fell $2.3125 a share, or 19.6 percent, to $9.50.

title: Oxford Health Posts Big Loss For 2d Quarter
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc., the popular health plan that has been struggling for nearly a year to return to profitability, reported yesterday a loss of $507.6 million in the second quarter, relecting several large charges and continued operating losses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCELHENNY, MARITA B.
description: McELHENNY-Marita B. August 11, 1998 formerly of Douglaston, NY. Wife of William J. McElhenny. Mother of Kevin, Brian, William, John & Thomas McElhenny. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Pkwy. and Northern Boulevard, Little Neck, NY, Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered in St. Anastasia R.C. Church, Friday at 9:45 AM. Interment in Mountain Grove Memorial Cemetery, Huletts Landing, New York.

title: Journal; Electric Kool-Aid Viagra
description: In my 1960's youth, America couldn't stop talking about -- or taking -- a drug that promised sexual ecstasy and a sensory trip. If memory serves, it was called marijuana and, though widely available, was illegal. Three decades later, the new national drug of choice also promises sexual ecstasy and, as a potential side effect, what the Food and Drug Administration describes as mild temporary perceptual ''changes in blue/ green colors.'' It is called Viagra, and not only is it a legal prescription medication, but anyone with a credit card can score some over the Internet without even seeing or speaking to a doctor. I know because I did.

title: Agco to Buy Cargill Unit
description: The Agco Corporation, the world's fourth-largest maker of farm equipment, agreed today to buy Cargill Inc.'s Willmar line of agricultural sprayers and spreaders to expand its product line. The maker of Allis and Massey Ferguson tractors will pay less than $50 million cash for the business, which is based in Willmar, Minn., and has about 220 employees, Agco's chief financial officer, Patrick Shannon, said. The purchase will make Agco the world's top producer of self-propelled agricultural sprayers.

title: ASHLAND CANCELS SALE OF 2.1 MILLION ARCH COAL SHARES
description: Ashland Inc. said yesterday that it had canceled the sale of as many as 2.1 million shares of Arch Coal Inc., the second-largest United States coal producer, because of a fall in Arch's stock price. The shares were worth about $48 million when Ashland announced plans for the sale in July. Based on Arch Coal's closing price of $21, the shares would sell for $44.1 million now. The sale would have reduced Ashland's stake in Arch Coal to 49 percent from 55 percent. Arch Coal was formed a year ago when Ashland Coal Inc. and the Arch Minerals Corporation merged. The company mines coal in five states, and has annual revenue of about $2 billion.

title: Drifting to a New Iraq Policy
description: These first days of August have brought a disquieting retreat by the Clinton Administration on Iraq. Without saying as much, the White House seems on the verge of altering seven years of American policy by letting Saddam Hussein slip free of the international effort to prevent him from developing a new arsenal of biological and chemical weapons. That would be a grave mistake.

description: To the Editor:

title: Another Flurry of Falling Bricks
description: New Yorkers praying for rain these last few weeks have instead been deluged with falling bricks and flying scaffolding. On Monday morning, three weeks after Times Square was tied up by a scaffolding collapse at the Conde Nast building, a section of masonry popped loose from the 40th floor of a building on Lexington Avenue, showering the streets below with thousands of small pieces of brick. These latest incidents have not yet matched last December's epidemic, when bricks tumbled from the side of a 39-story building on Madison Avenue, masonry plummeted from three other buildings and a six-story structure collapsed on 42d Street. But they were enough to remind New Yorkers of their vulnerability in a high-rise city.

title: Anthony Genovesi, Legislator, Dies at 61 in a One-Car Crash
description: Anthony J. Genovesi, a State Assemblyman and powerful political force in Brooklyn Democratic politics for two decades, was killed on Monday night in a one-car accident about 50 miles north of New York City.

title: THE CHEF; Deborah Madison
description: TWICE a week during the summer, I come home from the farmers' market with a huge assortment of vegetables. The possibilities abound, but I often feel an overwhelming urge to use this bounty to make a colorful, fresh-tasting vegetable stew. Others might choose to stir-fry, but I prefer these little braises because I like to get the vegetables tender, drawing out all of their delicious juices and allowing them to mingle.

title: Asia Crisis Takes Toll On U.S. Stocks
description: Stocks buckled yesterday as investors grew increasingly fearful that sickly Asian economies would drive down corporate earnings at United States companies in the second half of the year.

title: Court Rejects New York's Plan to Require Sale of Electric Cars
description: In a setback for the nation's fledgling market in electric cars, a Federal appeals court today rejected New York State's plan to require that automobile makers immediately begin selling thousands of electrically powered vehicles in the state.

description: SOMAN-Beatrice A. Died suddenly in her home August 10, 1998. Wife of the late William J. Soman. title: Women Win Democratic Primaries in Colorado
description: Colorado Democrats chose women today as their candidates for two significant races this fall: Dottie Lamm, a former newspaper columnist and wife of a former governor, for senator and Gail Schoettler, the Lieutenant Governor, for governor.

description: ''AH,'' the woman from Michigan said as the maitre d'hotel pulled out her chair, ''it's so calm in here.'' She settled herself in the chair, looked around at the spare elegance of Cena and added, ''It's not at all like New York.''

title: TV Notes; Exploring the Titanic
description: Fans of the Titanic, be they history buffs or romantics swayed by the Oscar-winning movie, will have a rare chance on Sunday to follow along live as explorers, both human and robotic, roam the ruins of the sunken ocean liner.

title: Police Detain 2 Over Spreading Internet Rumors : Virtual Riots in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysian police on Tuesday detained two people suspected of spreading rumors over the Internet in a case that officials say highlights the fear of racial and social strife in a country battling its worst economic crisis in at least a decade.

title: Treasury Securities Gain As Investors Seek Havens
description: Treasury securities made modest price gains yesterday as investors sought a haven from the stock market and from overseas markets.

title: Hotelier Restructures

Those plans have been in place since Mr. Schrager joined forces in March with NorthStar Capital Investment Corporation, a real estate investment firm in New York, in a series of transactions worth more than $530 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLER, H. LEONARD, RABBI.
