title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER EXPECTS TO TRIM ABOUT $100 MILLION
description: The International Paper Company expects to close about 25 plants and cut about $100 million in operating costs as a result of consolidating its $263 million acquisition of the Mead Corporation's Zellerbach distribution unit. International Paper said yesterday that it had completed the purchase of Zellerbach and would merge the unit with its Xpedx distribution business. The merger will add $1.2 billion to existing Xpedx sales, bringing combined annual sales at the unit to about $6 billion. The deal will expand Xpedx into seven new markets. Xpedx, based in Covington, Ky., distributes printing, packaging, industrial and graphic arts supplies and equipment. Shares of International Paper dropped $1.4375, to $42.625.

title: Testaverde May Get First Start As a Jet
description: Bill Parcells can be a pleasant sort of fellow, especially in commercials when he affects an almost jolly air. And sometimes he is enigmatic, such as he was today. Or was he?

description: It wasn't over until the ball rolled into the hole, but when it did, at the eighth hole of the Montclair Country Club yesterday, Yogi Berra had made a hole-in-one.

title: A Woman Cries Wolf Whistler
description: Stalked and harassed, made to feel unsafe in public places, the victims of street abuse in Maggie Hadleigh-West's ''War Zone'' often generate their share of sympathy. Too bad, because in a film that means to decry the treatment of women, a lot of the victims are men. And these tragically benighted wolf-whistlers are turned into prey by the filmmaker who hounds them. Dressed to stop traffic (or at least slow it down marginally), Ms. Hadleigh-West roams city streets with her Super-8 camera, cornering any fool who dares to look her over. By her own calculations, she was annoyed by 1,050 insensitive men during the five-week period when the film was shot.

title: U.S. CLOSES DOWN SOME OPERATIONS IN FOREIGN POSTS
description: Several American embassies and other diplomatic installations have temporarily closed down routine operations in response to threats made after the terrorist attacks on the embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, State Department officials said today.

description: Holderbank Financiere Glarus Ltd. (Holderbank) announced yesterday that it had acquired a 25 percent stake in Siam City Cement P.L.C. for 6.3 billion baht, or $150.3 million. The investment represents one of the first major acquisitions of a Thai industrial company by foreigners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, ARTHUR
description: GROSSMAN-Arthur, 62. Of Red Bank, New Jersey. On Tuesday, August 11, at home. Mr. Grossman was the owner and operator of Arlo Print and Copy Service, Red Bank, since 1977. Prior to that, he was employed as Controller and Cost Accountant, IFF, Union Beach, NJ. He was a leader and drummer of society orchestras as well playing in many bands across the country. He was born in Pennsylvania, grew up in Flushing, NY. He resided in N.J. for the past 40 years in Aberdeen and Lincroft, and then Red Bank for the past 15. Surviving are his wife of 40 years, Lois, three daughters, Deborah Pocetti, Yardley, PA., Barbara Bohanan and Susan Murphy, both of Shrewsbury, NJ, 8 grandchildren & sister Laura Diamond, Dallas, TX. & mother Irene Grossman, of FL. Visitation 7-9 P.M. on Wednesday, August 12, at The Worden-Hoidal Funeral Home, 60 East Front Street, Red Bank. Funeral services Thursday, August 13 at 11 A.M., at the funeral home. Interment Beth El Cemetery, Westwood, N.J.

title: Israel Removes One Roadblock to Treaty on Nuclear Material
description: Bowing to American pressure, Israel announced today that it would not block the next step in a United Nations effort to draft an international treaty that would halt the production of the fissionable materials used to make make nuclear weapons.

title: A City's Most Famous Poet Gets It in Writing
description: As a voice of the Beat Generation, poet, publisher and book seller, Lawrence Ferlinghetti has always held a prominent place in San Francisco's cultural community. Today, he was elevated to a loftier status.

title: Key Numbers: McGwire's 47th, Mets'  1/2-Game Edge
description: Whether he admits it or not, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine is obviously keeping close track of where his team stands in the National League wild-card race. He has every reason to.

title: CUNY Plans an Appeal On Remedial Education
description: The City University of New York yesterday filed a notice that it would appeal a preliminary injunction that would have temporarily prohibited it from carrying out its remedial education plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHATZ, ROBERT H.
description: SHATZ-Robert H., 79. Died at his home in Palo Alto, California, on August 4, 1998. Mr. Shatz had a productive and varied career in aeronautics and astronautics, energy resources and policy, and the design of high speed trains and boats. While at United Aircraft he led the design team for the Lunar Module Abort Guidance System which brought Apollo 13 back to earth following the emergency evacuation of the command module. He also worked for Lockheed, Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory, Hudson Institute, the Federal Energy Administration, & TRW. An avid skier and tennis player, he is survived by his wife Shanah and two children, Carla and Jonathan.

title: American Sales Help AXA's Revenues Grow
description: AXA S.A., France's biggest insurer, said yesterday that its first-half revenue rose 6.4 percent, to 197.1 billion francs ($33 billion), helped by its North American life insurance and financial services businesses. Sales of life insurance, which accounts for more than half of Axa's revenue, rose 6.3 percent, to 105.57 billion francs, propelled by a 28 percent jump in revenues in the United States. Those sales offset a 9 percent fall in Asia and little-changed sales across Europe.

title: Brothers Land On Their Side Of the Divide
description: SHRIEKS and squeals filled the yellow school bus as it bounced and bumped over the potholes along the factory-lined streets of the East Williamsburg Industrial Park. They subsided, only to be replaced by the bouncy beats of a hip-hop song on the radio. Bear Mountain was still an hour away, but the children from St. Barbara's Day Camp were getting psyched for the summer's final outing on Monday.

title: Colleges Agree to Share Chores, But Without Uttering the M-Word
description: Four years ago, LeBron Fairbanks, the president of a small, distinctively Christian liberal arts college in Mount Vernon, Ohio, had an inspiration. Budget cuts were threatening his institution, but, he figured, he could save ''bushels of money'' by combining resources with neighboring colleges.

title: Tangy Buttermilk, Sweet Memories
description: THERE'S no two ways about buttermilk: either you love its tart creaminess, or you shudder at just a glimpse of its cloudy film clinging to an empty glass. Having grown up in the Swedish countryside, where fermented milks were more common than fresh, I'm definitely in the first category, though I admit I never saw buttermilk drunk from a glass until I arrived in America.

title: A Painstaking Search for Answers
description: With its largest team ever assembled to investigate terrorism against Americans overseas, the F.B.I. is following a familiar method in East Africa, aimed at rapidly amassing enormous amounts of data that the authorities hope will yield evidence to unravel the bombing plot against the embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.

title: What Corn Has Come To: So Sweet, but So What?
description: WHATEVER happened to Silver Queen? Just when everyone is singing ''This Is the Moment'' at the peak of the sweet-corn season in August, I get cranky. No matter how fresh and sweet the corn that's being assaulted in a strip-and-search frenzy at green markets and roadside stands, what I want to know is, Why can't I find a single ear of my grandfather's beloved Silver Queen?

title: China Loosens Controls Over Foreign Banks
description: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, announced yesterday that it would allow foreign banks to start yuan operations in Shenzhen for the first time and that it would license more foreign banks to take deposits in yuan and lend out yuan in Shanghai's Pudong district. The central bank also said it planned to increase the limit on yuan-denominated working capital allowed for foreign banks to 100 million yuan ($12 million) from 30 million yuan, to ease controls on interbank borrowing and to allow foreign banks to engage in yuan-based consortium lending.

title: Hamlet Jolted by Charges That Woman Ran Brothel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONTRIER, GABRIEL
description: FONTRIER-Gabriel. The Aaron Copland School of Music at Queens College/CUNY deeply mourns the passing of its Professor Emeritus on August 5, 1998, and extends its deepest sympathy to his wife, May, and their four daughters. Prof. Fontrier joined the music faculty in 1947 after receiving degrees from Queens College and Columbia University. A student of Karol Rathaus, Fontrier taught courses in composition, theory and orchestration. He composed many orchestral, chamber and choral works and was the coauthor with his colleagues Sol Berkowitz and Leo Kraft of ''A New Approach to Sightsinging.'' Prof. Fontrier was also the music editor and critic for the Long Island Press in the 1960's and 70's. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the Aaron Copland School of Music, Queens College/ CUNY, Flushing, New York 11367. Raymond Erickson, Dean of Arts and Humanities Rufus Hallmark, Director Faculty, Staff and Students

title: A Budget Balance in Congress
description: With Congress in recess, Washington is filled with threats of another government shutdown over the budget in October. Underneath the surface, however, a fragile majority of moderate Democrats and Republicans is emerging in both the Senate and House that could set a less confrontational tone when lawmakers return in September. On budget issues, moderate Republicans are warning sensibly against big new tax cuts and spending reductions in essential areas. It would be healthy for Republican leaders to pay attention.

title: Aid Groups Try to Feed Kosovo Refugees
description: Two large cargo trucks eased through the throngs of refugees today in this block-long hamlet in the mountains of Kosovo. Stopping at a decrepit, empty building, the drivers unlashed the cargo covers and tossed them to one side. Instantly dozens of men grabbed the 110-pound sacks of flour from the trucks and stacked them against a wall.

title: Business Travel; Northwest Is Pressured To Reduce Some Fares
description: Bowing to pressure from North Dakota politicians and local airport managers, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would cut business fares to and from the state as part of a six-month trial to stimulate passenger traffic. The fares, discounted as much as 60 percent on connecting flights and 42 percent on nonstop flights, are available immediately for travel from Sept. 14 through March 31, 1999.

title: Low Profile Helps Peter's Development With Giants
description: Nineteen months after he signed with the Giants as a free agent in what was a highly controversial episode for the team, Christian Peter will start his first professional game Friday against the Jacksonville Jaguars. Peter, a defensive tackle, will replace the injured Robert Harris.

title: Tomatoes: Living Up to All That Potential
description: AT this time of year you hear people say, ''Give me a good tomato and I eat it like an apple.'' But no one actually does that, at least not more than a couple of times a summer. Unlike peaches, whose raw glory can barely be improved upon, tomatoes are all about potential. The difference between consuming a tomato out of hand and slicing it, then sprinkling it with a pinch of salt and a few drops of olive oil, is the difference between a snack and a dish. And the great thing about tomatoes is that it takes so little to convert them from one to the other.

title: NABISCO HOLDINGS PLANS TO CLOSE PITTSBURGH FACTORY
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it would close its Pittsburgh cracker factory, dismissing 350 workers, as the company seeks to cut costs to pay for more advertising. Nabisco, which makes Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers, said it would close the factory, its oldest, by Nov. 20. The plant operated at below 60 percent of capacity in the last year, the company said. The factory makes Ritz, Wheat Thins, Better Cheddars and Swiss Cheese crackers, as well as Ritz Bits and Twigs snacks. Nabisco previously said it would cut 3,100 jobs, resulting in about $100 million in annual savings.

title: Harlem Leaders Urge City and Youth March Organizers to Compromise on Location
description: A group of Harlem community leaders, concerned about the possibility of violent clashes with the police, urged city officials and organizers of the planned Million Youth March yesterday to keep open the prospect of having the event in Harlem but at a site other than Malcolm X Boulevard.

title: Hillary Clinton: Popular, and Hardly in Hiding
description: As Hillary Rodham Clinton's bus slowly chugged along the roads in upstate New York recently on a tour for historic preservation, she glanced out the window at a woman holding aloft a cardboard sign. It said, ''You Go Girl.''

title: Not Just Button-Down: Brooks Bros. on Fifth
description: Since August 1915, the Brooks Brothers flagship store, a mecca for the preppy and the conservatively attired, has been at Madison Avenue and 44th Street. Now, in an attempt to attract shoppers cut from a different cloth, Brooks Brothers has decided to open a branch store at 666 Fifth Avenue, on the northwest corner of 53d Street, a mere 10 blocks from its Madison Avenue showplace.

title: Congressman Is Seeking Release of Jailed Student
description: Representative Christopher H. Smith said he would travel to Myanmar today to push for the release of a New Jersey college student arrested there on Sunday for distributing pro-democracy pamphlets.

title: Connors Ponders Winding Down Career
description: Sounding very much like a player nearing the end of the line, Jimmy Connors strongly indicated today that he might be in the waning days of his Hall of Fame tennis career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COFFEE, MARGARET JENNINGS
description: COFFEE-Margaret Jennings, 77. Of Red Bank, New Jersey, formerly of Seneca Falls, N.Y., on August 10, 1998. Born in N.Y.C. Beloved and devoted wife of Joseph D. Coffee, Jr. for 56 yrs. Loving and loved mother of James Jennings, Mary Joyce Dies, Barbara Grace Wolf, Matthew Brian, Margaret Erin Giovannini, Ann Ellen Beach and the late John Allan. title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a patent awarded for an Internet auction system misidentified the court whose ruling last month helped pave the way for the new patent. It was the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, which hears appeals from district courts in patent, trademark and copyright cases, not the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

title: Potent Riches of Puerto Rico
description: THE term Caribbean food is a misnomer, suggesting a singular style when in fact many styles exist. Jamaican cuisine is perhaps the best known and most distinctive Caribbean food, but its Indian-influenced rotis, curries and spicy jerks, flavored with chili peppers and herbs, bear little relation to the rich, lusty foods of Puerto Rico, Cuba and the Dominican Republic, which favor garlic over chilies.

title: Troubled Health Plan Retaining Clients
description: Despite the relentless bad news concerning Oxford Health Plans Inc. -- and another heavy dose of it yesterday -- many of the New York region's large employers are continuing to do business with Oxford, at least for now.

title: City Is in the Running For G.O.P. Convention

title: Reviled in Life, Embraced in Death; A German Museum Honors an Artist Lost to the Holocaust
description: Gustel Moses-Nussbaum knew that her cousin, Felix Nussbaum, had been a painter. She also knew that, along with his parents and most of her family, he had died at Auschwitz. But it was only in 1960 that she learned that many of his oils were stored in a Brussels basement. Nussbaum had once said: ''If I perish, do not let my paintings die. Show them to the people.'' Mrs. Moses-Nussbaum felt duty-bound to make this happen.

title: He's Back Back, Baby: A New (Improved?) Ice

At the mixing board there, Ross Robinson, a hard-rock producer known for his work with heavy, rap-influenced acts like Korn and Limp Bizkit, played some the new music, which hasn't yet been heard publicly.

title: When Fact and Fiction Are Bonded by Bitterness
description: Until it suddenly ended, the friendship between V.S. Naipaul and Paul Theroux, as mentor and protege, was mutually rewarding over a period of more than 30 years. Now, with the forthcoming publication of Mr. Theroux's book ''Sir Vidia's Shadow: A Friendship Across Five Continents,'' and the controversy surrounding it, there is only bitterness. As often happens in a divorce, their friends are forced to choose sides. To someone who knows them both and has assiduously followed their careers, the result can only be a subject of great regret.

title: Canadian Troubles Echo Across Border
description: The Canadian dollar has fallen to its lowest level in modern times, and the commercial fortunes of dozens of towns along the border have fallen with it. Along almost all of the United States-Canada border, the Canadian side is much more populous, and shopping by Canadians, drawn by lower sales taxes, longer shopping hours and often more choices, had formed an important part of markets on the American side.

description: Rose Blumkin, who founded the Nebraska Furniture Mart in 1937, helped her son and grandchildren build it into the nation's largest home furnishings store and continued selling carpet there well past her 100th birthday, died on Friday in Omaha. She was 104.

title: Backpack Returns the Favor And Carries the Backpacker
description: ''It's a nomadic office,'' the industrial designer Lisa Smith said of this sturdy backpack with built-in stool, safe for anyone up to 250 pounds. She invented it while visiting Bali. Made of Indonesian materials -- canvas and chocolaty woven leather -- it is imported, tax free, as a craft item. At $199, the Seat Pack costs more than nylon backpacks, but Ms. Smith says it can support young and old. ''My 80-year-old mother uses it every 10 minutes when I take her shopping,'' she said. Weight: 4.5 pounds. To order: Levenger's, (800) 544-0880. BARBARA FLANAGAN

title: Spinoff Games That Outshine a Film Parent

Witness ''Small Soldiers,'' a popcorn film about cybernetic action figures on a malignant rampage. The movie is egregious. But the plastic toys that come with a Burger King meal are great.

The companies, which both make feeding and watering systems for poultry and swine growers, have operated separately since 1985.

title: Your Message Embroidered Here
description: The Monogram Shop in Easthampton, N.Y., has made a business of embroidered messages. Valerie Smith, an owner, can have a name, initials, even an E-mail address embroidered on terry robes, towels, linens, T-shirts and canvas bags. ''I was inspired by a friend who owns a similar store in London,'' Ms. Smith said. Any message or monogram costs $10. The towel shown is $20. The Monogram Shop is at 11 Newtown Lane. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, RAYMOND E., S.S.
description: BROWN-Raymond E., S.S. The Board of Directors, the Faculty and Staff of Union Theological Seminary in New York City are deeply saddened by the untimely loss of our beloved colleague and friend, Raymond E. Brown. For almost two decades Professor Brown blessed Union Theological Seminary with his teaching, his publications, his ecumenical involvements, and his gentle and wise presence. As Auburn Distinguished Professor of Biblical Studies, he was the first Roman Catholic ever to hold a tenured position on the faculty. A distinguished teacher and researcher of international acclaim, he attracted students in large numbers, filling the classroom to overflowing. Yet his erudition never obscured clarity and simplicity. He will be deeply missed. Our condolences to his brother, Robert J. Brown and to the Society of St. Sulpice, of which he was a member. A Mass of Christian burial will be held on Monday, August 17 at 10:30A.M. at Our Lady of the Angels Chapel, Catonsville, MD. A memorial service is tentatively planned at Union Theological Seminary on Friday, October 2, 1998. Anne Hale Johnson, Chair, Board of Directors The Rev. Mary E. McNamara, Interim President Dr. Rosemary Keller, Academic Dean

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KERR, M. DOROTHEA, MD.
description: KERR-M. Dorothea, MD. 8/13/183/20/98. Friends, colleagues and patients of Dr. Kerr were deeply saddened to learn of her passing on 3/20/98. Dr. Kerr began her medical career as a nurse almost sixty years ago, continued her education to earn her M.D. from Columbia University, and became the first woman to hold an internship in Internal Medicine at St. Luke's. Following a residency in Pathology, Dr. Kerr became an assistant medical examiner for the New York City Health Department. Her desire to bring empathy, understanding and effective care to patients led her to undertake a residency in Psychiatry at the Payne Whitney Clinic becoming one of the first women psychiatrists on staff. Dr. Kerr was Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry emeritus at Payne Whitney and Associate Attending Psychiatrist at the New York Hospital. In recent years, in addition to her private practice, Dr. Kerr worked with the Board of Education, evaluating adolescent behavior. Well loved and highly respected, she will be sorely missed and long remembered for her wisdom, wit, warmth and compassion.

In response, Mr. O'Brien, a 17-year-old baritone horn player from Westlake High School, near Cleveland, last spring set up a home-based Web site that insulted Mr. Walczuk.

Whenever there was talk, as often there was, about what was really going on behind the scenes -- who owed what to whom and why, or who hated whom and exactly how much -- his name invariably came up. ''Tony could tell you that,'' people would say, only to add, ''Of course, he won't.''

On a recent day, as he struggled to free a heifer stranded on a railing, Mr. Thaller's only helper was a young government archivist from the Rhineland, hundreds of miles west, who was vacationing on the farm.

title: Weaving Elegance With a Lighter Hand

Scalamandre has sold high-end woven silk damasks and brocades for the home since 1929 in a style more suited to palaces than apartments, but now it has relaxed its look. Call it low cal: the heavy cream has been skimmed off. The company hopes to furnish the homes of a younger, hipper clientele with fabrics like Precious Cargo, left, a chinoiserie print, and Ming Circus, below.

title: MOBIL PLANS TO BUY BACK STOCK WORTH UP TO $500 MILLION
description: The Mobil Corporation, the second-largest United States oil company, said yesterday that it would spend as much as $500 million to buy back shares of its stock. At current prices, Mobil could buy more than 7.6 million shares, or about 1 percent, for that amount. On the New York Stock Exchange, Mobil shares rose $1.3125, to $66.75, still substantially below the record price of more than $83 in March. The stock price has fallen as Mobil's profits have been eroded by a drop in oil prices, which are now near their lowest point in 12 years.

Persistent, quiet, dedicated work generates little in the way of headlines or air time. But if someone starts making outrageous comments and playing the fool, the reporters will come running.

title: Barbecue Pits for Those With Money to Burn
description: SMOKE gets in their eyes -- and that's only part of the attraction. Once man cooked over an open fire in a cave. Some time later came the 1950's backyard grill, a mammoth creation etched on the landscape in brick or stone. In the 60's, more mobile chefs, or those without backyards, swore by their portable hibachis and Weber kettle grills. And then came the 80's and the portable gas-fired grills that turned summer cookery into something as romantic as, say, lighting the kitchen range.

title: E-Mail Flaws Make Usually Confident Users Feel Uneasy
description: COMPUTER security has long been the sole province of a grizzled clan of experts who have despaired of getting the public to take the subject seriously. Skeptics have dismissed warnings of hacker attacks as alarmist, cynics have figured that attacks were inevitable, and victims have often preferred to not talk about it. Casual computer users have just assumed that the most likely targets -- big businesses and the Pentagon -- could take care of themselves.

title: Bumped From the Whitney, Nudity Finds a Showcase

The show, opening next June, will include an installation by Karen Finley, a drawing class in which she and others will take part as nude models.

One such program, ''Bridge Trix,'' prepared by Bob Wolff, many times a world champion, in collaboration with Neil Cohen, will challenge players at many levels. A demonstration can be viewed at www.bridgetrix.com. The program costs $34.95 including shipping and can be ordered by calling (888) 273-8749.

title: Tradition Burnished By a Czech Quartet
description: A lot of young string quartets these days have you sitting on the edge of your seat. With the Wihan Quartet, which played at the Frick Collection on Tuesday evening, you lean back, and your ears quietly put their feet up. The sound these Czech musicians make -- beautifully balanced, centered in warm, dark regions of tone color, musical in every part -- is deeply pleasurable and also deeply traditional. They are continuing the long history of Central European quartet playing, a fact they duly recognize in taking their name from Hanus Wihan, who founded the Bohemian Quartet a century ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DERBY, BENNETT MARSH, M.D.
description: DERBY-Bennett Marsh, M.D. The Faculty and Staff of New York University Medical Center deeply mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague, Bennett Marsh Derby, M.D., Professor of Clinical Neurology and Clinical Pathology at NYU School of Medicine. Dr. Derby had been a Faculty Member in The Dept of Neurology at NYU School of Medicine since 1965. He was a superb teacher, an active and effective clinician, and a productive investigator who made numerous contributions to the literature on neurological deseases and neuropathology. After attending Hamilton College, Dr. Derby earned his M.D. degree from The University of Virginia School of Medicine in 1956. He became Professor of Clinical Neurology at NYU School of Medicine in 1971 and Professor of Clinical Pathology in 1981. He also served as Chief of Neurology at The Veterans Administration Hospital. In addition to his hospital activities, he was a Consulting Neuropathologist to the Medical Examiner of The City of New York and to The State of Maine. Dr. Derby was a person of the highest degree of personal integrity whose intellect, imagination and leadership will be sorely missed. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Susan, and all the members of the Derby family. Edwin H. Kolodny, M.D., Chairman, Dept of Neurology NYU School of Medicine

title: PEPSICO BUYING OUT BOTTLING COMPANY BASED IN ALBANY
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the remaining 80 percent of one of its largest United States bottlers. The terms for closely held Pepsi-Cola Allied Bottlers Inc., based in Albany, were not disclosed. The bottler operates in New York, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania and has sales of about $375 million, according to The Albany Times Union. Pepsico's chief executive, Roger Enrico, is reorganizing the company's bottling system and considering converting a sizable stake in the company-owned bottling operations to public ownership. Emanuel Goldman, an analyst for Paine Webber, said Pepsi is likely to to spin off its bottling operations early in 1999.

title: CALENERGY WILL PURCHASE MIDAMERICAN ENERGY
description: The Calenergy Company said yesterday that it would buy the Mid American Energy Holdings Company for $2.6 billion in cash, the first time an independent power producer has purchased a utility in this country. MidAmerican, the largest utility in Iowa, has a network of power plants that burn coal, the lowest-cost fuel for producing electricity, and transmission lines that feed into the $6.3 billion Chicago market. Calenergy, an international developer of power plants that is based in Omaha, will pay $27.15 a share. It will also assume $1.4 billion of MidAmerican's debt and preferred stock. MidAmerican shares jumped 26 percent, or $5.25, to $25.25. MidAmerican, which is based in Des Moines, provides electricity and natural gas to 1.3 million customers. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGAN, WILLIAM E.
description: HOGAN-William E. New York University Law School professor of law emeritus and a leading thinker in the field of contracts and commercial law, died on July 31 in Montreal, Canada. He was 70 and lived in Southbury, Connecticut and in Longboat Key, Florida. Professor Hogan will be most remembered for the intense, yet good humored Socratic teaching style that made him a legend amongst the thousands of students he taught during his 36 years as a law professor. Professor Hogan began his teaching career at Boston College Law School. In 1960 he took a professorship at Cornell University, where in 1970 he was made the J. Duprat White Professor of Law. In 1981 he left Cornell and joined the faculty at New York University Law School. He retired in 1991. After graduating first in his class from Boston College Law School in 1952, professor Hogan served in the Air Force as a First Lieutenant until 1955. He received his S.J.D. from Harvard Law School in 1962. Professor Hogan was extensively involved in the development of the Uniform Commercial Code and served as a member of the New York State Commission on Uniform State Laws from 1974 to 1991. He served as Vice President of the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws from 1982 to 1983. An active member of the American Bar Association, Professor Hogan was Chairman of the Corporation Banking and Business Section in 1976. He was a life member of the American Law Institute, and worked on the Legal Advisory Committee of the New York Stock Exchange from 1982 to 1985. Professor Hogan had a lengthy list of publications and for two decades nearly every law student in the country was assigned the casebooks. Consumer and Commercial Transactions and Creditors Rights and Secure Transactions Under the Uniform Commercial Code (both co-authored with William D. Warren). He is survived by wife Joanne, children Nancy Rice, Thomas Hogan and Neal Hogan, and grandchildren Kevin Sayles and Jessica Sayles. Memorial donations to be sent to local chapters of the American Red Cross and to Covenant House 733 Breakers Avenue, Fort Lauderdale, Florida 33304.

Cherished grandson of Stanley and Pearl Hendler and Marcia and Irving Lewit. Services on Friday, at 10:30 A.M., at Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains.

title: Tyson Bid to Return Is Shifted to Nevada
description: One day before the New Jersey State Athletic Control Board was to make a decision on his application for a boxing license, Mike Tyson, the former world heavyweight champion, withdrew the application. He instead applied to Nevada, the state that revoked his license last year after he bit Evander Holyfield's ears during a championship bout.

title: Two Cheers for Consumerism
description: After the East Asian meltdown, many economists thought that American consumers would need to go on a spending spree to save the world from another Great Depression.

title: Salomon Executives To Leave the Firm
description: Pat Dunlavy and Bruce Koepfgen, co-heads of United States bond sales of Salomon Smith Barney Inc., are leaving the firm at year-end, according to an internal memo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, HARRY I.
description: PHILLIPS-Harry I. On August 13. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father to Arnold and Rachel. Devoted grandfather of Jonah and Mollie. Loving uncle to Phil, Ruth, Rochelle & Bob. Cherished greatuncle. Religious services today, August 14, 12:30 PM, at Gramercy Park Chapel, 152 Second Avenue (corner 10th Street), N.Y.C. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: 'On Stage and Off'
description: The ''On Stage and Off'' column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Theater Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: To the Editor:

title: Citing a Lead In the Polls, Ferraro Plans To Play Safe
description: With politicians, it is usually wiser to watch what they are doing than to listen to what they are saying. From that perspective, there is not much mystery these days about Geraldine A. Ferraro's strategy as she runs for the Senate Democratic nomination. Her public assertions notwithstanding, she is following the unadventurous approach of a self-presumed front-runner, doing as little as she can to spill the soup.

title: Three Times the Pain! Three Times the Gain?
description: In 1982, the sport of triathlon was about as popular in the United States as llama racing. But 11 hours into the fifth annual Ironman Triathlon -- a 2.4-mile swim, 112-mile bike ride and 26.2-mile run -- the women's leader, Julie Moss, 23, wobbled down Alii Drive on the Big Island of Hawaii and collapsed two miles from the finish. Refusing medical attention, she picked herself off the road, staggered a few more steps and crumpled again like a suit slipping off a hanger.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORE, CHESTER A.
description: GORE-Chester A. 8/14/18-4/19/97 Happy 80th Birthday, Daddy. I miss you every day. Love, Eloise

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANNIGAN, JAMES E.
description: BRANNIGAN-James E. (retired Lieut. NYPD) of Staten Island on August 13, 1998. Husband of the late Margaret (nee Ryan). Loving father of James J., Joseph P., Esq., Grace Ann, Esq., Margaret, M.D., and Frances. Dear father-inlaw of Bernadette. Adored grandfather of Evan James. Dear brother of Mary Bruce and John. Funeral from Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Ave, SI on Monday. Mass of Christian burial St. Teresa's Church 9:30AM. Interment Ocean View Cemetery. Visiting Sat. and Sun. 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Jean-Georges Vongerichten has an excellent sense of place. His first Manhattan restaurant, Lafayette, was a formal affair, one befitting its Upper East Side location. As he moved around the city, he matched each restaurant to the mood of its neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCBRIDE, EDWARD ARCHER
description: McBRIDE-Edward Archer. Of Manhattan. On August 5, 1998 at the age of 73. Decorated W.W. II veteran; recipient of 3 bronze stars, one silver star and the Purple Heart. Five-year President of the 90th Division Association. 17-year Police Auxiliary Captain. Survived by his daughter Elizabeth, two grandchildren, brother Alan, along with many nieces, nephews and longtime friends. Memorial service to be held Saturday, August 15, 11-12 P.M. at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, Manhattan.

title: Residential Real Estate; Adding 11 Floors to Meet Rental Demand in Chelsea
description: From a squat 7-story building with 90 apartments just 18 months ago, the Chelsea, at 160 West 24th Street, has been enlarged into an 18-story building with 204 apartments.

title: Gridiron Hero: He Runs, Catches and Barks
description: Don't tell the new Air Bud, a k a Buddy, but he doesn't look all that good in a football uniform. Maybe it's the shoulder pads. Despite that, ''Air Bud: Golden Receiver'' is a fine sequel to ''Air Bud,'' last summer's sentimental children's movie in which the title dog metamorphosed from abused clown's assistant to adored family pet to basketball star. But this time around it's the boy's story; the dog's mastery of a new sport is almost a subplot.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the financial strains on upstate New York since the fall of the Canadian dollar to record lows misstated the college affiliation of a woman who said she shopped in Canada. Rosa Spagnola graduated from Clarkson University, in Potsdam, N.Y.; Clarkson College is in Omaha.

title: Many Nations, One Big Party
description: If all New Yorkers share one experience, it's the sensation of suddenly feeling like a tourist without leaving the city. Take an alternate route, turn an unfamiliar corner, peek into an open doorway, and suddenly you could be in Tokyo or Timbuktu, with strangers chatting in an unknown language while intriguing scents waft from a kitchen. New York is Dakar north and Budapest west; there are contingents from Ireland and Uzbekistan, Lebanon and Peru. And they hold on to the places they left behind by gathering for music, theater or movies from the old country, wherever that might be.

title: TICKETMASTER'S ON-LINE UNIT TO COMBINE WITH CITYSEARCH
description: As expected, USA Networks Inc. said yesterday that its Ticketmaster unit would combine its on-line ticket-selling business with Citysearch, a provider of cultural-events information in major cities, and that it planned to sell shares in the combined company to the public. Terms were not disclosed. The combined company, after a public offering, would have a market value of about $700 million, said Victor Miller, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company. USA Networks, which has a 13 percent stake in Citysearch, said it would have a 62.5 percent stake in the combined company. Citysearch canceled plans for its own initial sale of 4 million shares for $11 to $13 each. Shares of USA Networks rose $1.0625, to $28.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: A Doctor And a Poet Transformed By a War
description: After serving heroically during the first part of World War I and winning a medal for bravery, the poet Siegfried Sassoon famously experienced a change of heart. In 1917, feeling that the war was no longer one he could sanction, he wrote a declaration that cited his objections, a document that was read aloud in Parliament. Because of this, Sassoon faced a choice between being court-martialed or being sent to a mental hospital. Urged to do the latter by his comrade Robert Graves, he entered Craiglockhart Hospital, a castle just outside of Edinburgh, with his defiance undimmed.

title: A Girl From the Wrong Side of the Glitz
description: Tamara Jenkins's playfully autobiographical ''Slums of Beverly Hills'' begins with the spectacle of Murray Abramowitz (Alan Arkin) overseeing the purchase of his daughter Vivian's first bra. It's a moment, like many in the film, that leaves Vivian (Natasha Lyonne) wide-eyed and aghast, incredulous over what goes on in her family. And no matter how such a father-daughter episode might play today, the film is set in a 1976 that it remembers as a more innocent time. In this atmosphere, Murray's behavior is simply overbearing and nosy beyond belief.

title: Man Charged in Assault Of a Woman, 62
description: A Vineland man was charged yesterday with sexually assaulting a 62-year-old woman just hours before two similar assaults occurred in the same neighborhood, county prosecutors said.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Winging It In New York
description: Tomorrow the Central Park Conservancy will give you a chance to meet the neighbors who live above you. These aren't the ones with the high heels and the loud stereo; in fact, unless you frequently gaze under the eaves of your building, you may not have noticed them at all.

title: Clinton Tearfully Receives 10 Bodies, Praising Lives That 'Nothing Can Erase'
description: To the strains of ''Nearer My God to Thee,'' the bodies of 10 Americans killed by the terrorist bomb in Kenya were borne home today and received at a solemn ceremony by President Clinton.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Royal Reaction To Book on Diana

title: CUNY Review By Regents Is Questioned By Governor
description: Gov. George E. Pataki questioned yesterday whether the State Board of Regents had the authority to approve or reject a plan by the City University of New York to bar remedial students from CUNY's senior colleges.

title: International Briefs; Mannesmann Net Income Rose 42% in First Half
description: Mannesmann A.G., the German telecommunications and engineering company, said yesterday that its first-half net income had climbed by 42 percent as its mobile phone business continued its strong growth. Mannesmann said its profit in the six months that ended on June 30 rose to 443 million marks ($249 million), from 311 million marks a year earlier. First-half sales climbed 22 percent, to 21.13 billion marks.

title: Settlement in Dispute Over a Painting Looted by Nazis
description: In the first Nazi looting case to be settled in the United States, the relatives of two Holocaust victims said yesterday that they had reached an agreement with a pharmaceutical company heir over ownership of a Degas landscape.

title: Children Left at Restaurant
description: A Brooklyn woman was charged yesterday with using a McDonald's restaurant as a day-care center for her children while she went to work as a school safety officer, the police said.

title: Canadian Regulators Investigate Livent
description: Canadian securities regulators said yesterday that they were investigating the accounting problems at Livent Inc., the Toronto-based company that brought the hit musicals ''Ragtime'' and ''Showboat'' to Broadway.

title: F.B.I. Reports Finding Pieces Of Bomb Truck
description: The F.B.I. agent in charge of solving the bombing of the American Embassy here said today that the bureau had found fragments of the truck that carried the explosives, and was piecing together a picture of what happened in the seconds before the bomb went off.

title: Championing Liberalism Under New Name
description: WHEN Martin S. Begun, for years one of New York's most prominent Jewish leaders, told his friends recently that he had decided to convert, some feared he had lost his mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALBREICH, STANLEY I. LITTLEFIELD
description: HALBREICH-Stanley I. Littlefield, Adams & Company mourns the loss of Stanley I. Halbreich, its President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board. Mr. Halbreich passed away August 11, 1998. The officers, management, employees and shareholders will miss his devotion, energy, leadership, vision and friendship. Stanley was our guiding force and inspiration. With our deepest respect to his beloved wife, Ada and the rest of his family, the Company's offices in New York and Huber Heights, Ohio will be closed on Thursday, August 13th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINDELS, DR. GEORGE W.
description: HINDELS-Dr. George W. On behalf of the faculty, alumni and students of the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery (SDOS), Dean Allan J. Formicola expresses his sincere condolences to the family of Dr. George Warren Hindels, specialist in Prosthodontic Dentistry and long-time practicing dentist. Graduating from SDOS in 1943 and a member of the 25 Year Club, Dr. Hindels was a cherished alumnus and faculty member of the School. His contributions to the field or Prosthodontics and to the School's development were significant. He will be sincerly missed by his longtime colleagues. Allan J. Formicola, D.D.S. Dean Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery

title: Holocaust Accord Ends Plan for Sanctions
description: A day after the $1.25 billion settlement between Holocaust survivors and Swiss commercial banks accused of profiting from the Nazi era, officials in several states said that they would drop threatened sanctions against Swiss financial interests, and a major Swiss insurer facing a lawsuit from victims of the Holocaust agreed to honor their outstanding life and property claims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENOVESI
description: GENOVESI-State Assemblyman Anthony J. The Board of Directors & staff of the Brooklyn Philharmonic extend our deepest condolences on the unexpected passing of a longtime friend and supporter, Anthony Genovesi. Robert C. Rosenberg, Chairman Craig G. Matthews, President

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Change Strategy in Narcotics Fight in Colombia
description: After steadfastly refusing to pay for programs to help Colombia's coca growers switch to legal crops, the American Government is shifting course and is now agreeing to finance alternative development under this country's new administration.

title: Shock in Greenwich Village At Shooting of a Shopkeeper
description: Residents and merchants in Greenwich Village expressed shock yesterday at the fatal shooting of a shopkeeper in one of the city's most peaceful neighborhoods.

title: Stock and Bond Prices Drop In Russia as Investors Bolt
description: Stock and bond prices plunged today, jarring Russian hopes that the Government could avert a depletion of its finances and a meltdown of the banking system.

title: Channel 9 Team Needs Snap, Crackle and Pop
description: Should a respectable sportscast be remade into an ungainly ''Regis and Kathie Lee'' imitation? Case in point: Channel 9's pairing of Russ Salzberg and Monica Pellegrini on weeknights into ''Sports Team 9,'' which looks like a news director's cumbersome attempt to craft a format that will keep female viewers from fleeing the sports report when it appears late in a newscast.

title: International Briefs; South Korean Union Issues a Warning
description: The Korean Metal Workers' Union warned yesterday that it would call a full-scale strike if South Korean police staged a raid on workers of the Hyundai Motor Company who have been striking for several weeks in the southern city of Ulsan to protest layoffs by the company, a union spokesman said. For starters, the spokesman said, the member unions will begin a six-day strike on Monday if the police force their way in.

title: AU BON PAIN TO SELL ITS BAKERY CAFES TO INVESTMENT FIRM
description: The Au Bon Pain Company said yesterday that it was selling its namesake Au Bon Pain bakery cafes to the investment firm Bruckmann, Rosser, Sherrill & Company for $78 million in cash to focus on its rapidly growing Saint Louis Bread chain. The sale includes 152 company-owned stores as well as its franchised business. Its co-chairman, Louis Kane, will join the company formed by Bruckmann, Rosser to acquire the chain. Bruckmann, Rosser, based in New York, also has interests in such other chains as California Pizza Kitchen and Jitney-Jungle Stores of America.

title: Wealthy Force Behind Murky Militant Group
description: While investigators pawing through the wreckage of the American Embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam have yet to find physical evidence that would point toward the bombers, suspicion in the intelligence community has centered on Osama bin Laden. Mr. bin Laden is a multimillionaire Saudi businessman who fought in Afghanistan against the Soviet Union and has a worldwide network of Islamic terrorists.

title: International Briefs; Singapore Eases Grip On Its Currency
description: Singapore said yesterday that it would loosen its grip on its currency by allowing companies to use it overseas, unlocking a potentially huge market for new securities denominated in Singapore dollars. The Monetary Authority of Singapore, the central bank, said it would relax guidelines on using Singapore dollars to finance overseas projects and allow the currency to be used by foreign companies selling stocks and bonds.

title: Around the World
description: As you travel the world in New York City, sampling the arts of many nations (article on Weekend page 1), you may want to avail yourself of their cuisines as well. Here is a taste of the multi-ethnic buffet. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NORRELL CORP., Atlanta, a temporary personnel and outsourcing company, acquired FSS International Ltd., a London-based recruitment company, for an undisclosed sum.

description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil futures rose sharply on speculation that Saudi Arabia and Venezuela may move to bolster prices by proposing further cuts in output. Crude oil for September delivery rose 50 cents, to $13.21 a barrel.

Dear sister of Gertrude Wofsey and Beatrice Diamond. Services will be held on Friday, August 14, at 12 PM, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: The Babe, Baseball's Enduring Enigma
description: Sixty-three years after his major league career ended, 50 years after his death, Babe Ruth remains a contemporary baseball presence. He is invoked daily this summer. His Yankees are once again trampling everything in their path. Fans and politicians jabber about the future of the ballpark that was built on his exploits. And as several sluggers bang out home runs at a prodigious pace, they endure constant comparisons with Ruth, who, whatever the record book says, remains the heart's champion.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They were the kind of unpretentious but remarkable people who represent America in diplomatic outposts around the world -- people doing their jobs day in and day out, working for peace, strengthening democracy, healing the ill, helping those in need, winning friends for America.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CODDINGTON, AUDREY WHEATON
description: CODDINGTON-Audrey Wheaton of New Providence, NJ, on August 11, 1998. Wife of the late Lyman Badgley Coddington, Jr. Beloved mother of Janet Halliday of Juno Beach, FL; Lyman Badgley Coddington, III of Washington, DC; Joyce Harrington of New Canaan, CT; Joan Boillod, of Summit, NJ; and Ann Mays of Wakefield, RI. Also survived by 9 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at the New Providence Presbyterian Church, corner of Springfield Ave. and Passaic Ave., New Providence, NJ on Saturday, August 15, 1998 at 11:00 am. Those who wish may contribute in her memory to SAGE, 50 DeForest Ave., Summit, NJ, 07901 or to Overlook Hospital, 99 Beauvoir Ave., Summit, NJ, 07901.

title: A Sensual Story the Heart Tells the Head
description: Our need for stories -- not just any old anecdotes but transporting tales of passion, heroism and loss -- may be as essential as our need for food. It is an appetite that embraces not just the classic fairy tales and adventure stories that are handed down through the generations but also our own personal narratives. The little storm-tossed autobiographies we compile help us explain and validate passions that might otherwise have no meaning once they've died. As skeptical as we may be about the boastful tales others spin about their romantic exploits, there is a part of us that hungers to believe and to be imaginatively swept by the most far-fetched fantasies.

title: A Long-Term Closing Under Sex-Shop Law
description: The first long-term closing of a strip club was ordered yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice in Queens under the city's new sex shop zoning ordinance yesterday.

title: Trading Mean Streets for a Land of Make-Believe
description: THE SILVER CASTLE

title: CBS to Sell 5 Boston-Area Radio Stations
description: The CBS Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell five Boston-area radio stations to the closely held Entercom for $140 million to satisfy Government requirements related to CBS's purchase of American Radio Systems.

title: Defying the Hitters, Hernandez Fans 13 and Wins
description: Before defecting from Cuba, Orlando Hernandez lived according to the whims of the state. But he is in the United States now, living where he wants to live, pitching the way he wants to pitch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILLING, CHARLES W.
description: PILLING-Charles W. On August 12. Minister of Music at Central Presbyterian Church and Director of The Central City Chorus, NYC. Survived by his partner Leonard DeCicco, his parents Jane and Alan Pilling, his brother Jack and sister-in-law Anne, his nephew Luke and niece Kris. Interment will be in Storm Lake, Iowa. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 26, at 1 PM at Central Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Central City Chorus or The Central Presbyterian Church Organ Restoration Fund, both at 593 Park Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

title: Michael Palm, 47, Innovator In Method of Reinsurance
description: Michael D. Palm, a former English teacher who made a fortune in reinsurance -- the business of sharing the risk of insurance companies -- and then contributed millions to benefit the arts, gay rights and AIDS treatment, died last Friday at his home in Telluride, Colo. He was 47 years old and also had homes in Manhattan and St. Croix in the Virgin Islands.

title: Handcuffed Suspect Puts a Choke Hold on Jersey City Officer
description: With the agility of a contortionist, a drug suspect sitting with his hands cuffed behind his back in the rear seat of a Jersey City police car late Wednesday night somehow managed to swing his hands under his legs and then put a choke hold on an officer in the front passenger seat, police officials and prosecutors said. A second officer, unable to pry his colleague free, then shot the suspect three times in the leg, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, ELIZABETH DE C.
description: WILSON-Elizabeth de C. of Manchester, Vermont and New York City died in her home in Manchester on Sunday, August 9th, after a brief illness. She was born in Pachuca, Hidalgo, Mexico November 20, 1908, daughter of Carlos Cravioto and Louise Ryals (Arkell). A beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great grandmother, she was the widow of Stephen A. Wilson and Orland Campbell. She was a lover and patron of the arts, an environmentalist, and tree farmer. A memorial service celebrating her life will be held at the Manchester 1st Congregational Church on Saturday August 15th at 11:00 am. The family requests no flowers be sent but gifts in her memory may be made to the Manchester Health Service, the Manchester Rescue Squad, or the Southern Vermont Art Center c/o Brewster Funeral Service, PO Box 885, Manchester, VT 05255.

description: Russian Stocks and Bonds Plummet Into Free Fall

description: BROCK-Sam. On August 12, 1998 of Jamesburg, NJ. Beloved husband of Betty. Devoted father of Ellen and Michael. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer and Rebecca. He will be in our hearts forever. Graveside services 1PM, Friday, August 14th, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Rituals From Old Formosa With Spins and Clapping
description: The culture and history of the nine aboriginal tribes of Formosa, believed to be the original inhabitants of the island of Taiwan, were fast disappearing when a group of young aborigines decided to preserve them. In 1991, the group began to collect, study and reconstruct the dances and songs of their elders. And so the Formosa Aboriginal Song and Dance Troupe was born.

description: LISZ-Gary Kent. Of New York City. On August 11, 1998. He was 44 years old. He was a painter, award-winning costume designer, & professor of Design at Parsons & The Fashion Institute of Technology. Mr. Lisz is survived by his parents, Dorothy & Leonard Lisz of Romney, West Virginia, his nephew, Paul Rodriguez of Washington, D.C., his companion Kenneth Daigle of Manhattan & countless collaborators and loving friends. A funeral service for family and close friends will be held Monday, August 17th, at 7 P.M. at the Fourth Universalist Society, at Central Park West and 76th Street. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions in his name can be made to The Hetrick-Martin Institute, 2 Astor Place, New York City, 10003.

title: A More Sedate Woodstock Tries to Lure Yuppies, Not Hippies
description: Twenty-nine years ago, people came here by the tens, and then hundreds, of thousands, abandoning spray-painted Volkswagen buses and bumper-stickered cars along clogged roads, walking for miles to the festival of rock-and-roll called Woodstock.

title: Historic Bungalow Camp Is Facing the Bulldozers
description: The southern stretch of Staten Island includes an unusual slice of land called Spanish Camp, where the herons glide and the Raritan Bay beckons. It is a place where the people living in the camp's bungalows recently enjoyed a form of entertainment not provided by satellite dish: a clear view of a rising full moon.

title: Pop and Jazz Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: He Likes Video Games? Nobody's Perfect
description: ''How Stella Got Her Groove Back'' is far from the first Hollywood movie to flaunt the look and attitude of a glitzy travel brochure. But it may be the first to blatantly portray a tropical paradise as a sexual mecca beckoning tired American businesswomen to shed their clothes and inhibitions and roll around with the local talent.

title: New Video Releases
description: Kundun

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Falls; Asian Slump Slows Exports
description: Japan's current account surplus fell in June from May, the ninth decline in the last 13 months, as exports to other Asian nations slowed and imports rebounded from a two-and-a-half-year low.

title: A Young and Uninnocent America
description: American 19th-century art is rarely as simple as it looks. A Thomas Cole landscape seems straightforward enough, with its mountains, forests and moody skies evoking an inspirational lift, a nostalgic sigh. In fact, its impulses are urgent and unsettling, full of personal disquiet, political directives, spiritual yearning.

title: Catching 30's New York With Light and Shadow
description: Few printmakers of the 1920's and 30's caught the spirit of New York in that era with quite the pizazz of Martin Lewis (1881-1962), an Australian who came to the city at 19 and made it his own. Buildings, views, neighborhoods, street gangs, storefronts, rooftops, shoppers, workers, idlers, relationships, even the weather, seem especially staged for Lewis, who got it all down in black and white, capturing people and architecture in the etching and drypoint techniques of which he was a master.

title: STONE RIVET AGREES TO ACQUIRE ENVIROTEST SYSTEMS
description: Stone Rivet Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Envirotest Systems Corporation, a provider of vehicle-inspection systems, for $17.25 a share, or $266.3 million. It will also assume debt of $275 million. Shares of Envirotest gained $1.75, to $16.75, on the American Stock Exchange. Stone Rivet is a unit of Britain's Newmall Ltd. Newmall is controlled by a group composed mainly of United States institutional investors, set up by Alchemy Partners. Envirotest, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., makes its vehicle-emissions testing equipment for states and municipalities.

description: To the Editor:

title: False Profits For 3 Years At Cendant
description: The Cendant Corporation, struggling to regain investor confidence amid an accounting scandal that has slashed its share price in half, had a good news, bad news story to tell investors yesterday. The good news was that profits for the first half of 1998 were robust. The bad news? More than $640 million of the profits reported for the last three years were fictional.

title: International Briefs; Revenues Rise 5.3% At France Telecom
description: The revenue of France Telecom S.A., Europe's second-biggest telephone company, accelerated in the second quarter as a surge in mobile phone use more than offset reduced tariffs for long-distance calls.

title: Disclosure of How a Gene Causes Breast Cancer
description: Scientists at the University of North Carolina have made an important discovery about how defects in one of the two breast cancer genes, BRCA1, raise the risk of the disease: They leave cells without the normal ability to correct certain mistakes that commonly occur in their genetic machinery.

title: Remembering The Tempests Of Adolescence
description: Fred Koehler is such a natural in ''When I Was a Girl, I Used to Scream and Shout'' you forget now and then that the play is not about him.

description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADY, JOHN F.
description: BRADY-John F. Died August 11, 1998. Born September 2, 1929 in Brooklyn, NY. Went to sea at the age of sixteen with U.S. Army Transport Service (now Military Sealift Command) for two years. Enlisted in the U.S. Navy in Seattle, WA. in December 1947. Served with distinction in China & Japan. Was decorated for service with USMC in the Korean War, a member of the ''Chosen Few,'' wounded in action and a recipient of the Purple Heart. Upon discharge, sailed five years with Merchant Marines as Second Engineer. Came ashore to work as a representative for his union, the Brotherhood of Marine Engineers, which later became American Maritime Officers. He held every union office (except President) for the next forty years, including Executive Director of Legislation Affairs in Washington, DC. He remained a consultant to his union until his death. He also was a founding charter member of the Friendly Sons of the Shillelagh (Jersey Shore). Survived by his long-suffering, ever-loving wife of forty-two years, Kitty (Catherine); daughters, Catherine of Pompano Beach, FL and Cynthia of Bradley Beach, NJ; sons, Phillip of Pompano Beach, John F. II of Bricktown, NJ and Scott (who is currently sailing with U.S. Merchant Marines); granddaughters, Danielle (''Tiki,'' 18) and Michelle (''Little Person,'' 15); and grandsons, John F. III (14), Patrick (12) and Kevin (10) (''Moe, Larry and Curly''); and Myles of Smiles, his ''Little Friend'' (4). Also survived by his sisters, Rusty of Deerfield Beach, FL., and Peggy of Long Island, NY. Funeral Liturgy will be Saturday 10 A.M. at St. Martha's R.C. Church, Herbertsville Road, Pt. Pleasant. Burial will follow at Monmouth Memorial Park. Visitation will be Friday 24PM & 7-9PM at Colonial Funeral Home, 2170 Highway 88, Brick, NJ.

title: Boy, 14, Is Charged in Beating Of Half Sister, 2, in Brooklyn
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was accused yesterday of beating his 2-year-old half sister so severely that she remains in critical condition.

title: Water Truck Discounted As Carrier Of Explosive
description: After initial surmises that the bomb that exploded here last Friday outside the American Embassy was attached to an embassy-owned water truck, investigators are shifting their attention to other possibilities.

title: Earnings at Kmart and Gap Are Better Than Expected
description: The Kmart Corporation and Gap Inc., two big retailers, reported quarterly earnings yesterday that were better than expected, aided by the strong economy and a return to the basic fashions favored by their mainstay customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALBREICH, STANLEY I.
description: HALBREICH-Stanley I. To Stanley: I want you to know how much I loved you and how much I treasured your loyalty, counsel, generosity and love. You will always remain my big brother and dearest friend. May you rest in peace. Michael Balber

title: The Staggering Russian Economy
description: The ailing Russian economy seems to have nine lives, but they are rapidly running out. The latest crisis, less than a month after the International Monetary Fund provided a new bailout, is bank-based. Russian banks owe lots of dollars and are having trouble paying them back.

title: 'Section 33'
description: Dumbo Art Center

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOSTEN, KEVIN B.
description: HOSTEN-Kevin B., Ph.D. 2/18/53-8/14/94. Remembered with much love always. Burl, Anne, Wanda, Paul, Ronal

title: Under the Spell of the Horses
description: One finds worlds within worlds in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., a fabled watering hole for high hats and hot tipsters over the better part of the last two centuries. There are the ancient mineral springs, the Revolutionary War sites, the New York City Ballet and the National Museum of Dance, the hushed forests and cricket-echoing parks, and the signposts of a civic history involving blinkered cads, visionary patrons and some of America's most prominent family dynasties. There is so much to learn and do that, for much of the year, it might be observed that Saratoga's quadripeds of distinction are its tourists, creeping toward their beds at the end of another exhausting day of sightseeing, rest and relaxation.

title: 7 Die in California Desert, Probably Left by Smuggler
description: In an oven-hot patch of desert just north of the Mexico border, the bodies of seven people were found today, apparently the victims of the heat and their dreams for a better life.

title: Can an Embassy Be Open and  Secure?
description: As the curator of the National Building Museum in Washington, I attended two meetings in 1980 with State Department officials and the architect Frank Gehry, who presented proposals for a United States embassy in Damascus, Syria. His design was architecturally impressive: a stark, white building behind an open courtyard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, LOUISE MARIE
description: ROSENBERG-Louise Marie, 63. Died peacefully Tuesday in her Wilton home, surrounded by family. With husband Peter, she transformed their business Vallin Galleries into a renowned Asian art gallery. Louise was an inspirational, nurturing mother and friend. She created a loving family & gracious home with beautiful gardens. She is survived by her husband, six children Robert, Jean, Michael, Thomas, Simon and Nicolas, five grandchildren, and sister Mary.

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Summer hours vary for galleries and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Six Jets Move Up, At Least For a Game
description: Vinny Testaverde, who is replacing Glenn Foley, and five other Jets who began the summer as backups learned today that they would start Saturday's preseason game against the Baltimore Ravens.

title: Reviewing CUNY's Admissions Policy
description: The proposal by trustees of the City University of New York to bar admission to CUNY's senior colleges for students who have not passed skills tests in reading, writing and mathematics is too far-reaching not to be reviewed independently by state education authorities. The plan, to be phased in over three years, could affect nearly half the students entering the 11 four-year colleges. Such sweeping change demands a full public review, as provided for under state law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, RAY
description: SMITH-Ray nee Blum in her 82nd year on August 12, 1998 of North Miami Beach, FL. Formerly of Cedarhurst, NY. Beloved wife of the late Al. Loving & devoted mother of Terry and Bob Bloom, Marilyn & Ed Brown, Dr. Arden and Susan Smith. Cherished grandmother of Nancy Lipman, Natalie and Phil Murphy, Linda & Don Panzarino, Dr. Suzanne Brown, Felicia Brown, Alexander and Asher Smith; and great-grandmother of Arielle, Jessica, and Daniel Panzarino. Fought a courageous and valiant battle against A.L.S. Funeral services will be graveside on Friday, August 14th at 10 AM at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Myrtle Avenue, Glendale, New York.

title: Righty From San Diego Could Solidify Bullpen
description: The Yankees are discussing the possibility of acquiring one of two relievers from the San Diego Padres, according to a Yankee official -- including the right-hander Brian Boehringer, whom the Yankees lost in last year's expansion draft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, NATHALIE PEARL
description: ISRAEL-Nathalie Pearl. On August 13, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jack Pearl and David Israel. Loving stepmother of Robert, Larry and the late Oscar Israel. Dear cousin of Bernice Jupiter and Roberta Fuchs. Cherished stepgrandmother of Andrea, Anthony, Ronald, Tristan, Michael, and James Israel. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, Saturday, 6:30-8:30PM with services Sunday, August 16th at 11:30AM. Contributions in her memory may be to the Actors Temple.

title: Weaker Dollar and Debt Sale Help Keep Securities Depressed
description: A weaker dollar and the third part of the Treasury's quarterly debt auctions kept prices of Government securities depressed yesterday for the second consecutive day. Also weighing on prices is the Federal Reserve's monetary policy committee meeting next week. The price of the benchmark 30-year bond dropped nearly a half-point, to 107, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.63 percent, from 5.60 percent on Wednesday.

title: U.S. Retreats From Vow to Use Force if Iraq Blocks Inspectors
description: As Iraq's challenge to the United Nations has become more acute, the Clinton Administration has retreated from its pledge of immediate military punishment if Iraq interferes with arms inspectors.

title: No Double Standard At Boston Globe
description: To the Editor:

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Ruble Throws Another Scare Into Markets
description: The growing possibility of a devaluation of the Russian ruble swept the world's markets yesterday. Although the Russians insist there will not be a devaluation, the threat has already led to a major selloff in emerging markets and proved a drag on Wall Street and other major stock markets.

title: West Point Greets the Enemy; Author Once Shunned Returns to His Alma Mater
description: Lucian K. Truscott 4th has never been shy about pointing -- or, more precisely, wagging -- his finger at his hallowed alma mater, which looms tall and imposing above the Hudson River here.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Public Lives on July 28 about plans for a fund-raising event for President Clinton at Amagansett, N.Y., misstated the relationship between the public relations woman Peggy Siegal and the gossip reporter Claudia Cohen. Ms. Cohen is not a client of Ms. Siegal.

title: RIGHTS EXPANDED IN MEDICARE CASE
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that Medicare patients are entitled to immediate hearings and other protections when they are denied care by health maintenance organizations.

title: Harmless? That's Just His Manner
description: The minute Louisa (Carri Levinson), the young bespectacled schoolteacher, walks in the door, you know she's too prim and repressed not to mean trouble. By the end of the movie, she's bound either to blossom into a ravenous sexual being or to kill somebody. Too bad the same thing isn't as clear about Henry (Neil Giuntoli).

title: Movie Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 6.

description: The Federal Trade Commission said that a popular site on the World Wide Web had lied to more than two million subscribers when it told them that it would not disclose personal information it had collected from them.

description: Now comes the hard part.

title: Ruble Rescue Redux
description: There is something about Russia's financial crises that won't quit, no matter how much money is thrown at them, no matter how hard the Government tries to do what its creditors expect.

description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a widow was entitled to collect her husband's accidental-death benefits although he died in a car crash in which he was illegally drunk.

description: To the Editor:

title: Images Shimmer Upon Screens, Installed in the Imagination
description: Installation pieces involving moving images, whether film or video, are prominent among art's current staples, and the number of women pursuing the medium is on the rise. So it barely bends the law of averages to find two such installations at the Whitney Museum of American Art: ''Swoon'' by Janine Antoni and ''Blind Side'' by Liisa Roberts. And it's not so surprising that they play off each other in revealing ways.

description: Michael Rosenfeld Gallery

title: Metro Business; Bank Picks Jersey City Site
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York announced yesterday that it had selected a 29,826-square-foot building at 30 Montgomery Street in Jersey City as the new site of its operations center, currently housed at Corporate Place South in Piscataway, N.J.

title: Players Drop Charge, Look to Arbitration
description: Faced with the failure of their litigation initiative, National Basketball Association players withdrew their unfair labor practice charge yesterday and prepared to fight the league's lockout on the arbitration front.

title: Frailest Residents Of Times Square Remain Uprooted
description: Three weeks after a construction scaffold collapsed, raining debris on 43d Street, killing one woman and forcing hundreds of people from their homes and businesses, some semblance of normality has been restored to Times Square. The glitter has returned to most Broadway theaters, street-corner peddlers are back, and the crush of traffic can once again be felt for miles.

title: Accounts
description: * Ames Scullin O'Haire Advertising, Atlanta, was awarded three accounts, with total billings estimated at $10 billion: the International Bottled Water Association, Alexandria, Va.; Randstad Staffing Services, Altanta, and Hire Power, New Canaan, Conn.

title: PRESIDENT WEIGHS ADMITTING HE HAD SEXUAL CONTACTS
description: President Clinton has had extensive discussions with his inner circle about a strategy of acknowledging to a grand jury on Monday that he had intimate sexual encounters with Monica S. Lewinsky in the White House, senior advisers have said.

title: Observer; Lament For a Lost Season
description: Calendrically speaking, this is what the British used to call the silly season. It was a time for sightings of the Loch Ness Monster. Men stately as monuments fled Westminster for Scotland, there to shoot small birds. Newspapers doubled their usual volume of stories about ghost-infested houses and messages arriving from beyond the grave.

description: An article on Tuesday about the winners of the Urbanworld International Film Festival omitted a credit for the winning documentary ''Classified X,'' directed by Mark Daniels. Melvin Van Peebles conceived, wrote and narrated the film, which is now to be known as ''Melvin Van Peebles's 'Classified X,' '' according to its distributor, Fox Lorber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGABIAN, LOUISE SOPHIE
description: AGABIAN-Louise Sophie. May 22, 1924 to August 7, 1998. Model, Artist, Interior Designer, Real Estate Broker and Business Woman. Her tremendous loss is mourned by beloved daughters Nina, Lori and Lisa; grandsons Samuel & Tristan; granddaughter Allegra; her many friends and extended family. She was married to Samuel Agabian who died in 1962, a former Executive Vice President of Sperry Rand Corporation. She touched and inspired all those who knew her and was loved for her vibrant, tenacious and indomitable spirit. Her unwavering devotion to her family and friends, especially those in need, is one of her legacies. Private service held in San Francisco August 11th. Memorial services will be held at 11AM on September 27, 1998 in New York at The Armenian Church of the Holy Martyrs, 209-15 Horace Harding Expressway, Bayside, New York 11364. 718-225-0235. For information, call: 415-775-1102.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The dollar declined against the Japanese yen as traders took profits and worried about potential action by Tokyo to support its currency. The dollar settled at 145.16 yen in New York, down from 146.44 Wednesday.

title: Gathering of Old-School Politicians Mourns a Master of the Craft
description: Their stories recalled long-forgotten eras of New York City political history, peppered with reminiscences of neighborhood campaigns in Brooklyn that even years ago had become the stuff of footnotes. Their common thread was the man who had either engineered the campaigns or produced strategies to derail them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCCOTTI, ANGELO
description: ZUCCOTTI-Angelo. Anne Alexis Cote Taylor, Pres. of the Board of Directors Robert D'Amico, M.D. Chairman of the Medical Advisory Board

description: When the Giants and Jacksonville met in the preseason last year, Jaguars quarterback Mark Brunell sustained a knee injury that kept him out of two regular-season games.

description: Threat to Swiss Lifted

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICE, HARRY D.
description: RICE-Harry D., Jr. Of Staten Island on August 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Joan (nee Harrigan). Loving father of Harry D., III, Michael and Ginger Mazzarella. Dear father-in-law of Joan Rice and James Mazzarella. Adored grandfather of Harry, IV and Meghan Rice and Ashley and Morgan Mazzarella. Dear brother of Kathleen Watts.
