Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Grit, Toil And Trouble
description: Videos arrive from all points on the compass, which always makes for interesting contrasts. This month, for example, a generally humdrum assortment of mainline movies gets a nice spin from two different kinds of films that themselves come from very different places.

title: Rent Laws Are Weak
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Apartment Building Planned for 42d St.
description: The J.D. Carlisle Corporation, a New York property investment company, has bought the development site at 627 West 42d Street for $21.5 million.

title: Animation Meets Charm In Whirligigs
description: On Sunday, Skinner Inc. of Boston auctioned off an Uncle Sam whirligig, or wind toy, for $12,650 at its sale of American Furniture and Decorative Arts. In fine condition, the 72-inch-tall carved wood and sheet-metal sculpture depicts Uncle Sam sawing a log resting on a sawbuck. Standing beneath a flagpole, Stars and Stripes flapping away, this Uncle Sam is quite the dandy. He has long, wavy blond hair and wears bold red-and-white striped pants, a long blue tail coat and a white top hat with a star-studded blue hatband. He braces his foot on a log meticulously painted to show individual rings of growth. The log moves back and forth as the wind hits an elaborate mechanism underneath, a carousel of wind paddles.

title: When She Says 'I Do,' She Means 'Not You'
description: Pity poor Francesca Babini (Ines Sastre), the beautiful daughter of proper bourgeois parents in a small north Italian town in 1899. Francesca has reluctantly agreed to wed Edgardo Osti (Dario Cantarelli), an affluent older businessman with beady eyes and a sly wet smile, in an arranged marriage that will solve her father's business problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLUGER, MICHAEL
description: KLUGER-Michael. On August 12, 1998. We mourn the passing of Michael Kluger, beloved husband, devoted father and grandfather. He was 76 years old. Mr. Kluger was born in Cracow, Poland. A Holocaust survivor and Talmudic scholar, Mr. Kluger led a Displaced Persons camp of 5,000 people in Salzburg, Austria, prior to emigrating to the U.S. Once here, he became a leader in business, civic and religious circles. He was a founding partner of SKS Associates and actively involved in real estate development and management for the past 27 years. He was also a founder and President of the New Cracow Friendship Society; former President and an active Baal Koreh of the Lake Success Jewish Center; and esteemed member and supporter of the UJA, AKIM, BEIT HALOCHEM and other charitable organizations. He was active in Holocaust education as a speaker and in the American and international gatherings of Holocaust survivors. Mr. Kluger is survived by his beloved wife of 52 years, Rose; his loving sons and daughters-in-law, Lawrence, Addie, Alan and Robin; and his precious grandchildren, Daniel, Allison, Katie, Andrew and Jason. Services today at 11:30 AM at Lake Success Jewish Center, Lakeville Road, Great Neck, NY.

title: Hernandez Gives Fans A Glimpse of October
description: If you closed your eyes and made believe you were wearing a fall jacket instead of a short-sleeved shirt, the calendar felt like it had jumped ahead two months in the Bronx last night. There was an October feeling at Yankee Stadium because 53,835 fans roared through the turnstiles for brilliant baseball instead of Beanie Babies, and Orlando Hernandez made their visits worthwhile.

title: The Haydn Quartets, Play by Play
description: The 68 string quartets of Haydn present a classic instance of great music more heard about than heard. For generations, many commentators, historians and knowing musicians have cited these works as among the greatest achievements in all of music. My colleague Bernard Holland recently wrote that Haydn was the supreme master of the string quartet, greater even than Mozart, Beethoven and Bartok, and this assessment is shared by many.

title: Unreadable Masterpiece
description: To the Editor:

A funeral service will be held at Church of the Advent in Westbury, NY at 11:00 AM on Saturday, August 15 with the reception afterward in the parish, 555 Advent St., Westbury, NY.

title: New Attacks Aimed at Ethnic Chinese Viewed as Test for Jakarta : Beijing Watching Indonesia Violence
description: SINGAPORE  Indonesian police on Thursday reported a new outbreak of anti-Chinese violence as hundreds of ethnic Chinese left the country or sought to do so for fear of more attacks.

title: Jurors Hear More Secret Service Testimony
description: Prosecutors briefly questioned several more Secret Services officers today before the grand jury inquiring into President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Ned Gillette, 53, Adventurer, Is Killed in Northern Kashmir
description: Ned Gillette of Sun Valley, Idaho, a 53-year-old adventurer, mountain climber, sailor, skier, photographer, journalist and author, was shot to death the night of Aug. 5 while sleeping in a tent in Kashmir, the disputed northern region between India and Pakistan.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the initial stock offering of Geocities, an Internet company, misspelled the name of a rival service offered by WhoWhere. It is Angelfire, not Anglefire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABB, SHIRLEY
description: ABB-Shirley. Much beloved wife of Marvin, passed away on August 12, 1998. Cherished and devoted mother of Toni and Wayne and loving grandmother of Sarah. She will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. Services Sunday 12 noon at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, L.I. Interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: California G.O.P. Senate Nominee Goes From Long Shot to Star
description: Less than three months ago, Matt Fong was little known outside California, where he is State Treasurer. Now, Republican heavyweights like Newt Gingrich and Trent Lott regard him as a new best friend.

title: Turf Champion Heads Saratoga Field
description: Like Mark McGwire and other heavy hitters, Chief Bearhart does not always hit a home run. In fact, he has lost two of his last three starts. But the Chief, the champion turf horse in North America last year, was made the 8-5 favorite today as he and six other grass specialists were entered in the $300,000 Sword Dancer Handicap on Saturday at Saratoga Race Course.

title: Bioterrorism Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Reopening In Midtown
description: Stores and theaters were hardly alone in suffering from the collapse of an elevator support tower on July 21 at the Conde Nast building under construction at Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets. The International Center of Photography Midtown at 43d Street and Avenue of the Americas was also forced to close the day of the accident, and could not reopen until Tuesday, a full three weeks later.

title: A Bid to Shield Medical Sales Of Marijuana
description: The City Council today designated the Oakland Marijuana Buyers' Cooperative as officers of the city, an effort to shield the group from Federal civil and criminal prosecution.

title: Police Find Bodies Of Man and Woman
description: The decomposing bodies of a man and a woman who the police said had been stabbed to death were found in a Harlem apartment yesterday afternoon.

title: Richard Mansfield Bilby, 67, Judge in Charles Keating Case
description: Richard Mansfield Bilby, a senior Federal judge in Arizona who presided over the 1992 case against Charles H. Keating Jr., a symbol of the savings-and-loan collapse of the 1980's, died on Tuesday as he was walking his dog near his summer home in Flagstaff, Ariz. He was 67 and a lifetime resident of Tucson, Ariz.

title: CABLEVISION TO PAY $160 MILLION FOR CLEARVIEW CINEMA
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Clearview Cinema Group Inc. for $160 million in cash and stock in its first move into the movie-theater business. Cablevision, the nation's fifth-largest cable-television operator, is paying $24.25 a share; 55 percent will be paid in cash and 45 percent in common stock. Cablevision is also taking on $80 million of Clearview's debt. Clearview, which is based in Chatham, N.J., operates 45 movie screens, primarily in New York and New Jersey. Cablevision's shares fell $1.1875, to $86.5625; shares of Clearview rose 50 cents, to $22.50.

title: A Taste of Water From the Third Tunnel
description: The Third Water Tunnel seems timeless. In 1954, city officials determined that it was needed, and in 1970 construction began on what has long been billed as the biggest public works project in America.

title: Of Love and Literary Betrayal
description: ''Some things you don't touch.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALM, MICHAEL
description: PALM-Michael. The Board of Directors and the staff of the American Foundation for AIDS Research (AmFAR) mourn the loss of a humanitarian and philanthropist whose commitment to the fight against AIDS and for the protection of the civil rights of gays and lesbians was exemplary. Mathilde Krim, Ph.D. Chairman, AmFAR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINKIN, SARAH RIEUR
description: MINKIN-Sarah Rieur. On August 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted stepmother of Dr. Vera F. Minkin. Also survived by her very loving family and many friends. Service Sunday, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street & Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to Hadassah, 50 West 58 Street, NY. NY 10019.

title: Kosovo Separatist Chief Picks Delegation Without Rebels
description: In a serious setback for Western governments hoping to end the war in Kosovo through negotiations, the ethnic Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, today named a team to negotiate peace with the Serbs that does not have the ingredient diplomats consider essential to success: representatives of all ethnic Albanian political forces.

title: Fewer City Students Pass Reading Exam
description: The percentage of New York City public-school children who passed this year's state reading exam fell sharply from last year, according to scores released yesterday to district superintendents.

title: Retail Sales Fell in July, U.S. Reports
description: Retail sales fell four-tenths of 1 percent in July, reflecting the General Motors strikes, the Commerce Department said today. Excluding automobiles, sales rose for the sixth time in seven months.

title: Air Traffic Control Errors Lead to Inquiry
description: Safety investigators are looking into whether an air traffic control center near Cleveland has routinely hidden evidence of operational errors, in which planes are mistakenly ordered to fly too close to one another, after discovering three such incidents on June 23 that went unreported.

title: At the Movies
description: Suddenly A Somebody

title: New Jersey Bank Acquired
description: Commerce Bancorp Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire the Community First Banking Company for $28 a share, or about $60 million. Commerce Bancorp, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., a bank holding company, said it had no plans to lay off any employees after the merger. Community First Banking is the holding company of Tinton Falls State Bank, a community bank with seven branches in New Jersey and assets of $190 million.

title: Disclosure About Another on Rowland Ticket, This Time by Candidate Himself
description: A week after embarrassing disclosures led another member of Gov. John G. Rowland's statewide ticket to quit the race, the Republican candidate for secretary of the state has volunteered that he is battling the Internal Revenue Service over back taxes and has no college degree, despite what his campaign biography implies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISHER, HAROLD
description: FLEISHER-Harold, Ph.D. The Covenant Foundation mourns the passing of Dr. Harold Fleisher, father-in-law of Dr. Jonathan S. Woocher, a founding member of our Board of Directors. A man of keen intellect and ready wit, Hal Fleisher will be missed by all who knew him. Our condolences to Jon, Sherry, Terri, Meredith and the rest of his devoted family. Susan Crown, President Eli N. Evans, Chairman Judith Ginsberg, Exec. Director

title: Dow Falls 93.46 as Threat of Russian Crisis Hurts Shares
description: A growing sense of crisis in the Russian economy helped push United States markets lower yesterday.

title: Judge Rules Home Is Jail For Boys Held In Girl's Death
description: A judge today ruled that two boys, ages 7 and 8, who are charged with brutally killing an 11-year-old girl for her bicycle can return home to await trial, but must wear electronic monitoring devices and stay inside 24 hours a day.

title: One Museum, Five Shows and a Million Lives and Passions
description: The Bronx Museum of the Arts is one of the city's more animated and resilient cultural spaces. A quick subway ride from Manhattan, it stands on the Grand Concourse, surrounded by Art Deco apartment buildings whose imposing facades are reminders of days when the neighborhood was upscale and middle-class.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11

title: Cola War II: The Bottler Battle; On Pepsi Front Line, It's Getting Dangerous to Go Solo
description: This is the capital of Pepsi country, where babies born at regional hospitals go home with Pepsi birth certificates, along with the state-issued ones. They grow up playing Pepsi-sponsored Little League and develop a taste for barbecue, hush puppies and one of the more unusual indigenous snacks: a package of salted peanuts poured directly into a bottle of Pepsi-Cola, to be drunk and chewed all at once.

title: Report Says City Economy Is Too Tied to Wall St.
description: New York City's economy is now more heavily dependent on Wall Street's fortunes than it was before the stock market crash in 1987, according to a report released today by the office of State Comptroller H. Carl McCall.

title: USA FLORAL IS ACQUIRING FLORIMEX FROM DIMON INC.
description: USA Floral Products Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Florimex Worldwide, a floral-products importer and distributor, for about $90 million plus assumed debt. USA Floral said the agreement would create a combined company with annual revenue of nearly $1 billion. USA Floral, based in Washington, is a floral-products distributor. Florimex, which consists of a number of Dimon Inc. units, has annual revenue of about $400 million. Dimon, based in Danville, Va., is a leaf-tobacco dealer and importer and distributor of flowers.

title: Wendell, Bard of Flushing, Now Can Close His Stanzas
description: For someone who says he does not necessarily want to bring attention to himself, Turk Wendell has an unusual way of going about it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, REBECCA
description: GREENBERG-Rebecca. Died on August 5, at home in Springfield, Mass., after a brief illness. Age 86. A lifelong social justice activist and teacher, she joined the Peace Corps at age 80. She was the widow of Bernard Greenberg, a negotiator for the United Steelworkers of America. She is survived by her children, Jean Stange of Denver, Colo., Linda Stone Davidoff of New York City, Richard of Springfield, Mass., and Adria Lique of Hopewell, N.J., 13 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

title: At the Mercy of Foolish Friends
description: A sybaritic Malaysian idyll at the start of ''Return to Paradise'' leaves a nightmarish aftermath throughout the rest of the story. In this brooding drama of friendship and moral responsibility, directed with somber intelligence by Joseph Ruben (''Sleeping With the Enemy,'' ''The Stepfather''), three friends endure the life-threatening consequences of a foolish mistake. Sheriff (Vince Vaughn), Lewis (Joaquin Phoenix) and Tony (David Conrad) cap off their post-college frolicking with a carelessness that ensnares Lewis. When the story picks up again, two years later, Lewis may have only eight more days to live.

title: Saddam Hussein Makes His Move
description: The two international inspectors who know the most about Iraq's efforts to create new weapons of mass destruction have raised an alarm that President Clinton and other world leaders must not ignore. Richard Butler, the chief United Nations weapons inspector, and Mohammed el-Baradei, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, informed the Security Council this week that they no longer had the means to monitor and prevent Iraqi programs to develop nuclear, chemical and biological weapons.

title: FINGERHUT IN $120 MILLION DEAL FOR ARIZONA MAIL ORDER
description: The Fingerhut Companies agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Arizona Mail Order, a catalogue seller of women's apparel, for $120 million. Arizona Mail Order will operate as a unit of Fingerhut, and Fingerhut said the transaction would expand its product line and its catalogue and data base marketing business. Arizona Mail Order, based in Tucson, has annual revenue of $140 million and more than 1.6 million customers. Fingerhut, based in Minnetonka, Minn., is a data base marketing company that sells products and services through catalogues, direct marketing and the Internet. It had $1.8 billion in revenue in 1997.

title: Reviving a Sunny French Confection
description: As psychedelic in its way as the Beatles' album ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band,'' which was released in the same year (1967), the French musical ''The Young Girls of Rochefort'' is a garish but charming curiosity that pushes giddy Gallic romanticism to the brink of camp. Created by Jacques Demy with the composer Michel Legrand (the same team that concocted ''The Umbrellas of Cherbourg'' three years earlier), the movie, which opens today at Film Forum, is a sun-drenched, candy-colored, singing and dancing valentine to the Hollywood confections of Vincente Minnelli.

title: Fedyk Signs
description: The Rangers have signed Brent Fedyk, a free agent left wing, the team said.

title: ESTERLINE TECHNOLOGIES AGREES TO BUY KIRKHILL RUBBER
description: The Esterline Technologies Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the privately held Kirkhill Rubber Company for $83 million. Esterline said that it had already acquired about two-thirds of Kirkhill's stock outstanding, representing shares held by the Kirkhill Employee Stock Ownership and Savings Plan. Kirkhill, based in La Brea, Calif., makes custom-engineered products for the aerospace industry from synthetic rubbers known as elastomers. It has annual revenue of $60 million. Esterline, based in Bellevue, Wash., makes engineered products for the commercial aircraft, aerospace and military industries. It had revenue of $210.3 million in the six months ended April 30.

title: Corrections
description: The Industry View column in Business Day on Monday, about Web sites that serve as marketing affiliates to other Web sites, included an outdated figure for the number of Web sites that serve as marketing affiliates for the on-line retailer CD Now. It is more than 75,000, not 11,000.

title: Miami Journal; Defying Doom Wishes of the Exiles, Castro Keeps Popping Up
description: The first time Elizabeth Gueits heard that Fidel Castro was dead, she was in school and 6 years old.

title: The City Life; Just Another Night at the Stadium
description: Beyond the right-field bleachers at Yankee Stadium, there is a gap high in the outer wall. From most seats, through that gap you can see the 4 train passing on elevated tracks. No one needs to be reminded where he is when he's sitting in Yankee Stadium, but when the 4 train passes the sense of place is suddenly made keener.

title: Japan's Corruption Fighter Is Shunted Aside
description: Earlier this year, it seemed that a sweeping corruption investigation might send a good number of Japan's mighty philosopher-kings, the bureaucrats who largely run the country, to prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOSKES, PEARL
description: SHOSKES-Pearl. On August 13, 1998. Beloved wife of Michael Shoskes. Loving mother of Janet Eschen and the late Jeffrey Shoskes. Adoring grandmother of Rebecca & Mark Eschen. Services are at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Sunday, at 9:45 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, DR. SIDNEY
description: ROTHSTEIN-Dr. Sidney. Temple Israel, Lawrence, New York mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to the bereaved family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi David M. Land, President

title: Close Enough to Evil To Look Beyond It
description: In three decades of studying guilt, responsibility and the nature of evil through the twin obsessions of her professional life, Nazis and child criminals, Gitta Sereny has regularly been accused of growing too close to her subjects, of becoming not only a confessor but an apologist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISHER, DR. HAROLD
description: FLEISHER-Dr. Harold, 76. Of Poughkeepsie, New York. Died on August 13 of leukemia. A pioneer in computers, he retired from a thirty-seven year career at I.B.M. as an I.B.M. Fellow. Professor Emeritus of Physics, S.U.N.Y. New Paltz, he also taught at Vassar and Marist Colleges, both in Poughkeepsie. Dr. Fleisher earned his Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Physics from the University of Rochester, and his Ph.D from Case Western Reserve University. He was the founding President of the Hudson Valley Technology Development Center and a Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Active in civic and Jewish affairs, he was a past President of the Jewish Federation of Dutchess County and a Board member of Temple Beth-El in Poughkeepsie. He is survived by his wife of fifty-two years, Terry, his children, Sherry and Jonathan Woocher, Leslie and Robert Schwartz, and David Fleisher and Melissa Krantz, and his grandchildren, Meredith and Peter, Benjamin, Rebecca, Adam, Jenny, and Sara. Services to be held on Sunday, August 16 at 1:00 P.M., at Temple Beth-El, Poughkeepsie. Contributions to the American Cancer Society or the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science. Shiva will be observed at the family's homes.

title: Finance Chief Confirms Steps To Aid Markets In Hong Kong
description: After days of speculative attacks on Hong Kong's currency, the government confirmed today that it had intervened to shore up the stock and futures markets.

title: Thompson Wins Her 20th Title
description: Jenny Thompson claimed her 20th individual national title Friday night, winning the 100-meter butterfly in the U.S. Swimming Championships in Fresno, Calif.

title: A Rerun From '97 Leaves Fassel Disturbed
description: For the third time in three meetings, the Jacksonville Jaguars brought out the worst in the Giants.

title: Semantics Alone Won't Save Clinton; Deviancy Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Religion Journal; Women Smash Yet Another Barrier
description: Over the last decade or so, a woman's serving as a bishop has become less remarkable among some Protestant denominations, as the office has been opened to female clerics in the United Methodist Church, the Episcopal Church and the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America.

title: Russia's Markets Rally as Western Powers Discuss Rescue
description: Russia's financial markets rallied today after the Kremlin and the major Western powers indicated that they were working on another round of plans to end the nation's economic crisis.

title: Cottage Tenants Settle With Developers
description: The cottagers are leaving their cottages.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column on Monday, about an accounting convention that lets companies write off part of the price of acquisitions as a cost of continuing research, overstated the degree to which Microsoft has used it. The company did such accounting once -- last year, to write off $196 million of the $425 million it paid for WebTV.

title: About New York; A Salesman Who Paid Attention
description: ZARA GRAUER still remembers her first date with Howard Bardach. He stepped aside to let her board a bus, then sat beside her and suggested they share some coffee and conversation. Walking home afterward, he asked her not to walk so fast.

title: Holocaust Study Doesn't Deny Jewish History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENNESSEY, JEAN (NEE CONA)
description: HENNESSEY-Jean (nee Cona) on August 13, 1998. Beloved wife of the late John. Dear mother of Jean Marie Sheridan, Kevin and Charles. Loving sister of Marie Oliva, Pauline Bryant, Catherine Chierchio, and Paul. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Funeral Monday 9am from Ridge Chapels Fourth Ave at 91st St, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 9:45am St. Rose of Lima Church. Visiting 79pm Sat; 2-5pm 7-9pm Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUNDERMANN, EDITH D.
description: SUNDERMANN-Edith D. Of East Quogue, Long Island, formerly of Pound Ridge, New York on August 13, 1998. Beloved wife of Richard. Loving mother of Eric and Kurt. Friends may call at the Oelker & Cox Funeral Home on Sunday 24PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Monday, 11 AM at the St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Mount Kisco, New York. Interment, private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the American Cancer Society, 30 Glenn St, White Plains, New York 10603.

title: International Briefs; Dennis Group Accepts Higher Bid From Henlys
description: Henlys Group P.L.C., a British bus maker, raised its bid for Dennis Group P.L.C. by 63 percent, to $:309 million ($501 million), topping a counteroffer from Mayflower P.L.C. and winning the endorsement of the Dennis board. The Henlys stock-and-cash offer values Dennis, which makes bus chassis, at 545 pence a share, based on the Henlys share price on Thursday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ENTERCOM COMUNICATIONS CORP., Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., , owner of 41 radio stations across the U.S., filed for an initial public offering of stock that is expected to raise an estimated $241.5 million.

title: Devastation From Explosion Permeates Kenyans' Lives
description: A fear swept the crowd gathered at the wreckage of the American Embassy the other day: that the 22-story Cooperative Bank next door was about to collapse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASLIN, PAUL
description: MASLIN-Paul. Beloved husband of Lucille; adored father of Janet and father-in-law of Ben; loving grandfather of John and Andrew. Services Sunday 1PM at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Hempstead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINBOND, BERNARD LIONEL
description: EINBOND-Bernard Lionel. Age 61. Beloved and loving husband of Linda Saxe Einbond. Loving and beloved father of Aaron Einbond and Julia Einbond. Services on Sunday at 10 A.M. at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINKIN, SARAH RIEUR
description: MINKIN-Sarah Rieur. Age 100. Four generations of the Minkin and Rieur families celebrate the life of Sarah Minkin. Loved and admired for her abundant energy and caring for others, she was an ardent advocate and exemplar of family loyalty, a healthy life style, professional responsibility and commitment to Jewish cultural identity. Born in Russia, she emigrated to the U.S. at age 14. She graduated in 1923 from the Nurses Training School of the Philadelphia Jewish Hospital. During World War II, after the death of her husband William Minkin, she enlisted in the U.S. Army Nurse Corps. After twenty years, serving in the Philippines, Japan, Germany and U.S., she retired with the rank of Major. Alert and in command until the end, Sarah Minkin leaves family and friends in whose memories and lives she will remain a vital force and influence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORCHARDT, MUTZ F.
description: BORCHARDT-Mutz F. August 14, 1998. Of New York City and East Hampton. Wife of Herbert H. Borchardt, mother of Robert L. Borchardt of Winter Park, FL and Susan B. Seigenfeld of Louisville, KY, mother-in-law of Trudi Borchardt and Edward P. Seigenfield, grandmother of Claudine Solin, Erik Nikolas & Gregory Borchardt. There will be a private burial.

title: Whitmans' Income Tax Was $300,000 for '97
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and her husband, John, earned $993,843 last year and owed $240,468 in Federal taxes and $58,652 in state taxes, according to the couple's 1997 tax returns.

title: For Clinton's Assistants, An Unpleasant Memory
description: ''I came to call it the 'Darkness at Noon' suite,'' said Sidney Blumenthal, President Clinton's communications coordinator, grimly recalling the bland yet fearsome grand jury room where dozens of Administration workers have been questioned by Federal prosecutors these past seven months, 12 blocks east of the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARVEL, AGNES STEWART
description: CARVEL-Agnes Stewart. On August 4, 1998 in London. Beloved wife of the late Thomas Carvel. Dear sister of Jane Ortowski and the late William Stewart, Isabel Zucchelli and Dorothy McLaughlin. The Service of Celebration and Thanksgiving for the life of Agnes Carvel is at 7PM Monday, August 17th at the Church of St Barnabas, Revolutionary Road, Ardsley, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Salvation Army or the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUMBINNER, ROSLYN SINGER
description: GUMBINNER-Roslyn Singer. The Jewish Repertory Theatre's Board of Directors and staff acknowledges with sadness the passing of our friend and benefactress, Roslyn Singer Gumbinner. To the Rinston, Ginsberg and Singer families and all who loved her, we offer our heartfelt condolences.

title: Civilians Flee Congo's Capital in Fear of Rebel Advance
description: Increasingly uncertain that the Government can keep approaching rebel forces at bay, thousands of foreigners and Congolese alike fled the capital today by whatever means they could.

title: Boaters' Paradise in the Bronx; A Marina Thrives Where Warehouses Cast Shadows
description: Along a narrow creek that divides a sooty Bronx industrial park from the whooshing traffic on the Hutchinson River Parkway, where the setting sun casts shadows of warehouses and tractor-trailers, exists a seagoing community like no other.

title: Times Square's Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ENRIGHT, DR. JOSEPH E.
description: ENRIGHT-Dr. Joseph E. Beloved husband of Kathleen, father of Shelly and Nicholas. Dear Joe, we miss you and you are forever in our hearts. Look forward to seeing you again.

title: FAST-FOOD CHAIN RESTATES 2D-QUARTER NET
description: The McDonald's Corporation restated its second-quarter net income to reverse a $125 million charge for a new food production system, saying it would spread the charge gradually as it pays for the changes. McDonald's, the world's largest fast-food chain, said it had made the change after discussions with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The change does not affect a $110 million charge McDonald's also took for headquarters job cuts. Net income was restated as $357.2 million, or 50 cents a diluted share, instead of $233.8 million, or 33 cents. The reversal did not affect profit from operations of $468 million, or 66 cents a diluted share.

title: Balloon Nears Halfway Point on Global Flight
description: Guided by a team of meteorologists, the balloonist Steve Fossett threaded his way through an ''atmospheric minefield'' yesterday and approached the west coast of Australia, completing nearly half of his attempted round-the-world flight.

title: Does Managed Care Save Money?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE RISES. Orange juice futures soared to a three-month high after a consultant predicted a smaller crop in Florida, the nation's biggest grower. Orange juice for September delivery surged 5.3 cents, to $1.125 a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, IRVING
description: STRAUSS-Irving. On Thursday, August 13th, 1998 of Hollywood, Florida. Formerly of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved husband of Lena (nee Goldfarb). Devoted father of Stanley Strauss and the late Allan Strauss. Loving grandfather of Jeffrey, Michael, Thomas, Kenneth, Andrew and Peter. Adored greatgrandfather of eleven. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey on Sunday, August 16, 1998 at 1 P.M. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ.

title: International Briefs; Hyundai to Shut Plants Blockaded by Strikers
description: The Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea's largest car maker, said yesterday that it would shut five factories indefinitely after a four-day blockade by striking workers turned violent. Hyundai said it would shut the plants in the southern city of Ulsan after failing to break the blockade and resume production. About 127 managers have been injured in scuffles with union workers, according to local news reports.

title: Toll Phobia and America's Interstates
description: The Arkansas Highway Commission's interest in imposing tolls on a stretch of one of its Interstates has trucking organizations talking like latter-day participants in the Boston Tea Party. Last week the truckers decried using anything beyond existing fuel taxes to maintain the Interstates, and deplored the Federal program that will authorize toll experiments in three states. Farther west, the San Diego region is acquiring more transponders to expand the use of variable tolls that motorists with no passengers pay to use I-15's high-occupancy-vehicle express lanes. Both toll experiments will test the proposition that critical stretches of the nation's Interstate system have more in common with telephone or cable lines than they do with parks.

title: Holocaust Study Doesn't Deny Jewish History
description: To the Editor:

title: LUCENT TAKES $145 MILLION CHARGE AGAINST EARNINGS
description: The telephone equipment manufacturer Lucent Technologies Inc. will take an extraordinary charge of $145 million in its fourth quarter. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Lucent will incur $65 million in costs related to research and development projects of Lannet of Israel, a supplier of network switches, which Lucent agreed to acquire for about $115 million in cash. Lucent will also take a charge of $80 million related to the in-process research and development projects of SDX Business Systems P.L.C., which Lucent acquired in July. Also, Lucent expects to take an undisclosed charge related to its $70 million acquisition of JNA Telecommunications Ltd. of Australia. Lucent is based in Murray Hill, N.J.

title: Rowland Picks Replacement Candidate
description: Scrambling to recover from a week of bad news, Gov. John G. Rowland today replaced a running mate who withdrew last week over revelations about his past, diluting the ethnic diversity of the Republicans' self-proclaimed ''rainbow'' ticket.

title: The Tribulations of Afghanistan
description: A medieval nation may arise from the rubble of modern war in Afghanistan. The Taliban movement, which seeks to return Afghanistan to the fundamentalism of its ancient villages, is winning military victories that have brought it close to uniting the fractious nation. Afghanistan needs a central authority and an end to the warlordism that has terrorized its people. If the Taliban provide it, the world will be tempted to normalize relations with them. But the Taliban must remain isolated until they end their own totalitarian policies.

title: Canada's Noble Gift
description: Canada's decision last week to give the Nisga'a Indians control of their ancient tribal lands in British Columbia was an overdue but honorable gesture, born partly of guilt for past injustices and partly from a belief that tribal sovereignty will lead to economic self-sufficiency. But the Government in Ottawa must make sure its trust is not abused. In particular, it must hold the tribe to national laws, especially those protecting the environment, even if that limits what the Indians hope to do.

title: The People, Just Wanting It All to Be Over
description: Beneath the glass gaze of a great stuffed elk head just up the coast in Dover, N.H., Bill Clinton delivered an extraordinary oration in the winter of 1992 that historians will probably end up calling his Last Dog speech.

title: Robert M. Luby, 88, Founder Of Regional Cafeteria Chain
description: Robert M. Luby, a restaurateur who had such a down-home devotion to quality and such an accommodating string of unemployed relatives that he helped turn a small Texas cafeteria business into a $500 million chain with more than 200 restaurants in 11 states, died on Thursday at a hospital near his summer home in Colorado Springs. He was 88 and had retired as president of Luby's Cafeterias Inc. in 1971.

title: The Age of Reasons
description: Language and technology march on. Even the excuse, once only a feeble handmaiden to reason, has been reconfigured to suit the new imperatives of our work-a-day postmodern age, Excuse-management techniques have lately taken our nation's capital by storm. In the ''old'' Washington, some misbehavior, personal or political, was too often explained away with one hackeneyed cliche after another - ''I was drunk'' being the formerly popular catchall.

title: Journal; Razzle Dazzle 'Em
description: The most short-lived comeback in the history of show business ended this week when Michael Ovitz was brought to grief on Broadway in a plot worthy of ''The Producers.'' The tale would match Mel Brooks's in hilarity if only thousands of innocent stockholders -- not unlike the little old ladies romanced by Zero Mostel into investing in ''Springtime for Hitler'' -- weren't left holding the bag.

title: Insurance Official Quits To Join Sports Agency
description: Elizabeth E. Randall, Commissioner of the State Department of Banking and Insurance, resigned yesterday, saying she intended to join the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority as vice president of project development and community relations, the Governor's office announced.

title: J. R. Malley, 86, Who Investigated Kennedy Slaying
description: James Roland Malley, a retired F.B.I. division chief who played a central role in the investigation of President John F. Kennedy's assassination, died on Aug. 7 at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 86.

title: Irvan Gains Pole On a Cooler Track
description: Ernie Irvan took advantage of a slightly cooler track near the end of a 46-car qualifying session for the Pepsi 400 to win his first pole at Michigan Speedway yesterday in Brooklyn, Mich.

title: C.I.A. Almost Bungled Intelligence Coup With Iraqi Refugee
description: When Khidhir Abdul Abas Hamza, one of Iraq's top nuclear scientists, defected in 1994, he expected the United States to welcome him with open arms. But American intelligence officials had no idea who he was.

title: Semantics Alone Won't Save Clinton; Plot Against Arkansas?
description: To the Editor:

title: Coors Offers Severance
description: The Coors Brewing Company will offer voluntary severance deals to 200 hourly workers at its brewery here. The severance program -- which will result in a third-quarter pretax charge of $17 million to $22 million -- is intended to reduce labor costs and improve profitability, Coors said today. Coors, based in Golden, Colo., brews Coors, Keystone and Blue Moon beers.

title: French Conservatives Split Over Extremists
description: France's conservatives, defeated last year by Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's Socialists, are reeling again after the party's latest decision and the reaction it provoked.

title: UAL EXPECTS TO SHOW IMPROVED FINANCIAL RESULTS
description: The parent company of United Airlines, the UAL Corporation, expects to beat its financial results for last year's third quarter and full year. The company said yesterday that its outlook remained ''generally consistent'' with the predictions of analysts in a First Call Inc. survey, which are $3.97 a share for the third quarter ending on Sept. 30 and $10.65 a share for the 1998 year. The company said its third-quarter outlook was slightly ahead of its earnings in the quarter a year ago of $579 million, or $5.61 a share, on revenues of $4.64 billion. The Chicago-based company attributed its outlook to continued strong demand for travel in the United States and the current low prices for fuel.

title: Democrats Get A Break in Maryland
description: Almost two-thirds of the nation's governors are Republicans -- 32 out of 50 -- and Democratic hopes for reducing that heavy preponderance in this year's elections have never been high. Political experts say the Republican tide that swept through so many states in recent years is still running high, and they rate 7 of the 11 Democratic governorships up for grabs in the fall as ''vulnerable'' to a Republican takeover.

title: Labor Dispute at Eight Cemeteries Prolongs Jewish Mourners' Grief
description: A four-month labor dispute at eight Jewish cemeteries in Queens and Brooklyn and on Long Island has left hundreds of mourners unable to dedicate gravestones of relatives and friends, as Jewish custom dictates, because monument company workers refuse to cross the picket lines of cemetery workers.

title: Modern Library Agrees to Pick 'Best' Better
description: Faced with widespread criticism of the list it released last month of the 100 best English-language novels published in this century -- most piercingly, in comments by two of the judges who helped compile it -- the Modern Library says it will significantly overhaul the way it picks its choice of the century's hundred best English-language nonfiction books later this year.

title: International Briefs; Thailand Approves Plan To Rescue Lenders
description: Thailand approved a new rescue program yesterday for its financial system, which has been crippled by recession, years of poorly planned real estate development and a currency devaluation. Getting lenders back on their feet is vital to pulling the economy out of its first recession in 30 years. The Government shut down more than 50 lenders last December.

title: Paul Maslin, 82, Realty Executive
description: Paul Maslin, a former real estate executive in Manhattan and the Bronx, died on Thursday in Goose Bay, Labrador, while returning to New York from a vacation that included a visit to the North Pole. Mr. Maslin, a resident of Roslyn, N.Y., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was 82.

title: From Britain, An Extrovert With a Glow
description: Cerys Matthews is a small blond woman with a hefty voice propelled by the constant hint of a belly laugh. She's the kind of woman who walks right up to the bar and orders a beer for herself, not waiting around for some hapless bloke to make her an offer. The songs the Welsh singer writes with her band, Catatonia, take a steamroller to the concept of romance; the best one, about all those tender emotions love can generate, is called ''Road Rage.'' Subtle, she is not.

title: Foreign Affairs; Time of the Turtles
description: I had an unusual interview the other day. It was with Dejair Birschner, the 48-year-old Mayor of Una, a town of 32,000 inhabitants on the edge of Brazil's Atlantic Rain Forest. The Mayor, along with a team of conservationists, took me on a tour of the rain forest eco-park near Una that is supposed to provide jobs so his people won't strip the forest bare and destroy one of the world's great ecosystems. Mayor Birschner says he understands that logging is not sustainable anymore. He knows the environmentalists have a point. But he also knows that his town really isn't prepared for life without logging. After our interview, the Mayor startled me by saying: ''Now, I want to ask you something. Do we have any future?''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials
description: In memory of those who died on Northeast Airlines Flight 258, August 15, 1958, Nantucket, Mass

title: Juvenile Justice: Facts vs. Anger
description: With every new tragedy involving children accused of murder, there is a louder drumbeat of demands for harsher laws to deal with what some experts say is a new breed of killer. So it was again this week when two Chicago boys, ages 7 and 8, were charged with the murder of an 11-year-old girl, and two Arkansas boys were sentenced for the shooting deaths of four classmates and a teacher.

title: Holocaust Study Doesn't Deny Jewish History
description: To the Editor:

title: Sometimes Company Loves Misery
description: Marc Anthony Thompson's new songs revolve around goodbyes. At Shine on Wednesday night, he sang about seeing a lover and daughter he left behind, about an ex-lover who keeps him ''forever standing by,'' about visiting a senile mother who's forgotten her son's name, and about fathers who vanished.

title: Does Managed Care Save Money?
description: To the Editor:

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES TO BUY SIX AUTO DEALERSHIPS
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire six franchised auto dealership groups in separate transactions that will add $650 million to the company's annual revenue. Terms were not disclosed, but Republic said it would pay primarily cash for the dealerships. Republic will buy House of Imports, Corona and Beach City Chevrolet and Don-A-Vee Jeep-Eagle, all in Southern California. It is also buying Willden's Pride Dodge of Las Vegas, Nev.; the Pitre Automotive Group of Phoenix, and Eastgate Ford of Dayton, Ohio. Republic Industries, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has units in the automotive, retailing and solid waste services business. The company had revenue of $7.8 billion in the six months ended June 30.

title: Strikes Cost G.M. $1.65 Billion
description: The General Motors Corporation estimated the third-quarter production losses as a result of work stoppages from labor strikes in Flint, Mich., cost it $1.65 billion after taxes, the company said today in a Federal securities filing.

title: L.S.U. Recruit Wins 1-Meter Springboard
description: Katie Beth Bryant won the 1-meter springboard in the United States Diving Summer Nationals last night in Atlanta, giving the Louisiana State recruit a sweep of the spring and summer championships.

title: Suspects Are Not Listed in Will Of Woman Who Disappeared
description: The will of an Upper East Side millionaire who has been missing for more than six weeks does not list the lead suspects in her disappearance as beneficiaries, officials involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Crucial Maneuver Completed In Repairs at Times Square Site
description: Three weeks after the scaffolding collapse at the Conde Nast building, the most critical part of the repair effort was completed yesterday. About 9:30 A.M., workers extricated an elevator cab on the 24th floor from the twisted wreckage of exterior elevator tower and scaffolding and lowered it to the ground.

title: United Advances To Title Game
description: Roy Lassiter scored twice as D.C. United advanced to the final of the Concacaf Champions Cup, beating Leon of Mexico, 2-0, last night in Washington.

title: Shackled Convict Leaps to Death in Hudson
description: A convicted thief recently charged in three killings kicked out the side window of a police van yesterday morning, hobbled in shackles to the edge of a bridge in Rensselaer County and leapt 65 feet to his death in the rocky shallows of the Hudson River, the authorities said.

title: International Briefs; China's Investment In Fixed Assets Surges
description: China's fixed-asset investment rose 22.8 percent in July over July 1997, the State Statistical Bureau announced yesterday. The growth figure came in above the forecast range of 14 percent to 20 percent that was found in a survey of analysts. For the January-July period, fixed-asset investment stood at 736.2 billion yuan, up 15.6 percent from the corresponding period in 1997, the bureau said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about Bashkim Dibra, a dog trainer whose clients have included many celebrities, misstated his role in Paws for Cause, a fund-raising event for the American Cancer Society. Mr. Dibra did not create the event; he was one of several people who first organized and ran it. The article also misstated the event's first year. It was 1992, not 1993.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I feel terrible for him, but I don't think he feels terrible for himself. He said the other night in our card game, 'I wish I could run again.' ''

title: Early Ad Campaigns By G.O.P. Hopefuls
description: Folks in Iowa and New Hampshire have long been accustomed to Presidential candidates, actual and potential, showing up to campaign for the next election before the dust has settled from the election just past. Mostly, the appearances are for making small talk and dinner speeches, or maybe to endorse candidates in local elections. There is little, if any, actual mention of the next Presidential contest, but everybody knows and understands the game that is being played, even if game time is still the better part of four years off.

title: The Chase Is On, With a Big Pack Nipping at Singh
description: With so many contenders, and so many possibilities, the stage has been set for a memorable weekend at the P.G.A. Championship.

title: Awaiting the Word From the President
description: ''The President would like to speak to you.''

title: Water Divides Haves From Have-Nots in West Bank
description: In the unrelenting heat of what has been an unforgiving summer, water should spell relief.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES ORDERS 15 MORE LONG-RANGE JETLINERS
description: American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, said yestrday that it had ordered 15 more 777 long-range jetliners from the Boeing Company to help the second-largest United States airline expand in international markets. The order is valued at $2.18 billion based on a list price of $145.5 million for the 777, though analysts say American gets deep discounts. The wide-body aircraft will be delivered in 2000 and 2001, American said in a statement.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 5 about cooking with peaches misstated the era in which cooks in the Topkapi Palace, in what is now Istanbul, created dishes combining peaches and meat. It was the Ottoman Empire, not the Byzantine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEICH, CAMHY, JEAN
description: GLEICH-CAMHY-Jean. On August 13, 1998. Beloved mother of Barbara Selter & Sandra KreschHagler. Dear sister of Beatrice Sussman. Adoring grandmother of Sara, Jessica, Zoe and Aimmee. Great grandmother of Sadie. Loving mother-in-law of Sam and Mike. Service Sunday 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to the Fund for Blood and Cancer Research, 407 East 70th Street, New York, NY 10021, C/O Dr. Morton Coleman.

title: A Deadly Turn to an Urban Reality
description: Donald McKayle's work has been a strong though quiet part of American modern dance history for nearly half a century. Mr. McKayle created a classic with his first piece, ''Games,'' in 1951. That seldom-seen dance and another McKayle signature work, ''Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder,'' were the highlights of a performance by the Dayton Contemporary Dance Company on Wednesday night at the Damrosch Park Band Shell at Lincoln Center. The program was the opening event in ''Dancing the Dream,'' a tribute to Mr. McKayle presented by the free Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival.

title: Think Tank; At the End of a Century of Philosophizing, the Answer Is Don't Ask
description: The cameras flashed and clicked. People stood on tiptoe to get a better look over the crowd. It was the last World Philosophy Congress of the 20th century, and some of the most important philosophers were onstage Wednesday evening in the ballroom of the Marriott Hotel: Willard Van Orman Quine, Peter Strawson and Donald Davidson. You might have thought that Plato and Socrates and Aristotle themselves had assembled for a symposium. When the cameras finally stopped flashing, the philosophers blinked and trained their thoughts on a single question: ''What have we learned from philosophy in the 20th century?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, ALBERT
description: LIPTON-Albert. On August 12, 1998. Beloved husband of Phyllis Lipton, dear father of Michael and Joshua. Theatrical director, producer and acting coach.

title: Gains for Balloonist
description: After a full week in an unpressurized capsule dangling beneath a balloon, a 54-year-old commodities broker and adventurer was nearing the halfway point of his attempt to be blown around the world.

title: Cloudy Blue Skies
description: With Russia facing financial turmoil, Asia sinking deeper into recession, the President fighting for his political life and the stock market swooning, the blindingly bright economic picture of the last couple of years suddenly looks murkier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, DOROTHY (NEE GARDNER)
description: ADLER-Dorothy (nee Gardner). On Thursday, August 13, 1998, of Hollywood, Florida. Formerly of Merrick, New York. Loving wife of the late Nathan Adler. Adored and cherished mother of Myra Levy, Stan and Barbra Adler, and Allen and Frances Adler. Loving and devoted grandmother of Amy Levy, Jessica, Andy, Alexander and Anthony Adler. Beloved sister of Milton Gardner, Fay Ciner, Lee and the late Moe Gardner. Cousin to Ruth Kolber, friend to many. We will miss her humor, kindness and generosity. For information Gutterman's Funeral Home, Rockville Centre, L.I. (516-764-9400).

title: Does Managed Care Save Money?
description: To the Editor:

title: On Senior Circuit, Players Avoid the Brashness of Youth
description: Many players learn the game when students, put it aside for years because of the demands of work and family, and come back to it later in life. This is the main reason the average age of the members of the American Contract Bridge League is 59. Tournament events for senior players -- those who are 55 or older -- have become very popular. They are primarily social, and the players do not have to put up with the occasional brusqueness of intense youngsters who think they are headed for international stardom.

title: APPLIED EXTRUSION SPURNS BID BY HUNTSMAN PACKAGING
description: Applied Extrusion Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had rejected a $10.50-a-share takeover bid by the Huntsman Packaging Corporation. The offer, valued at $117 million, failed in ''all material respects to serve the best interests'' of its shareholders, Applied Extrusion said. Huntsman Packaging, which makes film and flexible packaging, is an affiliate of the Huntsman Corporation, a private chemical company based in Salt Lake City. Applied Extrusion, based in Peabody, Mass., makes plastic films used in consumer product labeling, flexible packaging and health care applications.

title: Air of Agincourt, Bus Fumes and All
description: In most productions of ''Henry V,'' you do not see a man who isn't even a cast member walk on stage, get into his spruce-green Honda Civic and drive away. But those are the chances you take when you stage Shakespeare in a parking lot.

title: U.S. Urged Arms Monitor to Back Off From Clash With Iraq
description: The United States and Britain urged Richard Butler, the chairman of the United Nations arms inspectors, not to have a confrontation with Iraq by trying to hold a surprise inspection after Baghdad suspended cooperation with the inspectors earlier this month, senior American and British officials said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: Sideshow Makes Tyson Main Event
description: LEAVE it to Mike Tyson to rewrite a script. An armada of news media was prepared to descend on Trenton yesterday morning for Tyson's latest moment of truth: the day he would find out whether his privilege to box would be restored by the New Jersey State Athletic Control Board.

title: Board Hands Crew a $50,000 Gold Star
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew would be paid more than any other top school administrator in the country -- as well as President Clinton -- under a new contract the Board of Education is likely to approve on Wednesday.

title: Shh! They're Trying Not to Be Noticed
description: Sometimes major movie studios should be afraid to screen expensive fiascos for the press, but they go ahead anyway. ''The Avengers'' is Warner Brothers' would-be blockbuster that has actually had its light hidden beneath a bushel until opening day, and no wonder. With pseudo-suave repartee that would make Austin Powers blush and with so many shades of ''Howard the Duck'' that one scene depicts man-size pastel teddy bears sitting around a conference table, it's a film to gall fans of the old television series and perplex anyone else. I can't remember another Friday morning show where I heard actual cries of ''Ugh!'' on the way out the door.

title: Suspension Is Lifted On Gold Medalist
description: The Olympic gold medalist Gary Hall Jr., suspended after testing positive for marijuana, is free to compete again.

title: Girls Coach Hid Record As Killer, Officials Say
description: To obtain a job as a girls basketball coach at the South Brunswick YMCA, a Virginia man concealed the fact that he was convicted of killing a young girl in Virginia in 1983 and that he is a suspect in two 1996 murders there, officials said yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL HOME FOODS IS ADDING BUSINESSES
description: International Home Foods Inc. has disclosed that it is paying $126 million in cash for Libby's canned meat business from Nestle S.A. and already paid $39 million for the Puritan products business of Unilever Canada's Lipton unit. The terms of the transactions were previously undisclosed but were included in the company's latest quarterly filing with the S.E.C. International Home, which makes Chef Boyardee pastas, Crunch 'n Munch glazed popcorn, Bumble Bee tuna and Polaner fruit spreads, has purchased food businesses this year to increase revenue. The company, based in Parsippany, N.J., had 1997 revenue of $1.22 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, HARRY
description: PHILLIPS-Harry. Tifereth IsraelTown and Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member of long standing and extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Sylvia and the entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Carol J. Green, President

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Russian Markets Rally On Hopes of Recovery

title: U.S. Halts Business At Embassy In Albania
description: The State Department said today that it had shut down routine operations at the American Embassy in Albania because of ''recent declarations by Islamic extremists against the United States.''

title: Star of the Night, Act 89. This Time It's Pettitte.
description: The premise of competing with the rest of the American League is lost. The Yankees challenge themselves now, each other. Andy Pettitte tries to match Orlando Hernandez. Paul O'Neill always wars within. They all seem to be trying to play each game to perfection.

description: BASEBALL

description: An emotionally trying tournament for Stuart Appleby ended today when he missed the cut with a 36-hole total of 150, 10 over par.

description: CORWIN-Robert. Of NYC. Died on August 10, 1998 at age 47 of Cancer. Son of Harold and Anne Corwin of Stamford, CT. Also survived by Edward M. Corwin and Toni Logar of Rapid City, SD and Linda, Tom, Emily and Nathan Palmer of Milton, MA. He loved the theatre, photography and NYC. We will miss him always.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REAPE, VELDA
description: REAPE-Velda. Of Westbury, NY, passed away Monday, August 10. Beloved wife of Wilfred V. Reape. Beloved mother of Debbie Salmon and Diane Brown. Beloved grandmother of Melanie Fleming, Christian Haye, Dena Brown, Lisa Tripp, Troy Brown, Lori Salmon and Gina Salmon. A funeral service will be held at Church of the Advent in Westbury, NY at 11:00 AM on Saturday, August 15 with the reception afterward in the parish, 555 Advent St., Westbury, NY.

title: Clergyman Arrested In Rape of Girl, 12
description: A Queens clergyman was arrested last night and charged with the rape of a 12-year-old girl who is a member of his congregation, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, GEORGE
description: JACOBS-George. Died on August 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Violet Montrose. Father of Phyllis and Howard; father-in-law to Robert Smith and Arlene. Grandfather of David, Judith, Laura and Michelle; great-grandfather of Matthew, Alexander & Samuel. His memory will stay with us forever. Services August 16, 12 noon, at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK SLIDES. The dollar rose to a one-month high against the mark on concern Russia will fail to meet debt obligations to Germany, its biggest lender. The dollar settled at 1.8014 marks in New York, up from 1.7855.

title: Gary Lisz, 44, Costume Designer For Ballet, Theater and Movies
description: Gary Lisz, a costume designer for ballet, theater and film, died on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 44 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Israel's Lame Excuse
description: The Middle East peace process is going through rough times. The outcome rests for now in the hands of the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. His decision to allow negotiations based on an American initiative calling for Israel to pull out of 13 percent of the West Bank is a step in the right direction.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a custody hearing for two Chicago boys charged with killing an 11-year-old girl misspelled the surname of the lawyer for the older boy. He is R. Eugene Pincham, not Pimcham.

title: U.S. Bars or Expels Suspect Immigrants On Secret Evidence
description: More than two dozen immigrants around the country are facing deportation or exclusion from the United States largely on evidence that they are not permitted to see and that comes from people who are not identified.

title: RALCORP AGREES TO PURCHASE NUTCRACKER BRANDS
description: Ralcorp Holdings Inc., the No. 1 maker of private-label crackers and cereal, agreed yesterday to buy Nutcracker Brands Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash, increasing its share of the United States market for snack foods. Nutcracker Brands, a private-label snack nut business based in Billerica, Mass., is expected to have 1998 sales of about $42 million. In April, the St. Louis-based Ralcorp bought the nation's largest maker of store brand nuts, the closely held Flavor House Inc., for undisclosed terms. In July, Ralcorp agreed to sell its Beech-Nut Baby Food unit, the second-largest United States baby food company, to the closely held Milnot Company for $68 million in cash to focus on building its more profitable private-label businesses.

description: An American replacing an American as coach of the national soccer team is an idea that is gaining momentum, but Alan Rothenberg, the president of the United States Soccer Federation, reiterated yesterday that no one on the list of candidates had a strong edge.

description: Leaders of the troubled racing industry, gathering today for their midsummer Round Table conference here, were greeted by news that at least one market was thriving: the market for young horses.

description: A state judicial review panel has decided that a town justice from Rockland County should be removed from the bench for a series of remarks he made that made light of victims of domestic abuse.

title: Idaho Congress Race May Be 1996 Redux
description: Going into the 1996 election, Democrats figured they had a good shot at unseating Representative Helen Chenoweth of Boise. They said she was too conservative even for Idaho's heavily Republican and heavily conservative First Congressional District, which stretches the length of the western side of the state.

title: Judge Lets City Close Third Bronx Strip Club
description: A State Supreme Court justice gave city officials permission to padlock a third Bronx strip club yesterday as city officials continued enforcement of the zoning law restricting sex shops, which is a priority of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration does not have the authority to regulate cigarettes or smokeless tobacco.

description: FRIEDMAN-Fred. You are not where you used to be, but you are wherever we are. Love, Linda, Erik and Adam

title: A Three-Year Deal For Brind'Amour
description: The Flyers signed the restricted free agent Rod Brind'Amour to a three-year, $11.25 million contract, the team said yesterday in Toronto. The 11th-hour agreement came shortly before an arbitration hearing yesterday morning that would have decided the contract's value.

title: Arena's Scoreboard Cables Were Unsafe, Isles Charge
description: The Islanders charged yesterday that the operator of Nassau Coliseum failed to disclose crucial information that the movable hoist system that supported a 22,000-pound scoreboard for 10 years posed a potential safety risk.

title: Two Would-Be Partners See Shares Plunge
description: Shares of two makers of telecommunications equipment, the Ciena Corporation and Tellabs Inc., partners in a pending $7.1 billion merger, plunged yesterday, after Ciena announced that its third-quarter profits would be less than half of expectations.

title: Power, Electric and Electoral
description: Gov. George Pataki and his hand-picked chairman of the Long Island Power Authority are determined that before the November election there will be checks in the mail for all electric customers on Long Island. They are not willing to be deterred by so small a thing as a Federal judge's ruling.

title: Three Struggle To Meet Eligibility
description: Three of Ohio State's top players, including the Lombardi and Butkus Award winner, Andy Katzenmoyer, have yet to meet academic requirements that would make them eligible this season, which opens in three weeks.

title: INSIDE
description: Kenya Devastation Spreads

description: Finally, the Jets get to show what all the fuss was about, at running back that is.

title: Stottlemyres' Reunion To Take the Afternoon Off
description: The Stottlemyres have plans for this evening. Mel and Todd, father and son, will go out for dinner with the rest of the family and enjoy a rare summer get-together.

title: State Sues Wildwood Over Casino Land Deal
description: The State Attorney General's office has filed a lawsuit seeking to block officials in Wildwood from transferring a municipal parking lot to the Delaware Indian tribe of western Oklahoma, which wants to build a casino on the site.

title: Too Late to Say 'Extinct' In Ubykh, Eyak or Ona; Thousands of Languages Are Endangered
description: As the legend goes, when the Turkish sultan first heard of Ubykh, the bizarre-sounding language spoken by Muslims who had emigrated from the northwestern Caucasus in the mid-19th century, he dispatched a servant to learn more.

title: Developers Lay Claim to Stretch of Scenic River
description: The real white water, the ''Deliverance white water,'' is all downstream. But upstream, on the West Fork of the Chattooga River near the point where Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina meet, the gently flowing shallows provide an ideal training ground for paddlers who are not quite ready to navigate Class V rapids and 7-foot falls.

title: Stryker to Buy Orthopedics Unit From Pfizer for $1.9 Billion
description: The Stryker Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy Pfizer Inc.'s Howmed ica orthopedics unit for $1.9 billion, expanding its line of products to repair injured joints and bones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, NATHALIE PEARL
description: ISRAEL-Nathalie Pearl. On August 13, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jack Pearl and David Israel. Loving stepmother of Robert, Larry and the late Oscar Israel. Dear cousin of Bernice Jupiter and Roberta Fuchs. Cherished stepgrandmother of Andrea, Anthony, Ronald, Tristan, Michael, and James Israel. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, Saturday, 6:30-8:30PM with services Sunday, August 16th at 11:30AM. Contributions in her memory may be to the Actors Temple.

title: Muted Pressure on Iraq
description: The United States urged United Nations arms inspectors to avoid a confrontation with Iraq this month, officials say. Page A5.

description: Parker and Mary Carlson have an unpretentious attitude about making and marketing their wine.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MINSKOFF, HENRY H.
description: MINSKOFF-Henry H. In loving memory of a beloved husband, father and grandfather, forever in our hearts. Marjorie, Jim, Jean, Alan, Richard, Michael, Donna, Noah, Tasha, Henry and Laura

title: Films by Woody Allen And Emir Kusturica To Be Shown at Festival
description: The New York Film Festival has announced the schedule for its 36th annual presentation at Avery Fisher Hall, which opens on Sept. 25 with Woody Allen's ''Celebrity'' and closes on Oct. 11 with ''The Dreamlife of Angels,'' the first film by the French director Erick Zonca. Mr. Zonca's film, whose two young stars shared best-actress honors at the Cannes International Film Festival in May, follows the story of a pair of impoverished French women who forge a volatile friendship.

title: Ho Chi Minh City Journal; U.S. Embassy Passes Into History. Coming Soon: Real Estate Deals.
description: The most talked-about construction project in this city of soaring cranes and clattering jackhammers is a building that has come down, not gone up. It is the old United States Embassy, which until last month stood in the heart of the former Saigon as a brooding reminder of America's presence here during the Vietnam War.

title: TRACKING BAGHDAD'S ARSENAL: INSIDE THE ARSENAL: A special report.; Defector Describes Iraq's Atom Bomb Push
description: An Iraqi scientist who defected to the United States has publicly described for the first time the inner workings of Iraq's three-decade effort to build a nuclear bomb.

title: BARRINGTON PETROLEUM REJECTS SUNOMA ENERGY OFFER
description: Barrington Petroleum Ltd. has told a suitor, the Sunoma Energy Corporation, that its unsolicited takeover offer of the equivalent of $147 million is too low, and it has started meeting with other potential bidders. Brian Gore, chief executive of Barrington, a petroleum producer in Calgary, Alberta, said his company was preparing confidential information for interested parties to examine. On Thursday, Barrington hired the investment bank Nesbitt Burns Inc. to advise it on alternatives to the bid from Sumoma, which is also based in Calgary.

title: In July, Industrial Production Fell for 2d Consecutive Month
description: Industrial production declined in July for the second consecutive month as manufacturers struggled to overcome sluggish Asian demand and the General Motors strikes cut auto and truck output by 20 percent. Inflation remained tame at the producer level.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISZ, GARY
description: LISZ-Gary. The School of American Ballet notes with sadness the death of Gary Lisz, a gifted artist and friend. His designs for SAB's ''Puss In Boots'' are fondly remembered.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lack of Closure After Tyson Hearing Frustrates New Jersey's Commissioner
description: Larry Hazzard, the New Jersey boxing commissioner, said yesterday that he would have preferred Mike Tyson to proceed with his application for a New Jersey boxing license rather than withdraw and apply for one in Nevada.

title: Treasury Rally Surges Ahead While Stocks Continue Slump
description: Long-term Treasury rates fell to their lowest level in 30 years yesterday, but the stock market's increasingly painful slide continued.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAIGNAULT, ALEXANDER T.
description: DAIGNAULT-Alexander T., 82. Former Director and Executive VP of Finance for W.R. Grace & Co., died August 13 at his home, 575 Osgood St., North Andover, MA. He leaves his wife Elizabeth (Kendrick) Daignault, a daughter Anne Hartman of Brookline, MA, a son Alexander T. Daignault, Jr., of Gibson Island, MD, along with four grandchildren, Emily and Cindy Daignault and Peter and Ned Campion. A memorial gathering will be held in Quissett Harbor, MA at a later date. Donations in lieu of flowers should be sent to The Visiting Nurses Association, 67 Ter Heun Road, Falmouth, MA. 02540.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: WOMEN ON THE COURT
description: On the road with the New York Liberty, and other courtside views on the fast-breaking, family-friendly, all-out intensity of women's professional basketball. Reports by Kirk Johnson, Le Anne Schreiber and John Edgar Wideman, and photographs by Michelle V. Agins, in the Magazine.

title: Federal Judge in Maine Rejects Use of Vouchers for Religious Schools
description: Small towns in Maine that do not have their own public high schools routinely cover the costs for their children to attend private schools or public schools in neighboring districts.

title: War on Nicotine Began With a Cough
description: This city is rife with anonymous sources. So it might come as no surprise that when the Food and Drug Administration set out to determine whether it could regulate nicotine as a drug, its first big break came from a tobacco industry informant.

title: Clinton Clears His Weekend to Prepare for the Grand Jury
description: President Clinton has virtually cleared his calendar this weekend to prepare for his grand jury testimony in the Monica S. Lewinsky investigation on Monday afternoon. But he will not decide whether to give a public address to the country until he finishes answering prosecutors' questions on closed-circuit television, White House officials said today.

title: International Briefs; Astec Buying Unit From Northern Telecom
description: Astec P.L.C., the world's biggest independent maker of power converters, agreed yesterday to buy Advanced Power Systems, a unit of Canada's Northern Telecom Ltd., for $325 million in cash and debt to expand in the telecommunications market. The acquisition should enable the company to move away from the lower-margin PC market to the higher-margin telecommunications market. Under a long-term arrangement, Northern Telecom will buy 80 percent of Astec's products.

title: Reed Keeps Winning For Career-High 14th
description: Last season, Rick Reed, a baseball journeyman, surprised everyone by winning 13 games for the Mets. Tonight he went one better, winning his 14th game of this season, and he demonstrated again that he has turned into one of the National League's best pitchers.

title: Times Square's Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Brokerage Plans to Build Near Times Sq.
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter has signed an agreement to move into a new one-million-square-foot office tower on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets, according to real estate executives.

title: Liberty Set for a Showdown
description: The last time around, it was a painfully obvious mismatch. The Houston Comets ran over a shell-shocked Liberty squad four weeks ago by 79-54. But if the Liberty(17-10) is seeking to return the favor after that Madison Square Garden massacre, it is not apparent.

title: Chalmers Wylie, G.O.P. Stalwart in House, Is Dead at 77
description: Chalmers P. Wylie, who represented Ohio for 26 years in the House and helped to win approval of the Federal bailout of the savings-and-loan industry, died today in Columbus, Ohio. He was 77.

title: Ameritech Closing Centers
description: The Ameritech Corporation, the fifth-largest United States local phone company, will begin closing its customer service centers in Lansing, Mich., and Milwaukee as it seeks to eliminate $3 billion in expenses through 2002. Ameritech said the closings affect 305 employees in Lansing and 212 in Milwaukee. Since the plan was first announced in March, 128 employees have found other positions within the company, Ameritech said.

title: France Not in Plans
description: Tour of Spain organizers have dropped plans for the race to cross the border into France, thus avoiding the police drug raids that occurred during the Tour de France.

title: Religious Groups Mount a Campaign To Support Pact on Global Warming
description: The political debate on global warming, long dominated by arguments over science and economics, is spilling over into pulpits and pews as religious organizations speak out about morality, faith and the Kyoto Protocol.

title: Rockers 85, Sting 72
description: Merlakia Jones scored 12 of her 14 points in the final 4 minutes 30 seconds as the Cleveland Rockers maintained their Eastern Conference lead over the Liberty at a half game with an 85-72 victory over the slumping Sting last night at Charlotte, N.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFF, LILLIAN WIESEN
description: LEFF-Lillian Wiesen. Peacefully and bravely, in her 99th year. Our beloved ''Mama Cookie'' was a true humanitarian, supporter of many needy people, including artists, dancers, physical therapists, and a source of strength to her family and friends. She was the daughter of Max and Rose Wiesen, cherished wife of the late Phillip Leff, beloved mother of Ruth and Jerome A. Siegel and Joseph and Juanita Leff. Grandmother of Michael and Laurence Levin, Stephen and Amy Levin, Robin Kantrowitz, William and Sharon Levin, Henry Siegel, Elizabeth and David Carpenter, Carol Siegel, Julie and Jeffrey Satinover and Valerie and Joseph Godden. Great-grandmother of Adam, Max, Alex, Sebastien, Samantha, Eli, Noah, Sarah Emily, Rachel, Matthew, David, Emma, Sarah Kate, Annie and Jenny. Dear sister of Eleanor Leff and Irving Wiesen and sister-in-law of Tobie, Shirley and Mae Wiesen. ''Cookie'' was a former member of the Jewish Theological Seminary Board of Overseers and active with The United Jewish Appeal, The National Council of Jewish Women and Brandeis University. She received the Haym Solomon Award from the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith ''For her unswerving dedication to humanitarian and spiritual values.'' Lilly was a fine pianist and gave concerts in Town Hall and Palm Beach. Cookie believed in living life to the fullest. With her marvelous sense of humor, great compassion, love of art, dancing, music and everything exciting and interesting, she was a joy to be with. This darling, ''fey'', loving great-grandmother, grandmother and mother will be sorely missed, but she will live on in our hearts forever. Funeral service will be held Sunday, August 16th, 11 am at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87 Street & Madison Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the 92nd St. ''Y''.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a new executive team at the Internal Revenue Service misspelled the surname of the new chief information officer. He is Paul A. Cosgrave, not Cosgrove.
