description: ARMSTRONG-Catherine Joan. Of Scarsdale, New York, on August 14, 1998. Beloved wife of Michael Armstrong. Mother of Joanne, Diedre & Margaret. Grandmother of 11. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, New York, between the hours of 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. on Sunday, 5-9 PM on Monday. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Fatima Church, Scarsdale, on Tuesday, August 18 at 10 AM.

title: Op-Art
Giuliani Orders 5 City Hospitals To Wean Addicts Off Methadone
description: Following through on his promise to overhaul drug treatment in New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided that heroin addicts treated at city hospitals will typically be allowed to get methadone for only three months, city health officials yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENNET, SAMUEL A.
description: GENNET-Samuel A. On Friday, August 14, 1998. Born in Newark, NJ & lived in Verona, NJ. Beloved Husband of Pera (Nee Marion). Devoted father of Jan Gennet. Dear brother of Hilda Stern. Funeral Services are private. Graduate of New York University and Harvard Law School. Member of New Jersey & New York Bar, Bar of Federal Courts and Bar of U.S. Supreme Court. Founded the firm of Gennet, Kallmann, Antin and Robinson and was managing partner until retirement in 1992. title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Looking Back Sideways
description: Characters grapple with the complexities of loss and acculturation in THE STORE OF A MILLION ITEMS (Houghton Mifflin, paper, $12), a collection of 11 spare yet fervidly inventive short stories by the Jamaican-American writer Michelle Cliff. Several center on racial dynamics in unexpected ways. In a story called ''Transactions,'' a pale, pale-eyed salesman wants a child even though his ''brown-skinned'' wife emphatically does not. Acting on impulse at a squalid roadside shanty somewhere in the West Indies, the man buys a blond, blue-eyed toddler from her impoverished, German-speaking mother for $20 -- and discovers that his wish to ''never be lonely again'' is still a painfully long way from being fulfilled. For the characters in many of Cliff's stories, melancholy memories warp the present with a fun-house-mirror effect. (In one, a New York woman is gripped by concentric, near-hallucinatory remembrances of two dead friends.) Also spread throughout the stories are starkly drawn but vividly imagined passages that read like prose poems -- as in the title story, when the speaker recalls how the lushly stocked 1950's New York dime store of her youth brought shoppers ''as close to infinity as we dared,'' and in the story that catalogues the possessions of Julia Bulette, a real-life Virginia City prostitute, after her mysterious murder during the Gold Rush. Throughout ''The Store of a Million Items,'' Cliff displays a dazzling array of subjects, presented with the precision and finesse of one who knows her literary stock backward and forward. Megan Harlan

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Notes From the Memoir Club

The members, who included Virginia and Leonard Woolf, Lytton Strachey, Duncan Grant and Clive Bell, met for an evening meal and then read aloud papers that were usually autobiographical. The only condition imposed was absolute honesty, which for Vanessa Bell meant that certain matters, among them her complicated love life, were never broached (she was married to Clive Bell, whom she never divorced, though she lived for most of her life with Grant, who was homosexual). Still, in spite of some obvious omissions, as well as a lifelong habit of expressing herself less through words than through her sensitive drawings and paintings (a selection of which have been reproduced), these writings come as a delightful surprise. Intimate and unpretentious, wry and often gaily mischievous, they tell of her progress from childhood to maturity, describing the birth of early Bloomsbury and the heady freedom of breaking with the Victorian past. There are memories of trips to Paris (and stiff luncheon parties with the art dealer Ambroise Vollard) and of her first impressions of meeting the art critic Roger Fry, whom she later took as her lover. Interestingly, as both the book's editor, the Italian art historian Lia Giachero, who has written a brief appraisal of Bell's art, and Bell's daughter, Angela Garnett, who has contributed a lively introduction, point out, what Bell does not speak of is the urgency of her own artistic search. One wonders if perhaps this was not out of deference to her brilliant, silver-tongued sister, Virginia Woolf, with whom, she says, she vowed, from the nursery on, never to compete. Andrea Barnet

description: President Clinton's lawyer, David E. Kendall, is preparing him for testimony about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky. As director of Mr. Clinton's legal strategy, Mr. Kendall's reputation is also at stake.

title: Playing It The Company Way
description: Summer can bring out the most memorable in corporate gamesmanship -- not the back-stabbing kind, but those company-sponsored sporting events that can be a lot of laughs in spite of, or maybe because of, the players they attract. There are three-mile runs that appeal to hard-charging Type A's and softball games that sometimes draw the far less athletic. And, of course, some competitions get way too competitive. Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Television Debut
description: It may not be high drama in the usual sense, but the meetings of the 17-member Board of Legislators are among the newest fare being offered on local public-access cable television channels throughout the county.

title: Editorial Observer; Welcome to New York: The Place Where Two Candidates Are a Crowd
description: Thirty Second Job Aptitude Quiz: Take this test to determine whether you have what it takes to be a Democratic party boss in New York City.

title: A One-Man Rescue Squad for a Bit of Village Green
description: Pedestrians along the stretch of Bleecker Street between Broadway and Lafayette Street are often curious when they see a hose jutting from the second-floor window of the three-story red-brick building on the southeast corner of Crosby Street and providing a brisk flow of water to a tree on the sidewalk below. But few people would be likely to guess the history linking the tree, a Japanese sophora, and Gary Rich, an artist who lives in the apartment providing the water.

title: POSTINGS: In September, Events All Over the City; A Month for Home Owners
description: The month of September is Home Ownership Month in New York City, says Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani by proclamation. The celebratory events with which the Department of Housing Preservation and Development is marking the occasion underscore the variety in the types of buildings now being built or rehabilitated under city auspices.

title: Ideas & Trends; Armchair Sailors On the Seven Seas
description: LIKE an armada of tall ships, tales of the sea are sailing onto bookshelves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, MICHELLE. 50. (NEE YUBLON)
description: MORGAN-Michelle. 50. (nee Yublon) Born Sept 23rd, 1947 died Aug 3, 1998 of cancer in Virginia. Shelly is survived by her husband Richard Morgan and her step-daughter Letitia Morgan. A treasured sister, niece, cousin and friend. She will be missed by all who knew her. Rest in peace, sweet cousin.

title: Competition Lags For State Phone Service
description: FOR years, the Canon-Greater Hartford Open golf tournament had been sponsored in part by Southern New England Telecommunications, which provided telephone service in exchange for tickets and promotion. But in a cost-cutting effort SNET withdrew from the arrangement. So this year, the Connecticut Jaycees went looking for another company to help sponsor their fund-raising event. The replacement: Connecticut Telephone, a subsidiary of USN Communications in Chicago.

title: PULSE: LONDON EDITION; Carry On, Notting Hill
description: What Richard Curtis did for the holy state of matrimony in directing ''Four Weddings and a Funeral,'' he is about to do for London's trendiest neighborhood with his newest film, ''Notting Hill.'' Though the comedy, starring Julia Roberts and Hugh Grant, won't be released until next year, residents are already not amused. They fear Mr. Curtis will satirize them all as louche 20-somethings, known for their trust funds, drug-taking and love of rasta music. In real life, Notting Hill is home not only to trustafarians, but also to fashionable figures like Jade Jagger, daughter of Mick Jagger; Helen Fielding, author of ''Bridget Jones's Diary,'' and Nicholas Coleridge, of Conde Nast U.K. The most recent hot spots of Notting Hill, once a small artisan community, include the American restaurant Dakota (Madonna has already had two parties there); the Tabernacle, which imported Allegra McEvedy from New York's TriBeCa Grill to be the head chef, and the Pharmacie, owned by Sir Terence Conran. ''The anxiety is that the popularity of the film will attract crowds, who will drive out all that is bohemian and eclectic and replace it with money and the banal,'' said Philip Delves Broughton, a Notting Hill homeowner. Will he see it? ''Of course.''

title: In Radio's Past, a Hint Of the Internet's Future
description: AMONG many Internet enthusiasts, especially students, mentioning the Internet and regulation in the same breath is unwise. Veins swell, faces redden and someone announces, in effect: ''Regulation would ruin it! We'll fight it!''

title: Food and View With a Simpler Touch
description: Say you forgot your jacket on the way to the Terrace, a Morningside Heights institution in the heart of Columbia University territory. You'd be out of luck, because jackets are still required at the 23-year-old restaurant. But last month, on the rooftop outside the Terrace, the Sky Grille -- a less formal, lower-priced restaurant -- opened, owned and operated by the same people and affording the same spectacular view. The address is 400 West 119th Street, at Amsterdam Avenue. The executive chef, Kenneth Johnson, produces a full menu including smoked duck quesadillas ($8) and Moroccan spiced lamb kebab ($16.50). For dessert, as a nod to the neighborhood's students, the Sky Grille serves oversize chocolate chip cookies with milk, for $5. ALEXANDRA McGINLEY

title: Voters' Advocate Feels Poll Taxed
description: GRACE FITZGERALD quit her job last month because, she likes to quip, ''my daughter, my shrink and my allergist all insisted.'' Some job, I said. She was the coordinator of my polling site on East 16th Street, a job that paid her $250 a day, for one or two 16-hour days a year.

title: A '57 Chevy and a Drive-In of One's Own
description: TO put a little oomph back in one's marriage, Donald and Elise Orenstein suggest watching a drive-in movie in a 1957 Chevy convertible. ''It's fun in the back seat,'' said Mrs. Orenstein, who is back there with her husband as often as she can be.

title: Leslie Wims and Loren Morris
description: Leslie Alice Wims, the daughter of Letitia A. Wims of Culver City, Calif., and Dr. Warner B. Wims of San Francisco, was married last evening to Loren Wayne Morris, a son of Sandra G. Morris of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Wayne Morris of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Frederick Douglass Jefferson, a Presbyterian minister who is an uncle of the bride, officiated at Lyndhurst, the Jay Gould house in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: A New Proceeding and Higher Stakes
description: Veteran prosecutors of perjury cases and professors of law see legal risks for President Clinton whether he continues to say he did not have sexual relations with Monica S. Lewinsky or acknowledges a certain kind of sexual contact and trying to reconcile it with his earlier testimony in the Paula Jones lawsuit.

title: Finding Plenty of Uses For Staten Island
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Age of Viagra, It's 'Patient, Heal Thyself'; Help for Alcoholics
description: To the Editor:

title: Uptown, a Bucket Brigade Patrols
description: To see Margaret Parker, an elegant woman with a British accent, stroll out of her building on East 88th Street between First and Second Avenues, one might expect to see a Prada handbag on her arm. Instead, on Thursday she was toting several empty plastic buckets.

title: Parents Can Force Flexibility in the Workplace
description: To the Editor:

title: Christine Covell and Peter Gordon
description: Christine Covell and Peter Gordon were married last evening by Cantor David Benedict at the Roslyn Claremont Hotel in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Dorothy Parker's Back, Kinder and Gentler, Admirers Say
description: So what do you think! The waggishly wise Dorothy Parker is soon to dispense her pithy poems and acerbic essays again inside the warmly paneled Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

title: New Burials At Arlington Raise Issues Of Fairness
description: Space is becoming so scarce at Arlington National Cemetery that the announcement that three of the Americans killed in the bomb blast at the United States Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, would be buried there has helped reopen some old wounds.

title: PULSE: LONDON EDITION; The Queen's New English
description: Natural Spice: Nickname for Geri Halliwell (Ginger Spice), now seen walking about bereft of makeup following her split with the pop band.

title: McEnroe Comes Through
description: With both Bjorn Borg and Jimmy Connors out of the tournament, the promoters of the Citibank Champions for players 35 and over had high hopes last night that the lone legend left in the field -- John McEnroe -- would make it to today's final.

title: In Brooklyn, Brawley Insists She Was Victim
description: Ending the silence that kept her away from the courtroom during the recent trial of her former advisers, Tawana Brawley said at a ceremony in Brooklyn Friday night that her fight for justice is just beginning and insisted that 10 years ago she was the victim of a vicious crime.

title: Steps to Take When Picking Support Staff
description: SOMETIMES choosing the right pet for your life style is the easy part. After taking it home, there are a host of professionals you will need to keep your pet happy and healthy.

title: A Perfect Excuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Emily Stern, Jeremy Weitz
description: Emily Rachel Stern, a daughter of Debra Willen Stern and Dr. David H. Stern of Los Angeles, was married there last evening to Jeremy Matthew Weitz, a son of Lori Weitz and Dr. Daniel Weitz of Scotch Plains, N.J. Rabbi Neil Comess-Daniels officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: London Holiday

title: Children's Books
description: KATARINA By Kathryn Winter. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.(Ages 10 and up)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREGG, JOHN P.
description: CREGG-John P. On August 14. Retired Captain, FDNY. Beloved husband of Joan (nee Barry). Devoted father of Jeannette Merola, John, Mary Brunton, Elaine, Terrence, Kathryn, Geraldine Cahill, Patrick and Philip. Also survived by fourteen grandchildren. Visiting Sunday, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM, at M.J. Smith Sons, Inc., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10 AM, at Holy Name R.C. Church. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to the FDNY Burn Unit in his memory.

title: Richards Ruben, 72, Painter and Teacher
description: Richards Ruben, an abstract painter and teacher, died on July 21 in Venice, where he was teaching in the summer art program of the Pratt Institute. He was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: On the Beach
description: ON a blue bamboo-print sheet on a stretch of warm sand on Fire Island, a woman sleeps the luxurious sleep that belongs to actresses in mattress commercials. Her blond hair spills over her shoulders, her tanned arm flops carelessly over a paperback copy of Sandra Brown's cop drama ''Fat Tuesday.'' Farther down the beach, a sinuous woman with thumb rings, pearl-glossed lips, California eyes and a lemon yellow bikini contemplates ''Wheels of Life: A User's Guide to the Chakra System.'' ''I'm in the fourth chakra,'' she explains, then springs up and sprints into the green-blue surf.

title: Crazy Bones: Craze in the Making?
description: ''They're collectible, they're tradable, I get to have fun with them and I get to play games with them,'' said Preston Wollner, 8, of Park Slope, Brooklyn, explaining his passion for Crazy Bones, tiny toys that have recently cropped up in some pockets of the city -- mostly the pockets of young boys. Some local retailers even dare to say the name in the same breath as ''Beanie Baby.''

title: End of a Dream in Kenya
description: Two sisters who had planned to come to the United States were buried in their village eight days after a bomb ripped through the American Embassy in Nairobi. Page 6.

title: Leading Expeditions Of Musical Archeology
description: WHO, in musical history, could have guessed that a meddlesome figure like Leon Botstein would come along?

title: In a Period of Losses, Some Funds Find Gains
description: FROM its peak on July 17 through last Tuesday, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 9.9 percent. Several mutual funds, however, managed to return a tidy profit, testimony to the proliferation of bear-market funds, which sell stocks and index futures short to help returns in such times. Small surprise, then, that a 44-point spread separated the best-performing fund from the worst.

title: Sexual Politics
description: Lucky Bastard

title: POSTINGS: Going Up in Palisades, N.Y.; An Institute For Studying The Climate
description: A long, low building, curved to follow the contours of the land, has begun to rise on the campus of the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, the earth sciences research division of Columbia University, in Palisades, N.Y., just over the New Jersey border.

title: BACKTALK; To Fight Drugs, I.O.C. Needs Outside Help
description: The need for the International Olympic Committee's drug summit is obvious after a summer of drug busts at the Tour de France and the suspensions of the Olympians Michelle Smith de Bruin, Randy Barnes and Dennis Mitchell. But if the primary agenda is to redefine doping, as the president of the I.O.C., Juan Antonio Samaranch, has suggested, the effort will be wasted.

title: Ways to Begin Breakfast With Blueberries
description: OF all the abundant berries in season right now, blueberries are the best ones for breakfast. They are easy to add to a bowl of cereal or fold into pancake batter and, because they are delicious with maple syrup, they are excellent to warm with the syrup to top pancakes or waffles.

title: A 10th-Century Church Is Rescued in Old Cairo
description: IN a city whose modern sprawl so often threatens ancient treasures, the Egyptian Government has begun an unusual effort to preserve a religious site that has suffered from years of neglect and bungled repairs.

title: What War Looks Like Now
description: After the bombings of our embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, the bombing of the World Trade Center, and the bombings in Riyadh and Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, in 1995 and 1996, Americans must face the reality that more such attacks are inevitable, perhaps using weapons of even more terrifying power.

title: Money Ends a College List but Kiplinger's Picks Up the Slack
description: THE intense competition among personal-finance magazines has been thrown into sharp focus with the September issues of Money and Kiplinger's.

title: Correction
description: An answer in the Q & A column on Aug. 2 about bicycling in France rendered the name of a tour operator and its Web address incorrectly. It is Randonnee Tours, not Randonee Tours, and its site is:

title: Filling Big Political Shoes
description: For decades, the two-story brick building at 77 Conklin Street in Canarsie has been the nerve center of one of the city's most influential political clubs. It was where Meade H. Esposito, the once-powerful Brooklyn Democratic chief, oversaw the details of politics in the borough. It was the club of Stanley Fink, the longtime Assembly Speaker, and the domain, until his death last week, of Assemblyman Anthony J. Genovesi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDIN, JOHN A.
description: HARDIN-John A. Former President and Chairman of the Board of Mutual Broadcasting Corp. Died on August 1, 1998, at Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, New Jersey, after a brief illness. He was a ardent woodsman and fly fisherman and was a guide in Algonquin Park in Ontario, Canada, as a young man. Prior to becoming president of Mutual Broadcasting, Mr. Hardin was an accountant and financial consultant in New York City. he was born in 1911, in Montclair, New Jersey, he is survived by his wife, the former Edith Kaletsch, whom he married in 1937. A private memorial service was held.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 2 about bacteria that are resistant to antibiotics misspelled the name of a species of bacteria. It is Staphylococcus aureus, not staphylococcus aureas.

title: 'Minor Change' in M72 Bus Route Provokes Major Anger
description: It was, according to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a ''minor route change,'' one that did not require the protracted public examination that a major re-routing of buses would entail. But the boos, catcalls and held noses on the Upper West Side last week seem to indicate that the M.T.A. misjudged the change.

title: Jana Chasan and Gideon Romm
description: Jana Erin Chasan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Chasan of Yonkers, is to be married today to Gideon Zev Romm, a son of Rabbi J. Leonard Romm and Mrs. Romm of Bellmore, N.Y. Rabbi Jay Shoulson performed the ceremony at Congregation Kneseth Israel in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: The Sun Sets in the East
description: At twilight in the Hamptons, chamber music fills the air, and a dinner-dance supports social services.

title: Going Where a Lot of Other Dudes With Really Great Equipment Have Gone Before
description: John Tierney's article ''Going Where a Lot of Other Dudes With Really Great Equipment Have Gone Before'' (July 26) rekindled memories of filth, hunger, thirst and a perpetually damp sleeping bag on wilderness trips. Tierney is correct. The best stories are those that involve injury and a certain amount of pain. It isn't the destination that counts, but the journey. The trip home is a relief, but as the pain diminishes you dream of the next adventure.

title: Dealing With the Y2K Bug
description: BY now most people are probably aware of the term ''millennium bug'' -- that because of the way dates were represented in early computer programs, some computers may collapse at the start of the year 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  O'DONNELL, JAMES F.
description: O'DONNELL-James F. June 15th, 1941 to August 16th, 1997. Remembered and missed by family, friends and colleagues.

title: Anna J. Harrison, 85, Led U.S. Chemical Society
description: Anna Jane Harrison, an emeritus professor of chemistry at Mount Holyoke College and the first woman to be president of the 150,000-member American Chemical Society, died on Aug. 8 at Holyoke Hospital. She was 85 and lived in nearby South Hadley, Mass.

title: Big Web Sites to Track Steps of Their Users
description: Some of the largest commercial sites on the World Wide Web have agreed to feed information about their customers' reading, shopping and entertainment habits into a system developed by a Massachusetts company that is already tracking the moves of more than 30 million Internet users, recording where they go and what they read, often without the users' knowledge.

title: Blitz on Sex Outlets
description: Judges in Brooklyn, Staten Island and the Bronx grant requests from the Giuliani administration to padlock strip clubs and adult video stores immediately. But judges in Manhattan and Queens, confronted with nearly identical requests, refuse and instead hold lengthy hearings.

title: Clearing Misconceptions About Catholic Hospitals
description: Your recent article ''Saving Hospitals, But Not All Their Parts,'' [Aug. 9] highlighted an all-too-common misconception about Catholic hospitals -- that we are trying to impose our ethical standards on the population at large. This is not our intention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATLAS, PEARL
description: ATLAS-Pearl. On August 15, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Dave. Loving mother of Sheila and Joel. Adoring grandmother of Stephanie & Michael, Dan & Amy. Dear sister of Anne Silver. Service Sunday 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Break in the Clouds, Or More Storms Ahead?
description: LAST FALL, when the stock market fell more than 10 percent below its high for the first time since 1990, the reason was clear. Currency devaluations in Asia had aroused fears that falling export prices would hurt the profits of companies in the United States.

title: First Among Flacks
description: THE FATHER OF SPIN

title: The View From/Rye; Champions All: Children Race to Win in Swimming and Diving
description: THE scene could have been entitled ''Classic American Summer'': lavender dusk, pale orange moon, big aqua swimming pool. Around the pool, hundreds of people waving banners emblazoned with colorful insignia, whooping, whistling, cheering, ''Go, go, go.''

title: Valuing the Market
description: Strategists ground their forecasts of where the stock market is going on assessments of where it should be. Some assign a ''fair value'' to the market -- an appropriate price to pay for companies' future earnings. Others base market calls on technical factors-- trading patterns and the like. Here is a look at how four market experts arrive at benchmarks for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

title: Going to Shallow Depths at Sandy Hook Bay to Fish for Marine Answers
description: For the next several years, scientists will be trawling the waters of the Navesink River and Sandy Hook Bay in a long-term study of the estuary's ecology.

title: The Makeup Artist
description: My mother died recently, at 88. When I saw her in her coffin, she was wearing the ugliest shade of tangerine lipstick I have ever seen (probably sold only to undertakers). This is the woman who a few years back sent me to find a shade of Revlon lipstick that she had used since her college days. I felt the same urge to scrub her down and send her into eternity wearing her own shade of lipstick.

title: For Crop Prices, Competition Matters More than Rain
description: With the month's first drops of rain on Monday, many farmers relaxed a bit about the year's longest and most intense dry spell, and get back to the problem that plagues them rain or shine: earning enough from their crops to stay afloat.

title: How I Died
description: INGRATITUDE By Ying Chen. Translated by Carol Volk. 154 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $20.

title: Trial but Little Error
description: BRIAN MAHONEY, the 30-year-old chef and owner of Armadillo Crossing, describes his method of cooking as ''burn and learn.'' You would never guess, however, given the quality of the tender duck he serves on the bone, and the baby back ribs he glazes with honey, molasses and a blend of lively spices. One bite of his crisp sweet potato fries, and you'll wonder why his restaurant isn't crowded, even in August.

title: Other Bombs: Any Big Surprise Can Bring On a Bear
description: If investors can be blithe in good times, they can be squeamish in bad. Especially when the market is trying to decide which way to go, outside events are often the shock that sets off a bear market. It happened in 1973, when the worst postwar bear market coincided with the resignation of President Richard M. Nixon. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990 also sent the market into a spiral.

title: Epic Proportions
description: An Italian-American, overlong WAR AND PEAC (1956), though sensibly compressed from Leo Tolstoy's massive novel, has flaws. It also looks stunning in its photography, costuming and evolcation of Russia in this Napoleonic era. In a story that now seems surface, Audrey Hepburn (above, with Henry Fonda) is a charming co-star, but Mel Ferrer is listless. Henry Fonda is a plodding, scholarly Pierre but Vittorio Gassman makes a good, fiery Russian officer. Two elements are above reproach: the musical score and the magnificent battle scenes directed by King Vidor are so good that they compensate for other flaws. It is decidedly worth-while - Part 1, MONDAY at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. on the History Channel; Part 2 on TUESDAY, same times.

title: Hitting Home Without Touching All Bases
description: Babe Ruth. Dead 50 years today, he never seems to have left us. He was man and myth, a Brobdignagian force of nature who gorged himself on vices and home runs, who adored show business sweeties but reveled in the smiles of children.

title: Going Where a Lot of Other Dudes With Really Great Equipment Have Gone Before
description: John Tierney faithfully portrays the sense of fatigue that envelops the unwary during amateur adventure expeditions. The real danger comes when exhaustion overcomes fear. In short, you get so darned tired you just don't care anymore. This phenomenon has propelled me down river rapids and up sailing-ship masts, places I had no business being.

title: Two Cultures in One Body
description: ENSCONCED in a rose leather chair in her studio apartment here, Taewon Yi Kim, a classically trained coloratura mezzo-soprano, looks decidedly undivalike. Styling her hair on this particular morning, she declares, is ''useless.'' Casually dressed in somber colors, except for her fuchsia-and-electric-green slippers, the 32-year-old would easily blend in with the young Asian-Americans who frequent the clutch of Korean and Japanese establishments on Main Street.

title: Park Priorities
description: To the Editor: Our national parks should be places where we can find a little peace and quiet. Unfortunately, as ''Priorities in the National Parks'' by John H. Cushman Jr. (July 26) illustrated, visitors no longer can count on such an experience.

title: More Ticks. Thanks, El Nino.
description: EL NINO may seem like a distant memory, but the mild, wet weather it brought to much of the country earlier this year has helped spawn outbreaks of several illnesses in popular vacation spots this summer. With lush vegetation for food and shelter, rodents are proliferating, according to public health experts, and so are the diseases that they spread. Hantavirus, a deadly infection, has returned to the Southwest, and tick-borne illnesses like Lyme disease are spreading in most states.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Dog STAR

title: Lost in Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOUNTSIER, MARGARET
description: MOUNTSIER-Margaret Stevenson. Of Nutley, NJ, on Aug. 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late S. Rush Mountsier, Jr.; mother of Mrs. Sally Dietrick, Mrs. Elizabeth Diachun, Robert W., John S., Silas R. III, Stevenson, and William W. Mountsier; also survived by 18 grandchildren and 39 great-grandchildren. There will be a memorial service at Vincent United Methodist Church, Vincent Pl., Nutley, on Sat., Sept. 19, 1998 at 2 pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to Margaret Stevenson Mountsier Scholarship Fund, Westminster College, New Wilmington, PA would be appreciated.

title: Pigeons Struck by Darts
description: A flock of pigeons roosting in the oak trees along the eastern side of Eighth Avenue, between Fourth and Fifth Streets, has become the target of someone with a blowgun. At least six birds have been seen in recent weeks with metal darts as long as five inches stuck in various parts of their bodies.

title: Rosemarie Adams, Gary Wendt
description: Rosemarie Adams, a former corporate meetings planner, and Gary Carl Wendt, the chairman of the GE Capital Corporation in Stamford, Conn., are to be married this evening at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Karen Sayres, a minister of the United Church of Christ, is to perform the ceremony.

title: PULSE: LONDON EDITION; The Bloke Look
description: Suiting up in London used to be simple: bankers went to Savile Row, salesclerks to Marks & Spencer. But newly image-conscious young professionals want zippy suits with designer labels, like John Rocha's boldly colored, luxuriously lined, close-cut models (coming to Saks Fifth Avenue in New York in the fall). Owners are so attached to the new suits that they won't take them off for any occasion. After Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, eschewed white tie at a Mansion House dinner to deliver his annual speech about the economy, men started wearing suits instead of more formal attire to all kinds of upscale social functions. At London weddings, it is now more chic to exchange the traditional heavy black tailcoat for a tonic suit, in two-tone linen or silk, made by Jigsaw, due to open a branch in New York in the fall (prices start at $480).

title: Anne Pierson, Christopher Miller
description: Anne Mary Pierson was married yesterday to Christopher Yates Miller at the First Church of Christ in Farmington, Conn. The Rev. James Blanning, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: After Tower Collapses, Four Shore Rides Are Closed
description: The bungee-cord ride at Steel Pier in Atlantic City and three others like it at other shore parks are not open for thrill seekers. The Steel Fear ride in Atlantic City is being dismantled after a 180-foot tower collapsed last week, and others in amusement parks in Wildwood, Ocean City and Seaside Heights are being reinforced although no problems were found in those structures, said William Catanoso, whose family owns all four areas. The collapse is still under investigation by the state.

title: A Tranquil Authority On Degrees of Cruelty
description: IT comes as no surprise that the writer and director Neil LaBute's new movie, ''Your Friends and Neighbors,'' is as provocative and unsettling as his ''In the Company of Men'' was last year. In that film, his first, the ruthless misogynist Chad, played by Aaron Eckhart, memorably suggests to a colleague, ''Let's hurt someone.'' The six characters in ''Your Friends and Neighbors,'' a brutal and funny take on dysfunctional relationships that opens on Wednesday, might well be saying, ''Let's hurt one another.''

title: Office Market Booms in Strong Economy
description: AS a rising tide raises all boats, a strong economy lifts the entire Westchester office market.

title: Mike Tyson's Boxing License
description: Should Mike Tyson have had his license to fight in New Jersey approved by the state Athletic Control Board?

title: Multiplicity of Media in a Group Show and 2 Solos
description: 'Sense of Summer'

title: Webber Is Fined In Marijuana Seizure
description: Chris Webber of the Sacramento Kings was fined $500 for carrying a small amount of marijuana that was detected by dogs at the airport in San Juan, Puerto Rican customs officials said yesterday.

title: Clearing Misconceptions About Catholic Hospitals
description: The proposed takeover of private, non-sectarian Mid-Island Hospital by Catholic Health Services will result in further financial loss. Most tubal occlusions for female sterilization are performed in conjunction with childbirth. If this service becomes unavailable at Mid-Island, the pregnant patient who requires post-partum sterilization will choose to deliver elsewhere. This loss of revenue combined with the loss of income from other ''reproductive services'' will reflect negatively in the financial bottom line of the hospital.

title: In the Region/Westchester; High-End Houses Highlight Brisk 2d Quarter Sales
description: IN his 93-unit Hardscrabble Lake luxury detached-house development in the Town of Mount Pleasant, Jeffery S. Doynow has sold almost as many homes in the first seven months of this year as he did in all of 1997.

title: The Economy: Signs of Health And Rays of Hope
description: With the 1990's economic expansion poised to enter the record books as the longest ever in peacetime, it is shifting gears from the heady pace of the last two years to a more sedate one. Whatever negatives may be at work, the economy may well be a stabilizing, not destabilizing, influence for financial markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOUWEINE, HARRIET (BEAR)
description: SOUWEINE-Harriet (Bear) Of Delray Beach, FL. Widow of William. Died August 14. Mother of Candace, Jane and Jonathan. Sister of Roslyn Klein and Elaine Cohn. Grandmother of four. Memorial service JCA, Amherst, MA, 11 AM, August 17.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFF, LILLIAN WIESEN.
description: LEFF-Lillian Wiesen. Peacefully and bravely, in her 99th year. Our beloved ''Mama Cookie'' was a true humanitarian, supporter of many needy people, including artists, dancers, physical therapists, and a source of strength to her family and friends. She was the daughter of Max and Rose Wiesen, cherished wife of the late Phillip Leff, beloved mother of Ruth and Jerome A. Siegel and Joseph and Juanita Leff. Grandmother of Michael and Laurence Levin, Stephen and Amy Levin, Robin Kantrowitz, William and Sharon Levin, Henry Siegel, Elizabeth and David Carpenter, Carol Siegel, Julie and Jeffrey Satinover and Valerie and Joseph Godden. Great-grandmother of Adam, Max, Alex, Sebastien, Samantha, Eli, Noah, Sarah Emily, Rachel, Matthew, David, Emma, Sarah Kate, Annie and Jenny. Dear sister of Eleanor Leff and Irving Wiesen and sister-in-law of Tobie, Shirley and Mae Wiesen. ''Cookie'' was a former member of the Jewish Theological Seminary Board of Overseers and active with The United Jewish Appeal, The National Council of Jewish Women and Brandeis University. She received the Haym Solomon Award from the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith ''For her unswerving dedication to humanitarian and spiritual values.'' Lilly was a fine pianist and gave concerts in Town Hall and Palm Beach. Cookie believed in living life to the fullest. With her marvelous sense of humor, great compassion, love of art, dancing, music and everything exciting and interesting, she was a joy to be with. This darling, ''fey'', loving great-grandmother, grandmother and mother will be sorely missed, but she will live on in our hearts forever. Funeral service will be held Sunday, August 16th, 11 am at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87 Street & Madison Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the 92nd St. ''Y''.

title: The Beige And The Black

A few years ago, predictions that whites would eventually become a minority group in the United States galvanized the multicultural left -- and horrified the nativist right. More recently, news of the growing number of mixed-race Americans has inspired the political center with a vision of a true racial melting pot, one in which white and black alike will blend into a universal brown. But a closer look at demographic trends suggests that neither of these futures -- a nonwhite majority, a uniformly beige society -- will very likely come to pass. Instead, shifting patterns of racial intermarriage suggest that the next century may see the replacement of the historic white-black dichotomy in America with a troubling new division, one between beige and black.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; Look What the Cats Brought Home
description: Tomi Ungerer, the Peck's Bad Boy of children's book publishing, was once described as ''Jean de Brunhoff and Eugene Ionesco, together in one body.'' Indeed, with his mordant European wit, his sly textual puns and his penchant for animal characters drawn with a beguiling casualness, he has had his share of brilliant successes -- ''The Beast of Monsieur Racine,'' ''The Three Robbers,'' ''Moon Man'' and the perennial favorite ''Crictor.'' But in his more than 100 books, he has also had some spectacular flops, like the much-argued-about ''No Kiss for Mother.'' Ungerer's unsentimental -- indeed, antisentimental -- books have always fared well in Europe, perhaps even better than here in America. I fear that FLIX (Tomi Co/Roberts Rinehart, $16.95; ages 4 and up) is one of those Ungerer productions that will be better received abroad. In ''Flix'' a happily married cat couple are expecting a baby. Noticeably pregnant (or, as Ungerer says, ''profusely bulging''), the wife is ''seized by contractions'' and driven to the hospital. And there she gives birth to . . . a dog. The rest of the book is about how Flix -- the dog baby in a cat family -- grows up battling a predictable course of prejudice, and winning. In the end he marries another dog, and she, ''bulging with new life,'' is similarly seized by contractions and gives birth to . . . a cat. Alas, Ungerer, who has always fought against bias in his cartoons and adult work and championed the underdogs (no ''Flix'' pun intended) in his children's books, has been hoist by his own good intentions. He works so hard at his anti-racial-bias message that he ends up working in some of his own. For example, even growing up in an all-feline family, Flix speaks cat ''uttered with a dog accent.'' Why? Because dogs, no matter with whom they are raised, still sound like dogs? I'd hate to follow that argument into human society. Then the father cat explains the mystery of the birth: ''His grandmother was reputed to have been secretly married to a pug, and now, generations later . . . here was the result! 'It is a genetic mishap!' '' Ditto. Perhaps I am placing too much knee-jerk correctness on the shoulders of what is, after all, a simple picture book. However, it is clear that Ungerer is going for a Picture Book With Meaning. Which means that readers of whatever age need to look at it with as clear and unsentimental an eye as Ungerer himself has had in the past. JANE YOLEN

description: DeMAILLE-George. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of George J. DeMaille, associated with The Times from 1960.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESSINGER, PAUL J.R., M.D.
description: SCHLESSINGER-Paul J.R., M.D. 77. Retired obstetrician and gynecologist, died on Monday, August, 10 of a heart attack at home in Northampton, MA. A graduate of Harvard University and Harvard Medical School, he practiced on Long Island from 1950 to 1986. At Central General Hospital in Plainview, he served as Co-Director of the OB/GYN department from 1964 to 1986, and on the Board of Directors from 1964 to 1994. He is survived by his wife, Ann, three children, five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. An informal memorial gathering will take place Sunday, August 30 at 1 PM at the offices of his former partners at 777 Old Country Rd, Plainview, LI. Interment will be private.

title: Confess-O-Matic
description: Andrzej Urbanski, a computer scientist based in Poznan, Poland, has had enough with sweating it out in the Catholic confessional. ''The moment of confession can be very tense and you can forget your sins,'' Urbanski says. So the self-described ''crazy computer inventor'' created Reflex 1.0, the first confessional commercially available on CD-ROM. For $17.47, Catholics can rehearse with 104 yes-and-no confessional questions. Sales have been slow since the CD hit stores in June (eight units sold so far), but he's hoping it will catch on among Polish youth. To test that, we asked a confessor -- Karol Kasprzyk, a 22-year-old Polish computer entrepreneur -- to give it a whirl.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GILBERT, CHARLES A.
description: GILBERT-Charles A. Remembering Charlie. D.

title: Baseketball
description: Trey Parker, Matt Stone, Robert Vaughn, Ernest Borgnine, Trevor Einhorn

title: For Grand Jury, a Very Private Viewing
description: When President Clinton testifies on Monday to the grand jury investigating his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, it will not be his first time before video cameras in the long-running Whitewater saga.

title: Three Phases of Eve: Mother, Wife, Friend
description: When ''Thirtysomething'' ended its run on ABC, its viewers, a small group by network television standards but still numbering in at least six figures, were bereft. No more weekly visits at the home of Hope and Michael Steadman, where their friends all seemed to have a key to the front door and unlimited hours to talk -- about marriage, careers, relationships, parents, sex, children and death.

title: Where Talk About Prejudice Is Candid
description: ''IT'S an awful thing to say,'' confessed the Italian-American student, ''but when my grandfather died recently one of the first thoughts that went through my head was, 'Thank God I won't be the one to kill him!' '' He had never found out that she was dating a black man, she explained. Her mother had often told her that he would certainly die if he did.

title: Crime
description: Tony Hillerman is a wonderful storyteller, which means that you believe every word he says. In THE FIRST EAGLE (HarperCollins, $25), which like his previous police procedurals is set on the Big Reservation, straddling the Arizona-New Mexico border, a Navajo woman by the name of Old Lady Notah claims to have sighted a ''skinwalker'' -- a witch. In such a place, on such authority, it's easy to believe in skinwalkers. But as Joe Leaphorn, now retired as a tribal policeman, says, ''Witches offer an easy explanation for unexplained illnesses.'' So it's just as logical to suspect, as do some biologists working for the Indian Health Service, that a new and extraordinarily virulent strain of bubonic plague is abroad.

title: Bottled Tans Good Enough To Fool a Dermatologist
description: SAY what you will about a deep dark tan, but for many it is this season's vice of choice. With the consumption of luxuries -- and the flaunting of a luxuriously pampered look -- at full throttle, well-bronzed skin has a certain devil-may-care appeal, despite the health risks.

title: Style; A Fine Whine
description: It's mid-August in the whining capital of the world, when it's hot and therapists are away, and people are seething at the good fortune of others. With the severe whining watch in effect until Labor Day, it's time for a brief evaluation and review.

title: How a Man of Many Firsts Isn't Done Collecting Them
description: It is not often that a politician will look out of place at his own event. But there was Representative Robert Menendez last week, hands in his pockets and a slightly distracted look on his face, standing practically in the audience at a ceremony dedicating a pavilion -- to him.

title: In Our Times, You Call This Camping?
description: CAMPING used to be a horrible experience. In the distant days when I was a Boy Scout, we spent countless dismal nights trying to sleep on the rocky ground with extra-sharp rocks under our spines, trying to ignore the water dripping on our faces and trying to avoid hypothermia by enticing raccoons or almost any warm-blooded creatures into our sleeping bags.

title: BEST SELLERS: August 16, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Q&A/Mike Davies; Cautious Wrinkles in the Tennis Tradition
description: MIKE DAVIES of Westport is president and chief executive officer of the Pilot Pen International Men's and Women's Tennis Tournament, which opens tomorrow at the Connecticut Tennis Center at Yale University in New Haven.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; A Camp's Trails Include Well-Marked Career Paths
description: Joncier Rienecker, 15, likes to write, and plans to make a career of it. At Camp Mariah, she is getting a taste of a future in journalism.

title: Nina Shokraii, Matthew Rees
description: Nina Shokraii and Matthew Russel Rees were married yesterday at the Cosmos Club in Washington. Bishop William H. Nixon of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints officiated.

title: Town on Shaky Ground Is Seeing a Turnaround
description: Postcard views of snow-covered peaks, sparkling lakes and emerald pine forests surround this resort town 7,800 feet up in the Eastern Sierra. But to the dismay of residents, when the nation's attention is drawn to their town next to the Mammoth Mountain ski resort, it most often focuses on what is going on underground.

title: The Makeup Artist
description: I read Dana Tierney's beautiful story of her mother, ''The Makeup Artist,'' over and over (Lives, July 26). What a woman, the mother! What a writer, the daughter! Thank you for publishing her article.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARVEL, AGNES STEWART
description: CARVEL-Agnes Stewart On August 4, 1998 in London. Beloved wife of the late Thomas Carvel. Dear sister of Jane Ortowski and the late William Stewart, Isabel Zucchelli and Dorothy McLaughlin. The Service of Celebration and Thanksgiving for the life of Agnes Carvel is at 7PM Monday, August 17th at the Church of St Barnabas, Revolutionary Road, Ardsley, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Salvation Army or the charity of your choice.

title: Soak up the Atmosphere
description: Spending August in New York engenders envy, one of the least attractive of the seven deadlies. Lust, gluttony, sloth, pride -- almost any of them are more fun, but it's hard not to succumb to that peevish failing when people you know are off having great vacations and you are stuck in your walk-up, basting in odors of whatever's frying in the greasy spoon downstairs. The way to overcome this pernicious emotion is to deconstruct the vacation experience that brings it on, then find out how you can duplicate -- in your own home -- the defining moment. The beauty industry, genius at pouring big dreams into small packages, will aid you in this effort. In fact, it has already distilled the essence of your desire into a purse spray.

title: New York Actors Not California Dreaming
description: THE SETTING -- A muggy screening Monday of ''Slums of Beverly Hills,'' an offbeat comedy from Fox Searchlight Pictures starring Alan Arkin, Marisa Tomei and Natasha Lyonne and directed by Tamara Jenkins, a newcomer. She and nearly all the cast are native, amply accented New Yorkers. And the film is about a family of New York types, though lowly ones, lost in a trashy corner of Beverly Hills in the mid-1970's.

title: STRANGE REVELRY
description: * Most state fairs don't offer actual freak shows anymore, but strange things still happen. * The New York State Fair (starts Aug. 27) features Brian J. Ruth, ''Master of the Chain Saw,'' a chain-saw sculptor who, as a stunt, once trimmed his fingernails with a Poulan Handyman Plus ES-300. * The Iowa State Fair offers Norma Duffield (Duffy) Lyon, a butter sculptor who in 1994 fashioned a 400-pound, full-body Garth Brooks. * Last year, the Minnesota State Fair offered 27 different foods-on-a-stick, including ''Walleye on a Stick.'' * This year, 77 state and county fairs will hold a National Best Spam Recipe Contest. Twenty other fairs have requested to hold to the event. * In 1995, George Steinbrenner, incoming chairman of the Florida State Fair, pledged to reduce admission from $7 to nothing by 1998. Adult price in 1998: $7.

title: Youths See Summer Jobs As Training For the Future
description: IN a job market with strikingly low unemployment, many high school and college students in Westchester have been busily at work filling vacancies in a variety of job categories this summer. Like Andre Williams, 15, a busboy in Mount Vernon; Toni Susi, 16, an aspiring actress in Yorktown; Vincent Straface, 21, a peace officer in Rye, and Manoj Cheriyan, 19, a lab technician in Valhalla, they have been trying on part of their future for size.

title: In the Region/Long Island; A Huge High-Tech Center for Suffolk County
description: ALTHOUGH the last employees left in December, the blue Northrop Grumman sign still stands outside a sprawling 355,000-square-foot building occupying 82 acres just south of Sunrise Highway in this easterly section of the Town of Islip.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GELDZAHLER, HENRY
description: GELDZAHLER-Henry. 7/9/358/16/94. The Greeks used to say that there is not a short life or a long life. There's only one life. And the life you have is the life that you're given, the life you work with. It has its own shape, describes its own arc & it is perfect. Kay Bearman

title: Currencies: A Global Drama: As the Yen Turns
description: ''Now is the time to assess risks and rewards,'' said Mark Mobius, the managing director of Templeton Asset Management. As he headed off to Moscow this weekend, the list of risks was getting longer.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday about the popularity of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, among film production companies misstated the surname of a star of ''The Yards,'' a feature filmed there recently. He is Mark Wahlberg, not Waldman.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; Tours of Paris For the French-Impaired
description: Twenty years ago, nearly all walking tours of Paris were given in French. The English-speaking tourist usually had to be content with a sheet containing the essential facts to be covered by the guide. There always came a moment as the group walked through castle or street when the guide would say something and all the French tourists would laugh while the Americans would just look down at the written sheet, feeling slightly left out. Now Americans can be in on the joke, too.

title: August 9-15; Swiss Banks Reach Accord
description: After years of bitter dispute, Switzerland's leading banks settled a lawsuit with victims of the Nazi era who had accused them of improperly retaining their assets. The banks agreed to pay $1.25 billion to claimants in the class-action suit -- people who survived the Holocaust and the heirs of those who did not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUGGAN, CATHERINE VERONICA (NEE DUGGAN)
description: DUGGAN - Catherine Veronica (nee Duggan) Of Broadford, Co. Limerick, Ireland, died on August 13, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Loving mother of John P., Eileen Beasley, Sr. Christella, I.H.M. and Mary M. Proud grandmother of William and Robert Beasley, Kathy Clements, Joanne Stewart, Christine Burras, John and Karen Cronin. Also survived by 16 great-grandchildren and one great-great-granddaughter and in Ireland and England many nieces and nephews. Visiting on Sunday, 7-9 P.M., Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. A Mass of Christian Burial, on Tuesday at 10 A.M., St. Anselms Church.

title: Yale and Its Uneasy Road To Peace on a Stately Past
description: THE relationship between urban universities and groups promoting historic preservation is never easy. The two have different priorities, which sometimes mesh but frequently collide. For preservationists, the built environment is the major concern; for universities, it is merely a part of their academic mission. When universities acquire older buildings for their own use, or to help stabilize a neighborhood, preservationists fear that the structures will be demolished, or just wither away, vacant and decaying.

title: A Twist on Playing Dress-Up: Women in Kids' Stuff
description: SEVERAL years ago when the models in a Chanel runway show wore baby T-shirts by Petit Bateau under their $5,000 suits, high school girls all over the United States instantly imitated the tummy-baring Lolita look.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: The Young Guns; Working The Martini Shift
description: SEE, we have the edge over everyone else,'' Charlie Walk was saying. ''We don't go home after work -- we go out. We learn from one other.''

title: August 9-15; Popcorn, Peanuts and Valentino
description: Baseball traditionalists will tell you that fans come to ball parks for the pastoral experience, the clout of a mighty home run, an intense face-off between a flame-throwing righthander and a Bunyanesque hitter or the work ethic of a player who never sits out a game.

title: Thomas Wolfe's House Is Damaged by Fire
description: The Asheville, N.C., boardinghouse that was the childhood home of Thomas Wolfe and the setting for his autobiographical novel ''Look Homeward, Angel'' stands empty and charred after a fire on July 24 that authorities believe was set deliberately. The house, a national historic landmark that attracts 25,000 visitors a year, will be restored but will probably remain closed for at least a year, according to Mary Cook, director of public affairs for the North Carolina Department of Cultural Resources.

title: Katherine Snyder, Justin Vagliano
description: Katherine Sterling Snyder, the daughter of Diana F. Snyder of Essex, Vt., and Dennis C. Snyder of Ridgefield, Conn., was married yesterday to Justin Christopher Vagliano, the son of Sally V. Pettus of Sharon, Conn., and Alexander M. Vagliano of Norfolk, Conn. Arthur S. Rosenblatt, the First Selectman of Norfolk, officiated there at Sunset Ridge Farm, the home of the bridegroom's father.

title: Palmer Wine Maker California Bound
description: DAN KLECK, the wine maker at Palmer Vineyards for seven years and a prominent figure in Long Island's wine industry since 1979, is leaving to take a new job in California. His longtime understudy, Tom Drozd, is succeeding him.

title: Ideas & Trends: Social Security, Chilean Style; Pensioners Quiver As Markets Fall
description: OTTO VON BISMARCK, Germany's ''Iron Chancellor,'' started a worldwide revolution when he created the first state-run social security system in 1883. No one seriously challenged that model until another man of iron will, Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile, installed the first privatized pension system here 98 years later, in 1981.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, SIDNEY N., MD,
description: ROTHSTEIN-Sidney N., MD, 83. Passed away on August 13, 1998, from complications of cancer. Born in Warsaw, Poland, he escaped the Nazi onslaught and arrived in America in 1941. He enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1944, and served with distinction, earning a Bronze Star and Purple Heart. In 1946 he opened a solo practice of medicine in the 5 Towns, which he maintained for 50 years. His family loved him dearly. His patients adored his sense of humor, his bedside manner and his clinical skills. We will all miss him dearly. He is survived by Sophie, his wife of almost 59 years; his son, Edward and his family-wife, Ellen and children, Aaron and Emily; his son, Jeffrey; & his brother, Joshua. Funeral services will be held at 12:15 PM on Sunday, August 16th, at Temple Israel in Lawrence. In lieu of any gifts the family suggests that you send a donation to the charity of your choice.

title: No Pesticides
description: When it comes to fighting Lyme disease, Westchester should continue its no-chemical policy, the County Pest Management Committee recently told the Board of Legislators.

description: LE tout Washington rolled its eyes last week when First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton came up with a novel explanation for her husband's continuing travails.

description: HERE'S a merger boom that investors may not like: Responding to a confluence of industry currents, mutual fund companies are combining funds at a record pace this year. Such mergers, however, can burn the shareholders they are purported to help.

title: A Long-Horizon Mantra, With a Chorus of 'Diversify'
description: In light of the market's recent declines, The New York Times interviewed three families with differing investment philosophies to see what, if any, adjustments they were making. The Times also asked certified financial planners to review the portfolios and, if needed, make recommendations. The results suggest that investors have convinced themselves that sticking with stocks is the conservative thing to do.

description: HER thin legs straining for a toehold, her shoulders bunching purposefully, her face tightening with the effort, Claudia Dash of Rye, 6, turned over on the mat.

description: To sun-baked, cotton-mouthed beachgoers along the shores of the Rockaways, Ferrone Malone and his sack of ''not cold, but ice-cold'' libations spell relief.

description: Sandra Jean Foight, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd S. Foight of Randolph, N.J., was married yesterday to W. Nicholas Klose Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Woody N. Klose of Red Hook, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Sheffield officiated at the Presbyterian Church in Morristown, N.J.

title: Michelle Franks, John-Phillip Neill
description: Michelle Lynn Franks, the daughter of Bonnie and Sidney Franks of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., is to be married today to John-Phillip Neill, the son of Jacqueline Neill and Dr. John Neill of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Rabbi Michael Robinson is to officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: New Hotels
description: The developer of a large shopping center in Yonkers is negotiating with an unnamed company to build 450 hotel rooms in the city, Edward A. Sheeran, an economic development adviser to Mayor John D. Spencer, reported last week.

title: In Yiddish Music, A Return to Roots Of Torment and Joy
description: FOR more than a century, Yiddish music has survived in America. The melodic vernacular of displaced Jews from Eastern Europe, it is a music of secular wit and religious fervor, the music of a people in a conflicted dance with assimilation.

title: Home Is Where the Dishes Are
description: IT'S all my grandmother's fault, really. If she hadn't bequeathed me the colorful plates on which she'd served roast chicken and garlic potatoes every Sunday for years, I would never have started. Her haul of Harlequin -- those pointy-handled cousins of Fiesta ware that once sold for a pittance at Woolworth's but now command top dollar at collectibles shows -- set me on the path to collecting-heaven and storage-hell. Thanks to her china, dishes have become my obsession.

title: 3 Pros Are Grabbing the Bear by the Horns
description: THE bungee-like gyrations in the stock market the last two weeks may have scared away the faint of heart, but for money managers who are paid to stomach such swings, a plunge is simply a chance to pick up shares of solid companies on the cheap.

title: My Boris
description: I must take exception with one statement in Specter's article: that Yeltsin ''destroyed Communism in Russia.'' In fact, the Communist Party is the biggest and fastest-growing party in Russia. The Soviet Union used to be an autocratic country with a Communist ideology in which nobody believed. Today it is an autocratic country with a democratic ideology in which nobody believes. Big deal.

title: The Sport Of Rajahs
description: Long Island polo is a century-old tradition, introduced from Newport, R.I., in the 1880's. It took hold when Jay Phipps and Thomas Hitchcock established teams on their estates in Westbury. In the 1920's and 30's, when Michael Phipps, Tommy Hitchcock Jr. and Raymond and Winston Guest were the stars, their glamorous international matches sometimes drew 30,000 spectators. Long Island polo declined during World War II. But since 1995, with the founding of the Bridgehampton Polo Club and the Mercedes-Benz Polo Challenge, played on six consecutive Saturdays, a stylish crowd has flocked to Two Trees Farm and revived the glamour.

title: For the Blind, a Camp Leader Who Can Relate
description: WHILE waiting for their next activity, a half-dozen teen-age campers sprawled across the floor mats in the gymnasium at SUNY Farmingdale. With them was one of their counselors, Elizabeth Wurzer, and by her side was Luffy, her 3-year-old Labrador retriever.

title: When Shopping Around for a Place to Worship, Try the Mall
description: About 75 percent of Americans go to a mall at least once a month, while only 40 percent attend church or synagogue. So, the First Presbyterian Church of Mount Holly is going to the mall. The church celebrated the grand opening of its Burlington Center Ministry in Burlington Center last month. On the first floor, between a CVS drug store and a Sears department store, the ministry is designed to reach people whom organizers refer to as the ''unchurched.''

title: Nothing but the Truth
description: Unlike any of his modern predecessors, Bill Clinton seems to believe that he lives beyond the reach of public disappointment. Otherwise, how could he talk about picking an architect and having Hollywood raise $100 million for his Presidential library while at the same time allowing his aides to release the oddest trial balloon ever to float from the West Wing? We are now advised that the President of the United States may argue for continuance in office by telling a grand jury that he received oral sex, but that, in his view, the act did not constituent sexual relations since he did not touch any of the female body parts specified by a Federal judge.

description: To the Editor:

title: Scientists Debate China's Law on Sterilizing the Carriers of Genetic Defects
description: In an unusual move, the 2,000 scientists gathered here this week for the 18th International Congress of Genetics took time out from discussions of cloning and cancer genes to confront a controversial Chinese law, one that many experts believe permits doctors to require that people with serious genetic conditions be sterilized.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUGARMAN, EDWARD
description: SUGARMAN-Edward. On August 14, 1998. Devoted husband of Mildred. Dear father of Alice Murray. Cherished grandfather of Anna Van Doorn. Service Sunday, 11 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Masonic Brotherhood Fund.

title: Rumors and Contradictions Fuel Russia Market Crisis
description: As a branch manager of one of Russia's largest banks one of the commercial banks rumored to be on the brink of collapse in the latest wave of Russia's financial crisis -- the young man with a baby-face was frankly worried.

description: THIS weekend marks the 100th anniversary of the arrival of the Rough Riders to Montauk, and a summerlong series of activities to commemorate the event are in full swing.

title: Miss Miller, And Mr. Moulton
description: Margaret Elizabeth Blackwell Miller, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edgar R. Miller Jr., of Kennett Square, Pa., was married yesterday at her parents' house to Reynolds Ellsworth Moulton 3d, the son of Bessie Moulton of Falmouth, Me., and Mr. Moulton Jr. of Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. James Oren Reynolds performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Flower Power in the High-Tech 90's
description: The rolling fields of Max Yasgur's old farm are once again swathed in a psychedelic quilt of tie-dye-clad music fans. This time, though, the fans are carrying cellular telephones, and the automatic teller machines are just a few steps away.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report last Sunday about the Place, a restaurant and bar on West Fourth Street, misstated its ownership. Alexander Achilleos is not sole owner but an equal partner with Pablo Scheffel.

description: As Liberty point guard Teresa Weatherspoon left yesterday afternoon's home game against the Houston Comets with 1 minute 34 seconds to go, she pumped her fist in the air.

title: Roads of Skye
description: To the Editor: William Grimes's article ''The Misty Scottish Isle of Skye'' (July 19) evoked all the beauty and calm of that ''end of the world'' island; but he was correct to deal with the one-lane traffic situation in the first four paragraphs.

title: PULSE: LONDON EDITION
description: Jemima Khan, daughter of the late financier Sir James Goldsmith, shocked London society in 1995, when she forsook West End nightclubs and a university career to marry Imran Khan, a former captain of the Pakistani cricket team, and a Muslim. Followed by the paparazzi, she toured poverty-stricken streets of Lahore in a shalwar kameez, the Pakistani pajama-style pants suit. Surprisingly, the public deemed the look smashing. Now Ms. Khan (left) is introducing a line of Western clothes inspired by Pakistani dress: floor-length sequined cocktail dresses in heavy woven fabrics; dyed silk brocade coat dresses, chiffon cardigan wraps. Not all are as modest as Muslim law requires: some dresses come in shorter lengths and have halter necks. Ms. Khan said she wanted ''to design clothes that are sufficiently modest for me, but are still feminine and smart.'' The Cross and A la Mode, the boutiques that carry Jemima Khan, sold out in a week, and the racks remain empty. ''The dresses are made by hand in Pakistan, and each takes around three months to complete,'' explained Ms. Khan, whose dresses cost about $975. Proceeds go to a hospital founded by her husband.

title: Steamy Towelettes
description: The British can't legally obtain Viagra yet, but they do have access to a new product called Xcite!, moist towelettes soaked with human sexual pheromones -- that is, natural chemical secretions that supposedly send the right signals to members of the opposite sex. Currently being sold in nightclubs all over England (in restroom vending machines), Xcite! was developed by Kiotech, a British biotechnology company that has conducted pheromone research for years. In not-so-romantic language that may be fitting for these biotechnical times, Robert Page, a joint managing director with the company, claims that the towelettes, wiped anywhere on the skin, ''boost the wearer's sexual-smell signature.''

title: Lost in the Glow Of the Man at Her Side
description: THE history of 20th-century art has had more than its share of female artists whose achievements have been overshadowed by the art of their better-known male companions. The list includes Sonia Delaunay, Lee Krasner, Frida Kahlo, Helen Torr, Marguerite Zorach and Anni Albers. Georgia O'Keeffe is one of the few exempted from this category, largely because her husband, the photographer Alfred Steiglitz, worked tirelessly on her behalf.

For years, headquartered in a ramshackle red brick church in the Bronx, they enjoyed strong spiritual and cultural links to the mother church in Ethiopia, which many of them considered their homeland.

title: A History Lesson: For Major Indexes, A Long Way to Doom
description: For years, both the returns generated by stocks and the valuations that investors assigned to them have vastly exceeded levels experienced throughout market history. Some argue that outsized valuations are simply a result of a new era of investing in which the old rules no longer apply. These folks are happy to pay 200 times earnings for America Online.

title: It's Right Back to Boot Camp for Giants
description: In his second year as head coach, Jim Fassel has given his Giants, the defending champions in the National Football Conference East, a little more slack in training camp. Some workouts have been less physically demanding than a year ago, and the sessions during a few days have seemed shorter and less exacting.

description: FOR those mariners who harbor a certain affection for sailing in the grand manner, the city's ultimate yacht club is the New York Yacht Club, with its fanciful -- though landlocked -- Beaux Arts headquarters at 37 West 44th Street.
