title: Partch Instruments at a New Site
description: THE late Harry Partch was an American composer known as much for his musical inventions as for his music. Working within a notational system of 43 tones to an octave, he built a variety of instruments, which are as spectacular to look at as they are to hear, with names like the kithara, cloud chamber bowls and marimba eroica.

title: Carmi Gillon
description: Gillon was the head of Shin Bet, the Israeli internal security force, from 1994 to 1996. He's now on the advisory council of the Israel Policy Forum.

title: Two Shows, One Singling Out Ears And Another Focusing on Legs
description: OF two photography shows just reviewed, the one at the Main Street Gallery in Dobbs Ferry is all ears, while that in the Focal Point Gallery on City Island in the Bronx is long on legs.

title: GMC Tries On Some Designer Labels: DENALI; Here's a Preview Of Cadillac's Coming Attraction
description: IN Detroit's long-running struggle for one-upmanship, the Big Three take their victories wherever they can get them. When General Motors bought the Renaissance Center complex downtown, the new landlord got a certain pleasure in sending a group of tenants packing -- those whose office doors were emblazoned with the oval blue emblem of Ford.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Westchester section last Sunday about a New York State law that allows parents to send the fingerprints of a potential nanny to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a criminal background check misstated details of the case that prompted the law. The nanny, Ann Franklin, who eventually pleaded guilty to throwing 10-month-old Kieran Dunne across a room in their house in Rye, had answered a classified advertisement placed by Peggy and David Dunne; the Dunnes did not answer an advertisement placed by Ms. Franklin.

title: Mental Manipulation With Quarterbacks
description: The resume of Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde can be broken down this way: Many times, he displays the grace and throwing skill of a Hall of Famer. Then in the fourth quarter, with seven minutes left and his team trailing by a touchdown, there will be one throw when Testaverde will toss some awkward, goofy, comeback-killing interception.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLLIN, EDITH (NEE WEISSMAN)
description: DOLLIN-Edith (nee Weissman) Died August 6, 1998. Widow of Alexander Dollin. Beloved aunt of Debora Berger, David Berger, Jocelyn Keene, Diane Rosenholtz, David and Michael Weissman and Harriet Goldstein.

title: On the East Side, A Market Blowout Is Just a Breeze
description: THERE are many prisms through which to view the state of the economy. Stock prices are the current fixation, of course. But there are also consumer confidence figures, the long bond perhaps. And then there is dinner.

title: Pop/Jazz Briefs
description: SHERMAN IRBY: 'BIG MAMA'S BISCUITS'

title: United Way Reports Gifts Are Up 4.7%
description: The 1,300 local United Ways raised $3.4 billion last year, a 4.7 percent increase over the $3.25 billion raised in 1996 and the second year in a row that giving to the nation's largest private financer of social services charities has increased significantly faster than the rate of inflation.

title: Shipyard To Launch Its Biggest Vessel Ever
description: TUCKED behind an unprepossessing gray building, which abuts the shore line, a huge ferry is being built at the Derecktor Shipyards here, which the builders say will be the fastest passenger vessel in the United States. The high-speed ferry, which will travel at 50 knots, is to be launched next week.

title: GOOBERS BY MAIL
description: In Georgia this month, people are ripping green peanuts from the ground, tossing them in pots of salt water and boiling them. Are they protesting something? No, they're making boiled peanuts, a delicacy that's hard to come by in the North. That's where the Lee Bros. Boiled Peanuts Catalogue comes in. Founded by Matthew and Ted Lee, brothers based in Charleston, S.C., who attended Harvard and Amherst, the catalogue offers solutions to the peanut- access problem. Like: a two-pound Boil-Your-Own Peanuts Kit (dried nuts and instructions, $8) and a new item, canned boiled peanuts. It seems like a lot of fuss, but customers call in from all over -- a Canadian fan recently ordered 48 of the new cans. The Lees, who made serious money doing this last year, insist there's magic in wet goobers. ''Until you have tasted their haylike, earthy wonderfulness,'' says Matthew, ''you haven't had a peanut.

title: You Can Take the Girl Out of Nutley ...
description: ON her television show recently, Martha Stewart was making brownies and about to put in the eggs when suddenly she paused.

title: Health Clubs Consolidate as Membership Grows
description: Spurred by the rising popularity of health clubs among people more interested in improving cardiovascular fitness than parading toned pecs, two companies are aggressively expanding in the New York City area. With investment dollars pouring into the industry, scores of independent gyms and smaller chains are likely to be absorbed by major chains over the next few years.

title: Spano Calls Commitment To Tax Cut A Hard Task
description: ALMOST eight months into his administration and three months before he has to present his first budget, County Executive Andrew J. Spano said that he remains committed to a campaign pledge to reduce county taxes 15 percent over four years. He also said, however, that that is going to be harder to achieve than he had expected.

title: QUICK BITE/Montclair; How Do You Say 'Souffle au Chocolat' in Thai?
description: Ah, the pleasures of Thai food. The exotic flavors of lemongrass, kaffir lime, galangal, holy basil. The warming richness of tom ka gai (chicken and coconut soup). The fragrance (and burn) of the curries. The chocolate souffles.

title: Literary Cannibals
description: To the Editor:

title: Julie Landau, Tsvi Loring
description: Julie Ellen Landau and Tsvi Brooke Loring are to be married this evening by Rabbi Miriam Berkowitz at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Finley Oakley, Patrick Shaw
description: Finley Louise Oakley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Shields Oakley Jr. of Old Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to Patrick James Chapman Shaw, a son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Robert Shaw of Rochester. The Rev. Dr. Steward Herman performed the Lutheran ceremony at Union Chapel in the Grove, in Shelter Island Heights, N.Y.

title: Introducing a New Generation To American Impressionists
description: THE Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme is busy on a couple of new fronts these days, while continuing one of its major missions: the introduction of American Impressionist painters to the current generation of viewers. The current rediscovery is of Wilson Irvine (1869-1936), and the complete title of his show rings true: ''Wilson Irvine and the Poetry of Light.''

title: Pre-Concert Programs Offered at Bard College
description: TCHAIKOVSKY is the musician of the weekend at the Bard Festival at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, with panel discussions, pre-concert talks and concerts. The event on Friday at 8:30 P.M. in Olin Auditorium is titled ''Nadezhda von Meck: Patronage and Passion'' and offers music enhanced by readings from the letters that flowed between the composer and his benefactor.

title: Clinton Case Is Risky for His Legal Adviser, Too
description: President Clinton's private lawyer, David E. Kendall, has practically moved into the White House, prepping his client in sessions at all hours in the days before Mr. Clinton tells a grand jury about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky. As chief architect of Mr. Clinton's legal strategy, it is Mr. Kendall who will be at the President's side as he testifies on Monday.

title: Giving Pedestrians the Slip
description: CALLING all New York City history buffs! Quick, where's Coenties Slip?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECTOR, DOROTHY E.
description: RECTOR-Dorothy E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Dorothy E. Rector, associated with The Times from 1956, until retiring in 1977.

title: Italian Cuisine With a Magical Touch
description: THERE was a childhood party game in which players would look at objects on a tray and later see how many they could recall. At La Piccola Liguria in Port Washington, the tray has been replaced by waiters reciting specials. I counted 27 one night but may have missed a few. Many diners just throw up their hands in resignation or laugh nervously while trying to remember.

title: How a Sculptor Learned to See The Invisible
description: On June 14, the Jewish Museum in New York opened a retrospective of work by the sculptor George Segal that will be on view until Oct. 4. It has run concurrently with an exhibition of paintings by Chaim Soutine that closes today and then travels to Los Angeles and Cincinnati. On the day his show opened, Mr. Segal met at the museum with a group of art teachers and, after walking with them through his show, responded to questions. The following narrative, adapted from a videotape of that session made by the public-television station WNJN, illustrates how an artist develops the ideas that will shape a career.

title: Wild Weather, Topless Bars...; Foes of Topless Club Don't Belong in Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Fast Forward; What the Beep Is Going On?
description: A telephone rings. The microwave oven reports that food is ready. A clock announces the hour. Someone's pager has been paged. The fax machine has run out of paper. Or something -- anything -- has happened in a wristwatch, or computer, or alarm system, or dishwasher.

title: Marci Leder, Adam Haworth
description: Marci Beth Leder, a daughter of Gail and Joel Leder of Roslyn, N.Y., is to be married today to Adam Michael Haworth, a son of Diana and Bruce Haworth of North Woodmere, N.Y. Rabbi Moshe Edelman will perform the ceremony at the Woodbury (N.Y.) Jewish Center.

title: Laura Hodes, Mitchel Zacks
description: Laura Lee Hodes, a daughter of Hannah Hodes and Dr. Meyer Hodes of Oceanside, N.Y., is to be married in New Haven today to Mitchel Ethan Zacks, the son of Francine and Leonard Zacks of Glencoe, Ill. Rabbi James Ponet, the Jewish chaplain of Yale University, is to perform the ceremony at the Joseph Slifka Center for Jewish Life at Yale.

title: Yankee Fans Agree: Season Is a Waste Without a Title
description: Like those formless creatures who lurk under our beds in the night, dreadful thoughts now writhe in the minds of sentient Yankee fans. What if something goes wrong? What if they don't win it all? Fans talk about the nagging fears that not only might the season end badly, like life itself, but also that post-season defeat would negate this glorious regular season.

title: No Trade or Victory for MetroStars
description: Charlie Stillitano, the MetroStars' general manager, tried until the Major League Soccer's 5 P.M. deadline today to swing what he described as a blockbuster trade. That failed, and then Stillitano had to watch the Miami Fusion add to his frustration.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a Viewpoint article on July 19 about ways in which privatization of the Social Security system could affect the stock market misstated the background of the writer, Herbert Barchoff. He was a special adviser on issues involving small business for the President's Council of Economic Advisers in the Truman Administration; he was not one of the council's three formal members.

title: Suspect in Embassy Blasts Being Taken to Kenya
description: Law enforcement officials said tonight that American investigators in Pakistan were preparing to fly to Kenya with a man whom they identified as a suspect in last week's embassy bombings in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

title: A Crowd of Old Musicals Squeezes the New
description: AUDIENCES flocking to the Martin Beck Theater for the revival of ''The Sound of Music'' couldn't care less that many critics find the musical irredeemably saccharine. With its famously tuneful score, this 1959 show, the last Rodgers and Hammerstein collaboration, is comfortingly familiar. People watch dazed with happiness, bobbing their heads, along with the Von Trapp children as they learn their do, re, mi's, smiling with recognition as Maria lists her favorite things.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINTO, SEYMOUR
description: PINTO-Seymour. On August 10, 1998. Beloved husband of Maria Pinto. Dear father of Stuart and Richard. Beloved brother of Samuel Pinto and Mamie Fogel. Cherished uncle and good friend to many. Services were held Friday August 14.

title: PCB's Are Not Proven To Cause Cancer in Humans
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ONE THOUSAND AND ONE-SECOND STORIES By Taruho Inagaki. Sun and Moon, paper, $12.95.

title: Survivors' Guilt
description: THE MOURNERS' BENCH By Susan Dodd. 270 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $24.

title: Plan Would Open H.O.V. Lanes to All Cars
description: HEADS turned in May when Governor George E. Pataki canceled a $72 million project to build a high-occupancy vehicle, or H.O.V., lane on one mile of the Long Island Expressway in eastern Queens.

title: A Japanese Vision of the Ancient World
description: IN 1991, after collecting objects for the Japanese tea ceremony for 40 years, Mihoko Koyama switched to buying ancient and medieval art for the world-class museum she envisioned building on a mountaintop near here. Frail and in a wheelchair, Mrs. Koyama, an heiress to a textile fortune, moved quietly but with tornado force through the ancient art market.

title: A Bear Sees the Return Of 'the Reality Principle'
description: MICHAEL METZ is relieved that the stock market has retreated more than 10 percent from the dizzying heights of mid-July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STURSBERG, BABETTE L.
description: STURSBERG-Babette L. Passed away quietly at her home in Bernardsville, New Jersey, Thursday, August 6th, 1998. She was born on October 24th, 1914 in New York City & attended the Emma Willard School. She was the daughter of Edith Downey and Albert H. F. Stursberg. Three brothers, Laird Stursberg, Edward A. Stursberg, J. Hermann Stursberg and a sister, Barbara May Harding, predeceased her. She was survived by ten nieces and nephews. She lived the majority of her life at ''Edgewood'', her home in Bernardsville and was a supporter of the Somerset Bridal Path Association, the United States Equestrian Team and the Morristown Seeing Eye. It was her request that there be no services.

title: A Long-Horizon Mantra, With a Chorus of 'Diversify'
description: In light of the market's recent declines, The New York Times interviewed three families with differing investment philosophies to see what, if any, adjustments they were making. The Times also asked certified financial planners to review the portfolios and, if needed, make recommendations. The results suggest that investors have convinced themselves that sticking with stocks is the conservative thing to do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, LOUISE MARIE,
description: ROSENBERG-Louise Marie, 63. Died peacefully Tuesday in her Wilton home, surrounded by family. With husband Peter, she transformed their business Vallin Galleries into a renowned Asian art gallery. Louise was an inspirational, nurturing mother and friend. She created a loving family & gracious home with beautiful gardens. She is survived by her husband, six children Robert, Jean, Michael, Thomas, Simon and Nicolas, five grandchildren, and sister Mary.

title: August 9-15; New Help for Clinton
description: President Clinton is running the meter on his lawyers' clocks this weekend by preparing for his grand jury testimony on Monday. But he can take comfort in knowing that his new legal defense fund has raised more than $2 million in just six months.

title: Parents Can Force Flexibility in the Workplace; Another Option
description: To the Editor:

title: From Anita to Spider Woman in 90 Minutes
description: NEARING the milestone of a 50-year life in the theater, Chita Rivera is the epitome of an enduring crossover performer, as well known a box office draw on the casino circuit as a star of the Broadway stage. She may well represent the fin-de-millennium dream of a renaissance for the big-time American musical.

title: Bringing Outdoor Shakespeare to the East End
description: NO longer classical theater's castaway, the East End is staking an overdue claim to summer cultural credibility with free Shakespeare outdoors. A 75-minute ''Merry Wives of Windsor,'' adapted and directed by the veteran actress Peg Murray under the banner of Northeast Stage with Harold Prince as a backer, was, alas, further reduced, to only two performances on Aug. 7 and 8 in Mitchell Park in Greenport. But the expanding Hamptons Shakespeare Festival began its third season at Theodore Roosevelt County Park here on Aug. 5 with ''As You Like It.''

title: Badlands
description: To the list of hazards in the California desert (rattlesnakes, dehydration, U.F.O.'s), add unexploded military ordnance. From 1942 to 1944, one million U.S. Army soldiers passed through Gen. George Patton's Desert Training Center -- 12 million acres in the Mojave and Colorado deserts, east of Palm Springs, chosen for its resemblance to North Africa. Under great secrecy, troops practiced for war, tossing real grenades and burying practice land mines all over the place.

title: SPENDING IT / EARNING IT: VICARIOUS CONSUMPTION; Stables Fit for a King: Splendor in the Bluegrass
description: IN the Bluegrass, in the heart of central Kentucky, some horses live better than most people, in barns that look like castles or cathedrals, with spires and cupolas, stained-glass windows and garden sculpture, chandeliers and hand-forged gates.

title: All You Need Is Celebrity
description: A FRIEND of mine has a science fiction screenplay idea. In the future, celebrities become so godlike that they live in a separate world in the clouds, while mere humans toil on the earth below as their servants. It's like ''Planet of the Apes,'' but the apes are celebrities. And Charlton Heston is human.

title: Let's Go To The Hops
description: IN South Orange, it has been 10 weeks since the Soboti family opened the Gaslight Brewery and Restaurant and about nine and a half weeks since they decided that if they were ever going to sleep they would have to hire someone to clean up after closing.

title: OPINION; When Time Stood Still at the Beach
description: IT'S more than just the way we close each summer. It is the time we all took forward to the most all year. At the end of every August we stop, leave everything behind and celebrate ourselves, each other, our family, on the beach at Montauk.

title: Karen Wilkie and Stephen Newman
description: Karen Elizabeth Wilkie, a daughter of Patricia Cotter Wilkie and Dr. Bernard Wilkie of Charlotte, N.C., was married last evening to Stephen Julian Newman, a son of Frani J. Newman of New Harford, N.Y., and Matthew E. Newman of New York. Rabbi Adam Morris performed the ceremony at the Morehead Inn in Charlotte.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Trail Fever: Spin Doctors, Rented Strangers, and Thumb Wrestlers on the Road to the White House

title: 150 years later, a golden anniversary
description: Three years of special events in California will commemorate three 150th anniversaries: the discovery of gold in 1998, the Gold Rush in 1999, and statehood in the year 2000. While the celebration is statewide and its broader themes are Discovery, Diversity and Destiny, this sampling of events highlights Gold Rush history. The Gold Rush Race of tall ships from San Francisco to Long Beach-Los Angeles and then to San Diego in July 1999 is likely to be a high point.

title: A Husband's Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: The Buddy System Is Adjusted to Fit The Late 1990's
description: WHEN two movies, ''Return to Paradise'' and ''Clay Pigeons,'' were scheduled to open on the same day this month, sharp-eyed executives at Polygram -- the company behind the financing of these films -- looked at the cast lists and thought they were seeing double. Both releases star Vince Vaughn and Joaquin Phoenix. And while ''Clay Pigeons'' is a black comedy about a serial killer loose in a small town in Montana and ''Return to Paradise'' an earnest drama about the efforts to save the life of an American sentenced to death in Malaysia for drug possession, the studio feared that audiences might be confused if the two movies opened on the very same day. So ''Return to Paradise'' kept its opening date last Friday and ''Clay Pigeons'' was pushed back to early October.

title: Led by Australian, Japanese Crew Wins
description: It was as if there were two yacht-racing series going on within the Kenwood Cup off Hawaii this year. But when both sides finished racing Friday after 10 days of competition, a crew from Japan was named winner of the One Design 48 series, while sailboats from New Zealand won the team racing segment of the event.

title: Water, Water Everywhere, So Why Not Enjoy It?; On the Rolling Sea, Learning the Calm Of Fluke Fishing
description: THE horn sounded and Captain Mikey Hagens's voice came over the loudspeaker: ''O.K., everybody, lines in and good luck.''

title: At the Casinos
description: Atlantic City Hilton

title: On Language; Minding The Court's Language
description: Justices of the Supreme Court may hand down the final word on the law, but they cannot offer the final word on the words. That's for all of us to hash out (cf. Marbury v. Safire).

title: The Nation: Blacks Crunch the Numbers; Figuring Out Hispanic Influence
description: IN seven years, according to the Census Bureau, blacks will no longer be the nation's largest minority group, for the first time since the Federal Government began keeping an official count of the population.

title: A Staten Island Spot For Italian Entrees
description: Selatin Velija came to Brooklyn from Albania in 1970. Later he moved to Port Richmond on Staten Island, became interested in the restaurant business and worked as a chef for 15 years at LiGreci's Staaten. He opened his own Staten Island restaurant, Casa Milla, last month.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HEALY, MARTIN E.
description: HEALY-Martin E. Happy Birthday. Wings fit? Harp in tune? Much love. Miss you. All of us, especially El

title: Rochelle Sharpe and Richard Lewis
description: Rochelle Phyllis Sharpe, a reporter, and Dr. Richard Franklin Lewis, a neurologist, are to be married today on the grounds of the Audubon Naturalist Society in Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Amy Schwartzman is to perform the ceremony.

title: Free House Comes of Age, Trouncing a Strong Field in the Pacific Classic
description: Free House was the overlooked horse in last year's Triple Crown races, when the glory belonged to Silver Charm and Touch Gold. But today at Del Mar Race Track, Free House proved that he had grown up from a good 3-year-old to a sensational 4-year-old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTERFIELD, ALFRED W.
description: PORTERFIELD-Alfred W. On August 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Loving father of Alfred, Teresa Darby and William and grandfather of Victoria and Jill. Dear brother of Robert Porterfield and Grace Clayberger. He was a Korean War Veteran and a devoted member of the American Legion VFW, a recipient of The Purple Heart, Soldier's Medal, Silver Star, Bronze Star and Combat Infantry Badge. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday at St. John the Evangelist Church, 1st Ave. at 55th St. Call Frank E. Campbell for further information: 212-288-3500.

title: Times Square Visitors To Get High-Tech Help
description: Times Square, in the midst of its big cleanup, is about to open a new visitors center in a restored movie theater. The center, on the east side of Broadway between 46th and 47th Street, will even provide public restrooms, that rarest of Manhattan amenities, when it opens next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAFFEL, PEARL BRESLOW
description: TAFFEL-Pearl Breslow On August 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Albert B. Breslow and Samuel James Taffel. Devoted mother of Susan & Martin Dillon. Cherished grandmother of Eleanor & Daniel Petigrow and Alice Dillon. Loving great grandmother of Samara and Michaela. Graveside Services Wednesday, August 19, 1998, 10:30 AM at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, New York.

title: Filling the Need for More Tee Time
description: IN the early 90's, with the shade-tobacco business lagging, Kip Shepard and his three sisters and brother began to wonder if there might be better ways to use the family's 162-acre spread in South Windsor. ''It had been a family-owned tobacco farm since the 1800's,'' Mr. Shepard said, ''but we felt there must be some other way to derive revenue from our property.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MINSKOFF, HENRY H.
description: MINSKOFF-Henry H. In loving memory of a beloved husband, father and grandfather, forever in our hearts. Marjorie, Jim, Jean, Alan, Richard, Michael, Donna, Noah, Tasha, Henry and Laura

title: Joel Barr, Defector Linked to Rosenbergs, Dies
description: Joel Barr, an electronics engineer linked to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg who defected to the Soviet bloc in 1950 and became a leading force in the Kremlin's computer industry, died in a Moscow hospital on Aug. 1. He was 82 and had lived in St. Petersburg for many years.

title: American, Asian and Don't Forget Dessert
description: THE somewhat shabby-looking house with paint-peeling exterior did not inspire confidence about what awaited within, and the small interior rooms with cramped tables and uncomfortable chairs were not reassuring either. But as we studied the menu at the Frog and the Peach in Canton we began to brighten up.

title: Wild on the Water: L.I. Boaters Beware
description: WHEN Officer Joel Fuoco stopped a boater for speeding in Reynolds Channel behind Long Beach last weekend he also discovered that the operator had no valid registration for his vessel. The boater, who was traveling at 15 miles per hour, said he had no idea that he was in a 5-m.p.h. no-wake zone, or that his boat registration had expired this April.

title: When Jersey Eyes Are Smiling
description: PUB talk in the United Kingdom gets around to questions about home pretty fast. ''Where is it you're from?'' they say as we order a second pint. If we're in Ireland, where the conversation flows as freely as the tap, the same query might come midway through the first round. On our early journeys we answered ''New Jersey'' easily, but we noticed there was always something, some flicker behind the eyes, as they acknowledged our answer. Television images were playing in their brains and their faces grew sympathetic as they imagined a neighborhood of gangster dumping grounds and turnpike tankers.

title: MUSICAL FLOTATION
description: Boating through the Grand Canyon has become a bit cushier since John Wesley Powell first did it (with only one arm) in 1869. Next month, the Miro String Quartet of New York City will entertain paying rafters on a 10-day, $2,400-a-head raft trip sponsored by the Grand Canyon Music Festival. Quartet members will paddle like everyone else, but they'll also tootle out Beethoven and Smetana during pauses on quiet beaches. Extra rafts will carry the instruments in watertight cases because (darn) there won't be any attempt to play while actually running rapids. ''That way,'' says Allen House, a spokesman with Arizona Raft Adventures, the guide company, ''it won't look like the Beverly Hillbillies are going downstream.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, RAYMOND E.
description: BROWN - Raymond E., S.S. Friends, colleagues and former students lament the untimely death of the distinguished Biblical scholar Raymond E. Brown. The loss is immeasurable; anguish fills our hearts. Joana Battaglia, Myles Bourke, Mary Boys, Veronica Cook, Jerry Anne Dickel, Julie Galas, Beverly Gaventa, Jennifer Glancy, George Landes, David Lotz, Mary Christine O'Connor, Mary Rowe, Sarah Ryan, Robin Scroggs, Robert Seaver, Claudia Setzer, Eileen Tobin, Phyllis Trible, Janet Walton, Millie Weisbart

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/The South Great River, L.I., Neighborhood; Solitude With Parks and a Waterfront
description: THE tiny waterfront neighborhood of South Great River on the South Shore of Long Island has only one main road running through it. Its seclusion is enhanced by parkland, a golf course and both a riverfront and a bayfront. The downtown consists of the post office, a deli and a small Italian restaurant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, THEODORE A.
description: WOLFSON-Theodore A. August 14, 1998. Cherished husband of Toby. Loving and devoted father of Steven and Susan. Beloved grandfather of Samantha, Ilana and David. Also survived by his adoring mother Sarah Wolfson and brother Leslie. Funeral services will be held at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., 11:15 AM Sunday, August 16. Contributions may be made to Achilles Track Club for the Disabled, 42 W. 38 St., NY NY 10018.

title: They Got Game, And Laundry Too; Building a Team With a Whole New Game Plan
description: The 11 women of the New York Liberty have a pregame ritual: in the locker room just before they go out to play a basketball game, they hug -- not an ostentatious public hug of the sort that lots of professional athletes do, but a private, closed-door embrace that speaks more of kinship and sisterhood than of competition and sports. On this particular day in Phoenix -- just before the third game of a grueling five-game road trip, with the team on a four-game losing streak -- the group hug came spontaneously and naturally, says Sue Wicks, the Liberty's 6-foot-3 forward. Something in the team's spirit had been rekindled -- the ritual became a real expression of the players' bonds. And when they charged out onto the court, they won easily.

title: The Useful and the Fanciful, Often in One
description: LOOKING for a way to honor her dog, Needles, in the name of her gallery, Kate Mellina thought of those pointy monuments, Cleopatra's needles, and eventually settled on Cleopatra Steps Out. Despite the roundabout way the name was chosen, it fits because it recalls the romance of ancient times that once permeated Asbury Park.

title: Judgments About Art Involve Many Factors
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Have More Problems to Consider After the Loss
description: There have been few days preseason, regular season, even practices during the Bill Parcells reign -- on which the Jets performed as poorly in so many areas as tonight's 33-0 loss to the Ravens.

title: Ways to Begin Breakfast With Blueberries
description: OF all the abundant berries in season right now, blueberries are the best ones for breakfast. They are easy to add to a bowl of cereal or fold into pancake batter and, because they are delicious with maple syrup, they are excellent to warm with the syrup to top pancakes or waffles.

title: Rikers Island Guards Made 'House of Pain' for Inmates
description: When prisoners entered the special disciplinary ward, they often received ''greeting beatings'' from the guards as a portent of the brutality to come. At other times, jail supervisors ordered assaults on antagonistic inmates, and serious head injuries, bone fractures and perforated eardrums were common. One prisoner died of an avalanche of blows.

title: Woman Is Struck by Car and Dies
description: A 76-year-old Brooklyn woman died late Friday after she was struck by a hit-and-run driver near her home, the police said.

title: Liberties; 1600 Madison Avenue
description: In the new Tommy Hilfiger ad, a luscious young woman with cascading hair, pouty mouth, black leather pants and bare feet is curled on top of the President's desk, casting a come-hither look. The American flag is behind her.

title: Extra Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: On Indian Reservations in the West, Violent Crime Soars
description: The tranquil shore of Wheatfields Lake, a high-country fishing hole set among the ponderosa and sandstone here on the Navajo Reservation, would seem an unlikely place to encounter violence.

title: Crime Drops for Third Year in Row, a National Trend, and Reasons Abound
description: There were those who wanted to take take credit, those who had perfectly fine explanations and others elbowing for a little bit of both.

title: Security Is the Draw At Gated Communities
description: IN medieval times, towns were surrounded by walls for protection. Increasingly, on Long Island, neighborhoods are using gates. And a keeper of the gates.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Although short on quality musicals, the movie line-up on television this week includes an early pulp vehicle for Joan Crawford, a lively scenic adventure and two unusual thrillers.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: THE KURALT APPROACH

description: FLEISHER-Dr. Harold, 76. Of Poughkeepsie, New York. Died on August 13 of leukemia. A pioneer in computers, he retired from a thirty-seven year career at I.B.M. as an I.B.M. Fellow. Professor Emeritus of Physics, S.U.N.Y. New Paltz, he also taught at Vassar and Marist Colleges, both in Poughkeepsie. Dr. Fleisher earned his Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Physics from the University of Rochester, and his Ph.D from Case Western Reserve University. He was the founding President of the Hudson Valley Technology Development Center and a Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Active in civic and Jewish affairs, he was a past President of the Jewish Federation of Dutchess County and a Board member of Temple Beth-El in Poughkeepsie. He is survived by his wife of fifty-two years, Terry, his children, Sherry and Jonathan Woocher, Leslie and Robert Schwartz, and David Fleisher and Melissa Krantz, and his grandchildren, Meredith and Peter, Benjamin, Rebecca, Adam, Jenny, and Sara. Services to be held on Sunday, August 16 at 1:00 P.M., at Temple Beth-El, Poughkeepsie. Contributions to the American Cancer Society or the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICKANS, VIKTORIJA
description: MICKANS-Viktorija. Dentist, psychiatrist, psychoanalyst, artist, Latvian patriot, died peacefully on August 11 in her 81st year. Born March 25, 1917, in Nautreni, Latvia, the daughter of Joachims and Helena (Mugins) Mickans. Her life and work reflected the fate of her beloved country. As a young woman, she graduated from Rezeknes Teacher's College with highest honors. Her intellectual and emotional energies were directed to building a strong and democratic Latvia. During the horrors of the Soviet and Nazi occupations, she continued her work until forced to flee. As a displaced person she came to the realization that her contribution to the general welfare of humanity lay in the study of medicine. Again, under the most difficult of conditions, she completed her dental and medical degrees, graduating from the University of Munich with highest honors. In 1951, she arrived in New York and interned at Greenpoint Hospital, Brooklyn. She completed her residency in psychiatry at Bellevue Hospital. For the next almost four decades, she worked as a staff psychiatrist for the Catholic Charities Guidance Institute; the Bureau of Child Guidance, NYC Board of Education, Psychiatrist, Family Court, NYC; and as a psychoanalyst for the American Institute of Psychoanalysis as well as the Karen Horney Clinic. She was a Fellow of the American Geriatrics Society and of the American Acadmy of Psychoanalysis. Her memberships included the AMA; American Psychiatric Association, Association for the Advancement of Psychoanalysis, the New York Council of Child Psychiatry and the Association for the Advancement of Psychotherapy. Her commitment to Latvia was reflected in her ever generous support of Latvian organizations and philanthropies in the diaspora. Since 1991, her great energies were directed to supporting educational endeavors in the newly free Latvian Republic. A deep religiosity informed her life and work. She is survived by cousins in Latvia, her beloved godson Mikelis Svilans (Ottawa, Canada) and many, many friends. She is lovingly remembered by Dr. Rita D'Angelo and Dr. Astrida I. Butners, who provided care and support in her final difficult year. In Latvian: vieglas smiltis, mila Viktorija. Friends may call Monday, 6-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, Our Saviour R.C. Church, Park Ave. at 38th Street. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Quarters Not Included
description: There are no S.A.T. questions about sorting colors or using bleach, so it is possible - likely, in fact - that many students are heading off to college without knowing much about doing laundry. Caroline Nickle's son had never operated a washing machine in his life when he went off to college from Oklahoma 15 years ago, so she wrote instructions on a laundry bag. His friends kept asking to borrow the bag, and she realized she had had a good idea. A couple of years later, after moving to Bernardsville, she decided to go commercial, producing Mom's Lesson laundry bags. The bags include 11 suggestions, written in a style she describes as ''a little schoolteacherish and a little momish,'' both of which she is. An example: ''Never, never put wet things in the bag unless you are going right to the laundry to wash them.'' The bags, $12.95 plus $2.95 for shipping, are available from Nickle Productions, Post Office Box 73, Bernardsville, N.J. 07942; (908)204-9307.

title: Editorial Observer; The Circle Comes Round at Columbus Circle
description: When it comes to civic amenities, New York City has long known how to squander an opportunity. Take Columbus Circle, the repellent open space at the southwest corner of Central Park. In the 1950's, Robert Moses secured Federal slum clearance funds to raze the rundown theaters, shops and apartments to the west of the circle, only to put up the windowless New York Coliseum, of which Frank Lloyd Wright once observed, ''It's a great utilitarian achievement, but architecture is something else again.''

title: D.J.'s Mixing Turntable Wizardry

Virgil Thomson, writing in 1970 about John Cage's musical innovations, admitted that he felt he was watching ''a one-way tunnel leading only to the gadget fair.'' He probably would have said the same thing about turntablism if he judged only from recorded examples: there continue to be advances, but to what end?

title: The U.S. Will Stand Firm on Iraq, No Matter What

For seven years, we have successfully contained Saddam by maintaining the toughest multilateral sanctions in history, while the United Nations special commission on arms inspections, or Unscom, has managed to destroy much of Saddam's stockpiles of missiles and weapons of mass destruction.

title: A Utopia Awakens and Shakes Itself; Chautauqua, Once a Cultural Haven for Religion Teachers, Survives
description: In 1899, after the philosopher William James visited Chautauqua, the combination arts festival and resort here in southwestern New York, he wrote that he was ''spellbound by the charm and ease of everything, by the middle-class paradise, without a victim, without a blot, without a tear.'' But James said he was astonished on entering ''the dark and wicked world again, to catch myself quite unexpectedly and involuntarily saying: 'Ouf! what a relief! Now for something primordial and savage.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILHAUD, ARSLANIAN, MELVIE
description: MILHAUD - ARSLANIAN - Melvie. A writer and film director, died Thursday, August 13, 1998, at the age of 45, in New York City, following a long illness. She was born in Beirut, Lebanon, to Melancthon and Violette Arslanian, and raised in Antwerp, Belgium, where she had her primary education. She attended the University of Aix En Provence, France, where she received a degree in Philosophy and Letters. She continued her studies at New York University where she received a degree in cinematography. She has been a director and producer of several films including ''Styletto'' and ''Fading'', but her most acclaimed work was ''Above the Waves,'' which was a conversation with her grandmother, Beatrice, who was her role model in life. Ms. Arslanian-Milhaud is survived by her son Arsen; husband David; mother Violette Arslanian; and brothers Ara and Raffi Arslanian. The family will receive visitors on Monday, August 17, at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28th St, New York City, from 7-9 PM. Funeral service will take place at St. Illuminator's Armenian Cathedral, 221 E. 27th St, New York City, on Tuesday, August 18, at 11 AM. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAFFET, WILLIAM B.
description: TAFFET-William B. Age 83, a retired federal immigrations judge, died August 14th of a heart attack at his home in Boca Raton, FL. Judge Taffet graduated from New York University School of Commerce and New York University School of Law with honors. Following his retirement in 1971 from the Department of Justice, he became a partner in the firm of Colwin & Taffet in New York City, specializing in immigration law. Upon moving to Florida, he continued to practice law in that state, serving as a consultant to several international companies in the areas of immigration, naturalization and visas. Judge Taffet was a frequent lecturer at conferences of the American Immigration Lawyers Association and served on its board. He is survived by his wife of 54 years Elizabeth Orkin Taffet of Boca Raton, FL; a daughter Suzanne Taffet Fefer of Rockville, MD; a son Bruce Michael Taffet of Denver, CO; a brother Sanford Taffet of West Orange, NJ, and five grandchildren: Alyssa, Lori, and Will Taffet; and Rachel and Jonathan Fefer. Donations in Judge Taffet's memory can be made to the Henry S. Jacobs Camp, P.O. Box 16528, Jackson, MS 39236.

title: Political Notes; Local Race With a Major TV Budget
description: While candidates for statewide office in next month's Democratic primary have received a good deal of attention for their spending for television advertisements, they are not alone in buying media time. In a more local race, one candidate is planning a television blitz in which he will spend more than any of his opponents have raised for their entire campaigns.

title: Milan C. Kerno, 67, Investment Banker

Shiva will be observed Wednesday and Thursday at 8 PM, at the residence of Cynthia and Harry R. Adler. Contributions in her memory may be made to U.J.A. or to the charity of the donor's choice.

title: Bad Air Days
description: This long, hot summer has produced one of the worst smog seasons in years for the Northeastern United States. It has also been unkind to the lakes and streams in the Adirondacks and other Northeastern forests, which continue to suffer from acid rain. In both cases, there is a common culprit -- windblown pollution that originates in the coal-fired power plants of the Midwest and drifts eastward to poison the air over Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York and New England. But there may be relief on the way, in the form of new anti-smog regulations proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency and a bill introduced by New York's two Senators, Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse D'Amato. Both are under attack from Midwestern governors and Congressmen.

Penncorp, which is based in New York, also said that an investor group that includes the reinsurance company Risk Capital Holdings Inc., based in Greenwich, Conn., would not buy a stake in the company for $75 million, as had been announced last month. Penncorp shares fell $2.875 each, or 24 percent, to $8.75, hitting their lowest level since the company first sold shares to the public in 1992. The company said in February that it expected to get $450 million for the units. It said yesterday that it had cut the value of the units on its books by $140.5 million.

title: MAF BANCORP TO BUY WESTCO FOR $83.4 MILLION IN STOCK
description: MAF Bancorp Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Westco Bancorp Inc. for $84.3 million in stock, as MAF, a community bank, tries to increase its market share and cut costs. MAF, based in Clarendon Hills, Ill., will exchange 1.395 of its shares for each share of Westco, which is based in Westchester, Ill. Based on MAF's closing price on Friday, the transaction is valued at about $30.68 for each Westco share. Westco also gave MAF an option to purchase shares equal to 19.9 percent of its outstanding common stock.

title: Labor Eyes a Prize: Hotels of New Orleans
description: Jacqueline Smith, a 40-year-old hotel maid, knows all too well the hard reality that lies behind this alluring city's tourism boom.

title: WPP Group Reports A Good First Half
description: WPP Group P.L.C., the British advertising company, said yesterday that its first-half pretax profit rose by 19.7 percent, in part because a strong United States economy has led to an increase in advertising spending by United States companies. WPP, the world's second-largest advertising group after Omnicom Group Inc., said its pretax profit rose to $:93.8 million ($152 million) in the first half from $:78.3 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 11.6 percent to $:3.84 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNUBEL, FREDERICK H.
description: KNUBEL-Frederick H. The Faculty, Staff and Alumni of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism mourn the untimely death of Fred Knubel, Class of 1959. We express our sympathy to his widow, Judith Leynse, Class of 1962, and her sons. Fred's quiet dignity spoke volumes on behalf of the University as he told its story and history through his words and photographs. Tom Goldstein, Dean Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism

title: INSIDE
description: Bomb Suspect Questioned

title: Personal Health; Health Scares That Weren't So Scary
description: HOW often has your clock radio awakened you with the distressing news that something you eat, drink, breathe or do has just been shown in a new study to be a serious health hazard? And how often did it turn out to be a false alarm, unsupported by subsequent research?

title: Let's Play 7: Rain Crowds Mets' Crowded Week
description: Turk Wendell trudged into Shea Stadium at 7:30 yesterday morning following a flight from Phoenix to La Guardia Airport and decided the vacant blue sofa in front of his locker was more inviting than driving home to Port Washington, N.Y. The Mets' reliever snoozed in the clubhouse for five hours and woke up feeling slightly refreshed and ready to oppose the Colorado Rockies last night. Too bad for Wendell there was no game. He could have slept longer.

title: Senator's Other Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Enlisting the Viewers' Aid While Observing Daily Life
description: Ann Carlson is as much an adventurer as a performance artist, dancer and choreographer. Her new ''Grass/ Bird/Rodeo,'' performed on Saturday afternoon in the Doris Duke Studio Theater at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here, is predictably enough a journey through real time and memory.

title: As President Testifies, a Subdued Capital Waits for Word
description: It was a typical August day in the capital air heavy with humidity, skies pewter-gray, a thunderstorm in the afternoon, traffic slack. Vacationers' Bermuda shorts outnumbered locals' business suits.

title: Economy Lifts Incomes of Single Black Women Who Head Households
description: Three years ago, Nancy Wright was struggling to hold body and soul and two children together on the $237 she received in her monthly welfare check, supplemented by $187 worth of food stamps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAO, DORA (NEE FANG YAO, HUA)
description: BAO-Dora (nee Fang Yao-Hua). Beloved wife of Sandys Bao, devoted mother of Bette Bao Lord, Cathy Bao Bean, and Jean Bao, caring grandmother of Elizabeth Pillsbury Lord, Winston Bao Lord, and William Bao Bean, died on August 13. A private graveside service was held at Ferncliff Cemetery, Westchester County, NY. Memorial remembrances may be sent to the American Cancer Society, 20 Mercer St, Hackensack, NJ 07601-5600.

title: Disney/ABC Cable Unit Names Chief
description: Anne Sweeney was named president of Disney/ABC Cable Networks yesterday, in an appointment that had been expected since her mentor, Geraldine B. Laybourne, resigned from the position in May. Ms. Sweeney had been executive vice president of the division for two years, reporting to Ms. Laybourne, as well as president of the Disney Channel.

title: Frederick Knubel, 62, Director Of Press Office for Columbia
description: Frederick H. Knubel, director of public information at Columbia University and a spokesman for the university for 35 years, died on Saturday at Southampton Hospital on Long Island after emergency surgery. He was 62 and lived near the campus in Morningside Heights in Manhattan.

title: Liberty's Playoff Plans Put In Question
description: With Isabelle Fijalkowski getting every key rebound and Suzy McConnell Serio coolly directing Cleveland's offense by getting the ball to Michelle Edwards, it was apparent last night that the Liberty had met its match.

title: Stocks Ignore Global Fears, Rising Steeply
description: Wall Street shrugged off Russia's currency devaluation, another decline in Japanese stocks and saturation news coverage of President Clinton's grand jury testimony yesterday, pushing major market indexes higher and helping the Dow Jones industrial average post its largest one-day gain in two months.

title: Madras Journal; Political Melodrama: Don't Cry for Her, Tamil Nadu
description: Among great melodramas about politically powerful women -- the Evitas and Imeldas, the risen and fallen, the adored and despised -- India these days offers Jayalalitha Jayaram, a former movie star whose fickle control over a 27-vote bloc in Parliament threatens to topple the five-month-old Hindu nationalist Government.

title: Credit Rating Is Cut At Mitsubishi Electric
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, a Japanese maker of consumer electronics, chips and nuclear-power equipment, had its long-term and short-term credit ratings cut yesterday by Moody's Investors Service Inc., which cited poor prospects for the company's business performance. Mitsubishi Electric had its long-term debt rating cut to A3 from A2 and its short-term rating cut to Prime-2 from Prime-1, Moody's said in a statement.

title: Jury Finds Lawyer Was Harassed by Her Boss at New Jersey Agency
description: Ending a sexual harassment case that had tarnished the image of New Jersey's most powerful law enforcement agency, a state jury awarded $350,000 today to a former assistant attorney general who said her boss had made inappropriate sexual advances and lewd comments about women in the office and had grabbed her breasts and buttocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, CHRISTOPHER M.
description: SULLIVAN-Christopher M. Words are never enough. The entire staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourns the death of their dear friend, colleague and confidant, Christopher Sullivan. He moved through our complex world with the ease and grace of an international diplomat -assuring each of us that our problem was foremost on his mind. Chris joined the staff of Memorial SloanKettering in 1990 as Manager of Employee Relations. He spent the next eight years enhancing our everyday work lives. He leaves a legacy of appreciation and admiration from thousands of Memorial Sloan-Kettering staff members. Chris will be greatly missed. To his son, Daniel, and to the entire Sullivan family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Paul A. Marks, M.D., President John R. Gunn, Executive Vice President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, AUDREY
description: FARBER-Audrey. On August 16, 1998. Beloved wife of Murray, devoted mother of Sharlene Slutsky, Dodd Farber and the late Andrea Farber. Dear sister of Bernice Hoffman, loving grandmother of Jacqueline, Jason, Adam, Daniella, Alexandra and Colby. Adored great grandmother of Mallory. Services today, 11 AM at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGENBOGEN, MEYER
description: REGENBOGEN-Meyer. Age 87. Of Ellenville, New York, and Hallandale, Florida. On August 15, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Lillian (nee Slutsky). Loving father of Ann Bluestein, Laurie Regenbogen, Victor Regenbogen, Deborah Regenbogen - Pravda. Proud grandfather of seven grandsons, Adam, David, Andrew, Joseph, John, Matthew and Lev. Brother of Gertrude Kozinn. Father-in-law of Irwin Bluestein, Bruce Fleisher, Susan McDonald Regenbogen and Richard Pravda. Services on Monday, August 17, at 2 PM, at Ezrath Israel, Ellenville, New York.

title: Science Watch
description: Safekeeping in the Fridge?

title: Colonial Buys Unit of Rival In Australia Pension Business
description: Colonial Ltd. said today that it would buy the Australian and New Zealand insurance and asset management businesses of the Prudential Corporation of Britain for $800 million (United States), becoming Australia's fourth-largest fund manager.

title: Charges Are Dismissed in Sale Of Art in Parks in New York
description: Charges have been dismissed against three artists arrested for selling art in city parks without a license, as a judge held that city law prevents city agencies from licensing vendors who sell books and other written material.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAMORE, MORTON
description: ZAMORE-Morton. Age 78. On August 16, 1998. Beloved husband to Shirley. Loving and cherished father to Walter, Roslyn and Joe. Stepfather to Judie and Ken Paul, David Cohn, Hank and Fran Cohn. Adored grandfather to all his grandchildren. Devoted brother to Sibby Steiner, Molly, Julie, and Bernard Zamore. A caring uncle to many nieces and nephews. A loyal friend who will be missed by all who had the privilege of knowing him. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave, Bkln (Ave M).

title: TRION TO BE ACQUIRED BY MCLEOD RUSSEL FOR $52 MILLION
description: Trion Inc. said yesterday that it would be acquired by the British-based McLeod Russel Holdings P.L.C. for about $52 million in cash. Owners of Trion stock will receive $7.27 a share. Trion, which makes equipment to improve air quality, including humidifiers and air filters, had 1997 sales of $65 million. McLeod Russel, which has United States and British subsidiaries, said Trion's products would help it expand its air-cleaning business. Shares of Trion, based in Sanford, N.C., jumped 39 percent, gaining $1.875 a share, to $6.625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Not Your Father's Postage Meter; Pitney Bowes Survives Faxes, E-Mail and the Internet
description: Michael J. Critelli well remembers the uncertainty he faced when he became chief executive of Pitney Bowes Inc. two years ago. Investors -- and more than a handful of Pitney insiders -- were worried that faxes would kill regular mail, then E-mail would kill faxes, and finally, all these changes would kill Pitney's profits.

title: Personal Computers; Windows 98 Feature Combines TV, Terminal and the Internet
description: FOR all the recent media noise about the paucity of new features in Windows 98, surprisingly little has been written about WebTV for Windows, an intriguing addition to the operating system that foreshadows both the promise and the growing pains of mixing television with the personal computer.

title: Waning Christianity?
description: To the Editor:

title: Delco in Deals to Shed Marine Engine Units
description: Delco Remy International, a maker of automobile starters and alternators, sold marine-engine assets today as the company, a former General Motors unit, leaves that business to focus on auto parts.

title: Harold J. Ruttenberg, 84, Labor Leader Turned Executive
description: Harold J. Ruttenberg, a research director for the United Steelworkers of America who changed sides, became a business executive and remained outspoken on labor-management issues, died on Saturday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 84.

title: Big Profit Drop For Toys 'R' Us
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said today that earnings before a charge decreased 57 percent in the latest quarter as the company, the world's biggest toy retailer, failed to find a hit product to help it regain sales lost to discount chains. Net income fell 63 percent.

title: President's Strategy: Put Burden On Starr
description: With his admission of an inappropriate relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, President Clinton tonight unveiled a new legal and political strategy that effectively shifted the burden to the special counsel to carry on what Mr. Clinton described as a needless and intrusive enterprise.

title: Foreign Affairs; It's Time
description: It is now clear that President Clinton looked the American people in the eye last January and lied. Yesterday he acknowledged the inappropriate relationship with Monica Lewinsky that he earlier denied. He has betrayed his family, his party and his country. But we now have three stark choices: Impeach him, forgive him or limp along with him, berating him at every step and never allowing anyone to forget what he did. There is no stomach in the country for impeachment. There is too much at stake for the country to limp along for two more years. It's time to forgive -- not for his sake but for ours, not because his affairs are unimportant but because ours are more important.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, NORMAN
description: NEWMAN-Norman. The Board of Directors of Peninsula Counseling Center mourn the untimely death of Norman Newman. His commitment, compassion and wisdom enriched the lives of all who knew him. Martin Zuckerbrod, President Peninsula Counseling Center

title: Revealing Tchaikovsky When Not In Sorrow
description: I can remember standing in my college room staring intently into the black night, while my tape recorder spooled yet again through Tchaikovsky's ''Manfred'' Symphony. Today, no doubt, adolescents find other mirrors for their feelings of frustration and general sense of doom, but earlier generations heard in Tchaikovsky's music a voice that spoke powerfully to them in their youth, until gradually it began to sound like only a memory.

title: For 3 Bus Workers, Diagnosis Is Forgery
description: There was something suspicious about the doctor's note excusing a male city bus driver from work because of bronchitis. For one thing, the word ''adequate'' was spelled wrong. For another, the doctor was a gynecologist.

title: Leaders of Million Youth March Assail Giuliani and Press Ahead
description: Taking another step toward a showdown with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, organizers of a planned Million Youth March in Harlem said yesterday that they would seek a Federal judge's permission for the event but that the march would take place no matter what.

title: GE Capital Buying Metropolitan Life Unit
description: The GE Capital Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the commercial finance division of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. While terms of the deal were not disclosed, the price was estimated at $1 billion.

title: After Dry Spell, a Downpour Washes the Dust Off Umbrellas
description: Woe to those New Yorkers who were so lulled by the recent stretch of hot and rainless summer weather that they had made a habit of leaving their umbrellas at home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICK, SYLVIA G.
description: GLICK-Sylvia G. Cherished wife of Harry and mother of the late Lawrence. Dear sister. Services Wednesday, 2:30 PM at ''Parkside'' Chapel, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, SIMON
description: ABRAHAM-Simon. Husband of Gladys. Father of Vivian and Annette. Grandfather of Lisa, David, Heather, Joshua, Cori. Great grandfather of Andrew, Eric and Michael.

title: Julian Green, an Expatriate American Lionized as a French Literary Figure, Dies at 97
description: Julian Green, the prolific and highly idiosyncratic novelist, playwright and memoirist who was the first American elected to the Academie Francaise, France's gallery of 40 literary luminaries, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 97.

title: U.S. Says Suspect Does Not Admit Role in Bombings or Ties to Saudi
description: Law enforcement officials said today that a key suspect in the bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi had been interviewed at length by American investigators, but had not admitted any role and had not implicated Osama bin Laden, the shadowy Saudi-born extremist thought to have inspired the bombings in Kenya and Tanzania.

title: Even 3 Million Fans May Not Be Enough for the Yankees
description: Though the New York Yankees are on target to draw a record three million fans to their historic home in the Bronx this season, a spokesman for George M. Steinbrenner said yesterday that still may not be good enough to keep his team from moving to Manhattan or New Jersey.

title: Malaysia's No. 1 Bank to Cut Key Rate
description: Malayan Banking, Malaysia's biggest bank, said today that it would cut its key lending rate for the third time in six weeks, to 10.9 percent from 11.4 percent. The cut, effective Tuesday, came 10 days after the previous one.

title: Israel and Palestinians Are Right Not to Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Ericsson in Move To Buy Out Subsidiary
description: Ericsson A.B., the world's No. 3 mobile phone maker, said yesterday that it had offered to buy out the remainder of its Brazilian unit for $640 million in a bid to beef up its presence in its fifth-biggest market. Ericsson offered 37.11 reais per 1,000 Ericsson Telecomunicacoes S.A. preferred shares, representing a 55 percent premium over Friday's close. Phone equipment makers are set to cash in from last month's $19.5 billion sale of Brazil's phone infrastructure because companies will spend $52 billion in the next seven years to build and expand networks. Ericsson, which is focusing more on Latin America than its Finnish rival Nokia Oyj, has won more than $600 million in Brazilian network orders this year.

title: PLUS: HOCKEY -- Rangers; Whitmore Signed As a Backup
description: The Rangers signed the free agent Kay Whitmore yesterday as a possible backup goaltender to Mike Richter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPATT, RENA
description: SPATT-Rena, 104. Widow of the late Dr. Moses Spatt. Beloved mother of Irene and the late Milton. Dearest grandmother of Barney and the late Betty Ann, Hartley and Wendy, Deborah and Harry, Robert and Lisa. Darling great grandmother of Melissa, Martin, Samantha and Mark. ''May we all do so much for so many''. Services were held on August 17, 1998 at ''Boulevard Riverside Chapels,'' Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Brokers Barred for Misusing Clients' Funds
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers barred six brokers from the industry yesterday and fined them a total of $4.8 million for misusing their clients' funds.

title: Campaigns for supplements for that midlife event contend that Mother Nature knows best.
description: AN upstart Australian company hopes to capitalize on two trends -- the aging of female baby boomers and the growing popularity of dietary supplements -- to promote a new herbal treatment for the symptoms of menopause.

description: Following are President Clinton's answers, given on Jan. 17 in a deposition in the Paula Corbin Jones sexual misconduct lawsuit, to questions about his relationship with a former White House intern, Monica S. Lewinsky, who had been subpoenaed by lawyers for Ms. Jones:

title: VERITAS CAPITAL FUND BUYING UNIT OF WORTHINGTON STEEL
description: Veritas Capital Fund L.P. agreed yesterday to acquire the automotive metals unit of Worthington Industries Inc. Terms were not disclosed. The Worthington Precision Metals unit, which had sales of $53 million last year, has 375 employees at plants in Mentor, Ohio, and Franklin, Tenn. Veritas, which is based in New York, agreed in July to acquire PEI Electronics and has also agreed to purchase Republic Engineered Steels Inc. jointly with the Blackstone Group, another investment firm. Worthington, based in Columbus, Ohio, is the nation's largest independent steel processor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORES, JEAN
description: FLORES-Jean. On August 17, 1998. Loving mother of Dajin, devoted daughter of Molly Blatt and the late Bernard. Cherished sister of Martin (Betty) Munson. Adored aunt of Emma. Jean was a dedicated worker for many years at United Nations and most recently in the capacity of Public Relations Specialist for the U.N. Services will be held Wednesday, 12 Noon, at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 312 Coney Island Ave at the Prospect Park Circle, Bklyn N.Y.

title: One by One, the President Told His Closest Aides the Painful Truth
description: Before he addressed the grand jury and then the nation, President Clinton called in some of his closest aides over the weekend, associates said, and one by one, he told them that the accusation they had steadfastly denied for months was true: he had had an improper relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Metro Business; Chain Leases a Flagship
description: Restoration Hardware, a home furnishings chain headquartered in San Francisco, has signed a 15-year lease for 19,000 square feet of space on the ground and lower levels of 935 Broadway in Manhattan.

title: Man Says He Never Hid His Past at Nazi Camp
description: Jack Reimer, the retired businessman who is accused of participating in Nazi atrocities and then concealing his actions to immigrate to the United States, testified yesterday in Federal court that he had never hidden the fact that he had worked in the Trawniki concentration camp in Poland.

title: Ex-Klan Chief Goes on Trial In 1966 Killing
description: Today, for the fifth time in 30 years, a former imperial wizard of the Ku Klux Klan went on trial accused of masterminding a firebombing that killed a black civil rights leader in 1966. This time, prosecutors say they are confident that the jury in Hattiesburg, Miss., will reach a different conclusion from the four that deadlocked in the late 1960's.

title: Letting the Ruble Slide
description: Devaluation and default were steps the Russian Government wanted to avoid for fear they would unleash political unrest and anger foreign lenders. But yesterday the Kremlin took those steps because the alternative -- the collapse of the banks and eventually the economy -- seemed worse.

title: The New Brad Maynard Turns Back the Clock
description: It was January, and Brad Maynard had returned to his home in Indiana. One of the best punters in the history of college football, Maynard could not get the disappointment of his rookie Giants season off his mind.

title: BASEBALL: Home Run Derby Hits Wrigley; Battle Between Familiar Neighbors Has Fans Lining Up
description: Standing in a formidable line at the ticket window outside Wrigley Field this morning was Tim Foil, a Chicago sales representative, who was under as much pressure in his way as Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa have been in theirs.

title: President's Explanation Apparently Fails to Quiet the Republicans or Fire Up the Democrats
description: A number of Republican lawmakers said tonight that they were far from mollified by President Clinton's declaration to the nation that his ''not appropriate'' relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky was now between himself, his family and their God.

title: Gingrich Holding Fund-Raiser In Georgia Today for D'Amato
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has accepted an offer by House Speaker Newt Gingrich to hold a fund-raiser in Georgia on his behalf today, even as Mr. D'Amato's prospective Democratic challengers have sought to hurt him by repeatedly linking him to Mr. Gingrich's policies.

title: Chess; Queens 18-Year-Old Wins U.S. Junior Championship
description: Igor Shliperman won the tiebreak playoff against Michael Mulyar to take the 1998 United States Junior Championship title. The 18-year-old international master from Rego Park, Queens, will be seeded into the 1999 United States Championship.

title: . . . And There Was Whooping and There Was Moshing: The Third Day
description: Everything changed but the site, the hillside where the Woodstock Festival was held in 1969, for the third ''Day in the Garden'' festival show here today. The careful, relatively decorous, professional music of the first two days was replaced by rowdy, noisy, hormonally charged (though equally professional) rock. Onstage and off, people started to jump around. The headliners were current hit makers in their 20's and 30's, not performers who had been established for decades, and the audience had fewer parents and many more teen-agers, including a large contingent of squealing girls for the final band, Third Eye Blind.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: RUBLE DEVALUATION AIDS MARK. Germany's currency partly recovered from last week's selloff on hope that the floating of the ruble would ease the crisis in Russia, a big German debtor. The dollar fell to 1.7946 marks from 1.8014.

title: Small Towns Pay More For Services, Report Says
description: New Jersey's system of home rule costs some residents as much as $500 a year more in property taxes than they would pay under a regional authority, according to a report released yesterday by the Governor's Property Tax Commission.

title: Report Finds Prosecutor Had Conflict of Interest
description: The Passaic County prosecutor was twice involved in a conflict of interest when he failed to turn over to other authorities drug investigations in 1992 and 1995 involving a bar partly owned by one of his investigators, the state Attorney General's office said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVICH, MORRIS
description: DAVICH-Morris. Of Cranbury, NJ, Beloved husband of the late Frances nee Spector. Devoted father of Mitchell and Victor, father-inlaw of Barbara. Loving grandfather of Eric and Arlyn. Services ''Gutterman - Musicant,'' corner Passaic and Park St., Hackensack, on Wednesday at 1:30 PM.

title: 'Swamp Fever' Cases Linked to Triathlon
description: OFFICIALS from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and 42 state health departments are investigating an outbreak of leptospirosis, an infection contracted through exposure to contaminated soil or water, among participants in a Springfield, Ill., triathlon.

title: Senator's Other Legacy; We Need Term Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Sensible Flights of Fantasy
description: In the movable feast that the Mostly Mozart Festival has become this season, there is still much business as usual. Such was the story on Friday evening, when Carlos Kalmar, who was born in Uruguay and lives in Vienna, returned to conduct the Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Cone Wins His 18th And Courts History
description: David Cone is closer to his 50th birthday than to his high school graduation, and lines that did not exist 10 years ago cut across his face and neck when it is hot and he is straining to get outs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN LENTEN, BARRY (BERNARD F. JR.)
description: VAN LENTEN-Barry (Bernard F. Jr.). Your friendship graced by life for more than twenty five years, be it in New York, the Pines, faroff Abidjan. Your wit, fierce intelligence made your writings a treasured gift. Your courage and strength of spirit have been inspirational. ''Who is to say, old friends, How an old friendship survives? One day chums Having a laugh a minute, One day comes And they're a part of your lives.'' Peace be with you, old friend. Lady Cynthia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DYNE, GLADYS
description: VAN DYNE-Gladys. Passed away on August 17, 1998. Beloved mother of Martin, Walter and Paul. Loving mother-in-law of Phyllis and Zobine. Sister to Rose Tager. Dearest grandmother to Joshua, Matthew, Sonia, Alex, David, Steven, Natasha, Goldie and Josef. She was predeceased by her husband Robert. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association. Funeral services private.

title: Sports of The Times; Point Guard Gets Instincts From Home
description: THERE are times when the night job is not all that much different from the day job. Four people want her attention, her assistance, her touch. Suzie McConnell Serio's role is to deliver, no questions asked.

title: Russian Cigarette Plan
description: R. J. Reynolds International said yesterday that it had begun a $120 million expansion of its cigarette production plant in St. Petersburg, Russia. The Swiss-based tobacco operation of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation has already invested $400 million in the plant, which produced 37 billion cigarettes in 1997. After the expansion, the plant will be the company's second largest.

title: Scientist at Work: Dr. James W. Cronin; Looking for a Few Good Particles From Outer Space
description: AT 67, with a great career as a particle physicist and teacher already behind him, Dr. James W. Cronin of the University of Chicago has embarked on a new one as a kind of traveling salesman. He is campaigning in a score of countries for help in building a pair of gigantic cosmic-ray telescopes expected to reveal some tantalizing secrets of the universe.

title: Testimony by Both Clintons and Previous Presidents
description: Following is a list of the times when President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, as well as previous Presidents in the last two decades, have provided testimony. President Clinton is the first President to testify in a criminal investigation of his own conduct, but other Presidents have testified in criminal matters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, CARLTON E., SR.
description: ANDERSON - Carlton E., Sr. Passed away suddenly. Survived by his children, James H. Anderson II, Deborah L. Grove, Diana A. Yeisley, Carlton E. Anderson II, and grandson, James H. Anderson III. Memorial services Wednesday, 5 PM at the Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Trinity Church.

title: A Democrat, but an F.O.G. (as in George)
description: When Gov. George W. Bush of Texas was, by his own admission, the party-animal-like president of his Yale fraternity, Roland Betts was his rush chairman. When Mr. Bush needed a political launching pad, Mr. Betts helped buy the Texas Rangers and set Mr. Bush up as managing partner. And now that Mr. Bush, a Republican, is expected to run for President, Mr. Betts is warming up as his unofficial finance chairman and head cheerleader in New York.

title: Last Night's Address
description: Following is the statement President Clinton made last night after testifying by closed-circuit television to a grand jury, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Corrections
description: Two pictures yesterday with a front-page article about Americans who buy surplus military jets from former Soviet-bloc countries carried incorrect credits. They were by Tracie Rozhon of The New York Times.

title: Things Change Rallies to Win Adirondack
description: A gray filly named Things Change showed today just how much things can change for 2-year-old horses trying to make the big leagues of racing at Saratoga.

title: Speech Deepens Split Over Clinton's Actions
description: Lisa Wessels describes herself as ''pro-Clinton'' and Scot Baker says he is ''anti-Clinton,'' opposed points of view that have not prevented the Seattle couple from planning to marry. And when the two, both 30 years old, met after work this evening and watched President Clinton admit a ''not appropriate'' relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, both chose the same word to describe the televised address: ''Embarrassing.''

title: President Decision Before One On Coach
description: Coach Bruce Arena, who guided D.C. United to the Concacaf Champions Cup on Sunday, only added more credibility to his chances of becoming coach of the United States national team.

title: CLINTON ADMITS LEWINSKY LIAISON TO JURY; TELLS NATION 'IT WAS WRONG,' BUT PRIVATE
description: Saying that he had misled his wife and the public, President Clinton admitted in a solemn and grim-faced address tonight that he had had an intimate relationship at the White House with an intern. He also acknowledged the relationship in testimony to a Federal grand jury.

title: The Mayor's Crusade Against Methadone
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's drive against methadone maintenance programs for heroin addicts ignores the most authoritative medical advice and could lead to more suffering among those struggling to control their addiction. The Giuliani administration cannot shut down most of the 36,000 state and federally funded methadone treatment slots in New York City. But Mr. Giuliani says he will end methadone maintenance for the limited population that he can directly control -- the roughly 2,000 people in public hospitals who receive the treatment. The new policy may also be applied to addicted inmates in city jails.

title: Treasuries End the Day Mixed Amid Russia and Japan Fears
description: Treasury bond prices ended slightly lower yesterday, while shorter maturities edged higher, as investors grew more concerned about the economies of Russia and Japan.

title: Mediator Failed to Sway Iraq on Arms, Security Council Is Told
description: The United Nations told the Security Council today that its mediator in Iraq had failed to persuade Baghdad to resume cooperation with the two agencies trying to find and eliminate its weapons of mass destruction, diplomats and other officials said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 10 about the hijacking of a plane in Congo to transport rebels to open a new front against the Government referred incorrectly in some editions to the route taken. The plane flew from a rebel-held area in the east to the western part of the country, not from west to east.

title: Still Playing Key Role On a Most Painful Day
description: The lawyer whose guidance and support has mattered most in the President's career -- his wife -- was not by his side when Mr. Clinton made his televised address to the nation tonight nor was she part of the legal team advising the President earlier today in the White House Map Room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEW, RALPH H.
description: CHEW-Ralph H. Of Greenwich Village, NY. Tireless friend and gifted thinker, loving partner of Denise, adored father of Sally, Katherine, and Atu, died on August 2, 1998 at 70. A dominant figure in the export trade as President of Chew International Group and NEXCO. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to Common Cause, The North Shore Animal League, or friends of Washington Square Park. A Memorial Service will be held Friday, August 21st. at noon at 12 West 12 St. NYC

title: N.H.L. Is Close To $600 Million Deal
description: The National Hockey League said yesterday that it was wrapping up a new five-year, $600 million deal with ABC and ESPN that will start in the 1999-2000 season.

title: Jim Murray, 78, Sportswriter And Winner of Pulitzer Prize
description: Jim Murray, whose humorous, vinegary and graceful columns for The Los Angeles Times made him one of only four sportswriters to win the Pulitzer Prize for general commentary, died Sunday of cardiac arrest at his home in Los Angeles, the newspaper reported. He was 78.
