title: Levi Sells 25 Outlets
description: Designs Inc., the operator of 121 retail clothing stores, will buy 25 outlet stores from Levi's Only Stores Inc., a unit of Levi Strauss & Company, for about $12 million as Designs moves to eliminate its Boston Traders brand and concentrate on name brands. The purchase consists of 16 Dockers outlet stores and 9 Levi's outlet stores in the Eastern United States.

title: Congo Rebels Cut Power and Water Again
description: Rebels again cut electricity and water to this capital of five million people today, heightening fears about an imminent attack. As the threat intensified, support for President Laurent Kabila apparently grew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, EDITH
description: WARD-Edith. On Aug. 16, of Mahwah, NJ formerly of New York City and Palisades, NY. Formerly with The Center on Transnational Corporations of The United Nations. Survived by her husband, Ben and her brother, Gerald Halpern. Services are today, 11:30am, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Ammirati Executive Announces Departure
description: Duncan Pollack, a longtime top executive at Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York, said yesterday that he had resigned.

title: Inland Steel Plans to Repurchase Shares
description: Inland Steel Industries Inc. said today that it expected to repurchase common shares for $30 each, the low end of its projected range of $30 to $34, to distribute proceeds from the recent $1.4 billion sale of its steel unit to Ispat International N.V.

title: McKesson-Arrow Deal
description: The McKesson Corporation, a drug wholesaler, announced today that it would be the primary supplier of pharmaceuticals to the Arrow Corporation's 68 prescription centers, in a five-year deal worth $500 million. Arrow, based in Farmington, Conn., is a closely held pharmacy company with sales of $90 million last year. McKesson, based in San Francisco, will provide services and technologies to increase Arrow's return on assets and reduce its costs, the company said.

title: Metro Business; Floor of Office Space Fills Needs of Gap
description: Gap Inc., the clothing retailer, has leased the entire fourth floor, about 10,500 square feet, of 680 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan for its public relations department.

title: Israel and Palestinians Are Right Not to Trust

title: Executive Changes
description: COLT'S MANUFACTURING CO., Hartford, said Steven M. Sliwa would be the new president and chief executive. Mr. Sliwa recently stepped down as president of Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in Daytona Beach, Fla. He replaces Ronald Stewart, who resigned.

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE TO SELL ALASKA OPERATIONS
description: Century Telephone Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its operations in Alaska for $415 million in cash. Century Telephone said the buyers -- Fox Paine & Company, an investment fund company based in Foster City, Calif., and former executives of Pacific Telecom Inc. -- would also assume $43 million in debt. Pacific Telecom Inc., a unit of the electricity company Pacificorp of Portland, Ore., was purchased in December by Century Telephone for $1.5 billion and the assumption of $725 million in debt. Century Telephone, based in Monroe, La., said it would use the proceeds from the sale to reduce debt and to finance its acquisition of telephone access lines in Wisconsin from the Ameritech Corporation. Its shares rose 56.25 cents each, to $49.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIBBON, JAMES JOSEPH
description: GRIBBON-James Joseph. Artist and musician. Died peacefully at home on August 13, 1998, after a long battle with cancer. Jimmy will be remembered by his many friends for his talents in art and his accomplishments on a variety of instruments in many areas of jazz. One of the founding members of The Grove Street Stompers, he played cornet at Arthur's Tavern in Greenwich Village for over thirty years. He also played on a regular basis with The Gotham Jazzmen and was featured often with other groups in the area. His work as a graphic artist, where he received considerable recognition in his field, will live on after him. His warmth and his caring nature touched all who knew him. He will not be forgotten. He is survived by his wife, June Cora, his son, James Joseph Jr, his four daughters, Catherine, Elizabeth, Martine and Wendy; eight grandchildren, and his brother, Charles. Funeral service will take place at Christ Evangelical Lutheran Church at 337 Farview Avenue, Paramus, New Jersey, on Thursday, August 20, 1998 at 11:30am. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Hospice Program, 30 Prospect Avenue, Hackensack, New Jersey 07601. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Tailoring A Healthy Message To Blacks
description: COMPARED with whites, black Americans have higher death rates from all kinds of serious illnesses -- from heart disease, diabetes, stroke, some forms of cancer and asthma. Black babies are more likely to be born small and die in their first year, and black adults live fewer years than their white counterparts.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS RISES 8.7 PERCENT. Prices surged after a Midwest heat wave raised speculation that electricity producers would need more gas. The September contract rose 16.4 cents, to $2.041 per thousand cubic feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOVANOVIC, CORNELIA JUDITH (JUDY) LAURENTIA
description: JOVANOVIC-Cornelia Judith (Judy) Laurentia. In Windsor, Ontario (formerly of Bailey's Bay, Bermuda). On August 14, 1998 in her 40th year. Beloved wife of George and loving mother of Thea and Nicholas. She is survived by her loving mother Johanna Thyssen, brother Peter, sister Laurie Jacobs, brother-in-law Douglas, nieces Sara, Ellen and Cecile and mother-in-law Teodora, all of Windsor, ON., sister Lisa of Exeter, ON, brother-in-law Michael, his wife Jasmine Ritch, nieces Camille and Heather Jovanovic of Burlington, ON as well as many uncles, aunts and cousins in The Netherlands and London, ON. Pre-deceased by her father, the late Antonie Thyssen (1985). Friends may call at the Anderson Funeral Home, 895 Ouellette Ave., Windsor, Tel: 519-254-3223 on August 19th and 20th from 7:00 -9:00 p.m. Mrs. Jovanovic will rest at ''Grachanica'', the Serbian Eastern Orthodox Church, 1960 Meldrum Rd., Windsor on August 21 from 9:00 a.m. Funeral service at 10:00 a.m. Interment to follow at Heavenly Rest Cemetery, 5005 Howard Ave., LaSalle, ON. Memorial contributions may be sent to Weill Medical College of Cornell University, 1300 York Ave. C606, New York, N.Y. 10021, attn. Martee L. Hensley, MD, Assistant Professor of Medicine, payable to ''Cornell University, Division of Hematology/Oncology'' or Friends of the Centre, c/o Windsor Regional Cancer Centre, 2220 Kildare Rd., Windsor, ON N8W 2X3 payable to ''the Cancer Centre Campaign'' or The Bermuda National Trust, Hamilton, Bermuda or Patients Assistance League Service (P.A.L.S.), Devonshire, Bermuda or a charity of your choice.

Gertrude Parker, State Committee Member

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health page in Science Times today about health education for black Americans appears without its last line in some copies. The affected sentence, quoting Dr. Reed V. Tuckson on the need for accountability, should read, ''The bottom line is: are people surviving?''

title: Healthy Davis Takes Turn in Torre's Lineup
description: Chili Davis strolled into the Yankees' clubhouse shortly after 5 P.M. today, a bag in hand, his rehabilitation of an ankle injury complete after more than four months. Joe Torre, the Yankees' manager, told him he could play if he wanted, and Davis was in the starting lineup, batting third and serving as the designated hitter.

title: Shedding New Light on the Milky Way's Halo of Darkness
description: AMERICAN and Australian astronomers have found more evidence of dark objects apparently scattered throughout the fringes of the Milky Way, and they say this could solve the mystery of the dark matter that is unseen and accounts for most of the mass in Earth's galaxy.

title: Balloonist to Take It Easy After Stormy Crash at Sea
description: AFTER barely escaping death in the crash of his balloon at sea, Steve Fossett relaxed aboard a rescue ship in the South Pacific yesterday, saying that he planned ''to sit back and smell the roses for a while.''

title: Q&A
description: Seeing Stars

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, JOSEPH
description: BLUM - Joseph. Congregaton Adereth El mourns the passing of our esteemed member Joseph Blum and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Rose Marie, to his sons Robert and Steve who served as Vice President of our Congregation for many years, to his grandchildren, to all his relatives and many loving friends. Rabbi Sidney Kleiman Joseph Greene, President

title: Herman Revue to Close
description: ''An Evening With Jerry Herman,'' a musical revue starring Mr. Herman, the composer, along with Lee Roy Reams and Florence Lacey, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, Manhattan. The show will have run for 28 regular performances and 13 previews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTTERFIELD, HARVEY DEAN
description: BUTTERFIELD - Harvey Dean, the sixth Episcopal Bishop of Vermont, died on August 10th in Burlington. Bishop Butterfield was born in 1908, he graduated from the University of Vermont in 1931, and the General Theological Seminary in 1934. He married Carolyn Whitney in 1934. Rt. Reverend Butterfield is survived by his two children, Whitney Butterfield and Deborah Galbraith. A memorial service will be held at The Cathedral Church of St. Paul in Burlington on August 22, 1998 at 10:00am.

title: Spelling Agrees to Sell Westwood Studios
description: Spelling Entertainment Group Inc. has signed a definitive agreement to sell all of the stock of Westwood Studios, a unit of Virgin Interactive Entertainment Ltd., and other development assets to Electronic Arts Inc. for $122.5 million.

title: RUSSIA ACTS TO FIX SINKING FINANCES
description: The Russian Government moved hastily today to avert financial collapse with a series of drastic measures, including delaying payments for 90 days on foreign debt owed mostly by banks, restructuring Government bonds and sacrificing the ruble to market forces.

title: Where Promoter Goes, Big Names Fall in Step
description: As a promoter, Butch Buchholz is known to be particularly persuasive. That has been evidenced by the strong fields he traditionally attracts every March to his Lipton Championships in Florida, a combined men's and women's event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARING, ROBERT OSCAR
description: WARING-Robert Oscar. On August 16, 1998, age 75. Beloved husband of Celia, devoted father of Russell and Allan, father-in-law of Laurie and Janice, loving grand father of Justin, Julian and Courtney, dear brother of Jerome Weinberg. Services Tuesday, August 18, 12 noon, at ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: BOYKIN PLANS SALE OF HOTELS AND A BUYBACK OF SHARES
description: The Boykin Lodging Company said yesterday that it would sell some hotels it did not consider essential as it raises money to retire debt and that it would buy back as many as one million shares, or about 6 percent of its outstanding shares. Boykin, a Cleveland-based real estate investment trust that owns 31 hotels, also hired Chadwick, Saylor & Company for advice on raising money from private sources. Boykin is selling hotels after announcing last month that it would slow its pace of acquisitions. The company, which has bought 13 hotels this year, said in July that hotels were now overpriced. Boykin's hotels are mostly upscale or resort properties operated under such brands as Red Lion, Doubletree and Marriott.

title: Beijing Students and Women, Defying Ban, Protest Anti-Chinese Violence in Indonesia
description: Defying a ban by Government officials, students and women's groups held emotional protests today over the looting, killing and rape directed against ethnic Chinese during riots in Indonesia in May.

title: SCHOOL SPECIALTY PURCHASES ITS RIVAL BECKLEY-CARDY
description: School Specialty Inc. acquired a rival, the closely held Beckley-Cardy Group, yesterday for about $76 million in cash, expanding its business in the South and Southwest. School Specialty, an educational supply company based in Appleton, Wis., also assumed Beckley's credit facilities, valued at about $60 million. Beckley, based in Mansfield, Ohio, had sales of about $176 million in its 1998 fiscal year. The acquisition expands the company's presence in California, Florida and Texas, the company said. School Specialty's stock jumped $2.9375 a share, or 26 percent, to $14, in Nasdaq trading.

title: After Wait of Six Months, Sun Shines for Mickelson
description: It took Phil Mickelson more than six months to win the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am. But for a $450,000 first-place check, plus a $100,000 bonus for being the PGA Tour's top money-winner on the West Coast this year, it was worth the wait.

title: CUNY Injunction Restored
description: An Appellate Division judge yesterday reinstated an injunction barring the City University of New York from proceeding with preparations for a ban on remedial classes at its senior colleges in September 1999.

title: Fed Approves Huge Bank Deal
description: The $57 billion acquisition of BankAmerica by Nationsbank won approval today from the Federal Reserve, clearing the way for them to join forces and become the largest United States banking company.

title: Apology and Defiance Echo a Nixon Address
description: Bill Clinton looked exhausted and sounded as defiant as a regretful man could in his four-minute speech last night. It was not the familiar, soulful Bill Clinton who turned up, not the one who knows how to look a camera in the eye, but someone who seemed far more reluctant. But every poll in the last week told the President that he had to make this speech, and he appeared as uncomfortable as if the American people had subpoenaed him.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHYMATRIX CORP., West Palm Beach, Fla., a provider of management services to the medical community, said it would divest itself of its core physician-practice management business to concentrate on management of sites of clinical research trials. The company also wants to leave its diagnostic imaging and home therapy businesses.

title: Society Organizes to Make a Case for Humans on Mars
description: BRIAN BARNWELL has a nose for historical events. In 1955, he attended the splashy opening of Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif. In 1969, he visited Florida to witness the launching of Apollo 11, which sent men to land on the Moon.

title: Arts in America; Toting Chamber Music to Some Unexpected Chambers
description: As the headlands and mountains of Mount Desert Island merged behind them in a distant summer haze, 16 young musicians from the Kneisel Hall Chamber Music School and Festival disembarked here from a ferry boat ride across the harbor for the group's second annual invasion of the island.

title: Solutions or Impossibilities?  HIV Prevention for African Children
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Officials Protest Transfer Of Man Who Killed Officers
description: A 60-year-old convict serving a life sentence for murdering two New Jersey police officers in 1963 was moved today from a state prison to a minimum-security treatment center, touching off a protest by Bergen County politicians and law enforcement officials.

title: TENNIS: A Hidden Threat in Tennis; Teen-Ager's Case Points Out Over-the-Counter Access to Steroids
description: When Samantha Reeves, a well-regarded amateur finding her way through her freshman season on the women's professional tennis circuit, wanted to hustle herself back into shape after sustaining an ankle injury late in 1997, she said she decided to experiment with a newfangled ''all-natural'' dietary supplement, apparently on the recommendation of a friend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALM, MICHAEL
description: PALM-Michael. New York City Opera deeply mourns the passing of Michael Palm. As Co-Chairman of our 1998 Opening Night Gala celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Declaration of Human Rights, Michael shared with us his compassion, generosity and love of music. We extend our deepest sympathies to his many friends and family. Paul Kellogg, General Director

title: Thistle's Stock Plunges As Talk of Sale Ends
description: Shares in Thistle Hotels P.L.C., Britain's third-largest hotel operator, fell yesterday by more than 23 percent after Brierley Investments Ltd. of New Zealand, its partial owner, said talks to sell the company had broken off. Brierley said that the Thistle board had been in discussions with an unnamed buyer but that the talks had ended after the buyer put forth an unacceptable proposal.

title: Accounts
description: * Kodak Polychrome Graphics, Norwalk, Conn., a joint venture between Eastman Kodak Co. and Sun Chemical, to Eric Mower & Associates, Syracuse, to handle its account, which had been handled by Saatchi & Saatchi, New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. Other Mower offices in Albany, Buffalo and Rochester will also service the account. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million.

title: GAINSCO BUYING LALANDE GROUP TO EXPAND AUTO COVERAGE
description: Gainsco Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Lalande Group for as much as $40 million, adding high-risk-driver insurance to its auto-coverage business. Gainsco, a commercial auto and garage insurer based in Fort Worth, will pay $18 million in cash for the Miami-based Lalande; it said it would pay as much as $22 million more depending on Lalande's profits over a five-year period. One Lalande division covers nonstandard drivers; another unit provides claims adjustment to third parties.

title: SCATHING AND SAD, DEMOCRATS REACT TO CLINTON SPEECH
description: Prominent Democrats around the country, including some of President Clinton's most loyal supporters, starkly distanced themselves from the President today and expressed deep personal disappointment with his behavior, as well as political anxiety about the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENKOWER, RABBI MURRY
description: PENKOWER-Rabbi Murry. AMIT is deeply saddened by the passing of the beloved husband of our esteemed national JNS representative and national board member, Lillian S. Penkower. A revered rabbinical and Jewish communal leader, Rabbi Penkower was dedicated to the advancement of Torah and religious Zionism and was a proud supporter of our AMIT children in Israel. Heartfelt condolences to his devoted wife, daughters, sons and family. Evelyn Blachor, National Pres. Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN LENTEN, BARRY (BERNARD F. JR.)
description: VAN LENTEN-Barry (Bernard F. Jr.). Your friendship graced my life for more than twenty-five years, be it in New York, the Pines, far-off Abidjan. Your wit, fierce intelligence made your writings a treasured gift. Your courage and strength of spirit have been inspirational. ''Who is to say, old friends, How an old friendship survives? One day chums Having a laugh a minute, One day comes And they're a part of your lives.'' Peace be with you, old friend. Lady Cynthia

title: Minority Students Scoring Higher on A.C.T. Tests
description: More minority students took the A.C.T. college entrance examination this year and improved their scores slightly in the process, according to data released yesterday by A.C.T. Inc., one of the two major nonprofit organizations that offer college entrance tests.

title: Stain Of the Nation
description: It was probably too much to hope that the first line of President Clinton's address to the nation would be: ''Thank you for tuning in to my Presidential dialogue on race.''

title: Test Kitchen; A Whirling Dervish That Dips Right Into Your Pot
description: SOMEONE who hates washing dishes must have conceived the idea for the immersion blender. Bringing the blender to the pot rather than transferring the pot's contents into the blender saves a lot of dishes. No wonder immersion blenders have been a hit with home cooks over the last 10 years -- once we discovered that pumpkin soup could be thinned to a silky puree right in the pot there was no going back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, SYLVIA
description: GROSSMAN-Sylvia. Beloved by friends. Died in Mississauga, Ontario, Canada on Sunday, August 9, 1998. title: How To Tame Your Pushy Zucchini: Make Soup
description: ZUCCHINI is the vegetable that doesn't know when to stop. A backyard zucchini crop at this time of year can grow from merely abundant to brazen, overtaking the garden and leaving the gardener with more zucchini than anyone could ever need.

title: EMERGING COMMUNICATIONS CHAIRMAN RAISES BUYOUT BID
description: The chairman of Emerging Communications Inc., Jeffrey Prosser, offered yesterday to buy the 48 percent of the company that he does not already own for $10.25 a share, or $54.9 million. Mr. Prosser offered $9.13 a share in May, but a group of holders sued to block the transaction, saying his offer was too low. Emerging, which was spun off from Atlantic Tele-Network Inc. in December, provides local phone services on the United States Virgin Islands of St. John, St. Thomas and St. Croix and wireless services on St. Martin. Emerging's shares rose $1.625 yesterday, or 19 percent, to $9.9375. Mr. Prosser will own Emerging through his wholly owned company, the Innovative Communication Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAULIN, BENJAMIN
description: PAULIN-Benjamin. Beloved husband of Alice, devoted father of Amy, Louise Weintraub, Shari Thomson, and Gail Fazio, dear brother and loving grandfather. Services today 11 A.M. ''Parkside Chapels'' Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SEYMOUR

Cherished grandfather of Peter, Seth, Eric, Bari, Samantha and Lindsay. Retired President of River Bank Motors Corp. Reposing Thursday 7-9pm at Gallagher Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, Conn. Graveside service at 10:30am Friday at Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Tampering With Hopper's Iconic Beacon
description: Even on a warm, sunny August day, the view of Two Lights Lighthouse here is, well, Hopperesque. Scenic but somehow forlorn, frozen in a long-ago time, the lighthouse evokes the sense of isolation inherent in so many Edward Hopper paintings. Little wonder that ''Lighthouse at Two Lights,'' one of three major paintings and several watercolors he made of the scene, hangs in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was made into a popular museum poster and was reproduced on the six-cent postage stamp marking Maine's sesquicentennial as a state in 1970.

title: Can the President, and Country, Now Move On?; Wasted Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLUCCI, DR. TOMMASO
description: COLUCCI-Dr. Tommaso. The New York Republican County Committee extends condolences to the family of its Vice President and dear friend Tommaso Colucci. His loyal and staunch support will always be remembered. Senator Roy M. Goodman, Chairman

title: Gore, a Loyalist, Stands Steps Away
description: While many Americans spent a good part of the day mulling over President Clinton's speech acknowledging his relationship with a White House intern, Vice President Al Gore did his best today to continue avoiding the subject.

title: Hopscotching From Hilarity to Mourning, With Groundlings in Thrall
description: If it's not in ''Pericles,'' maybe it isn't possible in theater. This wonderful old bag of tricks has everything -- murder, kidnapping, drowning, lost children, resurrections, political intrigue, divine vengeance, a bordello redeemed by a virgin, admired rulers whose sex lives would arch Satan's eyebrow, pimps, homicidal jealousy, labor induced by a hurricane, birth onstage and eternal love. The opening scene portrays father-daughter incest so vividly that television would have to warn you to shield your children from it. What a play!

title: The Claw and Shell Guide To Crabs From Maine to Japan
description: ONLY a few members of the world's vast crab family make it to the American dinner table. Crabs must be bought live, cooked or frozen. Following is a guide to most of the varieties on the market.

title: Man Is Found Stabbed to Death In Greenwich Village Apartment
description: In the second killing in Greenwich Village in less than a week, a man was found stabbed to death in his apartment yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDERMOTT, JOSEPH
description: McDERMOTT-Joseph. Of Cresskill on Aug. 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Ellen (nee Stuart). Devoted father of Thomas and Brian. Dear brother of Kathleen. Dear son-in-law of Wallace J. Stuart. Age 57, President & Owner of Composites Services Corp. of Cresskill, NJ. Member of St. Therese's Church, Cresskill. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, on Wed, 3 to 5 & 7 to 9PM. Funeral Mass, Thursday, 9:30AM St. Therese's Church, Cresskill. Memorials to Fordham University Scholarship Fund or Appalachian Trail Conference appreciated.

title: In 1997, AIDS-Related Deaths In Prison Fell to 14-Year Low
description: The number of AIDS-related deaths among New York State's prison population hit a 14-year low last year, according to a report released today by the state's Department of Correctional Services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRON, ARTHUR
description: CITRON-Arthur. Beloved husband of the late Judith. Dear father of Joel and daughter-in-law Linda. Devoted grandfather of David and Steven. Adored great grandfather of Courtney and Mariah. Loving brother-in-law and uncle.

title: Intervention Props Up Hong Kong Stocks
description: Hong Kong stocks were rising today after ending slightly lower on Tuesday as the market was shored up again by purchases by the Government.

title: Mendoza And Irabu Out With Injuries
description: Ramiro Mendoza figured to be the backup plan in the event Hideki Irabu's sore left foot prevented him from making his scheduled start Thursday. As it turns out, ailments will prevent both Mendoza and Irabu from pitching.

title: Heinz Expands Ties With DDB Needham
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said yesterday that it would expand its relationship with the DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group by naming DDB Needham San Francisco to handle the account of the Smart Ones line of frozen entrees and desserts sold by the Weight Watchers Gourmet Food Company. Billings on the account, handled for a year by Jordan McGrath Case & Partners in New York, were estimated at $8 million to $10 million.

title: The Chef
description: A FEW years ago, needing some days of fishing to clear my head, I took my wife, Lisa, and our eldest son, Court, to the San Juan Islands off the coast of Washington. This part of America has some of the world's most spectacular natural scenery, with a series of pristine, forested islands dotting the tranquil waters of Puget Sound. We stayed in a small cabin on Orcas Island, where I'd heard that the salmon fishing would be stupendous. It was.

title: Clinton Wanted to Tell, Dick Morris Says
description: The way Dick Morris recalls that fateful Wednesday, Jan. 21, President Clinton seemed to want to tell the country right away that he had made a mistake with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: About New York; A Portrait Of Pride And Paunches
description: THE cobblestone streets around Jessie Nebraska Gifford's Vinegar Hill home are a no man's land of truckers and intrepid artists -- of both the visual and stickup kind. This little neighborhood, bordered by housing projects, the waterfront and the Brooklyn Navy Yard, makes her feel isolated sometimes. But at least she had the company of several nude men waiting to be framed.

description: UNITED HEALTHCARE CORP., -- Minnetonka, Minn., a provider of health care coverage, is resuming its share repurchase program after the collapse of its plan to acquire Humana Inc., Louisville, Ky. United can buy back about $555 million of stock, based on Monday's closing price.

title: Otto Wichterle, 84, Chemist Who Made First Soft Contacts
description: Otto Wichterle, a Czechoslovak chemist who in 1961 used an Erector set and a phonograph to produce the world's first soft contact lenses, died yesterday at his summer home in Sdradisko, a Moravian village in the Czech Republic. Dr. Wichterle, a former president of that nation's Academy of Sciences, was 84 years old.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Managers of Russian Funds Are Left Guessing
description: For the second time in a year, mutual funds that invest in emerging markets have been snared in a foreign financial crisis. And once again, their managers are trying to value securities for which there is little or, in some cases, no real market.

title: Colombian Rebels Broaden Offensive With Attacks on Symbols of U.S. War Against Coca
description: As leftist rebels occupied Albert Schweitzer Hospital in the city of Miraflores 10 days ago, using it as a vantage point to attack a military base across the street, explosions and gunfire rained over the corrugated-tin roof of the hospital. A plane dropped bombs in the distance. Outside teen-agers fell dead and wounded.

title: Wine Talk; Delighting in a Remote Corner of France
description: THE French call this western Mediterranean corner of their country the last frontier. It is a vast expanse of arid, inhospitable land in southern France bounded by this city, the city of Carcassonne and the Spanish border. In the back country leading up into the Pyrenees and in some former fishing villages along the coast, the old people still speak Catalan, which has been described as the language of the Roman foot soldier.

description: ACHESON

title: Procter & Gamble calls Internet marketing executives to Cincinnati for a summit meeting.
description: AN advertising behemoth is gathering hundreds of executives for a one-of-a-kind conference with an ambitious goal: improving the Internet as a marketing medium by hastening the discovery of solutions to the panoply of problems that now vex cyberpeddlers.

title: Foundation Pledges $110 Million for Public Schools in Idaho
description: The Albertson Foundation, a $1 billion family-run charitable trust, has announced a three-year pledge to award $110 million in grants to public schools in Idaho.

description: Chad Curtis has been hitting so badly of late, Yankee Manager Joe Torre said before tonight's game that ''we need a Hoover vacuum cleaner'' to clean out Curtis's swing ''and start over.''

title: Rome Journal; The Pope and TV's 'Indelicate' Need for Planning
description: Death, unlike taxes, is still certain in Italy. Even Popes must someday die. And when the Pope is as towering a figure as John Paul II, there is one other certainty: every major television news organization will someday need a room with a view.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWIRTH, SAMUEL A.
description: NEWIRTH-Samuel A. Age 90. On August 18 at Calvary Hospital. Born in Poland and raised in Koln, Germany. He came to the United States in 1936 where he established an international reputation as a scrap metals expert and publisher of a highly respected newsletter on the subject. He is survived by his daughter, Wendy, son Charles and three grandchildren, Casey, Willy and Emma and sisters, Martha and Sophie. Services on Thursday 11:30am at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Despite Meola Ban, MetroStars Gain
description: With Tony Meola, their goalkeeper, captain and spiritual leader, serving a one-game suspension by the league, the MetroStars still managed to come up with an inspired performance tonight in a 4-1 victory over the Colorado Rapids at Giants Stadium.

title: Woman Is Said to Rob The Same Bank Twice
description: A woman who robbed the same bank twice in four days was caught yesterday in Sayreville, a day after bailing her husband out of jail with the stolen money, the Union County prosecutor said.

title: In Umbrage and Admission, It Was Vintage Bill Clinton
description: It was just over four minutes long, barely 500 words, the shortest big speech of Bill Clinton's Presidency. It had to satisfy the President's lawyers, his public and his wife, and it came together only after a grueling day of testimony to a Federal grand jury and frantic final tinkering.

description: Prices of Treasury securities ended slightly lower yesterday.

title: Few Successes to Back Mayor's Methadone Limits
description: It took Diana, a 34-year-old recovering heroin addict from the Bronx, exactly 95 days to wean herself from methadone at a residential clinic on Manhattan's Lower East Side last year. ''I counted every day,'' she says. ''On Dec. 8, they announced I was drug free. It was the greatest feeling in my life.''

title: Beyond Satire, With Daring Feats
description: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo sold out well in advance of its weeklong Joyce Theater season, which opened on Monday night. (An extra show has been added for Sunday night.) The final curtain calls on Monday brought to mind the kind of ecstatic response that once regularly greeted ballet companies performing at the Metropolitan Opera House. All this for a company of comical male ballerinas?

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to East End Hospice, 1111 Riverhead Road, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978, or your favorite charity.

title: Character Rating Sinks, Raising Questions About Ability to Lead Nation : 'I Misled People; I Deeply Regret That'
description: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton's televised admission of an inappropriate relationship with Monica Lewinsky brought a sharply critical response Tuesday from some Republicans and a sharp decline in the public's opinion of his character. But it left unanswered questions about the extent to which his ability to lead the nation has been compromised and where the investigation goes next.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENLEY, DR. MARTHA KATHERINE
description: HENLEY-Dr. Martha Katherine Reese Henley, 91, died Monday, August 17, at Scotland Memorial Hospital. A memorial service will be at 11 A.M. Thursday at Scotia Village. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Thomas L. Henley; a son, Dr. Thomas L. Henley, Jr. of Solana Beach, CA; a daughter, Katherine Youman of Cuenta, Ecuador; seven grandchildren and five step grandchildren. She was a 1935 graduate of John Hopkins Medical school, and was a practicing pediatric psychiatrist at Cornell and New York Hospital and was a consultant for the New York public schools. She retired to Laurinburg in 1991. Memorials may be made to Laurinburg Presbyterian Church, 600 W. Church St., Lauringburg, NC 28352. For information McDougald Funeral Home and Crematorium.

title: India Taps Into Its Diaspora; Expatriates Buy Bonds for Love of Country, and 7.75% Interest
description: They were plied with platters of hot kebabs and glasses of Johnnie Walker and served platitudes about the prosperity of Indian immigrants in the United States. Then, the doctors, diamond merchants and sundry other deep-pocketed Indian-Americans who filled a room at the midtown Manhattan restaurant Shaan the other night were delivered a remarkably simple pitch: Make money. Help the motherland.

title: In Testimony, Man Denies War Crimes At Nazi Camp
description: Over 47 years, Jack Reimer, the retired businessman who is accused of participating in Nazi atrocities, has told many stories of his wartime experiences to many investigators -- so many, he has maintained during four days of testimony in Federal District Court in Manhattan, that he was no longer sure of what he knew, when he knew it and what he really meant to say.

title: TBWA Worldwide Adds Stake in Japan
description: TBWA Worldwide in New York, part of Omnicom Group, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in the Nippo Corporation in Tokyo from shareholders including the Nissan Motor Company, a large TBWA client. Terms were not disclosed.

As he settled into his business-class seat facing a video screen that normally serves up a choice of eight movies, Mr. Fjalstad, 29, was told that the system was working for other passengers but his was on the blink.

He loves music and has written a new rap song with phrases like ''If I ran you over'' and ''bounce to this'' and ''built to last.''

title: $25 and Under; Ranging the Globe, in the Hands of a Brazilian Chef
description: IN theory, Cafe Colonial could be a formula for disaster. Perched as it is on the edge of a newly trendy neighborhood and serving a menu of indeterminate ethnicity to a fashionable crowd, it could easily be a cliche of bad food and worse attitude. The surprise is that the food is so good and the service so sweet.

title: Breast-Feeding and H.I.V.: Weighing Health Risks and Treatment Costs
description: This village is really just a muddy patch of ground in the tall trees near where the Nile flows out of Lake Victoria. The men work on coffee plantations. The women bear children, fetch water from the well about a mile away and cultivate cassava, potatoes and bananas.

title: Ciba Specialty Plans To Eliminate 1,100 Jobs
description: Ciba Specialty Chemicals A.G., the Swiss company that is the world's second-biggest maker of specialty chemicals, said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,100 jobs and possibly sell one of its biggest units. Ciba's first-half operating profit rose 2.7 percent, to 490 million Swiss francs ($325.7 million) from 477 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. Analysts had expected an 11 percent increase.

title: Glamorous Flamenco Revisited
description: The Jose Greco II Flamenco Dance Company is a throwback to the past in the best possible ways, to judge by the program the company presented on Saturday night in the Ted Shawn Theater at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. The dancing is straightforward and fairly traditional in a streamlined way, and it unabashedly aims at pleasing the audience. One could see them following Mr. Greco's father, the glamorous popularizer of Spanish dancing in America in the 1950's and 60's, right onto ''The Ed Sullivan Show,'' if it still existed. One of the few concessions to the 1990's is the airy simplicity of the staging and the performance space.

title: TMP WORLDWIDE TO BUY AUSTRALIAN RECRUITER
description: TMP Worldwide Inc., one of the world's largest recruiters and the owner of the Monster Board job-search Internet site, will buy the Australian recruiter Morgan & Banks Ltd. for $209 million in stock. The stockholders of Morgan & Banks will get no more than 0.1124 share and no less than 0.07025 share of TMP stock for each share held, based on the currency exchange rate at closing. Shares of TMP jumped $2.3125 yesterday, to $36.125; they have soared more than 51 percent in the last 12 months. TMP, based in New York, is betting that buying Morgan & Banks will bolster its intern-to-chief-executive strategy as more people turn to the Internet for jobs and employees.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES 4.8 PERCENT. Prices surged after the Green Coffee Association, an industry group, said stockpiles had fallen to the lowest level since February. The September contract rose 5.35 cents, to $1.163 a pound.

title: War Between the Sexes: No Prisoners Are Taken
description: In its coolly unapologetic sexual fury, Neil LaBute's ''In the Company of Men'' was such a hard act to follow that his second film, ''Your Friends and Neighbors,'' is of automatic interest. Once again exploring a chasm of bitterness separating men and women, how much further could this savagely articulate filmmaker go?

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: INTERVENTION THREATS HELP YEN. The yen rose for the fourth time in five days after Japanese Finance Ministry officials said they might sell dollars to support the currency. In New York, the dollar fell to 145 yen from 145.96.

title: North Korea's Nuclear Ambitions
description: North Korea seems to have been caught preparing to betray its 1994 commitment to trade in its nuclear weapons ambitions for $6 billion in international assistance. American intelligence agencies have detected construction of an elaborate underground complex. If completed, the nuclear reactor and plutonium reprocessing plant expected to be built there could allow the North to produce as many as half a dozen nuclear bombs two to five years from now. Washington must insist that work on this project be halted immediately. If North Korea wants economic cooperation from the United States it must honor its promise to renounce all nuclear weapons activity.

title: Air France Reports Loss From Pilot Strike in June
description: The strike by airline pilots at Air France in June, just as World Cup competition was starting in France, cost the struggling airline one billion francs ($165.9 million) in lost profit, a spokeswoman for the company said yesterday. She said the strike also cost the airline 1.6 billion francs in lost revenue. ''It will be very difficult to recoup these losses,'' she added. She declined to say whether the airline would have a profit for the first half or the full fiscal year.

title: Turkish Duel Over Islam Seems to Fade
description: Three Turkish generals who led the military's campaign against what it sees as the rising influence of Islamic fundamentalism have retired or been transferred to provincial posts, where they will presumably have little to do with politics.

title: Metro Business; Kessler Joins With Bally
description: Bally Total Fitness and the Kessler Rehabilitation Corporation of West Orange, N.J., have agreed to set up physical therapy centers in 100 health clubs in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and six other northeastern states over the next few years, Bally's chief financial officer said yesterday.

title: F.B.I. and Local Police Raid a Nairobi Hotel
description: F.B.I. agents assigned to the case of the twin bombings of embassies here and in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, raided a hotel here on Tuesday, along with local police, seizing the registration book and taking in the manager for questioning, a desk clerk at the hotel said this morning.

title: U.S. Pressing Kabul to Oust Saudi Linked To Bombings
description: The United States is urging the Taliban militia in Afghanistan to expel a Saudi-born multimillionaire from the country in hopes that he can be captured as a suspect in the bombing of American embassies in East Africa, senior Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about three parades that were held in New York City on Sunday misstated the starting time of one, the Dominican Day Parade. Nelson Pena, the president of the parade, said it began on schedule at 1:35 P.M. and was not delayed for the arrival of Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. A picture caption with the article misstated the location of the India Day Parade. It was on Madison Avenue, not the Avenue of the Americas.

title: BELL CANADA INTERNATIONAL AND A.I.G. IN KOREAN DEAL
description: Bell Canada International Inc. and the American International Group Inc., the big New York-based insurer, teamed up yesterday to buy 39.4 percent of the Hansol PCS Company of South Korea, one of the Asian nation's three cellular phone companies, for $265 million. The Montreal-based Bell Canada, which is 75 percent owned by the Canadian telecommunications giant BCE Inc., will pay $159 million for a 23.6 percent stake, while A.I.G. will acquire 15.8 percent for $106 million through investment funds. Hansol PCS is controlled by a group led by the Hansol Paper Company.

title: U.N. Says Iraq Will Have More to Spend on Food and Medicine
description: As President Saddam Hussein of Iraq continues to defy arms inspectors and to demand an end to the eight-year trade embargo against his nation, the United Nations said today that Iraq would have more money to spend on imported food, medicine and related supplies this year than at any time since sanctions began in 1990.

title: Dorothy West, a Harlem Renaissance Writer, Dies at 91

title: AFC ENTERPRISES TO PURCHASE CINNABON INTERNATIONAL
description: AFC Enterprises, the owner of Churchs Chicken and Popeyes Chicken and Biscuits, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Cinnabon International Inc., a retail bakery company, for $65 million. The Seattle-based Cinnabon, which features cinnamon rolls, owns 214 sites and has 144 franchise sites. Its outlets are in malls, airports and supermarkets. The acquisition is the fourth in the last year for the Atlanta-based AFC as the company expands its restaurant formats, building cash flow in anticipation of an initial public offering in 1999. Recent purchases include the Seattle Coffee Company.

title: 'Safe Rooms' Urged in Areas Prone to Tornadoes

title: STAFFMARK AGREES TO ACQUIRE BRITISH SEARCH CONCERN
description: Staffmark Inc., a recruiter of executives and corporate managers, said yesterday that it would buy Robert Walters P.L.C., another search firm, for $178.8 million in stock. The price values Robert Walters at 429.5 pence a share. Staffmark, which recruits mainly for the computer and pharmaceutical industries, wants the London-based Walters for its strength in placing people in financial services companies and accounting firms. Staffmark, based in Fayetteville, Ark., has offices in 29 states and in Canada, Britain, South Africa and Thailand. Under the agreement, Staffmark will exchange 0.272 share for each Walters share. Walters rose 93.5 pence a share yesterday, to 372 pence, in London trading. Staffmark fell $1.4375, to $24.25.

title: Conservative and Hispanic, Linda Chavez Carves Out Leadership Niche
description: Linda Chavez was one of the most powerful Hispanic officials in the Reagan Administration, with an influential voice in Hispanic affairs. She even had an office in the West Wing of the White House.

title: A REBUFFED ROPER ENDS PLAN TO BUY LEACH HOLDING
description: Roper Industries, a maker of fluid handling, industrial control and digital imaging products, said yesterday that it had canceled plans to buy the closely held Leach Holding Corporation for $125 million in stock after Leach withdrew from the deal. Roper said last month that it had signed a nonbinding letter of intent to buy Leach, which sells controls and analytical instruments used in various industries. Roper had planned to issue stock valued at about $125 million to Leach shareholders. Although Roper, based in Bogart, Ga., did not say why Leach had withdrawn from the agreement, Roper's share price has been declining in recent months.

title: Giuliani Panel Drops Measure On Campaigns
description: In the latest in a series of hurried retreats, the mayoral commission considering amendments to the City Charter bowed to sustained criticism last night and abandoned a campaign finance measure that had been its main proposal.

title: Betrayal and Embarrassment
description: The American President is a person who sometimes must ask people in the ranks to die for the country. The President is a person who asks people close around him to serve the government for less money than their talents would bring elsewhere. The President sometimes requires that people out in the country sacrifice their dollars or their convenience for national goals. All he is asked to provide in return is trustworthiness, loyalty and judgment. These concentric circles of the national family simply want the President to have enough character not to abuse their devotion.

''We will expand into the heavy truck market, independent of whether we buy or form cooperations with another company,'' Ferdinand Piech, the chief executive of Volkswagen, said in an interview with Capital, a German magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, THOMAS, ROBERT, ED. D.
description: AMES-Thomas-Robert, Ed. D. The consumers, staff and members of the Board of Trustees of YAI/National Institute for People with Disabilities mourn the passing of Dr. Thomas-Robert Ames, a passionate advocate for the rights of people with developmental disabilities to lead lives of productivity and fulfillment. He was a pioneer in developing communitybased services for people with disabilities and, as a professor at the Borough of Manhattan Community College (CUNY), he inspired and prepared a generation of professionals to work with people with disabilties. He will long be remembered for a lifetime of helping others. A memorial service is scheduled for 1:30 pm on Friday, September 18th in the Great Choir of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. It was Dr. Ames' wish that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be sent to the New York League for Early Learning, 460 West 34th Street, New York, NY 10001-2382 to further support programs and services for infants and children with developmental and learning delays and disabilities. Marcella Fava, Chairman Dr. Paul. H. Levitz, Vice Chairman Board of Trustees Dr. Joel M. Levy, CEO Dr. Philip H. Levy, COO YAI/National Institute for People with Disabilities

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUALL, IRWIN J.
description: SUALL-Irwin J. At age 73. Father of Mark and brother-in-law to Joan. Recently, former Director of the Fact-Finding Department at the Anti-Defamation League for 27 years. Earlier in life, he served in the Merchant Marine, and received a Fulbright Scholarship at Oxford University. Returning to the United States, he became an organizer for the ILGWU and went on to become national secretary of the Socialist Party. Irwin was an uncompromising and courageousfoe of Nazism and Communism and a fervent supporter of the United States, the civil rights movement and Israel. His incisive intellect, analytic skills and clarity of mind made him a forceful and unrelenting warrior for human rights. There was only one Irwin. His family, friends and comrades will miss him and love him forever. Following a private funeral, the family will be at home from 5:30 to 10 p.m. on Thursday, August 20, at 511 East 20 Street, Manhattan. A memorial meeting will be held in September.

title: AMERICAN TOOL AGREES TO ADD POLYHEDRON HOLDINGS
description: The American Tool Companies of Hoffman Estates, Ill., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Polyhedron Holdings P.L.C., a British machine tool maker, for $:33 million ($53.2 million) in cash. American Tool, which is closely held and 44.9 percent owned by the Newell Company, said it would pay Polyhedron 88 pence a share. The acquisition, recommended by the Polyhedron board, gives American Tool a presence in Britain, which it sees as one of its most important markets, and expands Polyhedron's business in the United States. Polyhedron's shares rose 19 pence, or 29 percent, to 85 pence.

title: 7 Bidders Scrimmage for Rights to Browns

Game faces on, members of each group emerged more hopeful than ever that theirs would be the lucky one chosen to pay a record price for a sports franchise, a sum expected to exceed $500 million.

description: Housing starts unexpectedly surged last month to their highest level in more than 11 years as contractors worked harder to keep up with record home sales.

description: GARDENING has few heroes, being generally an unheroic pastime, but William Price, 84, is surely one of them. Blind for more than 50 years, he does all his gardening by himself, once someone else turns the soil with a rototiller in the spring.

description: A former Miami City Commissioner was sentenced today to a year in jail, the maximum penalty, for trying to cover up voter fraud in last November's election. The former commissioner, Humberto E. Hernandez, until recently one of the city's most powerful politicians, had been convicted on a misdemeanor charge.

Religious service at funeral home Thursday 8 P.M. Funeral Friday 10 A.M. from funeral home. Interment Lutheran Cemetery, Middle Village, NY.

title: 3 Armed Joy Riders Take Washington Cabdriver to Queens
description: A cabdriver in Washington who picked up three passengers who asked to be driven to New York Tuesday night was robbed at gunpoint, handcuffed, blindfolded and put into the trunk of the car for eight hours while the gunmen took a joyride to Queens, the police said yesterday.

description: In the largest corporate relocation to lower Manhattan in more than a decade, the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America has announced that it will move its headquarters and transfer about 1,700 employees to 7 Hanover Square from 201 Park Avenue South at 17th Street near Union Square, its home for more than 85 years.

title: REPUBLIC TO BUY 7 AUTO DEALERSHIPS
description: Republic Industries agreed yesterday to buy seven closely held auto dealerships for an undisclosed price as it begins an expansion in the Baltimore and Washington markets. Republic, the world's largest retailer of autos and trucks, said the cash purchases include Fox Automotive Group of Baltimore, the 47th-largest United States auto group, with six dealerships, and L.P. Evans Motors, a Mercedes-Benz dealership in North Miami, Fla. Republic, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is led by its chairman, Wayne Huizenga. It said the dealerships would add about $400 million in annual revenue. The company had $10.3 billion in revenue last year. Republic plans to open two Autonation USA used-car megastores in Baltimore and four in the Washington area beginning in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRODEN, SOL
description: GRODEN-Sol. 85 of Scarsdale, NY on August 18. Predeceased by wife Gertrude. Beloved father of Ruth and Max Horn, Walter and Barbara Groden. Devoted grandfather of Judy, Sarah, Debbie, and Suzanne.

description: The Microsoft Corporation has a fresh antitrust challenge on its hands from an unlikely source -- a small software supplier in Connecticut.

title: New Entry in Your Mailbox

Since the first Manhattan store will not open until November, city dwellers can use the catalogue to get a head start on 400 offerings -- from leather armchairs to Buhach (an insecticide from 1876), boot scrapes and, of course, hardware. To order catalogues: (800) 762-1005. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: 2 Midtown Detectives Suspended Over Roles in a Queens Dispute
description: Two police detectives assigned to Manhattan's Midtown South Precinct were suspended from the force yesterday on charges that they left their posts on Tuesday night to drive to Queens and take sides in a landlord-tenant dispute as a favor to a friend.

description: As rebels closed in on this capital today, President Laurent Kabila scrambled to obtain foreign military support to repel a final assault.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUALL, IRWIN J.
description: SUALL-Irwin J. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of one of our longtime civil rights professionals, Irwin J. Suall, who was a brilliant and resourceful ADL activist for over thirty years. Irwin was key to the League's leadership in the fight against antiSemitism, racism and organized hate. We extend our deepest and heartfelt sympathy to his son Mark and his sister-in-law Joan. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem, secure in the knowledge of his solid legacy of service and his indelible place in the hearts and minds of his colleagues. Abraham H. Foxman, National Director Elizabeth J. Coleman, Director Civil Rights Gail L. Gans, Director Fact Finding

The Kingspark acquisition includes 32 million square feet for potential development.

title: Times to Buy More Shares
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its board had authorized spending as much as $575 million to buy back additional shares of the company's class A common stock. So far this year, the company has bought about six million shares for $201.2 million. The shares, which touched a 52-week high of $40.6875 on July 6, closed yesterday at $30.75, down 18.75 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Young Mr. Lincoln? Auction May Shed Light
description: Ever since the small, leather-encased oval daguerreotype of someone who looks like a young Abraham Lincoln surfaced a few years ago, experts have been arguing about it. If the picture, made around 1843, is of the 16th President, it would be Lincoln's first likeness, predating a daguerreotype in the Library of Congress that was made between 1846 and 1849. It would be a major historical discovery.

description: Garry Mauro, swift and streaked with sweat, doggedly guided a V-formation of lesser candidates across a sun-crisped lawn in a section of town called Idiots Hill, so named, residents explained, because it was once so far from downtown that people thought only an idiot would live there.

description: JOE TORRE can peek into the opposing dugout tomorrow night in Texas and easily recognize his rival, Johnny Oates, the Rangers manager. Their mental scraps are always intense but friendly. Their respect is mutual.

One was caused by terrorists, and the other was a blow to a system intended to help ferret them out.

He can almost remember how it felt to be one a decade ago when he first played Ivan Lendl, and he can definitely remember what happened to him the first time Lendl glared in his direction from across the net on a blood-red Italian clay court. The teen-age Sampras didn't cry, but he did cringe. And lose.

Mr. Khouri, an architect, has started a furniture company, Comma, with Roberto Guzman, a fellow architect. Mr. Khouri's first 15 pieces of 70's-syncratic design include the milk acrylic Dookia Display Unit ($4,500) and the red lacquered acrylic Screen 2 ($2,750). title: Blueberry Days, Log-Fire Nights
description: VACATIONERS with a puritanical streak are drawn to Maine, where stark blue skies and towering evergreens meet jagged gray rocks and the endless high-low seething of ocean tides. Here, even leisure activities have an edge, whether it's knuckling down to sail in a stiff wind or charging up graveled hills on a bike. Writers like E. B. White and Robert McCloskey have found Maine rich in material for moral tales of innocence unsettled by nature's unpredictability. Ralph Lauren and Martha Stewart can only dream of bottling this essence of virtuous American simplicity.

title: Treasuries End the Day Unchanged
description: Treasury bond prices were unchanged yesterday, with the dollar continuing to slide against the yen. This was attributed to talk of possible intervention by the Japanese to aid the yen. Also, a report of stronger-than-expected housing starts gave investors little incentive to buy bonds with yields near record lows.

description: The Liberty has been a fan favorite, attracting crowds of 19,563 and 17,396 in its last two home games.

description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew defended his $50,000 pay raise last night on both personal and professional grounds: he wanted to insure that he could pay his college-age children's tuition, and, he said, he deserved it.

description: Is the grand alliance between United Airlines and Delta Air Lines dead? Delta's pilots union, which has the power to veto the most critical part of the link with United, said yesterday that Delta's decision not to give the union a voting seat on its board effectively ended the alliance.

title: Lewis Carroll Revisited: In a Looking Glass, Darkly
description: Even by Victorian standards, Charles Lutwidge Dodgson was a considerable eccentric. When the shy Oxford University lecturer veered away from his academic interest in mathematics to publish ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' and ''Through the Looking Glass,'' he hid behind the nom de plume of Lewis Carroll and, even late in life, refused to acknowledge that he was the author of the best-selling children's classics.

title: Neuberger & Berman Set to Sell 15% Stake in a Public Offering
description: Neuberger & Berman, the investment-management partnership founded in 1939 by Roy R. Neuberger, the well-known investor and art benefactor, said yesterday that it planned to sell 15 percent of its shares in an initial public offering that would value the company at $1.7 billion.

Three dramatic turns, in fact, as the Chicago Cubs' Sammy Sosa grabbed the major league home run lead from the St. Louis Cardinals' Mark McGwire, only to see McGwire grab it right back.

title: Prague Spring Revisited
description: Thirty years ago tonight the Soviet Union and its choir, the Warsaw Pact, invaded Czechoslovakia. The invasion wiped out what the Government of Alexander Dubcek called Socialism with a human face, which had established a free press, some political rights and intra-party democracy. A new book, ''The Prague Spring '68,'' helps answer the question of why the Soviets invaded Czechoslovakia, as it had Hungary, while it overlooked insubordination elsewhere.

title: Ex-Klansman Implicates Chief in Killing
description: In the vernacular of the White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan of Mississippi in the violent 1960's, a ''No. 1'' was a cross burning and a ''No. 2'' was a whipping. A ''No. 3'' was a firebombing and a ''No. 4,'' the most severe punishment of all, was a killing. Only the highest-ranking Klansmen could order a No. 3 and No. 4, said Billy Roy Pitts, a foot soldier in the White Knights in the winter of 1965-1966.

description: The most comprehensive survey of permanent layoffs in America finds that in the last three years, a smaller percentage of workers were downsized than in any other period in this decade. But the layoff rate is still significantly higher than in the 1980's, and women now get pink slips almost as often as men.

No matter how many times he or she swiped it through the scanner, that jar of peanut butter just wouldn't go through.

description: Fame easily finds a place like this, with its climate so embracing, its surroundings so inspiring and its population leavened so liberally with artists and new immigrants.

Speaking after a meeting of economic officials, Mr. Sabirin described Government injections of cash into faltering banks as an option. Alternatives include finding new investors or persuading existing investors to put up more cash.

title: JACK HENRY TO BUY PEERLESS FOR $36 MILLION
description: Jack Henry & Associates Inc., which provides computer systems and automated teller machines to financial services companies, agreed yesterday to buy Peerless Group Inc. for $7.25 a share in stock, a total of about $36 million. Shareholders of Peerless Group, based in Richardson, Tex., will receive 0.16145 Jack Henry common share for each share they own. Peerless, with 1997 revenue of $30.1 million, will expand the customer base of Jack Henry, which is based in Monett, Mo. Peerless installs information systems for community banks and credit unions throughout the United States. Peerless rose 30 percent, gaining $1.50 a share, to $6.375, in Nasdaq trading, while Jack Henry fell $1.59375, to $44.

title: Court Will Let Gates Testify in Closed Session
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered that pretrial questioning of William H. Gates and 16 other Microsoft Corporation executives be taken behind closed doors, overruling a lower court judge who had ordered lawyers to take public depositions in the Government's antitrust case against the software giant.

title: Split Between Commentators and the People May Help Clinton
description: Inside Washington, pundits and editorial writers excoriated a destroyed Presidency. Republicans whisper, some loudly, about impeachment hearings or resignation. Some Democrats are putting distance between themselves and Mr. Clinton.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Vice President Al Gore's reaction to President Clinton's speech acknowledging his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky referred incorrectly to Mr. Gore's status in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000. While Mr. Gore will probably be a leading contender, it is too early to call him the likely nominee.

description: Talk of business came first today in this tiny rural farm town that the people here call the ''middle of Middle America.'' There were cumbersome export restrictions to discuss, and the need for trains to haul out crops.

Delaware will play Toms River, N.J., tonight (ESPN2, 8 o'clock) for the regional title, with the winner advancing to the eight-team Little League World Series in Williamsport, Pa., starting Sunday.

title: Blocking Out the Sun, Not the Sunny View
description: West-facing windows are fabulous for a view of the river. But as the sun begins to set, temperatures begin to climb. East- and south-facing windows have the same problem -- even in August. Of course there are window blinds, but they shut out the view. There is air-conditioning, but why try to overcome the sun's radiant heat when you can cut it in half? Consider Solis: a virtually clear film applied directly to windows.

title: Piazza Is Focusing on Team Goals
description: Mike Piazza was speaking in a whisper yesterday when a question about how the fans at Shea Stadium have treated him caused his voice to drop even lower. Piazza frowned, stared down at the clubhouse carpet and spoke so softly that he could have been in a library and bothered no one.

title: With Admirers Like These Around, Kohl Needs No Detractors
description: You know that Chancellor Helmut Kohl must be in trouble when even European intellectuals who say they admire him come to Berlin for an opposition campaign rally proclaiming the end of an era.

title: iMacs Are Selling Fast But the G3 Is Truly Hot
description: Sales of Apple's new iMac are hot. So is one problem with Apple's new Powerbook G3 series laptop computers, according to customers and technicians.

description: Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, which provides phone service in Connecticut, and a union representing 6,300 of its workers are to restart informal negotiations today on a new contract.

Beloved brother of Betty C. and Mary E. Wilson and the late John T. Cherished uncle of Martha A. and Joseph J. Snee and John C. Wilson. Loving cousin of Sr. Elizabeth Butler S.C. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St, NYC, Friday 2-5pm. Mass of the Holy Eucharist, Friday, 7:30pm St. Bernard's RC Church. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 10am celebrated by His Eminence John Cardinal O'Connor, St. Bernard's RC Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: F.C.C. Takes a Harder Look at 'Microradio' Stations
description: FOR five years, Richard Edmondson snuck the sounds of defiance from his living room and into his community. As operator of an unlicensed radio station called San Francisco Liberation Radio, he wedged his way onto the airwaves, using a vacant frequency to broadcast 12 hours a day. The programming included news, music and shows like ''Voices of the Rebellion,'' which focused on homelessness issues, and ''Time Out,'' a program for children, often with a left-wing political lesson.

title: High Costs of 'Joe Black' Challenge Industry Rule
description: It's an unwritten Hollywood rule that action and special effects movies, like ''Titanic,'' go over budget. Unpredictable weather, computer glitches and expensive crowd scenes all contribute to soaring costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, ESTHER
description: WEXNER-Esther. Devoted wife of the late Phillip. Dear sister of the late Al Benzon and Marty Benzon. Cherished aunt of Jay, Shari, Melvyn, Norman and Steven. Great-aunt to many. Services Thurs. 1:30 p.m. at ''BoulevardRiverside Chapels'', Bklyn, 312 Coney Island Ave at Prospect Park

title: Roller Coasters Take a Ride From Wild To Wired
description: PASSENGERS on the Riddler's Revenge roller coaster squealed with exuberance and panic, from the initial 15-story plunge right through to the last of six fearsome spirals, many at freeway speeds.

title: Boston Globe Columnist Resigns Over Authenticity of 1995 Story
description: Eight days after salvaging his career at The Boston Globe, the star columnist Mike Barnicle resigned yesterday, at the newspaper's request, when editors could find no evidence that two young cancer victims he described in a 1995 column had ever existed.

title: In America; Clinton on the Wire
description: ''No one is ever better on the high wire,'' said former White House press secretary Dee Dee Myers in a television appearance before Bill Clinton's address to the nation on Monday night.

title: Caldor Given Extra Time
description: A United States bankruptcy court has given the Caldor Corporation, the discount retail chain, an extra six months to reorganize its finances. Caldor, which filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code in 1995, will have until next March 1 to file its reorganization plan with the court. Caldor, based in Norwalk, previously had until Sept. 1 to file its plan. The Chapter 11 filing frees Caldor from the threat of creditor lawsuits while it reorganizes.

title: Livent Says Accounting Woes May Cut Net Worth
description: The new managers at Livent Inc., the producer of Broadway shows, said yesterday that the company's accounting woes could significantly reduce its already slender net worth.

title: Fried. Krupp's Profit Doubled in First Half
description: Fried. Krupp A.G. Hoesch-Krupp, the German industrial conglomerate, said yesterday that its pretax profit more than doubled in the six months that ended on June 30, as its automotive and steel units benefited from strong demand in Europe and the United States. Krupp, based in Essen, Germany, said pretax profit amounted to 411 million marks ($228 million) in the first six months of 1998, up from 204 million marks a year earlier. Sales rose 4 percent, to 12.66 billion marks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, RAHSAAN T.
description: JACKSON-Rahsaan T. Born March 24, 1974, loving son of Richard and Deborah Jackson, passed away Saturday August 15, 1998. You will always be remembered.

description: WASHINGTON  The Clinton administration lowered its profile Wednesday as it weighed reaction to the president's admission of an inappropriate relationship with Monica Lewinsky and anxiously awaited her second appearance before the grand jury on Thursday.

Cherished grandfather of Joanne, Patrick, Michael and Zhana Kinane. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, August 21 in Seattle, Washington. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Queens, N.Y.

title: Prosecutor in Archer Case Says Tapes Back Informant
description: The informant in the price-fixing investigation of the Archer Daniels Midland Company provided investigators with tape recordings corroborating his allegations that the company had hired prostitutes in an effort to obtain information about the activities of a competitor, a Federal prosecutor said today during a court hearing.

description: The Government plans to pull back the curtains today on 15 candidates for one of the tougher job assignments of the 21st century.

title: Corrections
description: Maps yesterday with an article about fears of breast-feeding in Africa because of the AIDS epidemic carried erroneous shading in some copies, overstating or understating the incidence of H.I.V. or AIDS among pregnant women in several countries. Corrected maps appear today on page A10.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN EXTENDS GAINS. The dollar continued to weaken against the yen, as worry grew about currency-market intervention before meetings of American and Japanese officials. The dollar fell to 143.93 yen from 145 on Tuesday.

title: Images in fall fashion magazines take a break from daydreams for a little reality check.
description: IS high fashion trying to speak to the masses? Flip through the September issues of fashion magazines, and there appears to be a subtle shift in the sensibility of fashion advertisers this fall season.

description: FOX-Elizabeth G. Of Wellfleet, Ma. Formerly of Caldwell, N.J. on August 18, 1998. A Memorial Service to be announced.

title: Two-Day Rally Is Ended As Dow Slides 21.37 Points
description: Stocks ended slightly lower yesterday, as cautious investors stepped back from a two-day rally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, NORMAN, ESQ.
description: NEWMAN-Norman, Esq. Yeshiva of South Shore and its affiliates are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved, dedicated president, who served our organization with devotion and distinction. Norman was a devoted husband, father, son and brother whose brilliant mind and compassionate heart were always available to help others. He was an exemplary community leader who, as president of the Yeshiva, helped us forge our way into the next century. He will be greatly missed. Rabbi Benjamin Kamenetzky Dean

title: Irwin J. Suall, Fierce Fighter Of Bias for A.D.L., Dies at 73
description: Irwin J. Suall, who for three decades headed undercover investigations of groups regarded as inimical to Jews on behalf of the Anti-Defamation League, died on Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center at 114th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. He was 73 and lived in the Tudor City area of Manhattan.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Trimming Stock Options' Sails; Accounting Proposal Would Lift the Cost of Repricing
description: It's happened recently at Netscape Communications, Apple Computer, Bay Networks, Oracle, Best Buy and Oxford Health Plans, among others. The company's stock plunges, and its board immediately acts to reduce the price at which employees can buy shares through the stock option program. A new, lower exercise price, the company argues, keeps workers from abandoning ship to a competitor. In a tight labor market, anything that keeps employees happy is crucial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, ALICE HOWLAND
description: EDWARDS-Alice Howland. Age 84 on July 8, 1998. Singer of opera & art song & vocal coach. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Edwards, cellist. Loving mother of Kate and Harriet Edwards. Grandmother of Victoria Kirk. Devoted sister of Harriet Flynn and Thielo Howland. Interment private. Memorial service at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84 Street, Sunday, August 23, 2 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Melvin D. Yahr Parkinsons Research Fund, 5 East 98th Street, New York, New York 10029.

title: Traditional Furniture Maker Takes a Radical Design Turn
description: From the folks who've brought you dark, heavy timbered oak furniture for 93 years -- L.& J. G. Stickley -- comes a design departure for fall 1998: the 30-piece Metropolitan collection. More Shaker meets Biedemeier than monobrow Mission, the dining, bed and living room furniture is cherry wood and walnut. Above, the loft chest with nickel pulls, $2,782. At E. J. Audi, 160 Fifth Avenue (21st Street); (212) 337-0700.

title: Man Who Lost Primary Can Run as Independent
description: A candidate for the House of Representatives can run as an independent in one Congressional district even after having lost a party primary in another district, a state judge ruled yesterday.

title: UConn Departs On Overseas Tour
description: The University of Connecticut men's basketball team left Boston last night for a 14-day, six-game trip to England and Israel. The tour by the Huskies, who are expected to be one of the best teams in college basketball next season, will include games against two Israeli teams that have former UConn stars on their rosters.

title: Swiss Want Bhutto Indicted in Pakistan for Money Laundering
description: A Swiss investigating magistrate said today that he had amassed enough evidence, including the purchase of a diamond necklace, to indict Pakistan's former Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, on money-laundering charges tied to contracts with two Geneva-based companies.

title: Prominent Heart Surgeon Has License Suspended
description: A prominent surgeon who is credited with turning Erie County Medical Center's troubled heart surgery program into a success has had his medical license suspended for a year after he was accused of throwing a towel at one nurse, pushing another and splattering blood on a third.

title: Teaching Parents How to Protect Children on Line
description: AFTER logging on to a chat room for timid people, ''Britny02'' said she had just moved to a new town and was interested in learning new things. Within half a minute, she was receiving messages from a man who said he was significantly older and wanted to know about what sort of new things she was interested in learning, if she had ever messed around with a boyfriend and if he could call her. Soon three or four other men were propositioning the teen-ager.

title: Man Accused of a Killing After Dispute Over TV
description: An argument over what to watch on television ended violently Monday night when an East Orange man fatally shot his roommate, the Essex County Prosecutor's office said yesterday.

title: Environmentalists Urge State to Halt Road Link
description: A coalition of environmental groups called on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday to halt a plan for a 6.7-mile highway linking the New Jersey Turnpike with Route 1, saying it would destroy 18 acres in one of the state's most environmentally delicate areas.

title: TRINET AND MENLO BUY SUBURBAN PROPERTIES
description: Trinet Corporate Realty Trust Inc. and Menlo Equities L.L.C. bought five suburban office and research and development properties in San Jose, Calif., yesterday for about $50.4 million, as the companies expand their industrial real estate holdings. The companies, both real estate investment trusts, each own 50 percent of the property, which includes five fully leased buildings with a total of 308,889 square feet. The properties, which are in northern San Jose and are known as Technology Center, will be managed by Menlo Equities.

title: Personal Shopper; Thereby Hang Tails and a T-Shirt
description: LET it all hang out -- on hooks, coils or flying hangers. It's a given that no one ever has enough storage space. Here are organizers that let clothes come out of the closet. (And one modular system that can pull a closet together.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, ROBERT B., SR.
description: EVANS-Robert B., Sr. A resident of Grosse Pointe Shores, MI, died at his residence on August 17, 1998. He was born March 19, 1906 in Richmond, VA. He was a graduate of Virginia Episcopal School, The University of Lauzon, and the University of Michigan. He was the founder of Evans Industries and was a former chairman of American Motors. He was a prominent republican, an industrialist, and an avid sportsman. He is survived by his wife Jane Preston Evans and his children Jane Evans Jones and Robert B. Evans, Jr. Also surviving are four grandchildren and two great - grandchildren. Memorial services Thursday, August 20th 11:00am at Christ Church Grosse Pointe, 61 Grosse Pointe Blvd, Grosse Pointe Farms, MI. Donations to The Boy Scouts of America-Detroit Council, 1776 W. Warren, Detroit, MI 48208. For information contact the Wm. R. Hamilton, Company, Mt Clemens, MI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINER, PETER H.
