Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Yale Law School Fund. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Bullish on Times Square Neon; Wall Street Muscles Into Mecca of Commercial Glitter
description: Ever since Trimble's Whiskey erected the first neon sign there nearly a century ago, Times Square has been New York's glowing, pulsating marketplace for everything from steam irons to video cameras, Camels to Calvins. Now, though, it is beginning to hawk a very different kind of product: the stock market.

title: Wording Change Skewed Poll After Speech
description: A small change in the wording of a poll question by The Gallup Organization led to a significant overstatement of the drop in President Clinton's personal favorability rating after his speech on Monday.

title: NEXSTAR CONSIDERS SPINOFF OF DRUG UNIT
description: Nexstar Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that its board was considering spinning off its drug-discovery business, prompting the top executive of the pharmaceutical company to quit in disagreement. Patrick Mahaffy resigned as president and chief executive and also left the company's board. The company will be led by its management committee, consisting of its chairman, Larry Gold, and four vice presidents. Shares of Nexstar, which is based in Boulder, Colo., rose 68.75 cents, to $9.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Abe Lincoln at 34? Christie's Hopes So
description: Citing forensic analyses and an interesting provenance, some experts believe that an 1840's daguerreotype to be auctioned by Christie's is of Abraham Lincoln in his Illinois Legislature days. If genuine, it would be the earliest likeness.

description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Chip Makers Warn of Profit Shortfalls
description: Two computer chip makers said today that they expected sharply lower quarterly results because of Asia's economic crisis, and a third said its quarterly net earnings fell 81 percent.

title: Yanks Strike a Rare Note of Imperfection
description: The Yankees loaded the bases in the seventh inning tonight, the blood and guts of their lineup due to bat. Andy Pettitte assumed his teammates would score a bunch of runs and come back. They always do. Just hang in there, Pettitte told himself as he stood in the runway behind the dugout. He was sure they would beat the Twins.

title: After Assemblyman's Death, Ally Is Chosen for Ballot Slot
description: Nine days after the death of Assemblyman Anthony J. Genovesi, Democratic officials in Brooklyn yesterday designated Frank R. Seddio, a lawyer who was one of the late Assemblyman's political lieutenants, to replace Mr. Genovesi on the ballot for the Assembly seat.

title: Jets Put Rivalry On Back Burner
description: They may be wearing the helmet designs of a bygone era on Thursday, and they may be facing the team that once symbolized the Establishment, but to the Jets, the meeting with the Giants has become just an exhibition game rather than a rite of passage.

title: A Record for Gordon Is Only Miles Away
description: Having already established himself as the driver to beat this season, Jeff Gordon has a chance to preserve his place in Nascar history this weekend with a fifth straight victory.

title: Economic Scene; Fallout as Russia devalues its way toward a market economy.
description: THE reaction in the West this week to Russia's decision to, in effect, default on some loans and devalue the ruble has been one of fear mixed with disappointment. The fear that a Russian financial debacle would spread elsewhere has so far proved exaggerated. Russia's nuclear arms cache might intimidate faraway places, but its Netherlands-sized economy does not.

title: Arrest in Robbery and Murder of Ex-Sailor
description: A man described by the authorities as a homeless drug addict has confessed to murdering an 81-year-old retired merchant seaman who had invited the man into his Staten Island home 10 days ago to use the telephone, the police said yesterday.

description: ZONE-Marty. 1957-1993. The love of my life. Ton

title: Modest Charter Plan Serves a Mayoral Goal
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani created his Charter Revision Commission last spring, he described its mission in the noblest of terms: to present to the voters a series of much-needed changes to the City Charter, the hallowed how-to list for the governance of New York City.

title: Wheatley a Nonperson in the Backfield
description: The blueprint for the redesigned Giants backfield will be unveiled in Thursday night's preseason game with the Jets: Gary Brown as the starter at halfback, Tiki Barber as the third-down specialist and Charles Way as the fullback who frequently switches to a halfback carrying the football.

title: Italian Insurer Agrees to Pay $100 Million in Holocaust Suit
description: The biggest Italian insurance company, Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A., told a Federal judge last night that it would pay $100 million to Holocaust survivors and the heirs of victims for life insurance and annuity policies that it refused to honor after World War II.

title: Kohlberg Kravis to Acquire Paint Company in Germany
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company said yesterday that it would buy Herberts, a German paint company, for $1.7 billion in a deal that represents the American buyout firm's growing ardor for buying, revamping and selling companies in Europe the way it has at home since the mid-1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHIA, DEWEY TEH, HUAI
description: CHIA-Dewey Teh-huai. Age 86, on August 18th at Greenwich Hospital. Born in Shanghai, China. He came to the United States in 1956 where he established an oceanic shipping and international trading business. He is survived by his wife, Kitty Shun-hua, son Pei-yuan, daughters Pei-hsin and Pei-loh, daughter-in-law Frances, sons-inlaw David Gedalecia and Adrian Lo, and seven grandchildren.

title: Peter H. Kaminer: Legal Aid Society Official, 83
description: Peter H. Kaminer, a litigator who was senior managing partner of the law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts in New York from 1963 to 1983, died Monday at his home on Park Avenue, said Stephen A. Weiner, a partner at the firm. Mr. Kaminer, who was 83 and suffered from terminal cancer, took his own life, associates said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TOMEO, ANTOINETTE E.

description: A woman wounded by a stray bullet as she sunbathed on her backyard patio last week has sued the man who admitted firing the bullet.

title: Coffee Traders In Brazil Deal
description: Hencorp Becstone & Company, a privately held securities trading firm, today bought 50 percent of the Brazilian commodity trading firm Commcor to expand its business in coffee futures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDERMAN, LEWIS MARK

Graveside funeral services are Friday August 21 at 11am in the Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Crabiel Parkwest Funeral Service, New Brunswick, NJ.

title: Compiling Your 'Greatest Hits' on Disk
description: EVERY music collection has one -- the hourlong compact disk acquired solely for the sake of a three-minute song. The bait might have been a popular single that sizzled on a summer movie soundtrack or a nostalgia-inspiring hit that gleamed in the middle of a golden-oldies collection, but many listeners are lured into sinking $15 on an unfamiliar album after catching one hook-laden tune on the radio.

title: Details for New Center at Newark Airport
description: The developers of a proposed hotel and conference center complex on the fringes of Newark International Airport today detailed their plans for the project, which would tap into a growing need for hotel rooms and meeting space within easy reach of the airport.

title: New Questions Over Gore Role As Fund-Raiser
description: Justice Department investigators have obtained a 1995 White House memorandum with hand-written notations that appear to contradict Vice President Al Gore's account of his fund-raising telephone calls in President Clinton's re-election campaign, Government officials said today.

title: Northwest Halts Fare Increase
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation rescinded a day-old increase in leisure fares yesterday, a day after other airlines followed suit in raising fares.

title: A Quiet Birthday and a Reunion With a Trusted Friend
description: After a quiet day spent only with his family, President Clinton celebrated his 52d birthday tonight with his informal counselor, golfing buddy and locker-room confidant Vernon E. Jordan Jr., resuming a close association interrupted by the Lewinsky affair.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Saturday about drunken-driving charges against Brian Scan tlebury, an official at the New Jersey Department of Transportation, misstated his blood alcohol level and the legal limit in New Jersey. His level was measured at 0.19 percent, not 1.9 percent, and the limit is 0.1 percent, not 1 percent.

title: Prime Directive Shows Up Tactical Cat in the Special
description: It isn't for nothing that D. Wayne Lukas is known as the master of 2-year-old horses. In 1984, he saddled his first winner of a juvenile stakes at Saratoga, the racing world's grandest stage for building young careers. Since then, he has trained 24 winners of Saratoga's prestigious juvenile stakes for colts and fillies.

title: Richard Boswell Finn, 80, Expert on Japan
description: Richard Boswell Finn, a former naval intelligence officer, diplomat and scholar of Japanese affairs, died on Monday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 80 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: An Inside Peek at Homes By an Architectural Legend
description: McKim, Mead & White -- both sides, now. From 1879 to 1906, the New York architects created more than 300 private homes, from apartments to shingled summer cottages to lavish American palaces. Now, with a new book, the public can peek inside. Two years ago, Samuel G. White, a Manhattan architect and a great-grandson of Stanford White, saw 30 of the 100 surviving homes. The result is ''The Houses of McKim, Mead & White,'' published by Rizzoli.

title: Trial Is Over for a Man Accused in War Crimes
description: The civil trial of Jack Reimer, the retired businessman accused of concealing his role in Nazi war crimes, ended yesterday after two weeks of anguished courtroom recollections from Holocaust survivors and numbingly detailed descriptions of how a Nazi training camp worked.

title: Plan Offered to Reverse Lilco Pay Deals
description: Top officers of the Long Island Lighting Company who received large severance checks when the utility merged with Marketspan have been told they must return the money if they expect to keep their jobs at Marketspan, company officials confirmed today.

title: Bringing Extra Passion to a Fine Romance
description: THE word ''nuance'' does not generally describe interactive media. In most digital environments, the impetus is to race ahead with both guns blazing, solve all the puzzles, beat the big bad boss and never look back -- only ahead, to the next product. They're like theme restaurants that pack tables and jack up the music so that you'll eat and leave as quickly as possible. How refreshing, then, to find the digital equivalent of a candle-lighted bistro, tucked away on some side street, where patrons are encouraged to stretch a few cups of coffee into literary conversations that last for hours.

title: 30 Years of Love and Chronicling Cuisine
description: In a rare example of marital and professional alignment, Michael and Ariane Batterberry -- gatekeepers of Manhattan's foodie culture -- are celebrating almost every possible anniversary a couple could in one year.

title: Executive Changes
description: DAMES & MOORE GROUP, Los Angeles, an engineering, consulting and environmental services company, named Arthur Darrow chairman, succeeding George Leal.

title: The Reno Watch
description: While President Clinton's reputation for integrity continues to plummet, Attorney General Janet Reno seems to be thinking about salvaging hers by appointing an independent counsel. Aides say that within the next few days she will complete her review of an exhaustive report in which her chief prosecutor for campaign finance irregularities, Charles La Bella, argues for naming an independent prosecutor to investigate White House fund-raising during 1996. Such an appointment is 18 months overdue, but it is encouraging to see news reports that Ms. Reno is at least lurching in the right direction.

title: MAGELLAN ENDS TALKS ON SALE OF SOME ASSETS
description: Magellan Health Services Inc., a managed-care company, said yesterday that it had ended negotiations on the planned $310 million sale of some assets and its stake in a joint venture that runs psychiatric hospitals. Magellan, which focuses on mental-health plans, intended to sell its Charter Advantage L.L.C. unit, including a toll-free phone line and some hospital joint ventures, to Charter Behavioral Health Systems L.L.C. for $280 million. Shares of the Atlanta-based Magellan fell $2, to $14.25.

title: The Yankees Are Fans, Too
description: The Yankees were spread all over their clubhouse here today, some playing cards, some chatting. When Mark McGwire batted in the 10th inning, however, many of the players gathered in front of the television mounted high on a wall to watch the slugger bat, as rapt in their attention as any fan at Wrigley Field.

title: Unit of Core Labs Agrees to Pay Fine
description: A unit of the Dutch company Core Laboratories N.V. has agreed to pay a $4.9 million fine as part of a proposed plea agreement in which it would acknowledge falsifying United States environmental reports and violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, the Justice Department said this week.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you call someone a terrorist, you must have proof. If there is proof, we will certainly sit down and talk to the U.S.''

title: The Bidding for World Titles Starts Tomorrow in France
description: The World Championships beginning in Lille, France, tomorrow may prove to be the biggest ever. Thousands of players from around the world will take part, with a particularly large contingent from Europe. There will be a full schedule of events: open teams, open pairs, women's teams, women's pairs and mixed pairs, plus events for seniors and juniors.

description: GOLDSTEIN-Seymour. On August 17, 1998. Devoted husband of Sonja and the late Beatrice. Loving father of Andrew, Janet and the late Peter. Father-in-law of Ed. Cherished grandfather of Peter, Seth, Eric, Bari, Samantha and Lindsay. Retired President of River Bank Motors Corp. Reposing Thursday 7-9pm at Gallagher Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, Conn. Graveside service at 10:30am Friday at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla.

title: Learning to Love Brown

His first instinct, he said, was to introduce a little drama into the life of this nearly century-old shipping company by changing the color of its trucks.

title: A Black Cat in a Dark Room
description: Much has been said and published about the current standoff between Iraq and the United Nations arms inspectors. But those criticizing Iraq for suspending its cooperation with the United Nations special commission on arms inspection, better known as Unscom, give no recognition whatsoever to the underlying reasons that led Iraq to adopt this position. It is time to set the record straight.

title: Internet Service Providers Victorious on Access Fees
description: Internet service providers won a major victory yesterday when an appeals court upheld the Federal Communications Commission's decision to exempt them from paying local phone companies the access fees the phone companies are allowed to charge long-distance carriers.

title: Green Urges Cuts in Defense To Finance Social Programs
description: Mark Green, a Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from New York, called yesterday for substantial cuts in Pentagon spending over the next five years, saying the nation was wasting money on defense that should instead go to school construction, health care for children and other domestic initiatives.

title: Miramax Goes Back To Previous Agency
description: Miramax Films has renamed Harvest Communications in New York to handle the media portion of its tri-state New York area advertising account, with billings estimated at $20 million, citing problems with the agency that had handled those duties for only a month, Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York.

title: Hollywood's Kindest Cuts; Invisible Film Editors Start to Emerge From Director's Shadow
description: Michael Kahn still remembers his nervousness when Steven Spielberg hired him to edit ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind'' in 1976. On his first day on the job, after editing a scene, Mr. Kahn awaited Mr. Spielberg's reaction.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph yesterday with an article about planned changes to the site of a lighthouse and keeper's cottage in Maine that was painted several times by Edward Hopper carried an incorrect credit. The photo, of Hopper's painting ''Lighthouse at Two Lights'' (1929), was from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: State to Convene Summit On Blacks and the Police
description: State Attorney General Peter G. Verniero announced yesterday that he would convene a summit this winter on relations between law enforcement and black New Jerseyans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, ADOLPH
description: STONE-Adolph. Beloved husband of the late Mary C. Stone, and Sylvia B. Kline, cherished father of Elizabeth and Daniel, devoted grandfather of Nathaniel and Rachel. Services will be held Friday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Mozart Index In the Fourth Week: Bear and Then Bull
description: By the middle of the fourth week of playing Mostly Mozart, the Festival Orchestra would have good reason to be exhausted, and that was how it sounded on Tuesday evening in Beethoven's Second Symphony, at the start of an oddly programmed concert under Gerard Schwarz at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Four Defensemen Added to Roster
description: One day after signing defenseman Eric Brewer to a three-year contract, the Islanders yesterday signed four other defensemen: Dean Malkoc, David Harlock, Mike Gaul and Barry Richter. The four will compete at training camp, which begins Sept. 13 in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: A Shortsighted Tobacco Decision
description: A Federal appeals court ruling that the Food and Drug Administration does not have authority to regulate tobacco or prohibit tobacco sales to children inappropriately limits the power of the F.D.A. The decision, which reverses a Federal district judge in North Carolina, ignores the broad authority granted to the agency to protect the public from unsafe drugs and devices. A sensible reading of the law would put tobacco within the agency's purview.

title: Collapsing Lilco Parachutes
description: Golden parachutes for executives are often exorbitant, but they have a certain logic. By assuring a company's senior officials that they will be richly compensated if they lose their jobs as a result of a takeover, golden parachutes encourage them not to resist a merger that might benefit shareholders.

title: U.S. SEEKS MEANS TO BRING SUSPECT FROM AFGHANISTAN
description: As United States officials focus on a Saudi exile, Osama bin Laden, as a prime suspect in the embassy bombings in Africa, they are considering strategies for how they might negotiate his capture with the Taliban, the fundamentalist Muslims who control Afghanistan, officials said.

title: Building Is No Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: Yoshii's Summer Drought Is Over
description: Masato Yoshii kept waiting for his drought to end and kept wondering if it ever would. Yoshii was approaching three months without winning in the major leagues, a startling stretch considering he has remained in the rotation and the Mets have remained in the skirmish for the wild-card berth.

title: Lipinski and Kulik Join the Tour
description: The Olympic champions, Tara Lipinski of the United States and Ilya Kulik of Russia, announced yesterday that they would join Scott Hamilton and Kristi Yamaguchi on tour this season with Stars on Ice instead of Champions on Ice, where reigning gold medalists have traditionally been showcased.

title: Sometimes the Homeless Are the Working Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Met Open Lead Is Shared By Pair Who Stay Together
description: Two players who played together for two rounds are the co-leaders and will be playing together again on Thursday in the last group of the day in the third and final round of the Met Open.

title: Ayckbourn's Dark Laughs
description: The drawing-room murder mystery is dusted off and polished in Alan Ayckbourn's new comic thriller, ''Communicating Doors,'' which opened last night at the Variety Arts. The twist in this British import is that the mayhem occurs in a hotel room with a strange set of doors that act as a time machine. The guests include both killer and victims over a 40-year period. Mary-Louise Parker, right, is irresistible as a dominatrix who stumbles into the role of heroine.

title: Yankees Find the World Can Be Far From Perfect
description: A square brown trash bin rests in the middle of the visitor's clubhouse here, and as Joe Girardi prepared to toss his paper plate after the Yankees' thoroughly distasteful loss and post-game meal tonight, some special garbage caught his eye.

title: Except for Israel, Mideast Is Notably Silent on Strikes
description: Israel was quick to congratulate the United States tonight for its missile attacks on suspected terrorist bases, but the early reaction from many other governments in the Middle East was a notable silence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELMANOVICH, JULIA, M.D.
description: ZELMANOVICH-Julia, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the untimely death of Dr. Julia Zelmanovich, 26, as a result of a tragic accident. Dr. Zelmanovich, an outstanding resident physician in the Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Women's Health, was admired and respected for her dedication to her work and remarkable sense of compassion for her patients. She will long be remembered for her smile, energy and upbeat personality. Our sincere and heartfelt condolences are extended to her parents and her entire family. Spencer Foreman, M.D., Pres. Irwin R. Merkatz, M.D., Chair Dept of Obstetrics & Gynecology and Women's Health Montefiore Medical Center

title: Hard Bargain: Buying a Baby, Selling a Soul
description: Stockard Channing does not look at home in a Louisiana trailer park. Which is a point ''The Baby Dance'' wants to make. There she is, as Rachel Luckman, a well-dressed Hollywood executive, making her way through the trash-strewn yards, fending off barking dogs, avoiding the stares of half-naked men who are working on a car. Finally she reaches the trailer of Al LeFauve (Richard Lineback), an unemployed pipe fitter, and his wife, Wanda (Laura Dern), who is very pregnant with their fifth child. Rachel is there to buy their baby.

title: Ferraro Turns Testy With TV Interviewer Over Repeated Requests to Debate
description: A routine television interview with Geraldine A. Ferraro turned into an on- and off-air scrap yesterday as her host repeatedly pressed Ms. Ferraro about why she was declining invitations to debate in the Senate Democratic primary race.

title: Looking at India's Upheaval From the Inside (and the Side)
description: In the beginning, photography was referred to as the handmaid of art. It might have been called the valet of history as well, for it promised to serve its times, make them presentable and arrange for them to appear unwilted onstage before large audiences in very long plays. These services have been something of a mixed blessing. The handmaid eventually tried to usurp her mistress's place, and the valet often sent history into the world naked.

Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Summer hours vary for galleries and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Corinne G. Levin, 68, an Advocate for Children
description: Corinne Greenberg Levin, an advocate for children and the director of the independent Teacher Center in New Haven since its founding 27 years ago, died on July 27 at Connecticut Hospice in Branford, Conn. A New Haven resident, she was 68.

title: Heart Groups Urge Caution On Viagra
description: Viagra, the impotence pill, may be dangerous to more people than previously reported, a finding that has prompted two cardiology groups to urge doctors to exercise caution when prescribing the drug.

title: At the Movies; How Fox Got Its Groove Back
description: A black flag wasn't quite fluttering at 20th Century Fox last summer, but the mood at the studio was decidedly bleak. ''Speed 2: Cruise Control,'' the adventure-action sequel to ''Speed,'' was the biggest disaster of the summer. And the studio had sunk more than $140 million in ''Titanic,'' whose cost had run amok. The word was that Rupert Murdoch, who owns the studio, would chop off a head or two.

title: Man With Mission Takes On the U.S. At Far-Flung Sites
description: From his Afghan redoubt, Osama bin Laden has declared war on American interests everywhere, fueled by rage against American power in the Middle East, and backed, United States officials say, by an international network of terrorists and companies.

title: Residential Real Estate; For Visitors Who Stay Awhile, New Residences
description: Hoping to capture a piece of both the strong housing and lodging markets in Manhattan, developers of apartment buildings are offering extended-stay residences as well as traditional apartments under one roof.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUTOY, LOUIS
description: KRUTOY-Louis. 57. Of Scottsdale, Arizona, died August 20. The President of Harbor View Financial Services, Inc., Hoboken, NJ. He leaves his wife Andra, sons Howard and Ryan, daughter Jessica, daughter-in-law Sharon, and brother Herb. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. Services will be held on Sunday in Scottsdale, Arizona. It is the family's wish that in lieu of flowers contributions be sent to The Leukemia Society of America.

title: For 'Twelfth Night,' a Daxophone, Tibetan Bowls and an Indian Drum
description: Early in the process of composing incidental music and songs for the Lincoln Center Theater's current production of Shakespeare's ''Twelfth Night,'' Jeanine Tesori went to a downtown percussion store with her orchestrator, Rick Bassett, and made an unusual request.

title: ABN Amro Earnings Up 20% in First Half
description: ABN Amro Holdings N.V., Europe's eighth- largest bank, said yesterday that its profit rose 20 percent in the first half, as income from loans and trading offset higher bad debt provisions for its loans in Asia. ABN Amro said net income rose to 2.445 billion guilders ($1.21 billion) in the period, from 2.038 billion in the first half of 1997.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Dining section on Wednesday about the popularity of the peekytoe crab and an article in the House & Home section on Thursday about a summer cottage in Maine misstated the name of an island in Penobscot Bay. It is Deer Isle, not Deer Island.

title: Arvidsjaur Journal; Sweden's Frozen North Can Be Balmy for Business
description: There is a new item these days in the display cases of woolen Laplander hats, elk skins and boldly colored wood carvings in Arvidsjaur's open-air market. Boosters of this town near the Arctic Circle hope it is a talisman of their future.

title: Saving the Ruble
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITICS OF CLINTON SUPPORT ATTACKS
description: The most cherished axiom of American foreign policy is that politics stops at the water's edge, meaning that political opponents support the President when missiles are flying. Today, it mostly worked, but the challenge of President Clinton's latest crisis crystallized when some critics uncharacteristically cried foul.

title: Access Fees and the Internet
description: A Federal appeals court decision this week should benefit Internet users and the fast-growing electronic information industry by holding down connection costs. The decision upheld the authority of the Federal Communications Commission to exempt Internet service providers from interstate access charges paid to local phone companies. The issue was raised in a lawsuit by telecommunications companies challenging Federal regulations intended to deregulate the industry. The lengthy decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit allows the agency to get on with that task without dampening growth in the electronic information sector.

title: People
description: * Chris Clark, a senior vice president at GCI Group, New York, part of Grey Advertising, was promoted to head a new unit, GCI Interactive, as managing director.

title: Striking Against Terrorism
description: The United States has every right to attack suspected terrorists if there is credible evidence showing that they were involved in attacks against American citizens or were planning such attacks. That seems to be the case in the missile attacks ordered by President Clinton in the Sudan and Afghanistan, an impression strengthened by quick support from House Speaker Newt Gingrich, Senator Orrin Hatch and other leading Republicans. But since these attacks were ordered from a White House weakened by scandal, Mr. Clinton needs to take extra care to reassure the country that the attacks were not timed to help repair his shaken Presidency.

title: Foreign Turmoil Drives Investors From Dow to Treasuries
description: Turmoil in overseas economies sent investors fleeing stocks for the safety of bonds yesterday, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond to another new low.

title: Correction: AIDS in Africa
Family Fare; Making a Splash In Brooklyn
description: Compared with the Caribbean, Coney Island is not a prime spot for scuba diving. But the lack of tropical fish and spectacular coral hasn't fazed the Urban Park Rangers; they have other treasures in mind.

title: Youth March Organizers Sue the City
description: The organizers of a planned Million Youth March sued the city in Federal court yesterday, saying that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's refusal to grant them a permit to hold the event in Harlem next month was both unconstitutional and reflective of the Mayor's discriminatory treatment of the city's black residents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, SELMA
description: SHERMAN-Selma.The Rabbi, Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst, NY and its Affiliates express deepest sympathy on the passing of its member. We grieve with the family on its loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Allan Kroningold, President

title: TWINLAB AGREES TO BUY MAKER OF IRONMAN NUTRITION BAR
description: The Twinlab Corporation, which sells about 1,000 nutritional products in 43 countries, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held PR Nutrition Inc. for $39.1 million in stock to expand its line of Ironman Triathlon products. PR Nutrition, based in San Diego, employs 45 people and had $16.5 million in sales last year. Its PR Ironman Triathlon Bar accounts for about 95 percent of its sales and is marketed to athletes and people who want to lose weight. Twinlab, based in Hauppage, N.Y., had sales of $213 million last year. Its stock rose 25 cents, to $34.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBEL, JOHN
description: LOBEL-John. On August 19, 1998. In Pompano Beach Fl. after a long illness. Beloved husband of Lili. Loving father of John and Peter. Fond father-in-law of Jannie and Diane. Dear grandpa of Joseph and Samuel. He will be mourned.

title: Fed Voted 10 to 1 in July to Keep Rates the Same
description: Federal Reserve policy makers voted 10 to 1 at their meeting on July 1 to leave the overnight bank lending rate unchanged at 5.50 percent, minutes of the session released today showed.

title: Insurers Set $17.8 Billion Stock Deal
description: In a merger of insurance giants, American International Group, a world leader in corporate insurance, agreed yesterday to buy SunAmerica Inc., a pioneer in selling investments for retirement, for stock valued at $17.8 billion.

title: McGwire Hits Historic 50th and Keeps Going
description: Mark McGwire was the main attraction on a glorious baseball stage in New York last night and was basically expected to perform like some sort of home run-hitting robot. Push a button, then watch him swing his bat and blast another homer. Actually, he somehow made it look simple.

title: What a Difference the News Makes: Clinton as Commander in Chief
description: After a week of what felt like nonstop talk about sex, ties and audiotape involving President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky, television screens were overtaken yesterday by news of a different shock value.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDGAR, MARY JANE
description: EDGAR-Mary Jane. 80. Of Kennett Square, Pa. Died Wednesday August 12, 1998 at Kendal at Longwood, Kennett Square, Pa. Wife of the late Robert W. Edgar, Sr. Born in Chicago, Ill., daughter of the late Harry and Laurene Rutledge Hoppe. She had lived in Kennett Square since 1992 coming from New York, N.Y. She was a member of the St. George Episcopal Church, Flushing, N.Y. She was a homemaker and worked for Dupont before her marriage. She was a former educator. She graduated from Oberlin College, Oh. with a B.A. in Fine Arts and she was a former Trustee for the Bowne House in Flushing, Queens, N.Y. Mother of Robert W. Edgar Jr of Mendota Heights, Minn. and Sarah Elizabeth Edgar of Rego Park, N.Y. Sister of John R. Hoppe, Long Beach, Ind. Grandmother of Brynne Rutledge Edgar and Rachel Warren Edgar, both of Mendota Heights, Minn. Services and interment will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Bowne House Historical Society, 345 Hudson St, NY, NY 10014. Info: Dellavecchia Reilly and Smith Funeral Home, West Chester, Pa.

title: 1,877 Summonses Issued In Attempted Drug Deals
description: Six months after Jersey City officials authorized the police to ticket people caught trying to buy illegal drugs, the department announced yesterday that it had issued 1,877 summonses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDE, SYLVIA
description: SEIDE-Sylvia, Miami Beach, FL, formerly Cedarhurst, NY. Beloved wife late Jack Seide; loving mother Myra and Carl Wapner, Lewis Seide, Gary and Laura Seide. Grandma Sylvia to Joy and Mark Schustek, John and Joan Wapner, Michael and Jack Wapner; Melissa and Andrew Rubin, William and Kathy Seide. Loving great-grandmother.

description: In boxing there are lists of the top boxers and lists of the boxers the top boxers will not fight. Among welterweights, Jose Luis Lopez, ranked No. 2 by the World Boxing Association, is at the top of both lists.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS AGAIN. Japan's currency rose for the fourth consecutive day after a top Finance Ministry official said it was still too weak, raising the threat of intervention. In New York, the dollar fell to 143.19 yen, from 143.93.

description: Prosecutors dropped assault and related charges yesterday against a restaurant bouncer who was the only person charged in a June brawl involving dozens of firefighters.

description: MARK McGWIRE is a tough guy to budge. Pitchers can't knock him off the plate, and inquisitors can't throw him off his stance on the home run record.

title: Tobacco Gave $140,000 To Rowland, Report Says
description: Gov. John G. Rowland, who this year opposed a bill to increase the state tax on cigarettes, has accepted nearly $140,000 in contributions from tobacco interests since he was elected in 1994, according to a report released today by a public-interest group.

title: Wagging Tongues in 'Incredibly Cynical Times'
description: When the news that the United States had bombed terrorist targets swept through her midtown Manhattan office yesterday, Valerie David felt a predictable knot of emotions: sorrow for any loss of lives, concern about the precision of the attacks, fear about where this would all lead.

title: Thanks to Overseas Sales, Honda Reports Big Profit Gain
description: The Honda Motor Company is benefiting more than ever from its global reach, a distinction once ridiculed by domestically focused competitors in Japan's automotive industry.

title: Home Video; Chiller Theater For Primates
description: In 1969, Richard Zanuck was trying hard to sign up Charlton Heston for a sequel being made by 20th Century Fox, which was run by Mr. Zanuck. A year earlier, Mr. Heston had starred as the astronaut Taylor in Fox's highly successful ''Planet of the Apes.'' Now his services were badly needed for ''Beneath the Planet of the Apes,'' the second installment of what would become a five-film series.

title: Police Shoot Man Holding Machete; Family Says They Broke In Like Robbers
description: A legally blind 65-year-old man who the police said was wielding a machete was shot early yesterday by officers searching for guns and explosives at his son's Staten Island apartment, the police said.

title: Collector Market Gets a High-Profile Lift
description: THE stock market may be gyrating, but the classic car market is rocking and rolling.

title: Sehorn Sidelined for Year, So Giants Lose Twice
description: The Jets won their annual preseason game with the Giants tonight, 27-23, at Giants Stadium. But for the Giants and their fans, the game will not be remembered for how it ended but for how it began, when cornerback Jason Sehorn sustained a season-ending knee injury returning the opening kickoff.

title: Hartmann Wins Met Open For Fourth Title of the Year
description: Rick Hartmann, who arrived in the metropolitan area six years ago after playing for 10 years on the European tour, is starting to spread fear among golfers in the area, the way Bruce Zabriski and Darrell Kestner have done for the last decade.

title: Political Chess at City Hall
description: As Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Council Speaker Peter Vallone have made clear in recent months, terrific gamesmanship does not always make for great government. In this case, the Mayor and the Speaker are locked in a grudge match that started over their disagreement about moving Yankee Stadium. It is time for both men to back down before this unnecessary contest harms New York City.

description: The United States attacked targets in Afghanistan and the Sudan with roughly 75 cruise missiles fired from Navy ships in the Arabian and Red Seas timed to strike their targets simultaneously, senior Administration and military officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCALPIN, FRANK
description: McALPIN-Frank. In accordance with the Divine Will of our Heavenly Father, Frank McAlpin departed this life on August 15, 1998 at 7:15 am, at Wayne Nursing Home, Bronx, New York. Frank McAlpin, the son of the late Evalena and John McAlpin was born on May 3, 1900, in Augusta, Georgia. He received his formal education in the Georgia Public School system. He was the eldest son of four children, his sisters, Mildred and Evelyn, and brother John all preceded him in death. In the early forties, Frank came to New York where he once again met ''his Pearl'', who would later become his wife. After a short courtship, Frank and Pearl were married on March 22, 1947 at St. Mark's Church. Frank worked for the New York Times where he retired in 1961. Then he enjoyed his favorite pass time to the fullest; baseball. He leaves to mourn his devoted wife Pearl, numerous relatives and friends.
