description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, NACHUME
description: MILLER-Nachume. Artist, teacher, husband, father and friend on August 20, 1998 at age 49. Born in Frankfurt, Germany, immigrated to Israel in 1950. He came to New York in 1966 to study at the School of Visual Arts where he became a much loved member of the faculty, teaching painting and drawing in 1977. A prolific artist who has worked in almost all of painting's genres, his works are in the permanent collections of major museums and galleries throughout the world, noteably The Museum of Modern Art and The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City. An extraordinarily devoted husband and father, Nachume is survived by his wife Ruth and beloved sons Matthew 18, Danny 16 and Adam 12. He touched all who knew him with his exquisite intellect, visionary artistry and enourmous humanity. The world was a better place with him in it. Funeral 10am Friday August 21st at Riverside Nassau Funeral Home, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, LI. MILLER-Nachume. You will always remain in our hearts. Liliane and David Benrimon and children

title: Lincoln Center Homecoming for Jazz Lover
description: ONE of the last times we heard from Gordon J. Davis was in January 1983, when he abruptly resigned as New York City's very popular Parks Commissioner and left reporters to wonder, as he wryly puts it, if he was ''terminally ill or about to be indicted.'' Neither scenario was remotely true, but from then on, Mr. Davis's public life of promise and privilege -- would he run for mayor, go to Washington, lead an institution? -- took a quiet and private path.

title: G.O.P. Reticence Helps Clinton Play the Victim; Blameless Republicans?
description: To the Editor:

title: Moderate Republicans in Region Warm Up to Gingrich
description: In 1996, Democratic candidates across the nation were reading from the same play book. Attack the Contract With America. Call every Republican a radical conservative. And whenever possible, accuse opponents of being foot soldiers in Speaker Newt Gingrich's rebel brigade.

title: U.S. Says It Has Strong Evidence Of Threat Justifying Retaliation
description: The American strikes in Afghanistan and the Sudan today came after United States intelligence and law enforcement agencies had gathered what officials described as the strongest evidence ever obtained in a major terrorist case.

title: Century 21 Names Lowe as Its Agency
description: The Century 21 Real Estate Corporation unit of the Cendant Corporation has unexpectedly named Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York to handle the creative and media planning portions of its advertising account, with billings estimated at $40 million. The decision, made yesterday, came without a review.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RADIOMETER A/S, -- Bronshoj, Denmark, a manufacturer of measurement and analytical instruments, bought Sendx Medical Inc., Carlsbad, Calif., a maker of blood analysis systems, for $30 million.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Different Focus, Different Profit Figures
description: As the stock market struggles to get back on its feet, investors are focused on corporate earnings, buoyed by reports that profits among the biggest companies are still rising, albeit slowly.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUXTON, ALAN
description: BUXTON-Alan. August 21, 1996. Those we have loved really never leave us. They live on forever in our hearts. R.

title: A Pivotal Point In Inquiry for Bear, Stearns
description: Prosecutors have been granted a court order that temporarily halts witness testimony in cases surrounding the failure of the A. R. Baron brokerage firm, a signal that a grand jury investigation into Bear, Stearns & Company's role in the collapse is reaching a critical point.

title: Air Foley Takes Off And Flight Is Smooth
description: After a summer of inconsistency, Glenn Foley tonight finally produced the quick-strike effort that Coach Bill Parcells expected in naming him the Jets' starting quarterback.

title: The Sluggers Awaken
description: For a moment there it appeared that baseball's most hallowed record -- Roger Maris's 61 home runs in a single season, set in 1961 -- might be safe for yet another year. Nobody was throwing hittable pitches to Maris's two main threats, Sammy Sosa of the Chicago Cubs and Mark McGwire of the St. Louis Cardinals, and both men seemed to be tiring as the season entered its final months. Sosa hit 20 home runs in June, only 9 in July. By his own account, McGwire had been little more than an ''ornament'' in the last seven weeks, with 45 strikeouts and only 10 homers since July 1.

title: 2d Man Is Charged In Assault on Woman
description: A second suspect has been charged with sexually assaulting and robbing a 62-year-old woman in her home last week.

title: Canadian Court Rules Quebec Cannot Secede on Its Own
description: A simple vote in Quebec is not enough to allow the French-speaking province to legally separate from the rest of Canada, the country's Supreme Court said yesterday in a landmark opinion widely seen as fortifying the federal Government's efforts to keep the United States' closest ally from breaking up.

title: Backpedaling, Comically, Into a Menacing Future
description: Don't even think of putting up a struggle: Mary-Louise Parker is irresistible in ''Communicating Doors,'' Alan Ayckbourn's comic thriller of men with blood on their hands and women with time on theirs.

title: Kennedy Center Names 6 Performance Honorees
description: Shirley Temple, the little girl who saved a movie studio from failure during the Depression, and Willie Nelson, who helped reinvent country music, were among six people named today to receive the Kennedy Center's annual honors in the performing arts.

title: Phil Leeds, 82, Comic on Stage and Screen
description: Phil Leeds, a durable funnyman who began his pursuit of laughs as a stand-up comic in the 1930's and went on to work in theater, films and television, died on Sunday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNELL, MILDRED KING
description: CONNELL-Mildred King. On August 14. Beloved wife of the late Dr. John F. Connell. Dear mother of Patricia Connell Shakow of Kensington, MD, Peter J. Connell of Chevy Chase, MD, Sister Kathleen Connell, RSHM and Kevin M. Connell of New York. Another son, John F. Connell, Jr., died in 1988. She is also survived by 11 grandchildren and a great-grandson. Friends may call at Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills on Friday August 21 from 2-5 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Mercy Church, 70-01 Kessel St., Forest Hills on Sat., August 22 at 9:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINER, PETER H.
description: KAMINER-Peter H. The partners and employees of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts mourn the loss of Peter H. Kaminer, a partner of the firm for 40 years and our managing partner for 20 years. We will miss his extraordinary legal skills, his total devotion to the firm, the marvelous companionship which he provided, and his dedication to public service which set an example for all of us. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his son, Stevenson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DR. ELI
description: COHEN-Dr. Eli of Scarsdale New York. On August 18, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Natalie Cohen (nee Schreiber). Cherished father of Judith and David. Loving grandfather of Floren and Jason. Graveside services at Mount Hope Cemetery, Jackson Avenue, Hastings on Hudson, NY, Sunday, August 23 at noon.

title: Vorobiev Is Retained
description: The Rangers re-signed left wing Vladimir Vorobiev, who spent most of last season in the minors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, ROSE ELAINE
description: ALBERT-Rose Elaine. On August 20, at age 72. Beloved wife of Stanley, cherished mother of Diane Roskind and husband Robert, and Robert Albert and wife Janet. Loving grandmother of Dina Walsh and husband David, Scott Roskind and wife Cindy, and Andrea and Bradley Albert. Loving great-grandmother of Haley and Emily Walsh. Devoted sister of Louis Masur, Jr. Beloved mother to many others who knew her.

title: Bronx Man Charged In Fatal Stabbing In Greenwich Village
description: A computer programmer who went to a Greenwich Village hospital for treatment of gashes shortly after a man was stabbed to death has been arrested in the Tuesday morning killing, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCHUCK, CECELE
description: PINCHUCK-Cecele. On August 20, 1998. Beloved wife of David Pinchuck. Dear mother of Howard Pinchuck and the late Carole Bronson. Cherished grandmother of Meryl, Eileen, Margot, Michelle and Michael. And adored greatgrandmother. Graveside services today 11AM at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY

title: Extremes With Impossible Schemes
description: As he is about to walk onstage, an aging Frank Sinatra stops to light a cigarette, or more precisely to have one lighted for him. ''Match me,'' he tells a male lackey, only to have an off-camera woman with a sugary voice give him a light instead. ''Thanks, doll,'' he tells her, walking on. You can hoot at this style as irredeemably tacky, or view it as the essence of retro cool. You can even see it as both. Those possibilities suggest the breadth of appeal behind the HBO film ''The Rat Pack,'' which recreates a dizzyingly energetic, near-mythic phase of American culture. As anthropology or as sheer fun, a project called ''The Rat Pack'' offers immense promise. Even a misguided ''Rat Pack,'' like this one, holds some fascination.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Are Giants and Jets Willing to Sacrifice?
description: A few days ago, the Giants defensive lineman Keith Hamilton, one of the key players on the best young defense in pro football, committed a dual no-no. First, he missed his scheduled appointment with team trainers for treatment of an injury. That amounted to a fine of more than $1,000. Then Hamilton was late for a meeting. The coaches were not happy, so after scolding Hamilton, they fined him again. In all, Hamilton paid thousands of dollars in fines within a span of hours.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Treasury Bond Yields Fall As Investors Flee Stocks

title: A Test of Wills Over Drug Legislation
description: It was called Proposition 200 and it seemed straight-forward enough when it appeared on Arizona ballots in the fall of 1996. Backed by a well-financed grass-roots organization that called itself Arizonans for Drug Policy Reform, it proposed allowing doctors to prescribe marijuana and other illegal drugs for medical use by grievously ill and dying patients.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAX, GORDON
description: SAX-Gordon. 8/21/58-3/11/96 ''May your heart always be joyful/ May your song always be sung/ May you stay forever young.'' Today, your 40th Birthday, and every day, you are remembered and loved. Rene

title: INTEL STOCK FALLS 4 PERCENT AS ANALYST LOWERS RATING
description: Shares of the Intel Corporation fell 4 percent yesterday after an influential Merrill Lynch & Company analyst cut his investment rating on the company, the world's largest chip maker, to ''neutral'' from ''accumulate.'' The analyst, Tom Kurlak, said Intel's sales growth was certain to slow in coming years because microprocessor prices were falling as lower-priced personal computers became popular. Intel's stock price fell $3.5625 a share, to $86, in trading of 33.6 million shares, making it the most actively traded issue on United States exchanges.

title: How Can Terror Best Be Combated?
description: In the war against terrorism, experience suggests that any operation, whether an assassination or the sort of strike staged by the United States yesterday, has the quality of damned if you do and damned if you don't.

title: At Shea, Good Seats Were Few and Far Between
description: Hopeful fans began stationing themselves in the suddenly precious seats in the left-field loge section and the even more precious perches in the picnic area in left center field more than one hour before Mark McGwire was scheduled to take batting practice at Shea Stadium yesterday. They arrived early because finding a seat at Shea from which to corral one of McGwire's homers is almost as difficult as sneaking into the bullpen for an inning.

title: Thomas-Robert Ames, 68, Expert on Disabled
description: Thomas-Robert Ames, a New York educator and nationally known authority on the rehabilitation of the mentally retarded and disabled, died on Monday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 68 and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: Observer; Isn't It Rich? Aren't They a Pair?
description: ''I have been watching the most powerful country on earth making an ass of itself.''

title: Chocolate's in the Air, And Kisses Are Free
description: A girlfriend once sent me a greeting card with the message, ''I love you almost as much as chocolate itself.'' After some pondering -- and a handful of chocolate chips -- I resolved to take it positively.

title: Ulster Looks for a Glint of Hope in Reaction to Bombing
description: As Northern Ireland buried eight more victims of a terrorist bombing on Saturday, a guilty hope began to emerge today among officials, analysts and some ordinary people that some good may come of the atrocity.

title: Is It Only About Sex?
description: President Clinton, in his recent battles with Kenneth Starr, has taken the position that at this point the independent counsel is merely delving into his personal life, not investigating possible crimes. ''It is time to stop the pursuit of personal destruction and the prying into private lives and get on with our national life,'' Mr. Clinton said in his address Monday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROO, GISELA
description: KROO-Gisela. On August 20th, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Alexander. Loving mother of Katherina. Dear mother-in-law of Paul Grunfeld. Adored grandmother of Nicole, Natalie and Gabrielle. Service today, August 21st, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Go Mikey Go Romps
description: The Albany Handicap for 3-year-old horses foaled in New York State was won at Saratoga Race Course yesterday by Go Mikey Go, who swept home by 14 lengths in front of Ashley's a Hitter.

title: New York City Tightens Its Security, Just in Case
description: Once they received word yesterday that the United States had bombed targets in Afghanistan and the Sudan, New York City officials immediately tightened security in a routine that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani acknowledged has become all too familiar in recent years.

title: A Hard Line Will Stop Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Barnes & Noble Web Unit to Go Public
description: With competition intensifying among electronic booksellers, Barnes & Noble Inc. announced yesterday that it would sell shares to the public of its money-losing on-line venture, which trails in sales behind the pioneering leader, Amazon.com.

title: Mildred E.B. Smith, Specialist In Agriculture, Is Dead at 99
description: Mildred Elizabeth Buller Smith, who cut a singular swath through the 20th century by, among other things, picking apples and digging potatoes for the Women's Land Army in World War I, riding herd on New England milk prices for the Office of Price Administration in World War II and becoming a Connecticut television celebrity as a consumer price specialist, died on Aug. 12 at a nursing home in Hartford. She was 99, and it seems almost beside the point to note that she had been an agricultural economist for the University of Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGEN, STUART
description: REGEN-Stuart. Dear Shaun, Barbara, David and Richard, our hearts are with you at this time of deepest sorrow. Stuart's courage, determination and enthusiasm for life and accomplishment will continue to live as a guiding object lesson to all of us. May you take comfort in inspiring memories of Stuart's wonderful impact on his family, friends and the art world. The Goldberg family Arthur, Carol, Mark Aaron Beth and Josh Nash

title: Afghan and Sudanese Immigrants Doubt Merit of Attacks
description: Yes, they thought that the embassy bombings in East Africa constituted a crime of the lowest order. And yes, they thought that Osama bin Laden, a wealthy Saudi who has publicly threatened a holy war against the United States, came across as a shady character with an inordinate amount of power.

title: The Passions That Seethe Under the Orderly Surface
description: In the dead of night, a husband, inflamed by suspicion, returns home early from a fishing outing. In the bedroom, his beautiful wife, who sent him off with a neatly wrapped snack and wished him good luck, moans naked and ecstatic against the body of another man.

title: California Acts to Bar Gags in Defect Cases
description: CALIFORNIA motorists who obtain restitution from auto makers for defective vehicles may no longer have to promise they will stay quiet as part of their settlements.

title: PNC BANK AGREES TO BUY HILLIARD LYONS FOR $275 MILLION
description: The PNC Bank Corporation, a bank holding company based in Pittsburgh, agreed yesterday to buy Hilliard Lyons, a privately owned securities firm, for $275 million. PNC will pay for Hilliard with a combination of cash and PNC stock. Hilliard Lyons, based in Louisville, Ky., has 84 offices in 12 Midwestern and Southeastern states. PNC said Hilliard Lyons had focused its business on delivering high-end brokerage services and investment management expertise to affluent clients. The firm has about 550 brokers and money managers and more than 200,000 customers. Total customer assets at Hilliard Lyons are more than $22 billion, the company said. The deal was announced after PNC's shares closed at $48.9375, down 56.25 cents.

title: New Backyard in Lower Manhattan; Model Parks Along Hudson Prove Popular (and Populous)
description: Kate Young lives in the East Village but likes to walk over to the meticulously kept lawn outside Battery Park City to read. Marilyn Smith makes weekly visits to the esplanade from her Greenwich Village home. And Daryl Richardson of Chelsea says he likes the chain of parks along the Hudson in lower Manhattan better than Central Park.

title: A 'Tete' Gallery, From Regal to Roguish
description: Five summers ago, Evelyne Z. Daitz, director of the Witkin Gallery in SoHo, assembled a show with the title ''On the Elbow.'' More recently, convinced that ''other parts of the body need to be addressed'' and inspired by Graciela Iturbide's memorable portrait of an imposing woman in Juchitan, Oaxaca, wearing a headdress of live iguanas, Ms. Daitz decided that an exhibit with an ''on the head'' theme would be in order.

title: Feud Between Two Foot Doctors Led to Arson, Authorities Say
description: For 15 years they worked side by side in their Queens practice, cutting corns, treating bunions and ministering to stubborn cases of athlete's foot. But in the past year, Dr. Irwin Sater, 65, decided to put his three and a half decades in podiatry behind him, so he sold the practice to his junior partner and moved to Florida.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Our actions were aimed at fanatics and killers who wrap murder in the cloak of righteousness, and in so doing, profane the great religion in whose name they claim to act.''

title: Venezuelan Stocks Tumble On Fears of a Devaluation
description: Venezuelan stocks plunged 9.5 percent today, the biggest one-day drop in nearly four years, as the market here was rattled by worries that the Government might devalue its currency.

title: $10 and Under
description: Who says you can't eat cheaply in New York City? Here are a dozen restaurants where entrees, and often full meals, can be had for $10 and under. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Wild, Woolly, Maybe Wondrous
description: Hugh Hysell was determined to crack this fringe thing. Having been wait-listed by the organizers of the New York International Fringe Festival with a not-very-novel idea, a revival of ''The Night Larry Kramer Kissed Me,'' the aspiring Manhattan director racked his brain for a project that might be more in tune with the festival's ebullient spirit, its mandate to, above all else, make it new.

title: Surprise Showdown Looms in Wyoming
description: Wyoming is one of the nation's most Republican states, with the Grand Old Party enjoying a 2 to 1 registration edge over Democrats. So the odds are that the state's Republican Governor, Jim Geringer, will handily win a second term this fall.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Going downstairs at Blue Ribbon Bakery is a little like descending into the catacombs, a dark and mysterious space. It is a sensory experience, the room dominated by a brick oven so large you can easily imagine pushing a witch right into it. Arrive at the right time and you can eat your meal while watching the bakers as they work.

title: FUND AMERICAN ACQUIRES REST OF FOLKSAMERICA HOLDING
description: Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc. has acquired the 50 percent of the FolksAmerica Holding Company that it did not already own for $169.1 million in cash. Fund American said yesterday that it had bought the stake from four European companies: the Folksam Mutual General Insurance Company of Sweden; Wiener Staeditsche Allegmeine Versicherung A.G. of Austria; P&V Assurances S.C. of Belgium and Samvirke Skadeforsikring A.S. of Norway. FolksAmerica, based in New York, is the parent company of FolksAmerica Reinsurance. Fund American, based in White River, Vt., is an insurance and financial services holding company. It has assets of about $2.03 billion.

title: G.O.P. Reticence Helps Clinton Play the Victim; Goes to Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: From Fluff to 'Eternity': The Many Faces of Sinatra on Screen
description: One of the more unlikely romantic couplings to be found in a 1950's Hollywood movie was the pairing of Frank Sinatra as a gaunt, impoverished young composer from New York City and Doris Day as his indefatigably chipper apple-cheeked Connecticut dream girl. Ms. Day's character, who is engaged to another man throughout much of the film, is the singer with a family orchestra whose perky togetherness and taste for kitsch vaguely suggests a tacky Connecticut equivalent of the Von Trapps.

title: Enigmatic Portraits of Teen-Agers Free of All Context
description: One of the legacies of late 1960's avant-gardism was to shift meaning from product to process. The doing of something, like splattering molten lead into a corner or following a stranger through the city, became as significant as what the final artwork, if any, might look like.

title: Venator Reports Another Quarterly Loss
description: Venator Group Inc., the country's largest retailer of athletic shoes and clothing, yesterday reported its second consecutive quarterly loss, hurt by weak sales, which forced it to mark down prices.

title: A Nighttime Paddle Around Manhattan: Time, Tide and Tired
description: Sure, the waters of Baja are beautiful. So are those of Alaska, the Pacific Northwest and dozens of other world-renowned paddling destinations attracting thousands of avid kayakers each year. But the waters of Manhattan, with its lights and contrasts, might be the most beautiful of all.

title: New Video Release
description: The Apostle

title: U.N. Council Renews Sanctions After Iraq Expresses Defiance
description: After a defiant outburst from Baghdad today, the Security Council voted unanimously to renew economic sanctions against Iraq, and the United States representative to the United Nations warned that the sanctions might never be lifted.

title: Urban Singles in a Bossa Nova Mood
description: What could be more unpromising in the era of the yuppie romantic comedy than a movie about two attractive 30-ish urbanites drifting through the city and just missing each other until fate finally allows them to connect? Throw in some half-baked mystical notions that these two lonely hearts are truly destined to be joined and you have what sounds like a hard-to-swallow sugarcoated cliche.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, THOMAS, ROBERT DR.
description: AMES-Thomas-Robert Dr. Dear friend, esteemed colleague, founding member. His enthusiasm for learning, teaching and communicating was a model for all of us working in the field of disabilities. We shall miss him. Dr. Harold Michal-Smith, Pres. Board Members United World Partnership on Developmental Disabilities

title: Current Account Surplus Triples in Taiwan
description: Taiwan recorded a current account surplus of $753 million in the second quarter of this year, more than triple the surplus of $232 million in the first quarter, the nation's central bank announced yesterday. The surplus was $1.4 billion in the same period last year.

title: New Jersey May Cancel Staten Island Rail Link
description: A half-finished freight rail link between Staten Island and New Jersey was dealt a setback yesterday when an official in Union County, N.J., moved to pull out of the joint project, saying that changes in the plan meant that New York City now stood to reap nearly all the benefits.

title: U.S. CRUISE MISSILES STRIKE SUDAN AND AFGHAN TARGETS TIED TO TERRORIST NETWORK
description: Dozens of American cruise missiles struck targets in Afghanistan and the Sudan today in what President Clinton described as an act of self-defense against imminent terrorist plots and of retribution for the bombings of American Embassies in East Africa two weeks ago.

title: People Who Dance With Vampires May Find Thrills in a New Vein
description: So much fake blood drips, gushes, explodes and congeals in ''Blade,'' a hyperkinetic science-fiction horror film inspired by a popular comic book, that there's hardly a scene that isn't drenched in red. The crimson tide first rises in the movie's opening (and wittiest scene) in which a young man is escorted by a sinister-looking woman in a red wig into a disco hidden behind a metal door in the back of a meatpacking plant.

title: 'On Stage and Off'
description: The ''On Stage and Off'' column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Raids by U.S. Agents and Tirana Police Reportedly Thwarted Attack on Embassy
description: In a series of lightning raids with the Albanian secret police this summer, American intelligence agents appear to have thwarted a bomb plot against the American Embassy here. They also seem to have broken up a ring of Egyptian Islamic terrorists using this nation's anarchy to set up a base.

title: Antiques; Seeing Beauty In the Bug On the Wall
description: Salvador Dali used to take live beetles to lunch with him at the St. Regis. He kept them in a clear plastic box on the table and watched, riveted, as they navigated mounds of sand. He found them more interesting than his companions. Vladimir Nabokov loved butterflies and was expert at catching them; he gave them names like Karner Blue and Satyr I and II. He may have taken his cue from the Surrealist Andre Breton, who mounted boxes of butterflies on the walls of his Paris apartment in the 1920's. Victorians, like the British aristocrat in the film ''Angels and Insects,'' invited young men who had scoured the globe for natural specimens to their homes.

title: U.S. Travelers Warned of Perils
description: Following are excerpts from a State Department advisory issued today on Americans traveling or living abroad:

title: Lewinsky Again Faces Jurors as Starr Seeks To Compare Accounts
description: In her second and probably final appearance before a grand jury here, Monica S. Lewinsky offered more specifics today about her sexual relationship with President Clinton and the gifts he gave her as prosecutors sought to draw distinctions between her testimony and that of the President only three days ago, lawyers close to the case said.

title: G.O.P. Reticence Helps Clinton Play the Victim; Starr's Next Task
description: To the Editor:

title: Conagra Expands Links to Grey
description: Conagra Inc. has expanded its relationship with Grey Advertising in New York by naming the agency to handle advertising for its Healthy Choice line of food products with lower-fat, lower-sodium recipes. The account, with billings estimated at $40 million, has been handled since the products' introduction in 1988 by Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis, which is majority owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the number of black law students at the University of California at Berkeley misstated the given name of the dean at the Boalt Hall School of Law there. She is Herma Hill Kay, not Herman.

title: James Carter, 99, an International Banker
description: James Prescott Carter, an international banker and economic consultant who also bred Aberdeen Angus cattle, died on Aug. 10 at his home in Keene, Va. He was 99 years old.

title: Bayer Profit Fell 14% in Second Quarter
description: Bayer A.G., the German chemical and pharmaceutical company, reported yesterday that its second-quarter profits fell an unexpected 13.9 percent. Bayer said its net income fell to 870 million marks ($486 million) from 1.01 billion a year earlier. Second-quarter sales fell 1 percent, to 14.05 billion marks.

title: Hospital Fined For Overwork Of Residents
description: As part of a statewide investigation, State Health Department officials fined Brooklyn Hospital Center $14,000 yesterday for overworking young doctors enrolled in its residency training program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELD, JOSEPH S.
description: HELD-Joseph S. Beloved husband of the late Anne. Loving father of Edward and Barbara and the late Dr. Robert Held. Adored grandfather of Alyssa, Marc and Jennifer Held and Halley Ovis, Evan Held and Allison and greatgrandfather. Services 11:30 Friday at ''Boulevard Riverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, N.Y.

title: Denver Journal; 1,000 Miles Away From the Ocean, the Surf Is Up
description: With the Rocky Mountains looming to the west, plumbers at Ocean Journey, a $93 million aquarium scheduled to open next summer, are installing the ultimate faux ocean: an acrylic walk-through tube that will be pounded with waves of salt water while floors vibrate and hidden atomizers spray sea scents.

title: Ex-Investment Banker Is Arrested in Scheme
description: A former investment banker was arrested yesterday on charges that he tried to break into the computer system of a large Wall Street firm and drop in an E-mail message that would support his claim that the company had dismissed him because of his race, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the columnist Mike Barnicle's importance to The Boston Globe misstated the given name of a vice president and assistant to the publisher there. He is Alfred S. Larkin Jr., not Albert.

title: N.H.L. Governors Approve Deal
description: The National Hockey League Board of Governors has approved a five-year, $600 million ABC-ESPN deal that will start with the 1999-2000 season, and the league is expected to announce the pact next week.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: Unabomber's Kin Collect Reward Of $1 Million for Turning Him In
description: David Kaczynski and his wife have been given a $1 million reward from the Justice Department for turning in David's older brother, Theodore, as the Unabomber.

title: Guilty Plea By Mother, 20, In Prom Death
description: In a barely audible, childlike monotone that gave little hint of remorse, the 20-year-old woman who delivered her child during her high school prom last year and then placed his body in a trash can pleaded guilty today to aggravated manslaughter in the child's death.

title: Steel Trader's Woes Hurt Japan Stocks
description: Japanese stocks were lower this morning after Okura & Company, a trading company that sells steel products and machinery, said it would seek protection from creditors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITIN, SUSAN SHETHAR
description: WHITIN-Susan Shethar. Age 95. On August 19, 1998 at home in Little Compton, RI after a stroke. Wife of the late Prentice Shethar and the late Richard C. Whitin. Mother of Norman Shethar of Little Compton and NYC. Stepmother of Prentice Shethar of Amherst, NH; R. Courtenay Whitin of Boston, MA, Thompson M. Whitin of Higganum, CT and Little Compton; Mrs. Charles (Mary) Rockwood of Jekyll Island, GA. Also survived by 15 step-grandchildren and 19 step great-grandchildren. Memorial service Saturday, August 29 at 2 PM in United Congregational Church, The Commons, Little Compton, RI. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to the United Congregational Church or to Sakonnet Preservation Society, c/o Lawrence Anderson, 20 Haffenreffer Lane, Little Compton, RI 02837. Waring-Sullivan Funeral Home, 508-676-1933.

title: United States Fury On 2 Continents
description: SUDDEN STRIKE -- The attack was carried out with 75 ship-launched missiles timed to hit simultaneously. Page A10.

title: An annual survey finds relations deteriorating between clients and their agencies.
description: THE relationship between agencies and advertisers is deteriorating, according to an annual survey, after two years of results that had begun to narrow a yawning chasm between the two sides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, REMSEN N.
description: WOLFF-Remsen N. Also known as Viv Blum. On August 18, 1998. Photographer/writer. Loving father of Sarah and Naomi. Unique friend of Jochem. Service Sunday 8 p.m. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Ave.

title: AUTODESK SAYS IT WILL ACQUIRE DISCREET LOGIC
description: Autodesk Inc., a maker of software for engineers and designers, said yesterday that it would buy Discreet Logic Inc., a maker of special effects for movies and television, for about $520 million in stock. Under the terms of the agreement, Autodesk will issue 0.525 shares for each of Discreet Logic's outstanding shares. Autodesk is trying to expand its product line to include software related to the Internet and multimedia industries. The proposed acquisition was disclosed after United States stock markets had closed. Shares of Autodesk, based in San Rafael, Calif., rose 12.5 cents, to $32.625. Discreet Logic, based in Montreal, rose $2.375, to $16.

title: Salsa's Would-Be Sabado Night Fever
description: Randa Haines's likable mess of a movie ''Dance With Me'' wants so desperately to be the ''Saturday Night Fever'' of salsa that you can feel it huffing and puffing and straining its Achilles tendons to try to detonate the same mixture of sex, alienation and terpsichorean transcendence as the 1977 blockbuster that launched John Travolta into orbit. But despite plenty of smoke and fire, the big liftoff never arrives, and the climactic dance-contest sequence is a botched fizzle.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SILVERMAN, RICHARD
description: SILVERMAN-Richard. 8/21/23-1/ 10/87...It's not far down to paradise. Sailing takes me away to where I always heard it could be. Just a dream. The wind to carry me..

title: On My Mind; The War Against Ireland
description: First Belfast had to be visited again, not to see but to listen. Then, across the border invisible but for surveillance towers, to the Republic of Ireland -- south to Dublin and the city and county of Cork, westward through the mists of Kerry and then east and north across the country toward Dublin again -- all the while listening, listening, to friends and their friends, experiencing a special happiness I never thought I would taste in my lifetime of journalism.

title: N.F.L.: ROUNDUP
description: MIAMI

title: Unhealthy Smog Levels Reported on 28 Days
description: Smog in New Jersey rose to an unhealthy level on 28 days between May 16 and July 31, two more days than during the same testing period last year, according to a report released yesterday by the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group.

title: 3 Guilty of Giving Drugs To East German Athletes
description: Two doctors and a swimming trainer from the former East Germany were convicted and fined here today on charges of systematically feeding growth-enhancing steroids to young athletes, the first convictions in what is expected to be a long line of trials over drugging athletes under the old Communist regime.

title: Sampras and Rafter Exit on Different Notes
description: Tennis icons do not usually have to deal with heckling, but there was plenty of it on the stadium court today at the Pilot Pen International. Faithful fans who had waited a decade for Pete Sampras to make a second appearance at this beleaguered event watched in indignation as the top-seeded player came to a virtual standstill instead of standing up to the spoiler, 100th-ranked Leander Paes of India.

title: A Bit of Barnum on Broadway; Livent Drew In a New Team Despite Juggling Expenses
description: Behind the curtain at Livent Inc., the corporate theater producer, the flamboyant impresario Garth H. Drabinsky did not just produce Tony Award-winning Broadway musicals. He also created a brilliant but mythical setting for his business, a world where much of his famously lavish spending was visible on stage but somehow rarely hurt the company's bottom line.

title: A Hard Line Will Stop Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Gifts to United Way In New York Rise 8%
description: United Way of New York City said yesterday that it had raised $33.8 million in pledges in the year ended June 30, up $2.6 million, or 8.3 percent, from the previous year. The campaign was the third in a row in which donations grew significantly faster than the rate of inflation.

title: Baseball Asking if Umpires Sold Balls From Wells Game
description: Major League Baseball is investigating the possible role of American League umpires in the sale of baseballs used in the perfect game that David Wells of the Yankees pitched against the Minnesota Twins May 17.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, JACK E.
description: ROBBINS-Jack E. Eighty-five, of Palm Beach Gardens Florida. Formerly of Larchmont NY. Devoted husband of the late Marilyn. Loving father of Patricia, Joan Conners and B.J. (Robert Fields). Adored grandfather of Jarett and Brett Conners, Jenna and Jake Fields. Retired President of Poirette Inc. Services Sunday 12:15 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Ave, NYC. ROBBINS-Jack E. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of Jack Robbins, a distinguished former member. On behalf of all Fairview members, we wish to express our deepest condolences to his family. Andrew J. Frankel, President Judith Weil, Secretary

title: For Art, Too, A Summer In the Sun
description: No one can say that New York is outdoor sculpture-challenged. If you travel around the city in summer, in addition to the time-honored monuments that appear at every turn, you will find many a newish work or works ensconced on temporary sites.

title: Ex-Klansman Testifies at Leader's Murder Trial That Klan Was Benevolent
description: Spectators at the trial of a former Klansman accused of ordering the murder of a respected civil rights leader were surprised, to say the least, when another former Klansman described the White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan of Mississippi as a benevolent organization that only existed to give money to the rural poor and pass out fruit baskets at Christmas.

title: Notes Raise Question on What Gore Knew
description: The notes of a senior aide say that at a November 1995 White House meeting where the distinction between hard and soft money was apparently discussed, Vice President Al Gore told the others present to ''count me in'' on making fund-raising telephone calls that are now the subject of a Justice Department review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROZA, STANLEY C., JR.
description: BROZA-Stanley C., Jr. Passed away August 19. Beloved husband of Margot. Father of Jennifer Hanham, Donald and Bruce Goodwin. Grandfather of Amanda, Chloe, Sophie and Oliver. Brother of Elliot Lawrence. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday, August 23 at 3 P.M. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NYC 10021.

title: DIANON SEEKS TO ACQUIRE UROCOR FOR $80 MILLION
description: Dianon Systems Inc., a provider of clinical testing services, offered yesterday to buy Urocor Inc. for $7.50 a share in cash, or about $80 million. Urocor said it was evaluating the proposal. Urocor, based in Oklahoma City, provides products and services used to diagnose and treat urological problems. Dianon, based in Stratford, Conn., conducts lab testing for physicians. Urocor's shares rose to $6.1875, up $1.3125. Dianon's shares fell 62.5 cents, to $6.875.

title: In Shift, Pataki Proposes Major Expansion in Housing for Retarded
description: Two months after 26 retarded adults were found to be living in homeless shelters in Westchester County, Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed a major expansion of a housing program for developmentally disabled people, one that is intended to place thousands of them in group homes around New York State.

title: U.S. Suspected Deadly Production Line
description: VX, the nerve agent that the Administration says that Sudan was preparing to make, is one of the most deadly nerve agents known to man, especially when applied to the skin. A 10-milligram drop on the skin can kill an adult human in 15 minutes.

title: Clinton's Words: 'There Will Be No Sanctuary for Terrorists'
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's statement at the White House on military strikes in Afghanistan and the Sudan, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription company:

title: INSIDE
description: In Permafrost of Norway, Hunt for the 1918 Flu Virus

title: Nets President Hints Again At Leaving Meadowlands
description: Watching John Calipari and his coaching staff conduct a basketball clinic at the Newark Boys and Girls Club today, Nets President Michael Rowe intimated that his team might soon be doing business again in this city -- for good.

title: In the Norwegian Permafrost, a New Hunt for the Deadly 1918 Flu Virus
description: They start digging on Friday morning, the five grave diggers all the way from London. Actually, much of the time they will be hammering through ice.

title: TRINET AND PRUDENTIAL BUY 12 PROPERTIES IN CALIFORNIA
description: Trinet Corporate Realty Trust Inc. and the Prudential Insurance Company of America teamed up yesterday to buy 12 office and research and development properties in Milpitas, Calif., for about $136.5 million. The properties contain 900,000 square feet on 61 acres and are 100 percent leased to companies like the Atari Games Corporation, the Quantum Corporation and the LSI Logic Corporation. The seller was not identified. The purchase expands Trinet's holdings in the Silicon Valley, which has some of the lowest vacancy rates in the country, by about 50 percent, to 35 properties, with 2.7 million square feet. On Wednesday, Trinet, which is based in San Francisco, and a partner bought five properties in San Jose for $50.4 million.

title: Long Enmity Between U.S. And Sudan Boils Over
description: The air strike against a factory in the Sudan today marked the first act of open warfare in the long-simmering hostilities between the United States and the Islamic Government in Khartoum.

title: Cell Phone Carcinogens?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORFINK, JOHN W. III
description: LORFINK-John W. III, of the Depository Trust Co., on Tuesday, August 18, 1998. Husband of Mary (nee Crawford). Father of Christopher and Amy R. Lorfink. Services by McLaughlin Funeral Home, 625 Pavonia Ave., Jersey City. 201798-8700

title: A Novel Way to Get All A's
description: You'd like Cooper. Everybody does. He's a good-looking rich boy who arrives for his freshman year in college with chilled martini glasses in the mini-bar, an abundance of drugs and more charm than the law should allow. His mottos are ''College is our last chance to go crazy'' and ''Bad grades are meaningless. They're like parking tickets.'' Cooper (Mark-Paul Gosselaar, who was Zack Morris on NBC's ''Saved by the Bell'') parties every night, cuts all his classes every day and is big trouble for his roommate Josh.

title: Two New England Shows Honor Homer, Native Son
description: Given his life -- born in Boston, died in Prouts Neck, Me. -- and rugged themes, from deep woods to open sea, it's small wonder that Winslow Homer (1836-1910) is a New England institution. It isn't even surprising that two museums of the region are currently staging shows of his work. The Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., is presenting ''Winslow Homer: Artist and Illustrator,'' while the Portland Museum of Art in Maine has come up with an ambitious but more familiar survey, ''Winslow Homer Facing Nature.''

title: ATTRACTIONS
description: Museums and Sites

title: Bronx Woman Is Shot to Death In Front of Her Sons, 4 and 6
description: A Bronx woman was killed in front of her two young children yesterday after two gunmen forced their way into the family's apartment demanding money and jewelry, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the mathematician Andre Weil on Aug. 10 misstated the nationality of the mathematician Jacques Bernoulli; he was Swiss, not French. The obituary also misstated Dr. Weil's connection with the Riemann hypothesis. He formulated and proved a hypothesis that is analogous to it, but did not create the Riemann hypothesis itself.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: A Hard Line Will Stop Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Costa Rica Plant to Close
description: Suffering from a steep drop in demand for chips, pagers and cell phones, Motorola Inc. will close its manufacturing plant in San Jose, Costa Rica. Motorola said today that the plant, which produces quartz- and ceramic-based products for communications equipment, became dispensable because of technology changes, weak sales and automation developments. The plant employs 985 workers and will continue to operate ''for a few months.''

title: As Help Arrives, Congo Officials Reject Talks With Rebels
description: A day after several African Governments pledged to help President Laurent Kabila repel an attack on his Government, a leader of the rebellion said he was willing to negotiate a cease-fire in the 18-day war that is increasingly becoming a political battleground for rival African nations.

title: Houston Industries and Powergen End Talks
description: Houston Industries and Powergen P.L.C. have ended negotiations that could have led to a merger and are not expected to resume them, people close to both companies said.

title: Novell's Net Slightly Exceeds Estimates
description: Continuing its recovery, Novell Inc. reported earnings yesterday that modestly exceeded Wall Street estimates.

title: From Soap Star to Hit Singer With a Career Crisis Midway
description: She recorded one of the top-selling albums of the year so far, but when Natalie Imbruglia, a small, slender figure in jeans and a T-shirt, with sunglasses propped on her head, moved through Nobu restaurant in SoHo recently, she was barely noticed. Her cover-girl face, featured in magazines and music videos and on billboards, drew not a glance.

title: HALLIBURTON TO SELL STAKE IN ENERGY INDUSTRY COMPANY
description: The Halliburton Company agreed yesterday to sell its 36 percent stake in a petroleum industry products company for $265 million to Smith International Inc., an oil industry services company. Smith already owns 64 percent of the company, M-I L.L.C., which supplies drilling products, services and equipment to the petroleum industry. The deal is expected to close by the end of the month. Halliburton is a Dallas-based energy services and construction company. The company had 1997 revenue of $8.82 billion. Smith International, based in Houston, had 1997 revenue of $1.56 billion.

title: Mandela Says Congo's Neighbors Will Hold Talks on Revolt
description: As the countries entangled in the civil war here threatened to turn the nation into a battlefield for divergent ethnic, political and diplomatic rivalries, President Nelson Mandela of South Africa announced plans for weekend talks with the leaders involved.

title: U.S. Says Raids Worked and May Stall Terror Attacks
description: The Administration made measured claims of success today for the cruise-missile attacks in the Sudan and Afghanistan on Thursday. Officials said the attack on a mountain redoubt in Afghanistan would disrupt training and, possibly, future attacks by terrorists sponsored by Osama bin Laden.

title: Was Clinton's Confession Too Little or Too Much?; Apology Isn't Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: VARIAN ASSOCIATES PLANS TO SPIN OFF TWO DIVISIONS
description: Varian Associates Inc. said yesterday that it would reorganize its health-care systems, semiconductor equipment and instruments businesses into three public companies. Varian will spin off two of the three businesses, giving its shareholders stock in the new entities. The company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said the reorganization would not lead to large layoffs of its 7,000 employees. The shares of Varian soared $6.875 each, or 19 percent, to $43.

title: Suicide-Law Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Support, and Concern, Voiced In Harlem Over Youth March
description: For weeks, the debate over next month's planned Million Youth March has largely been confined to mayoral news conferences, televised sound bites, newspaper articles and, most recently, a Federal courtroom.

title: Fire Sale of Asian Assets Undermines Economies In Russia and Venezuela : Stock Markets Drop Across Europe and The Americas
description: NEW YORK  Stock prices crumbled in Europe and the Americas on Friday as deflationary pressures from Asia infected other emerging markets, notably Russia and Venezuela.

title: Two Senators Say Evidence Of Plotting Is Compelling
description: President Clinton's top national security advisers today began showing a small group of lawmakers the evidence they had to justify the missile attacks on terrorist targets. Although they would not reveal precise details, lawmakers interviewed said they agreed that the case against Osama bin Laden is as compelling as the Administration contends.

title: French Team Defends Title At the World Championships
description: The opening of the world championships here this afternoon was a proud moment for Jose Damiani, the president of the World Bridge Federation. This industrial town in his home country will be the center of the bridge world for the next two weeks.

title: Fillies Take Aim At Jersey Girl
description: Jersey Girl, who has won 9 of her 11 starts and seven straight this year, will be watching from the sidelines at Saratoga Race Course today while other fillies race to overtake her on the road to the 3-year-old championship. And two daughters of Unbridled will be playing the lead roles: Banshee Breeze, winner of last month's Coaching Club American Oaks, and Manistique, racing's newest monster, who has won her three starts by a total margin of 31 lengths.

title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE REACTION -- U.S. Raids Provoke Fury in Muslim World; Russia Is Critical
description: Almost nostalgically, it seemed, Russia reopened its cold war phrase book today to denounce the United States for its cruise-missile attacks on Afghanistan and the Sudan. But in almost the same breath, it declared that the differences would have no effect on President Clinton's trip to Moscow 10 days from now.

title: Pastor Chuck's Bully Pulpit; S.E.C. Challenges a New Road to Material Salvation
description: The sums were not huge. No famous people or exotic locales were involved. But investigators call this a swindle with an unusual angle: that it had God on its side.

title: Boroughs Need Voice in Mayor's Recycling Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Unit Tracks Cases Onto Internet
description: Christian Curry had what appeared to be a foolproof method for winning a lucrative judgment in a Federal discrimination lawsuit he had filed against his former Wall Street employer, investigators say.

title: When to Strike Back
description: We seem to have gotten this one about right. The United States Government has concluded that Osama bin Laden, a rogue Saudi millionaire with a record of sponsoring terrorist activities, organized the nearly simultaneous bombings of our embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing and wounding both Americans and local citizens. After reaching that determination, the Government, working quickly and quietly, planned and executed a limited and measured military response, bombing targets in both the Sudan and Afghanistan, seeking to destroy Mr. bin Laden's capacity for further terrorist acts.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INDUSTRIAL HOLDINGS INC., Houston, a maker of industrial connectors, bought A&B Bolt and Supply Inc., Lafayette, La. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Taking On the Terrorists
description: Bill Clinton has launched a battle against terrorism that promises to take the United States into unfamiliar intelligence, military and diplomatic terrain. It is important at the outset that the White House and the American people understand the risks involved and set limits on the actions that may be taken. The opportunity to combat terrorism must be pursued aggressively, but the difficulties and dangers should not be underestimated.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Before the jury came out, he started emptying his pockets, took off his watch in anticipation of what was going to happen.''

title: Man Who Sold Baseballs Says He Faked Letter of Authenticity
description: In a bizarre twist to the sale of baseballs supposedly used in David Wells's perfect game, the man who sold the balls to a Long Island memorabilia dealer said yesterday that he wrote the letter authenticating Wells's signature on the balls and then forged the signature of the American League umpire Al Clark on the letter.

title: Boroughs Need Voice in Mayor's Recycling Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Was Clinton's Confession Too Little or Too Much?; Worse Lies
description: To the Editor:

title: A Boy's Death Spurs Changes In Connecticut
description: A week after a 6-year-old New Haven boy who was being monitored by state child welfare workers was found dead with signs of abuse, Gov. John G. Rowland responded to the case today by firing a child welfare supervisor and transferring five managers.

title: Advances for Mayor In Sex-Shop Battle
description: In two more victories for the Giuliani administration's crackdown on sex businesses, the owner of a Bronx strip bar agreed to reopen the business yesterday as a non-adult night club, and a Queens adult video store was closed after its owner failed to appear in court.

title: Ex-South Africa Leader Guilty of Contempt for Refusing to Testify Before Truth Panel
description: A court today found former President P.W. Botha guilty of contempt for repeatedly refusing to testify before the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission about his role in atrocities committed under his rule in the apartheid era.

title: Holocaust Survivors Sue German Smelter
description: A suit filed yesterday in Newark on behalf of Holocaust survivors charges that a German company profited by smelting gold that the Nazis confiscated from Jews and by manufacturing a poison gas, Zyklon-B, used in the death camps.

title: A Look at How the Fight Against Terrorism Will Change : Struggle Gains New Dimension
description: PARIS  The U.S. war against terrorism assumed a new dimension with the cruise missile strikes at targets in Afghanistan and Sudan. As with any adjustment to policy, questions abound. This is an effort to answer the most crucial ones.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Ex-Friends of JonBenet's Parents Call for Special Prosecutor
description: Three former friends of the Ramsey family have asked for a special prosecutor to take over the stalled 20-month-old investigation of the killing of JonBenet Ramsey, the Colorado beauty princess.

title: Was Clinton's Confession Too Little or Too Much?; The Integrity Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Was Clinton's Confession Too Little or Too Much?; Hollow Cries of Betrayal
description: To the Editor:

title: McGwire Admits Taking Controversial Substance
description: In his pursuit of Roger Maris's home run record, Mark McGwire has become a folk hero, with testaments to his popularity unfolding daily. Beginning today in Pittsburgh, the Pirates will play host to the St. Louis slugger in the first back-to-back regular-season sellouts in Three Rivers Stadium's 27-year history.

title: Sports of the Times; Fassel Made Right Call On Sehorn
description: AFTER the ligaments in the right knee of Giants cornerback Jason Sehorn were torn apart while he returned a kickoff against the Jets on Thursday night, it did not take long for the second-guessing of Coach Jim Fassel to begin. As word of Sehorn's injury spread among the players during the game, some mumbled to each other on the sideline about why one of the best athletes in football was being ''wasted'' on special teams.

title: Essex Avoids Fines By Improving Jails
description: Sixteen years after ordering Essex County to reduce overcrowding and improve sanitary conditions in its jails, a Federal judge has ruled that conditions have improved enough to lift the threat of nearly $300 million in fines against the county.

title: Was Clinton's Confession Too Little or Too Much?; He Did No Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Truck Accident Jams L.I. Expressway
description: A tanker truck carrying nearly 11,000 gallons of gasoline created a weekend driver's nightmare this afternoon when it overturned on the Long Island Expressway, halting all traffic in the heart of Nassau County for more than eight hours.

title: The Audience Dodges a Hail of Jokes
description: No one can accuse ''Wrongfully Accused'' of a shortage of jokes. Leslie Nielsen and his co-stars keep them coming, from a parody of ''Lord of the Dance'' to a romantic scene from ''Titanic'' with a slapstick twist. At one point, the ''Field of Dreams''-style baseball players have barely disappeared into the cornfield before Mr. Nielsen is already running from a small (very small) airplane a la ''North by Northwest.'' Unfortunately, most of the jokes just aren't very funny.

title: G.M. DECIDES IT WILL NOT JOIN BIDDING FOR KIA MOTORS
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had decided not to bid for South Korea's insolvent Kia Motors Corporation. But the Ford Motor Company and three Korean companies remained in the race. Ford, already Kia's biggest shareholder, and Hyundai Motor, Daewoo Motor and Samsung Motor submitted bids before the deadline yesterday. G.M. concluded that Kia and its affiliate Asia Motors ''would not be compatible with our strategic needs,'' Alan Perriton, president of G.M. Korea, said in a statement. Kia Motors is being auctioned after collapsing under $10 billion in debts last year.

title: E. G. Lowry Jr., 95, Insurance Executive
description: Edward George Lowry Jr., a former chairman and president of the General Reinsurance Corporation, died on Aug. 11 at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 95.

title: James A. Perkins, 86, Adviser On Higher Education Policy
description: James A. Perkins, a former president of Cornell University and an authority on higher education for philanthropic and national advisory groups, died on Thursday at a rest home in Burlington, Vt. He was 86 and had lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: U.S. Raids Provoke Fury in Muslim World
description: In mosques, on street corners, and from some government ministries, many Muslims voiced fury today over the American missile strikes in Afghanistan and Sudan and predicted that the assault would beget more violence.

title: Advice to Women in Rock: Get Wild but Not Too Wild
description: An old pop music pun applies to Patty Griffin, who played the Bowery Ballroom Tuesday night: she is caught between rock and a hard place. The hard place is the category of the empathetic female songbird, currently the main one (besides rhythm and blues diva) open to women who want to make it to the top of the charts. With her gem-cut voice and unceremoniously insightful songs, Ms. Griffin could easily settle into that style.

title: Hong Kong Curbs Effort to Prop Up Market
description: After a weeklong buying spree to prop up the slumping stock market here, the Hong Kong Government let the free market take over today. And stocks promptly tumbled.

title: As Floods Rage, Relief Efforts Just Beginning in China
description: Even as battles against raging flood waters continue in parts of China, relief workers have begun the herculean task of providing food, water, health care and housing to the millions who have been displaced by the floods.

title: Was Clinton's Confession Too Little or Too Much?; Romantic Misconception
description: To the Editor:

title: Savoring An Appetizer Of Italian Surprises
description: For fans of Baroque music in the 1960's, I Solisti Veneti often seemed like a vast offshore recording factory. The chamber orchestra and its director, Claudio Scimone, plowed through scores by the ream and churned out hundreds of disks for the French Erato label, many of which were available inexpensively through the Musical Heritage Society's mail-order record club. In more recent times the group has been eclipsed by period instrument bands, but Mr. Scimone and company have continued their explorations, both in the Baroque and into the 19th century, and they have found ways to keep their performing style fresh.

title: Clinton's Gifts to Lewinsky Exceed Earlier Disclosures
description: During their final White House meeting on Dec. 28, President Clinton gave Monica S. Lewinsky more than a half-dozen ''going-away'' presents, including an Alaskan stone carving and a decorative pin, said several lawyers familiar with Mr. Clinton's grand-jury testimony on Monday.

title: Overseas Markets Send Wall Street Reeling
description: Investors hoping for a languid summer day of stock trading were treated instead to a wild ride yesterday.

title: Wells Brings His Season Full Circle Against Texas
description: In describing his pitcher's personality, Joe Torre would refer to David Wells by his nickname this spring and say, ''The Boomer is the Boomer.'' Wells was not exactly sure what the Yankees manager meant by this, but he guessed it was not a compliment.

title: Sehorn's Sudden Injury Leaves All the Giants Hurting
description: Less than a minute had gone by in the Jets-Giants game Thursday night when Tiki Barber turned to look at Jason Sehorn, the Giants' most gifted player, whose bounty of athletic gifts engendered an aura of invincibility that fed an entire team.

title: Wanda Toscanini Horowitz, Pianist's Bulwark, Dies at 90
description: She wrote no symphonies, played on no concert stages, conducted no orchestras, but Wanda Toscanini Horowitz, who died yesterday at her Manhattan home at the age of 90, played a unique part in this century's music world.

title: Same P.L.O. Covenant
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Botha Guilty of Contempt

title: Nestle to Acquire Rest Of Unit in Philippines
description: Nestle S.A., the world's largest food company, agreed yesterday to acquire the 45 percent stake in Nestle Philippines Inc. held by the San Miguel Corporation for $640 million. Nestle said its full takeover of the unit, which makes powdered drinks and ice cream, ''underlines its confidence in the growth potential of the Philippines.'' Nestle Philippines Inc. had 1997 sales of $708 million, making the Philippines Nestle's second-largest market in Asia after Japan.

title: HIGH MARKS GIVEN TO THE PRESIDENT BUT NOT THE MAN
description: President Clinton continues to draw high ratings from the American public for his job performance, but his acknowledgment of a relationship with a White House intern has produced signs of a darkening public view of both the President's moral character and his overall personal image, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Correction
description: An article on Sunday about consolidation in the health club industry misidentified the chain that hired Christian Pacifico after he sold his Gold's Gym franchises. It is Towns Sports International, not Bally Fitness.

title: Former Premier Defends 2 Allies In Spain Courts
description: Former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez today formally joined the defense team of two senior officials who served in his Government in the 1980's and are appealing 10-year sentences for their roles in the kidnapping of a suspected Basque separatist.

title: PRO BASKETBALL; Playoffs Begin, and Houston Is the Target
description: Will the Women's National Basketball Association playoffs be a one-team race? Or will this be a down-to-the-wire post-season?

title: Drafting of Williams Looking Prudent Now
description: Suddenly, the Giants no longer have to defend their decision to use their first-round draft choice to select defensive back Shaun Williams. Instead, they are thankful anew that Williams was around when it was their turn to pick last April.

title: Big Japanese Bank Sets an Overhaul, but Foreigners Don't Cheer
description: Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, which has come to symbolize the problems of Japan's banking system and the Government's slowness in addressing them, announced a revamping tonight that paves the way for an injection of public funds and increases the likelihood of an eventual merger with the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company.

title: New York Muslims Fault U.S. Bombings
description: The American bombings in Afghanistan and the Sudan did not come up at all during juma -- traditional Friday prayers -- at Masjid Alfalah, a mosque in Corona, Queens, that is attended by Muslims from many nations. But afterward, it was clear they were on everyone's minds.

title: Clinton, Dogged by Scandal, Juggled Politics and Bombing
description: In retrospect, the only public hint of the assault to come -- the only moment when President Clinton's intense, parallel preparations for his political survival and for a strike against terrorists might have crossed -- came on Monday night.

title: Clinton Lawyer Appeals Ruling On Privilege
description: Warning of a constitutional crisis, a lawyer for President Clinton asked the Supreme Court today to overturn a lower court ruling that some of the President's legal advisers must testify in the investigation of Mr. Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: FASHION MEETS FICTION
description: Fall's clothes of the moment, beautiful and evocative, are a perfect counterpoint to a special magazine issue's four short stories, by Diane Johnson, Robert B. Parker, Barbara Cartland and Gish Jen. Fashions of The Times.

title: Discovering a Bit of Heart in the Sitcom Cupboard
description: The trappings of ''That 70's Show'' are specific. The decade is invoked through leisure suits and bell bottoms; lava lamps, smiley faces and the Hustle, and references to Todd Rundgren and the gasoline shortage. But the appeal of this new sitcom, which Fox is unveiling tomorrow night, is its universal heart. Peering out from beneath the laugh track is the coming-of-age story of a 17-year-old boy and the girl next door, his lifelong pal who has unsettlingly become the object of his hormone-soaked reverie.

title: Beliefs
description: Most traditional codes of sexual ethics, whether set down in sacred texts like the Bible or the Koran, or simply prescribed by tribal customs, share two premises, amply confirmed by recent events: Sex is crazy, and sex is a big deal.

title: Bill for Utility Choice Expected From Trenton
description: A bill that would allow residential customers to choose their electric company is expected to be introduced in the Legislature when it reconvenes next month, state regulators said yesterday.

title: Was Clinton's Confession Too Little or Too Much?; Risking Blackmail
description: To the Editor:

title: Cranes, Steel, Intellects: Rebuilding Berlin
description: ''It is a new city,'' Mark Twain said of Berlin little more than 100 years ago, ''the newest I have ever seen. Chicago would seem venerable beside it.'' Outwardly this seems true today of central Berlin. The city is a forest of cranes, cavernous construction sites and a rising palisade of new Government ministries and imposing embassies (including the United States', not far from the Brandenburg Gate).

title: Think Tank; Medicine's 10 Greatest Hits: Curiosity's Reward

title: Robert W. Warren, 72, Wisconsin Federal Judge
description: Robert Willis Warren, a senior Federal judge in Wisconsin who caused a national uproar in 1979 when he reluctantly became the first Federal judge ever to sign a prior restraint order against a magazine, died on Thursday at Columbia Hospital in Milwaukee. He was 72 and lived in Mequon, a Milwaukee suburb.

title: After Air Strikes, City Tightens Security
description: The heightened security measures at public buildings in New York City went almost unnoticed yesterday.

title: Mets Salvage a Split and Cool Down McGwire
description: Bobby Valentine knew he would be second-guessed for waiting too long to pinch-hit Mike Piazza in the Mets' 10-5 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals in the first game of a doubleheader last night at Shea Stadium. But the manager's decision to go to a six-man rotation has worked out fine.

title: Japan Sets Aside Money For Loans to Businesses
description: Japan's Trade Minister, Kaoru Yosano, said yesterday that the Government would designate 40 trillion yen, or $282 billion, in loans for small businesses that face difficulty borrowing from banks. The Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi, asked other ministers to study steps to promote financing for small companies by Friday, Mr. Yosano said.

title: Devils' General Manager Wants End to Long Summer
description: Speaking in a low but firm voice over lunch, General Manager Lou Lamoriello of the Devils said today that the memory of last season's stunning first-round playoff loss to Ottawa was still hard to swallow.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Drop in Hong Kong As Free Market Takes Over

title: Top Prospect Rushes In And Is Welcomed by Torre
description: Ryan Bradley thrived in Class A less than a month ago, three levels removed from the major leagues. But Bradley, the organization's top pitching prospect, joined the Yankees for tonight's game, completing a rapid rise.

title: Russia's Environmental Dissident
description: Few Russians can do more to help their country solve one of its most perilous radioactive waste problems than Aleksandr Nikitin. Mr. Nikitin was an engineer on a nuclear submarine in the Soviet Union's Northern Fleet and a nuclear safety inspector in the Soviet, and then the Russian, defense ministry. Later, he raised public alarms over nuclear waste left in the Arctic by submarine accidents and haphazard disposal of spent reactor cores. But instead of listening to Mr. Nikitin's recommendations, Russia is prosecuting him for high treason and disclosure of state secrets. Amnesty International considers him its first major Russian prisoner of conscience case since Andrei Sakharov. His trial is likely to begin next month, underscoring the risks that environmental activists face in a Russia whose security service and justice system can still be twisted against dissidents, Soviet-style.

title: Starting Position Worst for Gordon
description: If Jeff Gordon makes Nascar history today by winning his fifth consecutive race, he will have to do it from his worst starting position of the streak. Gordon qualified seventh on the half-mile oval at Bristol Motor Speedway in Bristol, Tenn., yesterday.

title: In Sudan, Furor And a Warning Amid the Ruins
description: Not quite 24 hours after American cruise missiles hit a factory in a decrepit industrial area of this capital, clouds of white smoke and acrid smells still hovered over the site tonight. Deep puddles of water on muddy ground attested to the firefighting efforts after the strike.

title: Foreign Affairs; Angry, Wired and Deadly
description: President Clinton called Osama bin Laden's terrorist group ''a network not sponsored by any state, but as dangerous as any we face.'' Nothing better summarizes the most immediate threat to America today. It is not from another hostile superpower. There is none -- for the moment. It is from super-empowered individuals, super-empowered angry men.

title: Turning Crises Into Comedy In the Bronx
description: JONATHAN ROSARIO answered his door dressed as if he were ready to go on stage and do his comedy routine: black vest over a loose white shirt, burgundy jeans and impeccably shined shoes. He excused himself and lingered in the foyer, where he keeps a pantheon of saints and celebrities.

title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE REACTION -- U.S. Raids Provoke Fury in Muslim World; Backing in Europe
description: European leaders today generally supported President Clinton's bombing raids in Sudan and Afghanistan, and even those who appeared uneasy defended the right of a country to counter-attack terrorists.

title: Young Mr. Lincoln?
description: Over the last few years, in courtrooms coast to coast, the benchmark of human identity has gradually shifted to the DNA standard, the molecular dog tag inherent in even our most fragmentary bodily bits. Where genetic material -- that laconic term -- survives, other proofs of identity are essentially immaterial. But what about a case like the daguerreotype, soon to be auctioned by Christie's, which may or may not depict Abraham Lincoln, circa 1843, as a young Illinois state legislator? If it is Lincoln, the portrait could be worth a great deal of money, because it would be the earliest portrait of him known to exist. If it is some less illustrious young man, the portrait would have, as they say, only antiquarian interest.

description: It's billed as a fun, free summer picnic, a great chance for the regular folks to mingle with Republican officeholders at a magnificent island estate and feast on hot dogs and barbecue, tofu and stir-fry. The main attraction is Speaker Newt Gingrich, who will be trying to establish a new category in the Guinness Book of World Records: greatest number of individual photographs taken with people in a single day.

title: A Late Bloomer Takes Charge Early

He did so well, in fact, that he tried four times to get onto the PGA Tour in the 1970's, but never came close.

title: New Suspect Held in Kenya, And Islamic Agency Searched
description: Kenyan authorities are holding a second man in connection with the bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi, the F.B.I. confirmed today, declining to comment on a local newspaper report that witnesses had picked him out in a line-up as the man who threw a grenade at security guards outside the Embassy seconds before the bomb exploded.

description: AMP Inc., a leading maker of electronics equipment, rejected a $10 billion bid yesterday from Allied Signal Inc., igniting a rare hostile takeover battle in a market that has grown accustomed to friendly mergers.

And their mother, the elderly Ellie Dahmer, bowed her head and thanked God for the jury's verdict that, almost 33 years after the crime, found an old, stooped Klansman guilty of ordering her husband killed.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

title: TELLABS DELAYS VOTE ON DEAL TO PURCHASE CIENA
description: Tellabs Inc. put off a shareholders vote yesterday on the company's pending purchase of the Ciena Corporation, after Ciena said it might not win an important contract from the AT&T Corporation. The shares of Ciena, the largest maker of products that increase capacity on phone networks, fell $25.5313, to $31.25. Tellabs, whose equipment helps route local phone traffic, rose $5.1875, to $62.4375. Ciena, based in Linthicum, Md., was hoping to sell its equipment to AT&T after one of Ceina's largest customers, Worldcom Inc., said earlier this year that it would buy less from the company. Michael Birck, Tellabs's president and chief executive, said in an interview that the company would schedule a board meeting next week to discuss the acquisition, valued at $7.1 billion when it was announced. ''We've got to evaluate everything based on what we heard today,'' Mr. Birck said.

Bratton, the former New York City Police Commissioner, has given him credit for an important concept in the much-publicized reduction of crime in American cities, especially in New York.

title: STAR TELECOMMUNICATIONS SHARPLY CUTS OFFER FOR PT-1
description: Star Telecommunications Inc. reduced its offer to buy PT-1 Communications Inc. by more than half yesterday, to $242.2 million in cash and stock, after securities regulators rejected Star's proposed accounting for the transaction. Under the revised terms, Star will issue 15 million shares and $20 million in cash. Based on Thursday's closing the acquisition is valued at $242.2 million, which is less than half the $591 million Star agreed to pay closely held PT-1 on June 9. Star is a long-distance telephone company, while PT-1 is the nation's largest prepaid calling-card company. The Securities and Exchange Commission told Star the acquisition was subject to purchase accounting rather than pooling-of-interests accounting. Star's shares fell 81.25 cents each, to $14, in Nasdaq trading.

It showed in the way Ms. Eder talked about her horses and the urge to browse for antiques on a lazy summer afternoon. title: The Rainbows Are Coming!
description: I was taken aback by the account of the Rainbow Family's recent stay in the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest in Arizona (Sunday: ''The Rainbows Are Coming!'' Aug. 2). A few years ago, the group came to Vermont and stayed nearby in the Green Mountain National Forest. Out of curiosity, my daughter and I hiked up to see what was happening, and we were pleasantly surprised to find a well-organized gathering of thousands of people. Some were using drugs, it is true, and some nudity prevailed, but there were also positive aspects, like hospitality to all, wonderful music and signs warning against abusing the land or polluting the river. A hike a couple of weeks after the Rainbows left showed no remains of their presence except some areas seeded by members who stayed to make sure the land was in good condition. I find it strange that such a drastic turn of events could occur within such a short period of time.
