title: Superbugs
description: It is shocking to learn that bacterial microbes have now adapted to our best available medical defenses, and shocking also to uncover a strain of paternalism that continues to infect the medical profession (''Superbugs,'' by Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Aug. 2). According to your article, public-health professionals, privy to knowledge of consequence to all, unilaterally decided what to reveal of the truth and what not -- even to those people at immediate risk of infection. The rationale -- to stem public panic -- is tacitly accepted as ethically and pragmatically sound. Empowering alternatives to paternal attitudes that condone lying for the good of the public might be considered instead: developing stronger partnerships between professionals and nonprofessionals; committing resources to more effective public education.

title: Misconnection

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYERS, DAVID
description: BYERS-David. 77. A nationallyknown architectural and decorative arts consultant and a muchadmired contributor to the social and cultural life of Atlanta-and wherever he landed in his travelsdied of heart failure August 19 at Atlanta's Piedmont Hospital. A gentleman of wry, good humor, when asked what he did, Mr. Byers would answer, ''I help people with their problems. That is, their interior design needs''. His knowledge of the decorative arts was encyclopedic, spanning several centuries in England, the Continent and America. His energy was indefatigable as he journeyed around the country for his clients. His rooms were so admired that he assisted several generations of the same family in bringing elegance, beauty, comfort and magic to their homes. Based in Atlanta, Mr. Byers worked in decorative arts for more than 40 years, first at the W.E. Browne Decorating Company and then in private practice. During those years, he was a consultant to hundreds of private residences across the country and for numerous landmarks. They include The White House, Washington, D.C., (1970s); Diplomatic Reception Rooms, State Department, Washington, D.C. (1970s); Georgia Governor's Mansion, Atlanta; Mississippi Governor's Mansion, Jackson; The Boston Atheneum; Wright Stanley House, New Bern, N.C.; Edgewater, Barrytown, N.Y.; Roper House, Charleston, S.C.; Villa Albicini, Macon, Ga.; and the Baltimore Block Headquarters of the Georgia Trust for Historic Preservation. Mr. Byers assisted the Metropolitan Museum of Art with a 19th century furniture exhibition in 1968. He also designed the installation of the Philip Shutze Collection in the Edward H. Inman House at the Atlanta History Center. His rooms have been featured in Classic Atlanta and on the cover of The Most Beautiful Rooms in America. In spite of his work on these noteworthy assignments, Mr. Byers was always modest about his projects. Born and raised in Baltimore, Maryland, Mr. Byers was the younger son of Dr. and Mrs. Horace Byers. He studied architecture at the University of Virginia. He became a resident of Atlanta in 1945 when he joined the W.E. Browne Decorating Company. Mr. Byers retired as a shareholder and vice president when the noted Peachtree Street decorating company began to close in the late 1980s. Throughout his life, he was an ardent supporter of the Decorative Arts Trust and served on its board. Mr. Byers is survived by his sister, Shirley Byers of Baltimore, Maryland, and his cousins, friends and clients throughout the South and the nation. Memorial donations can be made to the David R. Byers Fund, Decorative Arts Trust, 106 Bainbridge Street, Philadelphia, PA 19147. A memorial service will be held at 3:00 p.m. on Wednesday, August 26 at All Saints Episcopal Church, 634 West Peachtree Street, Atlanta. Historical H.M. Patterson & Son, Spring Hill Chapel, 404-876-1022.

title: Crossing Back Over From Profane to Sacred

It transcends her own 23-year-old life, as stimulating as that may be with the success of her hip-hop group, the Fugees, her highly promising career as a musician and producer and her personal happiness mothering a baby boy. And it eclipses the back catalogue of rhythm-and-blues, although Ms. Hill has established herself as a tradition bearer by respectfully reworking the classic ''Killing Me Softly'' for the Fugees' biggest hit, writing a song for the regal Aretha Franklin, inviting the funk-rock guitarist Carlos Santana to appear on the solo album and recording part of that album at Tuff Gong Studios, founded by the reggae icon Bob Marley.

title: Tobacco Can Be Good for You
description: Few people realize it, but tobacco has remarkable potential to do some good. For years now, laboratory scientists have been inserting human and animal genes into tobacco plants, using recombinant (gene-splicing) technology to develop useful new medicines, biopolymers and industrial enzymes. This work is still in the experimental stage -- no tobacco-produced gene products are on the market yet -- but they're coming. Among the substances in development are new antibiotics, biodegradable plastics, a tooth-protecting solution and cancer drugs. All are being created and produced inside the ''evil weed.''

title: A Private Enemy Tries to Sabotage Public Filming
description: When Spike Lee was preparing to shoot scenes for his movie ''Summer of Sam'' on Suffolk and Rivington Streets a few weeks ago, his production company taped photocopied notices to telephone poles informing residents filming would take place. But the next day, the crew on the movie -- which is about the Son of Sam murders in 1976 and '77 -- was puzzled to discover that additional notices had appeared overnight. These unauthorized announcements, which claimed to be an ''open letter from Spike Lee,'' listed the office phone number of the location manager, Al Valentine, and stated that in return for ''disrupting the daily lives of poor people,'' Mr. Valentine would distribute free videocameras to the first 500 residents who called him. The production company received dozens of inquiries from people unaware that the postings were a prank masterminded by Al Giordano, 38, a Lower East Side activist who accuses the media industry of becoming too arrogant.

title: The Blockbuster Script Factory
description: In the course of what hollywood types refer to as ''development,'' a screenplay's journey from first draft to production will frequently take it through the hands of several writers. Not long ago, I told my lawyer that the latest draft of an action-comedy a friend and I are writing for Columbia Pictures was nearly finished, and he replied, ''Good, you'll hand it in just in time to be replaced.'' He was joking, but he also was not -- ''Small Soldiers,'' for instance, originally written by Gavin Scott, was purchased by Steven Spielberg in 1992, and successively revised by Anne Spielberg, Danny Rubin, Frank Deese and Lewis Colick, before a version by Adam Rifkin, incorporating Spielberg's suggestion that the titular soldiers be divided into two warring factions, was green-lighted for production last year. But in a world (to borrow the phrase favored by stentorian coming-attractions narrators) dominated by giant summer action movies, the development process hardly stops once a movie is deemed actually ready to shoot. These days, that's often when it picks up speed.

title: PULSE; Fire Island Fat Fix
description: George Dellinger wakes at 5 A.M. each Sunday and begins his donut marathon. By Jeep, ferry and, finally, little red wagon, he races to get his cargo of Krispy Kreme donuts from Eighth Street, where they're baked, to Fire Island Pines by 9. That's still not early enough for many of his customers, who often have just finished the night's dancing, haven't slept and want their fat fix. The Pines is better known for men with firm physiques than donut figures. But Mr. Dellinger, a party promoter inspired by his own post-dance cravings, got an exclusive contract for Fire Island anyway.

title: PULSE; Let's Twist Again
description: ''It all started during the first heat wave,'' explained Gwen LeMoine Sabahi, the owner of Parlor, a three-chair salon on Ninth Street that has produced some of the summer's most twisted hairdos. ''We were looking for a way to avoid blow-outs.'' Their solution was a modern, disheveled version of the African Zulu knot, hair coiled into a jumble of tiny bumps and secured with bobby pins. Clients started dialing Parlor (212-673-5520) in droves for the process, which takes 20 minutes, costs $30 to $50 (free with a haircut) and can be customized: weaving wet hair into a tapestry effect, adding flowered bobby pins or fashioning straight, dry hair into a spiky fan. Though Scary Spice was a pioneer of the look, teen-agers are not the only ones copying it. A pediatrician's wife recently came in to be knotted for a wedding. ''Messy is O.K. these days,'' Ms. Sabahi said. ''For a special occasion, you don't need a 50's French twist.'' LAURA BEGLEY

title: Looking Ahead to Fall and Beyond

Though it may look untidy, the plant will benefit from the additional month or two of photosynthesis. September will also be a good time to divide and transplant crowded clumps. Under the right conditions, peonies may be left undisturbed for many years, but when crowding occurs, diminished flowering signals it is time to lift and divide the clump.

We potent, grave and reverend signiors debated our choices over many ruminative lunches (ruminare, to chew on: a more than normally necessary exercise when you're browsing at the Century Club), and we certainly weren't short of titles to choose from. In fact, Harry Evans, who was then the president and publisher of Random House and the original dreamer-up of the idea, casually asked each of us to come up with our personal 100 favorites. If we had taken him at his word, the resulting master list -- allowing for a duplication rate of, say, 25 titles that everyone was likely to nominate -- would have totaled something like 750.

title: Lulu in Exile

This now employed 16 lucky people, all of whom amassed frequent-flier miles at an enviable rate as a result of their good attitude toward life. Arnie, who boasted the best attitude of everyone, wore Italianate suits in colors named for vitamin-rich vegetables like kale and eggplant. Also, he wore wraparound sunglasses and had his car washed inside and out while he went shopping with his girlfriend from Hong Kong, Lulu. Lulu did not have to have a good attitude, being cute and full of entertainingly skewed views. For example, she could never get over how underdeveloped malls were in America. She believed Americans were not true shoppers, being too enamored of parks. '

title: Past Jonathan Swift To Linda Tripp (Yeah. Whatever.)
description: I WATCH a lot of television in the summer, a bad habit from my childhood. My therapist would tell you that it was a strategy for defending my then-tenuous self-esteem. I was a chubby little monkey and often stayed indoors rather than suffer the pokes and taunts of the slenderer neighborhood children. My therapist would tell you that these children were simply projecting and neutralizing their own insecurities, that their thin sarcasms were manifestations of their own psychic pain. She would tell you that we were thus caught in conflicting systems of pre-emptive self-avoidance and fear management, all of which hardened into the pathologies of our emotional adulthood. My therapist would tell you all this, but she can't right now because she's on a Boogie board somewhere in the Fire Island surf with a blender drink jammed into each fist and cannot be reached, so I'm watching a lot of television again this summer.

title: A Gallery of Human Oddities That Are, After All, Human
description: HEIDI COMFORT is 8 years old and has a round nose, starry eyes and a large, animated mouth with teeth that don't look quite right. She can chatter affably in a manner far beyond her years and put even shy adults immediately at ease, but in other skills she is devastatingly impaired. Ask her to arrange a set of blocks into the simple pattern of a cross, and she can't do it, and she can't even see that she can't do it. She has a poor grasp of size, time and numbers. She veers wildly from being impatient, uninterested and unable to concentrate on anything for more than a moment to suddenly focusing in on a task, like feeding a barnacle at the local aquarium, to the sustained exclusion of anything around her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPALIAN, MALCOLM F.
description: TOPALIAN-Malcolm F. On August 18. An internationally respected expert on Oriental rugs who was founder of Topalian Trading Company of Manhattan, he was born in Istanbul in 1912, and emigrated to America in 1922 following the Turkish genocide of the Armenians. He studied at Harvard and Columbia universities and distinguished himself in World War II as a Master Sargeant in the Aerial Photographic Division of the Supreme Headquarters under General Eisenhower, from whom he received a certificate of merit in Berlin in 1945 for his ''shrewd processing of intelligence data.'' He was a founder of the St. Thomas Armenian Church in Tenafly, NJ, and a teacher at the New York School of Interior Design for more than 25 years. A devoted husband and father, he is survived by his wife of 46 years, Anita, his three children Suzanne, Elyse, and Mark, and his two sons-in-law Drew Pardoll and David D'Arcy. Visitation will be Sunday 2-4 and 79 PM at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly. The Funeral Service will take place Monday, 10AM at St. Thomas Church, East Clinton Avenue and Route 9W, Tenafly. Donations in his memory may be made to St. Thomas Church or to CASP, a project to sustain orphaned children in Armenia, c/o Mrs. Ashekian, 84 Ellsworth Blvd, Kensington, CT 06037.

title: The Picture of Bill Clinton
description: The sight of Bill Clinton striding into the White House in his role as Commander in Chief and the general support for his strike against terrorism remind us of the power inherent in even a wounded Presidency. It also reminds us, in the case of this particular Presidency, of its missing parts and of what might have been. The nation's immediate feelings about Mr. Clinton can be judged by the wide gaps between poll questions about his performance and those about his character. But now, if these last days of summer allow a breather for the President and the public, there may be time for deeper ruminations on the issues of trust and privacy in American politics.

title: Towering Savings in Kuala Lumpur
description: ''KUALA LUMPUR,'' said the saleswoman on the other end of the phone line at the airline ticket consolidators. ''Hmmmm,'' I answered. It was a city that hardly figured in my imagination, except for one thing. Well, actually, two very big things: the Petronas Twin Towers, completed in 1996, the tallest skyscrapers in the world. I'd seen a photograph of these two curvy, tapered 1,483-foot spires (33 feet taller than the Sears Tower) on the cover of Scientific American last year, and my New Yorker's pride bristled. As a teen-ager I had eagerly tracked the World Trade Center as it slowly rose to resculpt the Manhattan skyline. Now my hometown twin towers had been overtaken by this pair of sassy (but, I had to admit, beautiful) upstarts.

title: TRANE SPOTTING

Graves returned to New York, leaving behind his 8-ton ''Trane'' (pictured), which the Slovaks pragmatically renamed ''Spirit of Comradely Love.'' Before Graves died earlier this year, Scott Rogers, an American living in Prague, went looking to see if the work survived. He found it in Vysne Ruzbachy, a spa town in eastern Slovakia. ''We put a photo of three of Trane's favorite sidemen at its base,'' Rogers says, ''with flowers.''

title: Catnip

All around her, Parisians in elegant clothes ate tuna sandwiches. The little cat that sat under the table looking up at her must have belonged to the restaurant -- Paris was not a place you saw stray animals, was not like Greece or Rome in having hundreds of cats -- you never saw cats in Paris at all, except occasionally, glaring with burning, desirous eyes from the windowsills of their apartments at the pigeons disporting themselves unattainably below.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, NACHUME
description: MILLER-Nachume. Artist, teacher, husband, father and friend on August 20, 1998 at age 49. Born in Frankfurt, Germany, immigrated to Israel in 1950. He came to New York in 1966 to study at the School of Visual Arts where he became a much loved member of the faculty, teaching painting and drawing in 1977. A prolific artist who has worked in almost all of painting's genres, his works are in the permanent collections of major museums and galleries throughout the world, noteably The Museum of Modern Art and The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City. An extraordinarily devoted husband and father, Nachume is survived by his wife Ruth and beloved sons Matthew 18, Danny 16 and Adam 12. He touched all who knew him with his exquisite intellect, visionary artistry and enourmous humanity. The world was a better place with him in it. Funeral 10am Friday August 21st at Riverside Nassau Funeral Home, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, LI.

title: The Picnic

At least I was looking at the fall color. Hawk appeared to be memorizing the profile of a woman in a little black dress who was sipping a cosmopolitan at the near end of the bar and eating cashews and thinking, ''Thank God it's Friday.'' We were supposed to meet Susan at 7, which meant sometime before 8. Susan was never on time, and one got used to it, but one would have been happier if she were late by the same amount each time. However, when she came into the lounge looking better than anybody had a right to, one was so pleased to see her that one no longer gave a damn about how late she was.

title: Susan Graham Puts Pep in a Languid Past

The title of Susan Graham's new recording of Hahn songs, ''La Belle Epoque'' (Sony Classical ASK 60168), accurately indicates that the music is the expression of a particular period in history. title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Keeper of the Findspot
description: In 1863, during the heroic age of amateur archeology, a Frenchman named Champoiseau unearthed a Hellenistic statue of Nike on the island of Samothrace. Headless and armless, the Winged Victory was whisked away to the Louvre to take its place among the great icons of the Western classical tradition. But what of Samothrace, an Aegean outpost at the nervous northeastern edge of modern Greece? Photi Anthropotis, the hero of NIKE (Houghton Mifflin, $20), Nicholas Flokos's witty first novel, is the keeper of the ruined sanctuary at the ''findspot'' on Samothrace, and he is obsessed with the island's loss. ''Is our Nike a shoe for basketball,'' he demands, ''or our almost sacred heirloom?'' The local people take up a collection to send him to Paris: ''We await an Orpheus. For more than a century, we have awaited an Orpheus. A Jason even. What we have is Photi, courteous, sorrowful, unlucky. His name rhymes with Quixote.'' Returning to Samothrace without the Nike (they didn't expect him to steal it, just get over it), Photi finds the place recolonized by Susanna Regas, an American ''woman of learning, of PBS,'' who is famous for making documentary films about ''the heroic but pathetic stories behind the world's revered artworks.'' After she meets Photi, her project becomes more ambitious: how would he like to star in the actual repatriation of the Nike, which she will film live as it happens? Told in a wry, first-person plural reminiscent of a Greek chorus and filled with sly references to modern literature (''in dreams begins responsibility''), Photi's sad tale is spun out -- but more as farce than as tragedy. Gloria Rohmann

description: Like fashion itself, fashion photography is subject to trends, and one of the most recent has been an interest in narrative, in a series of pictures that tells a story. More often than not, the scenario is a sketchy, boy-meets-girl kind of thing, with an outcome that's fairly predictable. What would it be like, we wondered, to start with a real text by a well-known author -- to illustrate a plot instead of implying it, to read the dialogue between the characters? To find out, we commissioned short stories from four writers we admire and hired distinguished photographers to illustrate their words. The results, in the pages that follow, offer a reminder: This fall, designers have imagined women in gray (enlivened by the occasional touch of red), in silhouettes that run the gamut from narrow sheaths to full skirts, in lengths that range from mid-thigh to ankle. The clothes are diverse enough to suit a variety of moods and occasions, as demonstrated by the characters here and the situations in which they find themselves.

title: Editorial Observer; From Chivalry to the Nuremberg Principles

What is less remembered is that after defeating the French, Henry grew fearful the enemy was resuming attack. ''Then every soldier kill his prisoners,'' Henry orders in the play. In real life his knights hesitated and Henry called on archers to carry out an act then, as now, considered a violation of the laws of war.

title: Come the Revolution

It describes the events and the sites and a few other period attractions nearby. The guide ends with a chronology of Revolutionary events in the state, beginning with New Jersey's own tea party, in January 1774, when students at the College of New Jersey (later Princeton) burned tea in support of Boston's, and ending with Washington writing his farewell address to his troops in November 1781 at his last military headquarters, at Rockingham estate in Rocky Hill. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Mysteries of Seeing
description: Famously dissed by Picasso as a lightweight painter and long underappreciated, Pierre Bonnard (1867-1947) has made a comeback in the years since his death, a case made persuasively in BONNARD (Abrams, $60). Sarah Whitfield, the curator of this Bonnard exhibition, focuses on Bonnard's life, influences and stylistic development. She explains the cultural forces that shaped his work, carefully building a link, for example, between the literary figures of the day -- particularly the Symbolist poet Stephane Mallarme -- and Bonnard's elusive, often abstract, presentation of objects and his use of indistinct shapes to heighten the mystery of seeing. And she traces the deep and surprising role of Bonnard's longtime lover and model, Marthe de Meligny; among other things, we learn that the increasingly reclusive Marthe suffered from a mysterious, debilitating disease, probably asthma or tuberculosis, for which hydrotherapy was a popular treatment at the time. That may help explain why she is depicted so often washing herself or lying in a bathtub, and the sense of isolation and melancholy that infuse many of the later paintings. In his essay, John Elderfield, a curator at the Museum of Modern Art, explores Bonnard's visual vocabulary and the viewer's sensory experience of perception. In meticulous, often scientific, detail he decodes Bonnard's use of color, perspective and other devices in his optical bag of tricks. In the end, of course, it's the paintings that make the most eloquent case for Bonnard's greatness, and they are luminously reproduced here -- 273 illustrations, 115 in color. The final pages are dominated by haunting self-portraits, alongside Bonnard's frank declaration that he wanted his paintings ''to show what one sees when one enters a room all of a sudden.'' Scott Veale

Individual residential customers pay 18 cents per kilowatt hour, not 0.18 cents. Bulk customers, in commercial or master-metered residential buildings, pay 4.55 cents per kilowatt hour, not 0.0455 cents, plus an extra charge of $23 to $29 per kilowatt of power in the half hour of highest use each month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, CRAIG

Simon, 43, of Deerfield, Illinois, will be held at 1 PM, Tuesday, August 25, at Gutterman's Funeral Chapel at 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Mr. Simon, who died Saturday after a long illness was the Vice President of Sports Marketing for Frankel and Co. in Chicago. Previously, he was employed by Professional Sports Publications and was then President of his own advertising and marketing consulting firm. Born on Long Island, he lived in New York City and New Jersey before moving to Deerfield, Illinois, four years ago. Mr. Simon received his Bachelor's degree from Northeastern University and law degree from New York Law School. Surviving are his beloved wife, Geraldine, two devoted sons, Zachary and Derek, his adoring parents, Joyce and Lou, dear grandmother, Goldie Jean Lavine, and his loving brother, Rick. Memorial contributions in lieu of flowers can be made to the American Cancer Society.

He also said he could not understand why Major League Baseball would not believe the man who said he sold the balls and signed Clark's name to a letter authenticating Wells's signature.

title: Senator D'Amato's Choice
description: Most elected politicians love to complain about having to hit up campaign donors, but not Alfonse D'Amato, one of the Senate's happiest fund-raisers. Two years ago, he hauled in $24 million for Senate Republicans, much of it from banks and financial institutions overseen by the committee he leads. For his re-election drive this year, he has already harvested $20 million. A less likely supporter of campaign finance reform might be hard to imagine. But today we challenge that assumption. Mr. D'Amato is a flexible man in a tough re-election fight who has spent years in the belly of the fund-raising beast. Voters will be watching to see if he seizes the opportunity on one of the most important votes of his career.

From the City Hall insider to the merchant at the corner bodega, New Yorkers believe that they are tougher, cleverer and more worldly than anyone. This attitude is the United States' most democratic form of elitism. Those who tap into it can profit greatly, as the Beastie Boys, who played Madison Square Garden on Friday night, have proved.

Instead of relying on Nashville's established songwriters and producers, she writes her own material with her producer and her husband, Robert John (Mutt) Lange, who also produced Def Leppard; sometimes he makes the drums boom like rock drums. And where most country performers make their reputations through touring, Ms. Twain has sold millions of albums through video clips, radio play and television appearances. She performed her first full New York concert on Saturday night at the Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, faithfully reproducing the songs on her albums ''The Woman in Me'' (Mercury), from 1995, and ''Come on Over'' (Mercury), from 1997.

The two states must drop their rivalry over jobs and develop a joint strategy to insure the harbor's future as one of the world's premier ports of call.

title: Time for Mining Law Reform
description: With very little fanfare, the White House recently released a three-paragraph statement announcing the formal transfer of the New World Mine site to the United States Forest Service. Thus ended, officially and happily, a four-year struggle to prevent a Canadian mining company and its American subsidiary from building an environmentally treacherous gold mine near the border of Yellowstone National Park. But the forces that defeated the mine, including the Clinton Administration, have one more task ahead of them. That is to overhaul the 1872 Mining Law, the antiquated Federal statute that made it so easy for the company to acquire the mine site in the first place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILEY, PAUL R.
description: WILEY-Paul R. A retired executive of West Virginia Pulp & Paper Company (Westvaco), died on Thursday, 20 August in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida after a long bout with cancer. Dr. Wiley was born in Boston, Massachusetts on 28 May 1915, the second son of Nona and Harry Wiley. He received a B.S. from Harvard and a Ph.d. from the Institute of Paper Chemistry in Appleton, Wisconsin. Dr. Wiley was associated with Westvaco for 44 years. His first assignments were in the chemical laboratories in Mechanicville, New York, Covington, Virginia and Charleston, South Carolina. He was named a Vice President of the Corporation in 1974 & moved to New York City, where he assumed responsibility for the Timberlands Division & the Westvaco Development Corporation. In 1975 he was placed in charge of the Chemical Division & elected to the Board of Directors. Dr. Wiley's wife Helen Corrigan Luke died in 1996. He is survived by a son, Paul R. Wiley, Jr., three stepdaughters, Helen, Posy and Bobbie, six grandchildren, ten great-grandchildren, a sister Marcia and brothers John and Bob. A family memorial service will be held in the fall.

Mr. Kelley graduated from Choate Academy and St. John's Law School and attended Columbia University. Following his military service in World War II, he was an attorney for Prentiss Hall and Donovan & Leisure before joining Bristol-Myers Co in 1956. He was a member of the board of governors of the Greenwich Country Club and Greenwich RTM, and president of Putnam Hill Apartments, Inc. In addition, he was a member of the Union League Club of New York and a Life Master bridge player. Husband of the late Elizabeth Watson Kelley of Pittsburgh, he leaves one son, Marc Watson Kelley of Wappingers Falls, New York; two daughters, Christina Kelley Gilmartin of Milton, MA and Corrine Kelley Wagner of Scituate, MA; four grandchildren, and eight nieces and nephews. He was a brother of the late Randolph B. Kelley of Greenwich and Albert J. Kelley of Westport. The funeral service will be held at 1pm on Thursday, August 27 at Christ Church. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Greenwich Library.

The Jose Limon Dance Company, which adopted Mr. McKayle as its artistic mentor and resident choreographer in 1995, has long seemed to subscribe to that philosophy. On Thursday night at the Damrosch Park Band Shell, the company presented the final program of a tribute to Mr. McKayle that was a theme of this summer's Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival. Judging from the intent, unaccustomed stillness that fell over the Damrosch, the Limon troupe might well have been speaking directly to the audience's collective soul.

Just standing ovations by fans bearing witness to the unfolding of a historic event.
