title: KITTY HAWK TO PURCHASE SOUTHERN AIR TRANSPORT
description: Kitty Hawk Inc., the world's largest operator of air cargo planes, signed a letter of intent yesterday to buy the closely held Southern Air Transport Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock to expand its fleet. The tentative agreement follows a decision by the Fine Air Services Corporation and Southern Air to call off acquisition plans. The companies did not give a reason for ending the agreement. Tom Christopher, the Kitty Hawk chief executive, said that he wanted to expand the Dallas-based company's fleet of 120 planes with Southern Air's five leased Boeing 747-200 freight carriers.

title: Why Voters Don't Want Contrition
description: To the Editor:

title: Darby Betts, 86; Founded Episcopal Homes
description: Dr. Darby Wood Betts, an Episcopal priest who was an expert on church architecture and a co-founder of the Episcopal Homes Foundation in the Diocese of California, died on Aug. 14 at Spring Lake Village, an Episcopal Homes residence in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 86 and also kept a home in Castine, Me.

title: Advice to Relax Benefits Rafter
description: Winning the United States Open last year, Pat Rafter says, might have been the best thing for his career, but the pressure to keep winning got to him.

title: Why Voters Don't Want Contrition
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Blocks a Bonus For a Transit Executive
description: A decision by the New Jersey Transit Board of Directors to award an extra $45,000 a year in pension money to a departing executive was vetoed yesterday by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: U.S. and Iraq Toughen Stances on Weapons Inspection
description: The United States and Iraq hardened their positions today over Baghdad's decision to end cooperation with weapons inspections.

title: Putting Money Where Their Minds Are; Where Scientists Gather, Wagering Flourishes
description: AFTER escaping Germany within months of Hitler's rise to power in 1933 and wandering the world separately for 15 years, Maurice and Gerson Goldhaber were ready for the most ordinary of brotherly relationships when they reunited as particle physicists in the United States. So when Gerson was engaged in the experiment of his life, racing to discover a speck of antimatter called the antiproton, Maurice did what just about any scientist in a close family might do: He bet a colleague $500 that the antiproton did not exist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, HYAM
description: GOTTESMAN-Hyam. The management and entire staff of Ruder Finn mourn the loss of our friend and colleague, senior vice president of the firm. During his long career with us, Hy held many positions, and always acted with intelligence, wit and fortitude. He was ready to take on any task and could be counted on to achieve outstanding results. As manager of the Ruder Finn softball team he was one of the most enthusiastic and popular members of our staff. He would be pleased to know that we will plan an annual Gottesman award for the best softball player on our team each year to commemorate his leadership. David Finn, Chairman and all Hy's colleagues at Ruder Finn

title: Border Deaths Don't Change Mexico's View Of Crossings
description: The recent deaths of 10 Mexicans who were found in the California desert have drawn attention to Mexico's longstanding position of not discouraging its citizens from undertaking the illegal -- and increasingly dangerous -- journey across the border.

title: Bean Stays Upbeat For Holyfield Bout
description: Vaughn Bean, the International Boxing Federation's No. 1 heavyweight contender, hears the murmurs that his Sept. 19 bout against Evander Holyfield, the I.B.F. and World Boxing Association champion, does not have much appeal. But that does not bother him.

title: ENRON OIL AND GAS TO BUY INTEREST IN NATURAL-GAS FIELD
description: The Enron Oil and Gas Company, a natural-gas and oil exploration company based in Houston, agreed to buy a 19 percent interest in a Gulf of Mexico natural-gas field from Union Pacific Resources Group for $158 million. Enron Oil and Gas said the interest in the Matagorda Island field off the coast of Texas would increase its natural-gas reserves, which now make up 85 percent of the company's total reserves. Union Pacific Resources, based in Fort Worth, said it was selling its interest so that it could focus better on areas in the central Gulf of Mexico.

title: Burmese Opposition Leader Ends Latest 13-Day Roadside Protest
description: Myanmar's opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, returned to her home in the Burmese capital today after staying in her car for 13 days, surrounded by soldiers who blocked her from traveling to meet supporters.

title: A Moderate Thinks U.S. Shot Itself in the Foot
description: A normally serene scholar of Islam named Abdulrahman Abuzayd, who believes passionately in the wisdom of his religion and its values, is furious at the United States.

title: Prices of Treasuries Are Mixed; 30-Year Yield Rises to 5.46%
description: Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the price of the 30-year bond down for the first time in four days as the dollar fell against the Japanese yen.

title: Let Doctors Cut Cost of Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: How Brain and Spirit Wrestle With Limits, and Win
description: Only Oliver Sacks would have the wit to alert readers of ''Seeing Voices'' (one of his early books, about the deaf), that the footnotes are ''mental or imaginative excursions, to be taken, or avoided, as the reader-traveler chooses.'' Those footnotes are mini-essays, always worth the detour. More to the point, no one has better defined Mr. Sacks's writing. A neurologist and dazzling essayist, he creates travelogues of the best sort: forays into the human mind and personality.

title: Honors
description: Ron Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Clevenger, Chicago, was elected president of the Chicago Association of Direct Marketing. He succeeds Sheldon M. Soble, president of Creative Benefits, Chicago, who continues on the executive board.

title: Mexico City Journal; For a Famed Tortilla, Green Garnish?
description: In all of Mexico, no place has been shaped by destiny or scarred by history more than the enormous concrete square in this city's heart that is known by some as the ''gran tortilla'' and most simply as the Zocalo.

title: Stern Gives Testimony At Hearing
description: Commissioner David Stern testified yesterday during the first day of a hearing to decide whether players with guaranteed contracts should be paid during the National Basketball Association lockout.

title: President Clinton: the Screenplay
description: CONFIDENTIAL: FOR THE PRESIDENT'S EYES ONLY

title: For Teen-Agers, Tobacco Is a Gateway Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Northrop to Cut 8,000 Jobs In Wake of Failed Merger
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said today that it planned to reduce its work force by 8,000 people, or about 15 percent, by the end of 2000 as it tries to remain competitive as an independent aerospace company.

title: By Design; A Hint of the Exotic for Fall
description: There is a chapter in the fall fashion story devoted to romance, to exotic embroideries and patterns inspired by foreign cultures. The resulting clothing has an ethnic feeling but is never a literal interpretation of a country's mode of dress. It's a refreshing alternative to the new season's daily uniform of sweater and pants.

title: A Conversation: With Virginia Valian; Exploring the Gender Gap and the Absence of Equality
description: VIRGINIA VALIAN, a professor of psychology and linguistics at Hunter College in New York, normally studies how children learn language, but years ago she came across an academic monograph that practically left her speechless. The report demonstrated how the same professional credentials are evaluated differently depending on whether they are possessed by a man or a woman -- with the woman being the loser.

title: U.S. Forest Service Hopes to Buy a Costly, but Picture-Perfect, Slice of West
description: In what would be the largest purchase of private land by the United States Forest Service in at least a quarter-century, Congress and the Clinton Administration are working together on a deal for the Baca Ranch, a 95,000-acre expanse of pristine meadows and fir-covered mountains so emblematic of the West that it has served as backdrop for Stetson hat advertisements and Marlboro Man billboards.

title: Yankee Myth Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Media Talk column of Business Day yesterday about fallout from the resignation of the columnist Mike Barnicle from The Boston Globe misspelled the surname of the media critic for the on-line magazine Slate. He is Scott Shuger, not Shugar.

title: Personal Health; Do's and Don'ts for Thwarting Stalker
description: THOUGH stalking is often glamorized in movies and sitcoms, in real life it is anything but. For most victims, it is a waking nightmare characterized by constant fear and hypervigilance that triggers lasting emotional distress and sometimes results in bodily injury or even death.

title: Man Charged With Assault In Scalding of Brooklyn Girl
description: A Brooklyn man who the police said scalded and sexually abused his girlfriend's 5-year-old daughter was arrested yesterday on charges of assault and sexual assault.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSLER, LEONARD
description: HAUSLER-Leonard. Beloved husband of Diane. Devoted father of Brian and Kerri. Dear brother of Jeff and brother-in-law of Eve. Loving uncle of Alexis & Adriana. Services today 11:30 A.M. at ''Parkside Chapels'' Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: CALGON CARBON STOCK FALLS AFTER SALE PLAN IS ENDED
description: The stock of the Calgon Carbon Corporation fell 25 percent after the company suspended a plan to sell itself and said it would cut costs, buy back shares and step up its search for a chief executive. Shares of the maker of water-treatment products slid $2.4375 each, to $6.75. Calgon said staying independent was in the ''best interests of shareholders.'' Calgon, based in Pittsburgh, said it would focus on its main product line, activated carbon used to treat water, after an unsuccessful effort to diversify. The company said its reorganization plan would include the repurchase of as many as two million of its common shares, which have slipped 35 percent this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNABEL, IRENE S.
description: KNABEL-Irene S., 96. Formerly of Queens, died on August 20th in Tampa, Florida. She is survived by her nephew, Clifford, grand niece and nephew, Nicole and Servalon. Memorial services to be held in Tampa, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASWELL, CELIA
description: KASWELL-Celia. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Joan Katz and Robert Kaswell. Loving mother-in-law of Dr. Burton Katz and Kathy Kaswell. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The New York Chapter of Hadassa, 575 Lexington Ave, NY, NY 10022, in her memory. Services were private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DERRICO, MARGERY K.
description: DERRICO-Margery K., 69, of Ghent died Friday at Hospice Inn at St. Peter's Hospital Albany, New York. Survived by husband Joseph A. Derrico of Ghent, N.Y. Mother of Richard Puig of Clifton Park, N.Y. Todd Miller of Madison, WI. Stepmother of Elizabeth Derrico Chicago, IL, Susan Buske of Boston, MA, sister Joan Kleinwald of Manhattan and 3 granddaughters. Funeral services were Sunday at Congregation Berith Sholom in Troy, N.Y. Memorials may be made to the American Cancer Society or Hospice Inn at St. Peter's Hospital in care of Wenk Funeral Home, Chatham, New York 12037.

title: Unwanted Aid For D'Amato In a Sly Ad On Abortion
description: The voice is grizzled with age, a touch strident and quite definitely male. ''Right to life. That's me,'' the man says. ''And when it comes to the only issue that matters to Right to Life Party members like me, Al D'Amato's the guy we always count on.''

title: Why Voters Don't Want Contrition
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens Building Is El Salvador Norte; Immigrants Seeking a New Life Stay in Touch at 'the Embassy'
description: Even before Rosa M. Talavera left her home in El Salvador nine years ago, she knew exactly where she would live once she arrived in New York City: with relatives in a tiny apartment in a red brick building in Jamaica, Queens.

title: $15 Million Buyout Plan Is Signed For Flood Land
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday signed a package of water-related bills that included a $15 million buyout plan for 800 flood-prone properties along the Passaic River and a $100 million loan program for local drinking water and sewer projects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVIO, S. CHARLES
description: SAVIO-S. Charles. On August 22, 1998. Mr. Savio, a graduate of Fordham University School of Pharmacy, was the executive director of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association and was president of the Italian Pharmaceutical Society. He had been the proprietor of the St. George Pharmacy in the St. George Hotel for many years as well as pharmacies in the Carlyle and Beekman hotels. He is survived by his nephew Alfred B. DelBello, former Westchester County Executive and New York State Lieut. Gov.; nieces Bettina Filardi & Annmarie Carlo; 11 grand nieces & nephews. Friends may call Wednesday, 5-9 PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Funeral mass Thursday, 1 PM at Holy Family Church, 315 East 47 St. Interment will follow in Calvary Cemetery, Queens. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461

title: Hoyt Clarke Hottel, 95, Engineer Who Studied Alternative Fuels
description: Hoyt Clarke Hottel, a retired chemical and combustion engineer and a leader in the development of alternative fuels at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died on Aug. 18 at his home in Winchester, Mass. He was 95.

title: Missile Said to Be in Hands of Afghan Neighbor
description: An unexploded American missile, believed to be a stray from last week's attack on suspected guerrilla training centers in Afghanistan, has been found in a remote area of Pakistan, the Pakistani Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Clinton to Appoint Council To Oversee Safety of Food
description: President Clinton will appoint a high-level council to oversee food safety in the United States, an activity now performed separately by a dozen agencies, a senior White House official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRIOLO, ANNA
description: PRIOLO-Anna (Portanova). Of Clifton, NJ on August 22, 1998. Wife of the late Salvator. Mother of Robert Priolo, mother-in-law of Tina Louise. Grandmother of Anna Marie, Anthony, Theresa & Bridget. Funeral from Marrocco Memorial Chapel, 326 Parker Ave., Clifton, Wednesday at 9:30AM St. Andrew RC Church 10 A.M. Interment Moravian Cemetery, S.I. Contributions to Felician School for Exceptional Children, Lodi, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN INGEN, SCHUYLER
description: VAN INGEN-Schuyler. Of Boynton Beach, FL. Formerly of Manhasset, New York. On August 21, 1998. Peacefully after a prolonged illness. Beloved husband of Rose Marie and the late Elizabeth (nee Wilds). Devoted father of Judith, Alison, Kristine and Marion and grandfather of Lindsey and Blake. Memorial services will be held in the New York area at a time to be determined. Contributions in Schuyler's memory can be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: Chilean Field Yields New Clues to Peopling of Americas
description: THE clear, burbling waters of Chinchihuapi Creek flow out of misty hills, past dark stumps of an ice-age forest and through green pastures, where cattle graze and from time to time a farmer still finds a huge mastodon tusk eroding out of the peat. No one standing by the creek today would suspect that this bucolic place, known as Monte Verde, was so recently the scene of a pitched intellectual battle among archeologists over when people first inhabited the Americas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, MYRA JARMEL
description: FOX-Myra Jarmel. Passed away peacefully Sunday, Aug. 23, 1998. Beloved wife of Bernard. Devoted mother of Debbie, Mitchell, Nina & Evan. Cherished grandmother of Mollie, Emma, Rachel and Elizabeth. Sister of Walter Jarmel. Family will receive visitors at 355 South End Avenue, Apt. 21A, NY, New York, on Tuesday, August 25, 1998, through Saturday, August 29, 1998, from 7 PM to 10 PM. Funeral services will be held at 2 PM on Tuesday, August 25, 1998, at the Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st Street. Donations may be sent to the National Parkinsons Foundation, 1501 NW 9th Avenue, Miami, FL. 33136.

title: A Down-Home Philosopher Makes Old Songs His Own
description: Hit songs have a life of their own. Once they saturate the airwaves, listeners supply their own meanings, filling in back stories that the original songwriters never imagined. Melvin Van Peebles is one of those listeners. In ''Br'er Soul and Roadkill,'' the cabaret set he performed on Wednesday night at the Fez (where it returns tomorrow), he turned rock, pop, Broadway and disco songs into extensions of his own down-home philosophy. As he sees it, most of us are roadkill on the highway of love.

title: Goldman Keeps It Private Even in Going Public
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company officially registered to end its 129-year-old partnership yesterday and confirmed two things Wall Street has long surmised: It is obsessively secretive and phenomenally profitable.

title: Miscellany
description: BSMG Worldwide, New York, a unit of True North Communications, acquired APR/Wilkens, a public relations agency in Hamburg and Stuttgart, Germany.

title: Science Watch
description: Black Truffles: Viva Variety

title: Study Puts High Price on Fixing a Crumbling City
description: Offering a sobering portrait of an aging metropolis, a new study by the City Comptroller has found that New York would have to spend more than $90 billion over the next decade to make the necessary repairs to put the city's subways, water mains, schools and bridges in safe working order.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSFIELD, HAROLD G.
description: MANSFIELD-Harold G. On August 23, 1998, beloved father of Mark, Paul, and Gregory, also survived by five grandchildren. Funeral from Thomas M. Quinn and Sons Funeral Home, 3520 Broadway, on August 25, 1998. Mass of Resurrection on Tuesday at 10:30 from Most Precious Blood Roman Catholic Church. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The American Diabetes Association.

title: Finding the Center
description: Q. What is meant by the term ''geographical center''? How is it determined? What is the geographical center of the United States? Is that with or without Hawaii and Alaska?

title: Corrections
description: A listing of television credits on page B5 today with a review of ''Oliver Sacks: The Mind Traveler,'' a four-part PBS series about the workings of the brain, misstates the viewing time for the first part on Channel 13 in New York. It is at 8 tonight, not at 9.

title: Accounts
description: Gannett Suburban Newspapers, White Plains, to Korey Kay & Partners, New York, as the first agency to handle television advertising. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, EMILY
description: JAFFE-Emily. On August 23, 1998. Adored wife of the late Bernard Jaffe. Beloved mother of Jennifer Bell Gardy and son-in-law Martin Gardy, loving grandmother of Alison Gardy and Joanna Gardy. She was a woman of extraordinary talent and spirit whose unique voice will be greatly missed.

title: Investors Are Optimistic, But Cautious, About Russia
description: Investors around the globe took a cautiously optimistic view yesterday of the latest moves by Russia to reverse its recent economic slide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSCARINIS, ROSA
description: FOSCARINIS-Rosa. Pediatrician. We note with sorrow the tragic death of a dear friend, killed in a car accident in Athens, Greece on August 21, 1998. Funeral services were held in Athens on August 24, 1998. Our deepest sympathy to her husband Nicholas and daughter Maria. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, 819 F Street N.W., Suite 410, Washington, D.C. 20004. Alec and Mila Sedlis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREITAG, ESTHER
description: FREITAG-Esther. On August 24, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Manfred, loving mother of Bette Brody and the late John. Beloved Nana of Linda, Michael and Lisa. Also survived by two great grandchildren. An 11:AM chapel service will be conducted today from the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle, New York. Interment will follow at the Mount Pleasant cemetery.

title: A Child Is Killed, and So Is Faith
description: RESERVATION ROAD

title: Solon G. Vlasto, 94, Newspaper Publisher
description: Solon G. Vlasto, the publisher of what was once the largest daily Greek-language newspaper in the United States, died yesterday in a convalescent home in Athens. He was 94.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Suharto's Son-in-Law, a Much-Feared General, Is Ousted
description: The Indonesian military, pressing ahead with a risky housecleaning that has involved exhuming bodies and investigating high-ranking officers, today discharged a son-in-law of former President Suharto.

title: Down on Scale, Up in Rating; Davenport in Shape for Open
description: The tennis court belonging to Lindsay Davenport's absent host, a banking scion, was discreetly hidden by a hedge of privets and perennials. It was a thoughtful touch at the five-acre Shangri-La where Davenport, the lean but not mean fighting machine who is the hottest player on the women's tour, recently spent a long summer weekend recuperating from the long summer tear in which she has monopolized the hardcourts season with three consecutive titles.

title: Mondelo Makes His Mark
description: During three Major League Soccer seasons, the MetroStars have discovered that landing a big-name coach can often lead only to big-time disappointment.

title: Mathematics 'Proves' What the Grocer Always Knew
description: THIS month, Dr. Thomas Hales, a professor of mathematics at the University of Michigan, announced a solution to a problem that had plagued mathematicians for almost four centuries: What is the best way to stack oranges?

title: For Butterflies, a Promise of Peace With Truckloads of Trees
description: HIGH in the mountains of central Mexico, monarch butterflies arrive by the millions each winter to take refuge, their black and orange wings festooning stands of towering fir trees. But conservationists have grown increasingly concerned as the butterflies in these small patches of forest, some of which were set aside as preserves, compete with the needs of the residents around them.

title: Wary Eye to the Sea
description: A sluggish but powerful storm wobbled around the Atlantic, puzzling forecasters and making coastal residents from Florida to Virginia cast a wary eye toward Hurricane Bonnie. The storm was moving so slowly that trackers could not say when, where or even if it would hit land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBIAS, MARIA
description: DOBIAS-Maria (Nee Shepherd). On August 22, 1998. Born in Chorrillos, Peru on May 14, 1920. Surviving relatives include husband Dr. Bohdan Dobias, son John, daughter Paula Dupraz and granddaughters, Caroline and Isabelle. Services at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Forest Hills on Friday, August 28 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to United Cerebral Palsy of Queens, 249-16 Grand Central Parkway, Bellerose, NY 11426.

title: BankBoston Deal Is Backed by Fed
description: The Federal Reserve signed off today on the BankBoston Corporation's pending purchase of Robertson Stephens, the investment banking arm of the BankAmerica Corporation

title: U.S. Opposes Bail for Gotti, Saying Mob Tie Is Clearer
description: Brushing aside the latest bid by lawyers for John A. Gotti to win his release on bail, Federal prosecutors assert in new documents that they have even more evidence linking Mr. Gotti to organized crime.

title: Patterns; For J. P. Tod's, new outlets and products; From Norma Kamali, a shop-at-home service.
description: Expansion at J. P. Tod's

title: Iraq's Moral Code
description: To the Editor:

title: Union in Deal With Hyundai To End Strike
description: The Hyundai Motor Company and its union agreed today to cut 277 jobs -- only one-sixth the number sought by management -- ending a strike that crippled South Korea's largest auto maker.

title: 'Bridge' to Close
description: ''A View From the Bridge,'' the Roundabout Theater Company's revival of Arthur Miller's drama, is to close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Neil Simon Theater, 250 West 52d Street, Manhattan. The play, directed by Michael Mayer and currently starring Tony Danza, will have run for 251 regular performances and 23 previews.

title: VERTEX AND SCHERING TO DEVELOP DRUGS TOGETHER
description: Vertex Pharmaceuticals Inc. will receive up to $88 million under a pact with the German pharmaceuticals maker Schering A.G. to develop drugs to help regenerate nerves damaged by neurological diseases. Under the agreement, Schering, based in Berlin, will make up-front and research-support payments of $28 million over five years, plus milestone payments of $60 million. Vertex, based in Cambridge, Mass., will have North American manufacturing rights, while both companies will share marketing expenses and profits. Vertex said its compounds had been found to stimulate growth of nerve cells in the brain of laboratory animals with nervous-system injuries.

title: Let Doctors Cut Cost of Medicine; Market-Ruled Medicare?
description: To the Editor:

title: Day of Rest Isn't a Lost One for Slugger
description: Mark McGwire's pursuit of Roger Maris's single-season home run record went on vacation today, as McGwire was rested by Cardinal Manager Tony La Russa. But, as luck would have it, the game between St. Louis and Pittsburgh was shortened by rain with the score 5-5 in the bottom of the seventh, and it goes into the books as a tie game. Since the Pirates and the Cardinals will meet again in St. Louis for three games beginning Sept. 14, a game will be added to the series as part of a doubleheader.

title: Architecture Joins Music as Star of the Lucerne Festival
description: It is perhaps a measure of the mysterious power of opera that the summer music festival in Lucerne is far less well known than those of, say, Salzburg, Bayreuth, Aix-en-Provence and even Glyndebourne. Of these five, Lucerne alone does not present opera, limiting itself to a busy program of concerts and recitals. And that, it seems, suffices to give it a more modest place in Europe's crowded calendar of festivals.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES, Oak Brook, Ill., a maker of plastic packaging for meat and cheese, said it would eliminate 350 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, in closing manufacturing operations in Chicago and eliminating administrative jobs.

title: German Banks Lead World In Nail-Biting Over Russia
description: As Russia staggers through its financial crisis, few countries are watching with more anxiety than Germany.

title: People
description: John Kimball was named senior vice president and chief marketing officer at the Newspaper Association of America, Vienna, Va., succeeding Jim Currow, who left to join Morris Communications Corp., Augusta, Ga., as vice president for metro newspapers. Mr. Kimball had been senior vice president for sales at Macromedia Inc., Hackensack, N.J.

title: Car-Parts Maker to Grow
description: The Lear Corporation, the world's fifth-largest auto-parts maker, said today that it would spend about $4 million to more than double the size of a South Carolina plant, adding 100 workers to make seats for a new BMW sport utility vehicle. The plant, in Duncan, S.C., opened in 1994 to supply seats for BMW's Z3 Roadster. It employs 110 and will expand from 40,000 square feet to about 85,000 square feet. Terms of the BMW contract were not disclosed.

title: Spanish Hotels Scramble to Compete
description: A quickening battle in the domestic hotel market and increasing competition from abroad have sent traditional family-run Spanish hotel companies scrambling to insure their future, with nearly a billion dollars already committed to new investments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEERS, JANE GILBERT
description: BEERS-Jane Gilbert. On August 21 at age 74, Jane Beers died of heart failure. In the mid-1940's Jane came to N.Y. and became a fashion model, appearing in Vogue, Harper's Bazaar and other magazines. In 1965, Jane founded & became president of Red Carpet Associates, the first and most prestigious destination management company in Manhattan. For many years Jane served on the board of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Meeting Planners International and other New York associations. Survivors include her son Jeffrey, brother Dr. John Gilbert, sister Nancy Lindburg and two grandchildren. A Memorial service will be held on Thursday, August 27, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 10 A.M.

title: Airport Group Acquisition
description: Airport Group International, one of the world's largest airport operators, bought the cargo division of USAirports, an airport and cargo service provider, yesterday to expand into the cargo industry. Airport Group International, owned in part by George Soros, the international billionaire investor, and the Lockheed Martin Corporation, approached USAirports with the offer, the closely held companies said. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMANUS, EUGENE E.
description: McMANUS-Eugene E. Devoted husband of Theresa (nee McCann). Beloved son of the late Eugene and Helen. Loving nephew of Elizabeth. Brother of James, Maureen, Denis and the late John. Caring uncle of Denise, Michael, Robert Spillane, and Denis, Jr., Patrick, Thomas McManus. Reposing at Barrett Funeral Home, 424 West 51st Street, on Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9PM. Requiem Mass Sacred Heart Church, 457 West 51 Street, Thursday 10AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Mr. Yeltsin's Unsteady Hand
description: Five months after abruptly firing Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, Boris Yeltsin has just as abruptly brought him back. An increasingly erratic President Yeltsin flailing about in the Kremlin is becoming a major cause for concern in Moscow and in Washington, recalling the unnerving days when ailing and aging Soviet leaders like Leonid Brezhnev continued to wield power despite faltering judgment.

title: Fed Reports Decline in Loans to Large Businesses
description: Business loans to large customers declined in the second quarter, the first decline since the first quarter of 1996, according to a survey by the Federal Reserve.

title: G.O.P. Group to Run TV Ads Calling Opponent of Abortion Intolerant
description: A centrist Republican organization will begin running television commercials in the Binghamton region on Tuesday attacking Randall Terry, the anti-abortion advocate who is running in the Republican primary for Congress, saying he promotes hate, intolerance and extremist views.

title: Charting Lives Public and Private
description: The three dances presented by Jawole Willa Jo Zollar's Urban Bush Women here on Sunday in the Doris Duke Studio Theater at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival were a record of public and private histories. That record began in the present, looped back to the past and caught up with the present, with extraordinary poignancy, humor and immediacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, CHARLES
description: GOLDSTEIN - Charles. Beloved son of Selma and the late Louis. Brother of Julie Wolford. Services were held Monday, August 24.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about boys climbing on a steel structure along the Hudson River in Harlem misidentified the structure. It is a sculpture designed by Rod Knox and built of scaffolding materials in 1987; it is not construction scaffolding.

title: Excerpts From Ruling on Planned Use of Statistical Sampling in 2000 Census
description: Following are excerpts from the decision by a three-judge Federal panel in a lawsuit filed by the House of Representatives against the Commerce Department over the proposed use of statistical sampling in the 2000 census. The decision was obtained from the Federal District Court's Internet site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESIBILL, NANCY L.
description: ESIBILL-Nancy L. Ph.D, CRC. The faculty and staff of the New York University Rehabilitation Counseling Program mourn the loss of their friend. As a faculty member since 1974 & Program Chairperson since 1986, she was valued for her academic leadership, the currency of her teaching, and her untiring service to doctoral candidates. Nancy earned a M.A. degree in rehabilitation counseling at Hunter College and a Ph.D degree, also in rehabilitation counseling, at NYU. She was a active member of the vocational rehabilitation community and touched the lives of countless students, colleagues and consumers. She faced her own disabilities with resolute bravery and unfailing humor and was a model for all persons with disabilities for whom she was always a strong advocate.

title: For Teen-Agers, Tobacco Is a Gateway Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Kazimierz Dziewanowski, Ambassador of Poland
description: Kazimierz Dziewanowski, the first Ambassador of what he proudly called the ''new, democratic and free Poland'' to the United States from 1990 to 1993, died on Wednesday in a hospital at Pisz, Poland. He was in his late 60's and lived in Warsaw.

title: Jersey City-to-Midtown Ferry Will Be the First in Decades
description: Jersey City's resurgent waterfront is getting another ferry route to New York, its sixth, starting Monday, when New York Waterway begins running boats from the Harborside Marina near Exchange Place to West 38th Street. It will be the first ferry route from Jersey City to midtown Manhattan in decades.

title: British Air Likely to Buy Airbus Planes
description: British Airways, in a blow to the Boeing Company, is expected to announce its first purchase from the rival Airbus Industrie, awarding a contract this week for as many as 259 medium-range, single-aisle planes worth $11 billion, managers at one of the companies said.

title: Compaq Expands Draft Relationship
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Draft Worldwide by naming the agency's New York office to handle its direct marketing account in the United States. The account, with billings estimated at $60 million to $80 million, had been handled for five years by the direct marketing unit of Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York.

title: Allied Domecq Sets Reductions to Earnings
description: Allied Domecq P.L.C., the world's second-largest producer of liquor, said yesterday that it would take an additional $:115 million ($186 million) in one-time charges in the 1998 fiscal year to reflect moves to shed some assets and revalue its holdings of pubs in Britain.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's plans to distribute a drug to block radiation that causes thyroid cancer referred incorrectly to the health of Peter G. Crane, a lawyer who has lobbied to have the drug made available. He had thyroid cancer, but has been free of the disease since 1992.

title: Giuliani Takes Credit for Growth in Tourism
description: A record number of people visited New York City last year, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his quality-of-life campaign had played a crucial role.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, JOHN C.
description: CAMPBELL-John C., Jr., Brigadier General. The East End Hospice Board of Directors, staff and volunteers note with great sadness the death of John C. Campbell, Jr., devoted husband to Hospice board member and patron, Jane S. Campbell. John was a loyal supporter of Hospice. We are truly grateful to have had his counsel and friendship. We extend our deepest sympathy to Jane, his children, grandchildren, and to his many friends. We shall miss him greatly. W. Michael Pitcher, President Priscilla A. Ruffin, Director East End Hospice, Inc. Westhampton Beach, New York

title: U.S. Says Iraq Aided Production Of Chemical Weapons in Sudan
description: The United States believes that senior Iraqi scientists were helping to produce elements of the nerve agent VX at the factory in the Sudan that American cruise missiles destroyed last week, Administration and intelligence officials said today.

title: Passion for Blocking Puts A Free Agent on the Team
description: A year ago, Greg Comella was a senior at Stanford, where he played football and rarely watched the National Football League, especially the Giants, who played most of their games a continent away.

title: Mets Hit The Road With No Breather
description: The bulky blue duffel bags were packed with uniforms, gloves, caps and cleats and were lined up in front of every player's locker inside a cramped Mets clubhouse yesterday afternoon, an obvious indication that the team was bound for the road.

title: Wealthy Ride A Boomerang Back to Heart Of Leadership
description: It doesn't take much to set off a rumor in Moscow these days, as governments and policies are flipped around like flapjacks on a griddle.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall Street has reason to lose sleep over some signs that U.S. shoppers are showing fatigue.
description: THEY'VE shopped and they've shopped. Now are they starting to drop?

title: The Virgin Group tries to appeal to a downtown crowd with a new store and $1 million campaign.
description: TWO years after opening a giant music store in Times Square, what is Virgin Entertainment Group doing for an encore? Why, taking a cue from the singer Petula Clark and heading downtown.

title: Storm Floods South Texas, Leaving 14 Dead
description: The sputtering remains of Tropical Storm Charley pushed 200 miles up the Rio Grande Valley from the Gulf of Mexico before stalling early today and dumping more than a foot of rain on South Texas and northern Mexico, turning drought-baked arroyos into gushing drainspouts and leaving at least 14 people dead and more than 60 missing.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Colorful Beads, But Shaky History

title: Researchers Unravel The Motives Of Stalkers
description: STALKERS are wreaking havoc in the lives of millions of Americans. Every year, a recent national study by the Justice Department disclosed, an estimated one million women and 400,000 men are plagued by unrelenting pursuers who harass, terrorize and in some cases kill the victims or anyone else deemed to be in the way of a stalker's desired goal.

title: From Mosque To Museum; Restoring an Object's Surface May Petrify Its Heart
description: Not long ago, the imam at the Casbah mosque agreed to show an interested outsider the mosque's ancient minbar.

title: A Jets Rookie Gets Sacks and Criticism
description: Call it Bill Parcells's brand of tough love.

title: Hillary Clinton's Muddled Legacy
description: Hillary Rodham, in her 1969 Wellesley College commencement address, eloquently summed up the hopes of her generation: ''We're searching for more immediate, ecstatic and penetrating modes of living. . . . Every protest, every dissent, is unabashedly an attempt to forge an identity in this particular age.''

title: Elena Garro, a Mexican Literary Figure, Dies at 78
description: The Mexican writer Elena Garro, whose novels, plays and stories exploring the clash between illusion and reality in Latin America made her one of Mexico's most important literary figures behind her former husband, Octavio Paz, died on Saturday at Cuernavaca Hospital, south of Mexico City.

title: First Drug Approved for Crohn's Disease
description: THE Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the first drug specifically for Crohn's disease, an often debilitating bowel ailment that afflicts about 500,000 Americans.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR SLUMPS. Raw sugar futures fell 3 percent on concerns that demand from Russia, a big importer, would weaken at a time of large crops in Brazil and elsewhere. October raw sugar fell 0.26 cent, to 7.93 cents a pound.

title: Doubts Grow That Taliban Would Give Up Terrorist Mastermind to the U.S.
description: With Osama bin Laden having apparently survived the barrage of missiles rained down on his stronghold across the border in Afghanistan, the United States still has the problem of how to get its hands on the man it considers the No. 1 terrorist.

title: Conductor's Farewell In Music He Loves
description: In just a few days now, Simon Rattle will come to the end of his 18-year tenure as music director of the City of Birmingham Symphony. The final concerts will, quite properly, be given in the orchestra's hometown, for the audience that has supported this remarkable partnership. As for the wider world, the farewells took place at the Salzburg Festival over the weekend, with a performance of Szymanowski's opera ''King Roger'' and the last concert in a cycle of the Beethoven symphonies interlaced with contemporary British music.

title: Opponents Don't Fault McGwire For Pills
description: When Joe Torre played, one of the performance-enhancing tickets was a thick steak. Ten or even five years ago, players filled themselves with pasta, to load up on carbohydrates. And ballplayers of all generations have been liberal users of coffee and nicotine products.

title: Portrait of Lincoln?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Book on Political Reform Stirs Hopes for More Debate
description: The publication this month of a path-breaking book on political reform is stirring excitement among liberal intellectuals here, who hope that it will encourage more open debate about the rule of law, freedom of information and the role of the Communist Party.

title: New Yorkers Hit Small Jackpot ($60 Each)
description: The mailing sent out by American Family Publishers early this year for a multimillion-dollar sweepstakes carried an eye-catching inducement. ''It's down to a two-person race for $11,000,000,'' the promotion said. ''You and one other person in New York were issued the winning number . . . whoever returns it first wins it all.''

title: Police Say Man Killed Ex-Girlfriend And Himself
description: A man from Frankford, in the rural northwest corner of New Jersey, shot and killed his former girlfriend Sunday night and then killed himself, the police and prosecutors said. The woman, Lee Sorensen, had obtained a restraining order against her ex-boyfriend in May, officials said, but the Family Court judge in Sussex County who issued it had rescinded the order in July.

title: Angels Manage to Bring Down Misfortune on Yankees (Again)
description: A handful of almost imperceptible smudges exist on the Yankees' mosaic, and the Anaheim Angels are responsible for most of them. When the Yankees lost their first two games of the season, they were in Anaheim. When a 500-pound expansion joint crashed in Yankee Stadium on April 13 and forced the closing of the ball park, the Angels were in town.

title: Impeding an Accurate Census
description: The ruling by a special three-judge panel in Washington that statistical sampling cannot be used in the 2000 census will be a setback for the democratic process if allowed to stand. It would prohibit the use of sampling to supplement traditional methods that have failed to produce an accurate count for purposes of apportioning representatives in Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAMM, IRENE
description: TRAMM-Irene. On August 22, 1998. Devoted member of the Columbia University Physics Department.

title: U.S. to Ask Wider Libya Ban if Trial Is Refused
description: If Libya refuses an offer to try two Libyan suspects in The Hague for the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, the United States will press the United Nations to extend sanctions on Libya to include an oil embargo, a senior American official said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: AMP Makes Bid For an Insurer
description: AMP Ltd., Australia's largest fund manager and life insurer, started a $3 billion ($1.74 billion United States) takeover bid today for GIO Australia Holdings Ltd., a general insurance company.

title: More About WebTV: Ambitious New Card
description: LAST week's column on WebTV for Windows stirred up enough questions from readers about TV cards for personal computers to warrant a review of the latest and most ambitious of this breed of hardware, All-in-Wonder Pro from ATI Technologies.

title: Microsoft Co-Founder to Sell More Shares
description: The co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, Paul G. Allen, filed to sell 700,000 common shares of the world's largest software maker for an expected $73.3 million.

title: U.S. Drug Agency Opens Field Office in Paterson
description: Saying that drugs distributed in the region are often channeled through Paterson, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration announced yesterday that it had opened a field office in the city to work more closely with local authorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ELIAS
description: LEVINE-Elias. We mourn the passing of the father of our esteemed member, Ira Levine, and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with a television review of ''That 70's Show'' misidentified one cast member. The actor at the left was Topher Grace. (Wilmer Valderrama also appeared in the show.)

title: Why Voters Don't Want Contrition
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Defend Shooting Youth Holding Toy
description: Police officials yesterday staunchly defended the shooting of a Brooklyn teen-ager by two officers who mistook his water gun for the real thing, but the youth's distraught family demanded answers about why the officers fired at him 17 times.

title: YELTSIN COURTING COMMUNIST FAVOR
description: One day after he dismissed his Prime Minister, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia signaled a new approach to governing today by giving a greater voice to the Communist-led forces in Parliament that have sought to frustrate economic reform.

title: Bernard Van Lenten Jr., 56, Fashion Editor
description: Bernard F. Van Lenten Jr., a New York editor and columnist on the men's clothing industry who helped organize the first major private fund-raiser for AIDS research, died Aug. 15 at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 56 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COREY, ALAN LYLE
description: COREY-Alan Lyle, Jr. Died suddenly August 24. He is survived by his loving wife Patricia Grace. His children Patricia Corey Montgomerie, Alan L. Corey III and Russell G. Corey, eight granchildren and one great granddaughter. He was a member of the Meadowbrook Club, Piping Rock Club and the New York Racquet & Tennis Club. The service will be private. Contributions in his memory to The Center for Developmental Disabilities 72 Southwoods Rd, Woodbury, NY 11797-1099 or Palomine Riding for the Disabled 2294 Willoughby Ave, Seaford, NY 11783 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIND, LESLIE WOODROW
description: LIND-Leslie Woodrow. The Members, Jazz Community and Staff of Saint Peter's Lutheran Church, NYC, mourn the loss of Leslie Lind, father of Dale R. Lind, our Pastor to the Jazz Community, who died Saturday, August 22, in Frederick, MD, following a long illness. We express heartfeld condolences to his wife, Louise, daughter, Joan Chesser, sons, Dale and Robert, and grandson, James. Amandus J. Derr, Senior Pastor

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: CANADIAN DOLLAR'S SLIDE. The Canadian dollar fell to another all-time low, despite the 10th consecutive intervention by the Bank of Canada. The Canadian dollar fell to 64.55 United States cents, from 64.87 cents on Friday.

title: Resignedly, Russians Work Ever Harder for Even Less
description: Nina Kostina cheered Boris Yeltsin's ascension to the Presidency in 1991. She voted to re-elect him in 1996. She expected to be comfortablein retirement by now. Instead she is a cleaning woman at the Old Moscow Circus, working 11-hour days and taking home $70 a month -- maybe -- after last week's ruble devaluation.

title: 'High Society' Closing
description: ''High Society,'' the Cole Porter musical based on the play ''The Philadelphia Story'' by Philip Barry and the musical film version of ''High Society,'' with book by Arthur Kopit and additional lyrics by Susan Birkenhead, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street, Manhattan. The play, directed by Christopher Renshaw, will have run for 144 regular performances and 28 previews.

title: Claims Against Liz Claiborne Dismissed
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan has thrown out portions of a lawsuit accusing Liz Claiborne, the garment manufacturer, of improperly conspiring with union leaders to betray the interests of workers at a Brooklyn sweater factory. But the judge refused to dismiss two of the workers' key complaints against the union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLIKOFF, HARRY
description: POLIKOFF-Harry. The Officers, Board of Directors, Trustees and Staff of The Jewish Guild for the Blind, note with sorrow the passing of Harry Polikoff, husband of Guild Trustee, Wanda. He was a committed supporter of The Guild and its mission to aid blind and visually impaired persons. We extend our deepest sympathies to Wanda and the family. James M. Dubin, Chairman Alan R. Morse, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLUCINSKI, FRANCES
description: PLUCINSKI-Frances (nee Ostrowski). On August 23. Beloved wife of Theodore E., M.D. Devoted mother of Robert, James and Karen. Loving grandmother of three. Cherished sister of Helen Polanski and Wallace Ostrowski. Reposing Jurek-Park Slope Funeral Home, 728 4th Avenue, Brooklyn, until Thursday. Mass at Our Lady Of Czestochowa 10:15am. Entombment Greenwood cemetery. Visiting Wed. 2-4:30pm & 7-9:30pm.

title: 34 Stagehands Walk Off the Job At the Apollo Theater in Harlem
description: Stagehands at the Apollo Theater walked off the job yesterday, seeking health benefits, a retirement plan and higher wages.

title: Fatalities From Drunken Driving Drop, but Total Traffic Deaths Hold Steady
description: New figures on traffic deaths, released yesterday by Federal safety regulators, showed that campaigns against drunken driving are producing some success even as the overall number of deaths on the nation's roads remains stubbornly high.

title: An Injured Stevens Is Off Victory Gallop
description: Travers Week opened in the rain and mud today at Saratoga with the two leading players in next Saturday's historic race, Victory Gallop and Coronado's Quest, on the track working out for their duel in ''the summertime Kentucky Derby.'' But if Victory Gallop wins the Travers, he will have to do it without his regular rider, Gary Stevens, who injured a knee Sunday at Del Mar in California.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Lawsuit Attacks Bond Issue Aimed at Indian Expatriates
description: A Long Island man who was not allowed to buy bonds being offered by two Indian banks has filed suit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, saying the practice of offering them only to Indian expatriates violates state and Federal antidiscrimination laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, PHYLLIS
description: GILMAN-Phyllis. You were my role model all through my life. Your courage, inspiration, grace and wisdom will always be with me. We will all miss you. Love Ricki

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, DANIEL M.
description: KELLY-Daniel M. On August 23, 1998. Formerly a senior partner at Solomon Bros. and financial advisor for the Swiss Reinsurance Company. Beloved husband of the late Helen, he is survived by his children Daniel, Andrew, William and Ellen, his sister Genevieve Stellenwerf, grandchildren Nicholas, Alexander, James and Benjamin. Friends may call Wednesday, 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Funeral mass Thursday, 11 A.M., at New York University Catholic Center, 58 Washington Square So., NYC. Interment Greenwood Cemetery.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's the largest piece of inviolate land anywhere near a major city. Everything else that size is either very remote or very ugly. This is beautiful and close.''

title: Cancer Patient Arrested in Plot to Mail Sodium Cyanide Packets
description: A woma an stricken with cancer who lives in a van was arrested here on Sunday in what the authorities said was a plot to mail packets of sodium cyanide to at least 100 people, including medical professionals and a dozen or more New York residents, by disguising the contents as nutritional supplements.

description: DOHERTY-Barbara, 8/25/96 Friend. K.

title: City Is Sued Over Handling of Times Sq. Rallies
description: A civil liberties group charged in a lawsuit yesterday that the Giuliani administration is trying to silence political protest in the heart of the city by arbitrarily denying permits for the use of loudspeakers during demonstrations in Times Square.

title: COURT VOIDS PLAN TO USE SAMPLING FOR 2000 CENSUS
description: A Federal court ruled unanimously today that the Census Bureau's plans to use statistical sampling to supplement the 2000 census violated Federal law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, CRAIG
description: SIMON-Craig. Consummate boxing fan and friend. You will be missed at ringside, but your spirit will always be alive with those of us you touched. Deepest condolences to Craig's family. Valerie Salembier

title: Communications Towers Endorsed for Pinelands
description: The executive director of the commission that oversees the Pinelands National Reserve recommended yesterday that cellular communications companies be allowed to build an additional 23 towers in the environmentally sensitive region.

title: Sales Pitches In an Unlikely Place
description: Check-cashing offices are becoming sites for advertising messages as a company plans to install more than 3,000 television screens to take advantage of captive audiences standing in line waiting to cash checks or pay bills.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CISCO SYSTEMS INC., San Jose, Calif., named Bill Carrico as senior vice president of its unit that sells networking equipment to small and midsized businesses, replacing Howard Charney, who resigned for personal reasons.

title: A Mighty Hurricane on an Unsteady Path
description: Surfers rejoiced today while anxious coastal residents from Florida to Virginia kept a wary eye on Hurricane Bonnie, a sluggish but powerful Atlantic storm that is confounding forecasters with a wobbling track toward the southeastern United States.

title: From Tension, Truth; From Truth, Humor
description: ABOUT seven seconds after last week's bombing, Colin Quinn was sick of hearing ''Wag the Dog'' jokes. He's sick of the dress jokes, the Linda Tripp jokes and the Southern-fried sex jokes that pass for political commentary these days, and he's particularly sick that he can't use any of these jokes yet because ''Saturday Night Live's'' season doesn't start until next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKMAN, LARS
description: BERKMAN-Lars. The entire staff of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette mourn the passing of Mr. Lars Berkman, Senior Vice President and Director of high yield investments at DLJ Investment Management Corp. Mr. Berkman was one of the leading portfolio managers in the country, and in a short period of time made significant contributions to the growth of DLJ. He was a warm and caring colleague and will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held on September 9, 1998 at 10:30 A.M. at King Juan Carlos I Center at NYU, 53 Washington Square South. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, WANDA TOSCANINI
description: HOROWITZ - Wanda Toscanini. The Philharmonic Symphony-Society of New York, Inc. notes with deeo sadness the death of Wanda Toscanini Horowitz, a special friend of the Philharmonic. The daughter of Arturo Toscanini, Music Director of the Philharmonic from 1928 to 1936, she later married the pianist Vladimir Horowitz, who made his American debut with the Philharmonic in 1928. We extend our condolences to the family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Gunther, Chairman Deborah Borda, Exec. Director

title: White House Considers Adding to Defense Team
description: With President Clinton's worries shifting from the grand jury room to Capitol Hill, his senior aides are considering proposing that he hire an outside expert to help blunt any Congressional inquiry into a report by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, White House officials said today.

title: A Voice of Moderation and Civility
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Goldman, Sachs Money Machine
description: The biggest bull market of the past 15 years has been in capitalism itself, and no company has been better positioned to profit from it than Goldman, Sachs, the investment banking firm that has until now jealously guarded its financial details.

title: Survey Finds Public Support For Vouchers
description: Public opposition to taxpayer support for private and religious schooling, which was clear-cut several years ago, is softening, with Americans closely divided on the use of vouchers to pay tuition at private or church-sponsored schools, according to a poll released yesterday.

title: Once Again, Outer Banks Nails Down and Gets Out
description: The Outer Banks of North Carolina, an elbow-shaped strand of barrier islands that have been battered time and again by surging swells and withering gales, prepared today for its latest assault from the sea, with hundreds of thousands of residents and tourists evacuating ahead of the anticipated landing of Hurricane Bonnie.

title: N.B.A. Hearing Adjourned
description: An arbitration hearing yesterday to decide whether players should be paid during the National Basketball Association lockout was adjourned until Sept. 3.

title: Fending Off the Yangtze
description: To the Editor:

title: Office Building Is Sold
description: RFR Holding has bought the 22-story office building at 18 East 41st Street for $13.6 million from the investor Lloyd Goldman.

title: Explaining Our Actions in the Sudan
description: Although missile strikes were launched simultaneously on Afghanistan and the Sudan last week, those two countries do not merit equivalent treatment from the United States in its war against international terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMOND, NAOMI E.
description: RICHMOND-Naomi E. Of Riverside Drive, NYC, passed away on Friday, August 21, 1998. Beloved friend. Your brilliance, activism and moral support will be greatly missed. Barbara Riddoch

title: The Minimalist; For Delicate Fish, Fragrant Cushion of Fennel
description: COOKS with access to perfectly fresh fish make a fetish of cooking it simply, largely because the subtle flavor is easily lost, especially if the fish is of a delicate, white-fleshed variety. It doesn't matter much where you go or whom you talk to: when fishermen, chefs or home cooks are proud of their fish, they do not fuss with it.

title: Who's Afraid of Genetic Engineering?
description: Imagine a country placing such rigid restrictions on imports that people could not get vaccines and insulin. And imagine those same restrictions being placed on food products as well as on laundry detergent and paper.

title: The Creative Pit Updates the Dictum: Make No Little Plans
description: Ah, for the life of the brilliant visionary artist: the thrill of grand conception, the exhilaration of feverish creation, the profound satisfaction of realization. Then accolades and immortality.

title: Umpire Present as Wells Signed Baseballs
description: Al Clark, the American League umpire under investigation in the sale of baseballs that were purportedly used in David Wells's perfect game, acknowledged last night that he was present when Wells autographed balls but disputed an account that he received any of them.

title: Giuliani Picks a Chief Lobbyist Whose Father Once Held the Job
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed Anthony P. Piscitelli yesterday to be the city's chief lobbyist in Albany, saying Mr. Piscitelli had a ''genetic capacity'' for the position because his father held the job two decades ago.

title: Missile Strikes Violate Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Egyptians Hold Terrorist Chief, Official Asserts
description: One of the world's most wanted terrorists, the Palestinian guerrilla chief, Sabri al-Banna, better known as Abu Nidal, is being held by the Egyptian authorities in Cairo, according to an Arab intelligence official.

title: Africa's Widening War
description: Troops, planes and tanks from Angola, Zimbabwe, Uganda and probably Rwanda are now intervening on one side or the other of Congo's civil war. Their actions blatantly violate international borders and set an alarming precedent for turning other civil wars, like those in the Sudan and Angola, into regional conflicts. The fighting could also hasten the breakup of the huge but fractious Congo, creating a breeding ground for drug traffickers, warlords and terrorists in the heart of Africa.

title: Storm's Fury Is Already Felt in New York Area
description: Hurricane Bonnie made herself felt in the New York region with a vengeance yesterday, pounding beaches in New York and New Jersey and apparently claiming at least one life.
