title: Business Travel; Here's some advice for passengers if there is a strike this weekend at Northwest Airlines.
description: AS of yesterday, Northwest Airlines was still holding out the possibility of avoiding a strike by its pilots, but prudent passengers should prepare for the worst. That means bracing for a possible strike any time after midnight Saturday, unless there is a settlement.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Toms River Takes the Fun and the Streak Into a Semifinal
description: The Toms River second baseman Joey Franceschini fielded a ground ball and stepped on the bag to record the final out of a 5-3 victory over Greenville, N.C., this afternoon and the celebrating erupted on the field and in the stands. The New Jersey team had just added to its improbable run through the Little League World Series by winning its third game in three days and assuring itself of a spot in the semifinals on Thursday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHR, ROBERT E.
description: MOHR-Robert E. On August 25, 1998. Vice President of Timex Watches, he is survived by his two children Candace and Robert. Friends may call Thursday from 4:00 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., with service at 7:30 PM. Interment will take place in Indiana.

title: A Mass Crowns A Festival
description: For those of us whose seasonal clocks are linked to concert schedules, the first harbinger of summer's end is the final concert of the Mostly Mozart Festival, with the end of Tanglewood (next weekend) as confirmation. As has often been the case, Mostly Mozart took its leave with a work for chorus, orchestra and vocal soloists, in this case Mozart's ''Coronation'' Mass (K. 317). The impulse seemed oddly backward: coronations are typically the start of something, not the end. No doubt it would be too much to look for deep significance in the choice of work. That the ''Coronation'' is the best-known and probably the greatest of Mozart's Masses should be sufficient reason to end a festival with it, nomenclature notwithstanding.

title: The Serpent In the Garden Of Renewal
description: PLUMP, green apples plopped to the ground as Jose (Chema) Soto pried them loose from the branches. He climbed down and caught his breath, a reminder that he should exercise more since having a heart attack. He beheld the tree, which towered over the Caribbean-style wooden shack that he and his friends built in the middle of a Bronx community garden bursting with enough vegetables and flowers to rival any greengrocer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, LORRAINE
description: GOLDBERG-Lorraine. On August 25, 1998. Beloved wife of David. Devoted mother of Carol, Mark and Sharon, Debbie, Susan and Rich. Loving grandmother of Liza, Julia, Daniel and Eric. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, today at 11:30 A.M.

title: Ship With Proud History Arrives at Its New Home
description: When the Regina Maris, a 90-year-old three-masted wooden barkentine, was being towed out of Greenport Harbor Sunday night, crew members said that those left behind on the dock were taking bets that she would never make it through Plum Gut's rough tidal waters.

title: Hong Kong Shifts Stock Purchases
description: The Hong Kong government, intervening in the financial markets for a seventh session, held back a wave of stock sales today, sending prices higher.

title: Serbian Cannon Fire Kills 3 Mother Teresa Aid Workers
description: Three people bringing supplies to refugees have been killed by cannon fire from a police vehicle in what appears to be the most serious Government effort yet to terrorize aid workers.

title: The Chef; From Scratch, . . . Almost
description: WHEN I was just learning about fine cooking as a 14-year-old apprentice at an inn in upstate New York, I was fascinated by the dessert cart, as any kid (prospective cook or not) would be. I was particularly taken with the elaborate pastry cream creations like the napoleon. And as I learned by the time I got to culinary school, the ability to create those creamy classics was a hallmark of the professional.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARO, EVA
description: CARO-Eva. Dearest mother, forever in my heart and thoughts. I love you. Frances

title: Union Faults G.M. on Plans for Parts Unit
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers union strongly criticized the General Motors Corporation today, a sign that this summer's strikes in Flint, Mich. did not produce a reconciliation and that next year's national contract talks between G.M. and the U.A.W. will be contentious.

title: A Swimming Coach Savors His Title Shot
description: As the swimming and diving coach at Mount Vernon (N.Y.) High School, Larry Barnes has no concept of being in over his head. So to make that suggestion about his coming bout against Yory Boy Campas, for the International Boxing Federation junior middleweight championship, would be useless.

title: Marketing Diana, Princess of Brand Names
description: As the first anniversary of her death nears, Diana, Princess of Wales, has become a powerful princess of sales, unexpectedly developing into the equivalent of a strong worldwide brand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ALBERT
description: ROSENTHAL-Albert. Age 64. On August 25, 1998, of Scarsdale, NY. Loving husband of Deena, father of Ian, Sara and Alisa, and fatherin-law of Tallulah. Devoted brother, uncle, nephew, brother-in-law and friend. Service at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York, at 12:30 P.M., on August 27, 1998.

title: Into the Sheltering Arms Of Evangelical Colleges
description: For her civics class last spring at Lincoln High School in Portland, Ore., Rebecca Strong had to memorize the names of all the participants in the White House scandal, including the lawyers.

title: Liberties; Hiding Behind Skirts
description: During a Democratic debate in Denver in 1992, Bill Clinton was asked if he would want half his Cabinet to be women.

title: Missile Strikes Violate Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: British Leader Acts to Tighten Terrorism Laws
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain announced today that he was calling Parliament back into session from its summer recess next week to toughen antiterrorism laws. Similar measures are being contemplated by the Irish Republic after the bombing in Omagh, in the British province of Northern Ireland, that took 28 lives and wounded 220 people.

title: Up Close, Golfers Are Amazing
description: WHAT I did on my summer vacation: I watched the best male golfers in the world, from a few feet away. I have been raving about my experience ever since, so now I want to rave in print.

title: Cuban Exile Leader Among 7 Accused of Plot on Castro
description: A member of the board of the principal Cuban exile organization in the United States was indicted here today with six other men on charges that they conspired to assassinate Fidel Castro when he was on an official visit to Venezuela last year.

title: China Admits Ecological Sins Played Role in Flood Disaster
description: Charges are mounting here that bad policies and official neglect have worsened this summer's disastrous flooding in China, and the Government has made the unusual admission that its land-use mistakes are partly to blame and announced sweeping policy changes.

title: Administration to Fight Ruling Barring Sampling in Census
description: While acknowledging that a Federal court ruling on Monday was a blow to its efforts to use sampling to supplement the 2000 census, the Clinton Administration said today that it would still press Congress for the money the Census Bureau would need to plan for sampling.

title: Confidence Dips; Home Resales Rise
description: Consumer confidence fell this month but held close to a 30-year high, while previously owned homes were resold at a record pace during July, encouraged by plenty of jobs and low mortgage rates.

title: Hurricane and Flood Showing Their Fangs
description: From the sunny sands of South Carolina to the elbow-shaped strand of barrier islands that make up the Outer Banks of North Carolina, nearly half a million people were on the move in an effort to avoid the onslaught of Hurricane Bonnie. With sustained winds of 115 miles an hour, the storm was expected to strike today between Wilmington, N.C., and the southern end of the Outer Banks, near Cape Lookout National Seashore. Hurricane warnings were in effect across more than 450 miles from Cape Romain, S.C., to Chincoteague, Va., near the Maryland border.

title: Sparks, in the Spotlight, Is Even Talking About It
description: The image that Phillippi Sparks left behind last season was not pretty. In a season marred by illness and injury, where his status as the leader of the defensive backfield was taken away by Jason Sehorn, Sparks found himself in an ugly on-the-field scuffle with his teammates Conrad Hamilton and Jessie Armstead during a playoff game against the Minnesota Vikings. He then was flagged for pass interference, which led to the Vikings' winning field goal.

title: ENHANCED SERVICES AGREES TO TAKEOVER OF ZULU-TEK INC.
description: The Enhanced Services Company will acquire the assets of Zulu-Tek Inc., a marketer of interactive advertising, for about $24.2 million in common stock and redeemable preferred shares. It will also assume $6 million in debt. Enhanced Services, which is based in Houston and makes peripheral products for portable computers, said the transaction put a value of about 58 cents on each share of Zulu-Tek, which is based in El Segundo, Calif.

title: Grand Canyon Malls?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sailing in the Wake of Portugal's Navigators
description: The 14th-century voyages of Portuguese navigators and crews, among the greatest exploits of Europe's great age of exploration, stir more appreciation than excitement in the four-part documentary that begins tonight on PBS.

title: UBS Posts 5% Gain in Operating Earnings
description: UBS A.G., Europe's largest bank, today posted a 5 percent increase in operating earnings for the first half, exceeding analysts' expectations, aided by a gain in commission income and a decline in bad-loan provisions. Net income rose 22 percent.

title: O'Brien Bumped
description: Television executives spend endless hours examining coming prime-time schedules; they apparently spend almost no time examining upcoming political schedules.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Absent Principals

title: SUMMIT BANCORP TO ACQUIRE NEW CANAAN BANK AND TRUST
description: Summit Bancorp agreed yesterday to acquire the New Canaan Bank and Trust Company, a commercial bank in Connecticut, for $45.1 million in stock. Summit, based in Princeton, N.J., is a bank holding company with assets of $31 billion, deposits of $22 billion and 435 branches in New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania. New Canaan, based in New Canaan, Conn., has assets of $173 million and four branches. Summit entered the Connecticut market in June when it agreed to acquire NSS Bancorp of Norwalk, Conn.

title: Television
description: Fox Sports is discussing with Major League Baseball adding prime-time games that would feature the 61st or 62d home runs by Mark McGwire or Sammy Sosa.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about Nolo Press, the legal publisher, misidentified one of the promotional items that carry the company's motto. It is posters, not toasters.

title: West Coast Offense: Angels Beat Yankees Again
description: If there has been anything more magical than the Yankees' season, it has been the magic with which the Anaheim Angels have mesmerized the Yankees.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Anybody who does not abide by the mandatory evacuation, our law enforcement has been instructed to ask them their next of kin.''

title: McEnroe Works His Way Out of Open
description: With a hot wind swirling through the premises, yesterday was a difficult day to play for a living at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens. And the odd thing was, Patrick McEnroe did not have to be out there on Court 7 unsuccessfully battling the conditions and Michael Joyce.

title: Giants Have Surprise Visitor
description: LeShon Johnson arrived at Giants practice unannounced today and told Coach Jim Fassel that he wanted to be included in the team's plans. Ever the optimist, Johnson, recovering from lymphoma, was exuberant about seeing his teammates again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, MARTIN A.
description: PARKER-Martin A. On August 25, 1998. Naval veteran of World War II. Beloved husband of the late Ethel, loving uncle of Elaine O'Neil and Edward Roach. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd Street. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, 10 AM, St. Malachy's Church. Interment All Saints Cemetery.

title: Bronx Cheer of a Wine Guide
description: WITH ''The Wine Avenger'' (Simon & Schuster, $11), Willie Gluckstern establishes himself as the bleacher bum of wine writers. Mr. Gluckstern, a wine teacher and the wine buyer for Nancy's Wines in Manhattan, looks at a bottle of wine the same way the sun-and-beer-addled guy in the centerfield seats looks at the heart of the Marlins lineup: These guys call themselves baseball players? They make how much? You've got to be kidding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMANUS, EUGENE E.
description: McMANUS-Eugene E. Devoted husband of Theresa (nee McCann). Beloved son of the late Eugene and Helen. Loving nephew of Elizabeth. Brother of James, Maureen, Denis and the late John. Caring uncle of Denise, Michael, Robert Spillane, and Denis, Jr., Patrick, Thomas McManus. Reposing at Barrett Funeral Home, 424 West 51st Street, on Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9PM. Requiem Mass Sacred Heart Church, 457 West 51 Street, Thursday 10AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BOYLE, ELIZABETH P. (NEE CREGG)
description: O'BOYLE-Elizabeth P. (nee Cregg). Wife of the late John. Sister of Winifred. Mother of John, Elizabeth, Moira, Patricia, James and Joseph. Grandmother of Thomas, Shannon, Cara, Shawn, Michael, Christian, Meghan, Shane, Lauren, Claire and Mairead, died peacefully at home surrounded by loved ones. Visiting 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 P.M., Wednesday at M.J. Smith Sons, 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial 10:00 A.M. Thursday at Holy Name R.C. Church. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Brooklyn Hospice or The Windsor Terrace Senior Center.

title: U.S. to Pay Farmers to Shoo Cows Off City's Watershed
description: In a move aimed at cutting the flow of pollution and parasites into New York City's drinking water, the United States Agriculture Department plans to unveil a $10.4 million program today that will pay farmers to stop growing crops and grazing cattle along streams feeding the city's upstate reservoirs.

title: A Struggling Adobe Rejects Bid by Quark
description: The graphic software publisher Quark Inc. said today that it had offered to acquire the rival Adobe Systems Inc. at a premium to Adobe's current stock price but that the offer had been turned down.

title: In-Laws Say Bomb Suspect Led a Quiet, Religious Life
description: The main suspect being held in connection with the bombing of the United States Embassy in Nairobi two weeks ago was described by relatives in this seaside town as a simple fish merchant and carpenter.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING MICROSOFT'S ROLE IN INTEL DECISIONS
description: The two companies are so intertwined, so seemingly mutually dependent for their extraordinary success that the Microsoft Corporation and the Intel Corporation are often referred to as a single entity -- ''Wintel'' -- in recognition of the degree to which Microsoft's Windows operating system and Intel's microprocessors dominate the technology of personal computing.

title: DII BUYS CIRCUIT BOARD MAKER WITH OPERATIONS IN CHINA
description: DII Group Inc., a custom-electronics company, said yesterday that it had bought Greatsino Electronic Technology, a maker of printed circuit boards that has operations in China, from Universal Appliances Ltd. of Hong Kong for an initial price of $44 million. DII, based in Niwot, Colo., whose customers include the Hewlett-Packard Company and the 3Com Corporation, agreed to pay as much as $40 million more for Greatsino. DII plans to move the base of its Asia-Pacific operations to Hong Kong from Singapore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, DR. MATTHEW
description: BRODY-Dr. Matthew. Former Chief of Psychiatry and Neurology at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital for 40 years and Past President of King County Medical Society. Beloved husband of Muriel. Cherished father of Jane Anthony and Margery Gaffin. Adored grandfather of Samantha Vonderharr, Todd Ravinett, Jason Kinzler and Dylan Anthony. Dear brother of Sylvia Chandler, Jeannette Rattiner and the late Helen Siner. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 312 Coney Island Ave. (at Prospect Park), Brooklyn, today at 11 A.M.

title: Nasdaq Uncovered Short Sales Decline
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market fell 1 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday.

title: Vodafone Group To Buy Phone Network
description: Vodafone Group P.L.C., Britain's No. 1 cellular telephone company, agreed yesterday to buy the New Zealand mobile phone network owned by BellSouth New Zealand Wireless Holdings Inc. and ST Telecommunications for $750 million (New Zealand), or $369 million (United States), in cash. Vodafone will buy the network and related assets operated by BellSouth New Zealand, a partnership of BellSouth and Singapore Technologies, and the whole of the issued share capital of BellSouth New Zealand Ltd.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LASNER, ETHEL
description: LASNER-Ethel, 1917-1995. As each day passes, you are so very missed by your son, sister, nephew, niece, and friends

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE JUMPS. Coffee futures rose 5 percent on concerns that a planned strike of customs workers in Brazil would further delay exports after earlier port strikes. December coffee rose 5.65 cents, to $1.18 a pound.

title: Gore Gives No Hint That Anything Could Be Amiss
description: Looking tan and relaxed after a two-week Hawaiian vacation, Vice President Al Gore returned to full public view today, giving little hint that anything of major consequence had happened while he was away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISENBERG, ROBERT W.
description: WEISENBERG-Robert W. On August 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Yvonne. Devoted father of Allyn Patrica and Leonard. Loving father-in-law of Leslie. Graveside services were held Monday at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN SLIPS. Japan's currency fell against the dollar after Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa suggested that market intervention to support the yen was unlikely any time soon. The dollar rose to 144.21 yen from 143.95 on Monday.

title: $25 and Under; Relishing the Ancient Delights of the Incas
description: WHEN you sit down for dinner at Coco Roco, a bright, pleasant Peruvian restaurant that opened four months ago on the fringe of Park Slope in Brooklyn, the waiter sets down a little bowl of corn kernels that have been salted and roasted a deep, nutty brown. The corn, called cancha, has a crisp snap and a wonderful toasty flavor, and as I compete with the children at my table to scoop up the last few kernels, I'm wondering how I can make a meal out of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUZ, JEAN OSMUN
description: LUZ-Jean Osmun. Died of liver cancer in her home in Bedminster, N.J. on August 9, 1998. Jean was born in New York City, lived her entire life in Madison, N.J., and resided in Bedminster for the last 38 years. Jean is survived by her husband of 43 years, Carl, her daughter, Rebecca Storniolo, a sister, a brother, and 2 grandchildren. She was predeceased by her son, Carl III. Jean was the grand daughter of Mildred and James McGraw, the founder of The McGraw Hill Publishing Co, Inc.

title: Mild in Taste, Elegant in Look, Skate Joins the A-List
description: SKATE'S arrival as a Serious Fish, at least in New York, can be pinpointed to the day. It was on Jan. 28, 1986, the day Le Bernardin opened: skate was there on the menu, poached with browned butter.

title: Marsh & McLennan to Buy Big British Insurance Broker
description: Fortifying its position as the world's largest insurance broker, Marsh & McLennan of New York said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the London-based Sedgwick Group, the largest independent broker in Europe, for $2.05 billion in cash.

title: Bits and Bytes
description: Flavors of the Caribbean In the Air (and on the Web)

title: New Marketspan Leadership Includes 9 of Lilco's Top 26
description: Marketspan announced a new management team today, but it includes only nine of 26 former officers of the Long Island Lighting Company. The others chose to leave the company rather than return lucrative severance checks or were not asked to stay on.

title: Black Gains Found Meager in the Old Segregated States
description: The first comprehensive study of public higher education in the 19 states that once operated racially separate colleges presents a picture of continuing segregation fueled by political fatigue, court rulings, and admissions and financial-aid policies.

title: Big, Odd Spaces Feed Appetite for Off and Off Off Broadway
description: It's probably safe to assume that the builders of the old American Savings Bank near Union Square never imagined this scene: performers tethered to wires and pulleys dip and soar above a standing audience. Balloons cascade from the 40-foot ceiling, followed by soaking blasts of water and a shroud of fog. One performer loses his pants and zooms bare-bottomed into the crowd, joining his colleagues, who are clad but drenched. Later the spectators get into the groove, dancing furiously in this theater with no seats.

title: Obligations All Around
description: As Congress awaits a report from Kenneth Starr, potentially covering everything from the Whitewater affair to the Lewinsky affair and the possible obstructions of justice that might link the two, the President's predicament is really our predicament.

title: Wine Talk; Italy's 1997 Vintage: Poised for Greatness
description: THE trouble is that you want to believe. That this will be the year the home team makes it to the Superbowl. That this diet is going to do the trick. That (fill in the year) is going to be the vintage of the century in (fill in the country).

title: Saving O'Neill And Himself; Quintero Credits the Sources Of a Lasting Passion
description: The theater is Jose Quintero's lifeline. ''It is not a mere profession,'' he said. ''It helps me to clarify the process of living. I know my way around this ground. It's like reading Braille.'' He was standing in front of the stage at the Provincetown Playhouse in Greenwich Village and facing a group of theater students, teachers and professionals. ''I am here to open doors,'' he continued. The doors are to the plays of Eugene O'Neill. For nearly 50 years, Mr. Quintero has been the pre-eminent director of O'Neill and the artist most responsible for re-establishing the reputation of the Nobel Prize-winning playwright.

title: USEC INC. ANNOUNCES PLAN TO CUT ITS WORK FORCE BY 500
description: Usec Inc., which enriches uranium for nuclear power plants, said yesterday that it would cut 500 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, as it worked to trim costs and compete with foreign rivals. This year the company will offer voluntary severance packages to 125 workers in Paducah, Ky., and 125 in Portsmouth, Ohio, and next year it will make similar offers to 250 more employees. Usec said that if not enough workers accepted the offers, it would dismiss people to meet its target. Usec was created by the United States Government in 1993 to take over uranium enrichment previously handled by the Department of Energy. The Government sold the company last month in a public offering of 100 million shares at $14.25.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about reports that Iraqi scientists had helped produce chemical nerve gas components at the factory bombed by the United States in Sudan misstated the title and tenure of Antonio Monteiro of Portugal as head of the committee that monitors United Nations sanctions on Iraq. He is chairman for two years, not president for the month.

title: For Rhythm and Blues, Radio Days Are Over
description: To the Editor:

title: To Go; The Allure of Jamaica in TriBeCa
description: FROM out of nowhere, it seems, ISLAND GRILL, a colorful, breezy Caribbean restaurant, sprang up three months ago in the heart of TriBeCa. The pale island pastels, the thatch-and-coconut trim and the anthurium plants that beckoned flirtatiously from the half-dozen tables were almost enough to coax me to sit, but the pounding reggae beat, so loud and insistent that I could barely hear myself think, persuaded me to take out.

title: Anti-Americanism Suspected As Cape Town Club Is Bombed
description: A bomb, possibly set by Islamic fundamentalists angry about American missile attacks on the Sudan and Afghanistan, shattered the dinner hour in a crowded American-theme restaurant in Cape Town tonight, killing at least one woman and injuring 24 other people.

title: Citibank Sued Over Bonds
description: Citibank is the newest target in a discrimination lawsuit that charges three banks with excluding non-Indians from a bond sale.

title: VALSPAR TO BUY PACKAGING COATINGS UNIT OF DEXTER CORP.
description: The Valspar Corporation, a Minneapolis-based maker of paints and coatings that has annual revenue of about $1 billion, agreed yesterday to buy the Dexter Corporation's packaging coatings business for an undisclosed price. The unit makes coatings for beverage and aerosol cans and contributed $208 million to Dexter's $1.15 billion in sales in 1997. Dexter, based in Windsor Locks, Conn., is the oldest company listed on the New York Stock Exchange. It said last month that it planned to sell the unit so it could focus on chemicals used in the biotechnology, aerospace and electronics industries.

title: Grand Canyon Malls?
description: To the Editor:

title: Floyd Haskell, 82, Ex-Senator From Colorado
description: Floyd K. Haskell, whose tall frame and rugged good looks made him seem chiseled for his role as a United States Senator but who never felt quite comfortable in the part, died today at a hospital here in his hometown. He was 82.

title: Ads Are Coming To Dry Cleaners
description: Sales pitches are turning up almost everywhere these days, from supermarket floors to toilet stalls to stickers on bananas. Now you can add to the list the protective plastic garment bags and other paraphernalia at the dry cleaners.

title: 2 American Teams Lead In Early Bridge Rounds
description: The biggest world bridge championship ever continued here today with 233 teams from 47 countries in play in the Vivendi Rosenblum Cup competition for Open Teams. There are 16 qualifying groups, each with 14 or 15 teams, and 4 teams from each group will qualify for playoffs beginning Thursday.

title: Reed Keeps Struggling As Mets Lose to Giants
description: Starting pitching is supposed to separate the Mets from the Giants and the Cubs in the National League wild-card race.

title: Lewis Powell, Crucial Centrist Justice, Dies at 90
description: Lewis F. Powell Jr., the Supreme Court Justice who brought a voice of moderation and civility to an increasingly polarized Court during his 15-year tenure, died today at the age of 90. An announcement from the Court reported that Justice Powell, who retired 11 years ago and had been in failing health, died of pneumonia at his home in Richmond, Va.

title: The Napoleon Complex; Delusions of grandeur seize restaurant kitchens.
description: WHAT you get from chefs in restaurants today can resemble the conversation at a cocktail party: some of it is smart, and a lot of it is showing off. Consider the ostentatious trend toward greater and greater height on the plate, food sculpture that looks impressive until you try to eat it, and it falls to pieces.

title: I.M.F. Lets Its Rule on Full Repayment Slip
description: Pummeled by Asia and now Russia, the International Monetary Fund is gradually softening its policies, becoming more tolerant of arrangements it would have rejected a year ago -- and even allowing some Asian debtors not to repay all they owe to foreign banks.

title: HORSE RACING: Applying the Rule on Whips A Delicate Issue in Racing; Jockeys Travel Fine Line Between Use and Abuse
description: It has been five months since New York State issued its first rules on the proper use of the riding crop by jockeys, and the question still remains: to whip or not to whip?

title: Missile Strikes Violate Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: After Shooting by Police, Critics Say Illegal Toy Guns Are Still Too Easy to Get
description: The deadly looking water gun that fooled police officers and led them to shoot and critically injure a 16-year-old boy in Brooklyn on Sunday night was another reminder of what critics said yesterday has been an all-too-common problem: realistic toy guns that, although they are banned by law, are still too easy for children to get.

title: Threat Eased, Congo Leader Arrives Back In His Capital
description: As the rebel threat to his Government shifted away from the capital to eastern Congo, President Laurent Kabila returned here today after an absence of 10 days and, amid reports that his allies' jets were bombing the country's third-largest city, he urged ordinary Congolese to take up spears and arrows to crush the rebellion.

title: ABC and ESPN Expecting Profit From a 5-Year Deal
description: ABC and ESPN vowed yesterday to make a profit from a new five- year, $600 million television deal with the National Hockey League that will begin in 1999.

title: Drugs for a Nuclear Disaster
description: While the risk of a nuclear power plant disaster is very small, state and Federal disaster agencies owe it to people who live near reactors to help them guard against the health dangers of a nuclear leak or meltdown. The availability of potassium iodide pills can help that effort.

title: Merrill Lynch Dismisses a Debt Trader
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the biggest bond underwriter in the United States, dismissed a corporate debt trader, Michael J. Meyer, earlier this month for unauthorized speculative trading in United States Treasury bond futures, a company spokesman confirmed yesterday.

title: Slowly, Rising and Falling, Flood Swallows Town
description: Pat Calderon was standing on tiptoe atop his projection television console, the dark water in his living room so deep it was licking his chin, when his 82-year-old disabled mother, who was floating nearby on an upholstered love seat, asked if he would mind fetching her a dry blanket.

title: Promus Selects TBWA Chiat/Day
description: The Promus Hotel Corporation in Memphis said yesterday that it had named TBWA Chiat/Day in New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle the creative duties for the account of its Embassy Suites, Hampton Inn and Doubletree lodging chains. Billings were estimated at more than $35 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Ruble Falls Steeply, Causing New Wave of Panic

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEENAN, FREDERICK M., JR.
description: KEENAN-Frederick M., Jr., 74. A retired sports photographer for the Patriot Ledger, Quincy, MA, died August 24, 1998 at his home in South Yarmouth, MA. after a long illness. He was well known for his award-winning photo of Bobby Orr scoring the 1970 Stanley Cup hockey winning goal. He is survived by his loving wife, Barbara Keenan, his daughter Kathleen Keenan Snow of Provincetown, Boston and New York; two sisters and one brother and three stepchildren. Services will be held Friday, August 28 at 2 P.M. in the Downing Cottage Funeral Chapel, Hingham, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Alzheimer's Association, Cape Cod and the Islands Chapter, P.O. Box 953, Barnstable, MA 02630 or to Parkinson's Disease Association, 720 Harrison Ave., Boston, MA. 02118.

title: People
description: * David Krishock, vice chairman for global planning and business development at Saatchi & Saatchi, New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., left to become president and chief executive of Suntory Water Group, Marietta, Ga., part of Suntory International Corp., succeeding Harry Hersh, who retired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDMAN, BERNARD M.
description: WALDMAN-Bernard M., of 22 Governor's Row, West Hartford, CT died August 24, 1998 in Hartford, CT. Born in New York City, Sept. 12, 1920 and lived in West Hartford since 1956. Former National Officer of United Jewish Appeal. A distinguished businessman, Philantropist and community leader. He was our hero and will be especially missed by his loving wife, Bernice (Perlstein) Waldman; his beloved children, Nancy and Robert Pearlman, Jaime and Mark Seltzer, Keith and Jamie Waldman, all of West Hartford; two brothers Abe Waldman of West Hartford and Edward Waldman of Boca Raton, FL; two sisters Frances Shulberg of Boynton Beach, FL., Irene Cooper of Margate, FL. and was adored 'Papa' of six grandchildren, Marisa and Lindsay Pearlman of New York, Amanda and Matthew Seltzer and Zoe and Emma Waldman all of West Hartford. Funeral today in Hartford, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Endowment Foundation of the Jewish Federation of Greater Hartford or to the Emanuel Synagogue, 160 Mohegan Dr., West Hartford, CT. 06117. For information call Weinstein Mortuary, 860-233-2675.

title: Cleaner Act For Wise Guys
description: For nearly six years, Warner Brothers has been trying to get Martin Scorsese's Academy-Award winning film ''Goodfellas'' onto network television screens. But the film's graphic violence and cursing, even after Mr. Scorsese had edited it for television, made that seem impossible -- especially in the last few years, with the national debate over sex and violence on television and the need for a content ratings system.

title: An Avalanche of Death That Redirected a War
description: STALINGRAD

title: Temptation; The Notorious, Spellbound Cookie
description: IT'S round, oversize and dark underneath, the perfect cookie for Alfred Hitchcock, whose film ''The Birds'' finishes a limited run tomorrow night at the Film Forum in SoHo.

title: MMMPop! It's Hanson, Accompanied By Screamers
description: Little girls started screaming as the stage crew set up the opening act, and they didn't stop until Hanson sang its last encore on Monday night at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. Wearing Hanson T-shirts, they waved homemade signs announcing ''Hanson We Love U'' or singling out one of the three Hanson brothers -- Zachary, 12, Taylor, 15, and Isaac, 17 -- for particular devotion. Amid the pandemonium, the three cute blond brothers pretended they were playing an ordinary rock concert. They barely flirted with the audience, and limited their stage banter to lines like ''You guys ready to rock?'' The stage set was minimal; they didn't surround themselves with special effects. Hanson wants to be a band, not a novelty act.

title: Hardcover Revenge for a Broken Marriage
description: WHEN Catherine Texier returned from a visit to her native France in the summer of 1996, her husband of 18 years -- Joel Rose, a novelist and screenwriter -- greeted her with the news that he was packing up his books, clothes and photographs and leaving. The marriage, he said, was over.

title: Strike-Bound Apollo Skips Amateur Night
description: The Apollo Theater announced yesterday that it was canceling tonight's scheduled ''Amateur Night'' production because of a walkout by the Harlem theater's stagehands.

title: Missile Strikes Violate Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: RUSSIA INTERVENES AS ITS CURRENCY TAKES SHARP DROP
description: As Russia searches for a new Government and a program to pull the nation out of a tailspin, a fresh wave of panic swept through the country's financial institutions today. The currency plunged about 9 percent, three banks announced a merger to shore up their stability and the Government unveiled a plan to stretch out the repayment of its debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRITZER, ANNA
description: SPRITZER - Anna. 102 years young. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Loving and loved mother of Claire and Carl Fader, and the late Helene and Milt Bernstein. Adored ''Nanny'' of Vicki Diamond, Nancy and Michael Rehns, Jay and Carolyn Fader, and Norman Bernstein and Eileen Tobin, great ''Nanny'' of Danny, Kenny, Scott and Heather Rehns, Alison and Dana Fader, and Jennifer and Melissa Tobin. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30PM Thursday.

title: Eating Well; U.S. Eases Up on Irradiation, Antibiotics
description: IN little-noticed actions, the Food and Drug Administration has given the food industry more leeway in two controversial areas: the use of antibiotics in animals and the labeling of irradiated food.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: ARIZONA CARDINALS

title: Solis Set to Ride Victory Gallop
description: Alex Solis will replace Gary Stevens aboard Victory Gallop in the $750,000 Travers Stakes in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., on Saturday, Elliott Walden, the colt's trainer said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIDERMAN, MONTE
description: SIDERMAN-Monte. On August 24, 1998. Beloved spouse of the late Beatrice Kreindler Siderman and thereafter of Florence Shientag Gluck. Distinguished pharmacist. Also associated 40 years with the 21 Club. Dear uncle of Howard and Irene and Gary and Arlene Lustig. His many friends and admirers will miss his noble nature and delightful sense of humor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONAGH, JAMES G.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIASIN, GIAN, PAOLO
description: BIASIN-Gian-Paolo. Professor of Italian Studies at the University of California, Berkeley since 1981 died Monday, August 24, 1998 after two years of a courageous struggle with cancer. He is survived by his devoted wife and son, Rita and Giovanni of Berkeley, California, and in Italy by his loving mother, two brothers and a sister. He was a native of Italy (Sassuolo) where in 1956 he graduated from the University of Modena with a doctoral degree in Jurisprudence. He came to the USA in 1957 and here he continued his studies in Political Science and then in humane letters, earning the Ph.D. Degree in Romance Languages & Literature at The Johns Hopkins University (1964). Before joining the faculty at UC, Berkeley, he had taught at Cornell University and The University of Texas (Austin). A brilliant teacher and lecturer, much admired and beloved by his students, Professor Biasin was also a scholar and critic of international fame; during his academic career he received signal honors from several European and American centers of learning. In addition, he was passionately active in reaching out to the San Francisco and Bay Area ItalianAmerican community at large. In this respect, he was a frequent speaker, elegant, accessible and informative, at S.F.'s Institute of Italian Culture and at socio-cultural clubs such as ''The Cenacolo'' and ''The Leonardo da Vinci Society''. He was no less passionate about good food and the Italian cuisine, attested by the fact that he was the chief delegate of the San Francisco chapter of Italy's prestigious Accademia della Cucina. Indeed, the theme of food in literature was central to a number of his highly original and illuminating critical studies. But his range of thematic interests was wide, as can be seen by his perceptive use of interdisciplinary approaches and methods in his many writings, beginning with his very first book, ''The Smile of the Gods'' (1968). There will be a funeral Mass at 10:00AM, Friday, August 28, at the Parish Hall of Saint Mary Magdalena Church in Berkeley, 2005 Berryman Street, Tel. 510-526-4811.

Some college students might want to chill out in a velveteen inflatable chair (it's almost upholstered furniture); others would prefer to flop onto a stylish rug on the floor (dorm-room size at student prices). Appealing to either sex: the ubiquitous ''boyfriend'' (a pillow with a back rest and arms). Any quirky component is welcome.

title: Lufthansa Profit Jumps Despite Crisis in Asia
description: Deutsche Lufthansa A.G., Europe's No. 2 airline, posted an implied threefold rise in second-quarter profit as cost cuts, lower fuel prices and rising passenger traffic offset the effects of Asia's economic slowdown. Net income rose to 518 million marks ($287 million) from 156 million marks in the corresponding period a year earlier. Pretax profit in the three months through June, excluding one-time gains, rose to 803 million marks from 377 million marks a year ago. Second-quarter figures were calculated based on the company's first-quarter and first-half results.

title: Jury Duty Loses Some Sting in Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWELL, LEWIS F. JR
description: POWELL-Lewis F. Jr, United States Supreme Court Justice (ret), died at his home in Richmond on Tuesday, August 25, 1998. Justice Powell was born in Suffolk, Virginia on September 19, 1907. He was the son of the late Mary Lewis Gwathmey and Louis Franklin Powell. His wife of 60 years, Josephine Rucker Powell, died in the summer of 1996. Justice Powell is survived by his children, Josephine and Richard Smith of Houston, Pendleton and Robert Bowen of Whidbey Island, Washington, Molly and Christopher Sumner of Salt Lake City, Lewis and Lisa Powell of Richmond; by grandchildren, Elliott and Denise Smith, Quincy Smith, Lycia Carmody and Rocky Fried, Nathaniel and Vickie Carmody, Ryland Sumner, Kendall Sumner, and Emily, Hannah and Lewis Powell; by his great-grandson, Zachary Smith; and by his sister Eleanor Powell Dewey of Williamsburg. Funeral services will be held at Grace Covenant Presbyterian Church, 1627 Monument Avenue, at 11:30AM on Monday, August 31st. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lewis F. Powell Jr. Legal Services Fellowship at the University of Virginia Law School Foundation, Charlottesville, Virginia 22903.

title: First Day of School: The Desk as Lesson
description: BACK-TO-SCHOOL, the time of notebooks and protractors and sales circulars, has become one of the basic seasons of American marketing. Even adults decades out of the classroom can succumb to the pitch; it evokes certain primal school-day sights and smells and textures. At the Southern California Institute of Architecture (SciArc), the once-renegade school whose influence has shaped the look of design in Los Angeles, back-to-school means something different. There, first-year students don't buy stuff; they build their own desks.

title: Finally, a Device for Desk Potatoes
description: Television users who live and die by the remote control may soon be able to buy a computer counterpart. Interlink Electronics (www.interlinkelec.com) of Camarillo, Calif., has begun showing the Freedom Writer Pro, which the company plans eventually to market as a remote control for the computer. The hand-held wireless device can be used as a mouse and a touch pad, letting users surf the Net, read E-mail and even enter text using a handwriting recognition feature. For now, the device, which goes on sale in November for $199, is being marketed as a tool for presentations.

title: Freedom, One Way or Another

The saxophonist Branford Marsalis's quartet, playing music so new it hadn't been titled yet, sounded rhythmically tight and aggressive while keeping a door open to free improvisation. The pianist Randy Weston used a looser and vaguely African concept that seemed both quaint and messy by comparison.

title: TELECHECK SERVICES IS IN DEAL FOR QUICKCARD SYSTEMS
description: The First Data Corporation's Telecheck Services Inc. unit bought Quickcard Systems Inc., the first company to approve telephone customers' checks for mail-order companies, for an undisclosed amount. The Houston-based Telecheck, which approves customers' checks at retail stores, supermarkets and financial institutions, will expand its check approval services for catalogue companies, direct marketers and television shopping channels by acquiring Quickcard, based in Kimberton, Pa. Telecheck had 31 percent of the $61.5 billion check guarantee business in 1997, according to The Nilson Report, an industry newsletter. It is a subsidiary of First Data of Hackensack, N.J. First Data fell $1.25 yesterday, to $24.75.

title: WITH SLOWING PC CHIP SALES, ZILOG WILL TRIM WORK FORCE
description: Zilog Inc. said yesterday that it would cut 7.3 percent of its work force to cope with slowing sales of its specialty computer chips used in consumer electronics and personal computer products. Zilog said it would reduce its 1,650-member work force by eliminating 120 jobs at its manufacturing plant in Nampa, Idaho. Texas Pacific Group acquired Zilog and took it private earlier this year. The company eliminated 33 jobs in sales and at its headquarters last month to cut costs. Zilog, based in Campbell, Calif., said it would offer employees four to 10 weeks of severance pay, health benefits through December and assistance in finding new jobs.

She was 74 and lived in Emmitsburg, Md., where she was administrator of her order's provincial headquarters.

Nissan Motor is in talks to sell a stake in Nissan Diesel to Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany.

title: One Tiny Step for Janet Reno
description: With her decision to trigger a preliminary inquiry by Justice Department investigators into Vice President Gore's telephone solicitations, Attorney General Janet Reno has moved tardily and incompletely toward appointment of an independent counsel to investigate a small corner of White House fund-raising during the 1996 campaign. We would like to be able to salute her for a bolder embrace of her obligation to uphold Federal campaign laws and discharge an attorney general's overarching duty to assure the integrity of Federal law and the nation's electoral system. That is not possible given the narrow scope she has defined for the preliminary inquiry. But we can at least praise her for making a start toward conquering her now-legendary inertia and toward heeding warnings by the Government's top campaign finance investigators that she has been misreading the law on campaign violations and her own conflict of interest in this matter.

title: DRS TECHNOLOGIES IN $22.9 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR NAI
description: DRS Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to pay as much as $22.9 million for NAI Technologies Inc. as it expands its share of the market for rugged military computers and telephone equipment. DRS, based in Parsippany, N.J., a maker of electronic sensors and optical systems, said the purchase price depended on its six-month average share price when the all-stock transaction closes around Dec. 31. Shares of DRS fell 43.75 cents, to $10, and NAI was unchanged at $1.8125. NAI, based in Huntington, N.Y., makes computer equipment able to withstand extreme weather and conditions for military and government clients.

CBL, based in Chattanooga, Tenn., is also assuming $17.1 million in debt. The shopping centers are the Meridian Mall in a suburb of Lansing, Mich., and the Janesville Mall, between Milwaukee and Madison, Wis. The seller is the closely held Samuels & Associates Inc. The purchase brings CBL's acquisitions in 1998 to 6.3 million square feet for a total investment of $570 million.

Currency declines in Mexico and the fear of a devaluation in Brazil are also adding pressure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILMOT, VIRGINIA L.
description: WILMOT-Virginia L. A resident of Greenwich and Nantucket, died suddenly Wednesday, August 26, at Greenwich Hospital. She was 61 years old and died of natural causes. Mrs. Wilmot is survived by her husband, Clifford R. Wilmot, her mother, Laura Catalano Lancellotti of Garden City, NY, and her brother, William G. Lancellotti, Jr. of Williamsburg, VA. In addition, Mrs. Wilmot is survived by six stepchildren, eight grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. Mrs. Wilmot had a long career in the advertising industry working for such companies as McCannErickson, Pepsico, The Magnavox Company, and Richard K. Manoff, Inc. Born on October 27, 1936, she was the daughter of Laura Lancellotti and the late William G. Lancellotti. She graduated from Centenary College for Women and the Katharine Gibbs School. Friends may call at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT, Sunday, August 30th from 2-5 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Monday, August 31 at 10AM, St. Mary's Church, 178 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich. Donations may be made in her memory to the Greenwich Hospital Association, 31 Perryridge Rd.

Is he a robot, she wonders, the Antichrist, a space alien, the Messiah? ''Oh, no, it's worse than I thought,'' she concludes. ''He's working for the Government.''

title: Riding Radio Merger Wave, Chancellor Will Buy Capstar
description: The radio merger wave started by deregulation two years ago has reached a new crest. The Chancellor Media Corporation said today that it planned to buy the Capstar Broadcasting Corporation for $2.3 billion in stock plus nearly $1.8 billion in assumed debt, surpassing CBS as the nation's largest chain of radio stations.

title: Fox Searches for Plan For Home Run Chase
description: Predicting when Mark McGwire or Sammy Sosa could tie or pass Roger Maris's home run record of 61 may be a job more suited for a psychic friend than a TV executive. But on Monday and Tuesday, Ed Goren, the co-executive producer of Fox Sports, huddled with baseball executives to estimate when the network might pre-empt its programming to show McGwire or Sosa swing for 61 or 62.

He is survived by his wife Barbara Baumann Shipley, and his two sons, Zachary Kane Shipley (Nicole) and Dr. Joshua Beale Shipley (Linda), and his six grandchildren Alexandra, Victoria, Genevieve, Nancy Kane, Anna, and Lillian Shipley. He leaves a stepdaughter, Melissa Baumann Siebert (Johannes) and stepson, Merrill John Baumann (Patricia) and their children Remsen, Peter, and Jared Baumann and Rafe Siebert. He was predeceased by his wife of forty-five years, Nancy Kane Shipley. We all loved him and will miss him terribly. There will be a memorial service in Washington D.C. in the early fall. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in his name may be sent to Hospice of Naples, 1095 Whippoorwill Lane, Naples, Florida 34105. For further information Fuller Funeral Home 1625 Pine Ridge Road, Naples, Florida 34109.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGEL, RICHARD I.
description: NAGEL-Richard I. Consultant to the restaurant and wine industry as well as an academic, Richard Nagel was born in New Jersey and graduated from Rutgers University Magna Cum Laude & Phi Beta Kappa. He became a Woodrow Wilson Fellow at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He joined the faculty of North Carolina State University in the Philosophy Dept, a position that he held for seven years before choosing the food and beverage industry as his passion and his career. He was the food editor of I-AM Magazine for two years and the Beverage Director for Vista International Hotel and Hilton International's Corporate Food and Beverage office for domestic operations for four years. Richard Nagel worked with the Management team responsible for operations of the Sign of the Dove and Arizona 206 and became a Vice President Of Morrell and Company before going on his own as a consultant with his firm Beverage Analytics. He was a philosopher and a dear friend whose generosity, love and compassion touched us all. His friends, Nikos Antonakeas, Roberta Morrell, Peter Morrell, Ruth Morrell, John and Adrienne Morrell, Kimberly Janis, David Whitaker, Peter Perrone, Carol Altholtz, Barbara Olmsted Bart, Jack Sheehy, Steve Epstein and Mikkel Louvorn

title: Time To Get Serious In Africa
description: As we sift through the wreckage from terrorist bombs in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam, and mount retaliatory strikes against the bad guys, we are reminded once again of our uniquely American vulnerability to terrorism. But the current turmoil in Central Africa, where rival African alliances are fighting for and against Laurent Kabila's Congo regime, should also serve as a lesson. We must not let a natural preoccupation with our own physical security blind us to the need for realistic policies in Africa that will deter or check the spread of conflict and protect our growing interests in the region.

title: Blast Suspect Held in U.S. And Is Said to Admit Role
description: Federal authorities have brought a suspect in the bombings of the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania to the United States, saying that he had admitted that he was trained at terror camps in Afghanistan run by Osama bin Laden, the Saudi-born multimillionaire suspected of having inspired, organized and financed the bombings.

description: The American Red Cross in Washington has named Kaplan Thaler Group in New York to handle the creative assignment for a long-term brand image advertising campaign.

title: Brooklyn's Irish: a Clear-Eyed Toast
description: With the cruel relish of a bleak Irish wit, Colin Quinn recalls for us the peculiar narrow-minded characters of his Brooklyn youth: J. T., the scornful druggie; Aidan, the venomous alcoholic; Margaret, the perpetual martyr; Jimmy, the judgmental do-nothing. Yet for all the dark and finely drawn characters he introduces in the course of his one-man show, the most surprising character on the stage of the Helen Hayes Theater is Mr. Quinn himself.

title: With Its Dollar Plummeting, Canada Raises Its Key Rate
description: After weeks of hesitation, Canada's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate by a full percentage point today in an effort to halt the slide of the Canadian dollar, which has lost more than 10 percent of its value against the United States dollar this year.

title: Yankees Are Now Working Harder for Their Victories
description: Their usually precise starter failed miserably, their usually reliable middle reliever stumbled as a closer, but their unreliable setup man and a rookie making his major league debut finally pitched sharply enough for the Yankees to erase some of their concerns and give them life last night. Just when the Angels were poised to smack the Yankees one last time before they boarded an airplane, the Yankees smacked back.

title: Marshall Barer, 75, Lyricist For 'Mattress' and Mighty Mouse
description: Marshall Barer, the lyricist and the book writer (with Jay Thompson and Dean Fuller) for ''Once Upon a Mattress'' (the 1959 show that introduced Carol Burnett to Broadway), and the wit who wrote the words for the Mighty Mouse theme song, died on Tuesday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 75 and had lived for many years in Venice, Calif., where his home had been an informal salon for West Coast songwriters and performers.

title: Rafter Continues to Blaze Through U.S. Open Tuneup
description: For Patrick Rafter, it was women's day at the Hamlet Cup. Rafter, the dashing Australian who is seeded second, gave his fans something to swoon over this afternoon when he signed autographs, kissed a woman celebrating her 40th birthday and charmed his way through a question-and-answer session with more than 400 women.

title: Love Lasts Forever (or at Least Till the Show's Over)
description: For Brian McKnight, love is a fervent promise in a cascade of notes. The women in the audience, who outnumbered men two to one, unanimously squealed ''Yes!'' and at least one added, ''Sing it, Brian!''

description: With one month to reach immortality, Sammy Sosa is being introduced to a new set of fans, who have some learning to do. Entering tonight's game at Coors Field, the Chicago Cubs right fielder needed 10 home runs to break Roger Maris's single-season record of 61. He stood only two back of Mark McGwire, the St. Louis Cardinals first baseman.

title: DIAL AGREES TO BUY MANUFACTURER OF BATH PRODUCTS
description: The Dial Corporation, the maker of Dial soap and Purex detergent, agreed yesterday to buy Sarah Michaels Inc. for $91 million in cash to expand its growing line of bath and body products. It will also assume $94 million in debt. Sarah Michaels is a closely held company that makes shampoos, bath gels and powders sold at retailers like Wal-Mart. It had sales of $72 million in 1997. The acquisition complements Dial's purchase of Freeman Cosmetic on July 1. Combined with Dial's Nature's Accents line, the acquisitions would create a bath and body business with annual revenue of almost $200 million.

description: A Federal judge has ruled that organizers of a Million Youth March can use the streets of Harlem on Sept. 5. The decision was unwelcome to the Giuliani administration, but Judge Lewis Kaplan's decision did appear to reduce the chances of a worrisome confrontation between police and marchers determined to take to the streets without a permit. However, there are other safety issues that still must be addressed.

title: The Pleasure of 'I Told You So'; Shut Out by CUC, a Securities Analyst Is Vindicated
description: Robert L. Renck Jr., a Wall Street securities analyst, is a rumpled man with a sad-eyed smile, the sort Hollywood might cast as a middle-aged New York City detective. Always outspoken, Mr. Renck, who rose to be an All-Star Analyst on Institutional Investor's roster, prides himself on asking tough questions of the companies he scrutinizes on behalf of potential investors. And he expects answers. ''If you're going to take the public's money,'' he says, ''you've got to take the public's questions.''

title: Love, Death, Racism and Just Look Who's the Sheik
description: With a half-dozen scenes of highly ritualized Philippine stick fighting and two striking ballroom dance episodes, Chris Millado's ''PeregriNasyon'' (''Wandering Nation'') strikes one as a play aspiring to become a ballet. Often during the performance by the Ma-Yi Theater Ensemble one wishes it were just that. Its story of dreams, adventure, love, loyalty, deadly conflict and loss is gripping and easy to comprehend, but frequently Mr. Millado's blurred plot and mystical dialogue get in the way.
