title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDAL, ELSA SAID
description: HANDAL-Elsa Said. A resident of Quito, Ecuador, died August 13, 1998, succumbing to the fatal effects of a cerebral aneurysm. Daughter of the late Juan Said and Sara Said, Santiago, Chile, she grew up in Peru and Chile, where she attended school and college. The Said family had extensive business interests in the financial and industrial areas in Chile, Peru and Bolivia. Her late husband, Abraham, who was involved in textiles & steel in South America, died at Lenox Hill Hospital on June 29, 1987. While in Ecuador, she was active in children's causes. Indeed, she will be remembered as a kind, understanding and supportive woman with a love for art and entertaining. She will be missed by her many friends and family in the United States and South America. Elsa is survived by her two children, John Handal of Quito, Ecuador & Susan Warner of New York City and her two grandchildren Philip Warner Jr., and Christina Warner. Ecclesiastical services were held at the Siervas de Maria Chapel in Ecuador and at St. Thomas More in New York. Interment was in New York and details regarding a memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZMAN, REBECCA NEE RECHIN
description: SALTZMAN-Rebecca nee Rechin. On August 26, 1998. Beloved wife of Boris. Loving mother, friend, and advisor to Burt and Kay. Cherished grandmother to Ian, Ben, Gabrielle, Nessa and Beth Moira. Great grandmother to Sarah and Adam. Stalwart in her beliefs; a steadfast family member, neighbor and friend.

title: Report Assails Transit Delays In Fixing Buses and Subways
description: New York City Transit's system for replacing faulty bus and subway parts is plagued by inefficiencies that compromise service and put passengers at potential risk, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said in a report released yesterday.

title: Rivera Welcomes Early Call
description: Mariano Rivera was surprised when he was told that his appearance on Wednesday was only the second time in his career that he had been summoned to notch a potential six-out save.

title: MARKETS JOLTED, DOW OFF 4.1% AS THE RUSSIAN ECONOMIC SLIDE ADDS TO PRESSURES ON YELTSIN
description: Stock market investors around the world, frightened by the depth of Russia's economic turmoil and its possibly contagious effect on Latin America, rushed for the exits yesterday in search of safer places to put their money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASSER, JUDGE LAWRENCE L.
description: LASSER-Judge Lawrence L. On August 26, 1998, of Pottersville, NJ. Beloved husband of Mary (nee Rosenfeld) Lasser. Devoted father of Peter L. Lasser, Thomas A. Lasser, Robert Lasser and Judy Weisman. Loving brother of John O. Lasser. Devoted grandfather of Elisabeth, Callie, Juliana, Allan & Madeleine Lasser; Katie, Melanie and Sam Weisman. Funeral from Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue, Short Hills, New Jersey on Friday, August 28th at 11 AM. For additional information please contact Bernheim-ApterGoldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, Maplewood, New Jersey at 973-763-3505.

title: 3 Suspects Bound for Cairo Held in Restaurant Bombing
description: Police officers investigating the bombing of a Planet Hollywood restaurant here stopped an Air Egypt plane on the tarmac as it was to take off for Cairo today and detained three people, a police spokesman said.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: The 100 Best, With Omissions

title: Eliminating Hidden Weapons; Too Much Secrecy on the Sudan
description: Americans of both parties rallied around President Clinton's decision to launch military strikes against alleged terrorist installations in Afghanistan and the Sudan. But the Administration's refusal to share more information about its choice of targets and timing is disturbing. By its excessive secrecy, Washington only increases skepticism about its claim that the Shifa chemical factory in the Sudan was really producing nerve gas ingredients and thus had to be destroyed to prevent new terrorist attacks.

title: An Evil Intruder in a Family Paradise
description: ''See the Sea'' and ''A Summer Dress'' were shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 31. The films open today at the Quad Cinema, 13th Street, west of Fifth Avenue, Greenwich Village.

title: Imagery of Slumber and Danger: A Prelude to the Apocalypse
description: One of the first images you see in ''Modern Times: Photography Between the Two World Wars'' in the Howard Gilman Gallery at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is Henri Cartier-Bresson's 1933 picture of a Spanish boy with his back arched in front of a wall splattered with paint or blood. ''Has this child been stabbed or is he in the throes of an ecstatic dance?'' the text on the wall asks. ''Actually he is arching his back to catch sight of a ball.'' Somehow, knowing the boy's real situation does not change the atmosphere of danger and ecstasy. The picture still invites a momentary panic that the boy is about to drop dead.

title: The Name Game
description: Naming a restaurant after a particular dish or ingredient is audacious. Certainly, it raises expectations for that dish. Here are a dozen restaurants in New York City where the food measures up to the name. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: A Cadillac Design Heads Toward the Edge
description: CADILLAC, with its rich tradition but lackluster recent past, has been casting about for a new flagship to embody the brand's attributes. Its designers have come up with a design concept for a two-seat roadster, the Evoq, that will be shown to the public at top-tier auto shows next year.

title: President Goes Forth, To Mixed Reception
description: Wading into a public arena for the first time since he admitted 10 days ago to having had an affair with a White House intern, President Clinton today received a strong vote of confidence for his public policies but a mixed review of his personal conduct.

title: In Census Sampling, People Are 'Lost'
description: To the Editor:

title: Turmoil in Russia And in the Markets
description: I.M.F. STEPS BACK -- No quick decision on lending more money to Russia. Page A12.

title: When a Show Must Go On, It Goes, Even for Few Fans
description: It should have been a summer treat as light and refreshing as a cherry ice, but the first American appearance by All Saints melted a little upon arrival. Wollman Rink in Central Park seemed like an ideal setting, given the vocal quartet's current status as England's newest sugar pop favorites and its dreamy American Top 10 hit, ''Never Ever.'' But the Wednesday night show, sponsored by DKNY Jeans, Interview Magazine and the radio station Z-100, fell prey to a humid, rainy night on which most of the fans who had free tickets decided to stay away.

title: Don't Rush to Judge Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Media Talk column of Business Day on Aug. 17 about the a change in the international edition of The Miami Herald described the plan incorrectly. The existing version will be replaced by a shortened version of the Miami edition; the international edition is not ending.

title: SNYDER SAYS IT WILL ACQUIRE CLINICAL COMMUNICATIONS
description: Snyder Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Clinical Communications Group, a closely held provider of marketing services to the pharmaceutical industry, for $108 million. Snyder, based in Bethesda, Md., is a marketing-services business with offices in the United States, Britain, France, Ireland and Hungary. Clinical Communications, based in Greenwich, Conn., provides CD-ROM's, satellite-delivered training services, custom publications and other products to pharmaceutical companies. Snyder shares fell $4.625, to $35.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGELSTEIN, NORMA
description: VOGELSTEIN-Norma. In loving memory of Norma, a very special and unique human being whose loss has left a great void in our lives. Our deepest sympathy and condolences to Charlie, Lynn and Stanley. With all our love, Melek, Buz, Sue, Beebo, Fran, Tiya & Doots

title: Bomb Explodes in Tel Aviv, Wounding a Woman Seriously
description: A pipe bomb exploded in a trash can on a busy Tel Aviv street today, causing one serious injury and adding to a new wave of tension in Israel and the West Bank.

title: Don't Rush to Judge Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Rolls-Royce Reports A Flat First Half
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the world's No. 2 airplane-engine maker, reported yesterday that it had no growth in the first half of the year in its core business as competition squeezed margins on engines. Operating profit for aero-engines before research and development costs was unchanged at $:195 million. But the company's net income rose 11.5 percent, to $:107 million ($175 million) from $:96 million. Lower research and development spending accounted for the increase, more than outweighing a decline in profit at its industrial power division.

title: Exotic Excursions to Self-Enlightenment
description: Matsuo Basho, the 17th-century Japanese haiku master, viewed travel as a path to self-enlightenment, to ''our everlasting self which is poetry.'' The photographers in ''Women Travelers'' at the Staley-Wise gallery in SoHo appear to share his sensibility, many of them producing astonishingly beautiful images of faraway places that are insistently expressionistic.

title: Making a Virtue of Banality Spiced by Glitz and Camp
description: Darren Hayes of Savage Garden, the Australian duo that performed at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night, seems to be playing out the fantasies of every singing waiter, piano bar patron and karaoke star in the history of sing-along pop. The vocalist's devilishly theatrical performance worked on show biz cliches with such jocularity that their broad strokes hit like air kisses.

title: Metro Matters; Big State, Big Dreams, Big Talk
description: I love NY as much as the next guy. But still I don't quite get it.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Week in Review on Sunday about hypocrisy in Washington misspelled the name of an expert on manners. She is Letitia Baldrige, not Baldridge.

title: When a Pure Poet Falls Back to Earth
description: Six decades before poetry slams turned a fragile literary art form into a gladiatorial sport, wiltingly sensitive versifiers who would faint if asked to declaim their rhymes on a stage could bask in the fantasy that publishing a slender volume of their exquisite insights might one day catapult them into international fame and fortune. As T. S. Eliot had proved and W. H. Auden was showing, in the 1930's, poets could be stars. According to the myth of the starving artist, to be a great poet was to follow a higher calling worth almost any sacrifice of material comfort.

title: Caterer Settles Lawsuit Claiming Bias Against Female Waiters
description: One of New York City's best-known caterers has agreed to pay $425,000 to settle a class-action sex discrimination lawsuit brought by waitresses who said they were denied the opportunity to work at lucrative private parties.

title: Toms River Leaps Into Little League Final
description: They all made the pilgrimage here from Toms River, N.J. Several hundred came by the busload and the carload, having clearly caught the fever over their Little League team. One devoted fan even came dressed in a monkey suit, holding up a sign that read, ''Unleash the Beast from the East.''

title: Counterfeiting Scheme Used City's Stationery
description: Counterfeiters were literally trying to make a profit off the city of Newark's name, Federal agents said yesterday.

title: Now 'Titanic' Goes by Truck
description: No one knows exactly how big it will get. But big. ''Nothing approaches this,'' said Stan Meyers, executive vice president of Baker & Taylor, the country's second largest video distributor. After many years in the business, Mr. Meyers has seen the biggest: ''The Lion King'' (the very biggest), ''Jurassic Park,'' ''Forrest Gump,'' ''Men in Black.'' Now, though, casting a larger shadow across the landscape than the spaceship in ''Independence Day'' (the second biggest), comes ''Titanic.''

title: Korean Economy Shrinks by 6.6%
description: South Korea's recession deepened in the second quarter, data released today showed, and the economic contraction could worsen further.

title: To Much Relief, Hurricane Fails to Live Up to Potential
description: Two years ago, residents of this surfside resort just east of Wilmington, returned to their island after the passing of Hurricane Fran and found utter devastation. Sand dunes were flattened. Beachfront houses were swamped. Boats were tossed ashore.

title: Billboard Plan To Name Drug Dealers
description: Aside from facing a prison term, convicted drug dealers in Brick Township could also have their names posted in public on billboards under a plan approved by the Atlantic County Prosecutor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANHEIMER, MARJORIE
description: MANHEIMER-Marjorie. In Plantation, FL. on August 20, 1998. Cherished wife of Henry S. Manheimer, beloved mother of Robert and Peter, loving mother-in-law of Bonnie, devoted grandmother of Kenneth, Sarah, Dena, Charles, and Eric, sister of Richard S. Stein. Service and interment at 3:00 PM Sunday, August 30, 1998, at Union Field Cemetery, 8211 Cypress Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens.

title: From the U.S.: No New Answers, No New Money
description: With Russia in economic free fall and only four days before a planned summit meeting between President Clinton and the Russian President, Boris Yeltsin, Clinton Administration officials said today that Mr. Clinton would go to Moscow with words of encouragement but no new money.

title: M.F.S. PRO CHAMPIONSHIPS
description: Pioline and Muster Head to Quarters

title: From a Published Judge to a Published Poet
description: WHEN Bruce M. Wright was a Criminal Court judge in the 1970's, his habit of setting low bail or no bail for some of the black defendants who came before him earned him the name Turn 'em Loose Bruce, but in some quarters he was -- and remains -- a hero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNN, HARRY H., JR.
description: LUNN-Harry H., Jr. Christie's Photographs Departments in New York and London mourn the loss of our friend, colleague, and mentor Harry H. Lunn, Jr.

title: Where a Sense of Place Is Still Cast in Stone
description: Like a dowager in decline, Buffalo still has good bones to remind people of her more prosperous and glamorous days.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEORGE, ALLAN
description: GEORGE-Allan. 7/31/14 to 8/28/79. A unique man, remembered by everyone who knew him. You live on in my heart and soul. Life has never been the same. Love always, Catherine.

title: I.M.F., Pressing Russia on Earlier Loan Pact, Takes Time to Rule on New Cash
description: Rather than give Russia a quick infusion of money in an emergency attempt to ease its economic crisis, the International Monetary Fund has apparently decided to take up to a month to consider whether to lend Russia more money.

title: INSIDE
description: Trouble on Sex Offender Law

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ROBERT I.
description: GOLDMAN-Robert I. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation are deeply saddened at the death of Robert I. Goldman, a stalwart supporter, dedicated friend, and devoted member of our Banking and Finance Committee. His commitment to our mission was reflected in his exemplary efforts on behalf of the Jewish people at home & abroad. We will always remember him, not only for his personal generosity, but also for his leadership role as a campaign volunteer. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Melva; his daughter and son-in-law, Olexa and Bowen Farrell, and all the members of the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Donald H. Layton, Chair, Banking and Finance Div. Stephen D. Solender, Exec. VP

title: F.T.C. Says Merck Deal Cut Competition
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that Merck & Company had reduced competition in the pharmaceuticals market for a time after it bought Medco Containment Services, a managed-care drug sales company, in 1993. Merck announced on Wednesday that it had agreed to antitrust safeguards requested by the commission.

title: Second-Quarter Economic Growth Faster Than Estimated
description: The economy grew at a faster pace in the second quarter than previously estimated, even though it was weighed down by the strikes at the General Motors Corporation and slower exports to Asia.

title: Sharp Eye (and Wit) for Foibles
description: Not many visual artists view their work as plays or novels, but that was how the English satirist and social critic William Hogarth (1697-1756) saw his. He spun out scathing sagas in the form of paintings and engravings, produced in series like the famous eight-part ''Rake's Progress'' (1735) and the six-chapter ''Marriage a la Mode'' (1745).

title: Hooked on Big-Yield Government Bonds, Credit Industry Reaps Whirlwind
description: It was a brief but wild ride for Russia's cowboy banking empires, and, like the economy on which they were saddled, they appear headed for disaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILNER, LILLIAN
description: WILNER-Lillian. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Lillian Wilner, beloved mother of our devoted members Dr. Mark and Beth Wilner. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, BARBARA BLIVEN
description: TURNER-Barbara Bliven. Beloved cousin of Anne Logue Belickis. Memorial services will be held at a later time. Andrett Funeral Home

title: Toms River Reaches Little League Final
description: With hundreds of hometown supporters in the stands at Williamsport, Pa., the Toms River, N.J., team defeated Greenville, N.C., 5-2, last night to take the United States championship and reach the final of the Little League World Series.

title: Feel the City's Pulse? It's Be-bop, Man!
description: In 1964, Thelonious Monk, one of the pioneers of be-bop and perhaps jazz's greatest composer, was asked by an interviewer to define jazz. Though Monk disliked questions and usually ignored them, this time he didn't miss a beat: ''New York, man. You can feel it. It's around in the air.''

title: That Profitable Prophet Communed With Death
description: Strange things are afoot again in the Buckinghamshire village of Midsomer, this time at the Lodge of the Golden Wind Horse. That's a comfy commune whose paying customers hope to be transported to a higher spiritual plane. Trouble is, some people there are leaving this lower plane rather abruptly. Dead, you know.

title: Nazi-Era Slave Laborers to Sue German Companies
description: FRANKFURT  A New York lawyer who has successfully pressed legal cases linked to the Holocaust against Swiss banks said Thursday that he would file a sweeping class-action lawsuit in the United States on Monday against 16 German industrial companies seeking damages on behalf of wartime slave laborers.

title: Story of '54,' As in Studio
description: In the 70's, the cult of hedonism and fame was celebrated nowhere more zealously than at the Manhattan disco Studio 54. Mark Christopher seeks to evoke the demonic energy of that club awash in light, sounds and drug-enhanced eroticism in ''54.'' The film follows a young hustler (Ryan Phillippe, above) as he climbs from busboy to bartender under the wing of the club's director, Steve Rubell (Mike Myers). Assorted glitterati have cameos.

title: Investing in Subways
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutual Fund Investors Seek Safer Havens
description: Individual investors, whose determination to buy stocks whenever the market takes a tumble has been the bulwark of the bull market of the 1990's, appear to be weakening under the weight of a monthlong decline in equity prices.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Summer hours vary for galleries and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Amoco Is Sued Over Brain Tumors in Workers
description: Over several decades, 19 current or former employees of an Amoco Corporation research center in the Chicago suburbs have been stricken with brain tumors and four of them have died. Nobody knows why, and researchers hired by Amoco have been trying to figure out whether the cases have a common cause.

title: A 50's Meteor, in Music and Romance
description: In the raucous, comic ''Rashomon'' of rock-and-roll titled ''Why Do Fools Fall in Love,'' the brief, meteoric career and busy, turbulent marital life of the singer Frankie Lymon furnish the pretext for a trip through time to the 1950's and 60's, when much of a generation fell under the spell of a new kind of music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRON, IRVING R., DDS
description: BARRON-Irving R., DDS. On Aug. 25. Formerly in practice in Flushing and Greenpoint. Husband of the late Dora Katz Barron. Father of Bonnie Richman and Reesa (David A.) Ackerman. Grandfather of Jeffrey, Andrew, and Kevin Schachter. Great-grandfather of Jessica Schachter. Brother of Manuel and Edward. Companion of Evelyn Bittman. We have lost a truly kind, loving and gentle man.

title: Council Overrides Veto on Stadium Vote
description: Reviving the debate with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over a referendum on a new stadium for the Yankees, the City Council voted 39 to 8 yesterday to override the Mayor's veto of a bill that would put the question to voters in the fall.

title: FRENCH COMPANY IN $1.4 BILLION DEAL FOR BERG
description: The Berg Electronics Corporation, the fourth-largest maker of electronic connectors, agreed yesterday to be acquired by the No. 3 company, Framatome Connectors International of France, for about $1.4 billion in stock. Framatome will pay $35 a share for Berg's shares, and it will assume almost $400 million of debt, Berg said. Shares of Berg climbed $10.4375, or 48 percent, to $32. The combination would make Framatome the second-largest maker of the devices used in everything from coffee makers to computers, behind AMP Inc., which is fighting a takeover offer from Allied Signal Inc. The Dallas-based investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst bought Berg in 1993 from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, and partners at Hicks, Muse and at Mills & Partners still own about 20 percent of Berg.

title: Considering Familiar Turf From Unfamiliar Angles
description: David Lowery has every right to call himself a Southern rocker. He started his musical career in Northern California with the hippie-punk consortium Camper Van Beethoven, but for many years he has lived in Richmond, where he leads the hard-hitting rock band Cracker. On Wednesday night at Irving Plaza, supporting its newest album, ''Gentleman's Blues'' (Virgin), Cracker boogied with the best.

title: IVEX PACKAGING FORMS JOINT VENTURE TO BUY BAGCRAFT
description: The Ivex Packaging Corporation said yesterday that it had created a joint venture that would buy the Bagcraft Corporation of America from Artra Group Inc. for $89 million in cash and a $2.5 million promissory note. Ivex will receive a 49 percent stake in the venture, called Packaging Dynamics, and an undisclosed amount of cash and debt, in exchange for its Detroit paper mill. Ivex and Bagcraft executives, along with other investors, will control the remaining 51 percent. Bagcraft makes sandwich wraps, window bags, microwave popcorn bags and waxed bags. Ivex makes specialty bags for consumer and industrial products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EZRA
description: COHEN-Ezra. On Aug. 26, 1998. Born Brooklyn, NY May 4, 1919. Loving husband of Ray. Devoted father of Barbara, Marilyn, Jacqueline and Susan. Doting grandfather of 14 grandchildren. Also survived by 7 brothers and sisters. Formerly vice president of the Sunweave Linen Corp. Active supporter of the UJA. He will surely be missed by all who he touched. He was a man who believed that actions speak louder than words. He lived his whole life by this.

title: Residential Real Estate; Putting Big Lofts in Small Buildings
description: Residential brokers call them boutique buildings, small former commercial structures in downtown Manhattan neighborhoods that developers are converting to spacious condominium lofts to appeal to families moving to the area.

title: At Least Psychologically, Moscow's Shadow Is Looming Large
description: Fears of an economic meltdown in Russia put heavy new pressures on Central Europe today, but many economists and Government officials said the reaction was driven more by market psychology than economic fundamentals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, NATHAN
description: KLEIN-Nathan. After an extended illness. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Father of Seena & Edward Parker, Maxine and Steven Greenspan. Grandfather of Jeremy Parker, Adam & Janis Greenspan. Services Friday, 11:15AM, Riverside Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Attorney General Rejects Lowering Alcohol Limits
description: In a report delivered to a Senate task force yesterday, State Attorney General Peter G. Verniero said he would not recommend that New Jersey lower the blood alcohol level for drunken driving to 0.08 from 0.10 because there is not enough evidence to show that drivers are significantly impaired at the lower level.

title: Careful Steps On Career Path
description: Renee Zellweger (left) has a few things in common with Ellen Gulden, the character Ms. Zellweger plays in the coming ''One True Thing,'' which also stars Meryl Streep and William Hurt and is to be released by Universal on Sept. 18. Ellen is a budding magazine writer, and Ms. Zellweger initially wanted to major in journalism when she entered the University of Texas. The two are brainy. They are also uncompromising, but in a way that sets them apart and also explains why Ms. Zellweger, a surprise hit in ''Jerry Maguire'' two years ago, has been choosy in the parts she has played since then and is only now emerging with a major role in a big picture.

title: New York Council Approves Stiffer Campaign Fund Rules
description: The New York City Council voted overwhelmingly yesterday to revamp the city's campaign finance rules, seeking to reduce the role of money in elections and to ease fund-raising burdens that often leave candidates spending more time speaking to donors than speaking about issues.

title: Eliminating Hidden Weapons; Illusory Inspections in Iraq
description: The resignation of Scott Ritter, a top American inspector on the United Nations team charged with penetrating Iraq's deadly-weapons program, is the latest and most dramatic warning that the Clinton Administration and the U.N. are abandoning a firm approach toward President Saddam Hussein. Richard Butler, chairman of the U.N. inspection team, and Mohammed el-Baradei, head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, have previously warned that the inspectors could no longer guarantee they had Iraq's weapons programs adequately policed. Now Mr. Ritter charges that the inspections designed to ferret out hidden weapons have become an illusion.

title: The Fellow Travelers
description: In his drive to consolidate his power, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin has embarked on the first attempt since the fall of the Soviet Union to negotiate a sharing of power between the remains of the Communist Party and the tycoons who rose from the ashes of socialism.

title: Teen-Ager Says Father Physically Abused Her
description: After the Croatian teen-ager Mirjana Lucic accused her father and coach, Marinko, of physically and mentally terrorizing her for the past 10 years while grooming her for tennis stardom, she has fled to the United States with her mother and four siblings. Mirjana Lucic is, on the eve of the United States Open, seeking a restraining order to prevent him from interfering with her when she competes there next week.

title: Washington Stands By, Keeping Its Head Down
description: When Russia was the heartland of what Ronald Reagan called the Evil Empire, bent on spreading Communist dogma and power around the globe, the United States developed economic, military and diplomatic weapons to contain and eventually to help eliminate the danger.

title: BB&T AGREES TO $554 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR MAINSTREET
description: The BB&T Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Mainstreet Financial Corporation in a stock transaction valued at $554.3 million. The transaction will be accounted for as a pooling of interests, with an exchange ratio set at 1.18 shares of BB&T common stock for each share of Mainstreet common stock. Mainstreet's shares jumped $7.875 each, or 30 percent, to $33.375, while BB&T's stock was down $1.50, to $30.6875. BB&T, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., operates 512 banking offices in the Carolinas, Virginia, Maryland and Washington, D.C. Mainstreet, based in Martinsville, Va., operates 11 community banks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 8 about security standards at American embassies and a chart that day showing the time line of attacks on American targets abroad misstated the number of deaths in a bombing in Lebanon in September 1984. Similar errors appeared in a chart on Aug. 9 and an article on Aug. 10 about the Administration's urging increased spending for embassy security.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISLER, HAROLD K.
description: RAISLER-Harold K. Beloved husband of Aline Stevens and the late Mary. Loving father of Jeanne Raisler and son-in-law Jonathan. Devoted grandfather of Joshua and Josina. Cherished brother of Robert and Dolly, stepchildren Peggy and Marty Winkelman and Randall and Alice Stevens, grandchildren Taryn, Jaime & Tiffany, nephews Steven & Gordon Jacobson. His optimism and outstanding generosity has enriched all our lives. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday, August 27, 6-9 PM. Service Friday, August 28, 11:30 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHMAN, RICHARD K.
description: GERSHMAN-Richard K. On August 26 at age 69, Richard Gershman died in the New Milford, CT. Hospital of respiratory disease. Son of the late Isaac Gershman (former general manager of the City News Bureau of Chicago) and the late Agnhild Gershman. Richard was born in Winnetka, Illinois. Richard was a journalist for the City News Bureau and later was a public relations representative first for CBS and then for various other firms and govermental agencies. He is survived by the love of Ruth Carpenter of New Milford, Connecticut, the Gershman family of Stamford, Connecticut, and Riverside, California, and the Kennedy family of New Haven, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, gifts in his memory should be made to the New Milford Hospital.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Rain Is Likely As Storm Lasts
description: As the remnants of Hurricane Bonnie move out into the Atlantic, forecasters say the weather today in the New York metropolitan region will be mixed.

title: BANCORPSOUTH AGREES TO BUY FIRST CORP. OF ALABAMA
description: Bancorpsouth Inc., based in Tupelo, Miss., agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held First Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. The First Corporation, based in Opelika, Ala., is the holding company for the First National Bank of Opelika, which has two offices and assets of $150 million. Bancorpsouth has assets of $4.5 billion and operates 134 bank offices in Mississippi and Tennessee. Earlier this summer, Bancorpsouth and the Alabama Bancorp, Inc. agreed to a merger, which is expected to be completed this fall. Bancorpsouth's stock fell 56.25 cents, to $18.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The Sky Is Blue and the Waves Are Unpredictable: Surf's Up!
description: The sky was brilliant blue and the water had a silver sheen of glare. I sat on my nine-foot surfboard and waited for one of the waves that give Long Island's most famous surfing spot, Ditch Plains in Montauk, the reputation for making even average surf seem perfect.

title: Now, Conflicting Views From Women Who Supported Clinton
description: There is something startling about the vocabulary that women who have supported President Clinton now use in conversations about him: phrases like skirt chaser and laughingstock, nouns like idiot and jerk, adjectives like feckless, sleazy, self-indulgent, gross.

title: Eddie Shipstad, 91, Skater and Founder of Touring Ice Show
description: Eddie Shipstad, a onetime Minnesota rink rat who learned early that a little fancy skating would attract a crowd on the ponds of St. Paul, then made a fortune proving that a lot of fancy skating would draw throngs across the country, died on Aug. 20 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 91 and a founder of the Shipstad and Johnson Ice Follies, the first of the traveling extravaganzas on ice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROUTT, DR. BOBBYE
description: TROUTT-Dr. Bobbye. The New York University Postdoctoral Program in psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis deeply mourns the loss of Dr. Bobbye Troutt. As supervisor, analyst, teacher and friend, she inspired us with her warmth, humor and generosity, with her rare ability to combine intellectual brilliance with intimate compassion, and with her courage and integrity. She was an irreplaceable member of our community.

title: FOSTER WHEELER TO REVAMP A UNIT AND TAKE A CHARGE
description: The Foster Wheeler Corporation said yesterday that it planned to revamp its Power Systems Group and post a third-quarter charge of $175 million for its Robbins Resource Recovery operations. The company also said it planned to change its accounting policy for development and start-up costs and to cut overhead costs of the group in half, to $7.5 million. Foster Wheeler, based in Clinton, N.J., is a global construction and engineering company. The decision to post a charge for the Robbins waste-to-energy operations in suburban Chicago came after a warning last month by the company that a reserve established last year to cover mounting losses at the incinerator would run dry in the fourth quarter. Foster Wheeler's shares slipped 56.25 cents, to $13.3125.

title: Japan Stocks Fall 2%, but Rebound From a 12-Year Low
description: Stock markets around Asia nose-dived in early trading today, as investors feared that the deep Russian economic crisis would hinder economic growth in the West and slow a recovery in this region.

title: Graf Looks Like Graf In Walloping Coetzer
description: Not many players have beaten Steffi Graf three times in one year. But Amanda Coetzer of South Africa is one of them, having defeated her in three of their four meetings last year, with two of those victories coming in Grand Slam events, the Australian Open and French Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUME, DONALD
description: HUME-Donald. The Brooklyn College community mourns the passing of Donald Hume. His forty-one years of service to the college will be long remembered and deeply appreciated. Vernon E. Lattin, President, Brooklyn College

title: The Allies Of Samper Eye Asylum
description: As a court investigation opens into a 1996 decision by Congress to clear the President at the time, Ernesto Samper, of criminal charges, a group that championed him in Congress is trying to obtain asylum in Europe.

title: SALTON/MAXIM IN $53 MILLION DEAL FOR TOASTMASTER
description: Salton/Maxim Housewares Inc., a maker of household and personal-care appliances, agreed yesterday to acquire Toastmaster Inc. for $7 a share, or $53.2 million. It will also assume debt of $47.9 million. Salton/Maxim, based in Mount Prospect, Ill., markets kitchen and home appliances, personal and beauty care products and clocks. Toastmaster, based in Columbia, Mo., makes such electrical consumer appliances as bread makers, toasters, ovens and clocks. It had full-year revenue of $155.3 million, as of June 30. Toastmaster's stock rose 25 cents yesterday, to $6.375. Salton/Maxim fell $1.5625, to $12.9375.

title: Paperweights: Beauty Plays All the Angles
description: What do President Clinton, King Farouk, Eva Peron, Colette and Truman Capote all have in common?

title: In the Fury of a Hurricane, TV Crews Cover the Storm by Standing in It
description: Beside an overturned basketball goal in Morehead City, N.C., Jim Cantore abandoned the comparative safety of his Weather Channel ''live'' truck, planted his feet, squinted one eye against the blowing rain and, with his pants legs flapping madly and the wind rushing into the microphone with an electronically muted roar, brought Hurricane Bonnie into America's living rooms.

title: Internet Concern Names First Agency
description: The San Francisco office of Saatchi & Saatchi was named yesterday as the first agency of record for Snap, an Internet directory, search and navigation service based in San Francisco.

title: Malaysia Output Down 6.8%; Nation Formally in Recession
description: Malaysia's economy contracted for a second consecutive quarter, the central bank said today, confirming that the country had fallen into recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, PEARL
description: SIEGEL-Pearl. Devoted wife of the late Joseph Rosenzweig and the late Leo Siegel. Adored and adoring mother of Cindi & David. Loving sister of Murray Roseman. Cherished aunt. A gentle soul who touched all she knew and was equally loved by all. Services are Friday at 12 noon, at ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Fringe Benefits For Children
description: The creators of the Second Annual New York International Fringe Festival are making sure that this year children aren't, well, left on the fringes. They have not only set up Fringe Jr., a series of quirky productions for young theatergoers, but they have also established a kind of drama central where children can try performance art of their own.

title: MARKETS JOLTED, DOW OFF 4.1% AS THE RUSSIAN ECONOMIC SLIDE ADDS TO PRESSURES ON YELTSIN -- His Opponents Want Changes, Including Him
description: Pressure mounted today on President Boris N. Yeltsin to cede some of his powers or even step aside as Russia's political leaders frantically negotiated over fundamental changes in the country's economic policies.

title: Ahab's Wife, Ignored in 'Moby-Dick,' Tries Again
description: Near the beginning of ''Moby-Dick,'' Herman Melville's epic tale of Faustian obsession, the narrator, Ishmael, learns about the man under whom he's about to embark on a three-year whaling cruise. It seems that Captain Ahab might be dangerously depressive, even a little crazy. But, declares Ishmael's informant, Captain Peleg, it is ''better to sail with a moody good captain than a laughing bad one.'' To which he adds, ''Besides, my boy, he has a wife -- not three voyages wedded -- a sweet, resigned girl.''

title: In International
description: NOT MUCH ADO ABOUT MOSCOW -- Russia's crises may threaten world markets, but it has not set off an emergency mobilization in Washington. Page A13.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUBRIN, ROSALYN
description: ZUBRIN-Rosalyn. On August 26, 1998. Beloved wife of Charles. Devoted mother of Linda Zubrin Ratner and Robert Zubrin; mother-inlaw of Dr. Douglas Ratner and Maggie Zubrin. Cherished grandmother of Jessica, David, Rachel, Sarah and Elliot. Services Friday, 12 noon, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opp LIRR), Great Neck, NY

title: In Business
description: COMMODITY PRICES SLIDE -- While selloffs on markets worldwide unnerved investors, the fall in commodity prices may be more worrisome in the long run. Page D1.

title: Don't Rush to Judge Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZBEDA, REGINA
description: ZBEDA-Regina. Sutton Place Synagogue extends condolences to our devoted member, George Zbeda and his family on the loss of their beloved mother and grandmother. Our sympathies to the entire bereaved family. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: An Uphill Battle for an Audience; Voter Interest Lags in Democratic Race for Attorney General
description: When the political season began, Dennis C. Vacco, New York's Republican Attorney General, presented an enticing target for Democrats. His poll ratings were lackluster, critics said he had dismissed a corps of experienced lawyers in favor of less-experienced ones with Republican ties, and he had been accused of not being tough enough on tobacco companies and corporate polluters.

title: The Fed's Modest Agenda
description: Today is the last day of the Federal Reserve's annual retreat in Jackson Hole, Wyoming. And to my surprise, they have been discussing economic inequality.

title: A Cabalist Riddle in a Mystery About Mysticism
description: THE LAST KABBALIST OF LISBON

title: Not Lost in Surf, Just Evading the Police
description: With Hurricane Bonnie bearing down on the Eastern Seaboard and rough surf advisories in effect, it was just the type of emergency call that rescue workers had been bracing for. Kimberly Kuda flagged down a police officer in Point Pleasant Beach just after 7:30 P.M. Monday to say her future husband had been swept into the Atlantic.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I've been surprised by how profoundly this has shaken me. On behalf of the 24-year-old girl that I used to be and the 46-year-old wife that I am now, I feel very shaken and betrayed on a personal level.''

title: New Video Releases
description: The Real Blonde

title: Chekhov Updated: 'Got a Problem With That?'
description: Honestly, the idea of chasing actors across Washington Square Park as they performed Chekhov was not all that appealing. That's the sort of thing the Gorilla Repertory Theater Company does. The actors perform a play in some outdoor setting, but when the scene shifts, nobody puts a new set in place; instead, the actors just move to a different area of the park, courtyard or whatever. The audience follows.

title: Environmentalists Assail Plans to Build Highway
description: A coalition of environmental groups stepped up a campaign against a proposed four-lane highway between the New Jersey Turnpike and Route 1 in South Brunswick yesterday, starting a television commercial that asks residents to telephone Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to oppose the plan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Libya's response to a proposal to bring two suspects to trial in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, misstated the nature of economic sanctions against Libya. The country is prohibited from importing certain items, not from exporting them.

title: Hitra Island Journal; Norway's Awesome Nature, Awesomely Overcome
description: Norwegians have long looked out on their deep fjords, snow-crested peaks and scatterings of scrub-covered islands as soaring symbols of their wilderness culture.

title: 6-Foot Snake Greets Tenants In New Home
description: When they moved to a new apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, on Wednesday, Pi Ming Chen and his family had no idea that one of the old tenants would try to stay on as a squatter. Yesterday, they found the hanger-on: a six-foot-long boa constrictor, curled around the base of a bathtub.

title: Giants Shrug Off Early Predictions
description: Quarterback Danny Kanell was asked this week if a victory was important in the Giants' final preseason game tonight against the Baltimore Ravens. If the Giants lose, they will complete the preseason with a 1-3 record.

title: Ex-Miami Commissioner Pleads Guilty in Conspiracy Case
description: A former Miami City Commissioner, Humberto E. Hernandez, pleaded guilty today to a Federal charge of conspiracy to commit bank, wire and mail fraud, less than two weeks after a Florida judge sentenced him to a year in prison for a misdemeanor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUGHLIN, GERTRUDE HUSTON
description: LAUGHLIN - Gertrude Huston. Wife of the late James Laughlin, died Wednesday, August 26, 1998 after a long illness, at her home, Meadow House, Norfolk, CT. Mrs. Laughlin was born in NYC and grew up in New York & Wilton, CT. She studied at Parsons School of Design in Manhattan and after completing her course of study worked for Helena Rubenstein in New York and Lucien Lelong in Chicago, before returning to New York to work at Blaker Advertising Agency. She later become the Art Director at New Directions Publishing Corporation, which was founded by her late husband. Mrs. Laughlin was for many years secretary of Community Board No. 5 in Manhattan and was active at Midtown South Police Precinct Community Council and at Encore Community Services of St. Malachy's Church. She was also a dedicated member of the Duke Ellington Society. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Encore Community Services of St. Malachy's Church, NYC, Norfolk Lions Club Volunteer Ambulance Fund, or Foothills Visiting Nurse Association of Litchfield County, Connecticut. Memorial service at noon on Saturday, August 29, at Church of Christ Congregational, Norfolk, CT.

description: In percent

description: Theater

title: Qaddafi Says 'Negotiation' Is Needed on Lockerbie Suspects
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said today that Libya would have to negotiate certain guarantees before he could feel confident about turning over for trial two suspects wanted in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about new variations on the napoleon pastry misstated the surname of a Brooklyn culinary historian. She is Leslie Brenner, not Brennan.

title: Sex, Drugs and Disco As a Hustler Gains A Suspect Celebrity
description: Years from now, if Mark Christopher's timid, meandering film ''54'' is spoken of at all, it will probably be lumped together with Whit Stillman's ''Last Days of Disco'' as one of two movies released in 1998 to bungle the same opportunity. Both films, while purporting to examine New York City's voracious late-1970's disco culture, adopt a primly distanced attitude toward a moment, just before the AIDS epidemic struck, when voluptuous hedonism became a kind of mass hysteria. Sex, drugs and disco: you couldn't ask for a juicier mix. But when it comes to squeezing juice, both movies come up dry.

title: Observer; The Pundit Warms Up
description: Diary of another day in the life:

title: Hush Puppies Co. Chooses Arnold
description: The Hush Puppies Company division of Wolverine World Wide announced unexpectedly yesterday that it had chosen Arnold Communications in Boston to create a global branding and integrated marketing campaign for the Hush Puppies footwear brand. Billings, estimated at $4 million, are expected to increase next year to $5 million to $10 million.

title: With Suspect in Town, Giuliani Steps Up Security
description: After learning yesterday that two suspects in the bombing of the United States Embassy in Kenya would be detained and prosecuted in New York City, city officials announced immediate plans to increase security in a section of lower Manhattan dominated by court and municipal buildings.

title: Officials of Men's Tour Ban Androstenedione
description: Citing health concerns, the men's tennis tour today banned androstenedione, the testosterone-producing pill used by the Cardinals slugger Mark McGwire.

title: Business Leaders Criticize City's Schools
description: New York business leaders have little confidence in the city's public schools, with many saying that high school graduates lack the skills needed to succeed in the workplace, according to a report released yesterday.

title: ING Income Rose 63% In the 2d Quarter
description: ING Groep N.V., Europe's fifth-largest financial-services company, indicated second-quarter profit rose 63 percent, helped by United States and Belgian acquisitions and as life insurance offset weakness in banking. Profit rose to 1.90 billion guilders ($930 million), from 1.17 billion last year, according to calculations based on first-half and first-quarter results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYP, COHEN, RUTH
description: RYP-COHEN-Ruth, 95. Loving mother to Judge Norman and the late Herbert Ryp; devoted grandmother to Benjamin, Margaux, Jacob and Elisheva; dedicated sister to David and Ruth Leventhal, Miriam Lewis & the late Edna Kessler & Sally Avis. An Eishes Chayil to all in Mitzvos, personal & business life. Graveside services Friday, August 28, 1998 at 11:30 A.M., Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey, 201-843-7628. For Shiva details 212-374-8470.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGHEE, ELIZABETH
description: McGHEE-Elizabeth. On August 23, 1998 at her home on Martha's Vineyard. Known to all as Buddy. She was the beloved widow of Dean Paul A. McGhee, mother of Stephen and Peter, grandmother of Paul, Elizabeth and Geoffrey, and friend to many of all ages on the isles of Manhattan and Martha's Vineyard. Burial is on Saturday, September 5. in Chilmark at 4:00 PM.

description: To the Editor:

description: A picture in the chart on Aug. 8, showing a bombing in Saudi Arabia, was connected to the wrong date on the time line. The event occurred in 1996, not 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAINER, MARGARET
description: HAINER-Margaret, age 93. On August 24, 1998. Wife of the late Irving. Loving mother of Martin and Ronald. Dear mother-in-law of Hilda and Jeanette. Beloved grandmother and great grandmother. Interment will be private.

title: One Too Many Jams Foil Reynoso
description: Bobby Valentine found himself in a quandary at 3Com Park today. His starter for the Mets, Armando Reynoso, had made 27 pitches in the first inning and 28 pitches in the second, and he had pitched out of serious jams both times.

title: The Travel Channel and Conde Nast Traveler are teaming up for a variety of cross-ventures.
description: A LEADING travel magazine is joining forces with a cable television network devoted to travel for cross-media and cross-marketing ventures that will include a prime-time travelogue series.

title: Parcells Has a Vision for Jets, but Just What Is It?
description: Hang around Bill Parcells long enough and you will hear him grumble and grunt, ''I go by what I see.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, WILLIAM H.
description: ROSENBERG-William H. Died August 28. Age 88. Decorated World War II veteran, he was also a Mason of the highest order. Survived by nephews Benjamin and Martin Lipnack and spouses and great nieces and nephews. Services on Sunday, at 9:45 A.M., at ''Garlick's,'' Coney Island Avenue near Avenue N, Brooklyn.

description: One statistic stands out to explain the importance of Japan, along with its misery:

title: A Nightmare in Search of Six Characters
description: Mark Dendy has moved from go-for-broke physicality to more carefully considered-seeming choreography and on to acting in his long, rich career in dance. His ''Dream Analysis,'' seen in January at the Joyce Theater, tied those threads together with daring sleight-of-hand. In the full-evening piece, which reopened on Thursday night for a three-week run at Dance Theater Workshop, a young gay dancer and his psychotherapist, who is in drag, talked their way through a nightmare inhabited by two Martha Grahams, two Vaslav Nijinskys, Judy Garland, a demented Southern mother, an even nuttier aunt, the dancer himself, two sadistic dance teachers and characters from ballets Nijinsky created or performed in. Astonishingly, they are all played by a cast of six.

title: Report Says 161 Schools Are in Need Of Repairs
description: In response to a state judge's order, New York City school officials reported yesterday that 161 of the city's 1,028 school buildings need repairs immediately or in the near future.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER FALLS. The prices of silver and other metals slumped, reflecting continued concerns that world economic instability will dim demand. In New York, silver for September delivery fell 22.3 cents, to $4.632 an ounce.

title: Whose Marital Rules?
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHWEST PILOTS STRIKE AS TALKS FAIL ON CONTRACT
description: More than 6,000 pilots at Northwest Airlines walked off the job last night, shutting down the country's fourth-largest airline in a strike that may cripple much of the Midwest.

title: Skinhead Split on Racism Is Seen in Killing of 2 Friends
description: Lin Newborn and Daniel Shersty were inseparable. It did not matter that Mr. Newborn was black and worked in a local body-piercing shop or that Mr. Shersty was white and was in the Air Force, servicing F-16's and other fighter planes at the nearby Nellis Air Force Base.

title: City Council Sues Giuliani Over Charter Commission
description: The feud between the city's top two officials worsened yesterday when Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone charged in a lawsuit that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had interfered with the city's legislative process by creating a charter commission solely to block a Council-sponsored referendum on the future of Yankee Stadium.

title: BankAmerica and 2 Other Big Banks Suffer Russia Losses
description: Adding to the list of American companies battered by economic turmoil in Russia, three more large banks reported trading losses there, but provided mixed signals about whether financial downturns elsewhere might lead to more widespread losses.

title: For Venus Williams, Singles, No Doubles
description: A year ago, barely 17, Venus Williams, the best young American tennis player, reached the women's singles final of the United States Open and won the mixed doubles with Justin Gimelstob.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFE, HARRY G.
description: WOLFE-Harry G. Loving husband and dear friend to Ann, died suddenly on August 25, 1998. He served in the U.S. Navy in World War II and was cited for heroism during the invasion of Sicily. He received his B.S. and M.A. degrees from Columbia University and taught at W.C. Bryant and L.I.C. high schools. He is survived by his wife Ann, sister-in-law Rita, five brothers William, Francis, Robert, John and Raymond, and twentyfive nieces and nephews. He was a gentle man and a gentleman, and will be deeply missed. Services will be held at Lloyd Home, 214-43 39th Ave., Bayside, today and Sunday 2-4PM and 7-9PM.

title: Russia Told to Implement Tough I.M.F. Reform Plan
description: The Finance Ministers of four economically powerful Western European countries warned Moscow today that the only way out of its current crisis was to make the tough economic changes long urged by the International Monetary Fund.

title: A Living History of American Judaism
description: Within the soaring sandstone building, with its ornately stenciled blue and gold walls and Moorish arches, the famous and the destitute worshiped for 126 years, marked the great moments of the Reform movement, and heard some of American Judaism's grandest orators eulogize both the meek and the mighty.

title: Fire Heavily Scars Landmark East Side Synagogue
description: The Central Synagogue on Manhattan's East Side, a 126-year-old twin-towered architectural treasure of Moorish inspiration that is a national and city landmark and the oldest temple in the state in continuous use by one Jewish congregation, was heavily damaged yesterday in a roaring five-alarm fire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNDON, REVEREND RAYMOND.
description: DUNDON-Reverend Raymond. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of St. Mary Magdalen Church, Springfield Gardens, on August 28, 1998. Reposing at Saint Vincent Ferrer Rectory, 1603 Brooklyn Avenue, Brooklyn, Sunday, August 30, from 2 to 7 P.M. Mass of Transferral will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Church on August 30, at 7:30 P.M. Funeral mass at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church, Monday, August 31 at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Renegade Challenger In Nevada G.O.P. Race
description: The bodyguard who sits at the entrance of the campaign headquarters of the gubernatorial candidate Aaron Russo has few if any words for visitors who walk in. He just sits there, way too big for his chair, incessantly spitting tobacco in a Styrofoam cup. But his menacing presence befits the renegade campaign of Mr. Russo, a rich Hollywood producer who swaggered into town just two years ago and has become an intimidating and unsettling force leading to next week's primary election.

title: Wall Street Itself Is Feeling Plenty of Pain
description: While banks worldwide have seen values tumble because of the Russian flu, Wall Street's brokerage firms and investment banks are suffering from their own version of a severe head cold.

title: A Saxophonist Willing To Rethink His Virtuosity
description: The saxophonist Joe McPhee began a three-day stand at the Knitting Factory's Old Office on Wednesday night with a solo performance, and it started with hardly any noise at all -- just some air coming from his soprano saxophone, thin and barely pitched. Then he began to manipulate that soft sound a little bit, hitting harmonics, and after a while notes edged their way to the surface, emerging in circular sprays. For the most part, it was a sustained five-minute act of circular breathing. What was noticeable above all wasn't the facility and speed of his playing but the quality of sound itself, which kept changing and was always a combination of things: serrated and bright-chrome, or smooth and reedy.

title: Toms River Ready for Fun in Final
description: Mike Gaynor, the manager of Toms River East, was standing outside Howard J. Lamade Stadium this afternoon with a look of morning-after exhaustion from the late-night delirium of winning the United States championship Thursday night. But the time for celebration was over, as his team was one day away from taking on Kashima, Japan, in the Little League World Series championship game.

title: Government Said to Gain Upper Hand in Congo's Capital
description: Two days after heavy shelling and gunfire erupted on the capital's fringes, Government forces continued to assert control over the area today, and fighting with rebels was confined to a few pockets.

title: Clinton Spoke Here (But No Need to Brag)
description: In the action-speaks-louder-than-words approach to politics . . .

title: Corrections
description: A film review and a listing of credits in Weekend yesterday for Bill Plympton's ''I Married a Strange Person!'' misstated its running time. The animated film is 74 minutes long, not 114 minutes.

title: Toyota to Raise Its Stake in Mini-Vehicle Maker
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it would raise its stake in the Daihatsu Motor Company to 51.2 percent from 34.5 percent, spending 37.1 billion yen, or $259 million, to cement control of the company, which is Japan's second-largest producer of mini-vehicles.

title: Wealthy Independent Stirs Up Race With Ads Assailing the Governor
description: B. Thomas Golisano is rousing a somnolent race for governor like a drumroll of thunder on a placid day. If not quite scaring anyone, he is at least getting people's attention and threatening a little rain on Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election parade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALT, ALFREDA SILL.
description: GALT-Alfreda Sill. On August 28 at age 87. Beloved wife of the late Dr. William Galt. Adored mother of George, Jack and Elizabeth. Grandmother of six. President of the Lifwynn Foundation, a psychological research organization in Southport, CT. For funeral service information, call Harding Funeral Home 203-227-3458.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ROBERT I.
description: GOLDMAN-Robert I. On August 27, 1998. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Congress Financial Corporation. Beloved husband of Melva B. Goldman. Father of William Douglas Lese, Peter Lawrence Lese and Olexa Farrell. Grandfather of Jason, Stephen and William. Brother of Suzanne Brown. Private services at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to Jewish Foundation for the Righteous, 305 Seventh Avenue, 19th Floor, New York, NY 10001, attention Ms. Stanlee Stahl, Executive Director; American Academy for the Dramatic Arts, 120 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10016, attention Ms. Betty Lawson; Beth Israel Medical Center Development Department, First Ave. at 16th St, New York, NY 10003, attention: Ms. Stafanie Steel; New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center Cardiac Care Unit, 525 East 68th St, NY, NY 10021.

title: Steady Graf Earns Trip To the Final
description: Steffi Graf continued her comeback in dramatic fashion tonight, recovering from a 5-0 deficit in the second-set tie breaker to beat top-seeded Lindsay Davenport, 6-3, 7-6 (8-6), and advance to the final of the Pilot Pen International tennis championships.

title: Fairer Elections in New York
description: Congress and the New York State Legislature may balk at revamping their cash-saturated systems for financing elections, but the New York City Council voted changes this week that should make elections in the city among the fairest in the nation. By a veto-proof vote of 42 to 5, the Council approved Speaker Peter Vallone's reform package that would lower contribution limits and increase matching funds for the voluntary campaign finance system in time for the 2001 elections.

title: It's a Dark and Stormy Night . . . and Here's Hong Kong Trying to Line the Clouds With Silver
description: Amid the battering of stock markets around the world this week, Hong Kong has seemed strangely stable -- an oasis of calm at the eye of the storm. But appearances are deceiving.

title: Let Russia Slow Down Its Reforms
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Spending Declines For First Time in Two Years
description: Consumer spending fell in July for the first time in more than two years as the strikes at the General Motors Corporation took a toll on auto sales. Analysts said falling stock prices could cause spending to weaken further.

title: Even as Latin Markets Plunge, Drastic Remedies Are Avoided
description: The recent panic in world markets has weakened Latin American currencies and drastically reduced the wealth of many Latin corporations, raising prospects that governments in the region may be forced to take Draconian measures to contain the crisis.

title: Carrefour to Buy Rest of Comptoirs
description: Carrefour S.A., France's biggest retailer, said today that it had agreed to buy Comptoirs Modernes for cash and stock that would amount to a maximum of 14 billion francs ($2.38 billion), plus assumed debt of about 1 billion francs.

title: Dow Off by 114 More Points, Ending Worst Week Since '89
description: Stock prices fell sharply again yesterday, as continued fears about instability in Russia and economic weakness closer to home produced the worst week for the American stock market in nine years.

title: On a Familiar Stage, Piazza Plays the Hero
description: Mike Piazza had to feel at home tonight. There were boos for the All-Star catcher every time he stepped up to bat. And then there were cheers to meet the jeers.

title: Teachers in Middletown Threaten to Strike
description: Less than a week before the school year starts on Thursday, union and school officials said yesterday that about 100 districts around the state had yet to settle contracts and that teachers in the Monmouth County community of Middletown were threatening to strike if last-minute intervention by the state failed.

title: Unhappy Birthday to You: Janzen Is Disqualified
description: An eventful day at the World Series of Golf featured both controversy and competition.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Tuesday and Thursday about the arrest of a man, Terrence Finney, in connection with the scalding of a 5-year-old girl in Brooklyn mischaracterized remarks made by Mr. Finney's lawyer, David Epstein, at Mr. Finney's arraignment on Monday. Mr. Epstein did not say his client had told him that the girl's injuries were accidental; he said the police had reported that Mr. Finney made that assertion in a statement to them.

title: Let Russia Fend for Itself
description: Exactly seven years after the abortive military putsch in Moscow that precipitated the collapse of Soviet Communism, Russia confronts yet another crisis. Back then, in August 1991, the consequences of the crisis appeared wholly benign, as it seemed to herald Russia's chance to move toward democracy and a market economy. Today, Russia's prospects are less clear and far more ominous.

title: Just How Thirsty Are You?
description: Late August in the city. Eighty-, ninety-degree temperatures and hazy, humid skies. Too little breeze. Too much ozone.

title: Top American Team Loses At World Championships
description: The top-seeded American team, headed by Nick Nickell of Manhattan, was ousted from the Vivendi Rosenblum World Championship here this afternoon. His team, which includes Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, lost by 48 imps to a Swedish group that calls itself Team Magic and lived up to its name.

title: TEXTRON AUTOMOTIVE UNIT ACQUIRES BRITISH PARTS MAKER
description: Textron Inc., a maker of auto parts and Cessna airplanes, bought Midland Industrial Plastics of Britain for an undisclosed amount to bolster its offering of automotive interior and exterior trim parts. Midland Industrial, with expected 1998 sales of $:44.4 million ($74.6 million), makes door and instrument panels, molded seat backs and other products for BMW, Toyota, Leyland and other car makers. It will be combined with Textron's automotive trim division in Troy, Mich. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., has acquired 12 European companies in the last 20 months.

title: Fritz Haber, 86, Dies; Simulated Weightlessness of Space
description: Fritz Haber, an aeronautical engineer who developed a way to simulate the gravity-free environment of space in the training of Apollo astronauts by flying a plane in a roller-coaster pattern, died on Aug. 21 at Norwalk Hospital in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Oxford Projects $300 Million Loss for Year
description: Oxford Health Plans, the troubled managed-care company whose stock has plunged more than 90 percent since last summer, estimated future losses and took questions at its annual shareholders meeting yesterday.

Reposing Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, Inc., 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, on Saturday & Sunday, 2-5 & 7-9PM. Mass Monday, St. Joseph's R.C. Church, 10:00 AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Glaucoma Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Harold Siegel, 80; Aided School Board
description: Harold Siegel, a former secretary and counsel to the New York City Board of Education, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Beware The Ides Of August
description: Which do you think is scarier? Is it that Scott Ritter, the top U.N. weapons inspector in Iraq, quit his job, accusing the U.S. and the U.N. of surrendering to Saddam Hussein? Or is it the story told by Russian economists about a Russian soldier behind the Urals who drove his army tank to City Hall to demand months of back pay? The soldier said he drove the tank not because he wanted to blow up the municipality but because he didn't have any other way to get there and couldn't afford cab fare. Or is it reading The Washington Post, where a State Department spokesman, James Foley, was quoted as saying that Secretary of State Madeleine Albright couldn't possibly be going soft on Iraq because, after all, ''Saddam Hussein has called Secretary Albright a snake and a witch, among other things''?

title: CADENCE DESIGN BUYING BELL LABS UNIT FROM LUCENT
description: Cadence Design Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Bell Labs Design Automation Group from Lucent Technologies Inc., putting Cadence's marketing muscle behind Bell Labs' advanced chip-design technology. Terms were not disclosed. Cadence, based in San Jose, Calif., said more than 100 Bell Labs researchers, developers and consultants would join Cadence and would continue to provide Lucent with chip-design services for three years. Cadence, which supplies the Intel Corporation and other chip makers with software and services to speed the design of computer chips, had revenue of $916 million last year.

title: Enter, The Audience; Trying to Gather Everyone In
description: It sits in plush seats or on hard benches. It watches. It claps. Sometimes it stands up and asks for more. Then it goes home. Critics have spilled a lot of ink writing about actors, playwrights, even directors. But what about the audience? Where has it been and where is it going?

title: PRATT & WHITNEY TO ELIMINATE 900 JOBS IN CANADA
description: The Pratt & Whitney unit of the United Technologies Corporation, among the world's top three aircraft-engine makers, said yesterday that it would cut 900 jobs in Canada as it trims research and development efforts. Pratt & Whitney Canada, based in Longueuil, Quebec, will cut mostly contractor and temporary jobs and will offer early retirement and voluntary severance packages, the company said. The Canadian Government's commitment to supporting research and development is ''insufficient to allow us to stay fully competitive in the global aerospace market,'' Pratt & Whitney Canada said.

title: Jets Roll Toward Opener With a Show on Offense
description: The Jets closed out the preseason tonight with an opening burst of offense so varied and potent that it simply stunned the Bears into a game-long funk.

title: Winning Black Votes In a Senate Race
description: In Missouri, as in most other states, Democrats depend on solid support from labor and blacks to give them a winning edge in elections. In the case of Attorney General Jay Nixon, the Democratic nominee in this fall's United States Senate contest, he has labor's backing but has been struggling to win over black voters.

description: ZUCKERMAN-Jeanette E. Formerly of Yonkers, N.Y. title: What Tropical Storm? Only Bliss in Toms River
description: With dark clouds and roaring winds hovering throughout the day, it would have seemed only natural for this town to spend the day like much of the East Coast, bracing for the wrath of Tropical Storm Bonnie.

title: GLUT FORCES CHIP-EQUIPMENT MAKER TO CUT STAFF BY 20%
description: Ultratech Stepper Inc., a maker of semiconductor-manufacturing equipment based in San Jose, Calif., said yesterday that it had cut 120 full-time positions, or about 20 percent of its work force, in a move to reduce costs. The company also said it would require all employees to take two days off a month for the rest of the year. Ultratech linked the cuts to a worldwide glut of computer memory chips and uncertainty over Asia's financial turmoil, which have injured its operations. Costs associated with the moves will lower earnings for the third quarter ending Sept. 30, Ultratech said. In the quarter a year ago, Ultratech earned $5.4 million, or 25 cents a share, on sales of $36.8 million.

title: British Cement Giant Expanding in Asia
description: Blue Circle Industries P.L.C., Britain's largest cement company, strengthened its position in Malaysia and Singapore yesterday, saying its Malaysian unit would acquire stakes in two cement companies in the region for $:252 million ($404 million) in cash and assumed debt. The unit, Malayan Cement Bhd., agreed to pay $:176.5 million to buy the 50 percent of Associated Pan Malaysian Cement it did not already own, giving it about 30 percent of the national cement market. It will also buy the Singapore-based Pan Malaysia Cement Works Singapore, assuming debt of $:75.7 million.

description: THE MARK GAINS. The dollar fell sharply against Germany's currency, weakened by plunges in stock markets in the United States. In New York, the dollar settled at 1.7575 marks, down from 1.7941 marks on Thursday.

description: Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday, extending a rally sustained by investors fleeing turmoil on world markets. Some profit taking, however, held back the gains.

title: BAY VIEW CAPITAL CANCELS $153 MILLION DEAL FOR PSB
description: The Bay View Capital Corporation of San Mateo, Calif., said yesterday that it had canceled its planned $153 million acquisition of the PSB Lending Corporation. As a result, it will take a charge of $850,000 in the third quarter to write off certain costs related to the deal, which was announced in June. The write-off, coupled with mortgage prepayments occurring faster than expected, will prevent Bay View from meeting analysts' 1998 earnings estimates, the company said. Bay View had been expected to earn $1.60 a share for the year and 42 cents for the third quarter. The savings and loan company decided not to go through with the cash and stock acquisition of PSB, a home-equity lender, after Federal regulators issued new guidelines limiting the amount of high loan-to-value home loans a savings and loan may hold.

title: DUPONT TO BUY SPANDEX BUSINESS IN SOUTH KOREA
description: The DuPont Company, the largest chemical company in the nation, agreed yesterday to buy the spandex-fiber business of South Korea's Tongkook Synthetic Fiber Company in a transaction Tonkook valued at $200 million. DuPont, based in Wilmington, Del., and the maker of Lycra spandex and Dacron polyester, derived about 11 percent of its $45.1 billion in 1997 sales from Asia. The acquisition of Tongkook, which is based in Seoul, fits with Dupont's strategy of seeking investments in Asia as declining currencies there make acquisitions cheaper.

description: Dorothy Manners Haskell, who became the Hollywood columnist for the Hearst Corporation after 30 years as the assistant to its syndicated columnist Louella Parsons, died on Tuesday at her home in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 95.

title: Russian Emigrants: Mixed Views on the Old Country
description: She only arrived in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, from Moscow two weeks ago, but Natalia Kuznetsova has followed the crisis at home by telephoning friends. She knows that the banks are closed, that the stores are closed, that the ruble is practically worthless. Her friends tell her they pass the days drinking vodka.

description: Tellabs Inc. and the Ciena Corporation agreed today to cut the ratio of Tellabs' planned stock-swap acquisition of Ciena by 20 percent, though investors said the price was still too high.

title: Taking Action on Patients' Rights
description: The Senate will not have much time to approve legislation on patients' rights when it returns next week from its August recess. Its chances of enacting something worthwhile will be slim if Republicans and Democrats insist on turning the stalemate into a campaign issue with which to hammer each other. The blame strategy, however, could backfire with voters who want protection from unfair health insurance practices.

title: State Investigates Ticket Scalping at U.S. Open Box Office
description: The State Attorney General's office is investigating allegations that employees in the box office for the United States Open tennis tournament illegally diverted prime seats to scalpers who in turn resold the tickets at vastly inflated prices, officials said yesterday.

description: The Philippines, becoming the latest Asian country to report an economic contraction, said today that its gross domestic product declined in the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.2 percent.

title: In Retreat, Hurricane Bonnie Sideswipes Long Island Coast
description: The tail end of Hurricane Bonnie sideswiped Long Island today as the storm slowly headed eastward out over the Atlantic Ocean, spinning off some heavy rain and gusts of wind but causing no major damage.

description: John Reizer says he always had the confidence to speak his mind and the ambition to set lofty goals. But it was not until he experienced the trek and triumph of winning a Little League World Series championship that he gained the courage to express those qualities.

title: Tape in Case of Youth and Pedophile Accidentally Erased
description: One of several tapes of telephone conversations from a sting operation against a man accused of molesting a 15-year-old Jackson Township boy was accidentally erased by a technician who was trying to make copies, the Monmouth County Prosecutor said today.

title: Search for Missing Widow Fails on Edge of Jersey City
description: The police searched an overgrown field on the outskirts of Jersey City for a second day yesterday, but abandoned the effort late in the day after failing to find Irene Silverman, the 82-year-old Manhattan widow who vanished eight weeks ago and is believed to have been killed in a swindlers' scheme to get her town house and fortune.

title: Sports of The Times; For Gibson, Her Legacy To Tennis
description: EARLY yesterday morning, three New Jersey mayors stood shoulder to shoulder in East Orange City Hall. One by one they invoked the image of Althea Gibson, the first African-American to win a major tennis title. In 1957 and '58, Gibson was the most dominating player in the world.

title: With Mozart, a Showcase for the Young
description: At this time of year, concerts dwindle down to a precious few, a fact that may help explain the sizable turnout for the concert of the New Amsterdam Symphony in beastly heat and humidity on Thursday evening at St. Peter's Church on West 20th Street in Manhattan. The relative inactivity also affords a reviewer the welcome opportunity to catch up with some of the hard-working musical institutions around New York, like this orchestra, that tend to fall by the wayside at the height of a crowded musical season.

Mr. Epstein did not say his client had told him that the girl's injuries were accidental; he said the police had reported that Mr. Finney made that assertion in a statement to them.

title: Skeletal Versions of Songs About Life's Bummers
description: Behind Juliana Hatfield's breathy, girlish voice are all kinds of trouble. Playing solo on an acoustic guitar on Thursday night at Acme Underground, Ms. Hatfield sang about suicidal tendencies and anorexia, addiction and paranoia, masochism and obsession and heartbreak. It's an understatement when she admits, ''I don't know how to be the perfect girl,'' in ''Bad Day'' from her new album, ''Bed'' (Zoe/Rounder), her fourth since she left the Blake Babies in 1992.
