title: MESA AIR TO ADD CCAIR FOR $45 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Mesa Air Group Inc. agreed to acquire CCAir Inc. for $45 million in stock, plus $15 million of assumed debt. Mesa Air said yesterday that it would issue shares equal to $5.40 for each share of CCAir. Mesa Air, based in Farmington, N.M., is a holding company for regional air carriers, including Mesa Airlines, United Express, U S Air Express and America West Express. It had revenue of $343.7 million in the nine months ended June 30. CCAir, based in Charlotte, N.C., provides service under the U S Airways Express name in the Southeast. It had sales of $32.7 million in the six months ended June 30.

title: Latin America's Immovable Rulers
description: Panamanians go to the polls tomorrow to decide whether their President, Ernesto Perez Balladares, can amend the Constitution to run for a second term. Mr. Perez Balladares's bid to stay in power is part of a trend among Latin American presidents, virtually all of whom are barred from running for two consecutive terms. If he is successful, he would be the fourth president to win a constitutional amendment for re-election in the past few years, and several others have contemplated trying. The trend is dangerous for fragile Latin democracies, contributing to the personalist rule that has plagued the continent.

title: PEN Leader in Mexico Tells of Threats
description: The Mexican novelist and poet Homero Aridjis, who is the president of International PEN, which defends freedom of expression, said today that he had received a series of chilling death threats.

description: The Giants' final preseason game, indeed the Giants' entire four-game exhibition season, revealed nothing new about a team whose strength was defense and whose weakness was offensive consistency.

title: Saving Private Berger

A legendary Times reporter, he found roguish tales among the mobsters of Murder Inc. and charming vignettes among the drunks on the Bowery. He invented our About New York column, and he could write it with the lilt of a St. Patrick's Day parade or the cadence of a caisson carrying war dead up Fifth Avenue. He was our master storyteller, the O. Henry of daily journalism. But in the spirit of his time, Mike Berger kept private lives private, most notably his own, no matter how illuminating the details.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: Nonfiction; Life and After Life
description: During his long and eventful career, John G. Morris operated at the heart of 20th-century photojournalism, working as a picture editor for Life, Magnum, The Washington Post, The New York Times and National Geographic. In the late 1940's, The Ladies' Home Journal, a less obvious member of that fraternity, gave him a base from which to hire photographers like Robert Capa, Martin Muncacsi and Lisette Model. In 1948 he ran a series, ''People Are People the World Over,'' photographed largely by Magnum photographers, which inspired Edward Steichen's renowned ''Family of Man'' exhibition. Morris begins his memoir, Get the Picture: A Personal History of Photojournalism (Random House, $30), not with his childhood but with his path to Life magazine. Before he ends his story in Paris, where he moved in 1983, he weaves several photographers, anecdotes, players, history and a credo or two into an engaging and informative tale. Not surprisingly, this veteran of photojournalism's glory days sees a decline in recent years, not in the committed, courageous and excellent photography still produced, but in editors and publishers who pander to focus groups and celebrity mania and do not provide outlets for photo reportage. Morris, an unapologetic humanist, believes in the persuasive power of images and discusses in some detail his efforts over the years to strengthen the role of photography in journalism. Despite his losses -- wives, friends, employment -- and the many frustrations of an often thankless and unheralded job, the 81-year-old Morris is an optimistic and amusing raconteur. Rosemary Ranck

title: Gershwin Is Still Cause for Rhapsody; An Inspired Borrower Of a Black Tradition

But his music and the good life that it provided for its composer were inextricably connected to the racial terrain of show business. The finer esthetic elements of his music came into existence as a result of an interracial training ground that transcended all the balderdash of the national skin game. But the troubling ethnic components of show business aren't usually discussed, particularly when a man of Gershwin's Jewish background is the subject, for fear, in that case, of being seen as anti-Semitic. My intent is to provide an overview of Gershwin more substantial than the skeleton of the great marlin that Hemingway's fishermen returned home with in ''The Old Man and the Sea.''

title: Should the Mississippi Files Have Been Reopened?

In the summer of 1964, Michael Schwerner, James Chaney and Andrew Goodman were shot and killed in rural Neshoba County, just outside Philadelphia, by members of the Ku Klux Klan. Although the F.B.I. compiled enough evidence to convict seven men on Federal charges of violating the civil rights of the victims, the State of Mississippi never brought anyone to trial on murder charges. title: Tribal Histories Encoded In Artifacts of Prehistory

title: The State Inherits a Trove of Old Maps and Deeds
description: When a researcher has questions about the history of land ownership in Eastern New Jersey, he automatically thinks of Frederick A. Gerken, the registrar for the oldest corporation in the United States, the East Jersey Board of Proprietors.

title: Shrink Your Thighs
description: Jungian analysis interprets the psyche through archetypes. Now, it's being applied to treat body types. Dr. DeAnsin Parker, a psychotherapist and the founder of the Goodson Parker Wellness Center, a gym and health club at 30 East 76th Street visited by fit celebrities like Elle Macpherson, Kyra Sedgwick and Yasmeen Ghauri, is taking the craze for mind-and-body mergence a step further than power yoga. Using Myers-Briggs test questions (''Are you usually a good mixer or quiet and reserved?''), Dr. Parker offers hourlong sessions, for $200, to classify clients into one of four personality types -- and matches them to a workout that she says is ''spiritually appropriate.'' For an introverted-integrated personality type, who likes to function on multiple levels, she suggests sports with complex circular movements, like golf. For a concrete personality type, who needs to see results and statistics, a treadmill is what the doctor orders. But some Jungian experts believe it takes more than an hour to classify a personality type. ''Jung wouldn't like it,'' said Paul Wink, a psychology professor at Wellesley College. ''He was always skeptical of Americans' need for a quick fix.''

title: Editorial Notebook; Wondering Where the West Begins
description: For the past few years I have driven west every summer, and every summer the question returns: Where does the West begin? There are plenty of common-sense answers, the kind that break this country up into regions as neatly defined as the pieces in a child's wooden puzzle. If it were just a matter of political boundaries, I would not look for the West before the Colorado border. And if it were just a matter of mood, the West would begin in upstate New York on the day I walk the horses into the horse trailer, check the running lights one more time and pull away into the fog of dawn.

title: Poor Face Grim Choices as Pakistan's Economy, and Government, Unravel
description: During such a tumultuous week, it might be expected that people here were preoccupied by the American missile attack in neighboring Afghanistan. After all, dozens of Pakistanis were among those killed in the barrage that fell on what the United States says were terrorist training camps.

title: Let's Not Panic -- Yet
description: Could the current craziness in world financial markets translate into a global slump, maybe even a new Great Depression? Of course it could. The story might go something like this: Over the next few weeks, investors, made jittery by the debacle in Russia, stage runs on the currencies of many third world countries. The governments of these countries respond by raising interest rates to 30, 50, 70 percent -- stabilizing their currencies but pushing their corporations into bankruptcy, provoking devastating bank runs and plunging their economies into deep recession.

title: Deer in Headlights

The reason may be the trial of 60 game-warning reflectors on a road that is ''very popular with deer,'' said Joe Suppiello, general supervisor for the county road department. The reflectors bounce the beams from a car's headlights to the roadside, freezing deer before the car itself passes.

title: SOAPBOX; Hung Up
description: SOME 20 years ago, I presided over the deregulation of the airlines. While the resulting competitive regime has been far from perfect, it has saved travelers more than $10 billion a year. Since passage of the Federal Telecommunications Reform Act early in 1996, it has been our national policy similarly to open the telephone business to competition. But in contrast with the airlines, that can't happen all at once: for one thing, challengers have to have access on reasonable terms to the local networks -- lines, switches and so on -- of the incumbent telephone companies with which they would be competing.

title: A 50's Question Reconsidered
description: WITH jowls, deep lines around her mouth and about 30 extra pounds, Halle Berry doesn't look like the Halle Berry we've come to know. Still, on this sound stage in February, she moves regally, like a star, which is exactly what she's playing: Zola Taylor, the flashy singer for the Platters, at the age of 48. What's most important about this scene, set in a Federal court in New York in 1986, however, is the fact that Zola Taylor is the widow of Frankie Lymon, the pop singer who wrote the 1950's doo-wop hit ''Why Do Fools Fall in Love?'' And she has come to court to claim a share of his royalties.

description: IN a market that until recently was obsessed with corporate earnings -- and that now seems obsessed with nearly everything -- few sectors have performed as peculiarly as airline stocks.

title: In a Painting, Gershwin Packed the House
description: WHEN George Gershwin traveled to Mexico for four weeks at the end of 1935, he went hoping for musical inspiration. He was exhausted by the mixed response and controversy surrounding the premiere of his landmark opera ''Porgy and Bess'': the hybrid nature of the score had satisfied neither the classical nor popular taste of the critics, who had been harsh about many aspects of the opera's form and content. He was ready for something new, and it was precisely this sort of trip that had borne fruit in the past. Not only had he spent time in South Carolina to soak up the Gullah rhythms and dialect when he was writing ''Porgy and Bess,'' but in 1928 he had been stimulated by Parisian taxi horns to write ''An American in Paris,'' and in 1932 a sojourn in Havana had inspired the ''Cuban Overture.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULHALL, WILLIAM F.

Reposing at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, Garden City, on Sunday & Monday 2-5 and 7-9. Her first album, ''Way Back to Paradise,'' to be released Sept. 22 by Nonesuch Records, functions as a primer not merely to the three-time Tony Award winner's vocal gifts, but to the work of several of the most promising young composers in musical theater today: Jason Robert Brown, Ricky Ian Gordon, Adam Guettel and Michael John LaChiusa, plus a talented newcomer, Jenny Giering. Their songs, sequenced as a suite, are the sum of Ms. McDonald's debut: 14 in all.

title: Strip Club Partners, Now Ruined, Blame Greed and the Mob
description: As the 90's began, Michael D. Blutrich and Lyle K. Pfeffer, two men from sedate, middle-class backgrounds, were riding high. title: 5 Principals From District Are Lured Away
description: For Melvin Katz, the temptation was just too great. After 33 years in the city's school system, seven of them as principal of Middle School 141 in Riverdale, he was entitled to a pension of more than $60,000 a year. He also had an offer to head a school in New Jersey that would pay him $85,000 a year with a possible bonus of $5,000. After much soul searching, Mr. Katz retired from his $76,000-a-year New York City job and took the principal's post in New Jersey, along with his pension.

title: Charting the Globe On a Cocktail Napkin
description: THE right drink does more than slake a thirst. It takes you somewhere, even though ''somewhere'' might be the very place you happen to be sitting. A whiff of calvados in the fall sends a fragrant message straight from the orchards of Normandy. Consumed on the spot, at a cafe in Rouen, it fills in a tiny blank space on the imagination's map. With a poet's concision, it explains the place. For centuries, Normandy has been apples and apples have been Normandy. What could bring the point home more memorably than a few ounces of the local spirit? A snifter is worth a thousand words.

Fragrant heliotrope and vivid dahlias add weight to airy bouquets of cosmos, gaillardia and helenium, but like all hollow-stemmed plants they will leak milky sap and wilt unless cut ends are seared with a flame. His happiness was an inspiration to all and he will be sincerely missed. Services to be held Monday 12:00 PM, Gutterman Funeral Home, Woodbury, NY.

title: A Season to Leave Well Enough Alone
description: THIS is the ''steady as she goes'' season, a good time to make some observations and outline a few reminders.

title: Vivid Evidence That Fashion on L.I. Thrives on Constant Flux
description: FICKLE as the weather, fashion thrives on flux. Hemlines rise and fall, silhouettes alter. Like other clothing-conscious locales, Long Island readily embraces change -- that single defining constant in the continuously morphing world of fashion.

title: Whose Voice Is That, Touting What's on TV?
description: AT times during his long career in radio as a disk jockey, Bill Rock remembers thinking that what he really wanted to do is work in television.

description: THE era of Arthur Ashe Stadium picks up where it left off. The men can still hit harder but the women are more interesting.

description: To the Editor:

title: With the Camera's Eye, Documenting a Fight Against Hunger
description: FROM its beginnings in the back of a station wagon more than 20 years ago, the Community Foodbank of New Jersey has grown into a program that helps supply food and groceries to more than 300,000 people each month. For the past two years. Barbara T. Beirne, a photographer from Morris Township, has documented the group's work and some of her images are the subject of an exhibit that opened yesterday at the Morris Museum.

title: The World: Tribal Rights; Throughout the Americas, Natives Invoke the Law of Land
description: EARLIER this month, after initialing the first treaty that his people had ever concluded with Canada's Government, Chief Joseph Gosnell Sr. held the document over the seal whiskers of his regal headdress and shouted, ''The Nisga'a canoe has returned.''

title: Spellbound
description: Remember the old subway ads for stenography school? ''If u cn rd ths u cn gt a gd jb.'' Let's play a variant on the task, and trnslt the following baby names into their conventional spellings. All were culled from recent state records, birth announcements and Web sites for parents: Jesyca, Traiscey, Aireol, Exevior, Imajine, Any, Kaytlinne.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Subjects range wide on television's movie menu this week, from a hard-boiled crime thriller and a mother-daughter melodrama to a tale of terror and a near-mystical Manhattan yarn.

title: Her Hands Were a Bridge to the World
description: HELEN KELLER

title: Cook's 62 Puts Him Among Leaders
description: For John Cook, today was a magnificent stroll down memory lane, a special day in the state where he was born, the state where he starred as a collegiate golfer at Ohio State, and the tournament where his father, Jim, is still the director.

title: For passionate eaters, an abundance of choices
description: In Buenos Aires, good food is relished, eating out a part of life. Humble or grand, Criollo or immigrant, the porteno has a restaurant he is ready to swear by. The best empanada? ''At El Sanjuanino, of course.''

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: Fiction
description: The Most Wanted

title: Singin' in the Subway
description: Much of ON THE TOWN, the Gene Kelley-Stanley Donen musical about sailors on leave, was shot in New York, using the city itself as a backdrop, a screen novelty in 1949. Surprisingly, the movie dropped most of the songs Leonard Bernstein had written for the original Broadway production, but the sprightly new numbers worked well against the lively canvas of city landmarks. Kelly and Donen, both dancers in Broadway's ''Pal Joey,'' superbly piloted the frolic and its nifty cast: Jules Munshin, Frank Sinatra and Kelly (above), with Vera-Ellen, Ann Miller, Betty Garrett, and Alice Pearce. It's an ebullient show whose spirit forecasts the Kelly-Donen masterpiece ''Singin' in the Rain'' - Friday 10 A.M. on Turner Classic Movies. Howard Thompson

title: For Symphonies, a New Season
description: EACH year, in the quiet period after most festivals have called it a summer, we like to look ahead to performances in the autumn (remembering that subscribers not only get the best seats but also lower prices and other perks.) What follows is by no means a complete listing, just an appetite-whetting sampler of good listening to come.

title: BAD TIMING ASIDE, CLINTON RESOLUTE ON YELTSIN SUMMIT
description: President Clinton plans to depart for Moscow on Monday hoping to repair his scandal-stained image while offering comfort -- but no aid -- for the wounded President of Russia, Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: A True Case Of 'Not in My Backyard'
description: About 100 people gathered on Harway Avenue between Bay 44th Street and 27th Avenue Monday and turned away a contractor hired to clear gardens and swimming pools from land they considered part of their backyards. Now the protesters are busy with their own construction project: cobbling together explanations of why they have rights to property they do not own.

title: Into the Void at Columbus Circle
description: WITH the selection of a design for the old Coliseum site on New York's Columbus Circle and plans afoot to spiff up the circle's core, this may be the time to appreciate the power of this place to stir the imagination over the years.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES PRESEASON TOP 20
description: THIS IS THE DAWN of the computer age in college football. No longer will the ranking be the sole domain of know-nothing sports-writers and broadcasters or coaches too absorbed in their own teams' fates to keep up with clashes across the country. In fact, the New York Times Computer Ranking will be included in the bowl championship series calculations. But it doesn't come on line until after the fourth week of the season. For now, Joe Drape is responsible for these selections. Please, no cards and letters. In a few weeks, you'll be able to blame the know-nothing machines.

description: CARR-Susan Price 2/16/46-8/30/91 (20 elul 5751) Beloved daughter, mother, wife. Mother D.K.C.

title: 'Cymbeline' By Way Of Trinidad
description: MOST people remember Hazelle Goodman for her role in Woody Allen's ''Deconstructing Harry,'' in which she played a call girl who, throughout the film, wore a pair of pink leather hot pants slit up the side and held together suspensefully with pink string.

title: Pamela Lippe and Scott Morris
description: Pamela Towen Lippe and Guy Winston Morris were married last evening at the Old Tavern in Grafton, Vt. The Rev. Julie Lineberger, a minister of the Universal Life Church, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Miss Quigley, Mr. Eberhardt
description: Kathleen Elizabeth Quigley, a daughter of Kathleen and Hubert Quigley of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joachim W. Eberhardt, a son of Ilse Eberhardt of Stuttgart, Germany, and the late Siegfried Eberhardt. The Rev. George Stewart performed the ceremony at St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church in Pearl River, N.Y.

title: Gershwin Is Still Cause for Rhapsody; A Serious Composer With Broadway Style
description: ON the piano-saturated ''Racket Row'' -- West 28th Street, also known as Tin Pan Alley -- the young George Gershwin plugged songs and wrote down ''Revolutionary Rag'' in 1919 for the musically illiterate Irving Berlin. Six years later for its premiere, Berlin joshingly telegrammed Gershwin, ''I hope your Concerto in F is half as good as mine in F sharp'' (the only key Berlin could play on the piano). In an interview just before Berlin died, he said: ''The songs Gershwin wrote in his last year are among the finest any of us wrote. We were all pretty good songwriters, but Gershwin was something else. He was a composer.''

title: Tourism Puts Some Back on Job; Less-Skilled Workers Are Especially Helped by Boom
description: For most New Yorkers, the tourists swarming Manhattan are a source of mixed emotions: amusement, exasperation, even pride. But for an increasing group of city residents, tourists are the source of something much more concrete: jobs.

title: Fighting the Good Fight Against Gloppy Peas
description: WHEN he first arrived to study in the United States, Ashim K. Datta was unfamiliar with the microwave oven.

title: A Theater's Ms. Fix-It
description: AFTER getting over her high school wish to be a car mechanic -- ''my protest against intellectualism'' -- Bonnie J. Monte, as a reluctant college freshman, figured she would be a film director. But her parents would not allow her to go as far as Los Angeles for four years.

title: Thinking Globally, Acting Locally
description: Who would have thought that strife between Hindus and Buddhists and a diplomatic dispute between far-off Asian nations could affect an East Side real estate deal? Apparently no one in city government, until a curious City Council aide looked up the proposed buyer, the Kingdom of Bhutan, and raised concerns about its human rights record.

title: Inspired by a Different Set of Saints
description: THE exhibition of sculpture by Bisa Washington at the Morris Museum contains 23 separate works. But with the help of a little explanation from Ms. Washington, they conspire to make up an epic that is both cosmic and local.

title: County Seeks Plans For New Golf Course
description: WESTCHESTER is proceeding with plans to develop what it hopes will be a premier public golf course on 174 acres in New Castle, formerly the Hudson Hills Golf Course, which it bought earlier this year from International Business Machines.

title: In a 3-Way Photo, Longest Nose Is Quest's
description: In a furious three-horse finish, Coronado's Quest raced to the head of the class of 3-year-old colts today when he won the 129th Travers Stakes by a nose over Victory Gallop, who in turn had a nose on Raffie's Majesty.

title: Sounds of Gershwin: A Record Guide
description: Seemingly everyone has recorded something by George Gershwin. To recommend even a handful of recordings as essential is only asking for trouble, but here goes.

title: Denial, Not Optimism, Props Up Some Funds
description: THE collapse of emerging markets has yielded plenty of detritus, but none more curious than a clutch of closed-end stock funds that, to the great misfortune of their investors, still hold stocks in those cratered economies.

title: On Personal Territory With June Havoc
description: IN a solo performance of a play in progress, June Havoc means to put a new spin on an old fable. Call it the spin of truth, spiced by the facts, and with pretty pictures, too. She calls it ''Baby June Remembers: A Love Story'' and is scheduled to go on stage with it on Saturday and Sunday at 8 P.M. at Lucille Lortel's White Barn Theater in Westport.

title: Miss von Bargen and Mr. Kehrli
description: Alexandra von Bargen, a daughter of Patricia Ann von Bargen of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, and the late Herbert von Bargen, was married yesterday to Christopher Bruce Kehrli, a son of Sterling Hilleary Kehrli of Newport Coast, Calif., and the late Bruce A. Kehrli. The Very Rev. Alan J. R. Neale performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Columba's Chapel in Middletown, R.I.

title: In Hoboken, Out Goes the Microbrewery, Back Comes the Music
description: Hoboken had begun to take Maxwell's for granted before it closed earlier this year. The nightclub had been a host to some of the greatest underground music of the last 20 years, including some groups who broke through to mainstream success, like Nirvana and the Smashing Pumpkins.

title: Alfonzo Swings, and Mets Soar
description: Edgardo Alfonzo found himself at shortstop for the first time this season for the final three outs of this afternoon's game. The Mets' regular third baseman said it felt strange, but considering the alternative, the Mets did not mind one bit.

title: Mother Against Toplessness
description: One critic has called Lina Accurso (left, in picture) ''that short belligerent woman.'' For 1,800 nights, the 46-year-old housewife has forgone the sofa to picket a strip joint, the Diamond Club, hoping to shame this ''stain on the community'' out of tiny Port Chester, N.Y. The town is only 12 miles from New York City, which recently padlocked 11 of 144 sex shops. Accurso is still hoping to shut down her first.

title: Coming in September: 3 New Features
description: Beginning next month, Money & Business will publish a group of new features that invite readers' participation.

title: Farnsworth Museum Adds Wyeth Galleries
description: Celebrating its 50th year, the Farnsworth Art Museum in Rockland, Me., has just opened its Center for the Wyeth Family in Maine.

title: The Finger Lakes
description: Tribes of the Iroquois Nation believe that the Finger Lakes were formed when the Creator's hands raked across the landscape. Geologists say that eons ago, glaciers lumbered past a slab of wet cement we now call central New York State and couldn't resist. In any case, nature provided 11 fingers, perhaps because it would take more than two hands to count all the region's charms.

title: Tenants vs. Landlord on Park Ave.
description: In 1994, shortly after the 13-story building at 823 Park Avenue, near 75th Street, was sold to a developer, Robert Manocherian, tenants of its rent-regulated apartments received notices that he had applied to the state for permission to demolish and rebuild the building's interior. Since then, he has refused to renew the leases on their apartments, whose rents range from $500 to $1,500 a month, far below the market rate for one of the city's most desirable neighborhoods. When Mr. Manocherian took over the building, about 10 of its 37 apartments were vacant, and the number of vacancies has increased to 17, tenants say.

title: An Impeachment Report? It's a Guessing Game
description: In the two weeks since President Clinton acknowledged having had an inappropriate relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, the capital's attention has been riveted by the prospect of an impeachment report that official Washington assumes the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, will send to the House of Representatives.

title: Ann Peck, David Reisen
description: Ann Peck and Dr. David Reisen are to be married today in Washington Depot, Conn. Rabbi James Rosenberg, a cousin of the bridegroom, is to perform the ceremony at the home of Jane and James Harpel, the bridegroom's sister and brother-in-law.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT; Don't Forget the Vision Thing In Deregulating Utilities
description: THE retail cost of electricity in the United States varies from 4 cents a kilowatt-hour in Kentucky to nearly 12 cents in parts of New York and New England. When the costs are added up, electricity is a $250 billion industry, with about 25 percent of the total supplied by public, government-owned utilities.

title: Oh, Those Beltway Innocents
description: It seems as if everyone outside of Washington is saying that they want the controversy over Bill Clinton's sexual infidelities to end. And it seems that everyone inside Washington is doing everything to insure that the controversy never will.

title: The Gowanus Canal: An Appreciation
description: THE thick, green water of the Gowanus Canal was baking in the hot August sun. Hollow windows of empty buildings and twisted fences brooded down on the water. Almost nothing stirred in the heat, except a plump black rat scurrying across broken stones that lay on the shore. The only other sign of life was David Lefkowitz's 21-foot powerboat, which putted downstream slowly, its propellers churning up a stink.

title: Tourism Puts Some Back on Job: Outdoor Food Vendor; A Chance to Try Out High School French
description: When Charlene Watson went back to work after 18 months of making do on unemployment and then welfare, she did not expect the job benefits would include learning how to count in German and practicing her rusty high school French.

title: Phones Overtake Crime In Rio Tourist Poll
description: After years of a combined effort by state and municipal police to fight street violence in Rio de Janeiro, results are beginning to show. Crime is down and tourism is up -- now telephones are the biggest problem.

title: With Transfers, Relocation Business Thrives
description: WHEN Ann Wheatley learned that her husband's promotion would mean leaving London for New York, she immediately started looking for houses in the New York area by way of the Internet.

title: Dear Mr. President: What to Do in Moscow
description: Henry A. Kissinger says that if President Clinton backed out of the summit meeting in Moscow, it would mean certain political death for Boris Yeltsin.

title: Even in hard times, a great eating city
description: At the height of Japan's boom in the 1980's, Tokyo was reputed to have more than 100,000 restaurants -- most of them tiny places tucked away in obscure corners. Who knows if the figure was right -- but it felt right. Some have closed with the onset of hard times, but Tokyo remains one of the world's great eating cities, and one of the few with food modeled in plastic for non-Japanese speakers to point to.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEER, FLORENCE FAY
description: BEER-Florence Fay. Beloved wife of Walter E. Beer, Jr. for 68 years. Loving mother to John and David. Devoted grandmother to Thomas, Amy, Jeffrey, Elizabeth, Andrew and to her great-grandchildren Tea, Nuala and India. Florence worked for many years for the Public Education Association and Vocational Advisory Service of New York and various organizations in Brooklyn Heights where they lived for 35 years. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Keene Valley Neighborhood House, Keene Valley, N.Y. 12943. A memorial service is planned.

description: CARLEN-Alexander, of Ridgefield, CT. on August 22, 1998. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Coyne Carlen; father of Judith and Matthew Carlen; brother of Miriam Asher and Birdie Lubert; grandfather of Sierra, Jamison and Olivia Carlen. Memorial service to be announced.

title: August 23-29; Mother Teresa Workers Killed by Serbs
description: Three Albanians working for the Mother Teresa aid organization were killed by cannon fire in Serbia in what appeared to be a Government effort to terrorize aid workers.

title: A Former Yalie Chases The Rock-and-Roll Dream
description: ''I ALWAYS saw myself as the kid who stepped up out of the front row and onto the stage and had the guitar for a while and carried that particular flame,'' Bruce Springsteen once told me. ''I wasn't interested in immediate success or how much each particular record was selling. I was interested in becoming part of peoples' lives and part of fans' lives and hopefully growing up with them.''

title: The Prostitute Who Read Sir Walter Scott
description: THE MURDER OF HELEN JEWETTThe Life and Death of a Prostitutein Nineteenth-Century New York.By Patricia Cline Cohen.Illustrated. 432 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.

title: The Carver Chronicles
description: I'm grateful to anyone who had anything to do with the proliferation of Carver stories. I, for one, can't get enough. With this in mind, I invite Tess Gallagher to pen some new short stories -- with Gordon Lish as her editor. That way, we can come to understand just how much these two influenced some of the best short stories of this century.

title: Delicacies of the Italian and Swiss Lake Country
description: THE large and beautiful lakes of north-central Italy represented an ideal of sunny Italy for generations of European travelers crossing the Alps southward. Nowadays they provide a precious refuge in nature for inhabitants of Milan and other northern cities. In May, my companion, Franco, and I took a long weekend exploring culinary offerings around three important lakes -- Maggiore, Como and Lugano. The brief trip took us to two Italian regions, Piedmont and Lombardy, and Ticino, the Italian-speaking canton of Switzerland, though not to their gastronomic capitals. Our favorites were a trattoria, a wine bar and three top-level restaurants.

title: Retreating for Spiritual Renewal
description: NOT far from the noise, stress and hyperactivity of the glass-walled infrastructure of Islandia's business district lies a small, well-kept secret.

title: Tourism Puts Some Back on Job: Hotel Housekeeper; Pampering Guests At $15.57 an Hour
description: For eight years, Violeta McZeno worked as a receptionist at a dental office in downtown Manhattan. She liked her job and made what she thought then was a good salary, $8 an hour. Then, two things happened: Ms. McZeno separated from her husband and she lost her job when the dentists moved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGEE, VINCENT F.
description: McGEE-Vincent F. 78, died peacefully on August 27, 1998 at home in New York City. Loving husband for 52 years of the late Helen; devoted father of Vincent, Gerald and Eleanor, Patricia and Richard Yates, and Kevin; proud grandfather of Brian and Ann, Maura and Emily; brother of Joseph and the late Walter McGee. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC Sunday 7-9 and Monday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate contributions to Corpus Christi Church, Vincent McGee Memorial Fund, 529 W. 121 St., NYC 10027 where a funeral mass will celebrate his life on Tuesday, September 1 at 10 AM. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Easy-to-Learn Skills Make Old Metal Shine Again
description: MOST do-it-yourselfers are willing to tackle furniture restoration projects because refinishing products are readily available and the skills are easy to learn. They are are less likely to work on metal objects, like vases, plates or lamps, because they assume that only experienced artisans can restore metalware.

description: MALAYSIA AND INDONESIA +

description: North Wildwood has agreed to stop clearing a municipal landfill that is supposed to become the site of New Jersey's seventh minor-league baseball stadium while the city determines what to do with 10 pairs of yellow-crowned night herons and their chicks nesting there.

description: Jill Cecile Feldman and Robert Alan Lerner were married last evening by Rabbi Joel S. Goor at the Rainbow Room in Manhattan.

title: NORTHWEST STRIKE GROUNDS ITS FLEET AND ITS CUSTOMERS
description: More than 6,000 pilots shut down Northwest Airlines today with a strike that stems from a history of mistrust between management and labor in the airline industry and two contradictory fears of the future.

title: Candace Hoffman, Matthew Wagner
description: Candace Michelle Hoffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theron S. Hoffman of Fairfield, Conn., was married there last evening to Matthew Clifton Wagner, a son of Edith N. Wagner of Sayville, N.Y., and the late Arnold Wagner. The Rev. David Rowe performed the ceremony at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

title: Hun Sen Stages an Election
description: Life has changed for the big men of small countries. Gone are the days when a thuggish third-world leader could find a superpower to support him, if only because the other didn't. Thirteen years ago, when Hun Sen first became Prime Minister of Cambodia, it was as the puppet of Vietnam and the Soviet Union, and they were not particularly bothered by political killings or a lack of elections. (The United States was equally indifferent to the corruption and abuses of Lon Nol, the Cambodian dictator it supported in the early 1970's.)

title: Ms. Hegarty And Mr. Kenny
description: Jacqueline Hegarty and George Christopher Kenny were married yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. James Boniface Ramsey performed the ceremony.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/ Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.; Natural Beauty in a Former Whaling Port
description: IT is nearly impossible to resist using the word ''quaint'' in describing Cold Spring Harbor, the historic whaling port on Long Island's North Shore.

title: Rabbi Promises to Rebuild Synagogue Damaged by Fire
description: When Rabbi Peter Rubinstein stood before his Central Synagogue congregation yesterday morning, many of the eyes he saw were moist. Usually, Saturday services in the summer are small, but about 100 people had arrived, some of them crying or hugging one another, everyone looking for strength a day after a five-alarm fire roared through their 126-year-old sanctuary.

title: District of charcuteries and fruit stands
description: ''Where do you shop for food?'' was the first question I asked when apartment-hunting in Paris. And one of the reasons I selected my current home, in the northern stretches of the ninth arrondissement, is because the movable feast that is Paris is so magnificently on display. There is the daily market on the Rue Cadet and every day except Monday on the Rue des Martyrs, a steep street that climbs up to Montmartre.

title: Suzanne Yelen, Mark Popofsky
description: Suzanne Yelen and Mark Samuel Popofsky, lawyers in Washington, are to be married there today at the Willard Inter-Continental Hotel. Rabbi M. Bruce Lustig will perform the ceremony.

title: Twin Pillars of Fire and Ice
description: The United States Open has always promoted itself as the biggest, brashest, richest, loudest Grand Slam of them all. One might also call it the most colorful, innovative, contradictory and maddening of the four majors. Since 1968, when the international tennis circuit voted to allow professionals and amateurs alike to compete openly for money (!), the U.S. Open has been the first and only Grand Slam tournament to change court surface three times -- from grass (1968-74) to clay (1975-77) to hardcourts (1978-present); the first of the Big Four to bust out of private-club traditions and into a public park -- from the cozy West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills to the U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows; the first and only Grand Slam event to use the tie breaker in all sets (debuting in 1970 with the heart-wrenching 9-point sudden death breaker); the first Slam to leave stodgy white-only garb in its pastel dust; the first (since joined by the Australian) Slam to play at night (1975); the first to break prize-money marks (from a total purse of $100,000 in 1968 to $1 million in '82 to $14 million in '98).

title: 50-Year-Old English Race Course Reopens
description: One of the most famous sports-car racing courses in the world, Goodwood Motor Circuit near Chichester, England, will officially reopen Sept. 18 to 20, looking much as it did when it made its debut 50 years earlier -- right down to the cars and many of the drivers of the era.

title: Whale Tissue Raises Worry on Toxic Chemicals
description: Dutch scientists say they have discovered toxic industrial chemicals in the tissue of whales that normally feed in deep waters of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Tourism Puts Some Back on Job: Art Consultant; Guiding Appreciators Of Contemporary Art
description: Three weeks ago, Todd Weissner's financial landscape was as barren as Wall Street on a Sunday. He had spent the last nine months as a gofer for various executives around the city, making calls, typing and filing letters and fetching coffee. He had gone for months without health or dental benefits. Out of desperation, he applied for a job as an art consultant at Martin Lawrence Galleries in SoHo. He landed it, and now sells art for one of the largest dealers of pop art in the country.

title: Three Early Adopters, of Sorts
description: WHILE Federal auto choice legislation remains a long shot this year, three states have adopted insurance systems that already give drivers some discretion to limit their right to sue for pain and suffering in exchange for lower premiums.

title: A Degree, and With It an Affordable Space
description: THE graduates, wearing crisp summer suits or floral dresses, sat patiently during the ceremony at the White Plains public Library here, waiting to receive certificates of achievement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NACHMAN, CHARLOTTE K.
description: NACHMAN-Charlotte K. on August 28, 1998, peacefully at home at age 101. Beloved wife of the late Arnold N., who died in 1943. Survived by her daughter Marjorie and son-in-law Howard Rosenthal; son Richard and daughter-in-law Sarah Gifft; grandchildren Ann, Ruth, Jesse, Elizabeth, David and Eric; six great grandchildren; and by her devoted care-givers Maud Morgan and Ruby White. Charlotte arrived in America from Hungary at age five with her mother and two brothers. Orphaned four years later, she grew up in the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, where she remained until she was 18. She graduated from Hunter College in 1918 and later was a remarkable elementary school teacher in the NYC public schools for almost 40 years. Not content to just ''retire,'' she learned Braille so that she might translate books for the blind. Then, for some 30 years, as a volunteer at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged on West 106th St., she created and directed a library for the residents. Charlotte will be missed and lovingly remembered by many. A memorial service will be held later.

title: Susan Margolis, Kenneth Miller
description: Dr. Susan Gail Margolis and Dr. Kenneth Scott Miller, both ophthalmologists, were married last evening at Troutbeck, an inn in Amenia, N.Y. Cantor Robert Abelson officiated.

title: Karen Dressner And Brian Boom
description: Karen Ruth Dressner and Dr. Brian Morey Boom were married on Monday in Tamarindo, Costa Rica. Einar Jose Villavicencio Lopez, a justice of the peace, officiated at the home of the bride's sister, Dr. Susan Curtis, and brother-in-law, Steve Curtis.

title: Drinking Water, And What Else?; From Wells In South Jersey Flow Radium, and Anxiety
description: LIKE most people in southern New Jersey, Catherine Rabbai learned about the water from news reports. The delicious drinking water from the well in the backyard of her two-story Pittsgrove home might have radium in it.

title: Legislators' School
description: If County Legislator Richard G. Wishnie has his way, his fellow lawmakers will be joining him and thousands of other Westchester residents in a September ritual -- going back to class.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPHARD, BOBBY
description: SHEPHARD-Bobby. August 9, 1998. Dear friend, we will always miss your charm and wit, the fun and songs you brought to us. Tommy, Linda, Corinne, Jan, Alan, Mel, Marta, Nancy, Chris, Fred, Andrea, and Bill and Diane

title: Vote Today In Panama Could Affect Canal's Fate
description: Officially, only the destiny of President Ernesto Perez Balladares will be decided when people vote Sunday on a proposal that would amend the Constitution here and allow him to seek a second consecutive term. But the future of the Panama Canal may also be at stake, and so the campaign here has turned extraordinarily ferocious.

title: Wendy Elias, Edward Sassower

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: Nonfiction; Daddy Was a Pontoon Bridge
description: Current American fiction has not been lacking in its awareness of television's grim effect on families, but nowhere has this theme been exploited quite so well as in Curtis White's new novel, MEMORIES OF MY FATHER WATCHING TV (Dalkey Archive, paper, $12.50). Chapters are constructed around classic programs of the 1950's and 60's like ''Bonanza'' and ''Highway Patrol,'' and the son's narration is constantly interrupted by words spoken by characters on the screen, plausible-sounding stage directions from the programs' scripts and other such static interference. The father, a TV addict, has been reduced to a stream of hallucinations that do not quite add up to a mind; but the son and his two sisters are, if anything, even worse off. If the father imagines he's become a pontoon bridge that the characters in ''Combat'' must destroy before the Nazis use it, the son at one point complains that he can't find his left hand. (The father's response: ''Call the F.B.I.'') The sisters are desperate: one seems to be delivering an endless monologue to no one in particular, while the other keeps walking back and forth between the TV set and her father in an unsuccessful bid for his attention. The son makes frequent reference to his own ''intellectual performance'' (he uses words like ''proaeresis''), but his erudition is, so to speak, all in his head. In the ''Sea Hunt'' chapter, supposedly spending the summer of 1963 at the Nassau Trauma Center with his mother -- who is under the impression that her unhappy husband has been underwater for several months in scuba gear -- he tells a nurse that '' 'trauma' is German for dream.'' It's not, of course; it's Greek for ''wound.'' Yet the confusion itself is instructive. White's wonderfully manic novel is built on the premise that the television industry manufactures dreams that wound and dehumanize even as they claim to entertain. William Ferguson

title: Inn's Warm Welcome, Continental Menu
description: WHAT a difference a year and a half makes! When we last visited the Roger Sherman Inn in New Canaan, new owners had taken over but had not yet taken charge. Slapdash service, slapdash meals were the rule. Three recent visits have convinced us that a steady hand is finally steering the inn's course. Beginning with a warm welcome from the maitre d'hotel and waiter, attention seems to have been given to every detail. The miniature Toblerone bars presented with the bill after dinner are a quiet reminder of the Swiss heritage of the owner, Thomas Weilenmann.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUART, DOUGLAS KLEINPETER
description: STUART - Douglas Kleinpeter. Died Friday, August 28, 1998, in NYC, at the age of 48. A Louisiana native and longtime resident of New Orleans, ''Klein'' lived in NYC since 1988. He studied in Italy and was a graduate of Loyola University of New Orleans and Parsons School of Design in NYC. Klein was a nationally recognized interior designer who had residential and commerical clients along the eastern seaboard. Klein is survived by his parents Walter Bynum Stuart III and Rita Kleinpeter Stuart of Lafayette, LA, and four brothers Walter Bynum IV, of Houston, TX, Robert Kenneth of Riyadh, Saudia Arabia, Ronald Sidney of Pensicola, FL, and Scott Matthew of Greenwich, CT. Other survivors include 11 niececs and nephews. Services will be held in Baton Rouge, LA, on Tuesday, September 1. Visitation will begin at 12:30 PM, followed by a funeral mass at 2:30 PM, at St. Joseph's Cathredral, 412 North St., Baton Rouge. A memorial service will be held in NYC at a later date. Rememberances may be made to The Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center, 455 First Ave., NYC 10016.

title: Me and My Woody-Headed Friend
description: Outsiders tend to find ventriloquists . . . different, like taxidermists or docents at wax museums. In fact, ''vents'' have the same urges as anybody: in the summer, they want to attend a snazzy professional meeting in a fun locale. Recently, 400 vents gathered in Las Vegas for an annual convention. Any oddness on display? ''It did get a little weird,'' admits Kelley Thomas, the event's publicist. ''People played the slot machines with dummies on their knees, and security, not realizing they were dolls, told the vents that kids weren't allowed in the casino.'' Mostly, though, the meeting was a reunion of a big, surprisingly diverse family. Here's a look.

title: At two markets, the best of the region's bounty
description: In Seattle's rapid coming of age as a great food city, locally grown, Asian-influenced produce has played a key, though largely unheralded, role. Exotic vegetables, feathery salad greens and lush rainbows of berries flourish on the urban fringe on small organic farms, many of them owned by Southeast Asian immigrants. From May through October, the best of the region's bounty turns up at two lively neighborhood markets: the University District Farmers Market on Saturday and the Fremont Farmers Market on Sunday, both a short hop north of downtown.

title: The View From/Chappaqua; Man's Castle That Is a Place for Drills in Basketball and Life

Walls are freshly painted and the floor sanded, but sparkling appointments remain intact, and the big stone fireplace is ready for a chill to hit the air. It is a pity that the entrance adjoining a bar that can be noisy and smoky is unchanged. And Tomaso's kitchen is still not particularly consistent in timing or preparation. But when a dish is cooked carefully, even the occasional fliers taken on the classics are welcome.

title: The Upstart Etchers of Britain Carry On
description: ENGLAND'S Society of Painter-Printmakers has been in existence since 1880. It began rather informally as a gesture of protest -- etching was not considered a creative art. The prestigious Royal Academy allowed engravers to be members, but not etchers. The etcher's group prospered, however, and in 1888 Queen Victoria added Royal to the society's name.

title: Architectural Philosophy
description: Alberta Ferretti is a designer known for her subtly layered look: tulle over cotton, a sliver of hand-beaded gauze peeking out from beneath the hem of a wool dress. So when Ms. Ferretti, who is based in Milan, asked the Manhattan architect David Ling to design her first store in New York, Philosophy di Alberta Ferretti, which opens in SoHo on Tuesday, he came up with the architectural equivalent of her clothes. The pristinely white 1,000-square-foot shop is a light-filled study of layers, from the sheer cotton scrim that veils the staircase to the running water glimpsed beneath a translucent glass floor. ''The wood is analogous to the wools and cashmere, the glass to the transparent fabric, the mirror to the crystal beading,'' Ms. Ferretti said.

title: A world tour, without leaving Manhattan

title: You Haven't Heard the Last of This
description: I AM fond of completely off-the-mark literary pronouncements, the weightier and more misguided the better. There's something comforting in those occasional lapses when a luminary lurches and trips over the humble stone his powerful torch somehow failed to reveal. Think of T. S. Eliot doubting the viability of the sonnet, a few years before Auden, Frost, Ransom, Cummings, Graves, Bishop, et al. coaxed the form to a florescence it hadn't seen since the Elizabethans. Or Ezra Pound equating clarity of expression with political clarity, championing lucid definitions as a bulwark against corruption and anarchy, and then pitching himself headlong into an ideological morass of Fascism, anti-Semitism and treason.

title: Should the Mississippi Files Have Been Re-opened? No, because
description: Ten years ago, when I moved to Greenwood, Miss., to work as a reporter at the local daily newspaper, one of the first things my new boss told me was that, had I come down two decades earlier, my mere arrival -- being a New Yorker fresh out of the Ivy League -- would have aroused the fervent interest of the State Sovereignty Commission. It was the first time I had heard of that organization, and I would hear about it again and again over the course of the next year, although never in mixed company (mixed according to race, that is), and never in tones much above a mumble. The Sovereignty Commission, a segregationist agency devoted to spying on suspected civil rights activists and sympathizers, had already been defunct for more than a decade, but it was clear that, like the Klan and the Citizens' Council -- both of which still existed as vestigial organs of a racist power structure that was officially obsolete -- it was capable of arousing at least an abstract kind of fear in certain types of Mississippians: the well-educated; progressives; activists, and African-Americans of any ilk.
