description: LUXENBERG-Morris. Beloved husband of Annette, loving father of Lynn and Mike Werner, Marc and Robin Luxenberg. Devoted grandfather to Stacey and Jodi Werner, Scott and Jennifer Luxenberg. Past-President of Congregation B'nai Abraham of Brooklyn, NY, member of Young Israel of Miami Beach and B'nai Brith.

title: Reforming Rape Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Chivington Journal; Effort Grows to Unearth Killing Field of Old West
description: One historian calls it the American My Lai. Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell of Colorado, the lone American Indian in Congress, calls it ''one of the most disgraceful moments of American history.''

title: Is There a Distinctive Long Island Cuisine?
description: THE defining moment, when a cuisine began to emerge from everyday Long Island food, may have occurred eight summers ago. That was when the Westhampton chef Starr Boggs served slabs of fresh tuna grilled rare accompanied with corn on the cob, sliced tomatoes, new potatoes and string beans to the hundreds of people attending the first Long Island Barrel Tasting and Barbecue at Hargrave Vineyard in Cutchogue.

title: Vivian George, Tyler Smith
description: Vivian Balfour George, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. George of New York, was married yesterday to Tyler James Smith, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David E. Smith of Albany. The Rev. George W. Busler performed the Episcopal ceremony at the bride's parents' house in Westhampton Beach, N.Y.

title: N.J. LAW; Debating How Much Assistant Prosecutors Are Worth
description: Spotlighting a statewide conflict between county prosecutor's offices and local governments, three assistant prosecutors in Morris County resigned this summer, all citing low pay as the reason.

title: The Carver Chronicles
description: As good an editor as Gordon Lish is and was (and the marked-up page that illustrates Max's article shows how good), it was the new intersection of literature and star-making machinery that Lish understood and took advantage of that was his real contribution to Carver. But following the traditional role of the P.R. man in our own popular literature, Lish is always stuck with being the guy behind the scenes who cleans up the mess, the Sammy Glick who never basks in as much limelight as those he has so successfully served.

title: THE VIEW FROM/Westport; Teen-Age Refuge At Toquet Hall
description: BRIANNA LEHNING, 14 years old, wanted to get involved with a teen-age activity program, but was told that she was too old. The same with Teen Night, which the Y.M.C.A. sponsors.''We're too young for bars,'' she said. ''We're like at a really bad age. You're like right in the middle -- too old for this, too young for that.''

title: Yankees Must Shine in the Fall
description: George Steinbrenner is not alone in believing that the Yankees have to validate their regular-season record by winning in the post-season, too. Lou Piniella, who drew a paycheck or two from Steinbrenner, offered a similar assessment yesterday, though not necessarily in the same threatening vein that might underscore the owner's comments.

title: Streetscapes/The Bergdorf Goodman Building on Fifth Avenue; From Architectural Links to Common Ownership
description: THE 70-year-old white marble, just cleaned last month, is soft and worn like an ancient monument, and anyone who stops in front of the Bergdorf Goodman Building on Fifth Avenue from 57th to 58th Streets will notice it. But a building is like a small ecosystem, and restoring a single element alters the balance, not always with positive results.

title: C. Dickerman Williams, 97, Free-Speech Lawyer, Is Dead
description: C. Dickerman Williams, a corporate lawyer who also represented freedom-of-speech clients of diverse perspectives, including The Daily Worker in the 1920's and The National Review in the 1960's, died on Aug. 12 at his Whitney Center retirement home in Hamden, Conn. He was 97.

title: Guidebooks on the Uncertain Path to a Well-Run 401(k)
description: WHEN the 200 workers at Hawaiian Host wanted a 401(k) plan, a host of vendors eagerly offered their services. But Stacey Nakasone, a human resources administrator at the Honolulu company, which makes chocolate-covered macadamia nuts, said she was overwhelmed trying to compare prices.

title: Vietnam Photo Leads to Unexpected Reunion
description: Martin Pineiro, a slim 50-year-old with a cane, hobbled into the Salvation Army's Borden Avenue Veterans' Residence in Hunters Point on Aug. 8. His Brooklyn apartment had just been destroyed by fire, and he was seeking shelter. In the foyer, he noticed a banner with the words ''Welcome Veterans Leave Homelessness.''

title: A Home Away From Home
description: THE SCENE: Lunchtime at Billy's, widely considered to be the oldest family-owned restaurant in the city. Once a neighborhood saloon for men who worked the East River's tanneries, breweries and slaughterhouses, this 128-year-old landmark on First Avenue and 53d Street now serves an even mix of Sutton Place matrons, 57th Street art dealers and midtown lawyers. The tablecloths are red-and-white-checked, the napkins are heavily starched and the paneling is dark mahogany.

title: One Amway Product Your Aunt Won't Sell
description: AFTER decades of peddling soap, detergent and toothpaste to Middle America, the Amway Corporation, the direct-marketing juggernaut, wants to clean up in another line of business: mutual funds.

title: A Harborside Complex Along the Potomac
description: THE first major marina to be built in the metropolitan Washington region in more than 15 years is to open next spring across a tidal bay from a national wildlife refuge that was designated to preserve the American bald eagle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EILERS, DORIS (NEE MILLARD)
description: EILERS-Doris (nee Millard). Suddenly in Boston, Massachusetts. August 26, 1998. Wife of F. Farny Eilers Jr. of Woodbridge, Connecticut and Nantucket, Mass. Mother of David Farny Eilers. At her request, their will be no services. Memorial gifts may be sent to: The Massachusetts Society for The Prevention of Cruelty To Animals, Nantucket, Mass. 02554.

title: The Wedding Dress That Ate Hollywood
description: IT'S the only formal party some people are ever invited to. It's the only couture dress many women will ever own. It's the only catered event many people ever attend. There's no mystery to why people love weddings and are thrilled to sit through them again and again. And in today's popular culture, geared to pander and give the people what they want and only what they want, audiences are getting plenty of opportunity to sit through weddings. Again and again.

title: August 23-29; Carcinogen Found in Fetuses of Pregnant Smokers
description: Researchers reported the first direct evidence that a cancer-causing substance from tobacco is transmitted to fetuses by pregnant smokers. Stephen S. Hecht of the University of Minnesota Cancer Center said his findings established that the nicotine-derived chemical NNK is not only received by the fetus but processed by the body.

title: Turning Nature Upside Down
description: SUMMER AT LITTLE LAVA

title: After One Career, It's Time To Start a Second or Third
description: ''THERE are no second acts in American lives,'' F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote in his notes for ''The Last Tycoon,'' a fictionalized portrait of a tragic movie mogul.

title: School Board Suit
description: Three school board members in Yonkers are asking the State Commissioner of Education, Richard Mills, to void the city's contract with the new Superintendent of Schools, Dr. Andre J. Hornsby, and to remove Thomas M. Weibrecht from the school board on the basis of a conflict of interest.

title: August 23-29; Libyans May Be Tried In Lockerbie Crash
description: After 10 years of grief for the families of the dead of Pan Am 103, blown up over Lockerbie, Scotland, there was some promise of justice.

title: Pro Comes to Rescue Of Hometown Hoops Center
description: Chris Gatling, the New Jersey Nets forward, laid the groundwork for his basketball career playing with other kids at the Police Athletic League center in his hometown of Irvington. ''It's my foundation,'' he said last year (On the Map, April 27, 1997). So when Mr. Gatling saw the center crumbling after it had closed for lack of funds four years ago, he bought it, then leased it to the city for $1 a year under a plan to restore the yellow brick building and its programs.

title: Cape May No Longer To Be Only County Without a College
description: Cape May County has been the only county in the state without its own college. But the process to change the situation began last week when Atlantic County officials agreed to share their community college formally with Cape May.

title: Reading the Rage-ometer And Offering a Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL BRIEFS
description: PUCCINI, CATALANI, PONCHIELLI:

title: Tricking Plants Into Blooming Early
description: IN gardening as in life, timing is everything. The fall asters are setting buds and the Joe-Pye weed is in full and glorious bloom, so naturally I'm thinking about next spring's sweet williams and cornflowers.

title: Style; Megamorphs
description: Merce Cunningham balked when his company manager first proposed that his dancers wear Rei Kawakubo's hump dresses as costumes. What did weird knobs and protuberances have to do with movement and line? How were people supposed to get around in those things? Then one afternoon Cunningham looked out the window of his West Village studio and spotted a woman carrying a baby in a Snugli and a young man on a cell phone. Suddenly he got it. ''The shapes,'' he said, ''were already there.''

title: Vineyard With Nod To Europe
description: At Sagpond Vineyards, the South Fork's most stylish winery, a European life style hovers in the air. Continental, especially Germanic, touches at the estate, at 139 Sagg Road in Sagaponack, may be apparent to visitors who meet the owner, Christian Wolffer (born in Hamburg in 1938), and his winemaker, Roman Roth (Rottweil, in the Black Forest in Baden-Wurttemberg, in 1966).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHAN, ALAN CLARK
description: NATHAN-Alan Clark. On August 28, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Marjorie and devoted father of the late Richard. Cherished grandfather of Mitchell and Bridget. Dear brother of Robert and loving partner of Bette Paris. He will forever remain in our hearts. Funeral services at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave. (9th and 10th Sts.) NYC, Sunday, 10:30 AM. Interment Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Clinton Plans To Keep Out Of Air Strike At Northwest
description: President Clinton refused early this morning to intervene in the Northwest Airlines pilots' strike, urging both sides to iron out their differences on their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMANN, TED
description: KAUFMANN-Ted. Master dowser and NY advertising executive. August 25. Survived by loving wife Carolyn at their beloved ''bewilderness'' North River, NY.

title: The Carver Chronicles
description: I read with a mix of interest and distaste your article on the collaborative relationship between Raymond Carver and Gordon Lish. Carver was a rare writer with a new and fresh voice whose stories resonate with emotion and strength. Whether or not Lish edited them might be worth a footnote in the archives of the works' creation, but nothing more. Nearly everything in life is collaborative.

title: August 23-29; U.S. Trial for Bomb Suspects
description: Two suspects in the bombings of United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania were brought to the United States to be tried on charges stemming from the Aug. 7 blasts, in which more than 250 people died and more than 5,000 were injured. Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali and Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, are to be tried in Federal court in New York City, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has ordered increased security. DAVID JOHNSTON

title: As Canadian Dollar Declines, U.S. Visits Rise
description: A DOLLAR is a dollar, except perhaps these days in Canada, where one American dollar is now worth about one and a half Canadian dollars, giving Americans a big boost as soon as they cross the border.

title: No Bed of Roses
description: I grew up on the Upper West Side two blocks from where John Tierney lives and moved to Chicago two years ago (The Big City: ''No Bed of Roses,'' Aug. 9). I now have a life style that I could never have afforded on my schoolteacher's salary in New York, where I couldn't afford an apartment with enough sunlight to sustain plant life, let alone my own. Gardens like the one on 89th Street offered people like me a brief distraction from the congestion Tierney seems so fond of. I miss the Upper West Side but probably wouldn't move back there even if my Powerball numbers came up.

title: Sharing Paradise With Ungrateful Swans
description: THE swans first glided into our view last year, four of them, a family come to welcome us to their island. We were on the deck overlooking the creek, new house-owners totally happy just watching water and feeling air, when Father Swan, big and watchful, led two tiny brown babies and Mom up to our bulkhead. They paused in the eel grass to eat, just another family on a night out to Friendly's. We named the parents Sylvia and Sidney and then, a mistake, named the cygnets Marcel and Albertine. Just as naming farm animals makes it harder to eat them, naming wild animals gives their death too much meaning.

title: For Drivers, a Way to Slay the Many-Headed Hydrant
description: To some residents of President Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, a yellow stripe means courage, at least of a mild sort. Without the city's knowledge, such a line recently appeared on the curb near a fire hydrant. And while no one seems to know who the rogue painter is, many say the action, which marks the zone within which parking is prohibited, is a boon to drivers.

title: Storm? What Storm?
description: WHILE Hurricane Bonnie raged off the coast of Florida last week, fishermen at the end of New Hampshire Avenue squinted at the cloudless sky, waved at tourists on sightseeing boats and debated the merits of fishing in a storm.

title: Kerstin Stanley, Scott Pasternack
description: Kerstin Stanley, a daughter of Linda Ekstrom Stanley of Belvedere, Calif., and Dr. John Stanley of Mill Valley, Calif., is to be married today to Scott Pasternack, a son of Mara and Gerald Pasternack of Arden, N.C. Cantor Ida Rae Cahana is to officiate on the grounds of the Point Judith Lighthouse in Narragansett, R.I.

title: Q&A/Dr. Constance Ward Iervolino; Task of Applying Standards to Classrooms
description: THE pressure is on for schools to have higher standards for all students -- pressure from the State Board of Regents, the business community and parents, among others. It will be the task of people like Dr. Constance Ward Iervolino, the new assistant superintendent of curriculum and instruction for the White Plains public schools, to make sure that all the tough talk about higher standards is not just talk, not just the latest educational fad.

title: Joining in the Party
description: George Gershwin loved parties. In fact, he tended to monopolize them, gloriously, at the piano. Certainly he would have viewed his 100th birthday, on Sept. 26, as one endless opportunity to play Gershwin. Much commemorative celebrating has already taken place. Here are some dates to keep in mind for those who want to join the party.

title: Truck Accidents, Another View
description: In the article ''Dissecting the Data on Truck Accidents'' (Aug. 9), the remarks of Mike Riley, president of the Motor Transport Association of Connecticut, were disingenuous at best.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF; On TV, a Backdrop Is Worth a Thousand Words
description: LIKE many other chief executives, I was media-trained. I did lots of speeches and press, radio and television interviews. I knew the media -- or so I thought until one day a few years ago.

title: Offers of Help Pour In for Damaged Synagogue
description: Two days after a roaring fire devastated the historic Central Synagogue on Manhattan's East Side, the senior rabbi of a congregation suffering something akin to mourning looked beyond the charred timbers and ruins of a magnificent landmark yesterday and saw some reasons for hope.

title: Market Selloff Could Forecast Trouble Ahead
description: The sharp selloff in stocks has led a growing number of people on Wall Street to wonder whether the stock market, often a leading economic indicator, may be forecasting a recession in the United States.

title: Lives of the Saint: Diana's Image Continues to Evolve One Year Later
description: On MTV, Diana, Princess of Wales, is seen as a pawn in a chess game who makes some clever moves and attains the status of a queen. On NBC's documentary ''Diana,'' Richard Attenborough all but canonizes her. On the History Channel, she is called ''unbalanced'' and ''manipulative.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ROBERT I.
description: GOLDMAN-Robert I. We mourn the loss of our dear personal friend and business associate, Robert I. Goldman, Chairman and CEO of Congress Financial Corp., Inc. Bob and his late associate Robert Miller, O.B.M., have played a significant role in the growth of our company. Bob's untimely tragic death shall leave an unfillable void. His legacy of a high level of integrity, honesty, and humanity shall remain with us forever, but we shall surely miss him. Our condolences to his family and all those that he touched. All his friends at the Renco Group, Inc. Ira Leon Rennert Chairman and CEO The Renco Group, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMS MERNS, STEPHEN
description: SYMS MERNS-Stephen. On August 29, 1998, at age 45. Beloved husband of Karen. Devoted father of Jillian, Daniel and Olivia. Loving son of Sy Syms and Ruth Merns. Adored brother of Marcy Syms Merns, Laura, Adrienne, Robert and Richard. Stephen was Vice President of Syms Corp and member and Secretary of the Board of Directors of Syms Corp, a chain of 43 apparel stores in 16 states. Steve gained most of his business savvy from his father, Founder and Chairman of the Board, Sy Syms. Early in his development at the Company, he began as a buyer and soon assumed a major role in the senior management of the Company. Stephen attended Pace University. One of his successes prior to joining Syms Corp included the development of his own export business. He was keenly interested in sports and contributed to United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, Inc., and Floating Hospital and Lighthouse Charities. Services Tuesday, September 1, at 1 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapels, 181 West 76th Street, Manhattan. Contributions can be made in Stephen's memory to the National Committee to Prevent Child Abuse, c/o Syms Advertising, 1 Syms Way, Secaucus, NJ 07094.

title: It's a Stealth Clinching for the Yankees
description: The emotional release of clinching a playoff berth causes men to act like Little Leaguers, form giant human piles and spray each other with carbonated substances. Scott Brosius was somewhat more subdued yesterday morning when he learned from a reporter that in beating Seattle Saturday the Yankees had clinched a spot in the American League playoffs, the earliest clinching date in the 20th century.

title: Grinding Gears Join Other City Serenades
description: By now the disadvantage of the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture courtyard as a site for the nine-week Summergarden concert series is well known: the traffic noise from 54th Street is terribly distracting.

title: Media Talk; From Mostly Wrong To Just About Right
description: Evidently, being right can excuse at least a few sins.

title: Shylock as an Ugly Caricature With a Hopeful Message
description: The first sound heard in the outdoor production of ''The Merchant of Venice,'' presented by Shakespeare & Company here this month was an Islamic call to prayer; the last was the Jewish Yom Kippur chant, Kol Nidre. In between were plenty of other invocations of ethnic and religious identity. A scimitar-wielding Moroccan and a buffoonish Spaniard strutted the stage. Mentions were made of the foppish French, the arrogant English and the drunken Germans. And, of course, there was the Jewish usurer Shylock, out for his pound of flesh, seeming to care more about his ducats than his daughter.

title: Remembering Diana, but Moving On
description: LONDON  The flowers are back, glazed under cellophane, laid at the railings of Kensington Palace and bearing the familiar moving or mawkish messages.

title: Rebel Terror Forcing Minority Serbs Out of Kosovo
description: The six front windows of Rade Smigic's hillside home in the village of Leucina open out on a bucolic panorama that starts with pear trees in the yard and then broadens to a valley with the family's fields and the homes of the ethnic Albanians with whom they had shared a simple rural life for as long as anyone can remember.

title: Equity Offerings Are Set
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSABI, MAYER
description: ROSSABI-Mayer. In honor of Mayer Rossabi and with loving memory by his family and friends, services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel today at 12:30.

title: In a battle over the prices of commercials during N.F.L. games, the sponsors played defense well.
description: EVEN if the National Football League season that begins in six days offers fans one close, hard-fought clash after another, it will be difficult to match the intense, high-stakes preseason skirmishing between the networks showing the games and the advertisers sponsoring them.

title: Honed Rafter Is All Ready
description: Patrick Rafter celebrated his Hamlet Cup victory today long enough to hoist the glass trophy and pose with his poster-size $45,000 check.

title: An Alternative to Impeachment
description: As members of Congress consider what to do about the scandal involving President Clinton and Monica Lewinsky, they might be interested in the circumstances surrounding my 1974 resolution to censure President Richard Nixon.

title: Toms River Hails Its Squad Of Little League Champs
description: Last December, Ken Kondek's wife, Chris, was planning a September trip to Las Vegas to celebrate a friend's 50th wedding anniversary. Mr. Kondek, an assistant coach of the Toms River East Little League team, refused.

title: Take That! McGwire Has a 500-Foot Reply
description: In what seems a game of home run cat-and-mouse, Mark McGwire is playing Tom to Sammy Sosa's Jerry.

title: Losing Ground, Even In His Own Party
description: A month after winning the Democratic nomination in the Michigan Governor's race, Geoffrey Fieger trails the Republican incumbent, John Engler, by almost 2 to 1 in the polls and seems to be steadily losing ground.

title: Guadalupe River Journal; When Rolling Down the River Gets Too Rowdy
description: William Mayo has seen just about everything from his wooden deck overlooking the oak- and cypress-shaded Guadalupe River.

title: U.S. Officials Wary on Moscow, Fearing Backsliding on Economic Changes
description: Administration officials warily monitored the maneuvering to form a new Government in Moscow today, disturbed by possible signs of backsliding on Russia's commitment to tough economic changes but reluctant to render a verdict until new personnel and policies were in place.

title: Northwest Says Its Final Offer Really Is Final
description: Setting the stage for what could be a long stand off, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would not alter the dollar value of the final offer it made to its pilots before they walked off the job on Saturday and grounded the carrier's 1,700 daily flights.

title: A Subdued Anniversary at a Place Dedicated to Diana
description: Glenice and Gordon Phillips were not able to get entrance tickets but drove 30 miles all the same today to this verdant, walled estate just to place a small bouquet of white flowers outside the wrought iron gates at the family seat of Diana, Princess of Wales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, SR. REGINA MONICA
description: CUNNINGHAM-Sr. Regina Monica. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent Mary the Queen, died Saturday, August 29, 1998. Survived by a niece Margaret Shanny (associate). Also survived by several other nieces and nephews and grandnieces and grandnephews. The wake will be Monday from 1-8 PM, at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St, Yonkers, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be Tuesday, 9:30 AM, at the Convent. Interment at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave, Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Hill Gives Team First Victory
description: Damon Hill gave the Jordan-Mugen Honda team its first Formula One victory in its 126th race, leading his teammate Ralf Schumacher across the finish line to capture a wet and wild Grand Prix of Belgium in Spa-Francorchamps.

title: Skip Away Triumphs Over Weight, but Only by a Nose
description: Weight has long been the great equalizer in horse racing, and today at Monmouth Park, it almost humbled Skip Away.

title: Behind Hate Speech, an Enigma; Youth March Leader's Past Is Rife With Contradictions
description: Few people outside the Nation of Islam knew much about Khalid Abdul Muhammad in November 1993, when, as the top aide to Louis Farrakhan, he railed so viciously against whites, Jews, Catholics, homosexuals and black civil rights leaders in a lecture at a small New Jersey college that Congress denounced him and Mr. Farrakhan eventually dismissed him from his post.

title: Bombs Won't Work Against Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Wouter F. Germans, Developer Of SoHo Gallery Building, 60
description: Wouter F. Germans, a partner in Hague Art Deliveries, which developed 420 West Broadway, one of the primary gallery buildings during the heyday of the SoHo art scene, died on Aug. 24 at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 60 and lived in Manhattan.

title: As Drugs in Sports Proliferate, So Do Ethical Questions
description: Mark McGwire, the brawny St. Louis Cardinals first baseman, has become a folk hero to many people for his skill at hitting home runs, baseball's most dramatic -- and clear-cut -- feat. The ball flies out of the park, or it doesn't. But McGwire's recent admission that he has used a testosterone-boosting compound for the past year has led him and his fans into a place where uncertainties abound.

title: In America; Health-Care Road Trip
description: Two new mobile health vans and a couple of support vehicles will leave from the West Side of Manhattan today on an eight-day, nine-state caravan that sponsors hope will call attention to the plight of millions of American youngsters who are not getting adequate health care.

title: SoHo as Fashion Victim
description: To the Editor:

title: From Science, a Horn of Plenty?; Risk of Impurities
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAITMAN, GERALD
description: WAITMAN-Gerald. The doctors and staff of East Side Physicians extend our deepest sympathy to our colleague Dr. Albert Waitman and family on the untimely death of his beloved brother, Gerald. Dr. Richard Geltman Medical Director

title: Reno Makes a Mockery of Finance Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Marketers Name Agencies for Accounts
description: Three marketers have announced their choices of agencies to handle their accounts.

title: Political Notebook; Brooklyn Candidate Prizes Endorsement by Dinkins
description: Barry D. Ford, the 35-year-old lawyer who is running for Congress in next month's Democratic primary, received some assistance last week in his quest to unseat Representative Edolphus Towns, the 16-year incumbent from Brooklyn.

title: Ex-Officer Shoots a Man Suspected in a Break-In
description: A retired police officer shot and wounded a man who the police said had broken into the Brooklyn home of the officer's mother yesterday afternoon.

title: Social Security's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Polls Give Incumbent A Reason to Worry
description: Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois breezed to victory in 1992 when she became the first black woman to win a seat in the United States Senate. But six years later, dogged by questions about campaign financing and why she paid visits to an African dictator, she finds herself struggling as she seeks a second term.

title: Campaign Reform's Next Hurdle
description: The Senate returns to Washington this week, more consumed than ever by the anguished debate over President Clinton. But lawmakers are living in a dream world if they consider themselves immune to Americans' general displeasure over ethics in public life. A recent New York Times poll showed that while most Americans have a low regard for Mr. Clinton's ''moral values,'' fully 65 percent thought his integrity was the same or better than that of most politicians.

title: Signs Show 'Wintel' Axis Is Beginning To Wobble
description: Everywhere around Silicon Valley these days, there seem to be signs that the so-called Microsoft Windows and Intel chip alliance -- the so-called ''Wintel'' duopoly -- may be unraveling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLIN, MARCELLA G.
description: BERLIN-Marcella G. (nee Gefsky). Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Loving mother of Carol Hartman, Jill Levings, and Melissa Berlin. Cherished grandmother of Marti, Jamie, Nyalls, Jodi, and Jonathan. Devoted great-grandmother of Kelly, Zabrina, Elijah, KC, and Nicole. Adored aunt to many nieces and nephews. Graveside services Tuesday, September 1, 11 AM, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Media Talk; Ex-Columnist Won't Join Book Tour This Fall
description: When it comes time to promote ''Africans in America'' this fall, one co-author will be missing in literary action from Harcourt Brace's planned eight-city tour to promote the weighty book about slavery.

title: Old Tractors Never Die; They Go to the Threshing Bee
description: There is something sublime about the sound of a World War II-era John Deere tractor, a graceful two-step in a field of thuds and idling rattles. Of course, there are some farmers who disagree.

title: Just One U.S. Team Remains In the Races for World Titles
description: After a day of intense drama today, one American team remained with a chance to win gold medals at the world championships here. The team headed by Bart Bramley, and including Sidney Lazard, Howard Weinstein, Steve Garner, Bill Pollack and Drew Casen, who barely qualified from the preliminary stage, reached the semifinal of the Vivendi Rosenblum Open Teams, beating a Danish team by 67 imps.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Toy Guns vs. Real Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; Software Engineer Tests Law on Encryption Code
description: Charles Booher was hardly surprised last month when two agents from the Department of Commerce knocked on his door in Silicon Valley and handed him a Federal subpoena. In fact, he had been expecting it ever since he first made his data-encryption program available on the Internet in the summer of 1997.

title: U.S. Studies Whether Big Tobacco Tried to Trade Ads for Votes
description: The Department of Justice is reviewing whether tobacco companies promised some Senate Republicans that they would pay for television advertisements if the senators voted to defeat the tobacco bill.

title: What Free Autograph?
description: Fans go to great lengths for autographs, but one man went overboard in the bottom of the fifth inning of the Yankees' game with Seattle yesterday. Wearing a No. 24 Ken Griffey Jr. jersey, the fan sprinted from the stands along the left-field line, directly at the Mariners' center fielder, with security people converging on him from all sides. Griffey stood in place, stunned, unsure of what to expect. ''You never know,'' he said later.

title: Consultant Sued for Expected Computer Malfunction in 2000
description: J. Baker Inc., a large apparel retailer, is demanding that Andersen Consulting reimburse it for the cost of a computer system installed nearly 10 years ago because the system is expected to malfunction in the year 2000, officials at the consulting firm said Friday.

title: Giants' Running Game Moves at a Walk
description: Only once in the last 30 years has someone other than a running back led the Giants in total yardage gained, and that was tight end Mark Bavaro during the statistically quirky 1987 season.

title: INSIDE
description: Albright in Sarajevo

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, WILLIAM H.
description: ROSENBERG-William H. The A.A.S.R. of Freemasonry Valley of New York City sorrowfully announces the passing of our illustrious Brother on August 28. His love of humanity illuminated the Lodge and all with whom he came in contact. The myriad members he sponsored over the years are a memorial to his memory and love of man. Services were held Sunday, August 30. Francis Dumaurier, M.S.A. and Commander-in-Chief

title: Sports of The Times; McGwire's Meltdown Was Unprofessional

title: Want the Newest of the New? Then Try Writing It Yourself

The young musicians in the Locrian Chamber Players banded together in 1994 to examine a specific corner of the new-music repertory. Their specialty is not defined by stylistic attributes -- their Thursday evening concert at Riverside Church included Minimalism, neo-Romanticism and a peculiar combination of Impressionism and funk -- but by vintage. Their focus is on the newest of the new, meaning works composed in the last decade. Just over half the works they played on Thursday were either composed or revised in 1998.

title: Training Abusive Militaries
description: For decades, Congress has tried to insure that American military aid and training do not go to foreign soldiers who use the assistance to kill and torture their own people. But a 1991 law allowed training by special forces units free of many Congressional restrictions. As a result, such trainers have been in more than 100 countries and have worked with some of the world's most abusive and brutal militaries. In some cases, their training works at cross purposes with American foreign policy. An amendment to the defense appropriations bill that will face House and Senate conferees as Congress returns would close this training loophole. Beyond that, the Pentagon should recognize the harm done by its close relations with militaries that repress their own people.

He was Adjutant of Theodore Roosevelt American Legion Post in New York and was honorary member of the New York Police Honor Legion. Survived by wife Barbara Harrington Murray; four daughters Delanne Virginia Marcussen and Katherine Lyn Schaer both of Tustin, CA, Carolyn Arcure of Ann Harbor, MI, Laura Christina Murray of Reno, NV; a son Verne Lee Murray III of Diablo, CA and seven grandchildren. Graveside services Wednesday, September 2, 10 AM at Ferncliff Cemetery, 280 Secor Rd, Hartsdale, NY. For more information contact Island Funeral Home, Hilton Head Island, SC, (843) 681-4400.

title: U.S. May Seek to Expand Evidence in Microsoft Case
description: The Government and 20 states suing the Microsoft Corporation are planning to ask a Federal judge to admit new evidence in their major antitrust case against the software maker, according to a person close to the investigation.

title: When Minds Do Not Meet
description: Judging by how the grand and improbable alliance between Russia's pro-capitalist leadership and its Communist critics exploded this evening -- on television, spectacularly, in a crossfire of accusations and threats -- one might think these people hadn't a clue about what to do with their country.
